title: In Interests of Science': A BeerCan Grand Prix
description: It was proved beyond scientific doubt yseterday afternoon at the Polytechnic Institute of New York that a Miller beer can equipped with a soldered flywheel and a lead clutch beats a Carling beer can with a rubber band and a lead pendulum.

title: Imports of Fuel Up As Demand Climbs; U. S. Output Down
U.S. Studying Beef Imports
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) The Treasury Department announced today that it had begun an investigation to see if compensatory duties should be levied on imports of frozen boneless beef from several European Economic Communities. Such imports amounted to $3.6 million last year, according to the Treasury.

title: Greece Said to Fear U.S.Turkish Accord Would Tip Balance
description: ATHENS, March 31 Western diplomats said today that Greece was afraid that Washington's plan to provide more than a billion dollars in aid to Turkey over four years would tip the balance of power in the Aegean toward Ankara.

title: CAREY SIGNS LAW FOR NEW LOTTERY
description: ALBANY, March 31 Governor Carey's office said today that it hoped that a newly reconstituted state lottery would begin in eight weeks, with tight controls designed to attract the patrons driven away when it was shut down last year amid revelations of lax management.

title: The Rioting in Israel
description: JERUSALEM; March 31 Both the Arab and Jewish communities in Israel seemed stunned today by the scope and violence of yesterday's demonstrations by Israeli Arabs that left six persons dead, scores injured and a host of unanswered questions about what went wrong. Galilee and other predominantly Arab areas were quiet today but tenSe, Only scattered and relatively mild . incidents were reported in a few villages in the. north.

title: SADAT WARNS SOVIET ON LEBANESE CRISIS
description: BONN, March 31 (AP) President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today cautioned the Soviet Union to stay out of the civil war in Lebanon. But he said he had no objections to peace initiatives by the United States and other countries.

title: Socialist's Art Posters Torn Down at Bonn Show
description: BONN, March 31 Conservative West German politicians tore up posters by a Socialist artist last night, forcing a show of his work to close here today.

title: Opera: Ines de Castro in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, March 31 Thomas Pasatieri, about 30 years old, already has composed 12 operas, the last of which had its premiere last night at the Lyric Theater. It was named Ines de Castro and was presented under the auspices of the Baltimore Opera Company. This is the group of which Rosa Ponselle, that supreme 20thcentury dramatic sonano, is artistic director.

title: Hussein Is Backing Syrians on Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON. March 31 King Hussein of Jordan reportedly told members of Congress today that probably only Syrian military intervention could restore order in Lebanon, but that the threat of Israeli retaliadon had blocked such a move.

title: Science Ponders Strads'
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., March 31  The Juilliard String Quartet played today in a hall that the second violinist at least thought was as bad as any they had ever played in, and to an audience that did not applaud. The quartet seemed to be having a fine time.

title: Senate Votes Bill to Revise the Hatch Act
C.A.B. Finds No Violation
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that requests for special charter flight treatment by Mr. Callaway were regrettable but not illegal.

title: Ballet: Timeless Moves
description: Ballets are virtually controlled by music. Music is the platform of the choreographythe sounding board, the base, the key. There have been a few successful ballets created without the benefit of musicsay David Lichine's La Creation or Walter Gore's Eaters of Darkness. But they have been few and far between, and by far the most successful of them all has been Jerome Robbins's Moves, created for the Spoleto Festival in 1959,

title: TESTS SEEK CURBS ON BREAST CANCER
description: ST. PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla., March 31 A Nebraska cancer specialist is planning to test daily doses of an estrogen hormone as a means of preventing breast cancer in women.

title: Reagan Says Kissinger Yields U.S. Leadership to Russians
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP) Ronald Reagan said tonight that he did not want to live in a world where the Soviet Union is No. 1, and quoted Henry A. Kissinger as saying that his job as Secretary of State was to negotiate for an acceptable secondplace position.

title: HIGH COURT RETURNS FOSTER CHILD CASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) The Supreme Court, in an unsigned ruling today, sent back to Federal court in Chicago a challenge to Illinois's fosI ter child support law. Under that law, foster children living with blood relatives do not qualify for the same welfare benefits as do children living with nonrelatives.

title: IMELDA MARCOS HAS NEW BACKING
description: MANILA, March 31 A wellorchestrated movement to arouse public support for naming Imelda R. Marcos as successor to her husband, President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in case of his disability, is being mounted in the Philippines.

title: Transit Authority Gets Temporary Base
description: The first thing New York City Transit Authority workmen did after setting up negotiation headquarters at the Americana Hotel here was to install their own telephone lines.

title: Amex and OTC Show Modest Rise; Trading Increases
description: Trading picked up slightly and prices showed a modest limprovement yesterday on the :American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: RICHARD H. MANDEL
description: Richard H. Mandel of 10 East 70th Street, who retired in 1968 from the AllState Welding Alloys Company, White Plains, which he founded in 1946, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Issues 76: Education
description: When Thomas Jefferson warned that no nation should expect to be ignorant and remain free, he raised education to top rank among national priorities. Economically and politically, this selfgoverning nation depends for its strength and resiliency on an educated electorate. Yet, in recent years, support for education has been severely shaken:

title: Miss Goolagong Sets Record
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UPI) Chris Evert and Evonne Goolagong advanced to the quarterfinals of a $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today with straightset triumphs.

title: Pennsy Reports Loss Narrowed in February
description: Trustees of the Penn Central Railroad, whose transportation properties were taken over today by Conrail, reported yesterday that the bankrupt Pennsy system operated at a net loss of $13.2 million in February and incurred a deficit of $43.1 million for the first two months of the year.

title: Stamp Auction Sets Record
description: An auction of 350 lots of Icollectors stamps and envellopes realized $1,127,625 at the Pierre Hotel last night. A spokesman for the Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries, the sponsor, said the amount was a new record for a single auction session.

title: F.B.I. as Burglars . .
description: In a more rational world the story of clandestine F.B.I. breakins, on a schedule of roughly once every three weeks for six years, into the offices of the Socialist Workers Partyan organization singularly lacking in political influencewould be dismissed as clumsy radical propaganda. Unfortunately, it is disbelief that must be suspended; the breakins are now a matter of record by the F.B.I.'s own admission, supported by the flawless bureaucratic jargon of the bureau's own files.

title: REAGAN, WALLACE LOSING BIDS IN OHIO
description: COLUMMJS, Ohio, March 31 (UP1) Neither Ronald Reagan nor Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will qualify a statewide slate of atlarge Presidential delegates for Ohio's June primary, Secretary of State Ted W. Brown said today.

title: GUITAR FASCINATION IN JOE PASS'S SOLOS
description: Joe Pass is one of the most fascinating of today's guitarists in what is turning out to be a golden age for the jazz guitar, The period is notable for its range and diversity of styles, as opposed to the great guitar greening in the . postWorld War II decade, when a multitude of guitarists appeared, all sounding like offsorine of Charlie Christian.

title: Insurer Cites Plans to Arrest Losses
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The management of the Government Employees Insurance Company told an overflow crowd of angry shareholders today that its incompetent judgment was partly to blame for the big fire and casualty insurer's problems. They also were told that the early retirement of the company's chairman. Norman L. Gidden, and perhaps other executive changes were planned within the next 12 months.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING Yonkers Raceway, Central and

title: JASCALEVICH AGREES TO SUSPEND SURGERY
description: Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the surgeon who is under investigation in connection with the possible murder of nine or more patients with curare at an Oradell, N.J., hospital a decade ago, agreed yesterday to refrain temporarily from operating at Christ Hospital in Jersey City.

title: Sitara Dazzles in Rich Kathak Dances
description: Kathak, northern India's classical dance school, is less familiar here than the Bharata Natyam style from the south. Thanks to the Asia Society, our education is being rounded out.

title: Miss Hearst Files Court Paper To Support Plea for Severance
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31Patricia Hearst,will testify that she was a prisoner of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army and a captive of William and Emily Harris, according to her lawyers, when she sprayed bullets at a sporting goods store to help to Irescue the Harrises, who were about to be seized as shoplifting suspects.

title: Personal Finance: Money Rates
description: Tourists to other countries always have to decide when to convert American dollars into foreign currencies. Should it be done here or there?

title: Kapp Seeking $12 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 Joe Kapp is asking for $12 million in damages, it was revealed in court today as attorneys continued their closing arguments in his antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: Rangers Beat Islanders, 31, With Taste of Playoff Form
description: One good game doesn't a season make, but the Rangers exciting and wellplayed 31 triumph over the Islanders last night at Madison Square Garden should help soothe a lot of hurt feelings.

title: Efforts for Humphrey Big Factor in New York
description: The potential candidacy of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota nas grown into a major factor in the New York Presidential primary, with more than 40 uncommitted delegate candidates running as avowed supporters plus subterranean backing on slates pledged to declared candidates that his friends here measure as much larger in numbers.

title: EDWARD D. SUGRUE
description: Edward D. Sugrue, former general manager of the now defunct Newark Evening News, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital in Newark. He was 71 years old and lived in Newark.

title: Indian Diplomat Gets Post
description: NEW DELHI, March 31 (UPI)  The Indian Government today announced the appointment of Jagat S. Mehta, a diplomat with 29 years of service as secretary to the Foreign Ministry.

title: ELIZABETH FREN YEAR
description: Elizabeth Arrighi Frenyear, executive secretary of the Pen and Brush Club here, died Friday at her home, 10 Fifth Avenue. She was 64 years old.

title: Artists'Rights to Lofts in NoHo Are Backed by Planning Body
description: The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to legalize artists livingandworking lofts in the area of lower Manhattan known as NoHo. Such arrangements have been permitted since 1970 in the larger SoHo district..

title: Rizzo Recall Drive
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UPI) A drive to unseat Mayor Rizzo through recall was officially announced today by a group that called the Mayor a tyrant.

title: Party Official in China Joins AntiTeng Campaign
description: PEKING, March 31 (Reuters)  A powerful new voice emerged today in a growing campaign against Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping, branded as a capitalistroader.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 1, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Giants Enroll McVay
description: John McVay was named yesterday assistant coach in charge of research and development by the New York Giants. The 45yearold McVay was head coach of the Memphis Southmen of the defunct World Football League in 1974.

title: Aaron Traister, 72, Taught At Bronx Schools, N.Y.U.
description: Aaron Traister, a teacher in Bronx schools for 45 years and an adjunct professor of English at New York University at his retirement in 1972, died Tuesday evening in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 72 years old and lived at 3967 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Marcus Welby Canceled With 8 Other ABC Shows
description: Marcus Welby, M.D., the medical series in which for the last seven years Robert Young has portrayed a benevolent general practitioner, has been canceled by ABCTV. Once the country's most popular television show, the series has declined in the ratings over the last two years. It was dropped from tne scneauie tnree weeks ago and replaced with Family, a contemporary soap opera.

title: PAUL J. SINGSTAD
description: Paul J. Singstad, managing director of Nors Associates, management consultants at 166 East 61st Street, died Saturday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 50 years old and lived at the East 61st Street address.

title: Youths Open Fire In Restaurant, Kill One and Wound Six
Carter Attacks Humphrey, Recalling His Defeat in 68
description: APPLETON, Wis., March 31 Jimmy Carter fired a rhetorical volley of warning shots across the bow of the Stop Carter movement that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota is reported to be encouraging in the Wisconsin primary.

title: Chandeliers and Murals Turn Tennis Court Into a Ballroom
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 Outside, the stars twinkled in a still and velvet sky. Inside, the twinkling came from 12 crystal chandeliers and 8 crystal sconces, casting a diffused glow on the green and white shirred fabric walls, the black and white murals depicting opera houses around the world, and the grass green carpet underfoot.

title: Udall Handling Hot Issues With Humor
DOW IS UP BY 732 AFTER 2DAY DROP
description: Stock prices snapped back yesterday after two days of decline as trading this week continued to lag at the slowest pace of 1976.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS CONDEMNED IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Match 31  The Security Council late tonight adopted a resolution condemning what it termed South Africa's aggression against Angola and calling on the South African Government to pay compensation for damages.

title: Rothko Fine Is Raised $540,000 by Surrogate
description: The multimillion dollar judgment and fine levied against Frank Lloyd and his Marlborough art galleries for their handling of hundreds of Mark Rothko paintings has been increased by $540,000.

title: Conoco Succeeds in Producing A Synthetic Gas From Lignite
description: The Conoco Coal Development Company said yesterday it had achieved success during February in producing a sustained output of synthetic pipeline gas from lignite coal at its Rapid City, S.D. pilot plant which uses the socalled carbondioxide acceptor process.

title: Realty Trust Sees Progress on Pact
description: IDS Realty Trust, a major real estate investment trust facing serious financial problems, announced yesterday that three banks that had earlier demanded immediate payment of a $30 million debt had withdrawn their demands.

title: SENATE TO STUDY URBANAID ABUSE
description: ATLANTA, March 31 Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, said today that he would hold hearings to look into allegations of flagrant misuse of millions of dollars in Federal funds intended to fight urban blight and improve living conditions for the poor.

title: Planned Move of a Squibb Unit Is Linked to F.D.A. Rule Change
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 31 The proposed new penicillin manufacturing standards published by the Food and Drug Administration last month in the Federal Register are considered a factor in a pullout from the state of at least some of the facilities of E. R. Squibb & Sons, one of the nation's largest drug companies and the biggest manufacturer of intravenous penicillin.

title: ROHM &
description: The Rohm & Haas Company, a large plastics manufacturer, said yesterday that it had made improper payments overseas, totaling $750,200 from 1971 through 1975. The company said the payments, which were made in nine countries, had been stopped.

title: Carter's Headquarters In the City Broken Into
description: A burglar who broke into Jimmy Carter's headquarters on Fifth Avenue Monday night stole $20 worth of stamps and some political documents that the former Georgia Governor's aides said were of little importance.

title: High Court Is Urged By Bork to Restore Capital Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  Solicitor General Robert H. Bork, arguing on behalf of the Government, urged the Supreme Court today to overrule its 1972 decision that struck down capital punishment as then practiced in America and to hold that the death penalty is constitutional.

title: San Francisco TieUp
description: Transport was hardhit by a strike of San Francisco's municipal craft workers. The walkout was in defiance of an injunction. P'age 61.

title: Philadelphia Special Prosecutor Ousted by Pennsylvania Official
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31  Walter M. Phillips Jr., the state special presecutor for Philadelphia, was dismissed today by Robert P. Kane, the Pennsylvania Attorney General.

title: 3 British Soldiers Killed By a Landmine in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 31 (AP) Three British soldiers were killed tonight by a landmine that blew up under their vehicle, the army said.

title: TRIAL OF SOLIAH BEGINS ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 31  Steven Soliah is being brought to trial for the armed robbery last year of a bank near here, his lawyer said today, only because he had given aid to Patricia Hearst and even fell in love with her.

title: U.D.C. PANEL URGES NEW CREDIT POLICY
description: ALBANY, March 31A special state commission that has spent the last year studying the financial collapse of the Urban Development Corporation recommended major changes today in the way the state borrows money and manages its debt.

title: Drunken Driver on TrialBut It's a Play
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 31 George M. Biber of Atlantic City was convicted of drunken driving today after a wellattended trial at the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The controller of a nursing home in Atlantic City has been indicted on charges of trying to bribe a state inspector. State Attorney General William F. Hyland said, announicng the indictment, that Milton Schwartz, controller of Shore Manor Ltd. allegedly paid a $500 bribe tO Elizabeth Kinney, a field representative of the Division of Health Facilities Evaluation in the Department or Health. Robert Del Tufo, director of the Division or Criminal Justice, said Mr. Schwartz had been charged with one count of bribery and an additional count alleging that he had offered to pay Mrs. Kinney $1,000 more every time she notified him in advance of a health department inspection at his nursing facility.

title: Ottawa Pollution Curb On
description: OTTAWA, March 31 (AP) Canada's Environmental Contaminants Act took effect today. The Environment Department now has the flower to collect information on possible contaminants, control or lknit their production or importation. and punish people who violate its rulings.

title: Night Out in Rhodesia: A Swirl of Drinking and Contradictions
SEC. SCRUTINIZES CI1YM.A.C. SWAP
description: An investigation of possible fraud in the sale of New York City securities, now under way by the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been broadened to include $1.6 billion of the city's notes that were part of a swap offer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation last year, sources close to the Government investigation disclosed yesterday.

title: KAISER INCREASING ALUMINUM PRICES
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday followed the lead of a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd. in raising the international price of aluminum by 4 cents a pound. The new price of 43 cents a pound will go into effect today. The Canadian company had announced a similar move on Tuesday.

title: Merchant of Stamford Aids Stratford
description: Bloomingdale's department store in Stamford. Conn., will give 10 percent of Saturday's gross receipts to help save the financially troubled American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford.

title: People and Business
description: Thomas S. Kleppe, the Secretary of the Interior, told the National Petroleum Council yesterday that his department planned to push ahead with its offshore oil and gas leasing program but said it would be unrealistic to set a firm schedule.

title: Yale Shows U.S. Art With London in Mind
description: American Art: 17501800 at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven bears the subtitle Towards Independence. Just how we read independence in this context is up to us. It could refer to the nation. It could refer to the art. It could refer to the cultural context in which the art is now being considered. Whatever it means, it's a good title for a very good show, one that will do honor to this country when it moves in July to the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

title: Rains, Winds and Time Erode a Saved Pink Cottage
description: GARRISON, N. Y., March 31 It was the truly simple things of life that attracted Andrew Jackson Downing: Tuscan villas, Venetian palaces, Gothic castles and most importantly, people rich enough to afford them.

title: Nigeria Cutting Budget
description: LAGOS, Nigeria. March 31 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Nigerian head of state, I into. Gen. Oluaegun Obaaanjo, today announced a 20 percent out in the federal budget for the comlng financial year.

title: Assembly Votes to Quash Stavisky Bill VetoImpasse in Senate
description: ALBANY, March 31  With cheers of selfcongratulation, the State Assembly tonightl overrode Governor Carey's veto of the StaVisky bill to restore millions in funds cut from the city's public schools.

title: High Court Is Urged By Bork to Restore Capital Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Solicitor General Robert H. Bork, arguing on behalf of the Government, urged the Supreme Court today to overrule its 1972 decision that struck down capital punishment as then practiced in America and to hold that the death penalty is constitutional.

title: Humphrey Issues Denial
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) Senator Humphrey denied today he was attempting to stop Mr. Carter from getting the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: BONN LEGISLATOR TESTIFIES ON ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 West Germany probably will not buy an expensive Air Force radar plane unless the United States buys a new battle tank developed by West Germany, a Christian Democratic member of Parliament told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today.

title: Callaway's Ski Resort Board Met at the Pentagon
description: CRESTED BUTTE. Colo.. March 31 (AP) The Crested Butte Development Corporation controlled by Howard H. Callaway, former Army Secretary, held a board meeting in his Pentagon office five months after ne was sworn in as Secretary.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) The Supreme Court held today that a system improving bank account statements was not eligible for a patent. Justice Thurgood Marshall said there was no need to hand down a broad ruling on program patentability. In a 1972 decision, the Supreme Court ruled that programs that did not involve new computer machinery were processes and not patentable.

title: Suit Tests ExMental Patients Residency
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, March 31 A battle has begun in the courts to evict four former mental patients from a house they share here on the ground, according to Mayor John Stapleton, that it is being used as an institution, violating the law.

title: I Don't Know If My Power's Gone
description: SUN CITY, Ariz.In his big years, Henry Aaron appeared calm, almost detached, but the adrenaline was flowing inside him.

title: Senate Fails to Override Latest Carey School Veto
description: ALBANY, March 31 Incensed Republicans in the majority in the Senate sought unsuccessfully tonight to override Governor Carey's surprise veto last night of the educationassistance formula in the budget. Democrats in the minority united to defeat the attempt.

title: Rains, Winds and Time Erode a Saved Pink Cottage
description: GARRISON, N. Y., March 31 It was the truly simple things of life that attracted Andrew Jackson Downing: Tuscan villas, Venetian palaces, Gothic castles and most importantly, people rich enough to afford them.

title: U.S. and Soviet Are Closer To Pact on Atomic Blasting
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The United States and the Soviet Union expect to complete an agreement limiting both peaceful and military nuclear eXplosions to 150 kilotons within the next several weeks, the White House and State Department announced today.

title: Government by Guru
description: ARKADELPHIA, Ark.People here tighten their sunbelts, dodge tornadoes, witness ruefully the decline of George Wallace and look hopefully toward the likes of Jimmy Carter and California Gov. Jerry Brown.

title: Fun for Children: A Playground With No Swings, SeeSaws or Jungle Gyms
description: Whatever the adults were calling it, for the children squooshy and fun just about said it all. While teachers and therapists were bandying about such terms as soft sculpture and play environment, a lot of different kinds of children were just having squooshy fun.

title: Assembly Votes to Quash Stavisky Bill VetoImpasse in Senate
description: ALBANY, March 31  With cheers of selfcongratulation, the State Assembly tonight overrode Governor Carey's veto of the Stavisky bill to restore millions in funds cut from the city's public schools.

title: Rockefeller, in Sydney, Stresses U.S. Pacific Ties
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 31 Vice President Rockefeller, said here tonight that the United States would stand by Australia and all Pacific nations to which it was bound by treaty, by mutual selfInterest, by duty and by honor.

title: Yankees Claim Messersmith
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 The Yankees announced today they had reached a fouryear written agreement with Andy Messersmith through his agent, hut Messersmith lmmediately denied he had agreed to pitch for the Yankees and said he would not play for them.

title: NBC Technicians, Writers Strike, but Service Goes On
description: SAN DIEGO, April 1 (UN) Some 1,700 technicians and newswriters went on strike against the NBC television network at one minute after midnight this morning, turning down an appeal from Federal mediators for a onemonth exitension.

title: W. T. Grant Asserts 14 of Aides Plotted To Pocket Funds
description: An attorney for the W. T. Grant Company, which concluded the going outofbusiness sales of its remaining stores, Saturday, told a Federal judge yesterday that 10 store managers and four field and area supervisors of Grant were involved in a scheme to prolong some store closing sales and pocket the proceeds.

title: LEFTIST ALLIANCE IN LEBANON EASES TRUCE OPPOSITION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, April 1 Lebanese Moslems and their leftist allies appeared last night to be moving reluctantly toward acceptance of a temporary truce in Lebanon's civil war in response to Syrian and other pressure.

title: HOUSE PANEL SAYS SCHORR CASE LAGS
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Federal and Congressional investigations into the unauthorized disclosures to the press of the report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence are bogging down, and persons active in the investigation are expressing doubts that they will be completed, much less support legal actions against anyone.

title: Contract Award
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday receipt of a $111.9 million Air Force contract for the advanced Airborne Command Post System.

title: People in Sports
description: Steve Busby, ace of the Kansas City pitching staff, has been placed on the 21day disabled list and will miss the opening day of the season. Busby had an 1812 wonlost record before he was sidelined with shoulder problems last year. He has been running behind in his conditioning this spring, chiefly because of the shortened training period and has not pitched in an exhibition game.

title: Cambodia Increases Rations
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 31 (Agence FrancePresse) Cambodian workers have had their daily ration of rice increased to about 500 grams, or a little more than It pound, Phnom Penh radio reported. The radio, monitored here, said the meat ration was now one pig for 10 people every 10 days. According to refugees who have crossed from Cambodia into Thailand, the ration had been a milk tin of rice a day, with pork reserve& for Communist officials.

title: Change Urged in Income Tax Exemptions
description: TRENTON, March 31 The Senate majority leader, Joseph P. Merlino, Democrat of Mercer County, said today that taxpayers should be given a $20 credit for each dependent against any personal income taxes owed the state rather than be allowed to deduct $1,000 for each dependent from their gross income before computing taxes.

title: 7 on Free Press and Times Man Win Sigma Delta Chi Awards
CORRECTION
description: An article on rent control in The New York Times yesterday stated incorrectly that persons 65 years old or older whose net income did not exceed $6,500 a year and who spent at least onethird of their income for rent were exempted by law from rent. increases. The correct age is 62 years or older.

title: CARL DOERING, 86, A BIOSTATISTICIAN
description: Carl Rupp Doering, a discoverer in 1928 of the link between cancer and heavy smoking, died Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: Videla Reassures Argentines on Human Rights
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 31 Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla's inaugural message as President contained commitments to human rights that reassured Argentines today on the intentions of the new military regime.

title: Marijuana Charges Dropped
description: LOS ANGELES, March :Hi (UPI) Charges against 12 persons accused of smuggling 16.6 tons of marijuana in fishing boats, reportedly the largest seizure ever made on the West Coast, were dropped yesterday because Federal judge Manuel Real ruled that the marijuana was inadmissible as eviden???e. He said the authoritiees did not have probable cause to stop and search the four motorboats that were carrying the mark Juana.

title: REAGAN APPEALS FORWIDESUPPORT
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31 Ronald Reagan made a broad appeal for popular support tonight in a 30minute paid network television speech that appeared designed to attract fresh financial backing from Democrats and independents, as well as Republicans.

title: Delaware &
description: The little Delaware & Hudson Railway. for many years a profitable connecting railroad among the big carriers of the Northeast, is sharply expanding its service area today.

title: Udall Denies Humphrey Dear; Says He Is No Stalking Horse
description: Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona said yesterday he was no stalking horse for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and did not need his help in the Wisconsin and New York Presidential primary elections April 6.

title: Jockey Files Suit On 72 Race Mishap
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 31 (UPI) Eddie Salazar, a jockey who was thrown from his horse in 1972 at the Nebraska State Fairground race track, has filed a lawsuit in District Court seeking $2 million in damages.

title: OWNERS OF HOME ACCUSED BY STEIN
description: MOHEGAN LAKE, N. Y., March 31 The owners of an adult home in Westchester County have been charged by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan with victimizing the couple who operate the home in an effort to increase real estate profits.

title: LEFTIST ALLIANCE IN LEBANON EASES TRUCE OPPOSITION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, April 1 Lebanese Moslems and their leftist allies appeared last night to be moving reluctantly toward acceptance of a temporary truce in Lebanon's civil war in response to Syrian and other pressure,

title: Note Mystery Solved: Newsweek Is Doing It
description: Folks in a position to make advertising decisions are forever receiving strange mail and packages from media that aim to affect their decisions.

title: Seaway Opens Saturday
description: BROCKVILLE, Ontario, March 30 (Reuters) The St. Lawrence Seaway will be opened to daylight navigation on Saturday morning, Allen Luce, director of operations for the Seaway Authority, said today. It had been hoped that the seaway would be opened on Thursday, but adverse weather caused a delay, he said.

title: Donovan Gives Views on Why Knicks Folded
Senate Fails to Override Latest Carey School Veto
description: ALBANY, March 31 Incensed Republicans in the majority in the Senate sought unsuccessfully tonight to override Governor Carey's surprise veto last night of the educationassistance formula in the budget. Democrats in the minority united to defeat the attempt.

title: Jackson's Opponents Criticize His Stand on Lebanon
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson returned to New York City yesterday, campaigning hard for the ethnic vote, while, some of his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination took sharp issue with remarks he made Tuesday in Wisconsin about how, he felt the situation in Lebanon should have been handled.

title: Spanish Opposition Is Seeking Foreign Pressure on Madrid
description: LISBON, March 31 Spanish opposition representatives began efforts in Portugal and other European countries today to win international support for their newly revised strategy to force political change in Spain.

title: 2,000 Homeless in Nepal Fire
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, March 31 (Reuters) A fire that has swept the town of Biratnagar for the last two days has made at least 2,000 people homeless and destroyed an estimated $6 million in property.

title: SENATORS REJECT NOFAULT MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) The Senate today dealt a major blow to legislationi that would require states to enact nofault automobile Insurance laws, sending the mea sure back to the Senate commerce Committee by a 49to45 vote.

title: Market Place
description: The small investor who has sought an opportunity to buy growth stocks at reasonable prices may be about to get his chance, according to Claude N. Rosenberg, a West Coast investment adviser and author of books on investing.

title: Conrail Takes Over Northeast's System
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, a quasigovernmental enterprise, took over the Northeast's railway networkseven bankrupt railroads headed by the Penn Centralat 12:01 A.M. today.

title: As in Chile, Economic Troubles Led to the Coup in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 28 The day after the military coup, the army major who was placed in charge of government public relations in Crdoba, Argentina's second largest city, gathered the local newspaper editors and imparted instructions for temporary press censorship.

title: DEADLINE AT HAND IN TRANSIT TALKS; INJUNCTION ISSUED
description: As negotiators raced to head off a transit strike threatened for today, the Transit Authority obtained an injunction in State Supreme Court barring an illegal walkout by 32,000 workers.

title: Lawsuit Against Kodak On Boycott Dismissed
description: A stockholder lawsuit against the Eastman. Kodak Company over a resohition dealing with the Arab boycott of Israel has been dismissed by agreement among the parties, Kodak announced yesterday.

title: Court Rules Karen Quinlan's Father Can Let Her Die By Disconnecting Respirator if Doctors See No Hope
description: TRENTON, March 31  The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the mechanical respirator that was keeping Karen Anne Quinlan alive might be disconnected if her attending physicians and a panel of hospital officials agreed that there was no reasonable possibility that she would recover.

title: The Flimflam in the Pumpkin Papers
Older Cities Plight Muted As an Issue by Candidates
description: The problems of older American cities, which played a role in the political campaigns following the urban riots of the mid1960's, have been muted in this year's Presidential campaign.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: NEW YORK Gregg Johnson, 213 pounds, New York, nutpointed Sergio Rodriguez, 201, Haiti, 8 rounds.

title: San Francisco TieUp
description: Transport was hardhit by a strike of San Francisco's municipal craft workers. The walkout was in defiance of an injunction. Page 61.

title: JOBLESSNESS DIPS IN CITY MID STATE
description: Unemployment in the city and the state fell slightly in February, with most of the improvemeht attributable to seasonal factors, the State Labor Department said yesterday.

title: QuinIons Will Act At Once on Steps To Let Karen Die
description: MOUNT ARLINGTON, N. J., March 31 Within hours after winning a State Supreme Court victory in their sixmonth struggle to establish their! daughttr's right to die with grace and dignity, the parents of Karen Anne Quinlan said here this afternoon that they, would waste no time in taking the steps that could lead to the removal of their comatose daughter's respirator.

title: Two Grant Stores Leased
description: BOSTON, March 31 (UPI)The Hubbard Real Investments Company said today that it had leased two former W. T Grant stores to S. S. Kresge & Company. The two stores are at Citrus Heights, Calif., and Drayton Plains, Mich. Hubbard now has gained possession of 10 of the 11 properties it had under lease to Grant, which has been ordered liquidated by a Federal bankruptcy judge.

title: Notes on People
description: Charles W. Robinson, a former businessman, was nominated by President Ford yesterday to be Deputy Secretary of State, the No. 2 position in the department. He would succeed Robert S. Ingersoll, former chairman of th6 BorgWarner Corporation, and Ambassador to Japan, who has resigned.

title: Buccaneers Go Far Off Draft Route
description: The Seattle Seahawks played it Rtraight in the National Football League's expansion draft, which ended late Tuesday, while the Tampa Bay Buccaneers went far eff course in search of elusive prizes.

title: Flu Plan Backed
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Congressional leaders in health affairs expressed support today for the Ford Administration's plan to vaccinate all Americans against the new flu virus, but some suggested that the effort also include immunization against polio, measles and other disease for those in need.

title: ROBERT H. KAPLAN 3D
description: BOSTON, March 31 Robert H. Kaplan 3d, professor In the College of Business Administration of Northeastern University, died Monday at his home In Lincoln, Mass. He was 47 years old and lived also In Edgartown, Mass.

title: ORION IS SUCCESSOR TO EQUITY FUNDING
description: Under a reorganization proceeding in Los Angeles Federal District Court yesterday, the Equity Funding Corporation changed its name to the Orion Capital Corporation, with consolidated assets of $400 million.

title: JOSEPHINE B. ORR
description: Josephine B. Orr, widow of Alexander M. Orr, a prominent amateur yachtsman, died Monday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Vineyard Haven, Mass. She was 89 years old and lived in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Advertising
description: Thanks to a national survey by W. R. Simmons Research sponsored by 15 national magazines, advertisers now know officially what they should have known through common sensethe person who buys a magazine is a far more important audience than the one who picks it up in the dentist's office.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON JOB FUND GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Democratic members of the House Budget Committee agreed today that they would try to add $2 billion to $3 billion for special jobcreating programs to next year's budget targets, over and beyond the spending on other Federal programs that the committee has already approved.

title: MartinHernandez Ride High As Winning Duo at Aqueduct
Reading Jimmy Carter
description: BOSTON, March 31 At least this much is clear by now: Jimmy Carter Is the most interesting new political phenomenon this country has seen in a long time. His appeal crosses some of the old lines of party and ideology. He has coolly withstood the worst that critics could throw at him, and polls show his national support deepening.

title: FRANCIS A. KETTANEH
description: Francis A. Kettaneh, founder and a partner in F. A. Kettaneh of Beirut, Lebanon, a distributor of American and European products, died Tuesday in his home at 888 Park Avenue. He was 79 years old and lived also in Cuddebackville, N. Y.

title: A Black Professor Urges Softening of Racial Issues
Alternative Offered to Kibbee's City U. Proposal
description: Contending that the Kibbee proposal for restructuring the City University would have its greatest impact on members of minority groups and the poor, the three minority representatives on the Board of Higher Education offered an alternative yesterday that they said would allow all five colleges threatened with closing or reduction of services to maintain their present status.

title: Geico Lays Some of Its Ills to Own Incompetence'; Banks Withdraw Demand That IDS Pay $30 Million
News Summary and Index
description: International

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON ELECTION UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The House decisively defeated today a proposal to continue the Federal Election Commission's power to issue advisory opinions on campaign issues without Congressional interference.

title: Bridge:
description: The team with the least international experience in the 1976 Bermuda Bowl next month will be Hong Kong, which won the right to compete by capturing the Far East title in Bangkok last November.

title: FORD VOWS UNITY FOR REPUBLICANS
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 President Ford pledged tonight that he would never do or say anything to weaken the Republican Party and said that all candidates for President should make the same promise.

title: SOUTHAFRICA RAISES ARMS SPENDING 40%
description: CAPE TOWN, March 31 (Reuters)  South Africa today raised military spending by 40 percent to meet increased threats on its borders.

title: FARMERS'
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Prices farmers get for raw agricultural products declined 1.5 percent in March but still averaged 12 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Last British Soldiers Leave Singapore Base
description: SINGAPORE, March 31 (UPI) Britain officially completed its military withdrawal from Singapore at sundown today, ending 157 years of service on the strategic island.

title: STRIKE AVERTED ON CITY'S TRANSIT AT LAST MINUTE
description: Negotiators for the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union reached a tentative settlement early this morning, only an hour and a half before the extended strike deadline set earlier in the night.

title: Collins &
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation, a large textile manulfacturer, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Mastercraft Corporation, a privately owned manufacturer of upholstery fabrics.

title: TEAMSTER STRIKE BEGINS IN NATION AS TALKS FALTER
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Thursday, April 1 Teamsters struck trucking companies last midnight, leaving their jobs first in the East as negotiators here failed to reach agreement on a new contract.

title: G.A.O. Aide Fears Rise in Letter Rate To 34 Cents by 84
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Without new postal sub. sidles, the cost of mailing a letter could increase to 34 cents by 1984, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: 7,200 Families Are Taken Off Day Care In Toughening of the Rule on Income
RENTS SUBSIDIZED FOR 20 FAMILIES
description: Thanks to a new Federal rentsubsidy program, Christopher and Desiree Gosein can now shop around for an apartment for themselves and their two small children, rather than continue to live with Mrs. Gosein's parents in four crowded rooms.

title: The Thai Ouster
description: The Thai Government's decision to terminate the remaining American military presence, except for 270 military aid advisers, was the logical consequence of the American withdrawal from and Communist conquest of Indochina. It was a judgment for Thais alone to make in their own security interest. The proper American response was that voiced by Ambassador Charles Whitehouse: We do not stay where we are not wanted; we will be leaving within four months [as requested].

title: CAREY OFFERS AID ON A BANKING BILL
description: ALBANY, March 31Governor Carey agreed today to participate in talks aimed at breaking the apparent impasse over a bill to grant checkingaccount privileges to savings banks. But he maintained his opposition to a solution that would require savings banks to agree to set up a fund to finance mortgages in areas nowa being redlined.

title: REAGAN APPEALS FOR WIDE SUPPORT
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31 Ronald Reagan made a broad appeal for popular support tonight in a 30minute paid network television speech that appeared designed to attract fresh financial backing from Democrats and independents, as well as Republicans.

title: Bonn and Moscow Give Up Plan For Nuclear Plant Inside Soviet
description: BONN, March 31 West Germany has abandoned a plan to build a $600 million nuclear power plant in the Soviet Union in a major political setback to West GermanSoviet relations.

title: San Francisco Transit Crippled by Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 31  Defying an injunction, municipal craft workers here went on strike today in an attempt to reverse salary reductions that had been ordered Monday by the city's Board of Supervisors.

title: 138,000 Volkswagen Autos Recalled for Emission Flaw
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., March 31 (AP) Volkswagen of America said today that it was recalling 138,000 Rabbit and Sirocco models because of possible malfunction in their emissioncontrol systems. Included in the voluntary recall are 18,000 1976 models and 120,000 1975 models..

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A mistrial has been declared in Waterbury, Conn., in the case against Murray R. Gold, a New York stockbroker who was accused of killing his former wife's parents in 1974. The jury reported it was deadlocked. His attorney, William M. Kunstler, asked that his client's bail be reduced from $250,000 to $10,000. Mr. Gold was accused of killing his former wife's father, Irving Pasternak, aged 71, and her mother, Rhoda, 66, on Yom Kippur night in 1974.

title: New Approach to Transit Talks
description: The biennial transit negotiations that came to a climax Ilast night had a much broader involvement than those of years past, when the Mayor played a dominant role in dealing with the Transport Workers Union. It used to be that the Mayor, at a critical moment, would find some additional funds with which to achieve a settlement. But for the last six years, a state agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and its subsidiarythe New York City Transit Authority, which operates the buses and subways  have been the direct participants in the bargaining talks.

title: Books of The Times
description: For millenniums, Iceland lay undisturbed, a povertystricken volcanic island adjacent to the Arctic Circle, admired mostly by the puffins and skuas who bred there. Some got to know Iceland during World War II; it was a way station on the way to Europe, and an Allied base was set up. All of a sudden the Icelanders, those descendants of Vikings, started to make their own destiny. Within 25 years Iceland was a tidily run socialistic country on the Danish model. It was a country where class distinctions were unknown, where the crime rate averaged a murder a year, where the literacy rate was 100 percent, where the people strode proud and tall. And where, in July, the sun never set; and In December it never rose.

title: U.S. Will Take 2 to Court Over Incident With Russians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, March 31 The United .States announced today that it was prosecuting two persons in Federal Court on charges of harassment of foreign officials and that it needed the cooperation of Soviet witnesses.

title: 10 NAMED BY FORD TO REVIEW BRIBES
description: WASHINGTON, March 31President Ford, declaring that corrupt business practices strike at the very heart of our own moral code and our faith in free enterprise, established today a Cabinetlevel task force to review the issue of overseas bribes by American corporations.

title: The SchorrCBS Story Is Still Untold
description: Much of the confusion that surrounds the future status of Daniel Schorr at CBS News can be laid to a legal agreement between Mr. Schorr and executives of the network forbidding them to discuss the situation beyond what was said at his suspension from CBS on Feb. 23. The agreement to observe silence, CBS officials have noted, was made to prevent the raising of extraneous issues until completion of th,e Congressional investigation into Mr. Schorr's acquisition of the secret House intelligence report that he later passed on to The Village Voice for publication. CBS News has said it would help defend Mr. Schorr, in paying his legal fees, and that it would vigorously support him on the question of a reporter's right to protect his sources.

title: Credit Market Prices Lower
description: As the credit markets drifted yesterday toward lower prices find higher interest rates, Federal funds traded as high as 6 percent and the Federal Reserve twice injected temporary reserves into the banking system to help push the key rate back down closer to the 4 percent level at which It has stayed most of the time since midJanuary.

title: Arabs Reported Trying to Keep Lebanon Question Out of U.N.
U.S. Investment Abroad Lagging
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The oncerapid growth of investment abroad by United States companies is tapering off, new Commerce Department figures disclosed today.

title: House Panel Rejects Assassination Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)  The House Rules Committee rejected today, 9 to 6, a request that Congress investigate the assassination of President Kennedy because of alleged new evidence not considered by the Warren Commission.

title: Nursing Home Is Given a New Chance
description: The Village Nursing Home won a new lease on life yesterday. Threatened with closing since last September, it was taken over by the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged under an 18month receivership that will be watched as a pilot operation.

title: Hussein Is Backing Syrians on Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, March 31King Hussein of Jordan reportedly told members of Congress today that probably only Syrian military invervention could restore order in Lebanon, but that the threat of Israeli retaliation had so far blocked such a MOM

title: U.D.C. PANEL URGES NEW CREDIT POLICY
description: ALBANY, March 31 A special state commission that has spent the last year studying the financial collapse of the Urban Development Corporation recommended major changes today in the way the state borrows money and manages its debt.

title: Springtime Means It's Circus Time in the City
HECKLING FLARES AT MADISON, WIS.
description: MADISON, Wis., March 31 Madison, which attracted national attention for its militant demonstrations in the student protests of the 1960's, has become the focal point of the first organized heckling of the 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: ERNEST C. GEIER
description: Ernest C. Geier, retired president and chairman of the Duplan Corporation, a textile manufacturer, died Tuesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 87 years old.

title: Wheat Futures Off In Listless Trading; Potato Prices Fall
description: In one of the slowest trading days floor members could remember, wheat prices on the Chicago Board of Trade drifted lower yesterday. The May delivery closed at $3.62, down from $3.68 a bushel, and the new crop month of July lost 9 cents to close at $3.50.

title: Virginians Found Success Through a Lost Retriever
description: A lost Labrador retriever helped Allen and Martha Lee Voshell of Virginia find their way into the dog show world. We saw a yellow Lab running alone the road near CharlottesNews ville, said Mrs. Voshell, called to her and she came to us. We took her home, phoned the sheriff and reported a lost dog. A week later, a student from the university claimed her.

title: Guerrilla Activity in Burma Tied to End of Vietnam War
description: RANGOON, Burma, March 31 (Agence FrancePresse) The Communist guerrilla movement in Burma's Shan State has taken on a new dimension since the end of the Vietnam War, the semiofficial Working People's Daily reported.

title: EDWARD JOHN GOING 2D
description: Edward John Going 2d, who retired as a vice president of SSC&B Inc., advertising agency, in 1973, died of cancer Monday evening in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an item in the Notes on People column in The New York Times yesterday, former Gov. Chester Bowles of Connecticut was erroneously described as the late Chester Bowles.

title: The Pop Life
description: Nils Lofgren, who closed a brief run at the Bottom Line last night, is yet another rocker who has won extravagant critical and cult approval without ever establishing himself in broad commercial terms.

title: Riders Are Stocking Up On 50c Subway Tokens
description: The possibility that the transit negotiations might lead to an increase in the fare has led many subway passengers to try to stock up on the 50cent tokens.

title: The Opera
description: It seems odd, but two of the most credibly human characters in the operas of Richard Strauss were created in the most artificial of theatrical traditions, the travesty, or pants, part. The more familiar, of course, is Octavian in Der Rosenkavalier, but the Composer in Ariadne auf Naxos runs a good second, and in some ways presents the woman singing this ostensibly male role with problems of greater subtlety.

title: Transit Crisis at a Glance
description: The public agencies involved in the contract negotiations are the New York City Transit Authority and its subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority. They operate the city's subways and publicly owned bus lines. Both are under the direction of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency.

title: Argentina's Planner
description: BUENOS AIRES. March 31  Jos Martinez de Hoz, Argentina's new Minister of the Economy, was on safari in Kenya earlier this month when a summons came by radio to the hunting camp. Return as soon as possible to Buenos Aires, the message said. A few days later, Mr. Martinez de Hoz stepped off a jet airliner in the Argentine capital and went into a threehour meeting with the commanders of the armed forces.

title: . . . Mr. Levi Calls a Halt
description: The order of Attorney General Edward H. Levi to destroy all records that resulted from a year's illegal electronic and physical surveillance of a newspaper columnist by the Federal Bureau of Investigation speaks well for Mr. Levi's determination to place the F.B.I. under the rule of law.

title: 200 Officers, Rehired With U.S. Aid, Come Back Unsure About the Future
description: Two hundred police officers, who were laid off during New York's fiscal crisis last June were rehired by the city yesterday, but returning to work, they expressed uncertainty about their future. If there are more layoffs, they would be the first to go.

title: South Carolina Democrats Give Carter 9 of Their 31 Delegates
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., March 31  The South Carolina Democratice convention voted late tonight to keep 13 of the state's 31 delegates to the national convention uncommitted as to a Presidential candidate.

title: Bonn and Moscow Give Up Plan For Nuclear Plant Inside Soviet
description: BONN, March 31 West Germany has abandoned a plan to build a $600 million nuclear power plant in the Soviet Union in a major political setback to West GermanSoviet relations.

title: Science Ponders Strads Secret
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., March 31  The Juilliard String Quartet played today in a hall that the second violinist at least thought was as bad as any they had ever played in, and to an audience that did not applaud. The quartet seemed to be having a fine time.

title: LIST OF CANDIDATES PUBLISHED IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31 (Reuters)  South Vietnam today published a list of 44 candidates who will contest 35 seats in Saigon when Vietnam holds its first nationwide general elections in a generation April 25.

title: Carter, as Governor, Got Free Rides On Planes of Lockheed and CocaCola
Federal Attorney Resigns
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (AP)Robert Curran, United States Attorney for the Philadelphia area, resigned today to return to his private law practice. Mr. Curran, 40 years old, has held the job for four years. His term was to expire in August.

title: Average Yield 5.781% At Sale of 1Year Bills
TV: Welter Skelter, onManson,Avoids Titillation
description: Hefter Skelter is being presented in two installments on CBSTV, tonight and tomorrow from 9 to 11 P.M. The production is based on the bestselling book that Vincent Bugliosi, the prosecutor in the Charles Manson case, wrote with the help of Curt Gentry. At issue. of course, are the notorious TateLaBianca murders, and the project has already generated some heated debate on whether such sensationally grisly material, no matter how carefully handled, should be presented on television.

title: Pupils Get a Taste of What School Was Like in 1776
description: MILLINGTON, March 31 The Millington School was transformed into a mock colonial village today as the 342 pupils in kindergarten to the fourth grade acted out American's life style of 200 years ago.

title: Irregular Practices In Option Trading Disclosed by Amex
description: Irregularities in options trading have been uncovered by the American Stock Exchange, the Amex disclosed yesterday.

title: Older Cities Plight Muted As an Issue by Candidates
description: The problems of older American cities, which played a role in the political campaigns following the urban riots of the mid1960's, have been muted in this year's Presidential campaign.

title: TEAMSTERS UNION INDUSTRY STRIVE TO AVERT STRIKE
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, March 31 Teamster locals all over the country began preparing tonight to set up picket lines at trucking companies as negotiators here continued to try to reach a lastminute contract settlement.

title: Shaw Fails In 2 Heats Of Swim
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 1 (UPI)  Tim Shaw, the world recordholder in the 400meter freestyle, failed to qualify this afternoon for the evening final of the event at the Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming championships. He also failed in the 200meter backstroke trials.

title: 3 Democratic Rivals Seek More U.S. Aid for Cities
Is Reagan A Democrat?
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The charge has been made in this corner that not a single effective Democratic Peak speech has been made so fir in the PresidentiaCbampaign, but this will have to be amended. For Ronald Reagan, of all people, has some forward with an attack on his own Republican Administration that is a Masterpiece of Democratic propaganda.

title: Food Prices Show 1.3% Dropinlifonth; Biggest Since 1974
description: Grocery prices in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area, adjusted for normal seasonal variation, declined by 1.3 percent in February, the largest monthbymonth decline since July 1974, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Angolan Plan Reported To Try Mercenaries
description: LONDON, Friday, April 2 (AP) Press and broadcast reports received here today said that a group of foreign mercenaries, including two Americans, are to face trial in Angola for war crimes.

title: The Quinlan Precedent
description: The unanimous decision of the New Jersey Supreme Court in the Karen Quinlan caseunless it is overruled by the United States Supreme Courtcould begin an entirely new era in the complex border area between medicine and the law. The importance of this boundary has grown with the advancing capabilities of medical science, which now can sometimes extend metabolism beyond the limits of conscious, productive or meaningful life.

title: City's Poor Jam Congressmen's Offices
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Robin Hood was right, says the sign in the South Bronx Congressional office of Representative Herman S. Badillo. It is a display of bravado, not policy, says Mr. Badillo, who adds that since the city started cutting its budget last fall it has the rich who have victimized the poor.

title: DR. X IS REINSTATED AT JERSEY HOSPITAL
description: JERSEY CITY, April 1 (AP)  Christ Hospital tonight reinstated the surgical privileges of Dr. Mario Jascalevich, who is under investigation in connection with the mysterious deaths of 13 patients at another hospital in 1966.

title: Out of the Woodstock, Hiss and Chambers
Senate Panel Rejects Schwartz Nomination
description: ALBANY, April 1  The Senate Finance Committee, as expected, voted today to recommend against confirmation of Herman Schwartz, Governor Carey's nominee to head the Commission of Correction. The full Senate is expected to vote next Thursday. No gubernatorial Inominee in memory here has been denied confirmation.

title: $5 Million Grant to Aid Medical School
description: NEWARK, April 1  The Foundation of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New. Jersey announced today the receipt from the Robert Wood; Johnson Foundation as the start of a $12 million fundraising effort for the state's niedk caleducation complex.

title: Failure of Engine on Big Jets Worries Safety Board
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that it was concerned about a possible repetition of the catastrophic engine failure that destroyed a DC10 jumbo jet here last fall.

title: 2 WEST BANK MAYORS ROUSE TO RUN AGAIN
description: JERUSALEM, April 1 (UPI) Two of the most influential Arab, moderates have resisted intensive Israeli pressure to get them to run for reelection as mayor in municipal elections in the occupied West Bank, Israeli military government sources said today.

title: Julius Schachter, Violinist, NBC Concertmaster, Was 67
description: Julius Schachter, concertmaster for the National Broadcasting Company orchestras from 1950 to 1066 and a violinist in television, radio and recordings, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home, 166 East 35th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: Life, Death and the Law
description: In ruling that the respirator that has kept Karen Anne Quinlan alive for nearly a year might be turned off, the New Jersey Supreme Court became the first court in the country ex?? ?? ?? ize the withdrawal of lifepreserving treatment where further medical intervention would not be in the patient's best interest.

title: Some Leaders Are Responding to Carter
description: It was a small gesture, perhaps, but Jimmy Carter considered it a big breakthrough when George Meany, the nation's most powerful labor leader, returned one of Mr. Carter's telephone calls to his home in Plains, Ga,. a week ago Saturday.

title: An American Atrocity
description: The dismissal of two grand juries that for years have been looking into the 1971 revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility puts an end to one set of injustices but perpetuates another. The loose grab bag of indictments against more than 60 inmatesabout 1,300 charges in all, most of which proyed insupportablehad already been dropped by the state, and the dismissal of the grand juries means no more such charges will be brought.

title: U.S. Rights Aide Assails ThirdWorld Bloc of U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Apr. 1  Leonard Garment, the United States member of the Human Rights Commission, today attacked the handling of rights issues in the United Nations, charging that a coalition of Sovietbloc and thirdworld countries had muzzled Western protests and twisted resolutions to legitimize its own repressive practices.

title: Both Sides Sum Up In Kapp vs. N.F.L.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1  The arguments were concluded at 4:45 today in District Court on the 23d day of Joe Kapp's antitrust case against the National Football League.

title: Life, Death and the Law
description: In ruling that the respirator that has kept Karen Anne Quinlan alive for nearly a year might be turned off, the New Jersey Supreme Court became the first court in the country exprivacy, toe court appointeu Miss Quinlan's father her guardian and empowered him to seek physicians and hospital officials who would agree to disconnect the respirator.

title: WHOLE SALE PRICES UP A BIT IN MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The whoelsale price index rose slightly in March after two months of decline, the Labot Department reported today. But the basic pattern of moderating inflation in the economy was unchanged.

title: White House Power Break
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI)  The electrical system at the White House failed for an hour last night, hut power for security and other essential services was provided by a standby engine, Presidential aides said today. They said the break in regular service stemmed from a failure in the Potomac Electric Power Company substation serving the White House.

title: PACT ON TRANSIT PEGS ALL RAISES TO COST OF LIVING
description: A paralyzing transit strike was narrowly averted early yesterday morning at a cost that ,city officials feared they could not match for other public employees within the limits of the city's already shaky, financial plan.

title: East Prussians Pondering Emigration From Poland
description: OLSZTYN, PolandThousands of German families living in Poland have been plunged into an agony of indecision by a new treaty, under which 125,000 Germans will be permitted to leave this country.

title: Credit Markets Ease
description: Credit market prices continued to decline in reaction to the Federal Reserve's sale of Treasury bills but later rebounded somewhat as a drop was reported in the money supply. Page 44.

title: Step Is Regarded as Bearish Indicator
description: Insiders corporate officers and directorsapparently stimulated by the rise in the market, have become heavy sellers, a study of trading figures released by the New York Stock Exchange shows.

title: USERY SEEKS END TO TRUCK STRIKE
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., April 1 Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr. pressed both sides in the trucking strike today to compromise and reach an agreement, in the hope of avoiding a court injunction to end the walkout that began last midnight.

title: FROZEN METHANE SIGHTED ON PLUTO
description: Evidence has been found that Pluto, the outermost of the nine planets circling the sun, is partly covered with methane ice. This has raised the possibility that Pluto is much smaller, than has been supposed and may, in fact, be a former moon of Neptune.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Striking employees of the Manhattan Transit Company, which serves 20,000 riders daily between Bergen. Passaic and Hudson Counties and New York, ratified a contract agreement yesterday.

title: U.N. Aides Say Angola Debate Shows Lack of U.S. Policy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1  Many delegates said today that the United States floundered in the Security Council's Angola debate, which ended late last night, because Washington lacks a coherent Africa policy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NAME IT, HEAR IT La Difference, a large elegant restaurant in the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue, at 45th Street, comes by its name naturally on at least two counts. It has Continental kosher cuisine. It also has a pianista smiling bundle of energy named George Parker  who immediately plays requests, and then some. Ask for any Cole Porter and you get an instant cavalcade.

title: Skateboard Generation Blooms On City and Suburban Concrete
description: Southern California, the source of countless outdoor cults, is now peddling one tied to asphalt and concrete, and the New York metropolitan area, much of which lies under the two substances, is buying.

title: Jackson Is Endorsed by Rustin In New Push for Black Voters
NBC Says Strike Cost $156,000 on First Day
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it hid suffered damages totaling $156,000 as a result of what it catled sabotage Sin New York City on the first day of a strike by. the National Association of BrQadcast Employees and Technicians, the engineers union whose members also Include maintenance personnel and news writers.

title: To Raise a Family in the City or in the Suburbs? The Total Dilemma
description: Middleincome parents who remain In the city are often scorned by their suburban friends. It's getting to the point where city parents can't go to a party in Lynbrook, L.I., without being attacked for neglecting their children's needs for open spaces and freedom from fear.

title: Notes on People
description: One of our, national treasures was how Arthur Rubinstein was described by President Ford yesterday as he presented the 89yearold pianist with the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award, in the East Room of the White House. Mr. Rubinstein tried to blush but failed.

title: Good Humor Corp. Is Fined $85,000 In Coliform Case
description: The Good Humor Corporation has pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to 50 counts of a 244count indictment charging the cotripAny and two officers with falsifying records to cover high chunts of conform bacteria in Good Humor products.

title: SILVERLIGHT'S JAZZ FULL OF EXCESSES
description: There ought to be someone hovering over jazz musicians who would say, Enough, already! This would spare many jazzmen from burying themselves in extended grandiosity, and it might also salvage such potentially good groups as Barry Miles and Silverlight, now appearing at the Village Vanguard, from the onus of their excesses.

title: Simon Hopeful on City Finances
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Treasury Secretary William E. Simon expressed cautious optimism today about New York City's finances, but Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, criticized what he called his Pollyanna attitude for believing that the city would be able to obtain credit when legislation providing Federal loans expires, in 1978.

title: Edward Streeter, Humorist, Dies at 84
description: Edward Streeter, humorist and author of two bestselling novels, Father of the Bride and Dere Mable, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Monte Cristo and Baskervilles Staged
description: George Bernard Shaw described melodrama as a simple and sincere drama of action and feeling. Quite often that simplicity and sincerity are ignored in pursuit of the epic and extravaganza. For that reason, despite some shortcomings, two current Off Off Broadway melodramas, The Count of Monte Cristo at the Jean Cocteau Repertory and The Hound of the Baskervilles at the CSC Repertory, are to be commended.

title: Books of The Times  Dad, the Endangered Species
description: In America today. says Maureen Green, the father may be an endangered species. He is being muscled out of his family by an increasingly competent and aggressive mother. Because he is not sure what his role is, he finds it difficult to defend himself. A palace revolution took place while he was at the office, and now he is the odd man out trying to get back in.

title: Delegate Candidates Counting on Friends
description: After all the speeches on national and international issues, after days of dawntomidnight campaigning by the Presidential hopefuls, the convention delegate races in next Tuesday's New York primary, as often as not, will turn on the success a delegate has in getting his friends out to vote for him.

title: U.S. Rights Aide Assails ThirdWorld Bloc of U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Apr. 1  Leonard Garment, the United States member of the Human Rights Commission, today attacked the handling of rights issues in the United Nations, charging that a coalition of Sovietbloc and thirdworld countries had muzzled Western protests and twisted resolutions to legitimize its own repressive practices.

title: MARINE RECRUITING TO BE INVESTIGATED
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI)  A House subcommittee will investigate Marine Corps recruiting and training practices in light of recent incidents involving death and injury to recruits, three Congressmen said today.

title: Rhodesians Indicating a Shift To Talks With Chiefs of Tribes
Largest Trucking Concern On L.I. Is Closed by Strike
description: DEER PARK, L.I., April 1 Long Island's largest trucking concern, Pinter Brothers, was closed today by a strike of its 110 drivers.

title: QUINLAN DECISION OPPOSED IN ROME,
description: ROME, April 1 The decision taken by the New Jersey Supreme Court in the, controversial case of Karen Anne Quinlan was criticized today by a professor in an interview on the Vatican radio station. The subject matter of the station's programs cosely reflect Vatican policy.

title: QUINLAN DECISION OPPOSED IN ROME
description: ROME, April 1 The decision taken by the New Jersey Supreme Court in the controversial case of Karen Anne Quinlan was criticized today by a professor in an interview on the Vatican radio station. The subject matter of the station's programs cosely reflect Vatican policy.

title: Paul Strand Dies
description: Paul Strand, one of the most influential of modern still and motion picture photographers, died in France at 85. Page 36.

title: USERY SEEKS END TO TRUCK STRIKE
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., April 1 Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr. pressed both sides in the trucking strike today to compromise and reach an agreement, in the hope of avoiding a court injunction to end the walkout that began last midnight.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Kellogg International Corporation, London, and Kellogg India Ltd., New Delhi, have been awarded contracts for a 1,000tonaday fertilizer ammonia plant for phulpur in North India by the Indian Farmers Fertilizer Cooperative Ltd. Both companies are affiliates of the Pullman Kellogg division of Pullman Inc. Cost of the entire project is estimated at $109 million.

title: Guinan and Yunich Settled Basis of Pact on Tuesday
description: The basic framework of the transit agreement was worked out in private discussions Tuesday evening in the New York Hilton Hotel between Matthew Guinan, the Transport Workers Union president, and David L. Yunich, the Transit Authority chairman. But the final pieces of the package were not put together until the early hours of yesterday morning.

title: Crisis Delays Reopening Of American University
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 (Reuters) The American University of Beirut announced today that classes would remain suspended because of the security situation in he country.

title: Court Blocks City's Cutoff Of Some DayCare Cases
description: A temporary restraining order has been issued in Federal District Court in Manhattan prohibiting the city from terminating day care to families solely on the ground that parents are enrolled in fouryear college programs.

title: Avco FirstQuarter Net Highest In 9 Years on 6% Revenue Gain
description: The Avco Corporation, the diversified industrial company, had its highest firstquarter net income in nine years with a large increase on a revenue gain of 6.5 percent, according to the company's report issued yesterday.

title: Dinosaur Resurrected From Extinct Parts
description: A dinosaur put together from used auto parts in New Jersey junkyards will be outside the Equitable Life Insurance Building at West 51st Street and the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan today. The skeletal beast32 feet long and 10 feet highwill be part of a Bicentennial exhibition sponsored by the National Sculpture Society that opens Monday and continues through April 22.

title: 2 Named for Indy 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 1 (UPI)Gordon Johneock, a former winner, and a veteran driver, Wally Dallenbach were named as drivers for cars eniered today in this year's Indianapolis 500 race.

title: COPPER AND SILVER SHOW SHARP RISES
description: Copper and silver prices rose sharply in active buying in the London market when traders rushed to rid themselves of British pounds.

title: Advertising
description: Ted Bates & Company, which pulled in some $60 minion in new billings last year, is understood to have been named the agency for Mr. Coffee, the automatic dripolator made by North American Systems, Cleveland. The company spent $13 million on advertising last year and is expected to push that to more than $15 million this year.

title: Spain to Try 4 on Charges Of Advocating New Regime
description: MADRID, April 1 (Reuters)  Four leading members of a new opposition political alliance were held for trial here today on charges of advocating a change in Spain's form of government, a crime punishable by up to 30 years in prison.

title: The Opera: Ashmedar by City Troupe
description: Add to your list of operas with devils: Ashmedai by Josef Tal. It was composed in 1971 and had its American premiere last night at the New York State Theater. Mr. Tal is an Israeli composer and is considered one of the avantgardists there. But if this opera is representative of his work, his avantgarde proclivities do not extend much beyond Alban Berg's Wozzeck. which had its premiere about 50 years ago.

title: Search Prompted by XRay Is Upheld
description: A Brooklyn Appellate Court held yesterday that it was not necessary to get a traveler's consent to search his luggage if Xray equipment at an airport found it contained a weapon.

title: Carter and Two Rivals Differ on the Economy
description: Jimmy Carter has established a position on economic issues that differs markedly from the stands taken by his two principal rivals in the New York Democratic Presidential pimary.

title: People in Sports
description: John Williamson, a starting guard for the New York Nets, suffered a severe sprain of the left ankle in Wednesday night's 116106 loss to the Pacers in Indianapolis. Williamson will be out of action for an estimated 10 days to two weeks, and could miss the first round of the American Basketball Association playoffs, scheduled to start on April 9.

title: Kissinger, in Rebutting Reagan, Calls Charges False Inventions
Lawyer Teaches Cooking
