description: CINCINNATI (AP)  Gary Schwartz, who teaches com mercial food management at, Aiken High School, has an unusual background for a cooking teacher. He is a graduate of Harvard Law School. I enjoyed law school, he explained. But law is too serious, I'm always serious about what I do. If what you're doing is already serious, then you're doubIll serious. And then Ws no fun"

title: Conrail Obtains a Loan of $309 Million
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1  The Consolidated Rail Corporation, taking over the bulk of the transportation properties of the Penn Central and other bankrupt Northeast railroads, today borrowed $309 million from a Federal agency for working capital and to repay an undisclosed amount of loans obtained recently to prepare for its initial operations.

title: Circus,Whirls Into Town With Happy Distractions
description: Just back from the Garden that's Madison, Square Gardenwhere the circus opened last night and limp from an exciting day that began with the city flanging by its toes over a threatened transit strike and that ended with all sorts of people whirling about in midair.

title: Britain, With Its Traditional Pageantry, Bids Farewell to Montgomery
description: WINDSOR, England, April 1 (AP)Britain laid aside economic and social concerns today and mustered traditional pageantry to bid farewell to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, the cocky little commander who turned gloom to glory in World War II. Field marshals and guardsmen, dressed in scarlet, gold and black, marched in solemn procession at Windsor Castle for Lord Montgomery's funeral. Lord Montogmery died a week ago at the age of 88. Veterans of Alamein, where Montgomery and a battered army began the North African thrust that turned the tide of the war 33 years ago, stood at curbside. The police estimated that 4,000 bystanders joined 1,000 specially picked soldiers along the funeral route. Nineteen cannon shots, a field marshal's due, echoed through the town, its flags at halfstaff, while muffled drums rolled and six black horses drew a gun carriage bearing Montgomery's flagdraped coffin, his familiar black beret resting on top. Mourners included Prince Philip, the Duke of _Edinburgh, who was representing his wife, Queen Elizabeth II, and representatives of dozens of nations. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. Supreme NATO commander, represented the United States. The Soviet Union, which snubbed the victory parade in London 30 years ago, sent one of its war heroes, Air Minister Sergei Rudenko. Five British field marshals were honorary pallbearers. The funeral took p/ace at the 500yearold St. George's Chapel, the place of worship and ceremony for the Order of the Garter, an exclusive band of royally appointed knights to which Montgomery belonged. The service, which was televised worldwide, ended with a bugle call and Lord Montgomery's coffin was driven to a simple burial under an ancient yew tree near his country home in Hampshire.

title: U.S. Note Protests to Russians On Harassment of Diplomats
description: MOSCOW, April 1 The United State's sent a note to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today protesting the continued harassment of American diplomats in Moscow.

title: Misses Goola gong, Evert, Barker and Wade Advance
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1 Chris Evert said she was really up for this match. She said she really wanted it. She wanted to beat Dianne Fromholtz so much that she almost could not control her feelings. She ,wanted revenge against the, first person since Denise Carter in 1971 to defeat her in the first round of a tournament. Miss Fromholtz did that to Miss Evert last week in Boston, and Miss Evert wanted to put her away early tonight in a quarter final match of the Virginia Slims Tournament at the Palestra.

title: COFFEE RISE JOINED BY GENERAL FOODS
description: The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest coffee retailer, yesterday joined the Folger's Coffee Company in raising prices.

title: Court's Ruling to Let Miss Quinlan Die Stirs Much Praise and Condemnation
description: TRENTON, April 1 oJseph T. Quinlan visited his comatose daughter today as controversy mounted over the New Jersey Supreme Court decision yesterday authorizing him to terminate her life and state officials studied the opinion to determine whether to appeal the ruling.

title: Senate Panel Backs Oil Divestiture By 4 to 3 After 11 Years of Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 After 11 years of intermittent, hearings on competition in the oil industry, the Senate antitrust . subcommittee approved. today a bill tn break up 18 large oil companies.

title: Teng Photos Being Purged From Hsinhua Picture Files
description: PEKING, April 1 (Agence FrancePresse) A purge of the official Hsinhua Press Agency's photographic files seems to be under way, with Deputy Prime Minister Teng HsiaoPing as the target.

title: Panels in Congress Set $413 Billion As Budget Target
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The House and Senate budget committees both finished work today on their budget targets and both decided to recommend to Congress total spending of somewhat more than $413 billion for the fiscal year 1977, I beginning next Oct. 1.

title: Paul Strand, influential photographer and Maker or Movies, Is Dead at 85
description: Paul Strand, one of the most influential practitioners of 20thcentury photography, whose wink in both still and motion pictures has gained increasing critical acclaim, died Wednesday at his home in Oregeval, a French yillage west of Paris. He was 85 years old

title: Flyers Take Aim at Street Hockey Title
description: FAIR LAWN, April 1 The Fair Lawn Flyers leave tomorrow for Leoministcr, Mass., to compete for the first national street hockey championship.

title: Background of Opera First Staged in 1964
description: Roger Sessions's opera Montezuma dates back some 40 years. In the 1930's G. Antonio Borgese, a Sicilian novelist, playwright, and refugee from Fascist Italy, traveled to Mexico. On his return he conveyed his enthusiasm for the history of that country to his friend, Mr. Sessions, who then went to Mexico himself with the Montezuma subiect in mind. Four years later, in 1941, Mr. Borgese sent the composer what Mr. Sessions recently called an enormous text in four acts.

title: Briton Talks With Nyerere
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 1 (Reuters) David Ennals, a special British envoy, said today he and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania had agreed that pressure on Rhodesia's leaders to accept iblackmajority rule must be increased.

title: Three Democrats On Pike Committee Asked to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Members of the House Select Committee on Intelligence have been asked by House investigators to give testimony voluntarily tomorrow about the unauthorized disclosure of the committee's report dealing with secret operations of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Big Board Changes Rules To Ease OddLot Dealings
description: Rules changes have been adopted by the New York Stock Exchange, the exchange said yesterday, to facilitate dealing in oddlots when its 380 specialists also become oddlot dealers on May 24.

title: About the Mets ...
description: Mike Vail, the rookie outfielder who dislocated his foot playing basketball two months ago, was placed on the 2Iday disabled list. But that was considered a positive sign rather than a negative one because Vail had been expected to miss two months of work. He is taking batting practice now and will stay in Florida for more conditioning when the Mets leave. Felix Milian, the second baseman. who reported late Irom Puerto Rico. missed another game with a slight elbow strain. One event that was not canceled by baseball's legal troubles this spring was Bradenton's annual Hall of Fame dinner. It was held Lit night with Pl Hall of Hunprq prvsent, including Bob l'eller, Ralph Killer, Lloyd Wittier, Red ?? and Monte Irvin.

title: Pound Falls Below $1.90; Wildcat Strikes a Factor
description: LONDON, April 1 (AP) The British pound sank below $1.90 for the first time today, undermined by wildcat strikes crippling the nation's biggest automaker and casting doubt on Britain's ability to achieve economic recovery.

title: Upstate Meeting Starts
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., April  The first thing Herb Cauthers, the track superintendent, did when he arrived at rainsoaked Monticello Raceway early today was to ask one of his staff to get the grader with the rubber blade out of the garage and have it ready for use.

title: Report Sees City Slipping In Its CostCutting Effort
description: The city's effort to overcome fiscal chaos is seriously slipping, according to the fourth and most critical report by a special deputy state comptroller on the budgetcutting program.

title: Lebanon's Leftist Leader
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1  Lebanese press cartoons have often depicted a mahatmalike figure dressed in white robes and spinning yarn from a nearby goat. The figure is57yearold Kemal Jumblat, a yogapracticing leader of the Moslem Druse sect, a wealthy landowner and Lebanon's leading leftist.

title: House Votes Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The House decisively approved today a bill that would reconstitute the Federal Election Commission but curtail the independence of the agency considerably more sharply than the measure the Senate passed last week.

title: ANTHONY B. AKERS, RAN FOR CONGRESS
description: Anthony B. Akers. who was the United States Ambassador to New Zealand from 1961 to 1963 and three times lost battles for a seat in Congress representing the fashionable East Side 17th District in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday in Wrightsville Beach, N.C. He was 61 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Israel Drops Proceedings Against Rosenbaum in Financial Case
description: TEL AVIV, April 1 Legal proceedings in Israel against Tibor Rosenbaum, the financier whose European business conglomerate collapsed in 1974, have been drooped.

title: Learning From My Lai: A Proposal on War Crimes
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn. On March 29, 1969, Ronald L. Ridenhour asked publicly for an inquiry into the events that he believed had taken place at My Lai, South Vietnam, a year before.

title: C.I.A. Said to Have Known In 50's of Lockheed Bribes
description: Many of the details of the bribery of Japanese politicians by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the late 1950's, in connection with the sale of the FI04 fighter plane to Japan, were reported at that time to the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency in Washington, according to a former C.I.A. official and Japanese sources.

title: Panels in Congress Set $413 Billion As Budget Target
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The House and Senate budget cornmittees both finished work today on their budget targets and both decided to recommend to Congress total spending of somewhat more than $413 billion for the fiscal year 1977, beginning next Oct. 1.

title: Udall Calls Carter Evasive on Jobs Bill
description: Mbrtis K. Udall lashed out with more than accustomed emotion yesterday at Jimmy Carter, saying that Mr. Carter was evading the question of whether he supported Congressional Democrats who are pushing full employment legislation.

title: Levi to Review F B.I. Surveillance, Then Tell Victims
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 At tarney General Edward H. Levi announced today that he had assigned a panel of Justice De. partment lawyers to review the Federal Bureau of Investigation's domestic counterintelligence program and, under certain circumstances, to notify its victims of actions taken against them.

title: Financing Problems Delay CanadianLockheed Deal
description: OTTAWA, April 1 Preliminary financing problems have delayed the signing of a contract between the Canadian Government and the Lockheed Aircraft corporation for the purchase of 18 longrange patrol aircraft from the American company at a cost to Canada of more than $1 billion.

title: Market Place
description: When Madison Fund Inc. announced at its annual meeting in Dallas last week that the future annual distributions would amount to 'at least 6 percent of _asset value, averaged over the previous two calendar years, the closedend investment company was copying a system that the Niagara Share Corporation has had in effect for many years.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NARA, Japan, April 1 (AP) Alfredo Escalera of Puerto Rico remained the world junior lightweight boxing champion after his title bout tonight with Buzzsaw Yamabe of Japan ended in confusion with a nocontest ruling. In the sixth round, Escalera, 1281/2 pounds, was swinging away the 130pound Yamabe, who was dodging some of the punches but reeling from a few others. Suddenly, Ismail Falu, the referee, also from Puerto Rico, stepped in and halted the fight. There had been no knockdowns in the bout to that point.

title: Skateboard Generation Blooms On City and Suburban Concrete
description: Southern California, the source of countless outdoor cults, is now peddling one tied to asphalt and concrete, and the New York metropoutan area, much of which lies under the two substances, is buying.

title: U.S. Is Encouraged by the CeaseFire in Lebanon but Fears That Conflict There Still Holds Dangers
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  United States officials said today that they regarded the ceasefire announcement in Lebanon as an encouraging development, but they still expressed concern that the political situation there could deteriorate further.

title: PACT ON TRANSIT PEGS ALL RAISES TO COST OF LIVING
description: A paralyzing transit strike was narrowly averted early yesterday morning at a cost that city officials feared they could not match for other public employees within the Emits of the city's already shaky financial plan.

title: Light Beam Treatments Reduce Diabetic Blindness
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Evidence that a treatment called photocoagulation reduces the risk of blindness in some diabetes patients was made public today by the National Institutes of Health.

title: Homicide Suspect's Neighbors Post Bail in Westchester Case
description: YONKERS, April 1 A former prostitute charged with manslaughter was freed today from the Westchester County Jail on $1,500 bail raised by county residents who say they believe she is innocent.

title: City U. Board to Ease Off on Tighter Entrance Rules
description: The Board of Higher Education has agreed to limit the applocation of a controversial entrance standard requiring eighthgrade reading ability for admission next fall to City Universkty, board sources said yesterday.

title: Regular PBW Trading Set In Penn Central Co. Stock
description: The PBW Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the common stock of the Penn Central Company was continuing to be traded on a regular fiveday settlement basis. On Monday the New York Stock Exchange transferred trading in the stock from a regular to cash on same day, settlement, indicating that the stock was in the delisting process.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Lebanon's warring factions agreecl last night on a 10day truce to give Parliament time to elect a new President to replace Suleiman Franjieh who has refused to resign. The truce became possible when Kemal Jumblat, the Moslem Druse and Socialist leader who beads the leftistMoslem alliance, said after a long meeting with his associates that his side would be willing stop the fighting temporarily under these circumstances. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: ExPresident Calls Marcos a Dictator; U.S.Refuses Asylum
description: MANILA, April 1  Former President Diosdado MacapagaI today denounced the martiallaw Government of the Philippines as a lawless dictatorship and then sought asylum in the United States Embassy.

title: Miss McMullen, at 68, Tied With Mrs. Berning
Kissinger Says Aides Probably Hear Calls
Assembly Wishes Byrne Happy 52d
description: TRENTON, April 1 Governor Byrne turned 52 years old today and the State Assembly honored him seriously and in jest.

title: It's Called the Wedge and It Goes to Their Heads
description: What do a champion figure skater, a modern dance choreographer and any number of women from a high school student to a middleaged beauty salon patron have in common these days? A short hairdo that falls over the forehead, bares the ear lobe and becomes a triangle in back.

title: Ford Expects Company's Reins To Remain Within the Family
description: DETROIT, April 1 Henry Ford 2d, who is recovering from a heart ailment, expects another member of the Ford family to have a job somewhere at the top of the Ford Motor Company if Mr. Ford should have to leave before normal retirement age.

title: Plane Explosion Perils Nixon Home and APlant
description: SAN ONOFRE, Calif., April I (UPI)  A small plane exploded and crashed into the ocean between former President Richard M, Nixon's seaside estate and a nuclear power plant yesterday.

title: Kuhn Dampens Toronto Move, Fails to Rule on Messersmith
description: In the confusion surrounding the Yankees and Andy Messersmith and the American League and Toronto, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn solved neither problem yesterday. But he did complicate the second one.

title: Max Ernst, Catalytic Figure in 20th Century Art, Dies
description: Max Ernst, the Surrealist artist, who was conspicuous even before World War I for his exceptional gifts and his power to startle and provoke, died in Paris yesterday. Ht.. would have been 85 years old today.

title: San Francisco Copes With City Workers Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI)  The Mayor took a cold shower at City Hall and travelers at San Francisco International Airport ate from paper plates today, the second day of a strike by city workers.

title: Dismal Pattern
description: Buying off overpowerful municipal unions with money the city did not have was a major element in New York's fiscal decline last year to the edge of bankruptcy. Now, under threat of a subway and bus strike, the Transit Authority has sewn the city into a new pay pattern that imperils its climb back toward fiscal health.

title: Three Policemen Fatally Shot Outside a Motel in Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla.. April 1 (UPI) Three policemen in plainclothes investigating what they believed was a stolen car were shot to death in a motel parkirrg lot today.

title: Max Ernst, Catalytic Figure in 20th Century Art, Dies
description: Max Ernst, the Surrealist artist, who was conspicuous even before World War I for his exceptional gifts and his power to startle and provoke, died in Paris yesterday. He would have been 85 years old today.

title: Anaconda Shares Acquired by Arco
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday the successful completion of its offer to purchase 6 million common shares of the Anaconda Company. The oil company's offer to the stockholders of the copper concern was $27 a share. Atlantic Richfield said that approximately 7 million shares were tendered, Purchases will be made on a pro rata basis in order to limit the acquisition to approximately A million shares, or 27 percent, of the 22.1 million shares outstand. ing. Therefore, A7 percent of the shares duly tendered by each tendering shareholder will be purchased.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY DOWN FOR WEEK
description: The national money supply declined moderately in the week ended March 24. Commercial and industrial loans outstanding also declined, according to Federal Reserve banking system data released yesterday.

title: Registration of Voters by Mail Upheld by High Court in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 1  The state's highest court today upheld a recent law allowing voter registration by mail, reversing a lower court's decision that the 1975 law was unconstitutional.

title: 2 Seized in Kidnapping of 2 Girls After One Is Shot and One Escapes
description: Two men who allegedly abducted two 16yearold girls at gunpoint outside a Queens high school Wednesday were seized on the Lower East Side last night after one victim was found shot and critically wounded and the other managed to escape unhurt from a Bronx apartment where she had been left bound and gagged.

title: Carter Gains AmongWisconsin Liberals and Unions
description: MILWAUKEE, April 1 Jimmy Carter has begun to attract scattered liberal and labor support to his nonideological Presidential candidacy in Wisconsin, a state where the Democrat left has held sway for more than a decade.

title: It's Spring at Last for Mets
Police Aide and Bodyguard Assassinated in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 1 (UPI)  Assassins armed with machine guns today shot and killed a highranking federal police official and his bodyguard, defying the new military junta's crackdown on terrorists.

title: Carey Bars Making Precise Cuts Legislature Asked
description: ALBANY, April 1 In a move that Infuriated lawmakers and their fiscal aides, Governor Carey began the state's new fiscal year today by refusing to go along with the precise job and expenditure cuts that the Legislature had directed him to make when it passed the budget two weeks ago.

title: Ruling to Let Miss Quinlan Die Stirs Praise and Condemnation
description: TRENTON, April 1 Joseph T. Quinlan visited his comatose daughter today as controversy mounted over the New Jersey Supreme Court decision yesterday authorizing him to terminate her life and state officials studied the opinion to determine whether to appeal the ruling.

title: States Get Federal Funds for Convention Security
description: WASHINGTON. April I (AP)1  Officials from New York and Missouri outlined today the security needs for the political nominating conventions this summer and won final approval for $5.2 million in Federal financial assistance.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The DiCom Corporation, the largest builder and promoter of nursing homes in the state, filed a voluntary bankruptcy proceeding in Federal Court in Brooklyn. The company said that although it had $11.7 million in accounts receivable, mainly from operators, the latter were having difficulty in meeting high interest rates or in obtaining state licensing. DiCom, described by state officials as a major trafficker in nursing homes, recently lost a suit to quash a subpoena by Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor. A spokesman for Mr. Hynes said the bankruptcy would have no effect on the investigation.

title: Chirac Calls on Gaullists to Combat Left
description: ST. JEANDELUZ, France, April 1 Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, invoking the nationalist spirit of Charles de Gaulle, today summoned the Gaullist party to combat for the defense of the Fifth Republic.

title: Film: A Widow Adopts:Hungarian Work Opens Modern Art Series
description: Kata (Kati Berek) is 42 years old, a widow and in good health. She is a self-reliant woman, not given to sudden enthusiasms or rash decisions. She has adjusted to circumstances over which she has no control and though she is not wildly happy, things could be worse. She might not have any lover at all, for example, instead of Joska, played by Laszlo Szabo, who once a week, is amusing and kind and attentive, and who has never once led her to think he would leave his wife and children for her."Adoption," which will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and Sunday at 8:30 P.M., is the measured, unsentimental story of what happens to Kata as she realizes there may be more to life than adjusting to outside circumstances. Kata decides she wants a baby and she does something about it.The Hungarian film, directed by Marta Meszaros, is the first of 12 that will be shown at the museum between now and April 13 in the annual New Directors / New Films series, a project jointly sponsored by the museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center."Adoption" is very much a woman's movie. Though its title has specific reference to Kata's actions after her lover refuses to give her a baby, the film has even more to do with surrogate relationships, particularly with the friendship that develops between Kata and a teen-age girl (Gyongyver Vigh) who has been put into a state home by her family. It is also about women without men (or with men who don't quite measure up) in a world still dominated by men.The style is introspective, or, at least, as introspective as it is possible to be in a movie that does not attempt to crash through to the subconscious. In the center of the screen most of the time, in the close-ups favored by the director, is the fine, angular, expressive face of Miss Berek, who may remind you of Annie Giradot minus the mannerisms Miss Giradot has been using lately."Adoption," which is Miss Meszaros's fifth feature, never explodes with the unexpected insights that separate great films from good ones. It takes no exciting chances. Rather, it records the details of one woman's life with the kind of deliberate care and intelligence that one can recognize without being especially moved.

title: Paul Strand Dies
description: Paul Strand, one of the most influential of modern still and motion picture photographers, died in France at $5. Page 36.

title: Issues 76: Welfare
description: Welfare has become a national blight, destructive of many of the people it is designed to help and threatening the solvency of state and local governments. Outlays for public assistance keep mounting, in good times as well as bad; resentment grows among those on the relief rolls and among those taxed to pay the bill while other community services wither.

title: LEFTIST ALLIANCE IN BEET ACCEPTS 10DAY CEASEFIRE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, April 2  Lebanon's warring factions agreed last night on a 10day truce to give Parliament time to elect a new president to replace Suleiman Pranjieh, the controversial Christian leader who has refused to resign.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES LEVY INDICTMENT
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed charges of trafficticket fixing brought against Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission, and John R. Fratianni, former deputy commissioner of purchase.

title: Humphrey Asks Marshall Plan for Cities
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, greeted by politicians and the press with the attention customarily accorded an active Presidential candidate, which he insists he is not, describedl a Marshall Plan for the Cities yesterday to a roomful of mayors and other officials.

title: Sessions Montezuma Comes to U.S.
description: BOSTON, April 1  The prevailing impression one is left with of Roger Session's massive opera Montezuma, which received its American premiere at the Orpheum Theater here last night, is of highminded seriousness.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: News Summary and Index
description: Lebanon's warring factions agreed last night on a 10day truce to give Parliament time to elect a new President to replace Suleiman Franjieh who has refused to resign. The truce became possible when Kamal Jumblat, the Moslem Druse and Socialist leader who heads the leftistMoslem alliance, said after a long meeting with his associates that his side would be willing to stop the fighting temporarily under these circumstances. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: Army Plans Closing Two Bases in City By September 1977
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The Army said today it would close Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Fort Totten in Queens as an economy measure eliminating 604 civilian and 410 military jobs.

title: Law Says Trout Are Ready, But the Weather Disagrees
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1  As fickle as a headstrong girl too sure of her charms, Spring lured the New York State trout fisherman with sweet scents and warm breath, then drowned his passion with tears when the hour of truth arrived.

title: C. I .A. Said to Have Known In 50's of Lockheed Bribes
description: Many of the details of the bribery of Japanese politicians by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the late 1950's, in connection with the sale of the F104 fighter plane to Japan, were reported at that time to the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency in Washington, according to a former C.I.A. official and Japanese sources.

title: Freedom Train Rolls On As It Marks a Birthday
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 1 Into Jefferson City they rolled, bus after yellow bus, convoys from all over the midMissouri countryside heading toward the brilliantly hued redwhiteandblue steam locomotive with the words American Freedom Train emblazoned on the cars it pulled.

title: Some Skateboarders in Rapture, Some in Traction
description: In the world of skateboarding, the kids who specialize in daredevil descents of steep roads, highway bridge underpasses or just about any slanted stretch of concrete are known as. !road rash riders,

title: AMEX RETRACES PHANTOM OPTIONS
description: Officials of the American Stock Exchange, now investigating options trades that never took place, theorized yesterday that the Amex specialists who were involved waited until just before the close of trading at 4 P.M. each day to make the phantom trades.

title: Jewish Group Shifts Domestic Priority To Jobs and Health
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 zThe American Jewish Congress announced today a major shift of its domestic priority to emphasize programs promoting full employment, national health insurance and welfare reform.

title: Gotham Giant Test For Unbeaten Zen
description: As usual, the alarm clock in the Long Island home of Jacinto Vasquez will go off at 5 o'clock this morning. By 5:15 A.M., the jockey who rode Foolish Pleasure to victory in last year's Kentucky Derby will be finishing a breakfast of two threeminute eggs, toast and espresso coffee prepared by his wife.

title: Business Briefs
description: Trans World Airlines has announced that its institutional creditors have agreed to extend to April 30 a debt deferral program that was to have expired yesterday. Charles C. Tillinghast, T. W. A.'s chairman, said the action was taken in light of the airline's improved cash position.

title: Goldsmith Brothers Will Close Nassau Street Store, Its Last
description: Goldsmith Brothers, a 90yearold company that was once the country's largest seller of stationery and office supplies, will close its last retail store at 77 Nassau Street within six weeks after a liquidation sale beginning Monday.

title: Credit Prices Continue Their Slide, But Money Supply Drop Spurs Rally
description: Credit market prices continued their slide early yesterday as they reacted nervously to the Federal Reserve's decision to sell $300 million of Treasury bills, and later they recovered as the money supply was reported to have dropped. The Federal Reserve's early sale of shortterm bills was done for one of the accounts it handles, but the central bank could have bought them itself instead of offering them in the market. Traders, who try to decipher the meaning of every Fed move or failure to move, wondered if the monetary authorities were hinting that they wanted interest rates to inch upward, and so Treasury bill prices declined. as the money supply was reported to have dropped. The Federal Reserve's early sale of shortterm bills was done for one of the accounts it handles, but the central bank could have bought them itself instead of offering them in the market. Traders, who try to decipher the meaning of every Fed move or failure to move, wondered if the monetary authorities were hinting that they wanted interest rates to inch upward, and so Treasury bill prices declined.

title: EDWIN B. BENJAMIN
description: Edwin B. Benjamin, an associate professor at Temple University for the last 17 years, died March 10 in an automobile accident in New Haven, Vt. He was 59 years old.

title: Screen: Salsa Medley  Latin Rhythms Linked by Pompous Narration
description: Salsa is an 80minute record jacket.

title: Connally Dines With Ford as Both Republican Factions Woo Him
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 John B. Connally was far back in the group when 16 members of President Ford's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board emerged from the White House today to take the oath of office in a Rose Garden ceremony.

title: Stewart of Oregon Named Fordham Basketball Coach
description: Dick Stewart, self  described as a tall, skinny college guard who could not shoot but clawed and scratched his way up, was selected yesterday as Fordham University's basketball coach. Stewart played three seasons as a starter for Rutgers when . the Scarlet Knights began their climb to national prominence during the 196667 season.

title: Latins, Fearful of Castro, Cancel Panama Meeting
Bonn Bars a Rise in Mark To End Trade Bloc Crisis
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 1  European government leaders struggled with limited success today to. keep the Common Market from coming apart over economic differences. But they did move toward agreement on the political issue of how to apportion seats in a new European Parliament.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.5 billion tonmiles, 13.5 percent above a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 467.478 cars, 12.3 percent above last year, which included the Good Friday holiday. The American Trucking Associations reported intercity truck tonnage was 23.1 percent above last year.

title: Site for Floating Nuclear Plant Studied
description: ATLANTIC CiTY, April 1 Exactly 2.8 miles seaward of Little Egg Inlet just north of here, a rusty orange and white tripod tower festooned with instruments rises 30 feet out of the ocean, marking the spot where Public Service Electric and Gas Company would like to place the world's first floating nuclear power plant.

title: Panamanian Minister Quits: Held Canal Talks With U.S.
description: PANAMA, April 1 (AP) Juan Antonio Tack, Panama's Foreign Kinister, and chief negotiator with the United States for a new Panama Canal treaty, resigned today for strictly personal reasons, a Government announcement said.

title: Messy Case of Mr. Messersmith
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 Here among the horseshoe hells and shuffleboard dens of swinging St. Pete, the ThreeQuarter Century Club is an oasis of cairn, the only corner of the baseball world untroubled by lockout or lawsuit, by free agents or the agents of free agents, by labor strife, rebellion, intimidation or reprisal. The Kids and Kubs of the ThreeQuarter Century Club have just completed their 46th season of softball with the Kubs on top by two games. Throughout the league there is peace and good fellowship, from smiling Rolland Pearson, 75, who batted 374 as a rookie with the Kids after seven seasons in the Liniment League, to Fred The Broadwell, 91, who hits like a sonuvagun for the Kubs, according to Maynard Van Horn, the league's president. Fred hit way over his 233 of last year, Mr. Van Horn said. He hit em where they weren't. There is no substitute for experience.

title: ExPresident Calls Marcos a Dictator; U.S. Ref uses Asylum
description: MANILA, April 1 Former President Diosdado Macapagal toddy denounced the martiallaw Government of the Philippines as a lawless dictatorship and then sought asylum in the United States Embassy.

title: Dow Industrials Off 5.35 in a Slow Day
description: The stock market gave ground yesterday after one of its worriesthe possibility of a nationwide trucking strikebecame an actuality.

title: From Japan to the U.N., a Liberated Wornan
description: TOKYO, April 1 During World War II, a teenager named Sadako Nakamura often left her home to hide in a backyard bomb shelter from American planes.

title: Leisure Dynamics at McCaffrey
description: Leisure Dynamics, a fairly new company in the field of games and hobbies, has consolidated its $2 million advertising account at McCaffrey & McCall.

title: FUNDS FOR HYNES PUSHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 1 The Assembly Ways and Means Cornmittee inroduced a bill today to restore most of the money requested in Governor Carey's budget to expand the staff of the office of the special prosecutor for nursing homes.

title: Cunningham Is Told to Testify by Court
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the Democratic chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, must testify before a special grand jury investigating political corruption in the Bronx.

title: The Schell Report
description: The Schell Commission named by Governor Carey to investigate the collapse of the Urban Development Corporation has produced an interim report that is refreshingly lucid, thoughtful and constructive.

title: Bridge:  Charity Tournament Draws Some Experts From Abroad

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, April 2  Lebanon's warring factions agreed last night on a 10day truce to give Parliament time to elect a new president to replace Suleiman Franjieh, the controversial Christian leader who has refused to resign.

title: Carter and Two Rivals Differ on the Economy
description: Jimmy Carter has established a position on economic issues that differs markedly from the stands taken by his two principal rivals in the New York Democratic Presidential primary.

title: AbdulJabbar Is Voted Most Valuable
description: In a competition dominated by centers, Kareem AbdulJabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers was named the winner of the National Basketball Association's mostvaluableplayer award for the fourth time yesterday, edging out Bob McAdoo of the Buffalo Braves and Dave Cowens of the Boston Celtics.

title: TRUCKING STRIKE UNEVEN IN AREA
description: The impact of the nationwide strike by teamster truckers who haul general freight began spreading acrossthe metropolitan area yesterday in what appeared to be an irregular pattern.

title: DECLINES SHOWN BY AMEX AND OTC
description: Investor concern over the nationwide trucking strike yesterday weakened prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Humphrey Asks Marshall Plan for Cities
Walkout Has Little Impact on First Day
description: DENVER, April l The nation weathered the first day of the truckers strike with little immediate impact on the economy, but widespread dislocations were predicted if the shutdown continued after tomorrow.

title: Rhodesia Nationalist Leader Reportedly Seeks New Talks
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April Reuters) The Rhodesian nationalist leader, Bishop Abel Muzorewa, said today that rival nationalist leader; Joshua Nkomo, was trying to get talks with Rhodesia's Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, going again.

title: Reagan Drops Chartered Jet As Campaign Funds Dwindle
description: LOS ANGELES. April 2Ronald Reagan's campaign lost its $50,000aweek chartered jet today because of a tightening money situation.

title: Tapping Computers
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.Like people, computers talking to one another can biviretapped. To protect themselves, more and more companies, such as the oil giants and banks, are putting their digital correspondence into secret form.

title: AntiU.S. Bombing in Athens
description: ATHENS, April 2 (Reuters)A bomb exploded inside a branch of the American Express bank in central Athens today in what was taken as the latest demonstration of antiAmerican sentiment following the grant of $1 billion in United States military aid last week to Turkey. A police spokesman said the device, a time bomb, was placed behind a column inside the bank. It caused neither casualties nor damage.

title: LAYOFFS WEIGHED IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, April 2After being defeated last night in her bid to have Connecticut's state employees work an hour longer each day, Gov. Ella T. Grasso said today that, to keep within the state's tight budget, she was left once again with the alternative of laying some workers off.

title: CRITIC OF MARCOS SAID TO BE HIDING
description: MANILA, April 2 (AP)Former President Diosdado Macapagal was reported in hiding in the Manila area today after the United States Government refused his request for political asylum. The asylum attempt followed publication of a book by Mr. Macapagal attacking the martiallaw Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos as dictatorial.

title: Police Seek Two Queens Kidnappers in Manhattan
description: Scores of detectives combed parts of lower Manhattan yesterday seeking two of the four men who kidnapped the 16yearold niece of a convicted major heroin dealer and critically wounded a friend of the girl last Wednesday afternoon.

title: DISTRICT 3 PLANS TO EXTEND HOURS
description: The board of a West Side school district has been the scene of parent protests over the ;shortened school day has decided to allow its 23 schools to return to their old schedules.

title: REV. JERE J. DINEEN
description: The Rev, Jere J. Dineen, pastor of Holy Spirit Catholic Church, New Hyde Park, L. I., died Thursday in the church rectory. His age was 70.

title: Frank Gilroy Wins Million Over Misuse Of His TV Detective
description: Frank D. Gilroy, a Pulitzer Prizewinning playwright, won a verdict worth more than $1 million yesterday because a television network, a production company and two publishers had used the character Amos Burke, whom he had created in books, without his permission.

title: Gulf to Resume Oil Output in Angola
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday it would resume pumping oil in Angola as soon as liossible at the request of that, country's Government.

title: Lutheran Leader Ousts 4 Dissidents
description: ST. LOUIS, April 2 (UPI)The president of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod removed four dissident district presidents today, and the leader of what is regarded as the church's moderate faction said the dismissal would lead to the eventual breakup of the 2.8millionmember synod.

title: Socialism With Two Faces
description: THE HAGUE  Marshall Tito's official. visit to Stockholm this week brought into friendly confrontation two contemporary types of independent socialism.

title: LEBANESE FIRIT IN SPITE OF TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2A 10day truce officially took effect in Lebanon today, but fighting continued in the capital and the countryside and individual violence increasdd with a wave of 30 to 40 abductions, according to the state radio.

title: Leftists Said to Dominate West Bank Election Drive
description: TEL AVIV, April 2 (Reuters) Campaigning began today for local elections in the occupied West Bank, where candidates sympathetic to the Palestine Liberation Organization are expected to find wide support.

title: P.S.C. Examiner Urges 4.9% Rise In Lilco's Rates
description: A Public Service Commission examiner recommended yesterday that the Long Island Lighting Company be granted a permanent increase of 4.9 percent in its electric rates, less than a third of what the utility sought.

title: LISBON PROCLAIMS SOCIALIST CHARTER
description: LISBON, April 2Portugal's new Constitution, proclaiming socialism as the national goal, was approved today and officially made public, but its language appeared to be more revolutionary than the present mood of the country.

title: Dr. Peter Herbut, President Of Jefferson Medical School
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 2 (AP) Dr. Peter A. Herbut, president of Thomas Jefferson University, died yesterday at his home in suburban Rosemont. He was 63 years old.

title: P.S.C. Examiner Urges 4.9% Rise In Lilco's Rates
description: A Public Service Commission examiner recommended yesterday that the Long Island Lighting Company be granted a permanent increase of 4.9 percent in its electric rates, less than a third of what the utility sought.

title: Virility in Washington
description: The final days of the Nixon Administration were no picnic for the White House men in charge of the atom bomb. David Eisenhower was constantly phoning to make sure the President hadn't asked to have it sent up to the Lincoln bedroom, and Henry Kissinger was so worried that he had It secretly sent to Nelson Rockefeller's estate at Pocantico Hills for safekeeninm

title: Fashion Lesson: On the Court, Take It Easy
description: The tennis players are coming out of their bubbles. The outdoor season is beginning.

title: Changes Are Expected in the City's DayCare System
description: City daycare centers will be reimbursed on the basis of their actual daily attendance, rather than their capacity, and underutilized centers will be either closed or consolidated, according to top officials at the Agency for Child Development.

title: Vienna Philharmonic in Brief U.S. Tour
description: The Vienna Philharmonic played at Carnegie Hall for the first time in 10 years Thursday night at the beginning in a brief tour it is making n this country in honor of the Bicentennial.

title: LEBANESE FPI IN SPITE OF TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2A 10day truce officially took effect in Lebanon today, but fighting continued in the capital and the countryside and individual violence increased with a wave of 30 to 40 abductions, according to the state radio.

title: Argentine Recovery Plan Reverses Peronist Policies
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 2Minister of Economy Jose Martinez de Hoz announced tonight an economicrecovery program for Argentina based on a major expansion of agricultural production and the granting of contracts to foreign oil companies to develop petroleum resources.

title: Arson Call Is Cited In Fire Fatal to 5 In Worcester, Mass.
description: WORCESTER, Mass., April (AP)"I just lit a big one. You better hurry, an anonymous caller told fire officials early today as a blaze swept through an apartment house, killing five persons and sending five others to the hospital.

title: How Rally Audiences Size Up the Candidates
description: As the three major contenders in next Tuesday's Presidential primary in New York campaign around the state, the effect they have on the crowds they address is strikingly different.

title: McGovern Says That Saigon Is Freeing Two Americans
description: WASHINGTON. April 2 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Government is releasing two Americans who were detained when United States personnel were evacuated from Saigon early last year, Senator George McGovern said today.

title: CAREY ASKS STUDY ON JOBLESS PAY
description: ALBANY, April 2Governor Carey will oppose any plan this year to revamp the system of employer contributions to the state's nearly depleted unemployment insurance fund.

title: Dance: Hearts of Palm
description: Lamhut's zany new dance work, Hearts of Palm, is dedicated to James Waring, the choreographer who died at the end of last year, and pays tribute to the many,, nostalgia pieces that. Mr. WAring composed in his own. humorous way.

title: Food for Elderly Grant Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it would spend the full $87.5 million appropriated for nutrition programs for the elderly this year, as sought by an antihunger organization's lawsuit. The result of the decision will be to release another $37.5 million for nutrition programs during April, May and June, a spokesman said.

title: Fewer Shot's Fired By the Police in 75 Than in Prior Year
description: Fewer than 2 percent, of members of the city's police force fired their pistols in the line of duty last year as the number of gun incidents declined for the third consecutive year, according to a Police Department report.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 2 (UPI) A fugitive who killed three policemen in a bid to escape capture died today from a pistol shot he fired into his own head when he realized he was trapped, the police said.

title: Deals Confusing Sugar Markets
description: The world sugar trade, still groggy from the sharp rise and fall of prices the last 18 months, has been thrown into confusion by recent contracts for massive Philippine sugar sales to two big American refiners.

title: Larchmont Voters Keeping Calm
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 2I don't understand it, George Rosenthal, owner of Larchmont's Corner Store, said a few days ago. There just doesn't seem to be much interest in politics this year.

title: A Tower in Paris Guards Art Treasures
description: DARTS, April 2Unknown to most Parisians, a tower 240 feet high and 180 feet in diameter is hidden behind the facade of a former bank in one of the city's most exclusive neighborhoods. It can be seen only from the top of the Eiffel Tower, from which the public is usually barred.

title: EMPLOYMENT UP 375,000 IN MARCH, TO 86.7 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Employment in the United States posted a strong gain in March, rising by 375,000 to A record 86.7 million, the Labor Department reported today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOUBLE DUTY Which Marcel Marceau do you preferthe Oerforrning mime on stage or the man himself autographing his new book in a Fifth Avenue store? Energetic New Yorkers can liaVe both. Tonight at 8:40 the artist performs at Queens College's Colden Center (7938080), at Kispena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway in Flushing. Tickets are $4.50 to $6.50.

title: CORRECTION
description: Pictures of a group of women with a new hairdo called the Wedge were transposed in The New York Times yesterday. The correct identities in the lower panel of pictures, from left to right, are Carolyn Oliner, Ann Benedetto, Mary Earle, Pat Shea, Joan Weitzen and Joan Rubenstein.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices afriday. London: Morning fixing $129.25, UP $0.05; afternoon sluing $120.70, down WA.

title: Amtrak Passes to Go Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) Amtrak announced today that it would raise prices this summer on special rail passes that allow unlimited train travel, The new summer prices, effective May 16, permit North American residents to purchase 14 days of unlimited travel for $250, 21 days for $325 and 30 days for $400. Prices for tickets sold before May 16 are $150, $200 and $250.

title: Why 1976 Is Beginning To Look Like $19.76
description: Billie Jean King plans to buy herself a miniature Liberty Bell. Governor Carey is in the market for sonic appropriate Steuben glass.

title: ST ATE SEEKS HOMES FOR HARDTOADOPT
description: ALBANY, April 2The State Department of Social Services started a new adoption service this week to recruit adoptive familiet for 2000, hardtoplace children now waiting for homes.

title: Health Officers Query Need of Flu Shots for All
description: ATLANTA, April 2Public health officers from states and communities throughout the United States closely questioned Federal scientists and administrators today on the plan to vaccinate the nation against influenza this year.

title: City Flashing Signs of Rehabilitating Pinball Machines
description: The pinball machinean outlaw whose flashing, zinging fantasies have been confined to a few arcades around the city since Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia raised his sledgehammer against its evilswas rehabilitated yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Monday to Thursday

title: RULES FOR CABLE TV RELAXED BY F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission, which has been accused of stemming cable television's growth, announced decisions today that it said wouldj case some of the restrictions on the industry.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of State Superior Court in Trenton upheld the dismissal of a school superintendent. who was accused of misrepresenting his educational qualifications and misusing a business telephone. The ruling upheld a decision by the State Board of Education. The former superintendent, Michael A. Pitch, was dismissed by South Bound Brook for unbecoming conduct. He was accused of having told his school board that he had a master's degree and 30 graduatelevel credits for the purpose of determining his salary.

title: 3 Assaulted by Vandals At Old Lincoln Hospital
description: Two staff members of Lincoln Hospital were assault,ed and one was stabbed Thursday when they surprised a band of vandals and looters in the mostly vacated buildings of the old Bronx facility.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Books of The Times
description: If the New Deal could be epitomized solely in individuals. Frances Perkins would be among the very few who, in life, character, philosophy, purpose and accomplishment, personified Franklin D. Roosevelt's efforts to save the American system by restructuring its social and econoniic base. Miss Perkins's service as Secretary of Labor from 1933 until President Truman abruptly dismissed her in 1945 was longer than any other Secretary of Labor's before or since. And although among these Secretaries she towers as a giant over pygmies, this is the first biography of her.

title: ExChevrolet Dealer Aide Gets Jail for Cheating G.M.
description: LOWELL, Mass., April 2 (UPI) Judge Henry Chmielinski sentenced George O. Edgerly to three to five years In Walpole State Prison today.

title: Gas Building Up in Mine
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 2 (AP)Air samples from the southeastern Kentucky coal mine in which 26 men died In explosions March 9 and 11 indicate that explosive methane gas is building up in the sealed shaft and that a small fire is burning. The Federal Mining Enforcement and Safety Administration says a third explosion could occur, but that it would not be a threat to public safety. As a precaution, the area around the site, the Scotia Coal Company No. I Black Mountain Mine at Oven Fork, has been roped off.

title: Lockheed Given Subpoena By Senate Subcommittee
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) A subpoena demanding that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation turn over information on its alleged illegal payments in Japan to the Senate subcommittee on multinational companies was served on the company's president today, a Lockheed spokesman here reported.

title: A's Jackson to Orioles
description: MESA, Ariz., April 2 (UPI) Reggie Jackson and Ken Holtzman were traded last night by the Oakland A's to the Baltimore Orioles for Don Baylor, an outfielder, and Mike Torrez and Paul Mitchell nitr hers.

title: State Aide Gets Award For Routing a Mugger
description: TRENTON, April 2 (UPI) An investigator with the office of the Public Defender received the State Award for Heroism yesterday for rescuing an elderly mugging victim.

title: Rockefeller, Ending Tour, Warns of Soviet Threat
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Saturday, April 3 (AP)  Vice President Rockefeller ended an eightnation tour here today, warning of a worldwide Soviet threat.

title: Art: Betty Parsons 30th Year
description: When Betty Parsons first opened her gallery in New York, the year was 1946, the serious audience for new art would fit around a large boardroom table, and the new art itself was still unproven. Today, just 30 years later, she and her gallery are still very much with us and both the art and its audience have ballooned all over the town. But her pleasure in a new show by a new artist is as contagious as ever. She has never lolled back on her past reputationindeed, few people have ever lolled less, in any sensebut on this 30th anniversary she has allowed herself a small retrospective of her first 10 years in business.

title: Peril to Ozone Shield Doubted In Report by U.S. Study Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) A Federal interagency group concluded yesterday that six suggested hazards to the earth's ozone radiation shield appeared to be no immediate serious problem but required further study.

title: Town Houses Approved
description: TRENTON, Aprir 2 (UPI)The State Department of Environmental Protection today gave conditional approval for construction of an 84unit townhouse development along the coastal area of Brigantine. The permit was granted on the condition that additional specifications for water drainage and green space be presented.

title: Messersmith Says Owners Kept Offers Low
description: After a sevenhour hearing to a nodecision in Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office, Andy Messersmith suggested yesterday that the owners had conspired to hold their offers low.the Yankees changed the wording in preparing the formal contract.

description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., April 2Labor Secretary W. J. Usery Jr. announced tonight that two major trucking groups and 140,000 teamstersonethird of those affected by a strike two days agohitd reached agreement on a new contract.

title: Roger Riviere of France, ExCycling RecordHolder
description: ST. ETIENNE, France April 2 (AP) Roger Riviere, a former world cycling recordholder who became a drug addict, died yesterday at his home, following a recent operation for cancer of the larynx. He was 40 years old.

title: Two Jetliners Nearly Collide at Spokane
description: A jumbo jet airliner that had just taken off in murky weather and a smaller DC9 overtaking it after missing a landing approach came very close to colliding Thursday over the Spokane. Wash., airport.

title: A Tower in Paris Guards Art Treasures
description: PARIS, April 2Unknown to most Parisians, a tower 240 feet high and 180 feet in diameter is hidden behind the facade of a former bank in tone of the city's most exclusive neighborhoods. It can be seen only from the top of theEiffel ToweA from which the public is usually barred.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The Monmouth Community Action Program will begin a third project next week to help the needy, particularly the elderly, overcome obstacles to good nutrition.

title: UNIT OF MARATHON SEEKS PAN OCEAN
description: Marathon Energy Ltd., a subsidiary of the Marathon Oil Company, announced in Findlay, Ohio, yesterday that it was ready to acquire at $18 a share any and all shares of the Pan Ocean Oil Corporation, owner of vast reserves of oil, gas and minerals. Marathon's offer, if successful, would involve expenditures of $260 million. On Thursday, Marathon purchased 3,263,726 shares at $18 a share from three directors and certain other shareholders of Pan Ocean and $15 million principal amount of Pan Ocean notes convertible into 1.875,000 additional shares. If the notes are converted, Marathon will own 36.5 percent of the 12,205,780 outstanding shares.

title: Books of The Times
description: If the New Deal could be epitomized solely in individuals, Frances Perkins would be among the very few who, in life, character, philosophy, purpose and accomplishment, personified Franklin D. Roosevelt's efforts to save the American systent by restructuring its social and economic base. Miss Perlrins's service as Secretary of Labor from 1933 until President Truman abruptly dismissed her in 1945 was longer than any other Secretary of Labor's before or since. And although among these Secretaries she towers as a giant over pytmies, this is the first biography of her.

title: Shapp Assails Mellon Bank On Pennsylvania's Funds
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2 (UPI)  Pennsylvania's Public School Building Authority voted today to strip the Mellon Bank of its control over $300 million in board funds after Gov. Milton 3. Shapp accused the Pittsburgh bank of betraying its trust.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 3, 1976

title: David Blair of the Royal Ballet, DancerChoreographer, Is Dead
description: David Blair, one of Britain's foremost dancers and a wellknown choreographer for the American Ballet Theater, died Thursday in London at the age of 43.

title: CHARLES BOCKLET, 66, STOCKBROKER, DEAD
description: Charles J. Bocklet, a former member of the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange and vice chairman for three years, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after long illness. His age was 66. He lived at 240 DeMott Avenue, Rockville Centre, L. I., and in Naples, Fla.

title: SecondRanking Haitian Is Dismissed by Duvalier
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, Haiti, April 1 (AP)President JeanClaude Duvalier has ousted Paul Blanchet as Intcrior Minister and Defense Minister.

title: Blaze in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, April 2 (AP)A fire fanned by high winds damaged today most of the buildings in a fourblock commercial area near downtown St. Louis, the police said.

title: Common Market Leaders Admit Wide Divisions
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 2Thel nine Common Market leaders concluded their spring conference today acknowledging that their countries had drifted so far apart on key economic issues that they could no longer register even, limited agreements.

title: HOUSE REVIEW SET ON LEVI PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) A House panel plans to review Attorney General Edward H. Levi's proposal to notify only some of the victims of the Cointelpro campaign of the Federal Bureau Investigation.

title: Unstopped Trucks
description: Partial settlement of the nationwide truck strike through the peacemaking efforts of Labor Secretary Usery eases a grave threat to continued economic recovery. Even in its first two days the tieup had begun to spread a shroud of secondary unemployment over automobile plants and other industries just starting to Dull out of the worst slums. in four decades.

title: Interstate Power Issue
description: The Interstate Power Company said it had registered 1.2 million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering that is expected to be sold, in conipetitive bidding, on May 19.

title: Knicks Defeat Bulls, 110 to 95
description: CHICAGO, April 2 (AP)The Chicago Bulls lost their coin flip with the Atlanta Hawks for the first choice in the National Basketball Association draft this afternoon. and then celebrated by dropping their 55th game of the season to the New York Knicks, 11095, tonight.

title: Udall to Stay in Race
description: SUPERIOR, Wis., April 2kepresentative Morris K. Udall predicted today that he would win the Wisconsin Presidential primary next Tuesday, but was contemplating ways to, continue his campaign for the Democratic nomination even If he lost to Mr. Carter.

title: Armory Robbed of Guns
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 2 (AP)Armed robbers awoke a guard at the United States MarineNavy Reserve Armory early today, tied him up and escaped with 164 guns, along with ammunition. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said two machine guns, 146 rifles and 18 pistols, were taken.

title: Bulgarian Communists Name Zhivkov to Retain Leadership
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 2Todor Zhivkov, whose tenure as a Communist Party leader exceeds that of any of his Sovietbloc counterparts, was redesignated today as head of the Bulgarian Communist Party for Ifive more years.

title: Court Backs Nonsmoker On a SmokeFree Office
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 2The right of a New Jersey Bell Telephone Company employee to work in a room free of cigarette smoke was upheld in Superior Court here today pending a full hearing.

title: TskTsk Yourself, Readers Reply
description: On March 22, an article titled TskTsk by Lew Powell, a reporter for The Charlotte Observer in North Carolina, appeared on the OpEd page. In it, said that he had winced at reading yet another offhand putdown of Mississippi by yet another glib New Yorker and that his native state had quietly become a right decent place to live. Among other criticisms of New York, he said that New Yorkers tend to inflict a Gothamocentric view on the rest of us. His article drew a number of replies, some of which appear below.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Maritime Fruit Carriers Company said yesterday that two of its ships that had been seized because overdue payments on mortgages held by the Danish Ship Fund, had been freed and had sailed from Hamburg, West Germany, and Rouen, France, where they had been held. The company said that the ship fund had agreed to debtservice. moratorium until Aug. 31 on the mortgages of the two freed vessels, the GladioIo and Orehidia, and two other of its ships, the Irsi Queen and Chrysanthema. It was agreed that there would be no further impounding of Maritime's vessels during that time.

title: The Screen: 'Lipstick':Glamorous Film About Raped Model Arrives
description: "Lipstick" is what might be described as a glamour film about rape. Its victim is a beautiful, hugely successful photographers' model, played by Margaux Hemingway, in real life a beautiful, hugely successful photographers' model who also happens to be Ernest's granddaughter.The rapist (Chris Sarandon) is a young man who composes avant-garde music and worships the works of another avant-garde composer, identified in the film as Sean Gage. Sean Gage? I'm sure that's what he says, though why "Lipstick" hesitates to drop the name of John Cage, I've no idea.It's certainly not because "Lipstick" is too discreet. It is, however, anti-intellectual in the ways that B movies always have been. The message of "Lipstick," if I read it right, is less about the physical and legal vulnerability of women than about the sexual hang-ups of eccentric young men who compose music with synthesizers and laser beams. The movie's subliminal message: Bring back the clavichord."Lipstick," which opened yesterday at the Loews State 2 and Loews Cine Theaters, was written by David Rayfiel and directed by Lamont Johnson ("The Groundstar Conspiracy," "The Last American Hero"), a shrewd, knowledgeable but not very interesting director, who is touted for his fearless way with controversial subjects. "Lipstick" is occasionally violent and crude, and about as controversial as the March of Dimes.The film appears to take rape seriously, though  the kind of rape in which the victim, who hasn't been permanently injured, must overcome the prejudices of a society that always suspects that such a rape victim got what she asked for. The only time "Lipstick" is believable is during the trial sequence when Anne Bancroft, appearing as the ferociously determined lawyer for the victim, presents the case not only for Miss Hemingway, but also for all women. It's almost like a training film, but it is effective.For a little while, anyway. "Lipstick's" heart belongs to an earlier, simpler time. It's no accident, I think, that the heroine is presented as a good Roman Catholic with a priest for a brother. We thus know she is a good girl. Neither is it an accident that the rapist is a composer of what the movie clearly believes to be crackpot music, and that the climactic sequencea second, even more vicious rape  occurs in a modern glass and steel building that, in a film like this, could be the architectural equivalent to "Sean Gage" music.Mr. Johnson treats Miss Hemingway very gingerly. She's not much of an actress yet, and there are times he seems to be protecting her by cutting away to other actors, when one would expect the camera to stay on her. Mr. Sarandon, who won an Oscar nomination for his small but effective role in "Dog Day Afternoon," does as well as can be expected with the role of the rapist.The revelation of "Lipstick" is another Hemingway, first name Mariel, Margaux's 14-year-old sister, who plays her sister in the film. As the chief witness to the events within the movie, and its ultimate victim, she gives an immensely moving, utterly unaffected performance that shows up everything else as a calculated swindle.

title: Kissinger Said to Rule Out A Visit to South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (Reuters)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has decided against visiting South Africa during Ms tour of black Africa later this month, United States officials said today.

title: Fabrication Is Charged
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2President Ford declared here today that Ronald Reagan's criticism of his defense policy was built on misleading statements and embellished by quotations attributed to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger that were a fabrication, an invention.

title: Laura Gurdus Bride in Israel
description: Laura Hope Gurdus, a solo ballerina with the Israel Classical Ballet Company, and Alan Steven Dolid, principal oboist of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, were married Thursday in Tel Aviv.

title: NEW TRANSIT PACT FACES CHALLENGE BY CONTROL BOARD
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board is likely to demand some modifications in the new transit contract because of its implications for other city unions, according to labor experts close to the recent talks.

title: Criticism Called Unjust
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2Ronald Reagan defended today his use of unverified quotations attributed to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and said that President Ford's criticism of their use was unjustified.

title: Dow Drops by 2.52 Points; Decline Is Fourth in Week
description: The stock market registered its fourth declining session of the week yesterday as concern over the nationwide teamsters strike and its possible harm to the economic recovery raised caution signals on Wall Street.

title: Boy, 15, Is Accused of Killing Chinatown Diner
description: A 155yearold youth who emigrated to the city from Hong Kong five years ago was arraigned in Family Court yesterday on charges of killing a woman and Smounding five other customers and a waiter in the CoLuck Restaurant in Chinatown Wednesday night.

title: Grain Inspection Reform Is Favored in House Vote
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The House of Representatives passed by a wide margin today a bill to reform the nation's scandalridden graininspection system. The vote was 246 to 33.

title: TRAPEZOID QUARTET PLAYS DULCIMERS
description: The four members of Trapezoid believe they make up the lonly dulcimer quarten the world. These four instrument makersSam Rizzotta and Pete Vigour from Virginia and Paul Reisler and Paul Yeaton from West Virginiahad to design and build their own instruments, ranging from soprano dulcetta or piccolo dulcimer, to a bass dulcimer, to have the family of instru ments necessary to fill out an ensemble.

title: Jury Rules Kapp Not Entitled to Damages
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 The National Football League scored a major legal and financial victory today when a Federal District Court jury found that Joe Kapp was not entitled to any damages in his antitrust suit against the league. He had asked for between $8,250,000 and $11,788,000, which, if tripled under an antitrust finding, could have come to $35,364,000.

title: INCREASE SLOWS IN PROBLEM BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The increase in the number of socalled problem banks has slowed markedly in recent weeks and may be approaching its peak, data compiled by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation indicated today.

title: 120 Israelis in the West Bank Dig in to Hold New Settlement
description: CAMP KADUM, IsraeliOccupled West Bank, April 2Viewed from the road a few hundred yards away, Kadum looks likea typical Israeli Army camp. Once inside the gate, however, the incongruities emerge: children playing tag among the jeeps, young mothers pushing baby carriages, women in jeans setting tables in a communal dining hall.

title: BROWN AHEAD OF 3 IN A GALLUP POLL
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who has yet to make a single speech or campaign trip in support of his nativeson Presidential candidacy, already has a larger national following than three rivals who have been campaigning for more than a year, according to a newly released Gallup Poll.

title: Indian State Defers Action On Forced Sterilization Bill
description: NEW DELHI, April 2 (AP)Final action on a compulsory sterilization bill providing jail sentences for unsterilized couples with three or more children has been deferred by the Maharashtra state assembly for at least three months.

title: 2 Women Share Lead
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 2 (AP)Pam Higgins posted a fourunderpar 68, and Jan Stephenson carded a 71 today to tie for the secondround lead in the $200,000 ColgateDinah Shore Winners Circle open with scores of 140.

title: Scholars Cultivate New Ideas on Piers the Plowman
description: It hardly, took the three days of conference to realize that those who would understand Piers the Plowman have a tough row to hoe.

title: Meera Agarwal Wed at Harvard
description: Meera Eleanore Agarwal, a candidate for an M.F.A. degree at Boston University, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday afternoon to Loran Tyson Thompson, a member of the class of 76 at the Harvard University Law School. The Rev. Ralph HeIverson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the Appleton Chapel at Harvard.

title: Limon's Malinche Tells Bit of History In Lilting Rhythms
description: While he was ordinarily drawn to subjects reflecting the more serious side of life, the late Jose Limon did turn to lighter subjects. One of his most perfectly realized daiices, La Malinche, tells a bit of Mexiican history in vivid cplyrs and Jilting rhythms. The Jose Limon Company presented the work Thursday evening at the Kauf mann Concert Hall.

title: DOUBT EXPRESSED ON CITY FINANCES
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Elmer B. Staats, Comptroller General of the United States, told Congress today that he was concerned about whether the current financial plan for New York is a realistic one.

title: Kapp Loses Case; A's Trade Jackson
description: Joe Kapp, former quarterback, lost his multimilliondollar antitrust suit against the National Football League last night. Kapp contended he was forced out of professional football because he had refused to sign a standard player contract. A Federald District Court jury in San Francisco decided Kapp had not suffered damages and should get no money.

title: Music: Philharmonic
description: Leonard Bernstein paid his respects to American music in this Bicentennial year in a threebythree program with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night: Roy Harris's Symphony No. 3, David Diamond's Violin Concerto No, 3 and Aaron Copland's Symplmny No. 3.

title: Nursing Home Owner Convicted in Extortion
description: BUFFALO, April 2 (UPI)A Buffalo nursing home operator was convicted on six counts of grand larceny by extortion, the office of the Special Attorney General, Charles J. Hynes, an nounced today.

title: Speedboat Ambulance Will Aid Boatmen on the Sound
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 2 A fouryearold highspeed patrol boat similar to those used by the United States Navy in Vietnam was launched here today as a floating ambulance.

title: Jackson Seen Aiming at Big State Victory
description: ALBANY, April 2Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington in the last few days has shifted the emphasis of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination in next Tuesday's New York primary.

title: Stock Commissions Continued to Drop In Last Third of 75
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 I Commissions on securities transactions tumbled further during the last four months of 1975 and deprived Wall Street of $107.1 million of revenues it would have had if negotiated rates had not been in effect, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission report published today.

title: ExHoffa Aide Sentenced
description: MIAMI, April 2 (AP)Nicholas J. Tweel, a former associate of James R. Hoffa, the missing labor leader, has been sentenced to threeyear terms and two threeyear terms, in prison for trying to evade more than $243,000 in Federal income taxes. Mr. Tweel, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Huntington, W. Va., was also ordered by United States District Judge Joe Eaton to pay a $30.000 fine.

title: Armory Robbed of Guns
description: KNOXVILLE, Term., April 2 (AP)Armed robbers awoke a guard at the United States MarineNavy Reserve Armory early today, tied him up and escaped with 164 guns, along with ammunition. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said two machine guns, 146 rifles and 18 pistols, were taken.

title: Ultraviolet Peril Indicated
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 (UPI)  Experiments with mice suggest that the ultraviolet part of sunlight might suppress body defenses against canceran idea that could have implications in assessing the impact of manmade atmospheric changes.

title: Electronic Alarm Watch Devised
description: WASHINGTON, April 2According to its developers, an electronic alarm wrist watch that was patented this week can be set to remind its wearer of various forthcoming events, including a series of conferences to be held today or a wedding anniversary six months off. Patent 3,946,549 was granted to Arthur F. Cake and assigned to Uranus Electronics Inc., Port Chester, N.Y., of which he is vice president for engineering. The watch is in the early stages of manufacture and the company plans to have it on the market next fall.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN LITTLE CHANGED
description: Grain and soybean prices showed little change in quiet trading yesterday, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Market Place
description: Some Wall Street observers are wondering whether the excellent reception accorded the million share offering of HyGain Electronics Corporation stock at $19.25 each on Wednesday is a harbinger of a new speculative era.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Metropolitan Region:

title: In Memoriam
description: FARRINGTONRlchard. Happy Birthday In Heaven father.

title: Spurrier, Hadl, Dickey Traded
description: Pro football's embargo on trades was lifted after five months yesterday and bodies moved around the National FootballLeague. Two important, quarterback transactions headed the list while of equal importance was a talkedabout third deal that failed to come off.

title: Issues 76: Race
description: The issue of race is muted but real, at the periphery of political consciousness in 1976. It does not appear central, as it did in 1964 when Lyndon JohnsOn was promising to bring to fruition what Lincoln had begun; nor does it even have the subliminal, codeword force that made George C. Wallace such a formidable candidate during the spring of 1972. Nevertheless, it remains a major problem, which is bound to affect America's future, even though the candidates have been inclined to treat it more as a tactical peril somewhat like rocks in the river for whitewater paddlers.

title: Events on Food Day Theme
description: Political scientists should turn their attention to food issues, because they give us a clearcut example of our Government's failure to live up to its responsibility to the public, said Dr. Michael F. Jacobson, the microbiologist who is codirector of the Center for Science in the Public Interest.

title: Criticism Called Unjust
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2Ronald Reagan defended today his use of unverified quotations attributed to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and said that President Ford's criticism of their use was uniustified.

title: SCHOLAR DEFENDS DIVERSE JUDAISM
description: WASHINGTON, April 2A noted religious thinker and biblical scholar criticized today that school of thought that would seek an end for diversity in Jewish life by merging the various branches of Judaism into a single religious philosophy.

title: Nixon SonsinLaw Accuse 2 Authors
description: David Eisenhower and Edward F. Cox, the sonsinlaw of former President Richard M. Nixon, yesterday denied having held views or made statements attributed to them in The Final Days, a newly published account of Mr. Nixon's departure from the White House.

title: NBC and Broadcast Union Set Strike Talks in Capital
description: Negotiations between the National Broadcasting Company and the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians have been set for next Thursday at 11:30 AM. at the Federal Mediation Bureau in Washington.
