title: Election Drinking Ban Ends
description: HONOLULU, April 2 (UPI)It is now legal to buy a drink on Election Day during voting hours in Hawaii. A bill to repeal the nodrinking law was signed yesterday by Gov. George Ariyoshi.

title: Henry M. Noe, 66, Lawyer And Noted Amateur Golfer
description: Henry M. Noe, a paitner in the law firm of Hays, Landsman & Head since 1960 and earlier with Breed, Abbott & Morgan, died of cancer Thursday at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 66 years old and lived in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Argentina Reverses Economic Policies Set by Peronisis
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 3Minister of Economy Jose Martinez de HDZ announced tonight an economicrecovery program for Argentina based on a major expansion of agricultural production and the granting of contracts to foreign oil companies to develop petroleum resources.

title: Brown on Foreign Policy
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 2 (UPI)Governor Brown said today that if he became President he would reshape American foreign policy to break the rigid mold of the last two Idecades. At a meeting of the California Conference of Ma chinists, he said the United States should reexamine its policy from Korea to Rhodesia and from Angola to Brazil. He added that he believed in a strong defense, a strong economy and a sense af patriotism in our country arid a sense of twhere we are going.

title: New Saudi Arabian King Speeding Modernization
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 31  King Khalid of Saudi Arabia fell regally silent, the story goes, when aides once grew too inststent in urging a policy followed by his half brother and predecessor, King Faisal.

title: Metropolitan Briefs City to Pool Funds to Earn Interest
description: Scores of cityagency bank accounts earning no interest will be consolidated to end the loss of potential earnings, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said. Most city money is pooled in an interestbearing account, but some agencies were permitted separate accounts to meet unusual circumstances..For instance, the Department of Health, for receipt of fees; had an average monthly balance in a separate account of $102,748, which earns no interest. M. Goldin put the loss of interest on accounts of three city agencies reviewed at $1'00,000 a year.

title: NEW TALKS SET IN COAST STRIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO. April 2 (UPI)Former Mayor George Christopher was named tonight a public representative in hegotiations aimed at ending a strike by city employees that has shut down the municipal railway and curtailed some services for three days.

title: Albany Budget Aide Retires After 34 Years in Agency
description: Albany, April 2Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the State Budget Director, today announced the retirement of John J. Corrigan, the deputy budget director, who joined the Division of the Budget 34 years ago.

title: Oil Crisis and Redession Have Slowed Rotterdam Port Expansion
description: ROTTERDAM  In the 1960's, the city of Rotterdam, which is noted for its Texanlike love of bigness and its farsightedness, began developing the mudflats area at the harbor entrance into a deepwater terminal for the giant oil, ore and freight carriers that were expected to dominate world trade by the ate 1970's. A threemilesquare manmade peninsula rose on the area.

title: Carter Presses Legal Fight for Delegates
description: Jimmy Carter's last words to New York voters yesterday were, Vote for me, and then, in an afterthought, Where my name is on the ballot, vote for me.

title: Alaska Pipeline Construction. Hampered by Welding Problem
description: ANCHORAGE, April 2Builders of the transAlaska oil pipeline, who discovered alleged falsified Xrays of welding work on the southern half of the 800mile project last summer, are now questioning 2,300 Xray pictures of welds on the northern part of the project.

title: Bridge:
description: There are times when a little extra thought before makitig the opening lead will reveal that the orthodox choice llas some disadvantage in the special circumstances that obtain.

title: U.S. Warns Carey It May Challenge New Medicaid Law
description: ALBANY, April 2The Federal Government praised Governor Carey this week for the moneysaving Medicaid reforms he signed into law Tuesday, but warned that some of them continue to violate Federal regulations in a way that might cause them to be overturned in court.

title: NEV TRANSIT PACT FACES CHALLENGE BY CONTROL BOARD
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board is likely to demand some modifications in the new transit contract because of its implications for other city unions, according to labor experts close to the recent talks.

title: A.C.L.U. Charges Systematic Cheating By Growers on Pay of Migrant Workers
description: GLASSBORO, April 2The American Civil Liberties Union said today that food and vegetable growers in the state were systematically cheating Puerto Rican migrant farm workers out of tens of thousands of dollars in wages every sununer.

title: JEROME SOLOMON
description: Jerome Solomon, president of the Biotic Drug Company of New York and the Minimac Company of Chicago as well as a vice president of Marcel Paper Mills here, died Thursday in Memorial. He was 63 years old and lived at 7020 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Carlo Cardinal Grano Is Dead; Veteran of Vatican Diplomacy
description: ROME, April 2 (UPI)Carlo Cardinal Grano, a veteran Vatican diplomat and a former chief of ceremony, died today at his home. He was 88 years old.

title: Opera: 2 FideHo Debuts
description: Rose Wagemann, who made her Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as Leonore in FideHo". had every qualification except one: Her voice did not have the quality or the control one expects to hear in a major opera house.

title: Playboy Sells Its DC9
description: CHICAGO, April 2 (Reuters) Big Bunny, Hugh Hefner's black jet arliner, has been sold for $4 million in cash, Playboy Enterprises announced today. it bought the DC9 in 1969. The company said it would make a modest profit on the to a Washington aircraft ??mpan.

title: Soviet Bomb Scares
description: The third bombscare evacuation in a week of American diplomatic offices in the Soviet Union, combined with threats of violence by scores of anonymous nighttime telephone calls, illustrates one reason why a reassessment of dtente is under way in the United States.

title: Opera: Passion of Shaw
description: The centerpiece of Thursday evening's Composers Ensemble program at Carnegie Recital Hall was the first performance of Bruce J. Taub's oneact opera, Passion, Poison, and Petrification or the Fatal Gozogene (197475).

title: Jersey Budget Cuts Jeopardize 2 Laws Against RacialBias
description: TRENTON, April 2Promulgated during the civil rights drive of the last decade, two of the state's toughest laws against racial discrimination in housing and employment that have rarely been enforced in the past are in jeopardy under budget cuts proposed by Governor Byrne.

title: Goldin Sees Substantial Help For City in Carter's Program
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that Jimmy Carter's proposals for Federal fiscal aid to the cities would mean very substantial yelp to this city as well as to all other cities.

title: MORTON WILL SEEK A WIDER CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Rogers C. B. Morton officially assumed command of President Ford's campaign committee today and said that he would ask the President to do more campaigning around the country than he has been doing up to now.

title: West German Unemployment Drops as Recovery Continues
description: BONN, April 2The West German economy continued to show signs of recovery today, with an announcement of sizable drop in unemployment in March to 1.19 million, or 5.2 Percent of the labor force.

title: Ruby Miller Dead; Star Gaiety Girl Of Edwardian Era
description: CHICHESTER, England, April 2 (AP)  Ruby. Miller, former music hall star, dancing partner of King Edward VII and coast of the stagedoor punnies, died in a nursing home here Friday. She was 86 years old.

title: Carey Is Warned by U.S. On Test of Medicaid Law
description: ALBANY, April 2  The Federal Government praised Governor Carey this week for the moneysaving Medicaid reforms he signed into law Tuesday, but warned that some of them continue to violate Federal regulations in a way that might cause them to be overturned in court.

title: NARCOTICS DEALER IS SHOT TO DEATH
description: A man, described by the police as a major dealer in illegal narcotics, was found shot to death yesterday in a car parked across the street from the office of Mario Merola, the Bronx District. Attorney.

title: Lockheed's Japanese Data Asked in Senate Subpoena
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) A subpoena demanding that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation turn over information on its, alleged illegal payments in Japan to the Senate multinational subcommittee by next Monday was served on the company's president today, Lockheed spokesmen here reported.

title: Italy in a Political Crisis Over Abortion
description: ROME, April 2A new political crisis over the issue of abortion has erupted here, threatening early general elections this year.

title: Art: Lennart Anderson Recalls Another Era
description: The painter who nowadays aspires to compete with the Old Mastersto partake of their range of expression by representing complex visual subjects and rendering them with. immense technical refinement while sustaining something of their basic human appealwould seem to be asking for nothing but trouble. The brightest critical opinion insists that painting now has narrower and more specialized functions to perform, and museums bulge with the paintings to prove it. The really serious and accomplished representational painter, though no longer as completely shut out as in the recent past, remains an outsider to the world of big" "reputations. He remains under suspicion of being a reactionary, and so is denied the kind of wholehearted acceptance readily granted not only to abstraction; but also to something like photorealist painting which,lhough egregiously representational, does not so much compete with the Old Masters as mock them

title: CHARLES MARKS, EXJUSTICE, DIES
description: Charles Marks, a former State Supreme Court justice, who presided at the Malcolm X murder trial in the 1960's, died of a heart attack Thursday in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 82 years old and lived in Miami Beach and formerly had lived in New York.

title: Waste Paper Shortage
description: A shortage of waste paper particularly used corrugated cartons, is becoming more serious across the country, the American Paper Institute said yesterday. Recycling mills are having great difficulty getting adequate supplies to meet the growing demand for paper board, it added.

title: Hourly Employees
description: Following is a breakdown of the hourly employees of the Transit Authority and the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority on each Jan. 1 since 1965:

title: 18 Czechs Reported Held In Drive on Pop Culture
description: PRAGUE, April 2 (Reuters)At least 18 persons have been arrested in the last two weeks in what appears to be a largescale campaign against unorthodox artists and pop music groups in Czechoslovakia, dissident sources said today.

title: Moon Over the Alley at Modern Museum
description: If the artistic vision of Moon Over the Alley were as sharply focused as its camera, this British film, playing today at 6 P.M. and Monday at 8:30 P.M. in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, might merit some outright praise rather than the benign nod of acknowledgement that seems its proper due.

title: Book on Nixon's Last Months in Office Challenged on Methods and Accuracy
description: The Final Days, the new book by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein about President Nixon's last eight months in the White House, is generating questions from journalists and historians about its methods of reporting history, denials from some of those named in the book about actions or remarks attributed to them and a spirited defense from the authors.

title: Harris: An Endangered Tweed
description: STORNOWAY, ScotlandMurdo Murray is a crofter, a small tenant farmer of a sort that has changed little In hundreds of years in Scotland. He raises turnips and potatoes on the barely arable nine acres of his two crofts and keeps blackface sheep on a common grazing ground.

title: House, 246 to 33, Endorses Reforms In Grain Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The House of Representatives passed by a wide margin today a bill to reform the nation's scandalridden graininspection system. The vote was 246 to 33.

title: Transit Aides Sure Raises Can Be Paid From Savings
description: Officials of the Transit Authority expressed confidence yesterday that they would be able to meet the added expense of their new labor contract through improved productivity and efficiency of operation.

title: LIDDY TELLS COURT JAILERS HARASS HIM
description: NEW HAVEN, April 2 (AP) G. Gordort Liddy, convicted Watergate conspirator, says Federal prison officials have harassed him because he has filed a suit attempting to broaden the mail rights of prisoners.

title: Nippon Steel Prices Up
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation reported yesterday in Tokyo that it had raised prices on sheet pile by 6.6 percent and by 6.25 percent on pipe pile, as of last Thursday. Other major Japanese steelmakers were expected to follow this action.

title: HOUSE UNIT BEGINS C.I.A.DATA INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Investigators for the House ethics committee informally interviewed today several members of the House Select Committee on Intelligence in an effort to find out what they might know about the unauthorized disclosure of the panel's report on activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Governor Urges Congress to Provide Alternative to Nursing Homes for Aged
description: TRENTON, April 2More than a score of witnesses, led by Governor Byrne, told a special Congressional committee that a drastic overhaul of Federal Medicare laws and regulations was needed if adequate care was to be provided to the elderly.

title: Yesterday's Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Inquiry Finds frayed Cable Caused Fatal Ski Accident
description: VAIL Colo., April 2 (UPI)A preliminary investigation, monitored closely by the Secret Service, has determined that frayed cable was responsible for derailing two gondola cars and killing four persons at the ski resort where President Ford snends his winter vacations.

title: CHARTER CHANGES PRESSED BY I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON April 2The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had sent to its member governments for approval a sweeping package of amendments to the Fund's basic charter.

title: To Save the Mails
description: Senator Gale McGee of Wyoming, chairman of the Senate Post Office Committee, would more than double the Government's subsidy to the Postal Service in an effort to prevent further erosion in the quality of its performance. His view is supported by Representative James M. Hanley. of New York, his opposite number in the House.

title: A.T.&T. Gets Extension
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to allow new leased private telephone rates to go into effect on 30 days notice by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, instead of seven days. The F.C.C. had set the sevenday notice when it ruled on Jan. 22 that the rates in effect then were discriminatory and unjustified. A.T. & T. is due to file the new rates next week. There are 19,000 private line customers, largely newswire services and government agencies.

title: Miss Goolagong, Chris Evert Gain
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 2The seedings have worked out perfectly, if not smoothly. Evonne Goolagong has all but floated into tomorrow's final of this Virginia Slims tennis tournament. Chris Evert, on the other hand, has crawled in.

title: INDIA NEWS AGENCIES COMPLETE MERGER
description: NEW DELHI, April 2 (AP)India's four domestic news services merged today into a Isingle national agency as part of a governmentsupported restructuring of the Indian press.

title: EMPLOYMENT UP 375,000 IN MARCH, TO 86.7 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Employment in the United States posted a strong gain in March, rising by 375,000 to a record 86.7 million, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Notes on People
description: Columbia University and its law school are in the midst of awarding some of their most distinguished honors. Today Milton Handler and Richard R. B. Powell, two law alumni and emeritus professors who between them taught for 83 years, will receive the Medal of Excellence at the law schooYs alumni luncheon at Low Memorial Library. The luncheon is part of this year's Columbia LaW Symposium, with such participants as Telford Taylor, who will moderate a panel on The Crisis in Intelligence Gathering"; Daniel Coburn, the courtappointed guardian of Karen Ann Quinlan, and City Comptroller Harrison Goldin. Professor Handler, an antitrust specialist, retired in 1972 after teaching 45 years the longest of any professor in the school's 118year history. Professor Powell, an authority on property law, taught for 38 years.

title: Shots Hit Soviet Mission; U.S. Calls Act an Outrage
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2Shots were fired into the Soviet Union's Mission to the United Nations during the night and an underground group called the Jewish Armed Resistance claimed responsibility later today.

title: DOUBT EXPRESSED ON CITY FINANCES
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Elmer B. Staats, Comptroller General of the United States, told Congress today that he was concerned about whether the current financial plan for New York is a realistic one.

title: Frigate Rammed Off Iceland
description: LONDON, April 2 (UPI)An Icelandic gunboat has rammed a British frigate three times in the latest round of a fishing dispute, the British Defense Ministry said today. The frigate was guarding British trawlers in disputed cod fishing waters off eastern Iceland when the ramming occurred. Damage to both ships was slight, a spokesman said.

title: Market Chiefs Honor A Unification Pioneer
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 2 Jean Monnet, the Frenchman whose ideas and persistence earned him the title of Mr. Europe when he helped create the Common Market in the 1950's, was rewarded today by being made an Honorary Citizen of Europe.

title: NORMA GREENSTEIN
description: Norma Greenstein, since 1963 associate program director at radio station WEVD, 1700 Broadway, died Thursday In New fork Hospital after a long illness. Miss Greenstein, who lived at. 315 East 72d Street, was 52 years old.

title: New Saudi Arabian King Speeding Modernization
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 31  King Khalid of Saudi Arabia fell regally silent, the story goes, when aides once grew too insistent in urging a policy followed by his half brother and predecessor, King Faisal.

title: Wisconsin: Milk, Beer, Paradox
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2Mention Wisconsin and people almost automatically think of a land of milk and beer.

title: Warner Bros. Will Modify FilmRental Agreements
description: Warner Bros. Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to modify its filmrental licens ing agreements in response to an antitrust investigation by the Justice Department. The company said it would consent to an order ending film rental that are based on both a per capita royalty and 100 percent of the gross box office receipts.

title: Fabrication Is Charged
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2President Ford declared here today that Ronald Reagan's criticism nf his defense policy was built nil misleading statements and embellished by quotations attributed to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger that were a fabrication, an invention.

title: Stockton Defeats Ashe
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 2 (AP)Dick .SiciCkton upset topseeded Arthur Ashe, 63, 62, today in the final of a tennis tournament that began in Lagos, Nigeria, last February.

title: Neighborhoods: Sylvan Queens Starts to Put Locks on Property
description: On what not so long tlgo were truck gardens, golf courses, marshes and woods, some. residents of Queens dwell in surroundings that are still pleasantly suburban.

title: I.R.S. HEAD QUIZZED BY U.S. GRAND JURY
description: MIAMI, April 2 (AP)  A Federal grand jury that reportedly is investigating three operations of the Internal Revenue Service resumed its work today after questioning Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, for more than six hours yesterday.

title: Philippines Borrowing
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) The I.M.F. said today it had made two loans to the Philippines totaling about $338 million.

title: State Employees Ratify 2Year Pact
description: The state's largest union of public employees, the Civil Service Employees Association, has approved a twoyear contract with tightened provisions for job security, but no firstyear increase in wages.

title: Portuguese Fish Canneries Are in Trouble
description: OLHAO, PortugalA siren wails to announce the arrival of a small trawler with its hold brimful of glistening sardines. The catch is good but almost everyone in the industry, from the fishermen and boat owners to canning factory owners and workers, talks about the crisis.

title: Japanese ExPremier Deplores LockheedCase Rumors
description: TOKYO, April 2 Formerl Prime Minister. Kakuei Tanaka broke a twomonth silence today to deplore what he called the speculation and irresponsible remarks that have linked him to the Lockheed scandal here.

title: CORRECTION
description: Pictures of a group of women with a new hairdo called the Wedge were transposed in The New York Times yesterday. The correct Identities in the lower panel of pictures, from left to right, are Carolyn Oliner, Ann Berle. detto, Mary Earle, Pat Shea, Joan Weitzen and Joan Rubengtein.

title: Bibi Andersson Says Swedish Police Harassed Her, Too, on Tax Matters
description: The time has come, Bibi Andersson said, for Sweden to be told that it was she who was taken into custody early in February, held for 36 hours of questioning about a sixyearold tax return, refused access to her lawyer, denied permission to speak to her 5yearold daughter and told she might face a year in prison.

title: Hungarian Posts World Swim Mark
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 2 (AP)Zoltan Verraszto, a muscular Hungarian, slashed almost 3 seconds off the world record in the 400meter individual medley tonight at the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming championship. He did it two lanes away from countryman who held the previous mark.

title: Pound Off to $1.87 for 2Day Drop of 5c
description: PARIS, April 2The British pound continued to topple in Europe's currency markets today, falling to $1.87 from $1.8840 yesterday and bringing the decline of the last two days to nearly 5.cents.

title: City Flashing Signs of Rehabilitating Pinball Machines
description: The pinball machinean outlaw whose flashing, zinging fantasies have been confined to a few arcades around the city since Mayor. Fiorello Ff. La Guardia raised his sledgehammer against its evilswas rehabilitated yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: BILL TO SAFEGUARD PRIVACY ADVANCES
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) A bill to protect Americans against invasions of privacy by the Government was approved today by a House Judiciary subcommittee.

title: Soviet Expert on U.S. Lays Chill to Politicking
description: MOSCOW, April 2 (AP)A Soviet specialist on United States affairs today attributed a chill in relations between Washington and Moscow to electionyear campaign talk and to the United States militaryindustrial complex.

title: C130 Sale to Egypt Near Approval
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was virtually assured of Congressional approval for the sale of six C130 military transport planes to Egypt after he told a Senate committee today that no further military sales to Egypt beyond prior commitments would be made this year. The prior commit ments involve some communications equipment previously approved by Congress.

title: Peanut Bowl A Bar Peril?
description: The free lunch long ago went the way of the nickel cigar. But free peanuts have survived as the inalienable right of the genus barfly. Indeed, for many serious toper, they may well comprise his principal solid food.

title: WALLACE TRIMS WISCONSIN DRIVE
description: MILWAUKEE, April 2Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is doing little more than mechanically going through the motions of campaigning for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Arol, Denying Fraud, Says It Helped City
description: The Arol Development Corporation declared yesterday that there was no evidence of fraud In its leasing of the Bronx Terminal Market, but considerable evidence of municipal ineptitude.

title: Antiques: Tarot Cards Reflect Changing Art Styles
description: GREENWICH, Conn.The hundreds of symbolsplashed tarot cards exhibited here have been tools used by gypsies over the centuries to tell fortunes.

title: Brazilian Censorship in Question After 21 Agents Fail Fitness Test
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 2 Last Sunday night, a televised performance of the Bolshoi Ballet, which was beamed to III countries, was not allowed to be shown in Brazil, presumably because it presented. a favorable aspect of the Soviet Union.

title: The Clam Broth House Bars Boys in the Band
description: HOBOKEN, April 2 (UPI)Boys in the Band, a play about homosexuals, has been banned at the Clam Broth House here, Arthur Pilez, owner of the restaurant, canceled next Sunday's dinnertheater performance when he learned the 1967 play dealt with the problems of a group of homosexual men.

title: AMEX ENDS MIXED; OTC SHOWS GAINS
description: Despite favorable economic news, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished with minor changes.

title: Derby Hopefuls Prance Into Spotlight Today
description: A horse working out at Belmont Park's training track yesterday morning stumbled and threw his exercise boy in front of Elmendorf's Play the Red. The Elmendorf colt was engaging in a gallop in preparation for this afternoon's $50, 000 Gotham Mile at Aqueduct. It seemed, for a moment, as if the 3yearold son of Crimson Satan might go down.

title: 3 April Primaries Appear Pivotal to Convention Vote
description: The schedule of Presidential primaries for this month is comparatively light. Only Wisconsin, New York and Pennsylvania will vote, as against five states in March and 15 in May.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Intermittait shelling and sniping in Beirut yesterday marked the second day of the armed truce in the Lebanese civil war. Gunmen pillaged and killed while Beirut's airport was jammed with people who took advantage of the truce to flee the country. There was no apparent progress in the search for a new president to be elected by Parliament during the truce period. President Suleiman Franjieh reportedly declared from his refuge in the town of Juniye that his resignation will not be a simple matter. L. Dean Brown, a Middle East specialist, and the special envoy of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, has been making the rounds of Lebanon's political leaders and appears to be confining himself to gathering information. His mission is regarded as being complementary to Syria's mediation efforts in the civil war. [Page 1, Column 7.]

title: Play: Back on Broadway
description: The surprise hit of the Broadway season has been Ellis Rabb's staging of The Royal Family, that old George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber comedy about a family of hysterically histrionic thespians that at times looks quite surprisingly like the Barrymores.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The New York State Attorney General's office has charged a bank with willfully failing to comply with full disclosure laws and exceeding its role as a lender for a condominium development in Queens on which the bank has started foreclosure proceedings.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Without hearing arguments or issuing an opinion, the Supreme Court has upheld a Virginia law against consensual sodomy. The effect of the ruling is to adopt the decision of a lower threejudge Federal panel, which had held that a state prohibition of sexual conduct against nature does not violate constitutional guarantees of due process, freedom of expression, privacy and freedom from cruel and unusual punishment.

title: N.F.L. Draft to Center on Running Backs
description: An earnest radio interviewer asked Lou Holtz, the Jets new coach, which one player he would like to have who could put the team in the Super Bowl. Holtz thought about it and replied, The referee.

title: Ahmed and The Old Lady
description: At 80, the lady of Jon Godden's title decides to venture into the high mountains of northwestern Kashmir. Sent to her grandson in India for safekeeping (it is wartime). Leah Harding seizes this as her golden opportunity to go beyond the blue horizon in search of exotic beauty and adventure.

title: State Plans BreastCancer Alert System
description: Governor Carey yesterday ordered his Health Commissioner to develop a statewide plan for the early detection of breast cancer following the report that the disease is public health problem that warrants high priority.

title: Salesmanship
description: YOUR body is realy like a car, amuscular young woman in a black jumpsuit was saying as she tried to persuade a potential customer to join a health spa in Melville. If you don't keep it in shape and give it an overhaul, it falls apart.

title: Soutar Barely Wins Bowling Final
description: MILWAUKEE, April 3 (AP) Dave Soutar of Kansas City defeated Denver's Les Schissler by one pin today for his 15th victory on the Professional Bowlers Association tour and his first since 1974. Soutar, who led the fiveman field into the finals of the $80,000 tournament, won the $10,000 first prize by beating Schissler, 207206, as Schissler left the 5pin standing in a 10thframe effort for a winning strike.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Sooner or later, all bad movies declare themselves, not with an outright confession of incompetence but in a scene or a sequence of such compelling wrongheadedness that it amounts to the same thing. It's something that seems to happen spontaneously, as if the movie, having some small residue of selfrespect, wanted us to know that it knows just how bad it really is. In W. C. Fields and Me, based on the memoir by Carlotta Monti, who was Fields's mistress for the last 14 years of his life, this confession comes fairly early in the film.

title: Close UdallCarter Battle Shaving UP in Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE, April 3The volatile voters of Wisconsin will decide on Tuesday the outcome of a latestarting Democratic primary that has become a close seesaw contest between Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona and former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter.

title: Plane Door Falls Off, Lands Near Girl, 4
description: MODESTO, Calif., April 3 (AP)A 60pound door broke Free from a San Franciscohound passenger airliner today and fell 20,000 feet to the ground here, crashing 50 feet from a child playing in front of her home, the authorities said.

title: Collees President Is Waiter
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 3 (AP)Joseph Palamoutain, president of Skidmore College here, waited on tables in the college dining hall Thursday as 170 custodial and cafeteria workers defied a court order to return to work.

title: Ali Amin of Cairo Is Dead at 62; Began a Leading Daily in Egypt
description: CAIRO, April 3 (AP)  Ali Amin, a founder of Cairo's daily Al Akhbar and one of Egypt's leading journalists for more than 30 years, died today. He was 62 years old.

title: Richard Burton: I Knew If I Didn't Come Back Now I Never Would
description: A few weeks ago, Richard Burton returned to Broadway after an absence of 12 years to star in Peter Shaffer's psychological thriller, Equus. Like everything else Burton does, his performance as Martin Dysart, the play's tormented child psychiatrist, created controversy and discussion. Some critics felt that Burton's long absence nom the stage had diminished his art, others that his reputation as a major actor had been reaffirmed. Among the latter, Walter Kerr called Burton's performance overwhelming, and the best work of his life.

title: Princeton poets
description: About a year ago the Princeton Series of Contemporary Poets was announced. I'm sure I haven't been the only one since then who has wondered what Ted Weiss, the appointed editor, would come up with. Not that I feared for quality. Ted, with his wife Renee, has been running the Quarterly Review of Literature for 30 years; his editorial credentials are the best; for that matter he is considerably better than a fair hand at writing himself, both poetry and criticism. But what kind of books would he choose?

title: Music in Review
description: David Levine has performed chamber music frequently, appearing with the Music from Marlboro ensembles and currently joining the violinist Rolf Schulte in ,a series of programs here. Last Wednesday night the pianist gave his first solo recital here in Alice Tully Hall, and his playing was a chambermusic experience in itself.

title: Connecticut Daily Sold
description: WINSTED, Conn., April 3 (UPI)The Scoggins Publishing Company of York, Pa., has become the new owner of The Winsted Evening Citizen, an afternoon daily newspaper serving the Winsted area since 1888. The sale price was not disclosed. J. D. Scoggins, the new owner, named Joseph A. Bradley as publisher.

title: Gunmen in Beirut Still Defy Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sunday April 4Intermittent shelling and sniping marked the second day of Lebanon's latest armed truce, and there was no sign of a political breakthrough on the issue of finding an acceptable successor to the Christian President. Suleiman Franiieh.

title: Susan Jasmine Married to David Walsh
description: Susan Jasmine. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Jasmine of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon to David Edward Walsh of Princeton, N.J., a production manner with Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick. N.J.

title: Federal Court Upsets Veterans Preference
description: BOSTON, April 3 (UFI)A threejudge Federal court has declared unconstitutional a Massachusetts law giving veterans preference in civil service appointments on the ground thaf it discriminates against women.

title: How to Dress the Part Of a Real English Gent
description: Sir! Pardon me, sir. The middleaged woman accosting the impeccably dressed gentleman on St James's Street in London was my wife, at her motive was not, as his glacial glance implied, carnal. I had asked Dorothy to detain him while I dashed inside the Constitutional Club for my camera. I wanted to record a Proper English Gentleman in his natural habitat.

title: Rules in Good Old Days
description: The National League played its first baseball season 100 years ago and things were fairly simple in the good old days before the introduction of the reserve clause, the. basic agreement and pensions.

title: Sondheim's Subtle Japanoiserie
description: On RCA's original cast recording of 'Pacific Overtures, Stephen Sondheim's score, emerging from the eyecatching surroundings of its Broadway production, proves to be much more varied and fascinating than it seemed in the theater.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The FoulingOut Rule
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GENERAL ELECTION IS ON IN THAILANE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sunday, April 4Voters go to the polls in Thailand today in the country's second general election since the end of military riAe in October 1973.

title: Unofficial Host For Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK JOHN LIMYANSKY tapped on his wooden booth with an acorn and a squirrel came running up. The Rutgers University security guard stooped down, and the squirrel, after bobbling the nut in its paws to make sure it was sound, ran off to find a suitable burial place for his prize.

title: Calvin Hill Accepts Redskins Contract
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) Calvin Hill. a running back who said that at age 29 he was ready to join the OvertheHill Gang, became a member of the Washington Redskins today, signing a multiyear contract as a free agent.

title: Bridge to the Past In Sergeantsville
description: SERGEANTSVILLE

title: A Cycler's Paradise
description: FOR the bicycling enthusiast, Long Island abounds with things to do and places to tour. From the New York City line to the easternmost tips, the island is crisscrossed by hundreds of miles of wellpaved secondary roads, ideal for the recreational cyclist.

title: A Play About Belfast
description: PRINCETON

title: CENSORS OF INDIA CONFUSING PRESS
description: NEW DELHI, April 3In al recent account of a rousing welcome that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi received during a visit to Bombay, India's nationI al news agency reported glowingly that admirers had crowded around her and garlanded her with marigolds.

title: Kathryn Kuehn, Charles D. Noll Planning Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul G. Kuehn of South Windsor and Stonington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Strider Kuehn, to Charles David Noll, son of Mrs. Charles A. Noll of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Dr. Noll who was an osteopathic surgeon and a member of the American College of Osteopathic Surgeons.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: MUNICIPAL UNION CHARGES RAIDING
description: The 25,000member union of city clerical workers is charging a sister union of welfare caseworkers with an 'unconscionable attack on the clerks competence and an attempt to move in on jobs it holds.

title: STAMPS
description: Four souvenir sheets depicting momentous events from the birth of the United States two centuries ago, and the largest souvenir sheets ever put out in the nation's postal history, are being issued for INTERPHIL76, the international philatelic exhibition taking place in Philadelphia beginning May 29.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Listen, reader: I am going to mention some words you hate to hear. These words will give you an almost irresistible urge to stop reading immediately and, perhaps, to tear up the paper. I hope you will not do so, because I am going to mention them just once. They will not be referred to again. This is a promise.

title: Headliners
description: The nomination of Herman Schwartz to head the New York State Commission of Correction has been rejected by the Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Schwartz, an advocate of prisoner rights and a law professor now acting chairman of the commission, was praised privately by committee members, but was opposed in the voting by conservatives and police organizations. Some RePublican opponents had hoped that Governor Carey would spare Mr. Schwartz the embarrassment of rejection by withdrawing the nomination. But Mr. Carey, apparently eager to win points with the disgruntled liberal Democrats, decided to force a confrontation.

title: The World
description: With entree to the councils of black national leaders and promises of economic aid, the British Government is trying to limit and defuse the potentially explosive guerrilla warfare along the MozambiqueRhodesian border.

title: Audit of an Audit Spoofs Levitt's Staff as Liability
description: With barbs, broadsides and a parody of the bookkeeper mentality, a state hospital in Queens has answered an audit of its operations by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt by issuing a pseudoscientific report entitled, Audit of an Audit.

title: Millicent Fenwick at Home
description: BERNARDSVILLE MILLICENT H. FENWICK did something late last month that she seldom gets to do. She stole a weekend for herself.

title: ALBANY NOTEBOOK
description: THE dust has barely settled on the lastminute brawling over the state's $10.78 billion budgetit took effect last Thursdaybut Albany legislators are already at work seeking amendments to restore cuts for programs and projects of special interest to their districts.

title: 4 Die in Turkish Quake
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April (Reuters)At least four persons died and 80 houses collapsed in an earthquake last night around the town of Dogubayazit, eastern Turkey, the state radio said today.

title: Routes to Anywhere
description: BICYCLE tourists on Long Island are blessed with some of the best cycling roads in the nation. The variety, most of all, is what's appealing.

title: Elizabeth Ukena to Marry in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ukena of Pelham, N.Y., and Monterey, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ukena, to Joseph J. Cation Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Catino of Moorestown, N.J.

title: RABBIS SUSTAIN POWERS OF PANEL
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., March 30The Conservative rabbinate beat back an attempt here this week to curtail the powers of a special committee that makes decisions on religious problems.

title: Precautions: Better Safe Than Sorry
description: Put tags with your name and home address inside and outside each bag.

title: What's In a Name? Not a Great Deal In Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, April 3  If you live in Massachusetts and you don't like your name, you may choose a new one. Or, if you tire of being known by just one name, then add a second one that suits your fancy.

title: Supreme Court's Rulings Will Not Change Much
description: As election law specialists in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey study the Jan. 30 United States Supreme Court ruling that voided major sections of the Federal Elections Campaign Act, they are finding that with only one significant exception, the decision will have a minimal impact on upcoming elections.

title: The gettingours branch of the movement
description: The question raised by this group of books is whether, if the equality sought by American feminists were achieved, it would have the slightest transforming effect on either our social institutions or our characters. This is not a new question. It was debated as ingenuously in the 19th century as by the 20th century women's movement. Nor is it a question that can ever be fully decided; rather, as changes in women's status do occur, it is simply that having been asked so often it cannot altogether be avoided. Not facing it leads to a narrowminded feminismit might be called the getting ours branch of the movementthat is as embarrassing for its moral as for its economic naivete. In this economy it is not possible for everyone to get theirs simultaneously. Advancement is always at someone's expense. If women's portion grows larger, whose will be getting smaller?

title: Ezra Pound: The Last Rower
description: American poets have often tried their readers as well as pleased them. But since Walt Whitman none has offered a greater perplexity than Ezra Pound. During 35 years, when he was writing his best verse, Pound thundered out social and political views which later he would shun as wrong and fanatical.

title: Along the Danube to Budapest: The Iron Curtain Revisited
description: The best way to Budapest is by boat down the Danube, which cuts a silver swath through the Hungarian capital. As Buda, with its stunning Matthias Church and swirling fishermen's Bastion, unfurls on the right like wedding cake with soft ice cream, and Pest, with its hulking Houses of Parliament, looms up on the left, the whole city envelops you.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The A.R.B.A. (American Revolution Bicentennial Administration) has reported on the first month's sales of its National Bicentennial Medals, and the report will be a surprise to the many collectors who expressed shock and resentment and predicted a bleak sales picture because of the outrageously high prices charged, especially for the gold. and silver versions.

title: Zen Defeats Cojak By Head at Big A
description: PenYBryn Farm's unbeaten Zen extended his streak to five yesterday in the 24th running of the Gotham at Aqueduct, hut the 3.yearold son of Damascus found the going much more difficult than in his preceding successes.

title: Say Wrong S.L.A. Members Were Convicted in Killing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3The four surviving members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army say, in interviews to be published next week, that the wrong persons were convicted of the murder of Dr. Marcus Foster, superintendent of schools in Oakland

title: Elocutionist, $5, Triumphs
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 3 (AP)E. C. Cashman's Elocutionist posted a VAlength victory over New Collection in the $135,800 Arkansas Derby today at Oaklawn Park.

title: A BellRinging Polar Bear Ambles Off Into Soviet North
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (UPI)When a school nurse heard a ring at the front door recently, she hurried to open it and found a polar bear standing on its hind legs and leaning against the bell, the Soviet press agency reports.

title: CARTER IS VICTOR IN 2 STATE RACES
description: Former Gov. Jimmy Carteri of Georgia easily outdistancedi his rivals yesterday as Virginia; and Kansas began the selection of their delegates to the Democratic National Convention.Butl he failed to score the sweep he had predicted in Virginia, where uncommitted slates showed surprising strength.

title: POLITICS Primary Concerns
description: FOR all the glamour at the top of the Presidential campaignspotlights, cameras, Secret Service, jets it still boils down to anonymous men and women working long hours at short pay in stuffy storefronts, or confronting confused or even belligerent voters. while distributing literature or canvassing by telephone.

title: The Press And Freedom
description: IN recent weeks, New Jersey newspapers have come under increasing attack from the state's judiciary, thus adding to an old fend that predates even the American Revolution.

title: FOOD
description: WITH the arrival of spring, traffic heading for Tice Farms in Woodcliff Lake is starting to get heavy again, especially on weekends. The place Is a ;mecca for applecider lovers, doughnut fanciers, onestop shoppers and gardeners in search of seeds.

title: 2 Seized in Busing Protest
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 3 (UPI)About 60 policemen arrested two persons today when they barred 200 antibusing demonstrators. from Churchill Downs race track. The demonstrators said they were rehearsing for Derby Day, May I. Robert Deprez, 39 years old, and Donald Holmes, 38, two of the protest leaders, were arrested on a misdemeanor charge of organizing a march without a permit.

title: Some Changes, but No Liberalization, No Freedom to Travel
description: EAST BERLINThere are many things in East German society. that are not what they seem and an East Berliner says the state's pretense that true socialism rules here is one of them.

title: Honest Pleasure Wins Florida Derby Easily
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 3Honest Pleasure, the strongest candidate for racing's Triple Crown since Secretariat, added a few points to his national ranking today when he easily won the Florida Derby for his eighth straight victory.

title: Starkweather
description: Charles Starkweather was a 19yearold Nebraskan who, in 1958, accompanied by his steady date, Card Fugate, 14, hit the road in a 49 Ford and blew out the brains of 10 people. In that year there was no S.L.A., no El Fatah, no slaughter by the busload in Ulster, no attempted or consummated assassinations of Presidents or C.I.A. muckaMucks, no bombings of airport baggage areas or sites of farewell addresses by tee tatners of countries. It was, in a word, a slow year for mass murder, and the media made the most of Starkweather and Fugate's photogenically repulsive grins. Starkweather had the brass to claim selfdefense, and was electrocuted. Fugate maintained, implausibly, that she was his hostage, and was given a life sentence. She has been, as the predictable ironies of such situations require, a model prisoner. Her parole hearing will be in June, 1976.

title: When Hifi Meets SciFi
description: When Edgar Allan Poe's intrepid Dutchman, Hans Pfaal, took off for the moon in a giant balloon filled with gas, he also gave rise to an entire literature dealing with space travel, robots, invasions from other planets, time warps and life on an Earth devastated by the bomb. The number of sciencefiction talcs on records and tapes is growing apace, and at least one new company, Alternate World Recordings, promises to devote itself entirely to readings and dramatizations of the classics of science fiction and fantasy. A vivid dramatization of a sciencefiction tale can sound chillingly realisticOrson Welles proved the point on Oct. 30, 1938 when his alltoocredible version of H. G. Wells's The War of the Worlds was broadcast on CBS radio. That Hallowe'en prank upset the entire nation as thousands of people took to the highways, fleeing invading Martians. Welles's tour  de  force, performed with a cast from his Mercury Theater on the Air, was recorded at the time and can be heard in a condensed, onerecord version on Audio Rarities or complete in a tworecord set available from Murray Hill Records at the bargain price of $5.99, The offtheair sound is execrable but the listener forgets that, as the creatures from Mars leave their spaceship and begin to take over the Metropolitan  all reported in the radio news style of the period by near  hysterical eyewitness correspondents.

title: Jackson Salutes Amigos in East Harlem
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson took his quest for broader support in Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary election to the streets of East Harlem yesterday.

title: Australia Loses People
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 3 (Reuters)A declining birth rate and fewer immigrants have brought Australia close to zero population growth, Minister for Immigration Michael MacKellar reported. He told parliament hat immigration figures showed noout 5,000 more people left Australia in 1975 than entered the country, the first year since 1947 that departures nutnumbereft arrivals.

title: In Wisconsin, Despite Ads, Udall Isn't Familiar Name
description: APPLETON, Wis., April 2Mary Hoffman, whose husband is an electrician in a paper mill, ticked off the list of Democrats who will be on the ballot here in the primary election Tuesday. She mentioned Jimmy Carter, Henry Jackson and poor George Wallace, who got her vote in 1972.

title: Change Slowly Emerging in Mozambique's Capital
description: MAPUTO. Mozambique, April 2 (Reuters) Although there are no outward signs of upheaval in this capital of newly independent Mozambique, a closer look shows that gradual but distinct changes are taking place.

title: Campaign Buttons Losing to TV, Direct Mail
description: Presidential candidates abound, but campaign buttons are scarce.

title: PEOPLE
description: THE way Leonard Braun remembers It, the good old days for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were when the chairman was Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's good friend, Dr. William Ronan. Mr. Braun, of Halesite, had occasion to remember the good old days when he appeared as a member of the M.T.A. before the Transportation Committee of the Suffolk County Legislature. Mr. Brailn tole the committee Mat the stale s ??? blems had made unlikely any further electrification of the Long Island Rail Road. Then he waxed nostalgic, saying: We were lucky when we had Dr. Ronan because he had a red phone on his desk and all he had to do was pick it and say, I need another $25 million'.

title: Let Them Eat Nothing
description: THERE will be much needless suffering if the United States Department of Agriculture's newly issued foodstamp regulations are implemented in June. They incorporate the most reprehensible features of legislation currently before Congress and, following as they do Administration dictates, in effect represent a usurpation of Congressional decisionmaking powers. Not only are the new guidelines (and the bills upon which they are based) politically tainted, they are economically implausible.

title: Kennedy Had Hideaway In Case of Atomic War
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., April 3 (AP)President Kennedy had a secret hideaway here he apparently never used.

title: Craven Gets Devon Show Post
description: After almost a halfcentury of watching horses prance around the ring, C. L. (Honey) Craven has taken on a new assignment. Starting this year, Craven, who will celebrate 50 years as a member of the National H or se Show staff next yea r, becomes manager of the Devon Horse Show in Devon, Pa. The Devon show is scheduled for May 28 through June 5 and marks the first of the major outdoor events in the East. It usually has the heaviest entry list in the area. Craven's appointment comes as a result of Jim Fallon resigning his manager's post at Devon to become executive secretary of the American Horse Shows Association.

title: An Annual Rite: Cleanup Time
description: IN hundreds of commu nities across the state, the annual spring cleanup ritual, in which municipal agencies help homeowners rid themselves  of junk that clutters attics, garages and basements, is under way. Handbills, letters and newspaper advertisements are heralding appropriate dates, methods of preparation and personal benefits.

title: JACKSON'S HOPES FACE MAJOR TEST IN NEW YORK RACE
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson's strategy of parlaying primary victories in the big industrial states into the Democratic Presidential nomination faces a major test in the New York Democratic primary this Tuesday.

title: For the Struggling OTB Bettor: A Pool of His Own?
description: Post time was still two hours away, hut Lonzy Burton had already made up his mind on the Aqueduct daily double,

title: TV VIEW
description: There is nothing quite like a passionate conviction for revealing the vast blandness of television. The world of manufactured productions, ranging from a situation comedy with mechanical laugh track to a political campaign exploiting comfortable images. is suddenly shattered. The true potential of the electronic Medium is glimpsed, however fleetingly. Two examples of this phenomenon have been provided in recent weeks, and both happen to have involved Malcolm Muggeridge. the British writer and man for all panel shows. In one, the Muggeridge presence was peripheral. as a commentator on the BBC's Solzhenitsyn interview that William F. Buckley, Jr,, acquired for his Firing Line series and aired here Saturday, March 27, at 6 P.M. In the other, Mr. Muggeridge holds stage center as the narrator/guide for A Third Testament, a sixpart series on the lives and teachings of six characters in search of God": St. Augustine, Blaise Pascal, William Blake, Siiren Kierkegaard, Leo Tolstoy and Dietrich Bonhoeffer.

title: Rag Trade Scores In Grand National
description: AINTREE, England, April 3 (AP)  Rag Trade pulled ahead of Red Rum over the last few yards today and won one of the most exciting Grand National steeplechases.

title: A Vindication of Sorts for the Last Angry Man
description: JAMES CATTERSON, the new Nassau County Attorney, needed only one tangle to learn the first lesson of being a public official in Nassau  don't mess with Ralph G. Sorley.

title: EAST RAMAPO TAX MEETS OPPOSITION
description: Residents of the East Ramapc School District in Rockland County are taking a new, hard look at school taxes.

title: 7 Elderly Tenants Are Killed in Fire At 2 Miami Hotels
description: MIAMI, April 3 (UPI)A fire that was believed to have been started by a fire bomb swept through two small hotels today, killing seven elderly persons, and forcing other residents to leap from windows. Fourteen persons were injured, two of them critically.

title: Ford Likely to Veto Hatch Act Revision
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., April 3 President Ford said here today that he would veto legislation giving Federal workers the right to take part in partisan nolitics.

title: Rich Prizes Awaiting Shore Golf Victor
description: Try to imagine how it would feel to play on the winning team in the Super Bowl, he voted the game's most valuable player and take the Super Bowl trophy.

title: The Region
description: The interplay of political and fiscal exigencies dominated a most unusual week in Albany in which Governor Carey was attacked by both political parties. One bill he had vetoed was overridden by the Democraticcontrolled Assembly; another was almost overridden in the Republicandominated Senate.

title: 2 ZOOLOGISTS FIND ANTS USING TOOLS
description: Some kinds of ants may use pieces of leaves, dried mud and grains of sandthe way New Yorkers use shopping cartsto carry home much more food than they could otherwise hold.

title: They Have Ordinary Concerns: to Make a Decent Living
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaFor a rural Rhodesian, the 21yearold cowherd in one of the country's cyclone fenced protected villages, was unusually forth coming.

title: RICHARD J. KAUL
description: Richard J. Kaul, former general manager of the Petrochemical Division of Exxon, died Thursday at his home, 4 Burchfield Avenue, Cranford, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: Cathy Schragis Wed to L. J. Heller
description: Cathy Robin Schragis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Schragis of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Lloyd Jeffrey Heller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Heller of Stamford, Conn.

title: Income Tax Form 1040 Is Termed Ambiguous
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (UPI)A professor at California State University says millions of Americans, including many who are well educated, cannot understand income tax form 1040 as it is written.

title: Yankees Withdraw Bid to Messersmith
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3Before Commissioner Bowie Kuhn could rule on the Yankees alleged agreement with Andy Messersmith, the Yankees ended the dispute today by withdrawing their claim to the pitcher.

title: BLACKS IN LONDON SHUN POLICE FORCE
description: LONDON, April 3  Six months after Scotland Yard opened a broad campaign to recruit more black policemen, it has disclosed that the effort is failing.

title: Battle Is Looming Over Auto Rallies
description: It would appear that a war (or at the least, a good shoving match) is brewing over the control of professional rallying in this country. The combatants are the Sports Car Club of America (S.C.C.A.), which until this year has had everything in rallying pretty much its own way, and the upstart North America Rally Association, Inc. (N.A.R.A.) of Nyack, N. Y.

title: Meryl Joy Greenfield Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour S. Greenfield of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meryl Joy Greenfield; to Dr. Jeffrey Hall Dobken, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Todhunter Dobken of Ridgefield Park, N.J.

title: Pipe Organs: A Jersey Heritage
description: IT has become quite the thing nowadays for American communities of all sizes to take inventories of their cultural resources and then publish the results somewhere along with attendance or dollar statistics intended to show that the town, region or state just kwes the arts.

title: Traveling down the river
description: To explorers the Niger, Africa's third longest river but greater than the Nile in volume, was even more elusive than the Nile. Far into the 19th century its source and outlet were still unknown, the location of the former not being determined until 1896. It was a river difficult to get to

title: F.B.I. FILES REPLY TO DAMAGE SUIT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, responding to a damage suit by the Socialist Workers Pary, says it investigated members of the Trotskyite party partly because it feared they might gain responsible positions not only in government but also in industry and education.

title: What Do I Hear for . . .?  The Cauliflower Growers Auction Opens the Spring Planting Season
description: RIVERHEAD

title: Home Sweet Home
description: IT was with much Interest that I read Towns vs. Developers. (Feb. 29), which described North Haledon as a town of little boxes on a hillside, a town that is white and Republican.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Twyla Tharp. Even the name is one of a kindsingular, distinctive and vaguely funny. It has become a brand of ballet. And Tharp herself, with her whimsical, pixie face and tough little body, has traveled all the way from champion batontwirler in some outskirt of American civilization to the launching pad of a tremendous career in bigtime show business. Of course, she may settle just for balletbut she didn't settle for batontwirling, and right now there seems to be a glitter of Broadway, Las Vegas and Hollywood glistening in her eyes.

title: Harvard Crew Repeats Copley Cup Victory on Coast
Point of View
description: The New York urban region has been like a large family of squabbling siblings  880 separate municipalities each wanting to go its own way, each fumbling the check for the costs of urban civilization. In prosperity, family squabbling could be tolerated Now, the region is in adversitynot just New York City with its bond problems but the whole region with its lagging economy. Like a family, we must face our problems together.

title: PEOPLE
description: Typesetting with meticulousrcare for spacing and imposition is almost a lost art, says John Anderson of Maple Shade. The large printing offices care little, as long as they get the jobs in and out quickly and make money in the process. Mr. Anderson felt so strongly about not letting the craft of classic typesetting be lost that in 1948 he set up Pickering Press, a workshop housing more than 700 fonts of type, including some rare ones from the last three centuries. He produces museum exhibition catalogues, limitededition books, posters and award certificates, and his typographic and graphic designs are in the collections of bibliophiles and institutions in several countries.

title: Finnish Dockers on Strike
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April (UPI)  Four thousand dockworkers walked off the job today seeking higher wages and better working conditions. worsening a strike situation already paralyzing much of Finnish agriculture and commerce.

title: Malaria Warning to Travelers Urged by World Health Aides
description: GENEVA, April 3Malaria, which the World Health Organization set out to eradicate 20 years ago, is now a growing Icause of concern in regions where it never existed or had already been conquered.

title: Everyday Movement As Dance
description: In choreographer Laura Dean's Circle Dance, 10 performers, dressed in simple white shirts and pants, walk in four concentric circles for 35 minutes. Except for an occasional reversal of direction, which requires the dancer to pivot on one leg, the movement never changes from the simple repetition of the same shuffling, bouncing, loosekneed step. At the end, the dancers break away from the circles and go into five minutes of highspeed spinning, and then all stop together.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Blue Angel Fire

title: The Big Conspiracy
description: In the confusion that surrounded his status, Andy Messersmith has a theory that was quite clear.

title: An Iowa Newspaper Is Ahead of Its Time
description: LAURENS, Iowa, April (UPI)Residents of this small northwestern Iowa community would have been ahead of their time, at least for month, if they had followed the advice of their local weekly newspaper.

title: Donna Jackson Bride Of Shultz Hartgrove
description: Donna Merrill Jackson, daughter of Donald W. Jackson of New York and Mrs. Richard Wallower of Plandome, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon in Manhasset, L. I., to Shultz Augustus Hartgrove. He is the son of Mrs. H. Kane Greenleaf of San Angelo, Tex., and the late S. Augustus Hartgrove.

title: Miss McKee Wed to Lee Donovan
description: Catherine Barbara McKee, daughter of `Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. McKee Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Lee Millard Donovan, a senior vice president of the Commerce Bank of Bethesda, Md.

title: Eric Maguire Fiance Of Suzanne Falcone
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Falcone of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Falcone, to Eric F. Maguire, who is on the sales staff of the Olivetti Commotion in Dallas.

title: ExDirector Backs Intelligence Unit Facing Abolition
description: A recommendation by the House Select Committee on Intelligence that the Defense Intelligence Agency be abolished has been condemned as asinine by the agency's former director.

title: Linda Frech Affianced To Michael C. Venning
description: Announcement has been made by Mr, and Mrs. Hans Alexander Frech of. New York of the engagement of their daughter, Linda Carol Hazard Frech, to Michael Charles yenning, son of Drs. Ruth and Geoffrey Venning of High Wycombe, England.

title: Beth Karten Fiancee Of Frank Abrahams
description: The engagement of Beth Karten, a freelance fashion designer, to Frank Abrahams, president and chairman of the Stockport Management Company, investment advisers and taxshelter consultants, has been announced by Mrs. Irving ICarten of New York, mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. David Berkow of Baltimore and the late David Abrahams.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: In Horror Movies, Some Things Are Sacred
description: Horrormovie madness is in full bloom on TV screens, in movie theaters, at film festivals and on campuses around the country. Every major city seems to have its own chilling variation of TV's Creature Features. and Hollywood is now at work on what will surely be one of next season's biggest blockbusters, The Heretic  Exorcist II. At 12 o'clock tonight, the prestigious Los Angeles Film Exposition will conclude its Midnight Monsters series"a tribute to the classic motion pictures that have brought fear to the hearts and minds of millions of American moviegoers  while on the other coast each Tuesday, at midnight, The Yale Film Society, like many other such campus organizations, presents the eerie likes of The House That Dripped Blood and Vampire Lovers in its popular Things That Go Bump in the Night series.

title: 199 Skippers Join Atlantic Solo Race
description: Tomorrow's the deadline. Qualifying cruise logs are due for entries in the singlehanded transAtlantic race from Plymouth, England. to Newport, R.I., which starts June 5. The fleet has more than tripled since the of last race in 1972, and promises to include some of the most interesting yachts afloat.

title: Convicts on Hunger Strike
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 3 (UPI)  The 43 condemned convicts in death row at San Quentin Prison have started a hunger strike in a protest to obtain more access to the prison library and better medical care.

title: India is as Indira does
description: The cameltracked deserts of Rajasthan slid beneath the wings of the British Airways jet speeding toward New Delhi. In the lounge several passengers sipped a wakeup glass of mango juice.

title: For Kapp, Defeat
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 Joe Kapp suffered a total defeat, but the National Football League scored only a limited victory when a jury found yesterday that the former quarterback had not been damaged by antitrust or contract violations and refused to award him any money.

title: Richard Lyon Is Fiance Of Andrea R. Franklin
description: Ann Kerr Franklin of Locust Valley, L.I. and Philip A. S. Franklin of Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Remsen Franklin, to Richard Addison Mitchell Lyon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Lyon of Pittburgh.

title: PRESSURE ON U.S. EXPECTED IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3African diplomats and United Nations officials are predicting that international pressure on the United States to halt its imports of strategic, minerals from Rhodesia will mount sharply in the next few weeks.

title: British Aren't at Home On the Playing Fields
description: LONDON, April 3, (Reuters)Contrary to repute, the British really don't care much for playing cricket.

title: Women of The Shadows
description: The myth About Italian womenor, for that matter, about Spanish women, Greek women, Arab women, women wherever a combination of custom, men and plain poverty has conspired to make their lives miserableis that these women have the real power. Not the strutting, pathetic power of their men but some sort of deep familial authority too subtle, too gently gratifying for a stranger to identify. The Mediterranean myth survives in everything from the distant literature of the social sciences to the punch lines of local jokes in a thousand villages.

title: Top N.F.L. Draft Choices
description: A total of 492 players will be selected in the National Football League's annual college draft on Thursday and Friday. Here are the ones, by position, regarded as the best pro prospects by the experts.

title: Letters
description: Alive and kicking

title: South Africa Dooms 103
description: CAPE TOWN, April 3 (Agrnce FrancePresse)A total of 103 people were condemned to death in South Africa last year. Police and Justice Minister Jimmy Kruger have reported. Of these, 96 were for murder, two for murder and robbery. two for roberry and three for rape, the minister said. He did not say how many of the sentences were carried out during the year.

title: 2,000 Ordered Dropped From Nassau's Payroll
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 3Declaring that Nassau County was now at the 11th hour in its efforts to have the Legislature give it approval to increase its present threecent county sales tax by a cent, Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive, ordered last week that 2,000 employees be dropped from the county payroll, effective June 1.

title: 28 Senate Subcommittees Held No Meetings in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, April 3A Library of Congress survey of committee activity in the Senate has found that almost half the Senate's 13S subcommittees held four meetings or less each last year and that 28 of them did not meet.

title: Plishka Sings a Freehold Love Song
description: FREEHOLD MOST of his neighbors are unaware that the burly young man raising a family in the twostory house down the block is Paul Plishka, one of the brightest lights on the American opera scene.

title: Tim Moore Sweeps U.S. Dive Titles
description: CLEVELAND, April 3 (AP) Tim Moore swept the three men's diving events with a victory in the 10meter platform final today in the Amateur Athletic Union senior indoor national championships at Cleveland State University.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE 0.2 percent in March to 179.8 (1967=100), the first increase in two months. Prices farmers received declined by 1.5 percent but were still 12 percent higher than a year earlier... The Composite Index of Leading Indicators rose 0.8 percent in February to 105.7 percent of die 1967 average, the fourth successive monthly rise.. . Unemploymtnt in March fell to 7.5 percent the work force, from 7.6 percent in February.. . Factory orders surged in February to $90.37 billion, up 2.5 percent over the January level. . Inventories rose by $171 million to $147.2 billion. . . F. W. Dodge reported that new colnstruction contracts in February totaled $6.14 billion a gain of 22 percent over February.

title: Eileen Starrs Wed To Francis Kelly
description: Eileen Virginia Starrs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Starrs of the Bronx and North Salem, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Francis Thomas Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Kelly of Forest Hills, Queens, and South Jamesport, L. I.

title: Buffalo Plant Hiring
description: BUFFALO, April 3 (UPI)Freezer Queen Foods Inc., announced yesterday that it would hire at least 120 new employees within the next 30 days.

title: Dr. Thomas Robinson to Marry Anne S. Jeffers, Vassar Senior
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Nicholson Jeffers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Sigourney Jeffers, to Dr. Thomas Drew Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Brooks Blackwell Robinson. Both families are of New York, where Dr. Robinson is a resident in medicine at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Best, the Unorthodox Irishman, Now Taking Soccer Seriously
description: For the first time in his illustrious and unorthodox career, George Best, the flamboyant Irishman, appears to have taken soccer seriously. Every day for more

title: Zumwalt Denies Having Direct Role In Reagan Speech
description: WASHINGTON. April 3 (AP) Retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt said today that he had no direct role in Ronald Reagan's decision to cite in a campaign speech controversial remarks attributed to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger by the admiral.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q. We have collected some old wicker pieces for use at our beach house and now want to know how old paint can be removed from these pieces without damaging the wicker. Also, can the dried out, brittle wicker be revitalized in any way?Mrs. J.A.B., East Brunswick, N. J.

title: BRITONS HEAD LIST OF ALCOHOL BUYERS
description: GENEVA, April 4 (Reuters)Britons are among the world's big spenders on alcohol, and Americans eat out in restaurants far more than other people, according to statistics published by the International Labor Organization.

title: Suzuki Is Golf Victor
description: KUALA LUMPUR, April 3 (AP)  Yutaka Suzuki of Japan won the Malaysian Masters golf championship today. His total was 285 for four rounds. Hal Underwood, an American, and Bobby Lim of Malaysia tied for second place.

title: Gail Garvey Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Garvey of Cheviot Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Ann Garvey, to Ronald Stephen Lewis, son of Jerry Lewis, the comedian, and Mrs. Lewis of BelAir, Calif. The future bride is a graduate of Loyola Marymount University. Her fianc, a graduate of United States International University in San Diego, received master's degree from the University of Southern California. They plan to be married in June.

title: A Bicentennial Approach to the Vegetable Garden
description: It is now or never for the Bicentennialminded gardener. This is the season to sow the seeds of the Revolution.

title: Detroit Student Loss Is Put At 1,043 Since Busing Began
description: DETROIT, April 3 (UPI)School officials say that 1,043 students, including 178 who ard being held at home by their parents, have left the Detroit public school system since a limited busing integration plan began Jan. 26.

title: Washington's Subway Declared Successful
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)Washington's new subway system is being declared a success after an opening week with 112,103 riders and no muggings.

title: No Island Is an Island
description: CAN the financial problems that have beset New York City move out to Long Island like the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who already have? Does the NassauSuffolk Standard Metropolitan Statistical Area, the second highest in per capita personal income of the country's 254 S.M.S.A.'s, face financial disaster? Is our tax structure, so heavily dependent on the real property tax, a threat to our economic future? Does the fact that Long Island is situated in an economically declining region mean that our future is bleak? Can it happen here?

title: Saigon Bars Sale of Books Published Before Takeover
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Agence FrancePresse) The Saigon Municipal Information and Cultural Service has ordered a temporary ban on the sale of books and other printed matter published before the takeover of the capital last April 30.

title: Dr. J and the Old School Spirit
description: WHEN the New York Nets take the court at the Nassau Coliseum Friday night against San Antonio in the first American Basketball Association playoff game, the athletes and hard  pressed coaches at Roosevelt High School will be watching more, than the score.

title: It's Never Too Late To Learn Chess
description: The FischerSpassky match in 1972 aroused an enormous amount of interest in the splendid and ancient game of chess, but many of the people who tried to learn the game then became overwhelmed with its complexity.

title: Adding Small Talk to the Art of Lecturing
description: GLEN RIDGE IBEGAN lecturing in New Jersey long before I started living there. It has been a uniformly pleasant experience, unmarred by some of the hairraising episodes I have been confronted with in other localities, like the floods I encountered in Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, the minor tornado through which I was driven in Illinois acrd the earthquakes of California.

title: In Case of Pain, Apply Conger Eel...
ART
description: MONTCLAIR MOSES SOYER is known primarily as an artist whose palette had a strong bias for people. He painted them in the streets, in the subway, at work and at play and sitting for portraits in a familiar environment.

title: Opera: Meistersinger Returns to Met
description: Die Meistersinger, Wagner's great comic opera, returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night after an absence of four years. The sole Wagner work in the company's repertory this season, it is being given only three times. Still, one must be grateful for small favors, although even a single performance of Meistersinger is scarcely a small favor.

title: In the World of Primaries, N.Y. Is a Regular Byzantium
Gros Is Slalom Victor
description: CASPOGGIO, Italy (UPI) Piero Gros of Italy won the slalom today for his third straight victory in the Valmalenco International Men's Alpine Skiing Week. Rolando Thoeni of Italy was second.

title: WHAT MAKES HUBERT NOT RUN?
description: Suddenly, everybody is watching Hubert H. Humphrey not run for President. After 20 years of pursuing national office, after three campaigns for the Presidency in which he was treated by substantial elements of his own party as pitiable, or a betrayer of the faith, or a retread, Senator Humphrey is the hottest political property in the Democratic Party. And such are the vagaries of politics that his resurgence has come at the very time when his most cherished beliefs are under attack as they have not been in a generation.

title: The MacNeil Report'TV's Other News Show
description: A few weeks ago, a TV news anchorman looked two of his guests remorselessly in the eye and asked, If you agreed with all the opinions of a Presidential candidate except his position on abortion, would you vote for him? The guests stumbled through their answers, but the question hung in the air.

title: Wendy Gemberling To Wed in Summer
description: The engagement of Wendy P. Gemberling to John R. Gambling has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Gemberling Jr. of Woodstown, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of John A. Gambling, whose Rambling With Gambling show is heard every morning on radio station WOR, and Mrs. Gambling of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Premier Miki Vows Lockheed Inquiry
description: TOKYO, April 3Prime Minister Takeo Miki of Japan pleaded with Parliament today to separate the Lockheed scandal from other issues and to get on with the work of the nation, especially the national budget.

title: Save the Farmland
description: IN a few weeks, the Suffolk County Legislature will be called upon to make a historic decision: Whether to borrow money to buy the development rights to some of the last remaining prime farmland on Long Island.
