title: PHNOM PENH SAYS SINANOUK RESIGNS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Mom. clay, April 5 (UPI)A Phnom Penh radio broadcast said today that Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia had resigned as chief of state and would be pensioned at $8,000 a year.

title: OTB , 5, Hopes to Grow; Betting Stigma Persists
description: The Offtracic Betting Corporation, which celebrates its fifth birthday on Thursday with dreams of enormous expansion into betting on baseball, football basketball, has not yet shaken off the stigma born in the back rooms of furtive bookmakers that it is still somewhat sinful to wager on a horse away from the track.

title: DeFreeze Brother Guilty
description: CLEVELAND, April 4 (AP)Carl DeFreeze, brother of the late Donald DeFreeze, a leader of the socalled Symbionese ILiberation Army. was _found guilty yesterday of aggravated murder in the shooting death of Jesse Smith, a bar owner, during a robbery here Dec. 27. Mr. DeFreeze, 22 years old, also was convicted of aggravated robbery and two counts of felonious assault. He was . found innocent of aggravated burglary and of murder during the commission of a burglary. His lawyer said that the convictions would be appealed.

title: Bienstock Sees an Upsurge In City's Economy in 80's
description: While prophets of doom are chanting litanies over New York City, the mighty lively corpse is on the threshold of development and expansion, Herbert Bienstock, the regional commissioner in the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said yesterday.

title: Barzin Lays Down Baton, Gloomy on Music Scene
description: The cultural explosion of the pat three decades is over, and today cultural organizations are struggling to keep their status quo. What is needed is more education In the arts, if they, are not to take second place to timepassing activities when people arrive at a 30hour work week in the near future. Otherwise people will become drooling morons in front of TV sets.

title: Furor Over Missile Decision Reflects Pitfalls of PolicyMaking Jobs in the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON. April 4At a time when the conflictofinterest problem has risen once again to haunt the Pentagon, Dr, Malcolm R. Currie, director 04 defense research and engineering, symbolizes the ethital judgments and pitfalls confronting industry executives who move into policymaking jobs in the Defense Department.

title: Personal Finance
description: Uncompensated casualty and theft losses can be deducted from income in computing Federal income taxes. But there are certain requirements that must specifically be met before making such deductions for property used for personal Purposes.

title: Wilkie Gets Third Title In A.A.U. Swim Meet
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 4 (AP)David Wilkie became the first triple winner at the national Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships when he captured the men's 200meter individual medley in a nearrecord time tnnight.

title: Districts With Slates In Tomorrow's Voting
Canadian River Overflows
description: PERTH, New Brunswick, April 4 (AP)About 500 people were evacuated from their homes And a hospital today as the St. John River continued to overflow its banks in western New Brunswick near the Maine border.

title: Ann Sage Is Bride Of Michael Alper
description: Ann sage, daughter of Dr. Maurice S. Sage of New York, president of the Jewish National Fund, and Mrs. Sage, was married yesterday to Michael Alper of Floral Park, LI., son of Edith Alper of Tel Aviv and the late Marcus Alper. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman performed the ceremony at the New York Hilton.

title: A New Gadfly Keeps Eye on House
A ROSEDALE HOUSE IS BOMB TARGET
description: The Queens police yesterday reported a new racial incident in Rosedale in which a black home buyer was the target of wouldbe arsonists working with a flammable powder and a Molotov cocktail. Neither device ignited, they said.

title: Patricia Shapiro Bride Of Lawrence E. Schatt
description: Patricia Ann Shapiro, director of planning at the Institute of Puerto Rican Urban Studies in the Bronx, was married last evening to Lawrence Edward Schatt of New York, coordinator of the Food Stamp Outreach Program for Oueens.

title: Porsche Driver Scores
description: ADENAU, West Germany, April 4 (UPI) Reinhold Joest of Vest Germany, driving a Porsche, won the Adenau auto race today on the Nuerburgring speed circuit. Joest covered the 156.8 miles at an average speed of 90.3 miles an hour. The race counts towards the world sports car championship.

title: Election Campaign Opens in Portugal Amid New Violence
description: LISBON, April 4 The campaign for parliamentary elections set for April 25 officially opened today with a Communist fiesta and a monarchist motorcade here and political rallies by the 12 other competing parties elsewhere in the country.

title: Blacks Join Jews to Press Bias Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Leaders of two major civil rights groupsone Jewish and the other blackpledged today to intensify their tollallo ration in the struggle against prejudice and discrimination in America.

title: Jackson Is Winner In Puerto Rico Vote For 11 Delegates
Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday that his auditors had been impressed with the high degree of professionalism and dedication in the care of patients in a network of 13 satellite clinics through which the South Beach Psychiatric Center serves 3,000 outpatients in Staten Island and Brooklyn.3 Arrested at Soviet Mission

title: Soviet Navy Loses Right To Use Egyptian Ports
Discount on Tennis For Married Pairs Ruled Out by State
PREMIER OUSTED IN THAI ELECTION
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, April 5Prime Minister Kukrit Pramoj lost his office yesterday when he was defeated for reelection to his seat in the National Assembly in Thailand's second general election in little more than a year.

title: U.S. ENERGY USE FELL FOR 2D YEAR IN ROW
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) High fuel prices, a mild winter and a slow economy combined in 1975 to reduce energy use in the United States for the second consecutive year, the Department of the Interior reported today.

title: Party in Germany Headed by Schmidt Loses a State Vote
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, April 4The Social Democratic Party of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt suffered a major setback today in a state election in BadenWtirttemberg. It was the last such test of voter sentiment before national elections Oct. 3.

title: The Proliferators
description: For almost a year, arrangements to export, to Brazil and Pakistan respectively, West German and French technology for making nuclear explosives have been proceeding behind a smokescreen of pious pledges to nonproliferation. Public opinion, Parliaments and even the Cabinets of the two countries have been fed misleading information about the supposed safeguards imposed.

title: Barcelona Police Attack Marchers; 200 Held in Madrid
description: MADRID, April 4 (AP)The police attacked leftist demonstrators with rifle butts, tear gas and rubber bullets today in a bloody twohour clash in Barcelona and arrested more than 200 people in Madrid in a crackdown aimed at stifling growing unrest with Spain's new Government.

title: MOYNIHAN TESTS POLITICAL WINDS
description: BUFFALO, April 4Daniel P. Moynihan stumped exuberantly across upstate New York to!day, extolling the Presidential lqualifications of Senator Henry M. Jackson in Tuesday's primary and testing his own potential as a candidate.

title: HEINZ M. GLAESKE
description: Heinz Maximilian Glaeske, former president of the G. Krueger Brewing Company of Newark, died of a heart ailment Thursday at his home in San Marino, Calif. He was 63 years old.

title: I Never Said That!
description: WASHINGTONWhen is a quotation not a quotation? Here is a quick guide to past and present disputes about the art of quoting:

title: Costs at Leading Colleges Going Over $7,000 a Year
YUNICH SAYS FARE MAY GO TO 65 CENTS BY SPRING OF 1977
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that subway and bus fares might have to rise to 65 cents next year unless the agency found an equivalent for $125 million in Federal subsidies that the agency expects to lose.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's Arts and Leisure Section of The New York Times incorrectly said that former Gov. Jimmy Carter favors an antiabortion constitutional amendment. In fact, Mr. Carter has stated that although he has personal reservations about abortion he nevertheless supports the Supreme Court. ruling on the subject and does not favor a constitutional amendment to undo what the Supreme Court has done.

title: Reagan's Speech on NBCTV Got 17 Percent of the Audience
description: Approximately 13 million persons watched all or part of Ronald Reagan's speech Wednesday night on NBCTV, the network's research departmentl says.

title: Slipping
description: Despite unaccustomed praise from Treasury Secretary William E. Sitnon, who expressed cautious optimism that New York City can achieve its goal of a balanced budget by mid1978, New Yorkers can take little comfort from testimony on their city's fiscal progress that was presented to the Senate Banking Committee this week.

title: J. LAWRENCE COOK, PIANOROLL MAKER
description: J. Lawrence Cook, sometimes known as Piano Roll Cook because of his career as an arranger, composer and maker of the rolls for player pianos, died of a heart attack Friday at his home, 57 Esplanade Street, Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: SOVIET CRITICIZES U.S. CRUISE MISSILE
description: MOSCOW, April 4 (AP)The Soviet military newspaper said today that the United States development of the newly tested cruise missile threatened to accelerate the nuclear arms race and could block a new agreement on limiting strategic weapons.

title: Jobs and Not Fish Win in Ohio Steel Town
description: YOUNGSTOWN, OhioFor as long as anyone here can remember, the narrow Mahoning River has been a steel rivera nearstagnant collection of grease, oil and metallic particles, all suspended in heated water that sometimes reaches 90 degrees. Each day, the eight steel mills that sprawl along the Mahoning's banks dump 158 more tons of debris into the water. Nobody here seems to care very much.

title: Israel Soccer Victor
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 4 (UPI)  Israel defeated South Korea, 31, in the Asia Group Three preliminary soccer series for the Summer Olympics.

title: Miss Douchkess Bride of Peter Gold
description: Barbara Gail Douchkess, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Douchkess of New York, was married at the Regency Hotel yesterday to Peter Steven Gold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gold, also of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge:
description: Two British experts held the lead going into the final session last night of the Cavendish Club invitation tournament here. In a field of 40 pairs, including many of America's topranked players and prominent performers from Canada, Central and South America, Irving Rose and John Forro of London were 202 international match points ahead of their nearest rivals.

title: A Rite of Spring: Jackson, in a Search For Ethnic Vote, Eats Ethnic Sandwich
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson or Washington took part yesterday in one of the more familiar rites of New York City campaigning.

title: Payoffs to U.S. Meat Inspectors Are Found Common in City Area
description: Federal investigators have uncovered evidence of widespread payments by meat packers and processors to Agriculture Department fond inspectors in the New York area a corrupt practice that apparently has been going on for years.

title: A Trimmer Reagan Camp Starts a New Round and Looks Forward to Texas Primary
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4Ronald Reagan opens a new and possibly conclusive round this week in his effort to take the Republican nomination away from President Ford.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Nets' Reserves Sparkle
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 4  In what amounted to a vacation from the rigors of the American Basketball Association season, the Nets played a happygolucky game against the Virginia Squires this afternoon and won easily, 136103.

title: Messersmith Market Is Reopened
description: The San Diego Padres, owned by the hamburger magnate, Ray .Kroc, indicated yesterday they.were willing to make a substantial offer for Andy Messersmith, provided the 30yearold righthander passed a physical examination. The Padres president, E. J. (Buzzie) Bavasi and his son, Peter, spoke with Messersmith's agent, Herb Osmond, Saturday night and again yesterday morning, only hours after the New York Yankees had withdrawn their offer for him.

title: PREMIER OUSTED IN THAI ELECTION
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, April 5Prime Minister Kukrit Pramoj lost his office yesterday when he was defeated for reelection to his seat in the National Assembly in Thailand's second general election in little more than a year.

title: 6 Argentine Labor Leaders Are Tried on Arms Charges
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 4Six labor leaders accused of illegal possession of arms went on trial today before a martiallaw court of six officers in the Patagonian oil center, Comodoro Rivadavia.

title: Athletes In Action Takes A.A.U. Title
description: BATON ROUGE, April 4 (AP)Tim Hall scored 25 points and pulled down 14 rebounds today in leading Athletes in Action to the Amateur Athletic Union men's national basketball championship with a 9480 victory over the Armed Forces.

title: LongLocked Town Safe Yields Its Secrets
description: SOMERS, N.Y.; April 4For threequarters of a century the safe in the Town Hall of this once populous Westchester community remained closed, its combination lost in obscurity. Last Friday, at 3:30 P.M., it was finally cracked.

title: MassIckx Win Race
description: ROME, April 4 (AP)Jochen Mass and Jackie Ickx drove a Porsche 935 to victory today in the Vallelunga SixHour car race.

title: Saco, Me., Is Angered By Loss of a Gun Contract
description: SACO, Me., April 2"Politics, grumbled Norman Boissonnault, who has spent nearly 13 years shooting off machine guns here. That's the only word for it.

title: Margery Satz Wed to Stephen Swigert
description: The marriage of Margery Ann Satz, who is with Jarrin Design Inc., industrial designers, to Stephen Bruce Swigert, a lawyer withDebevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates, took place yesterday afternoon at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, N.J.

title: Welfare Leaders Urge Stavisky Veto Be Upheld
description: A group of child welfare and human services leaders yesterday urged the State Senate to uphold Governor Carey's veto of the StaviskyGoodman education bill, asserting the bill should be defeated to protect the children of New York City.

title: The Gloomy Side of the Historian Henry A. Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Henry A. Kissinger's world view has become a contentious campaign issue between President Ford and his challenger Ronald Reagan. Other Secretaries of State have been con troversial; what makes this dispute unusual is that Mr. Kissingees policies seem to come under less scrutiny than his philosophy.

title: Electrified Rail Service Proposed for Shore Area
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 4Railroad travelers would be offered hourly and highspeed direct railroad service from International Airport in Philadelphia to South Jersey Shore resorts if an ambitious railelectrification and new route package unveiled here becomes a reality.

title: David Pindyck, Who Operated Callanan Market 50 Years, Dies
description: David Pindyck, who for 50 years had owned and managed L. J. Callaman's market on Vesey Street, once a city landmark, died Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived at 320 Central Park West.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VILLAGE VOICES Eight writers, neighbors of the New York Public Library's Jefferson Market Regional Branch, will be featured in four literary Monday evening programs being presented at the landmark building, 425 Avenue of the Americas (at Ninth Street) as part of the library's Bicentennial celebration.

title: Opera: A Concert Carlo
description: One might have figured that the Symphony of the New World's concert. version of Don Carlo yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall would have been enough to give any Verdi textual purist a bad case of the hives. There was only two and a quarter hours worth of music from this sprawling masterpiece, after all, not counting the single intermission.

title: Has the Trainer Got the Stamina
Congress and Ford Differ on Nuclear Fuel Enrichment
description: An impasse appears to be developing between Congress and the White House over etforts to expand the nuclear fuel enrichment capacity of the United States in the 1980's.

title: Unsigned Yanks Get Even
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 4Twentyfour hours after dropping out of the freeagent market, the Yankees put some of their newly freed money to use today by restoring the 20 percent salary cuts in the renewed contracts of their six unsigned players.

title: Army vs. Brooklyn College Football: A $151.94 Bill
description: Last fall, the Brooklyn College football team was invited to Puerto Rico to play in the Coco bowl and returned to Flatbush with a 5012 victory over InterAmerican University. a silver trophy and a civic reception at Borough Hall.

title: Leaders in Albany Say Sunshine Bill Has Support of Majority in Both Houses
description: ALBANY, April 4State legislative leaders have agreed, on a new sunshine law" that would require all government meetings, at all levels, to bel open to the publicunless the unit meeting votes to conduct an executive session.

title: Primary Ballots Link Candidates to Delegates
A New Gadfly Keeps Eye on House
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Each day, just before the House of Representatives convenes at noon, a darkhaired man takes up position near the Republican leadership table on the House floor within grabbing distance of a microphone and begins his afternoon's vigil.

title: Miss Lippman Wed to R. A. McKee
description: Victoria Alexandra Lippman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Aaron Lippman of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert Andrew McKee, son of the Rey. and Mrs. Henry McKee of Bury, England.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state's County Prosecutors called for a ban on possession of handguns and sweeping reform in New Jersey's criminaljustice system. In a resolution unanimously adopted at its annual conventioh in Atlantic City, the New Jersey County Prosecutors Association urged passage of state and Federal bills that would make it illegal to manufacture, transport. and own handguns, except for lawen.forcement. officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's Arts and Leisure Section of The New York Times incorrectly said that former Gov. Jimmy Carter favors an antiabortion constitutional amendment. In fact, Mr. Carter has stated that although he has personal reservations about abortion he nevertheless suoports the Supreme Court ruling on the subject and does not favor A constitutional amendment to undo what the Supreme Court has done.

title: BRONX AGED GET A POLICE ESCORT
Maryland Fire Kills One
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md., April 14 (UPI)One person died, 10 persons were injured and 70 tam. ilies were evacuated in a fire here tonight at a highrise apartment building. The dead person was identified as Alberta Dolly 68 years old. Firemen said thp blaze was caused by gas vapors in a kitchen.

title: Thousands Mass in Peking, Seemingly to Oppose Antirightist Drive
description: PEKING, Monday, April 5 (Reuters)  Chanting crowds in the tens of thousands massed around Peking's Great Hall of the People today in a political demonstration in support of the late Prime Minister Chou Enlai.

title: Cosmos and Aztecs Play Scoreless Tie
description: TEMPE, Ariz., April 4 (AP) The New York Cosmos and Los Angeles Aztecs battled to a scoreless tie in a North American Soccer League exhibition game today.

title: Scientists and Laymen Discuss Ways to Increase Public's Role in Making LongTerm Health Policy
description: WARRENTON, Va., April 4Last fall, two United States Senators expressed fears that medical progress could be hindered by a rift that was developing between scientific researchers and the public.

title: France Trails in Race for Mideast Trade
description: PARIS, April 4France is lagging behind major competitors in building up export markets in the Middle East despite its proArab policies, comparative trade statistics show.

title: East Germans Grow Frustrated Under Restrictions
description: EAST BERLINA mood of anxious frustration about the economic and political future seems to pervade East Germany as the country's Communist Party prepares for its ninth congress in May.

title: Chirac Gaining Support of CenterRight For His Drive Against France's Leftists
description: PARIS, April 4Less than two weeks after rumors spread here among knowledgeable politicians that Jacques Chirac was about to be ousted as Prime Minister, he is emerging as the embodiment of the hope of the centerright coalition for keeping the power it has wielded in France for 18 years.

title: Musings About a Village, and About Other Things, Too
description: WILMINGTON, OhioI've an eye for the minor ironies. Friends say this might be fatal. They are doing advanced work in the major ironies. No matter, I say. Enough for all. I myself live in three rooms, work small. I hear there are large topics in the world but this could be hearsay.

title: TV: Cave ft's Special FloundersUntil Mae West
description: The less said about most of tonight's Dick Cavett special, the betteror at least the less_gmbarrassigg for Mr. Cavett, who has betome TV's most prominent character in search of a format. For his latest hour, wmcn can De seen on CBS at 10, the former talkshow host goes on location to the Hollywood backlot areas of Paramount Studios. Wrapped in some tired sophomoric musings (what is more realthe world out here or the images created on movie back lots?), the show puts Mr. Cavett through some curiously humiliating turns.

title: Students Organize A Lobby to Seek More Federal Aid
description: Students at a number of private colleges and universities, concerned that rising tuition will keep middleincome and lowerincome students from attending independent schools, have formed a national organk zation to lobby for increased student aid from the Federal Government.

title: Discount on Tennis For Married Pairs Ruled Out by State
description: A Queens tennis club has discontinued a special annual membership rate for married couples and has dropped all references to marital status in its rates, application forms and advertising, under a conciliation agreement arranged by the State Division of Human Rights.

title: Israel Had 13 ABombs In 1973 War, Time Says
description: TIME magazine reports in its latest issue that israel has 13 atomic bombs that were hastly assembled and made ready for use during the middle east war of 1973 when the battle was going badly for the Israeli's

title: What Is An Aardvark?
description: Here is a simple test for aspirants to elected office. It is intended to reveal general, as against specialized knowledge. Score two points for each correct answer; a score of 80 is passing. Those candidates who cannot equal or better that grade should immediately fall silent and disappear.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mel Patrick Lynch, accused in the kidnapping of Samuel Bronfman II, heir to the Seagram's fortune, made an unsuccessful attempt to escape from police custody last night.

title: Greece Seeks Aid Parity With Turkey
description: ATHENS, April 5 Greece wants an American aid package comparable in size and duration to the one that Washington promised to Turkey last week, according to wellinformed diplomatic sources.

title: ExBoxer Hurt in Tub LOS ANGELES, April 5
description: (AP)  The former world lightweight champion, Mando Ramos, was in stable condition today in, the intensive care ward at Northridge Hospital after suffering head injuries in a bathtub fall yesterday, a hospital spokesman said.

title: W.G. PENFIELD, NEUROLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Wilder G. Penfield, one of the world's foremost neurologists who honed surgical techniques for treating epilepsy, died yesterday of abdominal cancer at Royal Victoria Hospital in Montreal. He was 85 years old.

title: 4 Ballets Seek to Manage City Center
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet and the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater will propose today that management of the City Center 55th Street Theater be turned over to them and to two Miter dance companies.

title: Agency Plans Trial Of People Movers In Three U.S. Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The Urban Mass Transportation Administration announced today that it would help finance the construction of fully automated people mover systems in as many as three cities this fall.

title: SHEA TO TESTIFY AT BANK'S TRIAL
description: A judge in Federal District Court, Brooklyn refused yesterday to bar testimony by William A. Sheaa major power in Democratic Party politics in the state and lawyer for the Security National Bank, which is on trial along with three of its former top officers on charges of violating Federal election laws.

title: Dunn, August Fight Today
description: LONDON, April 5 (UPI) The vacant European heavyweight boxing title goes on the line tomorrow when Bernd August, the West German champion, and Richard Dunn, the British champion, meet in a I5round bout at the Royal Albert Hall. For Dunn there will be more than a $60,000 purse and European title at stake. The 31yearold former paratrooper must win to clinch a world title match against Muhammad All in Munich May 25.

title: Esprit of Queens College Falls Victim to Budget Ax
description: A year ago Joseph S. Murphy, the president of Queens College, said that his institution had become the best passport to the middle class. Today it is a ticket to a less certain destination.

title: Dispute Over Choice of New Lebanese President Stalls Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 5 Lebanon's leftistMoslem alliance and Syria were locked today in a growing dispute over the choice of Lebanon's new President.

title: White House Denies Aim Of Easing Kissinger Out
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The White House press secretary denied today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was being eased out of the Ford Administration.

title: ARGENTINA PLANS FREER ECONOMY
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 5 Argentina's Minister of the Economy says the new military Government's economic recovery program will stress a return to private enterprise principles.,

title: Advertising
description: The people behind Gallery magazine, intentionally designed as an imitation of Playboy, have now come up with a magazine for women aimed at Cosmopolitan's lucrative.market. As a matter of fact, the cover of the first issue (May) of New Dawn shows a young woman tearing Helen Gurley Brown's brainchild in half.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Jackson On Rights
description: Senator Henry Jackson cam???aigned through Queens last week in pursuit of the twotoone victory he had predicted in the New York Presidential primary. Mr. Jackson was promising to do something about unemployment when a number of demonstrators for homosexual rights began to harass him.

title: Meyer Davis, Orchestra Leader, Dies
description: Meyer Davis, for half a century the Toscaniniand J. P. Morgan  of society band leaders, died yesterday in his home at 101 Central Park West. Hp yas 81 years old.

title: N.L. Picks 2 Umpires
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP) The National League today selected two rookieumpires. Jim Quick and Ed Montague, to replace Chris Pelekoudas and Shag Crawford, who retired after last season.

title: Jersey Utility Aide Asks Compassion On Bill Nonpayment
News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Issue and Debate
description: Last Thursday, Rhode Island stunned the racing world by telling its two thoroughbred tracks they would get no more parimutuel dates until they had merged or renovated their facilities.

title: Red Wing Injured
description: DETROIT, April'5 (UPI) Bill Lochead of the Detroit Red Wings may be immobilized for about four months as the result of an auto accident last night, the National Hockey League Club announced today. General Manager Alex Delvecchio said the right wing sustained neck injury in the crash that may require surgery.

title: Life of Howard Hughes Was Marked by a Series of Bizarre and Dramatic Events
N.H.L. Clubs Set To Open Playoffs
description: It took 18 National Hockey League teams 720 games and six month to do it, but they finally managed to come up with the 12 clubs to compete for the ultimate prize, the Stanley Cup, starting tonight. Believe it or not, the 80th and final game on every qualifier's schedule became the one that determined who would play whom in the twoofthreegame firstround series. It also took that long to learn that Chicago had finished first in the Smythe Division and joined Montreal, Philadelphia and Boston in gaining firstround byes.

title: Doctor Takes Florida Job
description: TALLAFIASSEE, Fla., April 5 (UPI) Emile D. Hemming, bead of the depariment of MA. Irma child nursing at Rutgers university, today was named dean OP school or nursing at Florida Slate University. Dr. !lemming has degrees from Columbia University and 25 N.ears ??? In the nurrsing pio. frssion and nursing education.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Tektronix Inc., Beaverton, Ore., said yesterday it planned to register 400,000 common shares in a secondary offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said the selling shareholder would be M. J. Murdock Charitable Trust which now holds 999,250 common shares of Tektronix.

title: Nyquist Follows Lackawanna's Integration Blueprint
description: ALBANY, April 5  State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist today issued a school integration order for Lackawanna, the dusty steel town on Buffalo's southern line, that incorporates most of the prcposals submitted by the local board there.

title: Strike's End Lifts Amex and Counter; Trading Moderate
description: Encouraged by the weekend settlement of the nationwide trucking strike, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market registered gains yesterday in moderate trading.

title: U.S. Plans Outlined
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) Under Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco refused today to rule out the possibility of American intervention in Lebanon, although he told Congress that there were no United States plans for action beyond evacuating American refugees.

title: The ExpectorGeneral
description: The papers say Senator Jackson is expected to win the New York primary, but they do not tell us who it who is doing the expecting. This is a vital omission, as a moment's reflection will illustrate.

title: State Dept. Summary of Remarks by Sonnenfeldt
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Following is the official State Department summary of remarks made by Helmut Sonnenfeldt, counselor to the department, at a meeting in London last December of American ambassadors in Europe.

title: U.S. Diplomat in Moscow Accosted Outside Theater
description: MOSCOW, April 6 A senior American diplomat was surrounded tonight by six or seven Russian men who grabbed his jacket and threatened him with retaliation for the harassment of Soviet diplomats by Jewish demonstrators in New York.

title: DR. GEORGE B. WILBUR
description: Dr. George Browning Wilbur, a retired psychoanalyst of South Dennis, Mass., and former editor and publisher of American Imago, a psychoanalytical Journal, died Saturday in a nursing home in Hyannis, Mass. He was 88 years old.

title: Prime Minister Callaghan
description: James Callaghan has become Britain's Prime Minister a few days after his 64th birthday because most of his Labor colleagues in the House of Commons decided he was best equipped among the possible choices to hold together a factionridden party and a shaky Government. It is no derogation of this able and immensely likable man to put it in these terms; but it does help fix the dimensions of accomplishment that it will be reasonable to expect from a Callaghan administration.

title: Benton &
description: Benton & Bowles has just become the agency for Peter Eckrich & Sons, a division of Beatrice Foods. The company, based in Fort Wayne, Ind., is a major manufacturer of processed meats.

title: Professor at Yale Will Make Westerns for Television
description: Howard R. Lamar, a professor of American history at Yale University, is becoming a television producer. He's going to make westerns.

title: Cuban, a Defector in Angola, Hijacks Airliner to Lisbon and Seeks Asylum
description: LISBON, April 5 A Cuban soldier has defected from his country's forces in Angola and requested political asylum here.

title: CITY LOANS TIED TO TRANSIT TRUCE
description: Beame administration officials said yesterday that an unstated but important factor In the transit settlement last week, was the concern that !a strike could have ruined the state's plan for a spring borrowing crucial to the city's need to raise cash for its Federal loan obligations.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters) President Ford asked the Senate today to ratify the 1976 international coffee agreement. The main aim of the pact is to restore world production to adequate levels after failure of the Brazilian crop last year.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CINEMA CITY A New York that is tough and tender, seamy and sophisticated is the theme of the new spring array of movie revivals, photographed entirely or partly in the city, starting tonight at 6 o'clock at the Downtown Film Club of the Seamen's Church Institute, 15 State Street at Battery Park,

title: The Jewish Voter In New York's Poll
description: More than anything else, what sets the Presidential primary in New York apart from all others is the influence of the Jewish voter. An insignificant political minority in most states, the Jews are a special dimension here, like the retired people in Florida, the independents who can vote in either primary in Wisconsin and the highly organized auto workers in Michigan.

title: Dr. King's Widow Is at Preview Of I Have a Dream in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Fighting back tears after a prelew showing of I Have a Dream, the widow of the slain; CiVil rights leader, the Revd Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., led a theater audience tonight in singing We Shall Overcome."

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Island Ease
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West IndiesOther Caribbean islands may offer better bonefishing, billfishing, or angling for tarpon, but none combines these endeavors with the easy warmth of Grand Cayman's residents.

title: HIGH COURT DENIES APPEAL BY CALLEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The Supreme Court refused today to review the courtmartial conviction of former Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of 22 civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of My Lai in 1968.

title: Times Unifies Its News and Sunday Departments
description: Immediate unification of the news department and the Sunday department of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher. The combined department, which will retain the name news department, will be headed by A. M. Rosenthal, the managing editor.

title: Russian Is Reported Arrested In Yugoslavia on Spying Charge
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 5 A Soviet woman working in Yugoslavia has been detained for the last two Months on charges of spying for the Soviet Union, qualified informants said today.

title: Recital: Vivian Taylor
description: Any superior solo performer possesses a welldeveloped sense of fantasy, an ability to fall easily and quickly under the spell of the composerto the extent that the composer has a spell to cast at all. This is an inborn gift, no doubt, and probably goes far toward separating similarly talented musicians into the categories of successful and unsuccess. ful public performers. Vivian Taylor, who gave a piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night, chose a program that stressed her awareness of the importance of musical fantasy.

title: City U. Board Acts To Save John Jay; Students in Protest
description: Acting on its controversial austerity program to restructure the City University, the Board of Higher Education voted last night to close or merge several of its colleges but accepted a modification that would allow John Jay College to remain open with a diminished enrollment.

title: E.C.A.C. Hails Rutgers
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., April 5 (AP) Rutgers, undefeated in the regular season, was named basketball team of the year by the Eastern College Athletic Conference today. The University of Bridgeport, Cheyney State College and Philadelphia Textile shared Division II honors and Scranton University won the Devision III award.

title: Two Japanese Off to U.S. In Lockheed Investigation
description: TOKYO, April 5 (AP)  Two Japanese public prosecutors left fnr Washington today to receive information about alleged payoffs In Japan by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Helping New York
description: An increasing number of distraught people have begun visiting the basement offices of Famil, a new volunteer service at 356 East 149th Street in the South Bronx, pour out their stories in the hope that a group of volunteers will be able to restore their lives to order.

title: Issues 76: Liberty
description: Each person possesses an inviolability founded on justice that even the welfare of society as a whole cannot override, wrote the Harvard philosopher John Rawls a few years ago. Therefore in a just society the rights secured by justice are not subject to political bargaining or to the calculus of social interests.

title: Profits Rise 48.8% at Carter Hawley Hale in Quarter
CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in Friday's account in The New York Times of the opening of the New York State trout season, the caption line under the picture of a .father and son fishing the West Branch of the Croton River in Putnam County said that the creel of five fish displayed had been caught in that stream. That was incorrect, and the fish, as the story noted, were taken elsewhere. The West Branch, from the West Branch Reservoir downstream to Croton Falls, is a trophy trout stream and the daily bag limit per person is three trout 12 inches or more long,

title: LOU GORDON
description: CHICAGO, April 5 (UPI)  Lou Gordon, a former allAmerica football tackle at the University of Illinois and an eightyear player in the National Football League, died yesterday in Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Oil Prospects Off Jersey Encouraging
description: The prospect of finding oil and gas under offshore sites in the Atlantic Ocean is very encouraging, according to the first reports from an exploratory well sunk by a consortium of petroleum companies 80 miles off the New Jersey coast.

title: Union to End NBC Strike; Network May Bar Return
description: Members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians who have been on strike against the National Broadcasting Company since last week were told by their leadership yesterday Ito return to work early tomorrow morning.

title: Harris Sure He Can Get Some Delegates in Nev York
description: Fred R. Harris slightly more subdued than in his previous local appearances as a Presidential candidate but professing optimism that we can get some delegates in today's Democratic primarymade hasty preelection visit to New York yesterday.

title: Soviet Sees Political Link
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 (AP) The Soviet Union charged today that an escalation of heated antiSoviet hysteria in the United States presidential race was responsible for a wave of antiSoviet harassment and violence in New York.

title: Defense Policy Debate
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Perhaps it was inevitable in al political year, but what started off as an important policy debate over the nation's basic defense posture has become lost in an argument over whether the United States or the Soviet Union is No. 1 militarily. It is an argument that has become one of the major issues between President Ford and Ronald Reagan in the Republican Presidential primaries. And it is an argument thai is impelling Congress to approve a $14 billion increase in the defense budget with little or no cuts in the $113 billion requested by the Ford Administration.

title: Reagan Appeal Nets $200,000 So Far
description: DALLAS, April 5  Ronald Reagan's nationally televised appeal for campaign funds has so far brought in more than $200,000 in contributions, the Republican candidate's aides reported today, and the expectation was that the figure would substantially increase by the time all the mail is counted.

title: Fire Kills 3 in French Port
description: SAINTNAZAIRE, France, April 5 (AP) An explosion and fire tonight in an oil refinery near this Atlantic coast port killed at least three men official sources said. The police reported one man missing and that about 10 were seriously injured.

title: Stage: Lanford Wilson's Early Rimers of Eldritch
49ers Acquire Plunkett
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP) Jim Plunkett, who missed most of last season because of injuries, became a San Francisco 49er today in a trade with the New England Patriots.

title: Bomber Slain in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 5 (ANA police reservist shot to death a man who tool.. part in one of a serrs of hornli attacks in the Belfas area today, the police reported.

title: Rhodesians Report Killing 13 Guerrillas in 4 Days
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 5 (AP)  Rhodesian security forces killed eight black nationalist guerrillas in the last four days, a Government communlaue said today.

title: Senate Bill Approves Anonymity for Victims of Rape
Doubles Team Talks Its Way To No. 1 on Women's Circuit
description: Sometimes it may appear to be more like baseball than tennis, as if it were a conference at the pitcher's mound. But as a result of their frequent discussions during action, Ann Kiyomura and Mona Guerrant have bedtime the most successful doubles team on the women's circuit this season.

title: GUILTY PLEA IS MADE IN CASE ON SHIP LOAN
description: Michael A. Panayotopulos of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., president of Interconfinental Mining and Abrasives Inc., admited yesterday that he made a false statement in 1972 about a ship charter to get a Chemical Bank loan of $343,000 for his corporation.

title: A Modified Soviet Bloc Is Avowed as U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Helmut Sonnenfeldt, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's chief adviser, told American ambassadors in Europe that it is in the longterm interest of the United States to encourage East European countries to develop a more natural and organic relationship with the Soviet Union, according to an official but nonverbatim summary of his remarks.

title: Spreading San Francisco Strike Strands 15,000 More Students
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (UPI) School buses were halted and most taxicabs idled today in San Francisco's growing transportation tieup resulting from a strike of craft workers employed by the city.

title: RapidAmerican to Settle 2 Suits for Up to $8 Million
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation and its McCrory subsidiary have agreed to make a settlement of at least $4 million and as much as $8 million in two classaction suits charging that a McCrory proxy statement issued in connection with a 1973 merger with the Lerner Stores Corporation had false and misleading statements.

title: U.S. Fighter, 23, Dies
description: SYDNEY. Ausralia, April 5 (Tuesday) (UPI) Chuck Wilburn, an American boxer Injured in a bout last week with Hector Thompson of Australia died today, hospital officials reported. Wilburn 23 years old, never regained consciousness. After being knocked out in a 10round bout last Thursday.

title: In Bergman Film, Beauty and Agony
Presidential Challengers Diverge on Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The foreign policy and defense catchphrases of the Presidential challengers have become virtually identical, but the slogans blur the decidedly different Visions each holds of the future role of the United States in the world.

title: Greenspan Doubts Teamsters Accord Is Inflationary, but Analysts Disagree
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Alan Greenspan, the Administration's top economist, today appraised the new contract between the teamsters union and the trucking companies as somewhat higher than I would have liked to see but not one that would add to inflationary forces.

title: NORMANN HERR
description: Normann Herr, president of the Bayonne Steel Products Company Inc., of Totowa, N.J., died on Saturday during a visit to St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. He was 61 years old and lived at 280 Hutchinson Road, Englewood, N..J.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Skidmore College student was killed and four others, including an 18yearold student from New Jersey, were seriously injured in a predawn fire that swept through a dormitory on the Saratoga Springs, N. Y., campus. The dean girt was Identifien as Judy Smith, 20 years old, of Harrisburg, Pa. Susan Miller, a freshman from Wayne, was one of four students seriously hurt in the fire, which broke out in Wilmarth Hall, a threestory coed dormitory built 1966. Fifteen other students were hospitalized and about 40 were treated for smoke inhalation at the scene, according to officials, who said the fire had begun in a firstfloot room used to store garbage.

title: NEW THAI REGIME COULD BE PROU.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 5 (AP) Thailand today appeared headed for a moderate, proAmerican Government as a result of general elections yesterday that gave the opposition Democratic Party a clear mandate to govern.

title: The Great Schism
description: BERKELEY, Calif.The first great schism in the Communist church"a doctrinal split that was to have major political consequencesoccurred when Mao Tsetung broke with MarxismLeninismStalinism as practiced and preached in Moscow. The Maoist vision was of a truly honest, simple, modest and classless societynot one dominated by a new class of selfrewarding bureaucrats and superproletarians.

title: Loss Laid to Uncertainties in Political SituationDollar Is Up Slightly
Bonn Sees No Significance in State Vote
description: BONN, April 5West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, said in an interview after his party's defeat yesterday in a state election, that he would take the loss seriously but added that the election was not fought on matters of national policy.

title: Two Berths Still Open In N.B.A.
description: A total of 30 games remain on the National Basketball Association regularseason schedule and 25 will have a bearing on determining the e remaining two playoff berths. the S50,000 for the learn witht the league's best wonlost record and the important homecourt advantages.

title: Detroit Local Defiant
description: DETROIT, April 5 (UPI) More than 3,000 Detroit area teamsters shouted defiance at their local union leaders today and vowed to continue their strike in spite of a national contract settlement.

title: Maloney Trial June 23
description: TORONTO, April 5 (AP) Dan Maloney of the Detroit Red Wings will stand trial June 23 on assault charges stemming from a National Hockey League game here last November in which Maloney allegedly caused bodily harm to Brian Glennie of the Maple Leafs.

title: Selection Process Offers Glimpse Into Labor Party
description: LONDON, April 5 The vote today that produced Britain's new Prime Minister also told much about the way the major parties go about choosing their leaders, and raised questions and even a few criticisms about that process.

title: FLU IMMUNIZATION BACKED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  Two flu bills, one authorizing a nationwide immunization program this fall and the other appropriating $135 million for it as sought by President Ford, were passed today by the House and sent to the Senate.

title: City Strike Threatens Giants'
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5  Those who believed that the San Francisco Giants, after so many tumultuous months, were out of the woods, now find that there may be a huge booby trap at the edge of the forest.

title: Some Spontaneity Is Seen
description: HONG KONG, April 5The violent protests in Tien An Men Square were viewed here today as spontaneous, at least in part.

title: Callahan, Party's Choice, Is Prime Minister of Britain
description: LONDON, April 5James Callaghan, the Foreign Secretary, was chosen today as Britain's new Prime Minister. He promptly called on the divided factions of his party to unify behind efforts to rescue Britain from its longterm economic decline.

title: WABCTV Wins Appeal on Report on Children's Home on S.I.
description: Ruling that nothing on a WABC,TV videotape depicting conditions in a Staten Island children's home warranted a prior restraint on its broadcast, the Appellate Division yesterday affirmed the station's right to show it.

title: PHYSICIAN SCORES MANPOWER PLAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5 The president of the American College of Physicians said today that proposed legislation to regulate health manpower might not correct the problem of poor physician distribution.

title: CHANGE RESISTED ON FOOD STAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The Senate resisted efforts by conservative members today to pare down participation in the foodstamp program, defeating three amendments to a disputed reform bill.

title: Cunningham Stays Idle
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5, (AP) Billy Cunningham, a forward for the Philadelphia 76ers will miss the National Basketball Association playoffs because of his knee injury, the team announced today. Cunningham has been idle since he tore cartilage in his left knee in a game with the Knicks Dec. 5.

title: Esprit of Queens College Falls Victim to Budget Ax
description: A year ago Joseph S. Murphy, the president of Queens College, said that his institution had become the best passport to the middle class. Today it is a ticket to a less certain destination.

title: Mets, Seaver Agree To a 3Year Contract
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 5 After two negotiating sessions in the groundskeeper's office under the third base stands at Fort Lauderdale Stadium tonight, Tom Seaver and the Mets agreed to a threeyear contract that the Mets said would make Seaver the first pitcher in baseball to reach the $200,000ayear level.

title: Recital
description: William Tim Read's recital Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall was billed as being for harpsichord and celestial clavichord, which might already have been enough to make rightthinking folk nervous. As it turned out, Mr. Read plays both the harpaichord and the clavichord very well, but he needs to rethink his notions of amplification and he very definitely needs a new covvwriter. His harpsichord selections Handel's Suite.No. 2 in F, James Hewitt's amusingly programmatic The Battle of Trenton and a nice French pairing of Champion de Chambonnieres's Chaconne in F and a furious Medee by Jacques Duphly (17151789) went very well indeed, fluently played and lavishly ornamented in a manner that never sounded stilted or affected,

title: Hughes Seen By 2 Pilots As Worn Out
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 5 (AP) When Howard R. Hughes was put aboard an air ambulance in Acapulco, Mexico, today, he looked wasted and like a tired wornout old person, according to Jeff Abrams, the copilot of the jet.

title: California Assembly Acts To Curb Atomic Plants
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.. April 5 (UPI) The State Assembly, in an unprecedented move, approved and sent to the Senate today legislation to place severe restrictions on the future construction of atomic power plants in California,

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed at Weekly Sale
FRENCH WEIGHING BEIRUT MEDIATION
description: PARIS, April 5 France will probably agree to an appeal by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt for a mediator in Lebanon, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: 100 in Capital Evacuate Subway in Breakdown
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The short opening leg of the capital's Metro subway system, which drew nearly three times more riders in its first week of operation than transit officials had expected, experienced a long breakdown this afternoon that forced the evacuation on foot of about 100 passengers stranded for more than an hour aboard a stalled train.

title: SHEA TO TESTIFY AT BANK'S TRIAL
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn refused yesterday to bar testimony by William A. Sheaa major power in Democratic Party politics in the state and lawyer for the Security National Bank, which is on trial along with three of its former top officers on charges of violating Federal election laws.

title: 100 Restaurants to Join in Central Park Food Fiesta
description: One hundred of the city's restaurants will offer a taste of the Big Apple o.n May 22 at a daylong festival in Central Park.

title: Howard Hughes Dies at 70 On Flight to Texas Hospital
description: HOUSTON, April 5 Howard R. Hughes died today as mysteriously as he had lived.

title: Philadelphia fire Kills One
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5, (AP)One woman was killed, four others were injured and 300 persons had to flee early today when fire broke out in a 32story luxury apartment building in the city's Society Hill section. The dead woman was identified as 5hirley Ingber, 50 years old.

title: Bank Officer Snatches Robber's Bag of Loot
description: The operations officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 221 Park Avenue South at 18th Street yesterday chased a bank robber for four blocks, then snatched away a bag containing $3,609 in loot.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: New U.S. Cemetery Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April (AP)  The House paqqed end sent to the Senate today a bill thast would eqtahlich a new nation cemetery at Quanten, Va.. 30 miles south Washinetna, le vole wag 31R to S. The cemetery would use about 620 acres of the Marine Cornq reservation at Quantico Tly hill atithor17est $2.1 million for development.

title: 31 SAID TO ESCAPE FROM SPANISH JAIL
description: MADRID, April 5 Thirtyone political prisoners, almost all of them Basques serving long terms, were reported tonight to have broken out of Segovia prison in one of the most spectacular acts of defiance yet staged by the Basque nationalist organization E.T.A.

title: Schorr to Receive Award By National Headliner Club
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 5 (AP)Daniel Schorr's report on the Central Intelligence Agency for his CBS radio network is among the winners of this year's National Headliner Club achievement awards.

title: Hair Codes for Policemen Upheld by Supreme Court
description: The United States Supreme Court ruled yesterday that police departments had the right to order police officers to wear their hair short and not to wear beards.

title: ASARCO IS RAISING CADMIUM PRICES
description: Asarco Inc., announced yesterday an increase of 25 cents a pound for cadmium products. This will make the new price for cadmium metal and oxide in ton lots $2.75 a pound delivered in the continental United States. On March 8, Asarco, the leading producer, had raised its cadmium price by 50 cents a pound to the $2.50 level. It was then followed by the St. Joe Minerals Corporation. Yesterday the other producers took no action on pricing.

title: Wheat Futures Up; Advance Is Shown In Corn, Soybeans
description: After a weak opening, wheat prices rose yesterday after some purchases by the Continental Grain Company. May wheat closed at $3,49 a bushel, up from $3.47 on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Industry Gains Bypass A.M.C.
description: DETROIT, April 5  The United States auto industry is making a comeback, with car sales up 33 percent this year, and Chrysler, General Motors and Ford are showing big gains. Rut, far from taking part in the comeback, American Motors has lost ground.

title: Reporters Notebook: Carter Group Uses Diplomacy in Reporting Endorsements
description: Endorsements from different quarters is an important part of any Presidential primary campaign, and getting them often requires the most exquisite diplomacy.

title: Doctor Asks Court to Overturn His Conviction in Fetus Death
description: BOSTON, April 5 The highest court in Massachusetts took under advisement today arguments that it should overturn the widely publicized conviction of Dr. Kenneth Edelin. the Boston City Hospital physician who was found guilty of killing an unborn fetus in a legal abortion here in 1973.

title: Dunk Shot Back For College Fives
description: Dunk shots are back in college baseketball  proof that memories of Lew Alcindor (Kareem AbdulJabbar) no longer haunt those who played against the University of California, Los Angeles. in the late 1960's. The stuff shot was outlawed for high school and college basketball in March, 1967, two days after Alcindor led U.C.L.A. to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship at the end of his sophomore or first varsity season. Nine years later the National Basketball Rules Committee reinstituted the dunk. The action was taken last week.

title: Board Votes to Go Ahead With Restructuring City. U.
description: The Board of Higher Education moved formally last night to approve its longawaited plan for reducing the scope of the City University by closing or reducing several of the system's colleges.

title: MURIEL L. HlNERFELD
description: Muriel Lesser Hinerfeld, executive vice president of Hiram Halle Memorial Library in Pound Ridge, N.Y., died yesterday of cancer in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 59 years old, the wife of Joseph B. Hinerfeld, a retired executive, and lived on Trinity Pass in Pound Ridge.

title: Barbara Walters Meets With ABC on News Show
description: Barbara Walters, for 13 years a star of NBC's Today show, confirmed yesterday that she had met with ABC officials to discuss the possibility of coanchoring the ABC Evening News with Harry Reasoner.

title: Brooklyn School Reports Epidemic of Head Lice
description: The principal of an elementary school in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn said ;yesterday that an outbreak of i head lice and nits among the 'school's student body had reached epidemic proportions and was affecting school morale and instruction.

title: City U. Board Votes to Retain John Jay
State Spring Loan Prospectus Issued
description: ALBANY, April 5  After weeks of legal wrangling, the state government and the major New York City banks today published and distributed to scores of banks and corporations around the country an 82page prospectus opening the final phase of the state's effort to meet its critical spring borrowing requirements.

title: Older Americans Month
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  President Ford proclaimed the month of May as older Americans month and called today for an end to the myths and prejudices about the capabilities of such citizens.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Violent demonstrations, apparently in support of former Prime Minister Chou Enlai and his associates were staged through the day yesterday in Peking's Tien An Men Square, and few attempts were made to stop them. Unarmed troops and workers militiamen tried to maintain order but were careful to avoid clashes, Authorities made no attempt to break up the crowds, apparently hoping that the demonstrators would disperse quietly. The demonstrations appeared to be a backlash to the socalled antirightist campaign begun as part of the power struggle in the Chinese leadership after Mr. Chou died in [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Flu Vaccine
description: A wellknown advantage of being President before a Presidential election is the ability to use the office and its power to build a positive image before the voters. President Ford mayor may nothave considered, least for a fleeting moment, the political dividends being seen as the savior of the American people's health when he decided to call for a $135 million rush program to vaccinate every person in this country against a new type of influenza virus.

title: People and Business
description: John J. McCloy, who headed a committee that investigated illegal political payoffs by the Gulf Oil Corporation, said yesterday that corporate attitudes on foreign payoffs had undergone a revolutionary change since recent public disclosures of the slush funds and suggested that Congress delay enacting any new legislation to remedy these ills.

title: Honolulu Curbs Smoking
description: HONOLULU, April 5 (UPI) Smoking is now banned in city meeting rooms, auditoriums and elevators. Violators will receive a police citation and can be fined up to $25. The ordinance, which went into effect yesterday, does not apply to city offices, restrooms or unenclosed areas, such as corridors or courtyards.

title: Adin A. Brown, Engineer With American Smelting
description: Adin A. Brown, a mining engineer who retired in 1963 as a vice president and director of American Smelting and Refining Company, now Asarco Inc., died Sunday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 78 years old.

title: WALTER A. GORDON OF VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: Walter Arthur Gordon, Governor of the Virgin Islands from 1955 to 1958, died Thursday at the age of 81 in Oakland, Calif.

title: Hair Codes for Policemen Upheld by Supreme Court
description: The United States Supreme Court ruled yesterday that police departments had the right to order police officers to wear their hair short and not to wear beards.

title: Callaghan, Party's Choice, Is Prime Minister of Britain
description: LONDON, April 5 James Callaghan, the Foreign Secretary, was chosen today as Britain's new Prime Minister. He promptly called on the divided factions of his party to unify behind efforts to rescue Britain from its longterm economic decline.

title: 18 More Food Spots CitedAs Health Code Violators
Athens Airline Walkout
description: ATHENS, April 5 (AP)Employees of foreign airline com panies in Greece began a fouPday strike today for higher pay, halting most of their airlines flights. The airlines struck were T.W.A.. Air France, KLM, Alitalia, Swissair, Sabena and SAS.

title: ONE KILLED, 8 HURT IN ALASKA AIR CRASH
Kaden Is Resigning As Byrne Counsel
description: TRENTON, April 5 Governor Byrne announced to day that his special counsel, Lewis B. Kaden, was resigning from the Governor's office, but would retain his ties with state government.

title: Hunger Strike Continues In Beacon Mental Hospital
description: BEACON, N.Y., April 5 A hunger strike of inmates at the Matteawan State Hospital for mentally ill prisoners entered its third day today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in Friday's account in The New York Times of the opening of the New York State trout season, the caption line under the picture of a father and son fishing the West Branch of the Croton River in Putnam County said that the creel of five fish displaye4 had been caught in that stream. That was incorrect, and the fish, as the story noted, were taken elsewhere. The West Branch, from the West Branch Reservoir downstream to Croton Falls, is a trophy trout stream and the daily bag limit per person Is three trout 12 inches or more long.

title: Veronique, a Lovely and Fragile Film
Carter and Udall in Last Wisconsin Push
description: MILWAUKEE, April 5  It was tyinguplooseends day in Wisconsin today for Jimmy Carter and Morris K. Udall, the two Democratic frontrunners, who skipped about the state in a last breathless hunt for support in tomorrow's Presidential primary_

title: SST NOISE CURBS VIEWED AS A BAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) British and French Government and aircraft industry officials contended today that noise levels for supersonic planes proopsed by the Environmental Protection Agency were discriminatory and would ban the Concorde from American airports.

title: Laborites Unity Hope
description: LONDON, April 5 He is known as Sunny Jim, but his moods are sometimes dark and chilling. He is the only Cabinet official to serve in three key postsChancellor of the Exchequer, Home Secretary and Foreign Secretary. But broad success in each job proved elusive. He has wide support in the ideologically divided Labor Party, but few people seem actually enthusiastic about James Callaghan.

title: HIGH COURT DENIES APPEAL BY CALLEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Supreme Court refused today to review the courtmartial conviction of former Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of 22 civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of My Lai in 1968.

title: African Says Kissinger Won't Rule Events There
description: NAIROBI, April 5 (AP)A spokesman for 47 African nations said today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is not going to dictate the events taking place in southern Africa or the tempo of the changes sweeping through the continent.

title: Court Upholds Tenure Of Monmouth Counsel
description: TRENTON, April 5 (AP) The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that a Democraticcontrolled Board of, Freehoders in Monmouth County had no legal right to dismiss the . county counsel, who was a Republican appointee.

title: Michigan State Hires 2 Head Coaches
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., April 5 (UPI) Acting one week in advance of a selfimposed deadline, Michigan State University hired Darryl Rogers of San Jose State today its football coach and named Jud Heathcote of Montana basketball coach. The new coaches replace Denny Stoltz in football and Gus Ganakas, who were dismissed on the same day last month. Stolz was forced to resign for his involvement in a recruiting scandal and Ganakas was dropped for failing to measure up to the university's standards. The 40yearold Rogers has coached 14 years and the 48yearold Heathcote has coached for 25.

title: Peking Plans Investigations
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, April 6 A frontpage editorial in the official Chinese Communist party newspaper Jemmin Jih Pao called today for strict in vestigations into a small .handful of class enemies who were said to be spreading ruors and inciting the masses, and asked for determined nutacks against them..

title: Credit Market Prices Up; Treasury Bill Rates Drop
description: continuing the climb that got started last Thursday, the credit markets again rose in price yesterday. The advance came in two stagesfirst in the morning and then in the afternoon following the publication of the minutes of the Federal Reserve's policysetting Open Market Committee for its midFebruary meeting.

title: Britain Captures Davis Cup Series
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, April 5 (UPI)  Britain defeated Switzerland, 41, in their European Zone thirdround Davis Cup tennis series today.

title: U.S. Assays Peking Strife As Move Against Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  United States Government officials said today that the violent demonstrations in Peking appeared to represent a major counterattack by supporters of a moderate political policy against radicals who had appeared in the ascendency in China since Prime Minister Chou Enlai's death In January.

title: People in Sports
description: Roy Danforth's return to the South was only one of several moves made by basketball coaches yesterday. Danforth, the coach at Syracuse for the last eight seasons, during which he com. piled a 14871, wonlost record and led the Orangemen to six straight postseason tonrnItments, was namd the new coach at Tulane. He succeeds Charles Moir, who left to coach Virginia Tech.

title: Radioactive Material Falls
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April (AP) A truck carrying a container of radioactive material struck a railroad bridge overpass tonight, hut no radioactivity escaped, the State police said, because the container (lid not rupture. The incident occurred on Route 66 near Factory Street, according to the police.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK NEW YORK BACKING PRIMARY TODAY
description: The three major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination wound up their drives for today's New York primary with diverse campaigning yesterday that reflected their political priorities and strategy.

title: Belfast Hit by New Wave of Bombings
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 5 Seven bombs exploded within an hour in Belfast today, damaging two major hotels and other buildings. One of the I.R.A. bombers was shot dead.

title: Town Opposes Nuclear Ban
description: ASHFIELD, Mass. April 5 (AP) A proposed ordinance to ban the transportation of nuclear materials through this Franklin County community has been defeated at a town meeting. Residents voted 6155 against the ordinance after a long debate on nuclear power. Ashfield is about 10 miles west of Montague where Northeast Utilities has proposed building a twinreactor power plant.

title: Notes on People
description: The Theater Guild will stage a Broadway production based on Golda Meir's life story next year, Philip Langner president of the guild, said yesterday in Tel Aviv. He said his company had acquired dramatic rights to Mrs. Meir's recent bestselling autobiography, My Life, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Tours of Met Museum Conducted in Spanish
description: Spanishlanguage tours of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are now being conducted on Tuesdays and Saturdays at 2:30 P.M. under the sponsorship of the museum's community programs department.

title: Pell Given Honorary Degren
description: BOSTON April 5 (AP)Senator Claiborne Pcll, Democrat of Rhodc Island, has been awarded an honorary doctorate of humane ???ers from the Massachusells College of Optometry.

title: Howard Hughes Dies at 70 On Flight to Texas Hospital
description: HOUSTON, April 5 Howard R. Hughes died today as mysteriously as he had lived.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK NEW YORK BACKING IN PRIMARY TODAY
description: The three major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination wound up their drives for today's New York primary with diverse campaigning yesterday that reflected their political priorities and strategy.

title: CARTER FORCES LOSE BID FOR VOTE DELAY
description: Backers of Jimmy Carter lost their bid to postpone today's scheduled primary elections in a dozen of the state's Congressional districts when a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday evening that they had not presented a sufficiently convincinig case.

title: Books of The Times
description: When I was a child, Richard G. Abell 'says, my father used to take me out in the backyard and show me the moon through a telescope. Hell, I didn't want to see the moon. I was lonesome. I wanted him to put his arm around me and tell me he loved me. But his father was too uptight to do this. He was a disappointed intellectual who had given up a promising career in astronomy to help support 11 brothers and sisters. As a result, he could see his son only through the wrong end of a telescope.

title: Islanders Wary of Playoffs
description: The big jet returning the New York Islanders home took off in Atlanta's hot night air. In the humid, rear cabin the players slumped in the seats, ties askew, their faces showing fatigue, disappointment and apprehension.

title: U.N. BODY ACCUSES U.S. ON PARAGUAY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5  The International League for the Rights of Man accused the United States State, Department today of covering up evidence of atrocities corninitted by the Paraguayan Government of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.

title: PURCHASING STUDY SEES GOOD BUSINESS
description: The nation's purchasing managers believe that the next 12 months will bring very satisfactory business conditions despite some concern on price increases according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Seaver Accepts Pact
description: Tom Seaver agreed last night to a threeyear contract with the New York Mets that will pay the pitcher more than $200,000 a year. Seaver had two meetings with the Mets board chairman, M. Donald Grant, before agreeing to terms. Details, Page 43.

title: Town Opposes Nuclear Ban
description: ASHFIELD, Mass., April 5 (AP)A proposed ordinance to ban the transportation of nuclear materials through this Franklin County community has been defeated at a town meeting. Residents voted 6155 against the ordinance after a long debate on nuclear power. Ashfield is about 10 miles west of Montague where Northeast Utilities has proposed, building a twinreactor power plant.

title: Carey Says Cunningham Must Make Choice Soon
description: SYRACUSE, April 5Governor Carey, while insisting that it would be premature for him to say whether Patrick J. Cunningham should step down as Democratic state chairman, indicated growing impatience today with the effort by Mr. Cunningham to, quash a subpoena issued by the special state prosecutor.

title: Adam Smith Recognized Anew
description: GLASGOW, April 5 Some 200 prominent economists, paying homage to Adam Smith, ended a fourday observance here mainly in agreement that his economic philosophy is worth reading again after years of disregard by Socialist and liberal governments in the Western world.

title: The Heroine of the State Department's Women
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Mere mention of the name Alison Palmer produces an immediate groan from somebut then there are those others who call her pioneer, a heroine, not a troublemaker.

title: Waits Shortened, Checks Speeded for Unemployed
Eastern Trucking Group Cuts I.C.C. Rate Rise Bid
description: The Eastern Central Motor Carriers Association, representing some 1,200 trucking companies, has modified its request for a rate increase to 4 percent for truckload shipments from the 5 percent sought earlier and pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission. The Association said Yesterday that it had also cut to 6.5 percent from 8 percent the rate increase for less than truckload shipments.

title: Drop in Breast Feeding Causes Health Problems in Poor Countries
New BusStop Signs Due in Midtown Area
description: Starting tomorrow, 161 newly designed busstop and information signs will he installed in midtown as part of polit bustransit improvement program.

title: City's 1975 Jobless Rate Was 10.6%,the U.S.'s7.5
description: In a new confirmation of the, severity of the recession in New York City, the Bureau of Labor Statistics revealed yesterday that the average unemployment rate in the city last year was 10.6 percent cornpared with the national average of 7.5 percent.

title: DAVID DENNISON, PHYSICIST, WAS 75
description: Dr. David M. Dennison, a theoretical physicist whose principal research was in molecular structure and infrared spectroscopy, died in Ann Arbor, Mich., Saturday. He was 75 years old.

title: Hispanic Judge Is Confirmed
description: It was another first for John Jose Dios yesterday when his nomination by Governor Byrne for District Court judge in Essex County was confirmed by the State Senate, making him the first Hispanic state judge in New Jersey.

title: Averell Broughton, ExHead Of Public Relations Society
description: Averell Broughton, a retired advertisingagency owner who was the first president of the Public Relations Society of America when it was formed in 1949, died last Tuesday at his home in Cuernavaca, Mexico. He was in his late 70's.

title: No Shift in Policy Voted By Fed Unit on Feb. 17
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters) The Federal Open Market Committee voted no essential change in monetary policy at its meeting on Feb. 17, according to a summary of committee minutes issued today.

title: Summary of Actions of the Supreme Court Announced Yesterday
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Half a Food Stamp
description: The United States Senate will vote today on an amendment to the food stamp bill that makes Ebenezer Scrooge look like the Ford Foundation. Simply stated, the amendment is designed to cut food stamp usage Puerto Rico in half. It does so by a complicated formula that would make the nation's most depressed areas either slash the benefits provided or pay money back to the Federal Treasury.

title: F.T.C. WEIGHS CURB ION ADS FOR ANTACIDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was considering requiring makers of nonprescription antacid remedies to put the same warnings in advertisements they now must include on labels.

title: Market Place
description: There has been a great deal of talk about changing the tax consequences of option trading, but there is little agreement about what, if anything, should be done.

title: Paris at ReadytoWear Time: Lots of Jostling, Lots of Trends
description: PARIS, April 5Sorting out the trends at the French readytowear shows for fall is no easier than buying a blouse at Bloomingdale's. The trouble is not that the choice is limited, but rather that it is overwhelming.

title: A Modified Soviet Bloc Is Avowed as U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Helmut Sonnenfeldt, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's chief adviser, told American ambassadors in Europe that it is in the longterm interest of the United States to encourage East European countries to develop a more natural and organic relationship with the Soviet Union, according to an official but nonverbatim summary of his remarks.

title: Nets Beat Spurs, 104102, Led by Taylor's 29 Points
U.S. Assays Peking Strife As Move Against Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 United States Government offiIcials said today that the violent demonstrations in Peking appeared to represent a majOr counterattack by supporters of a moderate political policy against radicals who had appeared in the ascendency in China since Prime Minister Chou Entai's death in January.

title: West Point Cadet Is Arrested In Rape of Rockland Housewife
description: A firstyear student at West Point who started on the academy football team last fall was arrested Sunday and charged with the rape of Rockland County woman.

title: Israel Denies Time Report It Had 13 ABombs in 73
description: JERUSALEM, April 5 (AP Israeli repeated today that it was not a nuclear power, and renewed its pledge not to be the first to introduce nuclear weapons into the Middle East conflict.

title: Plan to Merge 2 State Offices Scored
description: ALBANY, April 5 A legislative plan to merge the Governor's Economic Development !Board and the Secretary of State's Office of Community Affairs was viewed today by officials here as jeopardizing the integrity and efficiency of both offices.

title: Calcutta on Hard Course: Trying to Lure Tourists
description: CALCUTTA, IndiaShanta. Banerjee has. what. she concedes is a difficult jobtrying to lure foreign,tourists to the troubled city of Calcutta.

title: BLACK NATIONALISTS 68 TARGETS OF F.B.I.
