description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of lnvestigation targeted three black groups in Cleveland for counterintelligence program disruptions in 1968 although agents said they had no information that the groups were actively planning violent protest, agency documents disclosed today.

title: After a Scolding, Senate Votes To Send 25 to Get Magna Carta
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  Following an angry lecture by Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader, the Senate did an aboutface today and agreed to send a delegation of 25 members of Congress to London to pick up an original copy of Magna Carta,

title: Dow Climbs 12.51 As Volume Widens
description: Powered initially by settlement of the nationwide trucking strike over the weekend, the stock market moved ahead sharply yesterday in accelerated trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead by 5 points at the end of the first hour, gained ground steadily during the session to finish at 1,004.09 with a sparkling advance of 12.51 points.

title: Leon Lowenstein, ExChairman Of Textile Company, Dead at 92
description: Leon Lowenstein, former president and chairman of M. Lowenstein, & Sons Inc., a major textile corporation founded by his father and brother in 1889,. died yesterday in Mount Sinai: Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 92 years old and lived. at 480 Park Avenue in New York and Lowenbrook Farm in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Testimony Links Inspection Irregularities to Two Explosions That Killed 26 in a Kentucky Coal Mine
description: WHITESBURG, Ky., April 5 ;A miner who worked in the Scotia Coal Company mine where 26 men died in two methane gas explosions last month testified at a Federal hearing today that he had temporarily adjusted ventilation curtains in the area of the first explosion to satisfy a Federal mine safety inspector who was making an onsite inspection.

title: Skidmore Student Dies In Fire, 4 Badly Hurt
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 5 (AP) A Skidmore College student was killed and four others were seriously injured this morning when fire broke out in a threestory dormitory on the new campus.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CHRISCRAFT CASE TO BE REVIEWED
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The Supreme Court agreed today to review a $36 million damage Judgment won by ChrisCraft Industries Inc. against the Bangor Punta Corporation. ChrisCraft charged that Bangor Punta had competed unfairly as the two sought control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation in 1969.

title: Secrecy Shrouds Hughes Empire's Fate
description: SAN FRANCISCO. April 5 As the death of Howard R. Hughes was disclosed tonight. the ultimate disposition of his vast wealth was as big a secret as his personal life had been during his last years.

title: Lutheran College Head Resigns After Dispute
description: In a development that could hasten a formal schism in th Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, the president of th church's Concordia College in Bronxville, N.Y., has stepped down after a disagreement with the school's board.

title: Journalists Ruled Not Professionals
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that newspaper journalists were not professional employees as defined by Federal law.

title: G.A.O. Says Employees of Breeder Reactor Corporation Would Not Be Subject to Laws
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The General Accounting Office has criticized the quasipublic corporation that is developing a controversial kind of , reactor because its employees are not subject to laws on bribery, igraft and conflictofinterest.

title: FREDERICK C. GANS, ARCHITECT, 65, DIES
description: Frederick C. Gans, an assoil ciate partner in the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merill, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 65 years old.

title: Four Hours Behind the Mast
description: MIAMIThey could talk of tarpon fishing in the Florida Keys, Bob Philpott was saying, or in the Bahamas or across the state among the Ten Thousand Islands, but for dependably exciting action he would take Government Cut right here at home. Government Cut is the channel at the foot of Miami Beach through which cruise ships and other seagoing vessels Make their way into the Port of Miami. Bob Philpott said he liked to take his small boat and work just outside the mouth of the Cut with light spinning tackle and a small jig. We get them 100, 150 pounds, he said, and although I know fish look bigger in the water, I've seen some that must have gone 200. I think some stay in these waters all year, but it's just about time now for them to show up in numbers. Today, though, we'll be looking for kings, sailfish, whatever we can find in the Gulf Stream.

title: Invisible Again
description: WASHINGTONPresidential candidates have traditionally appealed to the black community almost exclusively in terms of civil rights issueswhen they have felt the need to appeal at all. Thus in bygone elections the candidates who won our favors stood for equal opportunity in education, employment, housing, public accommodations. voting rights. etc.

title: TAJ MAHAL'S MUSIC A RICH, TASTY BLEND
description: Roots music, a listener shouted to Taj Mahal during the singer's second show at the Bottom Liffe on Monday evenine. Come on. more roots.

title: JUDGE ALLEN MOSS OF CRIMINAL COURT
description: Criminal Court Judge Allen Moss died Monday night in University Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 69 years old and lived at 14470 41st Street in Flushing, Queens.

title: Bridge
description: The World Bidding Contest of the International Bridge Academy will be played worldwide tonight. In New York. this unusual event, in which each player has a partner but no opponents and the action proceeds in total silence, will be played at the Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street at 7:30 P.M.

title: TV in Homes Called Useful in Tracking Paths of Tornadoes
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 6 An ordinary television set, if tuned properly, can be used to track tornadoes and perhaps save lives, according to the Texas Information Center.

title: Real Test Pilots ShunClark Gable Image,SortOf
description: SAN DIEGO, April 5The men who testfly the nation's newest experimental aircraft cheered, whistled and stamped their feet when Rear Adm. L. A. Snead began their semlannual banquet here last weekend with the story of the 84yearold test pilot and his 78yearold wife.

title: 3 With Eyes for Senate Win Big as Delegates
New Cheating Case Erupts at West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 6 The United States Military Academy is investigating the possibility of a major cheating scandal.conferring with the investigation panel late last night. He had said earlier that they were seeking to determine if there is enough evidence to form an, allegation against any of the cadets.

title: CRIME BILL BACKERS AGREE TO CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)  Chief sponsors of a bill making wide changes in the Unitedl States Criminal Code have agreed to drop limited restoration of the death penalty in a move to save the measure.

title: Small Staff Runs Hughes's Summa Corp.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6 The death of Howard R. Hughes has left a vacuum of ownership and an abundance of mysteries about the future of an economic empire believed to be worth at least $1.5 billion and whose interests range across a broad spectrum of American business.

title: DayCare Bill Vetoed
description: President Ford vetoed a bill to provide $125 million in grants for Federally aided daycare centers. Details on page 9.

title: House Votes to Prohibit State or Local 2% Clubs
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) The 2 percent clubs will have to go out of business if a bill passed by the House becomes law.

title: Warfield Signed by Browns
description: CLEVELAND, April 6 (UPI)  The Cleveland Browns signed Paul Warfield to a threeyear contract today and said they were temporarily out of the bidding for Larry Csonka, Warfield's former teammate, on the Miami Dolphins and the Memphis South, men of the defunct World Football League.

title: Mays Is Left Standing With Trophy at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, April 6 A presentation by Willie Mays to the winner of tonight's third race was to be a highlight of the annual Oldtimers Night at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Court Backs Forced Land Sales On Farms Irrigated by U.S. Aid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed a lower Federal court finding here today and ruled that farmers receiving irrigation water through Federal flood control projects are bound by a land refrm law of 1902 that compels landowners to sell off excess lands above 1 60acres in exchange for Federal irrigation.

title: Books of The Times
description: Perhaps the most astonishing thing about reading the entire text of The Final Days Bob Woodward's and Carl Bernstein's detailed account of the last 15 months of Richard M. Nixon's Presidencyis that all the sensational revelations that have been released in the last fortnight don't really seem terribly important. The gossip

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Italian Party Chief ;inOneMan Drive, Seeks a National Consensus on Policy
description: ROME, April 6 Along with daily predictions of an impending collapse of Italy, a oneman campaign has been under way to try to bring politicians and union leaders together on how to insure economic survival.

title: Westinghouse Broadcasting Set To Reduce News Stall Abroad
description: The Westinghouse Boradcasting Company, which operates WINS in this area and similar allnews radio stations in Philadelphia and Los Angeles, is preparing to reduce substantially its newsgathering forces abroad, which now consist of six bureaus in Europe and the Middle East, and parttime correspondents in other major capitals.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Brecker Brothers Band, the folk singer Phoebe Snow, Jamaica's reggae singer Jimmy Cliff and the singercomposer Paul Simon will perform at a benefit Mr. Simon is staging May 3 at Madison Square Garden for the New York Public Library's Performing Arts Research Center at Lincoln Center.

title: COUNCIL BROADENS CURB ON RHODESIA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 The Security Council. in one of its infrequent unanimous decisions, today broadened the international sanctions against the white minority Government in Rhodesia by barring insurance and commercial licensing operations benefiting that country.

title: Wicker Comes Indoors, in an Array of Furniture
description: Furniture designers have shown that wicker need not be saved for the porch, back yard or summer place. Still, willow, rattan and bamboo pieces are naturals for the type of furnishing done in the vacation house or used to summerize a city apartment.

title: The Vienna Plays a Velvety Webern
description: If the Vienna Philharmonic needed a motto, it could easily be Here today, here tomorrow. The 134yearold Austrian ensemble radiates a feeling of permanence that gives almost any work it takes up a peculiar perspective. That was certainly true of the three works that Claudio Abbado, the Philharmonic's principal conductor, led at Carnegie Hall on Monday night.

title: U.S. Protests to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, April 6 (Reuters) The United Status Embansy delivered a protest note to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today after a senior American diplomat was threatened last night by Russians angered by demonstrations against Soviet officials in New York.

title: Carter Slowed; Outlook Unclear
description: The voters of New York and I Wisconsin delivered no very clear message about the outcome of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday. By giving a victory to Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington in one state, but not a very sweeping one, and by splitting their votes almost evenly between Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona and former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia in the other, they seem to have slowed Mr. Carter's rush toward nomination.

title: Soviet MIG Pilots Observed in Cuba, Pentagon Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 The Defense Department said today that some Soviet military pilots had heen observed flying MIG21 fithter planes based in Cuba.

title: Cause of Hughes's Death Is Given as Kidney Failure
description: HOUSTON, April 6  He weighed 90 pounds. His body was frail and dehydrated. His face, partly covered by a beard and moustache, was emaciated. His frame, once 6 feet 4 inches tall. had shrunk two inches.

title: Labor Chiefs Oppose Raids To Get Plants
description: TRENTON, April 6 A coalition of New Jersey labor unions adopted a resolution today urging New Jersey, New York and other Northeastern states to stop raitling each other's industry and to work together to demand a halt to the shifting of jobs to the South and Southwest.

title: Derby Eligibles1,2 In Big A Feature
description: A pair of 3yoarolds eligible for the Kentucky Derby, benefitting from a decided edge in the weights, finished 1,2 against six older horses at Aqueduct yesterday in the featured $25,000 allowance race.

title: CBS DROPS 5 SHOWS AND ADDS 6 FOR FALL
description: New situation comedies based on the movie Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore znd Jim Bouton's baseball memoir, Ball Four, will be among the six new shows on the CBS schedule next fall.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Consumer installment credit expanded strongly again in February though at slightly less than the January pace, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The growth of installment credit was $1.17 billion in February, compared with $1.29 billion in January and an average of $843 million in the fourth quarter of 1975. Automobile credit rose by $632 million.

title: Judge Denies Tax Charges
description: ALBANY, April 6 (AP)A Kingston City judge pleaded not guilty at his arraignment in United States District Court here yesterday to charges that he failed to file Federal incometax returns for four years. Special City Court Judge George Beck was released in his own recognizance after his arraignment on charges that he failed to file returns from 1969 through 1972 on a total income of $200,000.

title: General Strike in San Francisco Recommended by Labor Council
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 (UPI) Union leaders voted today for a general strike by all union workers employed in the City of San Francisco in a showdown over voterapproved pay limitations on city workers.

title: Jets New Coaching Staff: The Philosophy of Winning
Business Group Defends Plan by Ford For Commercial Uranium Enrichment
Former Federal Aide Indicted for Fraud
description: RICHMOND, April 6 (AP) Thomas F. Regan, ousted head; of the Small Business Administration office here was indicted today in what Federal prosecutors called a massive scheme to defraud and corrupt the agency.

title: Tax Situation of Estate
description: WASHINGOTN, April 6 (AP)  If howard Hughes left his fortune to medical research, it will escape Federal estate taxes.

title: Notes on People
description: After walking with Lady Bird Johnson among the newly planted dogwood and pine twos. President Ford dedicated 15 acres of Federal land along the Potomac River yesterday as a memorial to the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. The LBJ Memorial Grove, as it will be called, is near the Lincoln Memorial, and Mrs. Johnson said that one lovely spring day of 1968, near the end of the Johnson presidency, she and her husband had an impromptu picnic on the site.

title: Nomination Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UNI)  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Charles W. Robinson as Deputy Secretary of State, the No. 2 post at the State Department. Mr. Robinson, a native of California, would succeed Robert Ingersol, who resigned effective April 1.

title: Udall Reaction
description: MILWAUKEE. April 6 Representative Udall said tonight that he believed he had checked and possibly reversed Jimmy Carter's momentum today in Wisconsin and New York.

title: StudentLoan Agency Reports a Profit
description: WASHINGTON, Apri 6The Student Loan Marketing Association reported today earnings of $1.8 million for 1975.

title: EASING OF RULES ON WATER SCORED
description: WASHINGTON. April 6 The deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency assailed today some of the recommendations made last month on Water Quality to amend the Clean Waters Act of 1972.

title: Lorillard Trims Callo Billings
description: One of the more exciting advertising news stories 1974 was when little Callo & Carroll, with about $3 million in billings, landed some Lorillard billings then put in the neighborhood of $5 million. That's big league action on Madison Avenue.

title: PIT BEAST INQUIRY MARKED BY CLASH
description: WHITESBURG, Ky., April 6  Attorneys for the Scotia Coal Company clashed with a Federal mine safety panel today ovp whether a mine section that apparently touched off two methane gas explosions that killed 26 men last month should be classified as an active or an idle mine section,

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical failure, a map in some editions of The New York Times on Monday incorrectly indicated that Cubans were operating in, or threatening to have influence in, several nations or territories in the Red Sea and Persian Gulf area. It should have been restricted to Southern Yemen, Somalia, the Territory of Afars and Issas, the Dhofar region of Oman and the island of Socotra.

title: A Grinning Jackson Tells Of His Minority Landslide
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington acknowledged his victory in the New York Democratic Presidential primary shortly after midnight today with a wry remark about his own optimistic predictions earlier.

title: BANKS AND FIRMS SNUB STATE BONDS
Antitoxic Action
description: Legislation to control the marketing of toxic substances has now been given a third life by the United States Senate after having died at birth in both the 92d and 93d Congresses. The new bill, stronger than either of its Senate predecessors, has a fair chance of emerging from this Congress intact; the House bill closest to itintroduced by Representative Eckhardt of Texashas already been approved by an Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee.

title: British to Protest to Syria
description: LONDON. April 6 (Reuters) Britain is to make strong representations to Syria about reports that a British container ship, Cheshire Venture, was fired on yesterday in Lebanese waters by ships flying the Syrian flag, officials here said today.

title: Security Bank Head Had Office Next to Lawyer's, Witness Says
description: A partner in William E. Shea's law firm, George DeGenam, disclosed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that Patrick Clifford, former president of the Security National Bank, had directed the hank's affairs from the Madison Avenue offices of Shea, Gould, Climenko, Kramer & Casey.

title: SAUDIS WIDENING WORLD HOLDINGS
description: JIDDA, saum Arabia, April 6 The gold, overseas investments and convertible foreign currencies owned by the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency have soared in value to roughtly $45 billion, according to informed estimates made in business circles here this week.

title: Protest in Peking
description: Not since the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution of the mid1960's have foreigners in China seen anything comparable to this week's events in Peking. China had seemed to be so orderly, so completely controlled in recent years, that the outside world had almost forgotten that the Chinese, too, are quite capable of rioting, damaging persons and property, and protesting against the established order as they did. in the years 1966 to 1968.

title: Harry Nyquist, Inventor, Dies; Communications Lines Expert
description: Harry Nyquist, a retired Bell Telephone Laboratories scientist who was known for his inventions in communications, died Sunday in Harlingen, Tex., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: ARABS REMOVE 43 FROM BOYCOTT LIST
description: CAIRO, April 6 (AP) The Arab ecomomic boycott office has removed 43 companies from its antiIsrael blacklist but has decided not to make public the names of American companies removed from the list, Mohammed Mahgoub, head of the boycott office, said today.

title: For Stratford, All's Well That...
description: STRATFORD, Conn., April 6 The curtain will go up at the American Shakespeare Theater this year. It's in times of crisis when your friends come to your side, Konrad Matthaei, the theater's president, said today in announcing that the theater had succeeded in raising $300,000 in donations.

title: LESTER BACHNER, LAWYER, 78, DEAD
description: Lester R. Bachner of 930 Fifth Avenue, a senior partner in the law firm of Bachner, Tally & Mantel, 850 Third Avenue, died Monday in Palm Beach, Fla. His age was 78.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C. M. Dennis Boyd Is Dead; Investment Adviser on L.I.
description: C. M. Dennis Boyd, an investment counselor with the Alliance Brokerage Corporation of Wantagh, L.I., died Sunday afternoon while on a walk with the Winter Wheezers on Centre Island, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Jubilant Aides Say Ford Could Clinch Nomination Before California Primary
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Ford could nail down the Republican Presidential nomination before the winnertakeall primary on June 8 in California, his campaign aides said tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Knife Wielder Arrested on L. I.

title: CORRECTION
description: Through an editing error, an article in The Times on Monday about the state's Bicentennial Barge wrongly attributed to Philip Johnson a statement that legislators were furious over the escalating costs, but having built the bottom of the barge, as It were, they were too embarrassed not to build the rest of it. The statement was made by a legislative source. Also, the article wrongly stated that an outlay for airconditioning was in the initial budget for the barge.

title: Embarrassment
description: Just a few weeks ago, the State Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson, Sutggested that Governor Carey, order to avoid embarrassing himself, withdraw the nomination of Herman Schwartz to be Chairman of the State Commission of Correction. The Republicandominated Senate Finance Committee has voted the nomination down, apparently killing it. It isn't the Governor who should be embarrassedhis reported recall idea notwithstandingbut rather the Republican leadership in the Senate, which behaved disgracefully rejecting for this post a superbly qualified public servant.

title: About the Mets and Yankees...
description: Joe Frazier, the Mets rookie manager, is still considering making Jerry Koosman a relief pitcher. We gotta get a guy from the seventh inning on, Frazier said. Six, seven innings won't win a game. . . .. Frazier also has returned Dave Kingman to right field after a brief trial in left, with John Milner in right. I'm not saying it's the best that could be had, the manager said of Kingman in right, but it's the best we've got. .... Thurman Munson, who played left field, singled home the winning run in the Yanks 11inning, 32 victory over the Mets Monday night. I was overmatched, if you want to know the truth, said Munson, who was playing his first game since breaking a finger March 25. How I got two hits, I don't know. He is still some time away from being able to throw well and play at his regular position, catcher. . . . . Rudy May signed contract, leaving five Yankees unsigned.

title: When Milk Disagrees, A New Product to Try
description: A new milk product, containing culture regarded as beneficial, particularly to people with an inability to digest milk, is expected to be marketed soon in the New York City area.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS U.S. JOBS PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  A House committee today approved a threemonth extension of programs providing public service jobs for 320,000 workers hired by state and local governments.

title: MARKET WEAKENS ON PROFIT TAKING
description: A burst of selling hit the stock market late yesterday to leave the Dow Jones industrial average teetering just labove the 1,000 markits battleground for the last several weeks..

title: Domestic Makers Of Bleached Board Increasing Prices
description: Three domestic producers of bleached board announced yesterday price increases on their products. The moves follow by a day increases of $20 to $25 a ton on kraft iinerboard by three major Canadian producers. The International Paper Company and Wcstvaco said their prices for solid bleached hoard would go up by $20 a ton. International's price change will become effective April 15 and Westvaco's on May 31. The Continental Can Company said it planned to raise its prices by an average of 6 percent as of May 1. It would not give a dollar figure. The increases come at a time when the Government's Council on Wage and Price Stability is conducting a study of prices in the paper industry. That body said that from November 1975. through February 1976, wholesale prices of pulp, paper and allied products have in. creased at a 10.9 percent annual rate . . . more than four times faster than the rate of increase for all commodities2.7 percent.

title: TV: Portrait of Martha Graham's Dance Company
description: Publictelevision's Dance In America takes a dazzling leap into full artistic success this evening with a portarait of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Miss Graham gave her first solo appearance on April 18, 1926, in New York's 48th Street Theater. The 50th anniversary of that evening could hardly have a more impressive tribute than this program.

title: Are Young People Helpful? Employers Think Y.E.S.
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y April 6  When Jeannette Jacobson needed a high school girl to help out at a dinner party for 18 guests a few months ago, she did what Gerry Lichtman, accounts manager of Sunburst Communications Inc., did when she needed a part time inventory clerk.

title: Guerrilla Advertisement Spurs Owens Takeover by Venezuela
description: CARACAS, April 6 The Venezuelan Government, in a surprise move, said tonight that it would take over the local affiliate of OwensIllinois Inc. after the company had violated constitutional norms and Venezuelan laws.

title: Germans Set Michigan Plant
description: LANSING, Mich., April 6 (AP)  A German auto parts maker will open a factory in Battle Creek by September, Gov. William Milliken said today. Keiper K. G. will employ 150 at the facility, including 30 skilled toolanddie workers Governor Milliken said, and will hire its personnel locally.

title: About Real Estate
description: The final decision of the Union Carbide Corporation three weeks ago to move out of the city, taking 3,500 jobs, has reawakened memories of how the city lost another large corporate tenant. This was the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, which decided on its move in 1970.

title: VOTERS IN 2 STATES INTERVIEWED IN POLL
description: The New York Times and CBS News polled voters yesterday in both Wisconsin and New York as they left the polls. Through random sampling, 20 voting precincts were chosen in New York and 15 precincts in Wisconsin, and, within each precinct, each voter had an equal chance of selection.

title: Bridge:
description: The World Bidding Contest of the International Bridge Academy will be played worldwide tonight. In New York, this unusual event, in which each player has a partner but no opponents and the action proceeds in total silence, will be played at the Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street at 7:30 P.M

title: Soviet Is Expected to Try Three In Separate Cases of Dissidence
description: MOSCOW, April 6  Tivee political dissidents are expected to go on trial in separate Soviet courtrooms within the next 10 days.

title: The Iconoclastic Lichine Once More Invades Vineyards of Controversy
description: One day last spring, when the Bordeaux wine market was at its nadir, a wellknown St. Emilion grower contemplated the cold rain pelting down on his vineyards, thought of his bills and his unsold wine and said to a visitor: Maybe Lichine has the answer.

title: Mars to Block Light From Star Tonight In 5Minute Show
description: This evening, as the planet Mars briefly cuts off the light from one of the brighter stars in the current night sky, a guided tour of the event will be conducted on the observation deck of the World Trade Center if the weather permits.

title: Boxer's Death Stirs In in Australia
description: SYDNEY. Australia, April 6Chuck Wilburn of Cleveland died today, four and a half days after being knocked out with only 45 seconds remaining in his welterweight fight with Hector Thompson, the Australian champion.

title: G.E. Sales and Earnings Hit Peaks in 1st Quarter
PRICES MOVE UP IN GRAIN FUTURES
description: Strong commercial buying and some speculative short covering marked trading yesterday in grains and soybeans on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Escalator Run Amok
description: Costofliving escalators won their first enduring foothold in major labormanagement agreements with the 1948 contract between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers. That escalator was linked to the principle that workers should get an annual improvement of 3 percent in purchasing power to reflect the longterm growth in national productivity.

title: Kissinger Sees NATO End If Europeans Elect Reds
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has asserted that if Communist governments were elected in Western Europe the Atlantic alliance would be smashed and the United States isolated, according to a summary of his remarks.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Summary of Kissinger Speech to U.S. Ambassadors
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Following is the official State Department nonverhatim summary of remaths made by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger at a meeting in London fast December of American ambassadors in Europe:

title: The Jersey Turnpike Rhapsody
description: NEW MILFORD, N. J.  We've all heard it a hundred times.

title: Complaint on Csonka's Pact
description: MIAMI, April 6 (AP) Joe Robbie, owner of the Dolphins, went public today with his gripes about a fiveyear contract being sought by Csonka, claiming the former Dolphin fullback wants a financial package totaling more than $2 million.

title: MATCHING FUNDS NOT MISSED YET
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Nine Presidential candidates would have almost $1.3 million more to spend if Congress had not let the campaign subsidy program lapse two weeks ago, along with most of the powers. of the Federal Election Commission.

title: Jersey Accepts Decision Of Court in Quinlan Case
description: TRENTON, April 6Wiliam F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, said today that he would not appeal the New Jersey Supreme Court's ruling authorizing the family of Karen Anne Quinlan to remove the respirator that has kept her alive for almost a year.

title: Dunn Wins Title, Ali Bout Assured
Expatriate Blends Myth, Legends and Memories of Ireland
description: LONDON, April 6 "To be Irish, Edna O'Brien explained in a voice that still carried strong traces of County Clare, is quite a legacy. The Irish are a very complex, repressed, troubled, vivid people. They are at odds with each other and with other races.

title: Austerity Endangers an Endangered Species Project
description: NEWARK, April 6 A bumper sticker or window decal depicting a peregrine falcon in flight has gone on sale throughout the state in an effort by naturalists and conservationists to save New Jersey's endangered and nongame species project.

title: Issues 76: Foreign Policy
description: In campaign discussion of foreign policy, Presidential candidates of both parties appear to he running less against President Gerald Ford than against Secretary State Henry Kissineer.

title: Students Play a Role in Revival on Astoria Film Stage
description: Bernie Weitzman, Connie Milner, Joe Raguseo and 19 other filmstudies students at Brooklyn College sat on the cavernous sound stage in Astoria, Queens, where the Marx Brothers long ago made The Coconuts and Duck Soup, and marveled yesterday about the magic of the movie business.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Advertising
description: Leading newspapers in New York, London and Paris yesterday carried as an advertisement a political manifesto by a Venezuelan guerrilla organization placed by OwensIllinois as a condition for the release of its general manager.

title: Help Sought for Wild Birds of Greece
Dwindling Funds Force Wallace Campaign Cuts
description: MONTGOMERY. Ala., April 6 (UPI) Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, faced with rapidly dwindling national campaign funds, has dismissed all hut about 30 campaign employees, cut off financing for some 40 of his 50 national campalgo offices and is trying to sublease an airplane that costs him about $100,000 a month to operate.

title: The Other Power Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 One of the few sure bets in the Federal elections of 1976 is that the Democrats will retain control of the Senate and the House of Representatives, as they have done for 28 out of the last 32 years, but there is one important difference.

title: About New York
description: Margaret Conlin was gazing out the window of her secondfloor tenement apartment yesterday morning, elbows on the sill, palms cupped under her chin, matching life pass by on West 48th Street, when Jimmy McManus and Joe Maggio drove up.

title: New Golf Tourney for Women To Exceed $205,000 in Prizes
description: The price of women's golf tournaments just went up again.

title: FORD VETOES BILL FOR DAYCARE AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 President Ford vetoed today a bill to provide $125 million to the states to finance the cost of upgrading federally aided day care for children.

title: DayCare Bill Vetoed
description: President Ford vetoed a bill to provide $125 million in grants for Federally aided daycare centers. Details on page 9.

title: Social Security Numbers Will Track Runaway Welfare Fathers
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare has ordered the release of Social Security numbers to help track down runaway welfare fathers who cost taxpayers more than $1 billion annually.

title: Jersey Accepts Decision Of Court in Quinlan Case
Jacksonville Unit Withdraws Funds For Rape Victims

title: EUROPE BLOC TO AID 3 NATIONS IN AFRICA
description: LUXEMBOURG, April 6 The foreign ministers of the European Common Market decided at a meeting here today to give $27.5 million in community funds to Zaire, Zambia and Malawi to help cover losses caused by the Angolan civil war.

description: Three masked men escaped with $851,000 in cash yesterday after holding up two Wells Fargo guards on their way to deliver the money to a Citibank branch in the Daily News Building.

title: CARTER DEFENDS ALLWHITE AREAS
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 6  Jimmy Carter said today that the Federal Government should not take the initiative to change the ethnic purity of some urban neighborhoods or the economic homogeneity of welltodo suburbs.

title: BELAFONTE CALYPSO DIFFICULT TO RESIST
description: Harry Belafonte anticipated certain aspects of contemporary popular music some 20 years ago, when his stagy versions of folk songs and calypsos were wildly popular. Now folk singing has become something of a national pastime, pop music and jazz are moving to lilting Caribbean rhythms, and Mr. Belafonte is back with his first stage show in two years. Beginning a 30week tour, he is appearing through this weekend at the Westbury Music Fair.

title: HIJACKERS HOLD JET AT MANILA WITH 79
description: MANILA, Wednesday, April 7 (AP)Three armed men hijacked a Philippine jetliner with 79 persons aboard over the southern Philippines this morning, force the pilot to fly to Manila and demandede the release of six political prisoners, the Government announced.

title: Saint Laurent Was Hailed and Adored; For Kenzo, Tumult and Frenzy
description: PARIS, April 6The first bravos of the fall readytowear shows ricocheted from the rafters of the Paleis des Congres this morning. The audience rose to its feet as the wedding party of elegant peasants assembled on the runway and Yves Saint Laurent was hailed as the savior of fashion.

title: Irish in Syracuse Keep Green on Top, Even on Stop Light
description: SYRACUSE, April 6 This, city has an unusual traffic light. Some argue that it is the only one of its kind in the world.

title: Senators, in Compromise, Back Less Stringent Food Stamp Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Liberal Senate forces struck a compromise today with the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, Herman Ed Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, on a substitute food stamp reform bill, one less, stringent than the bill currently being debated on the Senate floor.

title: Maddox's Ordeal: Injured Knee and Injured Pride
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 6Elliot Maddox ran around the bases the other day. Well, not quite around the bases, more like around the perimeter, of the infield. And he did it clockwise instead of counterclockwise.

title: S.E.C. PLANS RIDE ON LISTING BRIBES
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission will provide guidelines by May 1 to corporations for disclosing improper payments to foreign government officials, the commission's chairman, Roderick M. Hills, said today. These guidelines will come in the form of a report to the Senate Banking Committee and other comments, Mr. Hills said at I National Press Club breakfast.

description: The Burmah Oil Company announced in London yesterday that it had signed a previously reported agreement to sell its 21 percent interest in the North Sea Ninian oilfield to the stateowned British National Oil Corporation for $167.5 million. Page 69.

title: Compromise Is Sought on Stavisky Bill
description: ALBANY, April 6Discussions aimed at reaching a compromise on the controversial Stavisky bill have focused on a request that teachers do more work in return for restoration of budget cuts in the New York City school system, one participant in the talks said today.

title: Cambodian Government Quits; Assembly to Pick New Regime
description: BANGKOK.Thailand, Wednesday, April 7 (UPI) The Cambodian Cabinet resigned today and will be replaced by appointees of the newly elected National Assembly, Prime Minister Penn Nouth said.

title: Spain Gets Equal Pay Law
description: MADRID, April 6 (AP) 1 Women and men will get equal pay for similar work under a law passed today by the Spanish Parliament. Women have traditionally been paid less in this country. The legislation shortens the workweek from 48 to 44 hours and raises the minimum working age from 14 to 16 years.

title: People and Business
description: Frequent reference to Nigeria's oil riches has given a misleading impression that the West African country faces no financial problems in development, the Nigerian Ambassador to the United Sttes, E. Olu Sam, said yesterday.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 6 (AP)The widow of Chuck Wilburn will get $25,000 compensation under the workers compensation laws of the state of New South Wales.

description: When Pema Thonden first came to New York she thought she couldn't breathe and she used to beg her husband to take her to the country. Mrs. Thonden had come from Tibet.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 If Howard R. Hughes signed a will before he died, the best guess is that his $1.5 billion estate will go to the medical foundation he established in 1954.

title: Lebanese Set Talks to Replace President
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, April 6 The speaker. of the Lebanese Parliament, Kamai alAssad, announced today that the body would meet Saturday morning in an empty villa on the city's MoslemChristian battle line to begin a process intended to ease President Suleiman Franiieh from office.

title: GrassFed Beef Is Cheaper, But What About Its Taste?
description: Grassfed beef, we have been told from time to time, offers solutions to many of the world's food problems. Because it is naturally leaner than the usual grainfed variety, it is lower in cholesterol, an especially important advantage to Americans who eat so much beef. But even more vital, in terms of the rest of the world, grain not fed to cattle can more easily and economically be shipped to feed hungry people.

title: Atom Plant Housing Ban Held Unneeded
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, April 6 The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the state's recent ban on housing projects near a nuclear power plant here was unnecessary as a public safety measure.

title: BOARD SAYS CITY U. STILL HAS DEFICIT
description: The chairman of the Board of Higher Education, following a tumultuous Monday meeting at which the board approved plans to close or merge several colleges in the City University. said yesterday that it was now up to the city and state to come up with the additional! money still necessary to run the university.

title: Stocks Are Mixed On Amex and OTC; Trading Moderate
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished yesterdays with small price changes in moderate trading.

title: Market Place
description: Peter J. White Jr. is hardly a revolutionary. He is 51, wears Brooks Brothers suits and follows conservative investing policies in managing a multimilliondollar stock portfolio. He rarely trades and the portfolio has shares in it that haven't been disturbed for a quarter of century.

title: Soviet Pays U.S. Fine; Trawler Is Released
description: BOSTON, April 6 (AP) A Soviet trawler cized by the Coast. Guard in the belief that she had taken 61 pounds of lobster illegally was released today after the payment of a $410,000 settlement. The captain of the 278foot stern trawler Anton Tammsaare, Valentin Alexandrovich Eleseez, pleaded no contest in Federal District Court to a charge of taking lobsters illegally from the Coat mental Shelf.

title: 21 Who Escaped Spanish Prison Are Captured at French Border
description: MADRID, April 6 The Spanish Civil Guard captured 21 escaped prisoners near the French border today after gun battles in which one prisoner was killed. Seven other escaped prisoners were still at large tonight.

title: Market Basket Drops by 1.4%
description: Aftetr teetering for weeks with no changes or fractional ones of no significance, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 1.4 percent for the week, the City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: To Swedish Labor, Equality Is Being Boss
description: The King of Sweden sat as a member of the audience at a hotel in Washington this week, listening to debate among Swedish and American industrialists, labor leaders and politicians over the link between productivity and industrial democracy. This was no new experience for 29yearold Carl XVI Gushas He has been prudently boning up for years on economics, sociology. Swedish industry and the organization of the labor market as part of his training for the monarchy. He has spent considerable time touring factories, talking with workers as well as bosses and foremen.

description: NEWARKThere is a high school here in which all students have been designated by the Federal government as delinquent. Everyone involved is enthusiastic about the school.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)  Legislation designed to reduce airline passenger. fares by making the industry more competitive was introduced today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today that it would be a tragic mistake for New York City to give its transit workers increased costofliving benefits, which, he said, would set a precedent that would cost the city $200 million to S400 million

description: KATONAH, N. Y. The notion that the more you spend for ingredients the better a dish will be is nonsense, Ed Giobbi was saying. It was approaching noon and his kitchen, one of the most comfortable and stylish in these environs, was rampant with the good odors of tomatoes, garlic. narslev and freshly chopped basil.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Essex County grand jury is to hear charges brought against Councilman Anthony Carrino of Newark after he smashed through the locked door to Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's office at the head of 75 protesters last March 23. The matter, which includes charges of malicious damage and assault and battery on the Mayor's bodyguard, was referred to the grand jury by the Municipal Court at the ouggestion of Matthew J. Boylan, the former State Criminal Justice Director, who is serving as the Councilman's lawyer

title: Japanese in Plea to Ford on Lockheed
description: TOKYO, April 6 A number of Japanese television personalities, writers, artists, editors, critics, comedians and scholars have contributed $165 apiece to publish an advertisement in The New York Times addressed to President Ford and the American people.

title: Democratic Strategy Called Key to Senate Vote on Income Tax
description: TRENTON, April 6 A showdown on a personal income tax for New Jersey residents is about one month away, with Democratic leaders settling on May 6 as a tentative day for the vote on the proposal. At that time, votes will not only be taken on the tax measures, but also on recommendations by the Joint Appropriations Committee of the Legislature for changes in the Governor's $2.76 billion budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: Gen. Lajos Veress, 87, Dies; Led Hungarian Resistance
description: Gen. Lajos Veress, a Hungarian officer who led resistance, to German occupation of his country in 1944 and in 1947, was imprisoned by the Communist regime, died March 29 in London, where he had livedf since he escaped in the 1956, uprising. He was 87 years old.

description: A second new yacht will be built for the defense next year of the America's Cup it was announced yesterday. This one, to be named Enterprise, will have Lowell North, the noted sailmaker and racing yachtsman from San Diego, as skipper. Olin Stephens is the naval architect.

title: FORD EASY VICTOR
description: MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, April 7 Jimmy Carter defeated Morris K. Udall yesterday in a tight contest in Wisconsin's Democratic Presidential primary. In the Republican race, President Ford was an easy winner over Ronald Reagan.

title: Greek Cypriots Raid US. Embassy in Aid Dispute
description: NICOSIA. Cyprus, April 6 (AP)  About 2.000 young, Greek Cypriots attacked the United States Embassy with rocks and burning sticks today to protest the proposed resumption of American military aid to Turkey.

description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 6 The United States Military Academy is investigating the possibility of a major cheating scandal.

title: Pound Is Bolstered After $1.8525 Low
description: BRUSSELS, April 6 (UPI) The British pound reached a historic low against the dollar during trading on European money markets today, but recovered somewhat on intervention by the Bank of England. The dollar declined against most European currencies.

title: Adequacy of Rail Freight To Be Studied by the State
description: ALBANY, April 6 (UPI) State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler said today that his department would investigate the adequacy of rail freight service in the state.

title: BURMAN OIL SELLS INTEREST IN FIELD
description: The Burmah Oil Company announced in London yesterday that it had signed a previously reported agreement to sell its 21 percent interest in the North Sea Ninian oilfield to the stateowned British National Oil Corporation for $167.5 million. The field is due to come into production in 1978. Burmah said also that a new agreement had been reached whereby the British National Oil Corporation would take a majority interest in a joint company with Burmah that would hold Burmah's stake In the Thistle field in the British sector of the North Sea.

title: Carter Slowed
description: The voters of New York and Wisconsin delivered no very clear message about the outcome of the race for the DemoIcratic Presidential nomination yesterday. By giving a victory to Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington in one state, but not a very sweeping one, and by splitting their votes almost evenly between Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona and former Gov. Jiinmy Carter of Georgia in the other, they seem to have slowed slightly Mr. Carter's rush toward nomination.

title: TROOPS IN PEKING BELIEVED MOVING TO MR VIOLENCE

description: WASHINGTON. April 6 (UPI)  The Food and Drug AsImibistration proposed today a ban on the use of Chloroform in drugs, cosmetics and food packages because of evidence indicating it may cause cancer.

title: Senate Unit Backs Tough Trust Rules For Merger Deals
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)  The Senate Judiciary Committee approved an antitrust bill today that would impose tough premerger notification rules on businesses and give states the power to recover triple damages on behalf of their citizens.

title: Chinese Moderates Seem to Use Chou's Name Against the Maoists
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 The forces in China that are generally called moderates by outsiders appear to be using the name of Chou Enlai in an effort to thwart the faction operating in the name of Mao Tsetung and possibly, to thwart the 82yearold Chairman himself, according to analysts here.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Senator Thomas F. Eagleton. Democrat of Missouri, urged today that Malcolm R. Currie be suspended as director of defense research and engineering pending an investigation into whether the Pentagon official had been involved in a conflict of interest involving defense contractors.

description: RICHMOND, April 6 (AP) Rebecca Yancey Williams, author of The Vanishing Virginian, died yesterday in a local nursing home.

title: Notes on People
description: After walking with Lady Bird Johnson among the newly planted dogwood and pine trees. President Ford dedicated 15 acres of Federal land along the Potomac River yesterday as a memorial to the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. The LBJ Memorial Grove, as it will be called, is near the Lincoln Memorial, and Mrs. Johnson said that one lovely spring day of 1968, near the end of the Johnson presidency, she and her husband had an impromptu picnic on the site.

description: It was midnight yesterday in Philadelphia and two hours earlier in Phoenix When Pat Williams called Iry kosloff. Williams is the general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers and Kosloff the team's owner. The 76ers had just beaten the Houston Rockets, 130129, in overtime and clinched their first National Basketball Association playoff berth in six seasons. Kosloff was in Phoenix visitinghis daughter, Mrs. Joyce Cooper, who recently gave birth to his sixth grandchild.

description: CHICAGO, April 6 (UPI) A Northwestern University medicalschool center for sports medicine has been established to provide educational and training programs that will, it is hoped, lead to better preparation and car of athletes and fewer injuries, it was announced today.

description: MOSCOW, April 6 (UPI) A Soviet official acknowledged! today that the Soviet Union had net fulfilled all of Egynt's requests for weapons ship. ments, but he stressed that Moscow had abided by its agreements.

I., April 7More than 60 percent of the major pipeline installed as part of the controversial $700 million Southwest Sewer District project was different from the design approved by the state, and same of it did not even meet the state's minimum standards, the chairman of the Suffolk County Legislature's Finance Committee charged today.

description: Stock prices registered their biggest drop in nearly four weeks yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 15 points.

title: No Process Of Law
description: STANFQRD, Calif.It is irresponsible. It is lawless. When a noted student of the Supreme Court uses stich words to describe the Court's performance in a case, one listens.

title: Cadet Indicted in Rape
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., April 7A West Point Cadet was indicted by a Rockland County grand jury today on charges of raping and robbing a 30yearold Bardonia woman.

title: Adolph G . Anderson, President Of Hartwick College, Dies at 62
description: Adolph G. Anderson, sixth president of Hartwick College in Oneonta, N. Y., died there Monday at Fox Memorial HosPital. He was 62 years old.

title: British to Sell Gas to U.S.
description: LONDON, April 7 (AP) A British subsidiary of Shell Oil has landed a big 10year contract to sell liquified gas from the North Sea to the United States. Shell International Gas said it expected the contract to be worth $1 billion, with deliveries to begin in 1979. The company said about six million tons of liquified propane and butane gas would be sold to Northern Liquid Fuels International of Omaha, Neb., a subsidiary of Northern Natural Gas of Nebraska.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KIBBEE IS WARNED ABOUT FISCAL PLAN
description: Two members of the Board of Higher Education said yesterday they that they would call for the resignation of Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of City University, unless he produced specific recommendations to resolve the university's fiscal crisis.

title: $31.6 Million Mall In Jamaica Planned; Stepin Revival Seen
description: Construction of a $31.6 million shopping center in the heart of the blighted Jamaica business district in Queens will begin late this year in what city officials and community leaders envision as the first major step in the renaissance of a oncethriving hub of commerce.

title: Wallace, Despite Four Defeats, Vows to Continue His Campaign
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 7Despite four straight primary defeats and a shortage of campaign funds, Gov. George C. Wallace said today that he would continue his fourth campaign for President. He instructed his aides to draw up a shoestring political itinerary that would keep him On the road much of the rest of this ionth and almost all of May.

title: PEKING BELIEVED TO ACT HURRIEDLY
description: HONG KONG, Thursday April 8China's surprise announcements last night of the simultaneous dismissal of the senior Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaopmg ana me promotion of Hua Kuofeng to Prime Minister were made in the name of the Communist Party's Central Committee.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 8, 1976

title: April Potatoes Off Active Platinum Up
description: The April futures contract for Maine potatoes expired yesterday at $7 a hundred pounds, the price in the cash market, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, The final quotation represented a decline of $1.82 on the day.

title: Fancier Claims Success With ESP Test on Dogs
description: Dogs have a supersensory awareness much more acute than a human, said Sylvia Fisher, and I'm certain there is some kind of thought transference between a person and his dog. I want to find out what makes it work.

title: Election Board Alleges Flaws In Wallace's Primary Petitions
description: The State Board of Elections told the district attorneys in seven upstate counties yesterday that it had found evidence of violations of the New York election law by eight supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Albert Denounces a Report That He Plans to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) Speaker Carl Albert angrily denounced today a published report that he would retire at the end of this year and would announce that decision next month.

title: A Divided Delegation
description: The New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention, which is the second largest and the host delegation, is at the moment fractionalized, factious and leaderless. The delegation's 206 district delegates and 68 delegates at large, apportioned to each candidate on the basis of his returns in Tuesday's Presidential primary, will he divided as follows:

title: 2 RECITAL DEBUTS IN SING OUT SERIES
description: Town Hall's Sing Out, America series took a curious turn Tuesday night when Karan Armstrong and John 11 Alexander made their New York recital debut. They sang an assortment of songs, arias and duets drawn frequently from a longabandoned repertory, but not quite frequently enough to suggest that the soprano and tenor were kidding the oldfashioned numbers or reviewing them nostalgically.

title: TROOPS ON GUARD
description: The Globe and Mail. Toronto

title: Market Place
description: Like most men in the investment world. Richard Bock, a stockbroker at Advest & Company, is always looking for speculative opportunities. On Friday he thought he had found an excellent one. He was fascinated when he returnee from lunch last Friday to discover Xerox April 60 options trading at .

title: There's No Left Left
description: WASHINGTON, April 7When Gertrude Stein bleakly surveyed Oakland, Calif she announced: There's no there there. In the same way, the results of the primary elections in New York and Wisconsin this week lead to this conclusion: There's no Left left.

title: Humiliation Is the National Pastime
description: AUGUSTA, Ga April 7Tomorrow the baseball season opens, the National Football League conducts its college draft and the Masters golf tournament begins. Jack Nicklaus won't start for the New York Yankees, Catfish Hunter won't be the first choice of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Leroy Selmon won't be leading the Masters; it will only seem that way. But never before has baseball needed baseball as much as it does now. After the lingering labor dispute, after the unpleasant aroma of the Andy Messersmith mess, after the unnecessary hassle of Tom Seaver's contract negotiations, baseball needs Catfish Hunter to pitch a shutout today or Henry Aaron to hit a home run or Pete Rose to slide head first. Or even Charles 0 Finley to make another trade. Assuming that Reggie Jackson reports, the Oakland A's trade that sent him and Ken Holtzman to the Baltimore Orioles might swing the balance of power in both American League divisions.

title: Wings Tickets Selling Quickly
description: Thousands of youths poured through plywoodreinforced glass doors to Madison Square Garden box offices yesterday to buy tickets to Paul McCartney's first ;concert here in 10 years.

title: Refusal to Reply to Bring Summons
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it was intensifying its investigation of major corporations by requiring them to answer 11 specific questions about possible bribes, kickbacks and other illegal payments.

title: Show at Guggenheim Is a Guide To Catalogue 5 Years in Making
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is a very peculiar institution. To a quite exceptional degree its collection of paintings still bears the stamp of Solomon R. Guggenheim, who died nearly 30 years ago, and of his formidable adviser, Baroness HiIla Rebay von Ehrenwiesen. The collection has of course been enlarged and modified since then, but its general tack in numerical terms is still that of the Museum of NonObjective Painting, which Guggenheim founded in the 1930's.

title: Books of The Times
description: The oceans are our last frontier, writes Elisabeth Mann Borgese. They belong to no one and to everyone. All life began in them, and they are our best hope for survival on land, because it is in the oceans that today's ecological crisis reaches its climax. Though it is not common knowledge, ocean organisms produce more than halt or tne world's oxygen. If pollution and radioactive wastes continue to pour into the sea, all life will eventually cease and the stench of putrefaction would send coastal populations scrambling toward the interior and many would perish in the struggle for the decreased supply of breathable air. Even now, Mrs. Borgese observes, the farreaching effects of DI. are thinning the eggshells of brown pelicans to a point where their young are being decimated. DDT and related chemicals are causing sea lions to give birth prematurely to pups, which soon die. Though threequarters of the world's populationthe poorer partdepends on fish for animal protein, the automated and computerized fishing techniques of more advanced countries are increasingly threatening that supply.

title: Foes Frustrated as Rhodesians Exhibit Confidence
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. April 2Despite mounting foreign pressures on Rhodesia's white minority Government, Prime Minister Ian D. Smith is continuing to hold adamantly and confidently to the reins of power and so far none of the apocalyptic scenarios advanced M the wake of the Angolan war have developed here.

title: Hua, Regarded as Moderate, Abstained From AntiTeng Drive
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, April 8A tall Chinese leader about whom little is known has emerged as an apparent compromise choice to end the adership fight that followed the death of Prime Minister Chou Enlai in January.

title: HeartImplant Patient Dies
description: CAPE TOWN, April 7 (Reuters)Hennie Goosen, 46 years old, the sixth person in South Africa to have a second heart implanted, died in the Groote Schuur Hospital here today.

title: Study Finds That Some Use of Antibiotics May Not Be Justified
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 7 A federally funded study in Pennsylvania hospitals has found that 20 percent of the antibiotic drugs prescribed may not be justified by present scientific evidence, according to results presented here today at la meeting of the American College of Physicians.

title: Hua is Now Viewed As the Heir Apparent
Frederick Harbison, Economist And Princeton Professor, Dies
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 Dr. Frederick H. Harbison, an economist who was chairman of the New Jersey Mediation Board from 1957 until 1970, died of a heart attack Monday while on a business trip in New York. He was 63 years old.

title: GRATTAN O'LEARY,87, SENATOR IN OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, April 7 Senator Grattart OLeary, who retired as editor of The Ottawa Journal to begin a political career, died today of lung cancer at his home here. tie was 87 years old.

title: Beame Assures City Workers They'll Get Delayed Pay Rises
description: Mayor Beame stressed yesterday that the city would honor its commitment to lift in September a oneyear wage freeze that city employees had voluntarily accented.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Hughes Estate Fight Seen As Doubts Rise About Will
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 There appears to be a growing feeling among knowledgeable associates of Howard R. Hughes that the eccentric billionaire left no will to guide the disposal of his great estate.

title: Stock Prices Drop On Amex and OTC; Trading Volume Off
description: Profit taking sent prices sharply lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: BIG WIN BY FRANCES COMMIES DROPS FRANC AND OTHER SHOE
description: PARISWhat would happen if Henry A. Kissinger's fears came true and the Communist Party in France or Italy was voted into power? For argument, assume it is France and that the Communists and their Socialist allies win a majority in the next legislative elections. There would be an immediate constitutional crisis, for the Fifth Republic Constitution makes no provision for a President and National Assembly of opposing tendencies.

title: Droo in Market Is Linked to Dispatch
description: A press dispatch that described a Washington meeting of New York City business executives to discuss the city's future contributed to a sharp drop in stock prices late yesterday.

title: Shopping Mail Is Planned for Jamaica
description: Construction of a $31.6 million shopping center in the neart of the blighted Jamaica business district in Queens will begin late this year in what city officials and community leaders envision as the first major step in the renaissance of oncethriving hub of commerce.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 750,000 common shares of Skaggs Companies Inc., at $25,125 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. The offering comprised 550,000 shares being sold by the company and 200,000 shares being sold by certain shareholders.

title: New Campaign Is Started To Ban Red Dyes in Food
description: A new campaign against red dyes in food was opened yesterday at a preview of today's observance of Food Day.

title: STONEHOUSE RESIGNS FROM LABOR PARTY
description: LONDON, April 7  John Stonehouse, the Member of Parliament who was brought back to Britain from Australia last July and charged with theft, fraud and conspiracy, resigned today from the Labor Party.

title: Buckley Not Source Of Reports of Views Of Kissinger, Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 7It was mistakenly reported in The New York Times today that Senator James L. Buckley, the New York ConservativeRepublican, had made copies of confidential comments on Europe by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and his adviser Helmut Sonnenfeldt available to other members of Congress.

title: Special Prosecutor Named
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (UPI) Bernard L. Siegel, first asist, ant district atorney of Erie County, has been appointed special prosecutor of Philadelphia, State A torney General Robert P. Kane announced Wednesday. Mr. Siegel, 37 years old, a member of the Pennsylvania Crime Commission, will replace Walter M. Philips Jr. who Mr. Kane dismissed March 31. Mr. Kone said Mr. Siegel would assume the $38,298ayear job later this month.

title: Venezuela Owens Move Creates Dismay
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 7Foreign businessmen in Venezuela expressed shock today at the Veriezuelan Government's decision yesterday to xpropriate the foreign assets of OwensIllinois de Venezuela, a subsidiary of the United States glass manufacturer based in Toledo. Ohio.

title: Recital
description: No musician should be discouraged from taking on the greatest challenges of the repertory simply because of youth. A 29yearold singer such as Siegfried Lorenz, tor instance, is certain to benefit from wrestling with Schubert's Die Winterreisse, and might even find things to say about that bonechilling song cycle that older artists overlook. But Mr. Lorenz's performance of the cyole at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, though tastefully and skillfully sung, was not particularly distinctive or revelatory.

title: An Arts Foundation Is Formed in Jersey By Business Leaders
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., April 7The formattion of Business Arts Foundation, which hopes to raise $100,000 in contributions by Oct. 1, was announced today as a move to unite corporations and culture.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A TOUCH OF CLASS The newest weekend entertainer in the Lincoln Center area is Peter Conway, a troubadour of sophisticated ballads. His partner is John Meyer at the piano in the Cafe du Center (7992254), on Columbus Avenue at 67th Street.

title: Moreland Panel Proposes Reform of Medicaid Rates
Fun for Children: Eating on a Ferry
description: Skylinewatchers have all kinds of ways to view the cityfrom skyscrapers, tour boats, helicopters. One of the newest view purveyors, and certainly one of the most unusual places to take children, is the Binghampton, a ferry converted into a restaurant on the. Hudson. It sits on the New Jersey shore almost directly across from the Riverside Church at 122d Street (where people who've climbed to the top can look down on people who've gone to the Binghampton to look up).

title: Reds Start With Spirit of 75
description: CINCINNATI, April 7 (UPI) Sparkey Anderson, Cincinnati Reds manager, has a modest prediction on the eve of the 1976 baseball season.

title: Strong Quake Strikes i SovietIranian Border
description: GOLDEN, Colo., Thursday, April 8 (AP)A strong earthquake shook a Central Asian area near the Soviet Union's border with Iran early today, the United States Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Service reported.

title: Baker's Wife Musical Coming to Broadway
description: The Baker's Wife, a new musical based on the Marcel Pagnol French film classic, will be produced on Broadway next fall by David Merrick. Toppl star of the film version of Fiddler on the Roof, will make his American stage debut in the show, costarring with Carol Demas, last here in Grease. The musical, now in rehearsal under the direction of Joseph Hardy, opens at the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera on May 11. Joseph Stein has written the book and Stephen Schwartz the music and lyrics. Joseph Stein has written the hook and Stephen Schwartz the music and lyrics.

title: Singer to Be Arraigned
description: ASPEN. Colo April 7 (UPI) Claudine Longet, a singer and actress, will be arraigned tomorrow for the March 21 shooting death of het lover, Vladimir Sabich, a former world skiing champion. District Attorney Frank Tucker has said that the charge against her would depend on whether the shooting was considered accidental.

title: Byrne Has a Perfect Day Passing in Preview of Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, April 7Governor Byrne played quarterback today at the future home of the New York Giants of the National Football League at the Meadowlands Sports Complex here and completed three short passes to members of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: RevenueSharing Change Urged To Gain True Regional Planning
description: A plan to use Federal revenuesharing funds as a goad to get suburbs to cooperate in regional plans that would help New York and other big cities was proposed yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne has commuted the sentence of Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, who is suffering from prostate cancer, the Governor's office said.

title: SIMPLICITY ACTS ON STOCK OPTIONS
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company Inc., subject to the approval of the Federal District Court for the Southern District, has agreed to raise the option price its chairman, James .J Shapiro, and four other officers of the company will pay if and when they exercise options they now hold to purchase the company's shares.

title: Notes on People
description: The United Mine Workers former president, 74yearold W. A. Boyle, began serving three consecutive life seatences yesterday jn a state penitentiary at Pittsburgh.

title: C.A.B. DENIES MOVE TO BAN CONCORDE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) hTe Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to ban the Concorde supersonic transport from the United States.

title: BARWICK TO SELL SHARE IN CONCERN
description: E. T. Barwick, chairman and chief executive officer of E. T. Barwick Industries Inc., of Chamblee, Ga. told his board of directors yesterday that he had signed an agreement to sell his stock and that of his immediate family to an unnamed purchaser. Mr. Barwick owns or controls 83 percent of the 10,183,598 common shares outstanding and his interest would have a value of about $23.2 million.

title: Prediction Pitfalls Shown in Wisconsin
description: The precariousness of forecasting the winner of an election or before all the votes are counted was illustrated in a dizzying succession of conflicting television broadcasts and newspaper headlines in the reporting of the results of Tuesday's race between Jimmy Carter and Morris K. Udall in the Democratic primary in Wisconsin.

title: Senate Aide Discounts Impact Callaway Had on Resort Ruling
description: WASHINGTON. April 7 (AP) There is no positive evidence] that Howard H. Callaway's efforts to expand his Colorado skill resort influenced a Forest Service decision paving the way for the expansion, according to a Senate investigator.

description: LONDON, April 7Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey met today with the men whose support he must have if his latest strategy to arrest Britain's economic decline is to workthe leaders of the powerful trade unions.

title: Health Care in the East German Way
description: GENTHIN, East Germany Helga Milner, a conductor on the state railway, came back to the daycare center the other evening and found that her yearold son, Nico, had come down with influenza in an. epidemic that is sweeping East Germany.

title: Mary Margaret McBride Of Radio Talk Show Dies
description: Mary Margaret McBride, whose homey network radio programs delighted millions of American housewives five days a week for more than 20 years, (lied yesterday at her country home in West Shokun, N. Y. after a long illness.

title: FORD VOWS VETO OF ANY EXTRA AID FOR ISRAEL IN 76
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 President Ford told Congressional leaders today that Israel was receiving adequate foreign aid from the United States and that he would veto efforts to increase assistance by $550 million this year.

title: Texts on Peking Changes and Account of Disturbance
Pesticide Is Linked to Animal Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, April 7As nut cf a program to alert !the public to cancer hazards 1. in the environment, the National Cancer Institute released today a report linking the pesticide Kepone to liver cancer in animals.

description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 7 (Agence FrancePresse)  Premier Kaysone Phomvihan will visit Moscow late this month at the head of a Government and party delegation, the Foreign Ministry announced here today.

title: Endorsement of Carter Is Sidestepped by Byrne
description: TRENTON, April 7Governor Byrne backed away today from formally endorsing Jimmy Carter, issuing instead a tepid expression of support for the former Georgia Governor for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Shapes in Plastic For Traditionalists
description: Even the most hidebound traditionalist with a loathing for plastic should be able to coexist with the designer line of home accessories by Edgar Watkins/Cublcs. which are intended to blend in with traditional furnishings.

description: This week the third annual worldwide managers meeting of Foote, Cone & Belding has drawn 45 such persons and their spouses to the Big Annie and the Regency Hotel.

title: Cordon Blah
description: Biomedical engineers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Johnson Space Center, Houston, are working on a project they call meal systems for the elderly. They rightly believe that old people who live alone do not prepare proper meals. But, the space scientists say, plastic packages of astronauts food could be mailed, parcel post, to lonely old men and women. Each package would contain a meal that would provide onethird of the daily dietary allowance necessary to the elderlyfood they could easily open and eat without preparation, and with no dishes to wash.

title: Beirut Tightens Security For Parley on New Chief
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7The commander of the Beirut Military garrison tonight proclaimed a total curfew in the rea where Parliament is to hold an important special session on Saturday. The curfew. Order came after shooting! erupted in the area for the second day.

title: 24 New York Executives Tell Panel Why They Prefer City Despite Woes
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Two dozen New York City businessmen told Congress today that the city's role, as what one of them called the center of the action, far outweighed what they considered onerous local taxes and a lack of amenities.

title: REGISTERED AGENT ADMITS ESPIONAGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 After nine apparently successful and moderately profitable years of spying, James F. Sattier came in from the cold last month and told the Justice Department about it.

title: Orr, Out of Playoffs, Waits for Gold Rush
description: Bobby Orr has decided not to rejoin the Boston Bruins for the Stanley Cup playoffs, but to continue therapy for his injured knee and wait for what his agent still believes will be the greatest money offer in the history of sports.

description: It was mistakenly reported yesterday, in a Washington dispatch of The Times, that Senator James L. Buckley had made available to other members of Congress secret summaries of addresses by Helmut Sonnenfeldt of the State Department and by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger on relations with Europe. Corrective material appears in a dispatch on page 2,

description: With the sharp increase in stock prices in the last few months, many persons have been able to obtain bank loans using their securities as collateral.

title: BOND PRICES RISE; BILL RATE 4.834%
description: Bond prices rose and interest rates declined yesterday as the credit markets extended the advance that began a week ago. In the afternoon, however, the upward move in the corporate bond market faltered and many issues gave up part of their gains. The weeklong rise in fixedincome security prices stemmed chiefly from the current belief that the Federal Reserve is not about to tighten monetary policy and also from the fact that the schedule of new bond issues for sale is light.

title: People in Sports
description: Two Hall of Fame members from different spotts, Whitey Ford of the New York Yankees. and Sugar Ray Robinson, the former world welterweight and middleweight. boxing champion, will be honored as outstanding New York athletes at the 50th dinner of the Boys Athletic League at the Plaza Hotel, April 27.

title: Cause of Alaskan Crash
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) A crash of Alaskan railroad trains near Mount McKinley, in which one person was killed and 62 were injured last July 5, was caused by failure of the train crews to follow operating rules, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Peking Convulsion
description: The political struggle in Peking that has been silently and secretly fought out in the three months since Chou Enlai's death has now resulted in a major political convulsion.

title: Loch Ness Monster: A Serious View
description: After years of ridicule directed against reports of a Loch Ness monster. scientists have begun to take seriously the possibility that such a creature does indeed inhabit the depths of the Scottish lake.

title: Patrick Day Wins First 3 at Big A
description: Eddie Maple was the winning jockey with Tartan's Imminence in yesterday's $38,400 Bed O'Roses Handicap at Aqueduct, but the Rider who provided the afternoon's chief conversation piece was 22yearold Patrick Day. Day, a Coloradan who made his career debut at Aqueduct only six weeks ago after a successful stand at the Fairgrounds in New Orleans, stirred the crowd of 17,888 by booting home the first three winners Melody Rush ($34.20 for $2), Royal Street ($13.20) and King floss ($21.40).

title: Connors, Ailing, Quits Tournament
description: HOUSSTON, April 7 (AP) Topseeded Jimmy Connors hit with the flu, withdrew from the World Championship Tennis circuit tournament at the River Oaks Country Club today.

description: WASHINGTON, April 7After six months of study by the White House and intense lobbying by broadcasters, the Ford Administration has decided against recommending legislation aimed at permitting cable television to compete against overtheair broadcasters.
