title: Brazilian Film Studies Tropical Love
description: Love is always dangerous but in the tropics it can be mortal. Fertility, a traditionally beneficent notion in the North, becomes a sick joke. Life proliferates and chokes: Too many mosquitoes and snakes. Turn your back on your garden for a minute, and vegetable sex has buried it under fronds and creepers. "Guerra Conjugal" is a Brazilian film, set in the pastel and languid town of Curitiba, that sees in the relations between men and women the virulence of a poisoned eclair. It is being shown as part of the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors series.Three stories intercut with one another. The first is about a middleaged lawyer who seduces everyone in sight. Finally, in horror and helplessness, he is seduced by an old schoolmate. Don Juan as the repressed homosexual.The second is about a young man who finds his satisfaction in progressively older women. The last is a horrendous crone of at least 80. Don Juan as the mother-fixated infant.If the first two episodes dispose of eroticism, the third lays out marital love. An aged couple quarrel more and more violently. He accuses her of thinking of other men; she tells him he disgusts her. Dying, he asks his son to see to it that the wife doesn't kiss his dead face. He dies; she grows miraculously younger."Guerra" is Tropical Gothic: It makes Southern Gothic look like cream of wheat. In its violent disgust for the human animalin this case the human sexual animalit occasionally reaches the inspired dementia of a Buuel. There are some brilliantly harsh and funny episodes.Mostly, though, its meansuneven acting, uncertain direction and overblown writingfall a long way short of its intentions. If the eclair is half-baked, there's not much use poisoning it.Good things, the saying goes, come in small packages. And the small packages that are the films of Eli Noyes Jr, are crammed with wit, beauty, inventiveness and a keen sensitivity to the lunacy and sadness of the human condition.Eleven of these filmssome animated, some live action, one a mixture of the two; some in color, some in black and whiteare being shown this weekend and next at the Film Forum in an 82-minute parade that should captivate a great many children, delight adults and disabuse anyone of the notion that when it comes to animation, Walt Disney and his disciples had the last word.Mr. Noyes is the sort of artist who can take a run through the alphabet with pen and ink in six minutes, stirring up comparisons with Maurice Sendak and Saul Steinberg with his drawing and leaving "Sesame Street" and Richard Scarry in his wake with his humor.In 8 minutes he can speak volumes about evolution, through  appropriately  a lump of clay transformed with seeming magic into all manner of life. In 60 seconds he can run through a lexicon of barks from a creative kennel full of dogs or make wild sport of the world's peanut-butter-and-jelly addicts. Given a country music background and a few grains of sand, he produces marvelous choreography.In live action, he transmits a crafty dog's-eye view of singles' life in New York and takes a bold excursion into one of the city's great conflicts  the war against the roach. His most eye-catching clay animation is reserved for "The Fable of He and She," an 11-minute film that suffers, however, from a heavyhanded story about sexual roles that Mr. Noyes did not compose.His own formidable powers of storytelling and political commentary are strikingly displayed in "The Dot," a 30-minute film that conjures up an eerie, Orwellian world and combines live action and animation to make a statement against repression.Mr. Noyes is a filmmaker of impressive accomplishment, and his work deserves to be seen.

title: Johanna Meier Calm Diva in Demand

Some two hours later, she will rush out on stage as the temperamental Prima Donna in the work and begin her Met debut without having had either a full stage or orchestra rehearsal. At 9:30 o'clock tomorrow morning the American soprano will be on a plane headed for Phoenix where she has an afternoon dress rehearsal of Der Rosenkavalier.

Two weeks ago the Government ordered La Scala to cancel a planned United States tour because of Italy's monetary crisis. Financial troubles have stalled in Parliament a planned $72 millions appropriation for 13 opera and concert houses.

description: CHICAGO, April 9An unusually dry winter and weeks of searing winds in the five major winter wheat states have reduced the crop expected this year by more than 26 percent, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Islanders' Sweep Eases Their Way
description: The New York Islanders aren't going to do everything the hard way in this year's National Hockey League playoffs. title: Phil Ochs a Suicide at 35; Singer of Peace Movement
description: Phil Ochs, the folk singer, guitarist and lyricist whose music provided some of the strongest notes of protest against the Vietnam War in the early 1960's, committed suicide yesterday morning at his sister's home in Far Rockaway, Queens, the family reported.

title: Film: Electra Retold by Angelopoulos
description: "O Thiassos" is a new Greek film of startling beauty and originalitythat is, for the first two hours or so. But it lasts four hours. Length is part of its problem. A much greater problem is that the political message that is only one of the threads in the first part thickens into hawser dimensions, strangling the film and the audience along with it.Translated as "The Travelling Players," Thiassos is a bloated, spoiled masterpiece. But it is, at the same time, the undoubted high point of the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors series, being shown at the museum today and Wednesday. So far, this year's series has given us a number of fairly dim talents, and sometimes considerably less than that.Theodor Angelopoulos, whose third film this is, possesses enormous talent; large enough to show clearly through his monstrous lack of restraint and, often, to overcome it. Since restraint is easier to acquire than genius, there is a basis for hoping that we are seeing the work of someone who is destined to become a truly great film maker."Thiassos" attempts to tell the story of modern Greece through the wanderings of a band of actors, an unskilled provincial group that sings and dances in front of village theaters to lure audiences inside for a performance of a rough shepherd's play.The action begins in 1939, goes through World War II and the civil war and ends in 1952. Using flashbacks, flash-forwards and narrated recollections, it manages to suggest a broader time span from the 1920's up to the time of the colonels' coup.The film's structure is even more complex than its time frame. It is the story of political developments in Greece as they affect the villages visited by the troupe: the right-wing prewar Metaxas dictatorship, the national unity of right and left during the brief fight against the Axis, the civil war andas the film sees itthe victory of reaction over popular forces.At the same time it is the story of the troupe itself; the decimation of the company under the stress of personal and political passion. Mr. Angelopoulos manages to blend both thingsthe jealousies and betrayals within the company and the political divisions of right and leftinto a retelling of the Electra tragedy.There is no space to begin to enumerate the many marvelous things that are accomplished. Over such a sprawling arrangement for example, Mr. Angelopoulos manages a fair unity of mood by shooting virtually the whole film in the cold, milky overcast of Greek winter.He has some prodigious images. The wartime famine is declared in a tiny scene. A solitary chicken is shown on a snow-covered slope; the members of the troupe advance upon it in black, crablike profile. He has filmed hunger.Elektra, the young actress, is accosted by a black-shirted member of a pro-Metaxas gang. She takes him to her room and tells him to strip. He does, completely. He takes off his first garments in leering anticipation; then, beneath her contemptuous gaze his movements become less certain. Finally, his total nakedness coincides with total humiliation as she turns and walks out. It is a scene of merciless justness.There are many scenes of equal brilliance and force. The acting and camera work are flawless. Mr. Agelopoulos takes many risks. He holds camera or characters still for minutes on end; he has scenes that consist of one character addressing the camera at length. Usually these things work, in surprising ways.But the film begins to flag in the middle. In part, the deliberate pace becomes excessive. Many of the slow gestures begin to seem like affectations.Furthermore, the message begins to shed its complexity and become simply a tract praising the Communist forces who lost the civil war and attacking and caricaturing the conservative victors and their British and American allies.The execessive politicization in a work of normal dimensions and equal ???talent???t would simply be a flaw. Here it is immensely magnified. The discoveries of the first two hours turn into a relentless pounding during the last two.

description: Commemorative and memorial masses on the first anniversary of the death of Josephine Baker, the entertainer, will be celebrated Monday in New York, Paris, Monte Carlo, Rome and Buenos Aires. The service In the city will be offered at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street, at 4 P.M. Memorial guest books signed by those attending will be sent to Jo Bouillon, her husband, and their 12 adopted children.

title: Palmer Cut, Won't Quit
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9With an 81 in the second round. Arnold Palmer missed the cut today for the final 36 holes of the Masters tournament. It was only the second time in 22 Masters that the 46yearold fourtime winner has failed to qualify for the final two rounds. He also missed the cut in 1968.

title: Sabres Eliminate Blues, 21
description: BUFFALO, April 9 (AP)Don Luce sent a 42foot shot past the rookie St. Louis goaltender, Ed Staniowski, at 14 minutes 27 seconds of overtime tonight to give Buffalo a 21 victory over the Blues and move the Sabres into the Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoffs against the New York Islanders. The first game of the series will be held here Sunday.

title: TEXACO AND MOBIL ASSAIL I.R.S. RULING
description: Texaco Inc. and the Mobil Oil Corporation, the nation's second and third largest oil companies, said yesterday that Thursday's Internal Revenue Service ruling with regard to productionsharing payments to foreign governments would1 make American oil companies noncompetitive with foreignowned oil companies.

title: Zeckendorf Sr. Is Accused Of State Tax Delinquency
description: A Manhattan grand jury yesterday charged William Zeckendorf Sr., ruler of America's largest real estate empire until its collapse in 1965, with failing to file state income taxes for 1972 and 1973 when due.

title: RICHARD COLLIGAN OF FREEPORT MINES
description: Richard V. Colligan, vice president of the Freeport Minerals Company, died Thursday on a tour of Freeport properties near Creede, Colo. He was 59 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Donald Byrne, a Chess Master Who Won '53 Open Title, Dies
description: Donald Byrne, a chess player and assistant professor of English at Pennsylvania State University, died Thursday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 45 years old.

title: U.S., SOVIET AGREE ON SIZE OF ATESTS FOR PEACEFUL USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The United States announced today that it and the Soviet Union had completed the proposed text of a treaty fot limiting the size of underground nuclear tests for peaceful purposes.

title: WASHINGTON CHIEF OF A.C.L.U. RESIGNS
description: Charles Morgan Jr., a leading Southern lawyer long active in the civil rights movement, has resigned as director of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union because, he said, the A.C.L.U. bureaucracy tried to restrict his public statements.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CAVALCADE A new Bicentennial exhibition, Theatrical Evolution: 17761976, tracing key phases of the American theater from its European roots to today's Off Off Broadway and including more than 600 art works and stage memorabilia, opens tomorrow and can he seen through June 20 at the Hudson River Museum, 411 Warburton Avenue, in Yonkers. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday: 1 to 5 P.M. on Sunday; and 7 to 10 P.M. Wednesday evening. Admission is free, but contributions are accepted.

title: Luanda Is Expected To Apply Formally For U. N. Aid Soon
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. April 9The new rulers of Angola arc expected to make a formal appeal for international help next week, a United Nations source said today.

title: INTENSITY IN MUSIC BY ALI AKBAR KHAN

title: Sales of Retail Stores Rose by 2.8% in March
description: Retail sales continued strong in March, rising by 2.8 percent over the February level and going ahead of March 1975 by 17.2 percent.

title: Solar Spacecraft Energizer Is Developed

Andrew Anchutin, a former RCA engineer, was granted Patent 3,948,468 for arrays of panels coated with solar cells that convert sunlight to electricity for operation of communications and other equipment aboard a spacecraft.

Today there are nine members of the club but their bickering, nitpicking and varying arguments make one wonder increasingly if the club still exists.

title: THEODORE DUTSCHMANN

title: They Thought It Would Never Come
description: Temperatures were creeping into the upper 40's, but a snaggletoothed wind whistling in from left field lent a Joe Namath touch to an entertainment starring that other New York folk hero, Tom Seaver. This is a folk hero, incidentally, whom the folks welcomed back with boos because he earns more money than they do. He also pitches better, and although he retired after seven frosty innings, he was the winning pitcher in the New York Mets' 32 victory over the Montreal Expos yesterday. It was a day that some feared might never comethe Sports opening day of New York's 1976 baseball season.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Vancouver

title: FISCAL AIDE URGES CITY SERVICES CUT
description: The city cannot be rescued from its fiscal morass until it stops making comparatively small, acrosstheboard reductions in expenditure and decides instead what services to retain and what to discard, Donna E. Shalala, treasurer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, declared yesterday.

title: LISBON ARMY CHIEF DENIES SPINOLA LINK
description: LISBON, April 9The Chief of Staff of the Portuguese Army today denounced a report linking him and other officers to a coup that former President Antonio de Spinola was said to be plotting in an attempt to discredit the country's military leadership.

title: Ecuador Earthquakes Kill 7 and Injure 50
description: QUITO Ecuador, April 9 (AP) two strong earth tremors a, minute apart shook the northern coast and mountains of Ecuador during the night. Authorities said that at least seven persons were killed and 50 injured and more victims were feared buried in rubble.

title: 2 Managers Unfazed In Big League Debuts
description: The toughest decision Joe Frazier and Karl Kuehl had to make yesterday in their first major league games as managers was probably what should they wear for the gusty, 49degree winds that greeted them at Shea Stadium.

title: Truck Tonnage Falls 7.3%
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The American Trucking Associations reported today that intercity truck tonnage in the latest week was 7.3 percent below the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage was 25.1 percent below the preceding week when the Teamsters Union was on strike. The rail carloading report was not available this week.

title: Payoffs Admitted, Some to Officials, By a Trash Hauler
description: WASHINGTON, April 9BrowningFerris Industries Inc., the nation's largest municipal trashhauling company, made payments of dubious legality totaling more than 5100,000 over the last four years, some of which went to public officials in the United States.

title: 300 in Drug Programs Keep Vigil at Gracie Mansion
description: Almost 300 former addicts and drug users who have been sitting and sleeping on the sidewalk in front of Gracie Mansion say they plan to stay there until the budget cuts for city and state drug abuse programs are restored.

title: Albany, as Aid to Business, Studies a Tax on Insurance
description: A sales tax on insurance premiums that could raise $400 million a year to permit reductions in other taxes that are driving business out of New York is being considered by state officials.

title: White Sox Win, 4 to 0, Veeck Style
description: CHICAGO, April 9  Fifteen minutes before the White Sox opened their season today, a bewigged man wearing Revolutionary War battle togs and holding a fife to his lips limped across the Comiskey Park infield on a wooden leg.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Luxury Amid Agony in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 9 Its banks are regularly pillaged, its police force is nonexistent. Armed men grab cars and lift wallets on busy streets in broad daylight. Artillery shells rain down on terrorized residential quarters. Christian neighborhoods are blockaded by leftist and Moslem gunmen.

title: Liturgical Dance Offers the Passion of Christ as Seen by Mary
description: Carla DeSola, in leotard and tights, slowly lifted her partner from an imaginary cross, then paused for instruction from the choreographer.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that the Venezuelan Government had filed a $231 million tax deficiency claim for 1970 against two of its affiliates, Creole Petroleum and International Petroleum (Venezuela) Ltd. An Exxon spokesman said that its legal counsel Venezuela regarded the claims as without legal foundation and said they would be resisted vigorously in the courts. The Venezuelan tax officials say that the Exxon affiliates income from export sales of Venezuelan oil in 1970 should have been calculated by retroactive application of tax valuation standards set by Venezuela in March, 1971.

title: Bombs Kill 2 in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 9 (Reuters)Two men were killed and 19 prsons were injured tonight in two separate bomb attacks on Roman Cathoicowned taverns in Northern Ireland, police officials here said.

title: WESTINGHOUSE SETS PARTIAL FUEL PLAN
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and three electric utilities that sued the company because it had canceled contracts to supply them with nuclear fuel, resolved part of the dispute yesterday with approval of a consent decree. This provides for Westinghouse to supply the utilities with 124,000 pounds of uranium by April 26.

title: $135 Million Voted By Senate to Fund FIu Immunization
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) The Senate passed today a $1.9 billion emergency funding bill that includes money to finance a nationwide flu inoculation program.

title: Finland Icedin by Strike
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 9 (Reuters)  Finland's icebreaker crews went on strike here today for higher pay, as many of Finland's ports remain icebound. Dock workers are already on strike and ships of the merchant fleet have been tied up for more than a week,

title: State to Study Alleged Defects in Pipes Of Sewer Project in Southwest Suffolk
description: LINDENHURST, LI., April 9 The State Department of Environmental Conservation announced today that it would assign engineers to investigate reported defects and discrepancies in pipelines already installed as part of the controversial $700 million Southwest Sewer District project here.

title: Proletarian Chic, or a Picket's VuittonBag Crisis
description: Last week, I became an active participant (although not exactly a seminal figure) in what is unquestionably, for me, the most fashionable and engaging strike of my life. So far, it has been (again, for me) an event of the most ferocious chic and politesse, not unlike, I suppose, the splendid Horseback Dinner given by C. K. G. Billings at the old Sherry's, five blocks away and 73 years ago.

title: LAURENCE WALRATH, EXI.C.C. CHAIRMAN
description: Laurence. Kaye Walrath, who retired as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1972, died Monday in George Washington University Hospital after a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived in Leesburg, Fla.

title: Proposed Catskill Land Gift Stirs Controversy on Taxes
description: TURNWOOD, N. Y.  A proposed gift to a taxexempt organization of 3,700 acres of land along the Beaverkill River, one of the in troutfishing streams n the country, is causing a major controversy in this sparsely settled area of the Catskill. Mountains.

title: WASHINGTON STAR MAY LAY OFF 200
description: WASHINGTON, April 9About 1,700 union employees lof the financially distressed Washington Star are to cornplete voting in the next few days on a company plan to lay off 200 workers and impose a wage freeze on the rest.

title: Mets Seek To Redefine Mays's Pact
description: Officials of the New York Mets denied a report yesterday that Willie Mays had not been paid last year because he had failed to fulfill his duties as instructor and coach.

title: Art: PousetteDart Paintings Glow With Color, Light
description: It is part of the paradoxical quality of pictorial art that a taste for the transcendental must be expressed by means of a sensuous appeal to the eye. The metaphysical must be stated in persuasive physical terms, a sense of the infinite captured in the finite specifications of pigment on canvas. It is in this paradoxical quality that much of the glory and the mystery of the art of painting resides, and few living artists have attained a mastery of its special powers greater than that of Richard PousetteDart.

title: JobHungry Students Turning to C.I.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9Despite the recent disclosures of wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency, the number of college students seeking jobs in the agency has Increased 30 percent over the last year, according to C.I.A. officials.

title: Nets Trounce Spurs, 116 to 101
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 9 The New York Nets saved some of their best basketball of the season for a game that counted tonight as they defeated the San Antonio Spurs in their playoff opener, 116101.

title: Albany, as Aid to Business, Studies a Tax on Insurance
description: A sales tax on insurance premiums that could raise $400 million a year to permit reductions in other taxes that are driving business out of New York is being considered by state officials.

title: JAPANESE PLEDGE TRADE IN SOUTH
description: ATLANTA, April 9  Industrialists representing 10 of Japan's largest corporations pledged at a meeting today with Southern government and business leaders to increase their investment and trade in the Southeast.

title: CBS President Quits
description: Robert D. Wood, presdent of the CBS television network since 1969, has resigned. No successor to the executive who brought All in the Family and other popular programs to the air has been named. Page 55.

title: For Jimmy Carter's Evangelist Sister, Inner Healing Is a Way of Life
description: Ruth Carter Stapleton, an evangelist who espouses a philosophy called inner healing, came to New York yesterday to promote her new book and her brother, Jimmy, the Democratic Presidential candidate, and not necep sarily in that order.

title: WILLIAM D. SHERRERD Jr.
description: William D. Sherrerd Jr., a Philadelphia investment banker, died Tuesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 74 years old.

title: Rare Children's Disease Tied To Solvents Used in Pesticides
description: SYDNEY, Nova Scotia, April 9Research conducted at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, indicates that Reye's Syndrome, a rare but often fatal children's disease, may he linked to chemicals used in pesticide spraying programs.

title: Floyd Raises Lead to 5 Shots
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9Jack Nicklaus said it: When Ray Floyd gets on a hot streak, he usually stays hot. If Nicklaus is right, then the 40th Masters may have been completed this afternoon, two days ahead of schedule.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A $2 BILLION RISE IN ARMS SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The House approved today a $33.4 billion military authorization bill that would add about $2 billion to the Ford Administration's defense program, primarily for construction of nuclearpowered ships for the Navy.

title: Minorities Protest a Plan For Adelphi Scholarships
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 9 (UPI)About 60 black and Hispanic students staged a demDnstration outside the Adelphi University student center this afternoon to protest a new university policy to centralize the awarding of scholarships.

title: Giants Play Ball, and Win, Despite Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 What seemed so unlikely two months ago and remained somewhat in doubt even this morning came to pass at Candlestick Park this afternoon: the San Francisco Giants opened the 1976 baseball season at home and they beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 42, before a crowd of 37,261.

title: JOHN TREVOR GARMEY
description: John Trevor Garmey, organist and choirmaster at the Union Church of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, from 1923 to 1950, died of a stroke Wednesday at the age of 91. He lived in Rochester.

title: Prices Rise Sharply In Coffee Futures
description: Coffee futures jumped the daily 2centsapound limit again yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The July contract closed at $1.18, up 2 cents. At the start of April the same contract sold at 1.10 7/10 a pound.

title: Ford Signs Law to Ease Municipal Bankruptcies
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 President Ford today signed into law a municipal bankruptcy act that makes it easier for New York and other financially hardpressed cities to petition for bankruptcy.

title: Head of CBSTV Quits
description: Robert D. Wood, president of the CBS television network since 1969, has resigned. No successor to the executive who brought All in the Family and other popular programs to the air has been named. Page 55.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Voters are advised that the state's new electoral rules require that those who want to change their political party affiliation must do so at least 50 days before the primary. This means that New Jerseyans intending to vote in the primary June 8 should file a declaration of their intentions by April 19.

title: HIRAM L. M'DADE
description: Hiram L. McDade, a tax lawyer who was executive vice president of Fiduciary Counsel Inc. of New York, died at Millard Fillmore Hospital in Buffalo on Tuesday after heart surgery. He was 60 years old, lived in Mountain Lakes, N.J., and had been in Buffalo on a business trip.

title: Information on Pesticides Inadequate, Train Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) Pesticide manufacturers have submitted inadequate information to get Government approval for use of the chemicals, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: ISRAELIS REBUKE U.S. AMBASSADOR
description: TEL AVIV, April 9Israeli officials today criticized the United States Ambassidor, Malcolm Tam, for having charged at a news briefing yesterday that Israel was trying to put pressure on Congress to approve more aid than requested by President Ford.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates to Friday.

title: Grand Jury Taking Testimony On seizure of Mellon Children
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn disclosed yesterday that a grand jury had started taking testimony in a.n investigation into the abduction on March 19 of the two daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon.

title: Callaway Publicity Plagues Ski Resort
description: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo.It has been so warm and gunny up on Howard Callaway's ski mountain that students on spring vacation have been schussing in Tshirts, their noses caked with white sunscreen goo, their faces as red as the burgundy that leaks from their wineskins into the melting snow.

title: RollCall on Overriding Veto of the Stavisky Bill
description: ALBANY, April 9Following is the vote by which the State Senate today sustained Governor Carey's veto of the Stavisky bill. Twothirds of the full Senate, or 40 votes, would have been needed to override the veto. There is one vacancy in the Senate.

title: CONSERVATION AIDES, QUIT ALBANY POSTS
description: ALBANY, Apr. 9 (UPI)Two more officials of the embattled Environmental Conservation Department have submitted their resignations.

title: Bell Cow
description: The agreement in principle of the Californiabased Bank of Americalargest in the nationto buy $100 million in New York State shortterm notes has markedly improved chances that the state will raise the $2.75 billion from the private credit markets it needs to cover its immediate cash requirements.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs to 5% state tax).

title: RAYTHEON PROFIT RISES IN QUARTER
description: The Raytheon Company, a diversified manufacturer of electronic parts and a major detense contractor, had record sales and earnings in the first quarter, the company reported yesterday. Its order backlog has been declining.

title: Italy Sliding Toward Premature Vote
description: Rome, April 9The Italian government, battered by a new political crisis, is moving toward a decision to resign and make way for parliamentary elections this June, a year ahead of schedule.

title: Black Mayors Cautioned On Presidential Aspirants
description: ATLANTA, April 9  Basil Paterson, the vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, urged the second annual convention of the Southern Conference of Black Mayors today to make certain that Presidential candidates took positive stands on black issues before supporting them.

title: FlameRetardant Sleepwear: Is There a Risk of Cancer?
description: With manmade factors increasingly blamed as cancercausing agents, controversy has come to rest lately on a seemingly harmless consumer product: children's sleepwear.

title: Learn Your Way, Library Program, Advises on Careers
description: A Learn Your Way program in the city's public librarries is providing educational and career guidance for those who wish to extend and improve their learning, to change careers, to earn a high school equivalency diploma or a college degree or to brush up on old skills.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED ON ALBANY DRIVE FOR SPRING LOANS
description: ALBANY, April 9  William H. Morton, chairman of a panel of bankers advising the state during its fiscal crisis, said today that he had become completely convinced the state would meet its vital spring borrowing requirement by the middle of next week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh Brothertfets Pick Twins
description: The Jets generated that stroke of romanticism that sometimes spices the long second day of the National Football League's annual draft of college players. In consecutive selections on the 12th round yesterday, the New York team drafted twin brothers from North Carolina State, Dave and Don Buckey, who had been coached in college by the Jets' new man, Lou Holtz.

title: Screen: Hitchcock's 'Family Plot' Bubbles Over
description: Not since "To Catch a Thief" and "The Trouble With Harry" has Alfred Hitchcock been in such benign good humor as he is in "Family Plot," the old master's 56th feature since he began directing films in 1922."Family Plot," which opened at theaters all over town yesterday, is a witty, relaxed lark. It's a movie to raise your spirits even as it dabbles in phony ones, especially those called forth by Blanche (Barbara Harris), a sweet, pretty, totally fraudulent Los Angeles medium, who nearly wrecks her vocal cords when possessed by a control whose voice sounds like Sidney Greenstreet's.But "Family Plot" isn't about anything as esoteric as spiritualism and its sometimes wayward votaries. It's about good old-fashioned greed, or, how to work very, very hard in order to make your fortune illegally. It's one of the many invigorating ironies of "Family Plot" that its con people are so obsessed by their criminal pursuits they never realize the easier way would probably be the lawful one.Then, of course, there would be no plot, and a high regard for plot is one of the distinguishing joys of both Hitchcock and this new film.Ernest Lehman's screenplay, based on a novel by Victor Canning, is about the efforts of Blanche and her boyfriend, Lumley (Bruce Dern), a good-natured lug who works as a cab driver but thinks he'd like to be an actor, to track down the missing heir to a huge West Coast fortune. If Blanche's spirits help her to find the fellow, she's been promised $10,000 by the heir's ancient aunt (Cathleen Nesbitt). Although $10,000 isn't exactly beyond our wildest dreams, to Blanche and Lumley it represents a lot of palms that won't have to be read.The object of their man-hunt, though they don't know it for a long time, is a wealthy Los Angeles jeweler named Adamson (William Devane) who, with his girlfriend. Fran (Karen Black), has a passion for oversize diamonds he cannot afford.To satisfy their passion, Adamson and Fran have perfected the art of kidnapping for ransoms of king-size jewels. When we first meet them, they are just completing the successful abduction of a fabulously rich, seemingly Greek international financier and, before the movie is over, they've had equally good luck with the abduction of a bishop, whom they snatch from the altar of his cathedral during mass.Hitchcock cross-cuts between the two couples in the course of the film to build a kind of menace-free but very real suspense. Fran and Adamson, who live in a very chic San Francisco town house (though the rest of the movie appears to be set in Los Angeles), are naturally worried when they learn they are being pursued by an eccentric fortuneteller and her taxi driver lover, and they take steps to eliminate the investigators.It's not revealing too much, I think, to report that these steps are never completely successful. Blanche and Lumley, merged, make a single bird-brain, but one whom heaven protects and fortune smiles on.As performed by Miss Harris and Mr. Dern, they are two of the most appealing would-be rascals that Hitchcock has even given us. For that matter so are Adamson and Fran (she has no last name, which leaves her matrimonial state in Old World, gentlemanly doubt). Though Adamson is portrayed as being perfectly willing to murder, when cornered, he never succeeds, and Fran is the kind of kidnapper who prepares gourmet meals for her involuntary guests.The four are extremely good company, like Hitchcock himself when, in an expansive, genial, storytelling mood, even his digressions have digressions, but always to the point of some higher entertainment truth.Hitchcock aficionados may well miss signs of the director's often overanalyzed pessimism. "Family Plot" is certainly Hitchcock's most cheerful film in a long time, but it's hardly innocent. One of the things that figure prominently in the plot, though it happens long before the film starts, is the story of a young man who, finding his stepparents boring, pours gasoline all over the house and incinerates the offending pair.It's a small thing, perhaps, but it continues the master's franchise on the macabre.

title: Music: Chamber Artists Ensemble Plays
description: Welding a collection of musicians, even toprung musicians, into a cohesive ensemble is no overnight job. It can take years, though in rare cases there is a comparatively quick congealing of personalities and talents. So, no one expected chamber music at a Parnassian level when the recently formed Chamber Artists Ensemble of New York performed at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night.

title: BUDGET AMENDMENTS DEFEATED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Senate defeated today all attempts to amend the budget targets for the fiscal year 1977 that were made by its Budget Committee.

title: political Scientists Vary On Constitutional Theme
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8In order to imagine a more perfect Union, the Academy of olitical and Social Scienct convened a conference hers this week.

title: Mr. Carter on Housing
description: For perhaps the first time in his wellplanned campaign, Jimmy Carter has been thrown on the defensive as he tries to explain just where he stands on the issues of open housing and racially as well as economically integrated neighborhoods. To Mr. Carter's credit he has not sought refuge merely in obfuscatory backpedaling after delivering himself of some offensive phrases; he bluntly and quickly apologized for them.

title: GEORGE GREENBERG
description: George Greenberg, who had been a stage manager on Broadway for many years, died Wednesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: Yankees' Protest Of Hill Goes Flat
description: MILWAUKEE, April 9Manager Billy Martin said today he had protested the Yankees' opening game loss to Milwaukee because the pitcher's mound at County Stadium was too flat.

title: Woman Held in Ford Threat
description: DALLAS, April 9 (UPI)A Federal judge ordered Sharon Denise Jones Morgan to be held today on $50,000 bond on a charge that she threatened to kill President Ford in a telephone conversation with a policeman she had known for more than 10 years. United States Magistrate Bailey Rankin, noting that Mr. Ford was due in Dallas within a few hours, appointed an attorney for the 27yearold Greenville, Tex, woman and ordered her to be retained in Federal custody unless she could raise bond. Mrs. Morgan said she innocent.

title: New Music From Israel
description: Thursday evening's League of ComposersInternational Society for Contemporary Music concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was unusually interesting even before a note had sounded. The program was devoted to new music from. Israel, and consisted of five first American performances and one first performance.

title: Antiques: Museum Sale
description: The deaccessioning auction offering everything from ??arty 19thcentury bitters bottles to a vintage horsedrawn fire engine at the Old Museum Village of Smith's Clove in Monroe, N.Y., has accomplished two goals.

title: Ellington's Widow Dies
description: Evie Ellis Ellington, the widow of Duke Ellington, the composer, pianist and bandleader, who died in May 1974, died of cancer Wednesday at New York Hospital. Mrs. Ellington, who was the Duke's third wife, was 64 years old and lived on Central Park South. She had been a dancer at the Cotton Club before her marriage in 1939.

title: Stage: Tale for Children
description: So much of children's theateris earthbound and derivative, it dulls rather than stimulates the imagination. Therefore it is refreshing to cone upon such a fanciful play an John Heuer's Cavern of the Jewels. Mr. Heuer wrote this fairy tale for the Circle Repertory Company under a Younger Play Commission grant from the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Ford, in Texas, Requests Stronger Drug Penalties
description: DALLAS, April 9President Ford, virtually conceding that legislation to reform the Federal penal code would not be passed this year, said today that he would ask Congress to act separately to establish stiff prison sentences for what he called merchants of deaththose who traffic in large quantities of hard drugs.

title: Mugging the Parks
description: Now that the flowering trees and shrubs are approaching full bloom in New York's great parks, it's time for the police to treat the good citizens who blithely break off branches, uproot shrubs and pick blossoms in the parks as the criminal vandals that they are.

title: Mexican Police Say Aide Forged Hughes's Name
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 9  Mexico's Federal Judicial Police announced tonight that one of the late Howard Hughes's aides will be charged with forging the signature of the billionaire when he entered Mexico two months ago.

title: Deaths
description: AMSTERElsie R., beloved wife of the late Henry, loved by daughter Carol and Edward Rivlin, by grandchildren Timothy and Judith, by sister Gisela Rosenberg. and the late Edwin Rosenberg, and by sisterinlaw Bertha Rosenberg. Services Sunday, 2 P.M., at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Friends of Central Park.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 9A fullscale debate on the outlawing or censoring of pornographic and extremely violent movies seems to be building in the State Legislature and elsewhere in government.

title: SOVIET AGAIN DENIES EXIT VISAS TO JEWS
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (Reuters) Soviet authorities have again refused exit visas to a majority among about 60 Jews who were told In February to ask for a review of their requests to emigrate to Israel, Jewish sources said today.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A $2 BILLION RISE IN ARMS SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The House approved today a $33.4 billion military authorization bill that would add about $2 billion to the Ford Administration's defense program, primarily for construction of nuclearpowered ships for the Navy.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Notes on People column in The New York Times on Wednesday, it was erroneously reported that the American Jewish Committee, publisher of Commentary magazine, and Norman Podhoretz, editor of the magazine, were codefendants in a $3 million libel suit filed by Golda Meir, the former Israeli Prime Minister, against Lev Novrozov, a writer. Litigation against the committee and Mr. Podhoretz was discontinued in January.

title: HELEN BINGHAM RYAN
description: Helen Bingham Ryan, executive vice president of the Ladies of Charity of the Archdiocese of New York since 1953 and founder of the Ladies of Charity of the United States, died Thursday. She was 74 years old and lived at 30 East 38th Street.

title: Jail Suicide in Yonkers Is Buried
description: YONKERS. April 9 (AP)A brief funeral service was held here today for 20yearold Steven Karagianis, who hanged himself in a jail cell Wednesday after being arrested on a probation violation warrant that had been canceled in January.

title: Cleric's Conviction Is Reversed Over Role of Women in Church
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis., April 9 (AP)A church review court announced today its decision reversing the conviction of the Rev. L. Peter Beebe for violating Episcopal Church laws by permitting women to celebrate holy communion with him.

title: 9 Steel Companies Fined In Price Conspiracy Case
description: HOUSTON, April 9 (AP)Nine steel companies and nine steel executives were fined a total of nearly $600,000 today after pleading no contest to charges of conspiracy to fix prices.

title: Butz Says He Forwarded a Resort Memo
description: DES MOINES, April 9 (AP) Earl L. Butz, the Secretary of Agriculture, said today that he forwarded a memorandum from a subordinate supporting thee. controversial expansion of Howard H. Callaway's ski resort in Colorado.

title: Notes on People
description: State Democratic leaders began yesterday to check applications for 66 atlarge delegate seats for the national convention in July. Among hundreds they received, one was from 87yearold James A. Farley. The former national chairman of the party and Postmaster General has attended every Democratic convention since 1924.

title: GEORGE WILLIAMSON
description: George Williamson, who retired three years ago as vice president and treasurer of Pepsico Inc., died Wednesday of circulatory complications. He was 63 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: U.S. SOVIET AGREE ON SIZE OF ATESTS FOR PEACEFUL USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The United States announced today that it and the Soyiet Union had completed the proposed text of a treaty for limiting the size of underground nuclear tests for peaceful purposes.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Israel Aid
description: The quarrel between Congress and the Administration over the amount of aid for Israel this year is not a dispute over how much would be enough to meet Israel's needs; it is, rather, over the question of how much Israel was told to expect just a few weeks ago, and why President Ford then suddenly changed his mind.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Births

title: Easier Recourse to Courts Is Urged
description: ST. PAUL, April 9In a heated protest against many of the proposals at the National Conference of Judges and Lawyers here, a prominent public interest lawyer called on the judiciary and the bar today to make it easier rather than harder, for people to take their problems to the courts.

title: Robert D. Wood, President Of CBS Network, Resigns
description: Robert D. Wood, president of the CBS television network since 1969, resigned yesterday to take a new position in Southern California, his home state.

title: The Bonn Coalition
description: At a time when Helmut Schmidt's prestige abroad may be at the highest point of his two years as West Germany's Chancellor, little seems to be going right on the home front for his coalition of Social and Free Democrats in this election year. The substantial losses sustained by both partners in state legislative elections in BadenWrttemberg this week are only the latest in a series of setbacks for Mr. Schmidt's Government.

title: ExGuardian of Karen Quinlan Wants to Review Court Decision
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 9The disconnecting of the respirator that has kept Karen Anne Quinlan alive for almost a year is likely to be delayed at least a week while her former courtappointed guardian and his lawyer review the New Jersey Supreme Court decision that allows her to die.

title: Federal Mediator Urged for Strike In San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (UPI)Former Mayor George Christopher withdrew today as! impartial observer in negotiations between the city and striking municipal craft workers, calling the 10  day  old walkout hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Japanese Businesses Strive for Lower Corporate Debt
description: TOKYO, April 9Some Japanese businesses, which were able to carry unusually large corporate debt burdens in the days of rapid economic growth have begun longterm efforts in recent weeks to trim these debts in preparation for an era of lower growth.

title: NORTHWEST BACKS, MICRODOT MERGER
description: Northwest Industries Inc. announced yesterday that its directors and those of its 84 percent owned Microdot Inc. have unanimously approved a merger plan under which Microdot would become a wholly owned Northwest subsidiary.

title: Tentative Rise of 9.8% a Year Set for U.S. Crude Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Federal Energy Administration published today a tentative schedule for domestic crude oil price increases at a rate of 9.8 percent a year through May, 1979.

title: The Revolutionary Paradox
description: It was a paradox 200 years ago and it remained so well into the next century. How is it that we hear the loudest yelps for liberty among the drivers of Negroes? Samuel Johnson said, looking across the Atlantic contemptuously. The question was still coming up a few years before the Civil War. Douglas and Lincoln, debating, went deep into the wellsprings of liberty to fathom the meaning in the language of the Constitution. Why was not slavery openly mentioned? Where were the actual words bondage, slavery or Negro? Douglas saw the omission as a justification for his views on the democratic extension of slavery, but Lincoln had a generous interpretation: It was hoped when it should be read by intelligent and patriotic men, after the institution of slavery had passed from among us, there should be nothing on the face of the great charter of liberty suggesting that such a thing as Negro slavery had ever existed among us.

title: Nigeria Faces Crisis Despite Oil
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 8After four years of relentless growth fueled by oil, Nigeria's economy is showing signs of distress.

title: Leeds Hackett Weds Veronica W. Byrnes
description: Veronica Walker Byrnes, a Chemical Bank vice president, was married in the city yesterday afternoon to Leeds Hackett, a senior vice president with the Marine Midland Bank's London office. Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appeals performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Use of Portuguese Workers Stirs Union Threat to Pipeline Project
description: READINGTON TOWNSHIP, April 9  Labor troubles are threatening to disrupt construction of a longdelayed pipeline from the Round Valley Reservoir in this rural Hunterdon County community.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Notes on People column in The New York Times on Wednesday, it was erroneously reported that the American Jewish Committee, publisher of Commentary magazine, and Norman Podhoretz, editor of the magazine, were codefendants in a $3 million libel suit filed by Golda Meir, the former Israeli Prime Minister, against Lev Novrozov, a writer. Litigation against the committee and Mr. Podhoretz was discontinued in January.

title: Panama's Leader Calls for New Pact On Canal by 1977
description: PANAMA, April 9 (AP)Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's chief executive, says serious trouble could erupt in the United Statesowned Panama Canal Zone if a new treaty is not reached by 1977 to turn the zone over to Panamanians.

title: Sadat Confers With Tito; Bid for Weapons Is Seen
description: BELGRADE, Yugodlavia, April 9 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and President Tito had talks today that were believed to include preparations for a nonaligned conference this summer, the Middle East situation and possible Yugoslav arms supplies to Cairo.

title: Advisory Group Is Named For the U.S. Patent Office
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 Secretary of Commerce Elliot L. Richardson has announced the appointment of a general advisory committee for the Patent and Trademark Office. Besides patent examining operations, such matters as legislation and treaties are to be considered.

title: Argentine Policeman Killed
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 9 (UPI) Gunmen killed an Argentine police inspector and critically wounded another policeman today in political violence.

title: FREDERICK S. BAKER
description: Frederick Sherman Baker, a retired editor and the author of three novels, died Thursday in Huntington, L.I. He was 73 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: HUMPHREY DRAFT MAY BE RENEWED
description: WASHINGTON, April 9A formal campaign by prominent Democrats to draft Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for their party's Presidential nomination is tentatively scheduled to begin late this month, after the Pennsylvania primary.

title: 4 Girls Taken From Foster Parents After Five Years
description: Four young sisters were taken yesterday from the Hicksville, L.I., home of their foster parents of five and a half years, who were ordered by a court never to see the children again.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED ON ALBANY DRIVE FOR SPRING LOANS
description: ALBANY, April 9  William H. Morton, chairman of a panel of bankers advising the state during its fiscal crisis, said today that he had become completely convinced the state would meet its vital spring borrowing requirement by the middle of next week.

title: Bank of England Supports Pound After It Hits a Low
description: BRUSSELS, April 9 (UPI)The British pound sank for a time to a low on European money markets today until the Bank of England intervened. The Italian lira sank to a low against the dollar.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: COPENHAGENVictor Galin dez. Argentina, outpointed Jessie Burnett. Los Angeles, light heavyweights 12 rounds.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Nets vs. San Antonio April 9Nets 116, San Antonio 101.

title: Release of Mrs. Ryan on Bail Appealed in West Germany
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, April 9 (UPI)West German prosecutors today appealed a court decision to release on bail Hermine BraunSteiner Ryan, the Germanborn New Yorker charged with Nazi concentration camp murders.

title: Solomon, Rosewall Gain Net Semifinals
description: HOUSTON, April 9 (AP)Harold Solomon, who could not win on his serve until the third game of the second set, posted a 16, 64, 63 victory over Ilie Nastase today in a World Championship of Tennis touranment at River Oaks Country Club.

title: Postal Fee Rises Of Up to 33% Set On Some Services
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The Postal Service announced today increases of tip to 33 percent in the fees for special delivery, registered mail and other services.

title: Hijackers Offer to Release Hostages in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, April 10 (Reuters)Three gunmen holding 12 Filipinos hostage on a hijacked plane today offered to set them free in return for a flight to a safe haven.

title: Cards Top Cubs, 50, On 6Hitter
description: ST. LOUIS, April 9 (UPI)Lou Brock, Ted Simmons, Reggie Smith and Hector Cruz drove in one run each tonight to back the sixhit pitching of Lynn McGlothen and give the St. Louis Cardinals a 50 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: COUNCIL UNIT ASKS A RESIDENCY LAW
description: Over the strong opposition of the presidents of both the police officers' and firemen's unions, a City Council committee voted out a resolution yesterday calling on the Legislature to require future municipal employees to live in New York City.

title: Ravenous Bluefish Attack Swimmers At Florida Beaches
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., April 9 (UPI)Ravenous bluefish pursuing schools of mullet went on a feeding frenzy along a section of the Florida east coast today, injuring at least a dozen swimmers and forcing the closing of 15 miles of beach from Fort Lauderdale to Deerfield Beach.

title: Basketball
description: Pistons 116, Hawks 108

title: Gillard Is Ruled Eligible to Play
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., April 9 (AP)Larry Gillard, today won a permanent injunction against the National Collegiate Athletic Association in his suit to insure his football eligibility at Mississippi State University.

title: Hungarians Assail Kissinger for View On Eastern Europe
description: VIENNA, April 9 (Reuters)Hungary, in an unusually sharp press attack on Henry A. Kissinger, today accused the Secretary of State of breach of faith in recent statements of American policy toward Eastern Europe.

title: Assembly in Connecticut Approves an Austere Budget
description: HARTFORD, April 9  The Connecticut General Assembly today approved a $1.8 billion budget only slightly altered and fully as austere as that proposed to the legislators in February by Gov. Ella Grasso.

title: Dog Track in N.H. Sold for $870,000
description: BELMONT, N. H., April 9 (AP)The Ferd Corporation of Nashua today bought the Belmont dog track for $870,000 at a sevenminute auction.

title: VORSTER AND RABIN MEET IN JERUSALEM
description: JERUSALEM, April 9 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa began talks here today with Israeli leaders, who ordered rigorous security measures for his fourday visit.

title: Court Frees Partner of Tannen
description: After wiretap evidence was ruled inadmissible, a Federal judge in Florida has thrown out an indictment for bookmaking and illegal gambling against a partner of Steve Tanrren of the New York Jets. Ira Israel Vernon was the majority owner of a boutique that Tannen had founded in Gainesville, Fla. Last Dec. 8 Vernon and several others: were arrested and charged with illegal activities. The indictment against the following also were dismissed: Arnold Tishler of Lynbrook, L.I., Jack Cohen of Brooklyn, Penny Griesmger and Michael Brudny of Gainesville and Joseph DeCicco of Miami, Tannen was never accused of wrongdoing.

title: Life at Home Disappoints Greeks On Return From Working Abroad
description: KILKIS, Greece  Fifteen years ago this town in northern Greece was a harsh place to live. Farmers grew some wheat and tobacco, but jobs were as scarce as new shoes. Then the mills and factories of Western Europe started calling for foreign workers and people throughout this region responded by the thousands.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold pilces Friday Lindon: Morning fixing $128.30, up $0.10; afternoon fixing $127.70 down $0.50. Paris: Afternoon market ?? $129.88 up $0.34 Frankfurt: Fixing 128.84 up $0.41 Zurich: $127.25 bld down $0.75. $128.00 Hnady & Harman base price, New York: $127.79, down $0.50. Engelhard selling price, New York: $128.20, down $0.50.

title: Carter Elaborates on His Ethnic View
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9With his campaign still off balance from the tempest over his use of the term ethnic purity in defending the integrity of neighborhoods, Jimmy Carter carried his Presidential bid today to Ohio, a state where tightly knit ethnic minorities constitute a considerable political force.

title: Zen Is Reported Passing Up Derby
description: Zen, winner of all five career starts, will bypass the Kentucky Derby regardless of how he does in the $100,000 Wood Memorial next Saturday at Aqueduct it was reported yesterday.

title: Gaullist Party Chief Quits; Succession Set for April 24
description: PARIS, April 9 (UPI)Andr Bord resigned today as secretary general of the Gaullist party to make way for a new leader to fight the growing power of the leftwing parties.

title: Ralph K. Rogers, Chairman Of a Management Concern
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 9 Ralph K. Rogers, chairman of the board of Rogers, Slade and Hill Inc., management consult. ants in New York City, died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Paris's Knitwear Message Pockets and Solids
description: PARIS, April 9Designers here tend to reinvent fashion every six months. Some seasons they're in better form than others, which means that last spring's hero can be this fall's disaster.

title: JobHungry Students Turning to C.I.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9Despite the recent disclosures of wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency, the number of college students seeking Jobs in the agency has increased 30 percent over the last year, according to C.I.A. officials.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Almost a year after the filing of a formal complaint against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for raising bridge tolls 50 percent, the Federal Highway Administration has ordered a full administrative law judge hearing on whether the increase was lawful. The Federal agency's action was in response to the complaint filed on April 16, 1975, by Representative Peter A. Peyser, RepublicanConservative of the Bronx and Westchester County. He has contended that the increase was unreasonable and has said he will request a. complete rollback of the tolls if they are found to be unlawful.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Payless Furlough Averted For City U. Faculty Again
description: The Chancellor of City University, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, announced yesterday that there would be no Payless furlough of faculty and staff members during the Easter holiday next week as had been proposed to cut costs for the financially pressed university.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Art: Chinese Landscape Paintings at the Met
description: One of the most disquieting experiences that one can have in a great museum is to stumble upon a Chinese landscape painting that is all of 1,000 years old. When we think how long it took for landscape painting as such to be taken seriously in Europe as an independent form of art, there is something humbling about the activity of the Chinese hermit landscapists who never had any doubt that what they were doing was completely satisfying.

title: CHINA CHIEFS JOIN ANTITENG RALLIES
description: HONG KONG, April 9 China's Foreign Minister and other senior officials led street demonstrations in Peking today expressing support for the ouster of Teng Hsiaoping, the former senior Deputy Prime Minister, as the nation's leaders evidently sought to prevent any further outbreak of unrest like the rioting in Peking on Monday.

title: Attorney Moves for Dismissal Of Counts Against Blumenthal
description: Louis Nizer, appearing as attorney for Albert H. Blurnenthat, majority leader of the State Assembly, declared yesterday that his client had performed pro hono publico for the public goodthose acts for which he had been indicted for bribery and perjury.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Clear skies will continue today over the Northeast; light snow may fall in the northern portions of Maine and New Hampshire. Cool weather is forecast from the Northeast and Appalachians to Florida and the Gulf States. It will be cool in the central Rockies, and mild throughout the rest of the country. Thundershowers may occur in eastern Nebraska, while rain, and possibly snowshowers, will prevail across southern Minnesota, South Dakota, Wyoming and Montana. Showers are expected along the Pacific Coast from Washingto into central California. Fair weather will occur elsewhere.

title: House Unit Almost Hired Admitted Spy
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 James F. Sattler, a political scientist who has admitted being a spy for East Germany for the last nine years, came close to being hired for a sensitive staff position on Capitol Hill last year. He lost the job when it was learned he was under surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Symphony No. 100, Haydn; Konzertsuck for Piano and Orchestra, Hiller; Overture to The Journey to Rheims, Rossini; Les Foliates, Franck; Symphonic Sketches, Chadwick; Overture  Panache. Chappell; Fantasy for Violin and Orchestra, Suk; Marche Caprice, Delius; Fete Boheme from Scenes Pittoresque, Massenet.

title: Mets Beat Expos, 32, in Opener; Seaver Goes 7 Innings, Fans 8
description: After six months of legal grappling, baseball reappeared in New York yesterday with bats and balls, and the Mets marked the occasion with a 32 victory over the Montreal Expos in chilly, windy Shea Stadium.

title: King Seeks Pro Offer
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 9 (AP)Bernard King, a sophomore from the University of Tennessee, asked the National Basketball Association today to place his name on the June draft list as a hardship case. He says that he will sign with the pros if he gets a satisfactory bonus offer. If not, he plans to continue his career at Tennesee.

title: Drought Reduces Wheat Estimate; Yield Still Large
description: CHICAGO, April 9An unusually dry winter and weeks of searing winds in the five major winter wheat states have reduced the crop expected this year by more than 26 percent, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLOGMay. In loving memory of a devoted wife, mother and grandmother.

title: 3 Assail Agencies OnPayoff Positions
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Internal Revenue Service came under attack yesterday from two prominent New York lawyers and a former S.E.C. official for their positions on foreign payoffs.

title: To Be Educated, or More Educated: That Is the Question
description: In the next few months hard choices will be made concerning the future of the City University of New Yorkchoices that go to the heart of the democratic nature of higher education and the types of programs that can most benefit a troubled city.

title: Bridge:
description: The mostdisappointed players at the end of the Cavendish invitational pairs tournament last weekend were certainly the British duo of Irving Rose and John Form.

title: Carey and Democratic Aides in Albany Seeking an Alternative to Stavisky Bill
description: ALBANY, April 9Negotia??ons began again today with ??newed urgency to find an alternative to the Stavisky bill, which was prevented from becoming law over Governor Carey's veto by the narrowest and possibly most temporaryof margins in a dramatic ??enate session that lasted until ??arly this morning.

title: A List of Special Musical, Dance and Dramatic Events During Holy Week
description: Palm Sunday, April 11

title: Japanese Dies in Blizzard
description: SAPPORO, Japan, April 9 (Reuters)  A 21yearold man froze to death on his way home from his office in a blizzard, the police reported here. An unseasonable storm has lashed Japan's main northern island of Hokkaido, bringing a record snowfall of up to 25 Inches.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, April 10, 1975

title: MarriageLaw Reform Clears Bonn Parliament
description: BONN, April 9 (AP)Parliament today passed a law that grants West German women equal rights in marriage and allows uncontested divorces after a oneyear separation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: BridgeToll Hearing Ordered

title: CHINA CHIEFS JOIN ANTITENG RALLIES
description: HONG KONG, April 9China's Foreign Minister and other senior officials led street demonstrations in Peking today expressing support for the ouster of Teng Hsiaoping, the former senior Deputy Prime Minister, as the nation's leaders evidently sought to prevent any further outbreak of unrest like the rioting in Peking on Monday.

title: Top Boy Scout Executive Resigning, Effective May 1
description: Alden G. Barber resigned yesterday as chief executive officer of the Boy Scouts of America, effective May 1, to pursue other interests.

title: CADET IS ACCUSED OF A SECOND RAPE
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 9 A cadet at the United States Military Academy who was indicted Wednesday on charges of raping a Rockland County housewife has now been charged with raping a Smith College student on the Academy grounds.

title: Market Place
description: One of the more interesting points about the current bull market is the strength of a number of basicindustry stocks.

title: Flu Cases Decline
description: ATLANTA, April 9 (AP)Widespread outbreaks of influenza ceased, but the number of deaths linked to flu and pneumonia continued above the epidemic threshhold countrywide at the start of April, the national Center for Disease Control said today.

title: HUMPHREY DRAFT MAY BE RENEWED
description: WASHINGTON, April 9A formal campaign by prominent Democrats to draft Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for their party's Presidential nomination is tentatively scheduled to begin late this month, after the Pennsylvania primary.

title: Looking Beyond The Nose
description: My friend Murray says it will be Ted Kennedy. What is impressive about this prediction is that Murray lives in Queens, which is that part of New York City inhabited by people whom people in Washington and Manhattan think of as the people.

title: Amerada Hess's Chairman Tells of Payments Abroad
description: Leon Hess, chairman of the Amerada Hess Corporation, said in a letter to stockholders this week that he had made a series of payments, substantial in the aggregate, to a foreign government official.

title: India, Wary of Pakistani and Chinese Neighbors, Amasses the Third Largest Army in the World
description: NEW DELHI, April 8India, a country that says it is devoted to peace but threatened by hostile neighbors, has gradually and quietly built up the thirdlargest army in the world.

title: Pacers Win, Even Colonel Series,11
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 10 (AP)Indiana's Billy Knight and Dave Robisch, controlling the middle while Kentucky's Artis Gilmore was benched with five fouls, rallied the Pacers to a 10995 victory over the Colonels tonight and a 11 tie in their firstround American Basketball Association playoff series.

title: The strange end of the Great War
description: The Australian Thomas Keneally has written a documentary novel about the behavior of the Allied and German signers of the Armistice in the forest clearing at Compiegne on Nov. 11, 1918, and I started it with misgivings. Did we really need another Ragtime or Travesties, reducing the great to dolls? Did we need a novel with arch editorializing chapter titles like The Puny Rvige of the Count's Obsessions and Bedtime Childishness? Did we need a novel written largely in little fauxnalf simple sentences, with occasional campy puns supplied by the narrator? And why, in a novel, the use of stage dialogue?

title: Lawyer to Wed Catherine Wiss, Aide of H.E.W.
description: Catherine Jean Wiss, a civilrights specialist with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in Washington, and Walter Christian Schumann, a lawyer with the Appellate Court branch of the National Labor Relations Board in Washington, plan to be mulled in June.

title: PASSOYER BEGINS WEDNESDAY EVE
description: As Jews prepared for the weeklong observance of Passover, which begins at sundown Wednesday, secular and religious leaders called on them to identify themselves with the plight of Soviet Jews and to give Israel greater moral and financial support.

title: Nuclear Test Ban
description: The 1974 NixonBrezhnev pact, aimed at extending the atmospheric ban on nuclear explosions to underground weapons tests over 150 kilotons, was to go into effect this spring, but only if agreement could be negotiated to limit the size of underground peaceful nuclear explosions (PNE's) as well, and to subject them to onsite inspection.

title: Answers/Questions
description: ROSE HIPS (March 28)

title: In Memoriam
description: BLOGMay. In loving memory of a devoted wife, mother and grandmother. BLOG FAMILY.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES New York 1, Montreal 0.

title: Howard Hughes: Prime Mover in U.S. Aviation
description: He died, appropriately enough, in an airplane.

title: How Not to Stop Carter
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C., April 10Ever since Jimmy Carter took the lead in the Presidential election, his opponents have been trying to prove he was all shell and no peanut. If he talks in generalities, he is accused of being fuzzy, and if he talks in specifics, he's accused of being dizzy. This is the normal fate of the frontrunner, but it seems to this reporter that he's now getting a bum rap on the ethnic purity issue.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE was a lovely sunny Sunday a week or so ago and I did what everyone else does on days like that, even though we should all know better. I got in the car and went for a drive. What with all the traffic, the fumes and smog created an atmosphere of miasma along what we laughingly call the open road and I realized I would have been better off at home enjoying early spring in my own backyard.

title: CONNECTICUT PUSH IS BEGUN BY UDALL
description: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., April 10  Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona swept through Connecticut today, hoping to pick up the liberal votes left over from the defunct campaigns of three other Democratic Presidential contenders.

title: 3 Hijackers Stuck At a Thai Airport With 12 Hostages
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 10 (AP)Three armed hijackers of an airliner and their 12 hostages, stalled here for the second day of what was supposed to be a short refueling stop, kept up their search today for a country that would offer them sanctuary.

title: 79 Arrested in Record Roundup By Police Fences in Brooklyn
description: Seventynine persons have been arrested for selling $2 million worth of stolen merchandise to police officers acting as fences in a decoy storefront, in what was called the most successful such operation in New York history.

title: ALBANY INCREASES BACKING FOR LOANS
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that the state was increasing its loanguarantee program for New York stutents attending its medical schools from $10,000 to $20,000 in an effort to encourage more low and middleincome students to study medicine.

title: What Course For Seniors?
description: OVER the last decade, a combination of senloritis (We are seniors now, we've met most of our requirements for graduation, let's just take it easy, no sweat this year for us), the anxiety to break free from school and begin to earn money in the real world, and the increasing opportunities for youngsters to enter college after their Junior year in high schoolthis combination has created a problem for publicschool administrators. Sadly, many are failing to cope with it without surrendering the responsibility to outside institutions whose motivations in assisting go beyond the simple desire to provide a meaningful 12th year for highschool students.

title: Spinola Arrives in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10 (Reuters)  Former President Antonio de Spinola Portugal arrived in Brazil today from Switzrland from which he had been expelled for engaging in political Activity. General Spinola made no statement on arrival. He is forhidden by Brazihan law to engage in political activities here.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I wish that Edward Albee hadn't directed the revival of his Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? because then he'd be able to see it. Seeing it with detachment, without having to worry personally about its specific stage effects, I think he'd feel two things. Enormous pleasure, to begin with. For the excitement that the play engendered when it first appeared in 1962 proves to have been not in the least dependent upon the shock value of the then forbidden words he used or even upon the outrage he stirred in many audiences by presenting the 23yearmarried George and Martha as vampires steadily at each other's throats.

title: Teachers: How Accountable?
description: GOOD teachers are essential to a good school system. In order to determine how good the teachers in a school system actually are, the administrators must have some measure of teacher evaluation.

title: Carter Impresses Blacks
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10 (AP)  Kansas City's black political leaders confronted Jimmy Carter today about his reference to ethnic purity and came away saying they were satisfied and impressed with his answers.

title: Luxury Condominiums Attract Corporate Owners
description: At ft time when many New Yorkers are doubtful about making any longterm investments in their city, one form of residential real estate is drawing millions of foreign and corporate dollarsthe luxury condominium.

title: Tin Pan Alley in Distress
description: Tin Pan Alley. Was it a street, a building or a style of music that was routed by rockandroll?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Sally Manning, Editor, Fiancee Of Mack Haning
description: Sarah Margaret Manning, shopping editor at Mademoiselle magazine, and Johnson McKinley liming Jr., administrator, news and information, with the RCA Corporation, plan to be married June 26 in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Dallas.

title: Playing OneonNone
description: In the affluent suburb of Garden City where I grew up, an athletically inclined 14yearold never lacked for things to do. Depending on the season and our parents' aspirations, we could play Little League baseball, football or soccer; take tennis lessons at the Casino, swimming lessons at the pool or golf lessons at any of three country clubs; bowl, ride or skate. There was a luxurious park three blocks north of us, another halfmile to the west.

title: The Busing Controversy
description: SCHOOL integration is one of the most emotional and volatile issues confronting suburban communities throughout New Jersey. The problem has polarized one town after another, after exacerbating racial tensions and lowering property values along the way.

title: PEKING TO PRESS ANTITENG DRIVE
description: HONG KONG, April 10In a cautiously worded but somewhat ambiguous editorial, China's official newspaper today said the country's socalled antirightist campaign should now concentrate on criticizing Teng Hsiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister who was dismissed earlier this month.

title: ChurchState Debate Arises in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, April 10  It is common wisdom in Ireland that when bishops and politicians quarrel here it is usually the layman who gets the worst of it. Over the years public men have learned to be wary of what used to be called a stroke of the crosier  a bishop's staffand it is not forgotten that in 1951 a government fell as a result of an episcopal condemnation of a proposed law.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: the pump.

title: U.S. AGENCY FINDS LIVING COSTS UP 7%
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The typical urban family of four, including two children, requires $15,500 a year to, maintain a moderate standard of living, the Labor Department said today. This, because of inflation, is $1,200 more than in the previous year.

title: Korman Captures Gymnastics Medal
description: WEMBLEY, England, April 10 (AP)Peter Korman, 19yearold student from New Haven, won the gold medal in the Champions All international gymnastics tournament today and showed he would be a serious contender at the Montreal Olympics.

title: Remodeled Structure To Open on Thursday
description: Babe Ruth may have built it in 1923 and City Hall may have rebuilt it 53 years later. But whatever the facts or fancies of baseball history, the 10 acres of the Bronx known as Yankee Stadium will reopen next Thursday after two years of modernizing.

title: Stein, Woolf & Joyce
description: It has been Gertrude Stein's fate to be known more as a personality than as a writer, a fate she would have strenuously condemned. Stubborn and implacable about the virtues of her work, she was for a time virtually its only enthusiasit, and even her biographers have tended to slight it while emphasizing, as Janet Hobhouse does in this pictorial biography, that she was one of the great personalities of the modern age. Miss Hobhouse's title bears the same message as James Mellow's Charmed Circle: Gertrude Stein and Company; namely, that the social history of that period was inseparable from the life of Gertrude Stein.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees will open their refurbished Yankee Stadium on Thursday against the Minnesota Twins. Pregame ceremonies honoring athletes who starred in the Stadium in its first 50 years will begin at 1:30 P.M. The game will start at 2, as will the Saturday game against the Twins. The Mets will be on the road all week.

title: CAREY PROPOSES CHANGES IN LAWS ON MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, April 10Governor Carey today proposed changes in the state laws affecting medicalmalpractice suits as recommended by a special advisory panel, but he appeared unwilling to accept its more sweeping recommendations, which could eliminate jury trials in malpractice cases.

title: Miss Philbrick Wed To John T. Wheaton
description: Barbara Gail Philbrick and John Theodore Wheaton, graduates of Susquehanna University, were married yesterday morning in Scarsdale, N.Y., in the Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Joseph Goodwine, assisted by the Rev. W. Murray Hunt, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE neatlooking, whitepainted clapboard house has long been a traditional part of the Long Island landscape, especially in many of the older communities of Suffolk County.

title: More Participation Needed in Colleges
description: Massspectator sports are Big. Business. When intercollegiate massspectator sports are brought under fire, the whole professional athletic system is jeopardized.

title: Not talking
description: The title of this book blithely begs a couple of questions to which I would accord logical priority: Can chimps read? What can chimps read?

title: U.S.Soviet Arms Talks Are Deadlocked
