description: WASHINGTON, April 10Efforts to conclude a new SovietAmerican agreement curbing strategic arms have again become deadlocked, and top Administration officials say they are not optimistic that the accord can be achieved before the November elections.

title: Their Music, Your Chamber
description: A COLD spring rain beats down on the pavements outside, but the lush, dappled strains of an Albert Roussel sextet fill the room. The walls reverberate the sounds of clarinet and oboe, notes lapping into the corners of the small room, around the hall and up a stairway crowded with listeners.

title: T.H. Thoren to Wed Jean L. Mesinger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Mesinger of Danbury, Conn., and Del Ray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Louise Mesinger, to Terrance Hughes Thoren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Thoren of Ithaca, N. Y.

title: ALBANY NOTEBOOK
description: THE political problems of Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, have been spilling over lately into neighboring Suffolk County, and presenting somewhat of an opportuliity to the tiny cluster of Suffolk Democrats in the State Legislature.

title: Two Women Hold Golf Lead in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 10 (UPI)Keiko Matsuda and Nayoko Yoshikawa of Japan shared the lead with fiveoverpar 153's today after the second round of the fourth World Ladies professional golf championship.

title: Hussein Visiting London
description: LONDON, April 10 (Reuters) King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today form Canada on a short visit. e will holds talks on Middle East development with the new Prime Minister. James Callaghan, British officials said.

title: The Military Industrial Complex Grows More So
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after he was severely reprimanded for attending a fishing lodge in the Bahamas run by a major defense contractor, Malcolm R. Currie, director of Defense Research and Engineering, appeared at a dinner sponsored by the National Security Industrial Association, a trade group of military firms.

title: Linda Hodges To Be a Bride
description: Linda Bea Hodges and Mark Alan Kivitz, members of the class of '76 at the Washington University Law School in St. Louis, have become engaged. Mr. and Mrs. Irving Smith of North Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Smith's daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Kivitz of Philadelphia.

title: The Nijinsky of Massapequa
description: MASSAPEQUA TO his many admirers, Andr Eglevsky is the man who brought ballet to Long Island. This month the Andr Eglevsky Ballet Company of Long Island is taking itself to the rest of the country on its first national tour.

title: Trade Concerned by Mariners' Age
description: The American merchant marine appears to be faced with a serious problemthe age and medical fitness of the men Who operate its ships. This view was expressed last week by the Marine Index Bureau, a commercial depository for data on personnel illness and injuries in the United States merchant marine and affiliated industries.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PRESIDENT FORD's new Cabinetlevel task force on corrupt business practices meets tomorrow for the first time. Its work is formidable. The task force will address the critical question of what should be done about the bribes, kickbacks, inflated commissions and other forms of deception that appear to have become an accepted element of selling American goods and services to foreign customers. There is, at this time, almost total disagreement on the proper remedy or remedies, and considerable skepticism that there even is such a thing as a remedy that would be effective.

title: FOREIGNERS FIND BULGARIANS WARY
description: SOFIA, BulgariaApril has warned the rugged mountains Or. Bulgaria, and there is weekend dancing in the streets of countless villages, as new marriages are celebrated in the traditional way.

title: The importance of being Fleischmann
description: LOS ANGELES. In an era when contract negotiations between musicians in America's major symphonic orchestras and their managements have all too often resembled the Immolation scene from Gdtterdammerung played motto agitato, only in Los Angeles have they been as tranquil as the Pastoral. The newest threeyear contract for the Los Angeles Philharmonic, signed earlier this year, was reached after negotiations that can only be termed astonishing.

title: U.S. Navy Regrets Search Of Women at Subic Bay
description: MANILA, April 10 (AP) The United States Navy expressed regrets following a formal Philippine protest against the search of Philippine women employees at Subic Bay naval base by security guards seeking stolen goods, the United States Embassy announced today.

title: The Diminishing Right to Fight City Hall in Court
description: ST. PAULThe Supreme Court has recently cut back to some extent on the rights of criminal defendants. It has taken some restrictive views of FirstAmendment, freespeech rights as well. But the leading issue for civilliberties groups this year, and for other critics of the Court as well, has been something else altogether.

title: Patricia Leflein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Leflein of Plainfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Jane Leflein, to David Mark Richmand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Richmand of Lakewood, N.J. Miss Leflein, who graduated from Rutgers Preparatory School, expects to receive a degree in occupational therapy from Tufts University next month. Her fianc, a Franklin and Marshall College alumnus, expects to receive an M.D. degree from the Tufts Medical School on May 16.

title: The Opera
description: Johanna Meier's debut with the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night in the title role of Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos was a happy one. The New York City Opera soprano was making an unscheduled appearance with the neighboring company because Montserrat Caball, who had been singing Ariadne, took off for Europe to be with her sick mother.

title: And His Troubles Are the Same: Economic
description: LONDONBritain has a new Prime Minister and a reshuffled Cabinet, but its difficulties, and the Government's preferred solutions to them, remain as before. It is Sunny Jim Callaghan at No. 10 Downing Street now rather than Harold Wilson, yet the replacement of one avuncular tactician by another is not expected to lead to dramatic changes in how the Government does business and with whom.

title: Pop Notes: A Superstar Is Born
description: With the rise of Frampton Comes Alive! as well as a single, 'Show Me the Way. to the top of the popmusic popularity charts, Englishborn guitaristcomposer Peter Fra??on has finally achieved the rock stardom he has been pursuing for the past five years.

title: Housing Scar in Edison
description: WILLIAM BUTLER, an elderly black man, gazed across a scrub  grown field as it darkened in the shadow of a latewinter sunset. Nearby, solitary in a thicket at the roadside, stood his old frame house.

title: For Lawyers Human Touch
description: NEWARK THE courtroom is hushed. The prosecutor stands and begins to question the witness. After a few minutes, the defense attorney gets up from his seat next to the defendant and sits in the chair just vacated by the prosecutor.

title: Weddings
description: EdlinLettowitz

title: PORT UNIT WEIGHS INDUSTRIAL PARKS
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering setting up waterfront industrial parks to help the two states and their metropolitan regions once again attract manufacturing firms to locate and invest in the region.

title: State Assay Reading Habits
description: THOSE Jerseyans who live on farms or in small countryside villages are more likely to enjoy reading murder mysteries or sciencefiction than the current bestsellers. In the suburbs and cities, it's just the opposite. And in all these areas, almost all readers are more apt to be glancing through hooks on hobbies than reading mysteries, hooks on current events or the bestsellers.

title: MEDIATOR MOVES IN BUILDING TALKS
description: Negotiators for the Realty Advisory Board and the union representing 20,000 employees in apartment buildings in the city have been summoned to a mediation session tomorrow aimed at averting a strike on April 21 that could affect hundreds of thousands of residents here.

title: SAUDIS ARE ACTIVE AMONG NEIGHBORS
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The Saudi Government has taken a more vigorous part in recent months in the affairs of the lesser nations of the Arabian peninsula.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 11, 1976

title: J. T. Moreland Weds Miss Wantland
description: Marlene Gail Wantland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Wantland of Portland, Ore., was married there yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Thomas Moreland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dawson Moreland Jr. of Rowayton, Conn.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: WITHOUT New Jersey Public Television, the state government would be almost invisible, according to Common Cause, a citizens' lobby group. We are more poorly informed about the performance of our elected officials than the citizens of virtually any other state, says William Singer of Somerville, chairman of Common Cause's Legal Committee. He urged the Legislature not to allow Governor Byrne to cut Jerseyvision's budget.

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: The following City Council Committees will hold public hearings this week:

title: Mary Elizabeth Ivancevic Is Bride
description: Mary Elizabeth Ivancevic, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Ivancevic of Portland, Me., was married yesterday afternoon in New Canaan, Conn., to James Cortlandt Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gouverneur M. Nichols of New Canaan.

title: His Health Problem Erodes Even HardCore Support
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.For the first time in the dozen or so years that he has been on the national political scene, George Corley Wallace is having trouble persuading voters that he is a serious Presidential candidate.

title: McEnroe Toppled In Junior Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 10Eric Fromm of Glen Head, Lt., and Peter Rennert of Great Neck, L.I., gained the finals of the Concord Hotel's 10th annual junior invitation tennis tournament today,

title: 4 Lutheran Leaders Defy Ouster With Backing of Their Boards
description: In defiance of the president of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, four district presidents removed from office by him early this month have declared their ouster invalid and have won the endorsement of their boards of directors.

title: Scranton on Rhodesia
description: William W. Scranton, the new United States Representative to the United Nations, made a good start last week on turning this country's southern Africa policy back toward traditional American ideals of selfdetermination and majority rule. He not only voted for but cosponsored a resolution adopted unanimously by the Security Council to tighten considerably the sanctions against Rhodesia's white racist Government.

title: Dean at Columbia U. Named To Head Horace Mann Unit
description: The appointment of Michael Lacopo, dean of admissions of Columbia University, as head of the Horace Mann School's Upper School (grades 11 and 12), effective next September, was announced yesterday by R. Inslee Clark Jr., headmaster of Horace Mann.

title: Historians, With Eye on the Future, Deplore Their Lack of Jobs
description: ST. LOUIS, April 10The Bicentennial contains a painful paradox for historians in the United States. It is that, while the nation's history is in the public eye, its historians by the hundreds find themselves unwanted.

title: Centenary Names Coach
description: SHREVEPORT, La., April 10 (AP)Riley Wallace, for eight years Centenary College's top basketball assistant coach, wan promoted to head coach and athletic director today.

title: Unemployment: The Legacy of the Recession
description: WASHINGTONLike several of its predecessors, the 197475 recession did a good deal of curative work for the American economy, it's widely agreed.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Urgent. Total Release! Super Release! Blockbuster! Under such exclamations major paperback houses several times a year stage allout efforts to make one of their promising titles the year's biggest seller. Typical is the campaign currently being staged by Pocket Books in behalf of Looking for Mr. Goodbar, Judith Rossflees chiller about the disastrous fate of a New York singles girl.

title: FOOD
description: ELIZABETH THE eightday festival of Passover, with its Biblical prohibition against leavened foodstuffs, requires special care in shopping. For example, most kosher oils and shortenings are made from corn, which is taboo during the holiday, while dried fruits and canned goods can he improperly processed or packaged.

title: Elsiedale Peters Sets June Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Snare Peters of Englewood, N. J., and Falmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elsiedale Peters, to Johny Armstrong, an assistant vice President in the New York office of Lloyds Bank International Ltd.

title: 40 Prison Inmates Set (and Sent) Back
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 10A hundred men played cops and robbers in Hofstra Stadium this afternoon, and afterward the losers were carted off and put behind bars.

title: Miss Fisher Wed To Gilbert Fishman
description: Francine Ellen Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Fisher of Great Neck, L. I., was married yesterday evening to Gilbert Stanley Fishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Fishman of Brooklyn.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The late John Creasey must have used more than 20 pseudonyms while writing his hundreds of books. Even while he was alive, however, publishers were anxious to cash in on the Creasey name. Thus a book would come out by John Creasey writing under the name of Gordon Ashe, or Norman Deane, or Kyle Hunt, or Tex Riley, or J. J. Marric or whatever. It still goes on. Here is LET'S KILL UNCLE LIONEL by John Creasey writing as Jeremy York (McKay, $6.95).

title: Who's in the
description: STOP E.R.A. leader Phyllis Schlafly talks of passing the hat for nickels and dimes to finance the movement, but it can hardly be so homespun. Among E.R.A. proponents, there has been much speculation that a helping hand comes trom segments of the insurance industry, whose sexdifferentiated practices might come under severe scrutiny if the amendment were passed.

title: POLITICS
description: SENATOR Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota would like to have it both ways in New Jersey. He would like to stay out of the Democratic Presidential primaries hereand in other states, tooas an active candidate. But he also would like to see the election of ostensibly uncommitted delegates who would favor his nomination.

title: Miss Button Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Button of Medway, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Hoag Button, to Dr. Peter Day Fleming, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. James Fleming of New York and Siasconset, Nantucket, Mass.

title: For young readers
description: When I was growing up, a dollhouse was just that, a simple house for dolls to live in and children to play with. There were no miniaturized Matisse paintings, Tiffany lamps bentwood rockers or oriental rugs. All of that was reserved for the houses that adults liked to play with, which was exactly where it belonged.

title: Congresswomen Often Opposed '75 Military Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 10An analysis of the 1975 voting records of women members of Congress, apparently the first such study ever made, lends support to the thesis that women office holders tend, more than men, to oppose increased military spending and a hardline foreign policy.

title: Women's Banking Goes West
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The view from one of this city's clattering cable cars quickly establishes that the community's reputation is not made on bread alone  meaning sourdoueh of course.

title: Government Encroachment Is Arousing Concern of Boatmen
description: Like a squall darkening the horizon, government's growing encroachment into yachting is drawing the concern of boatmen. It began in earnest six years ago with the controversy over standards for marine sanitation devices, then moved on to plans for eliminating yacht documentation, and now is plowing ahead into the area of coastal zoning.

title: Magic Water Furor in Greece Is Seen as a Clue to Tradition
description: ATHENS, April 6It all, started slowly. In midFebruary a group of 12 Greeks announced that they had discovered a cure for cancer, a special radioactive water found only on the island of Kos.

title: It Was a First, Albany's Denial of the Prison Job to Mr. Carey's Choice
description: ALBANYIn threatening to defeat Govenor Carey's nomination of Herman Schwartz as chairman of the Commission of Correction, the State Senate is apparently prepared to break a timehonored if unwritten Albany rule. Unlike the United States Senate, which questions Presidential nominees on matters of policy and philosophy and turns them down at least once in a while, the State Senate has traditionally taken the view that a Governor is entitled to pick his own people as long as the nominees are neither dishonest or incompetent.

title: Islanders to Try Buffalo Shuffle Tonight
description: A change of clothes, a hasty practice at their Long Island home rink and the New York Islanders were off and running again, this time to Buffalo. They open the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup hockey quarter finals against the Sabres tonight at 7 o'clock (Channel 9 on television).

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday on Government National Mortgage Association passthrough securities, it was stated that the interest income from the securities is exempt from state and city income taxes. However, the association stated that passthrough securities have no specific exemption from local income taxes, and counsel to the New York State Taxation Department has declared that, in his opinion, the interest income from Ginnie Mae passthrough securities is not exempt. Investment firms have been giving divergent advice to investors on the exemption feature.

title: Carter and Udall Lead as Delegates Are Picked In Iowa
description: DES MOINES, April 10 (UPI) Morris K. Udall made strong gains and Jimmy Carter bolstered his lead among Democratic contenders today in the selection of most of Iowa's delegates to the 1976 Democratic National Convention.

title: MidApril
description: By the second week in April the pattern is set. Winter ends. Spring comes. The stretch of daylight beyond darkness is well begun. Back in the hills there will he frosty nights and even Icy fringes, but nobody will be buried in snowdrifts. May lies just ahead. Now even skeptics can believe.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KATOWICE, Poland, April 10 (UPI)The United States hockey team defeated Sweden, 20, today in the world ice hockey championships.

title: 42d St. Project Faces New Obstacle
description: The city's top housing official changing his previous position because of a court challengehas agreed to submit for City Planning Commission review a proposal to switch the planned tenancy of a housing complex being built near Times Square.

title: DINING OUT
description: ALL that stuff about the New Naples Restaurant? Forget it. Jerry's is a pizzeria, pure and simple. Not a great pizzeria, perhaps, but a very good one. Reviewing pizzerias is a delicate business, something like reviewing Presidents' daughters who sing or getting technical when a woman asks, How do I look?

title: ART
description: LONG ISLAND museums, coerced into retrenchments by the recession, have turned adversity to advantage by swapping exhibitions with one another. One of the most conspicuous examples of this institutional rapprochement is the current exhibition at the Hechscher Museum in Huntington.

title: Whalers Go 2 Up With 61 Victory
description: CLEVELAND, April 10 (AP)  Larry Pleau, Brad Sclwood and Mike Rogers scored thirdperiod goals tonight as the New England Whalers overwhelmed the Cleveland Crusaders, 61, for a 20 lead in their threeoffivegame World Hockey Association playoff series.

title: Talks to Open Tomorrow On U.S. Philippine Bases
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (Reuters)The United States and the Philippines will begin formal negotiations Monday on the continued use of American military bases in the Philippines, according to the State Department.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Jaspers Win in Track
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.Manhattan won the onemile relay, the final event, today and triumphed in a quadrangular meet at Rutgers' Stadium. Manhattan totaled 76 points, Rutgers 75, Fairleigh Dickinson 30 and Plattsburg State 14.

title: Sports Scoreboard
description: Rowing

title: On the Joy Of Gardening
description: I have spent the morning working in the garden. When we, purchased our house many years ago, the trees had been leveled and we were faced with a flat, hard packed, barren back yard. A dismal sight!

title: Adrienne Simpson, Nurse, Is Bride
description: Adrienne L. Simpson, a registered nurse in the medical department of the United States Trust Company in New York, was married last evening to Robert S. Klanfer, manager of financial analysis for the PepsiCola Company in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Lunger in Crash
description: SILVERSTONE, England, April 10Brett Lunger, competing in a Formula I nonchampionship race, crashed today and suffered a slight concussion and a cut neck. He was taken to Northampton Hospital for overnight observation.

title: Mets Unbeaten; Yanks Win, 97
description: MILWAUKEE, April 10Don Money hit a grandslam home run in the ninth inning and the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Yankees, 109, today. Don Money flied out in the ninth inning and the Yankees defeated the Brewers, 97.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: ANTON CHEKHOV'S LIFE AND THOUGHT. (University of California, $6.95.) This selection of the Russian writer's published letters, together with the introductions and notes, provides an unsurpassed view of his literary, social and scientific views; the selection and commentary is by Simon Karlinsky, the translation by Michael Henry Heim and Mr. Karlinsky.

title: Why Khrushchev's Favorite Sculptor Chose Exile
description: Since the early 1960's, when Rudolf Nureyev made his dramatic defection at a Paris airport, a steady stream of distinguished Soviet artists has been arriving in the West. The accumulated effect of the recent exodus of Soviet artists has been compared to the mass departure of intellectuals from Nazi Germany in the 1930's. Nobel prizewinner Alexander Solzhenitsyn was deported. Poet Joseph Brodsky and author Andrei Sinyaysky were forced out. Others chose to leave: dancers Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov defected, and pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy and Mstislav Rostropovich emigrated with official exit visas. But until the arrival last month of sculptor Ernst Neizvestny who also left on his own and was granted an exit visano Soviet visual artist of international stature had come to the West since the days of Kandinsky and Chagall.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Three new operas came together the other week: an event rare enough to deserve a listing in the Guinness Book of Records. On Tuesday, March 30, in Baltimore, came Ines de Castro by Thomas Pasatieri, a young American. The following night in Boston came Montezuma by Roger Sessions. The night after that, under City Opera auspices in New York, came Ashmedai by Josef Tal, an Israeli composer.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: The House That Ruth Builtrebuilt
description: Tom O'Reilly was working the night sports desk at The New York WorldTelegram when the telephone rang. Say, pally, a fuzzy voice said, I got a question. Did anybody ever hit a fair ball out of Yankee Stadium?

title: Free Shots for Measles To Be Given in Glen Cove
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., April 10 (UPI)  Free inoculations against measles will be given here next Tuesday because of a reported outbreak of the disease in the city's schools.

title: Rosewall Saves Victory Over Dibbs
description: HOUSTON, April 10 (AP)Ken Rosewall saved 6 match points and defeated Eddie Dibbs, 63, 46, 76, in the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis River Oaks tournament today.

title: Horse Show Reults
description: AT WESTON, CONN.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have three mahogany tables with leather tops. The leather is marked and has deteriorated. Is there wood under the leather if I remove it, or will the leather have to be replaced? I want to refinish the tables and am not sure bow to go about it. S.D.B., Ephrata, Pa.

title: Joseph Lewitan, Founded German Dance Magazine
description: Joseph Lewitan, a former staff member of the United Nation who founded Der Tanz. (Germany's first dance magazine in 1927, died Friday while on a visit to Paris. He was 82 years old.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: EVEN though the breadth of his vision has become amply apparent, Henry Krajewski, if he were around, wouldn't know the place.

title: On to Pennsylvania
description: The struggle for the Democratic Presidential nomination increasingly takes on the character of a twoman race between former Gov. Jimmy Carter and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey. The Humphrey strategy envisages his choice as the compromise candidate of a deadlocked convention.

title: George And Anna
description: George and Anna, neither very prepossessing: she on the heavy side, he short and balding, both in their 30's, English, lower  middle  class; employed by the same London company, they drift into marriage, have a child, and drift apart. A virgin when he marries, George takes happily to conjugal sex and, when that bounty is withdrawn, fills in uncomplaining with adoration of his baby son. Anna's freefloating discontent crystallizes when George forbids her to go back to work; he has the notion that a child needs its mother. If he knew the sort of parent Anna wasletting infant Michael howl his griefs away, never speaking to the boy as she wheels him through the park  George might well have second thoughts, but she chooses not to tell him. Finally, through another unhappy mother, Anna falls in with a group of bookstore radicals, who read Marx and Mao and communicate via grunts and groans, and she finds some substance in her days.

title: Down to the Sea in Cement
description: WHEN Enchantress, the 130foot ferrocement  hull square  rigger from Port Jefferson, sets her 5,600 square feet of canvas sails and glides gently out into the Sound, workmen drop their tools in awe, office workers hang out of their windows to gape and automobiles start crashing into each other.

title: GOING BACK TO SPAIN
description: MIAMAN, Spain. Eleven years ago there was no road to Miaman. I left the taxi at a town on the main road between Santiago de Compostela and the Atlantic coast and walked two miles uphill through woods and along ox paths. On the way, I saw up close for the first time the tiny garden patches the campesinos traditionally cultivated in Galicia, the green northwestern corner of Spain. These were the minifundos that had kept the area backward and hungry.

title: It's Time for Termites
description: Now is the time when not only birds take wing, but termites, too. And whoever sees them on the premisesor thinks he doesis likely to be stricken with dread.

title: New American Music  A Mixed Bag
description: If nothing else, the Bicentennial is bound to heighten Americans' awareness of our native composers. Evidence to bolster this hope includes a mixed bag of new recordings that make available works of American music in uncommon profusion.

title: GARDENING
description: NOT everyone in an urbansuburban area is fortunate to have a plot of land large enough to garden on a grand scale. Many apartment dwellers have only a sunny window, a balcony or a terrace. Even those who live in onefamily suburban homes may have only a postagestampsized yard in which to garden. Shade from buildings and trees may limit the space for those plants requiring a great deal of sunlight. Even those with large gardens may wish to have a few intimate touches of color or green foliage on the doorstep or patio.

title: Vyga B. Gray Is Married to Tony Chills
description: Vyga Butvydas Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincas Butvydas of Troy Hills, N. J., was married in Cohasset, Mass., at noon yesterday to Walton Childs of Marshfield, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Childs Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., and York Harbor, Me.

title: Notes: Theater Comes To the National Parks
description: The National Park Service has engaged three troupes of actors to tour national park sites this spring and summer. The troupes will present two Bicentennialtheme dramatizations, one a 30minute play entitled We've Come Back for a Little Look Around, the other a twohour audienceparticipation production called People of '76.

title: Letters
description: I'm rather surprised The New York Times gave even the faintest aura of respectability, not to mention publicity, to The Two and their imaginary U.F.O.'s (Looking for: The next world. Feb. 29) When the verbiage is pared down, it amounts to two con artists attracting some rather naive people.

title: City College Proposes a Plan For $5 Million in Budget Cuts
description: Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the president of City College, yesterday disclosed cutbacks that would total as much as $5 million for next September if further reductions in the school's operating budget were mandated by the Board of Higher Education.

title: He Slept Here, Too
description: PARSIPPANY GEORGE WASHINGTON slept here, on this very spot on Barnsboro Road in Parsippany where I am writing this. After exhaustive research I am convinced of it.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Human Life Measure Called Vital to Nation

title: Colleagues Cited in Murder Of Rhodesian Rebel Chief
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 10 (Reuters)  A Rhodesian African nationalist leader. Herbert Chitepo, who died in a car bomb explosion here last year, was killed on the orders of fellow rebel leaders, a special commission of inquiry has reported.

title: Cays Beat Knicks, Clinch Tie for Title
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, April 10 (AP)Jim Chones scored 25 points as the Cleveland Cavaliers posted a 9994 triumph today over the New York Knicks and gained at least a tie for the title in the National Basketball Association Central Division.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WOLFSBURG, GermanySince he look charge of the financially troubled Volkswagen auto company in February 1975, Toni Schmticker has faced hard decisions about jobs cuts in Germany and about new investments in the United States.

title: U.S. Seabed Proposals Set Off Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 10New United States proposals for mining the mineralf of the ocean floor seem to have reassured copperexporting countries that have been worried about the impact on the world market of the new ocean resources. But the proposals also appear to have upset European countries gearing up to compete with the Americans in the new mining fields.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I was startled by Mr. Gladstone's casual reassurances on the subject of aluminum wiring [Home Clinic, March 28]. Mr. Gladstone states that some houses with aluminum rather than copper electric wiring have had problems with dickering lights, as well as with complete loss of power in several instances.

title: Schoolboy Joe Looks Back
description: Joseph Henry Nuxhall is a sports caster who is as much a part of the Cincinnati Reds as Johnny Bench, and he has been since before Bench was born. Joe pitched for the Reds when he was 15 years old, the youngest player ever in the major leagues, and in his 48th year he is still with them (not counting a brief sabbatical with the Kansas City Athletics and Los Angeles Any gels back when there were no Athletics in Kansas City and Angels in Los Angeles.) Besides broadcasting their games on radio, he pitches batting practice in the spring training, through the championship season and during the World Series when the Reds are in it, as they usually are.

title: TOKYO PRESS SLOW TO DIG INTO GRAFT
description: TOKYO, April 10Journalistic investigative reporting is apparently so new to Japan that there is no word for it in Japanese  and that may explain why newspapers here have so far been unsuccessful in uncovering much new in the Lockheed scandal that has gripped the nation's attention.

title: POLICEMAN IS HELD IN BURGLARY CASE
description: A 29yearold police officer land his brother were arrested for possession of burglar tools along with three other men learly yesterday in the Manhattan diamond district.

title: The World
description: The Lebanese Parliament has taken a necessary step toward a political settlement of the country's civil war: By amending the Constitution, Parliament has opened the way for selection of a new President to replace Suleiman Franjieh, the Christian leader whose removal was a prerequisite for Moslem leftists participation in a reformed government.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 ??AM: Yale Reports. F?? Selma to Boston and Tile Poetry of the Indian Oral Tradition.

title: Out of the Hubbub and Into the Woods
description: When the Simmons Company moved out of New York City last year, it did not head for the suburbs or a younger metropolis. It built its new world headquarters in a forest on the outskirts of Atlanta.

title: Transit Official Says Cost Cuts Will Pay for Pact
description: John G. de Rose, senior executive officer of the Transit Authority, says he is convinced that the costofliving adjustments called for under the agency's new contract with the Transport Workers Union can be paid for through internal cost reductions in the next two years.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Every camera owner has in his or her possession an invaluable tool that can help immeasurably in recouping losses after a robbery, flood, fire, tornado or other calamity that requires proof of previous ownership, or that requires identifying lost or stolen property for an insurance company. All too often insurance companies, as well as police, have to deal with householders who can only vaguely remember all of the possessions they have lost, or who cannot prove the worth (or even the original possession of) various items.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment to reduce the size of a proposed Congressional delegation to go to England to accept a copy of Magn?? Carta, which passed, 45 to 29. April 5.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: IS the Broadway musical a valid art form? Dies it matter? Would anyone care if it sank decorously into the Hudson with massed band playing selections from Oklahoma! on one bank and from Hair on the other? Remember Oklahoma!? Remember Hair?

title: Long Island /This Week
description: MUSIC & DANCE

title: Learning a Heritage
description: EAST HAMPTON UNTIL recently Cheryl Pharaoh, a descendent of the Montauk Indians who lived in the eastern regions of Long Island's South Fork, had never known much about her heritage. She had never even met a fullblooded Mantauk: the last of the local group, Pocanontas Pharaoh, died before the 12yearold Sag Harbor girl was born.

title: Saudi Finds a Way to Shift Teachers
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaA softhearted Saudi Arabian Prince has devised a simple technique for generating enthusiasm among teachers assigned to a particularly rugged corner of this rugged kingdom: raising their pay by 50 or 100 percent.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: FRENCH CRITICIZE MEDICAL SOCIETY
description: PARIS, April 10The authority of France's powerful national medical society is being challenged by a small but apparently growing group of doctors and medical administrators who consider its policies repressive and ultraconservative.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Unless otherwise noted, the critical Judgments in this Guide reflect the published views of Times critics.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than $50 bookstores throughout the United States. Weeks are sot necessarily consecutive

title: Former N.Y.U. Miler to Be Honored
description: Dr. T. Leslie MacMitchell will be honored as New York's outstanding track and field performer at the 50th anniversary dinner of the Boys Athletic League at the Plaza Hotel, April 27. A New York University miler in the forties and fifties, MacMitchell earned the reputation as the country's greatest mile runner during that era.

title: A.B.A., as in '06, Ponders the System and Reform.
description: ST. PAUL, April 10In 1906 a young Nebraska lawyer named Roscoe Pound shocked a complacent meeting of the American Bar Association here by listing in detail the problems of the nation's justice system, including interminable delays, inefficiency, archaic rules of procedure and contentious lawyers.

title: Brazil Regime Widening State Economic Control
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10Twelve years after the armed forces took power with a strong commitment to save and expand private enterprise, Brazil appears well on the road to creating the most successful and pervasive system of state capitalism in South America.

title: Carter Asks Reporters Why Query Is Repeated
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10 UMJimmy Carter asked reporters today to explain why his ethnic purity statement kept popping up as an issue when he has already apologized for it.

title: ALFRED T. SFORZA
description: Alfred T. Sforza, president of the SchiavoneBonomo Corporation of Jersey City, processor and broker of scrap iron and steel, died in his home Thursday of a heart attacls. He was 61 years old and lived at 360 East 72d Street.

title: BRIDGE
description: The Midas touch is something that all rubber bridge players would like to have. They imagine, foolishly, that if every hand they pick up is golden they will soon make a fortune, even playing at a modest stake. It does not occur to them, any more than it did to King Midas, that getting their wish would be fatal, at any rate in a bridge

title: A Lump in Simmons's Mattress
description: ATLANTA There are fighting words in the Simmons Company annual report this year.

title: The Fox Is Crazy Too
description: By the time he skyjacked a Boeing 707 at the age of 34a gesture made almost entirely for the sake of dramaGarrett Trapnell's life had become such a tour de force of guerrilla attacks on the system that Eliot Asinof has written an entire book just summing them up.

title: Eros The Greatest Dance Master
description: A few weeks ago, I attended a dance concert by Lucinda Childs at the Washington Square Methodist Church. Miss Childs is a delicately handsome woman, and her work in Robert Wilson's new opera, Einstein on the Beach, is full of a mysterious priestly eroticism.

title: LowIncome Housing: Hempstead vs. H.U.D.
description: ABRAHAM MEYER worked three jobs in order to buy his threebedroom house on Cornell Road in Franklin Square 16 years ago when he moved from Queens. Now that his son is in college he is working three jobs again. The house represents the largest portion of his savings and he likes the quiet, uneventful neighborhood.

title: Report Reasserts Value of Effort To Curb Insects With Sex Lures
description: Sixteen months ago the high ly publicized finding by a Pennsylvania chemist about the sex attractant chemicals of insects threatened to discredit the scientific basis of a major new area of research that promises safer alternatives to hazardous pesticides.

title: Ivan Nunez, Pianist, Heard
description: Ivan Nunez, a Chileanborn and trained pianist who has lived in New York since 1961, came to Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon to give his third recital there in three years. His program consisted of Copland's Sonata, Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 10, No. 3), Volume I of Albeniz's Iberia and Chopin's Fantasy in F minor, Nocturne in and Scherzo in B flat minor.

title: How to Play the Game
description: The game is played between two teams, or sides, of 11 players. One team bats while the other fields. The batting side tries to score runs while the fielders are trying to get the batsmen out. A match normally consists of two innings for each side.

title: GENESIS CARRIES ON SANS PETER GABRIEL
description: The latest American tour by Genesis, an unusually inventive, English rock group, can be seen as the answer to a single question. Will the group survive the departure of Peter Gabriel, its former lead singer, who lent! Genesis an unusual theatrical flare with his use of mime and masks, among other offects?

title: What's Doing in NEW ORLEANS
description: JAZZIt's prime time in New Orleans now. For the next few weeks the weather will be like a New England summer, with cool to pleasantly warm sunny days and cool evenings. The city is all cleaned up after the frenetic Mardi Gras and is settling down to more serious matters like the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. The festival began on Friday and will continue through next weekend at the Fair Grounds Race Track, 1751 Gentilly Boulevard, where tents are pitched, stages mounted and booths arranged to accommodate the bands, the food and the handcrafts in a setting of old live oaks, palm trees, lagoons and fountains. On the menu will be blues, rhythm and blues, bluegrass, folk ragtime, Cajun and country music and dishes like gumbo, crawfish pie and red beans and rice. There also will be a gospel tent and jazz tent, and tamales and stuffed pepper. The festival will run from 11 A.M. to sundown. During the evenings concerts will be held around townaboard boats in the Mississippi River, at the Royal Sonesta Hotel and elsewhere. The concerts will feature such performers as Allen Toussaint, Professor Longhair, Dave Bartholomew and Clarence Gatemouth Brown. Tickets for the festival are $2,50 a day for adults and $1.50 for children up to the age of 12. Tickets for the evening concerts. range from $6 to $7.50. All are available from the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Foundation (tel: 5045224786). Tickets cover only the music; the food is extra (about $1.25 for jambalaya and $1.50 for red beans and rice and hot sausage). Musicians on hand for the festival from Europe. Japan, Australia and other faraway places can be heard in spontaneous performances around town for a week or so after the festival ends. Festival or no, jazz is a New Orleans staple the year round. A favorite jazz place outside the French Quarter is Lu & Charlie's at 1101 North Rampart. Order a pitcher of beer for $3. There's a $2 cover charge on weekends for the music, which gets better later in the evening. The crowd is young, a comfortable mix of black and white. Other places, far from the tourist beat, in the Carrollton section, are the Maple Leaf Club, 8316 Oak Street, and Jed's University Inn, 8301 Oak Street. At Preservation Hall, 726 St. Peter Street, the musicians are getting older but they still sound good. You sit on benches or on the floor. The hall is open every night from 8:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M., $1 per person, (5045238939). No bar. Al Hirt performs at his place, the Al Hirt Night Club, 501 Bourbon, Monday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights. The $12.50 minimum includes two drinks (5045256167). Clarinetist Pete Fountain performs at his French Quarter Inn, 231 Bourbon Street, Tuesday through Saturday. The $11 minimum includes two drinks (5045234374).

title: P.S.C. IS ACTING ON YELLOW PAGES
description: The New York State Public Service Commission claimed jurisdiction for the first time last week over advertising in the Yellow Pages of telephone directories and the New York Telephone Company said that it would not challenge the action.

title: Writers And Politicians
description: Watching all the candidates compete in the Presidential primaries, I see curious likenesses between politicians and writers. In the first place both normally address themselves to populations rather than individuals. Writers and politicians are one person speaking to many. Of course a difference is that we writers take office first and then we create our constittuencies. That is to be a shade more arrogant than the politicians. But we have a saving grace: The power we assume is of no practical use to ourselves. If we are lucky we have our greatest influence when we dead.

title: Mary Sanders, Intern, Bride
description: Dr. Mary Ella Sanders, an intern at the Ochsner Medical Center in New Orleans, was married last evening to Ashton Phelps Jr. of New Orleans, vice president and secretary of The TimesPicayune Publishing Corporation. The Rev. Dr. J. Woodrow Hearne, assisted by the Rev. William George Scarlett 3d, performed the ceremony at the First Methodist Church in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: SCHOOL VOUCHERS REJECTED IN TEST
description: CONCORD, N. H., April 10The education voucher plan designed to give parents a choice between public and private education has been turned down by voters in six communities whose school districts had agreed to study the program.

title: Phyllis Lauder and Robert Kiley Marry in Montana
description: Phyllis Steinbach Lauder former general manager of the American Indian Arts Center, was married yesterday afternoon in Missoula, Mont., to Robert Leland Kiley, professor of art and dean of the School of Fine Arts at the University of Montana. Circuit Court Judge Jack Green performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: 31 in House Ask a Delay on Power Plant
description: DENVER, April 10Thirtyone Congressmen from around the country asked Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe today to delay his decision on whether to allow the proposed giant Kaiparowits power plant in southern Utah.

title: Costs Go Up and Ridership Goes Down
description: Years ago, Mike Quill, who was the leader of the Transport Workers Union, used to say that the subways and buses should he free; today, transit officials agree with himto an extent.

title: Black Net Star Who Hoped To Play Miss Wills Honored
description: Ora Washington was inducted into the Black Athletes Hall of Fame two weeks ago. But the seat reserved for her on the dais the night of the induction ceremonies was empty. The silver bowl, gold ring and medallion she was to receive have been returned to the Hall of Fame offices in New York. And Miss Washington's whereabouts remain a mystery.

title: ART VIEW
description: This year brings us the 100th anniversary of the birth of the Spanish sculptor Julio Gonzalezhe was born in Barcelona on Sept. 21, 1876and the Pace Gallery is marking the occasion with an excellent exhibition of his work. As Gonzalez's is one of the central contributions to the development or modern sculpture, the show is an important one. Yet the scale of his work is suchit might best be described as the scale of intimacythat its importance may no longer seem as selfevident as it once did. Gonzalez's is not an imperious talent; it does not impose itself, or consume all the oxygen in the territory it occupies. It is gentle, subtle, fine and small scale. Yet at a crucial moment in the history of sculptures it cut like a razor into the very flesh of this venerable medium, and left it radically changed.

title: Nigerian Decree Curbing Press Is Under Fire
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 10The Nigerian press is bristling under a new governmental decree that imposes severe penalties if an accusation of corruption against a public official is not correct in every detail.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONCure one problem, create another.

title: Fashion and Design
description: Brilliant colors. Natural fibers. Body wrappings. Bold prints. Masses of jewelry. The latest fashion trends? Yes, but not the newest ideas in the world. They've all existed in Africa for untold centuries. And it's to Africa that many Western designers and merchants are suddenly turning for inspiration. African designs in the United States have gone beyond the dashikis and turbans that some American blacks adopted in the 60's as a statement of black identity and, in their multiplicity, have become a fashion statement for whiles as well.

title: Baseball Box Scores
description: EGarner, Etchebarren, B.Smith. LOBOakland 7, California 8. 213Rudl, Garner, Bochte, L.Stanton, Chalk. 5Remy.

title: L. B. Kurland Is the Fiance Of Miss Hewes
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morris Hewes 3d of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet MacLaren Hewes, to Lawrence Berryl Kurland, son of Mrs. Carl Lewis Kurland of Boston and the late Mr. Kurland.

title: TeambyTeam Choices In N. F. L.'s College Draft
description: ATLANTA FALCONS

title: A Googly Won't Get You to 1st Base
description: Forget about Lord's, the Oval and those other shrines of firstclass cricket. For the uninitiated visitor who wants to see England's national game at its best, the villages and hamlets are the places to go. Village cricket has an advantage over top cricket in that you don't have to understand the game to enjoy it: enough that you have a perfect summer's afternoon, that you are sitting or lying in comfort and good company, and that you find the surroundings esthetically pleasing. You can treat the whiteclad players as performers in a somewhat obscure openair ballet. For backdrop, there is the rich, waving green of the surrounding elms in which doves may actually be heard to moan; for other music, there is the smart smack of the willow bat against the leather ball, and the restrained applause of the few spectators.

title: PEOPLE
description: Everyone, of course, has heard of Coccinella septempunctata. But did anyone realize that C. s., as its friends affectionately call it, has never showN signs of having permanently established itself in this country? Well, rejoice. Dr. Richard L. Jacques, assistant professor of hiological sciences at Fairleigh Dickinson University's Rutherford campus, is the first to discover that an unusual species of C. s., commonly known as the ladybird beetle, has established a base in the Hackensack Meadowlands of Bergen County. The beetle is considered a most beneficial insect, for it protects crops from aphids. Now Dr. Jacques has spotted a sevenspotted species that seems to have nothing to do with those that have been imported from abroad since 1956.

title: ESKIMOS OBJECT TO MINING PERMITS
description: OTTAWA, April 10Canadian Eskimos, angered over the granting of permits to prospect for uranium and other minerals in lands claimed by them, have demanded the resignation of the Minister of Indian Affairs, J. Judd Buchanan.

title: Book Ends
description: SelfPublisher. Among the drifts of books in this office, we spied one called How to SelfPublish Your Own Book and Make It a Best Seller! The book is by Ted Nicholas, a handy man with an exclamation point, and is, appropriately, published by his owns company, which now offers a list of six Ted Nicholas titles, including his biggest hit, How to Form Your Own Corporation Without a Lawyer for Under $50.

title: French Families Say Bienvenue To Americans In or Out of Paris
description: You know what they say about the French: It takes them forever before they invite you into their homes. Now Chez des Amis, a travel service started last year by two college chums, one French, the other American, is opening doors in every corner of that richly beautiful country and into the intimate lives of its people.

title: The Mall Moves Downtown
description: CHICAGOEven as downtown troubles of the nation's big cities worsen and the flight to the suburbs goes on, a growing number of urban developers are conducting a daring experiment.

title: BEAME DEMANDS CUTS IN OVERTIME
description: The heads of all city agencies were ordered by Mayor Beame yesterday to curtail sharply all overtime payments to municipal employees and to limit the number of hours put in by parttime workers.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Dear Taxpayer,

title: Harassing of U.S. Officials In Moscow Tapering Off
description: MOSCOW, April 10Harassment of American diplomats in Moscow has tapered off in the last two days after a series of threatening telephone calls, bomb scares and several confrontations in the street.

title: Italian Horseman Takes Jersey Teaching Post
description: It was a new and exciting world Nino Buttafuoco found when he arrived in the United States less than four years ago.

title: Food
description: Baked eggs Maryland

title: FOOD
description: CLEANING the freezer involves more than wiping finger marks off the door. While many of today's freezers are frostfree, eliminating the mess of periodic defrosting, occasional sorting and tidying of the contents of a freezer is still advisable.

title: PROP. PAUL HOLDEN CORPORATE EXPERT
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., April 10 (UPI)Paul E. Holden, a professor emeritus at the Stanford Graduate School of Business who conducted the first comprehensive study of American corporate leadership, was found dead in his home here. yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: Tax wealth, not income
description: To argue about tax policy is really to argue about the distribution of wealth in this country. And that is a subject that makes us very nervous. We avoid discussions of economic justice like the plague. At least by default, we accept the idea that our wealth should be distributed unequally. Do we also approve of such an idea? Do we secretly share a belief that the concentration of much of our wealth in the hands of a relative few is somehow essential to the health and stability of our society? The notion curious, certainly, but how else to explain our reluctance to adopt tax policies that would have greater equalizing effect?

title: A Senator's advice
description: He ran for President but found that it was mindless, alienating him from his work and family. He is candid enough to tell us that after all his traveling he was not known by more than 1 percent of the population. A cynic would say that, since he could not become President, he now wishes to curb the power and excesses of the office, the high living that so offends this simple and decent man. But such cynicism would be wrong.

title: Epilogue
description: Pensions in Spain

title: Lisa F. Deutch Married on L.I.
description: Lisa Faith Deutch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Deutch of New York and Hewlett, L.I., was married last evening to Stuart M. Cantor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mel Cantor of North Woodmere. L.I.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Chicago

title: Riding The Ump Ain't Cricket
description: Not a country mile from the banks of the Thames, spectators gather each Sunday morning on the fringes of a wellworn patch of London greenery to observe a transplanted spectacle. As Queen Elizabeth's Life Guards, in glittering armor, shape up at Knightsbridge Barracks to canter off to man the portals of nearby Buckingham Palace, cries of strike, safe and yerrout, as well as earthy Americanized AngloSaxon rejoinders, rise from an improvised Hyde Park baseball diamond across the road.

title: Taylor Yale Six Coach
description: NEW HAVEN, April 10Tim Taylor freshman hockey roach at Harvard for the last six years, has been named Yale's new head coach of hockey. Taylor succeeds Paul Lufkin, who was dismissed last month after four seasons. The Elis were 421 wonlost last season and have had just one winning season in the last nine years.

title: The Nation
description: Two statements, attributed to State Department officials, about the United States power relationship to the Soviet Union have been seized upon by critics of dtente as evidence that the Ford Administration takes an essentially defeatist, propitiatory approach to the Russians. The Administration, however, says that one of the statements was never made and that the other has been misconstrued.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., which is celebrating the 50th anniversary of the founding of its Museum of Art, turns out to have done very well as an art collector. Its Alumni Loan Exhibition is now on view at Hirschl and Adler, through April 24, and will then be seen at the college's own museum from May 3 through June 13.

title: Sealyham Triumphs At Montreal Again
description: MONTREAL, April 10The topwinning Sealyham terrier in the history of the breed in Amrica,.Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, who hasn't been out since Westminster at Madison Square Garden Feb. 10, made a brilliant return to the ring tonight.

title: Floyd Leads by 8 Strokes In Masters; Nicklaus Is 2d
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10What it conies down to is this: Can Jack Nicklaus spot Raymond Floyd eight strokes tomorrow and hope to beat him in the finale of the Masters?

title: A Cesspool Of Problems
description: FROM the very beginning, it was meant to he a showcase project. There were times when John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, would boast about the Southwest Sewer District to visitors, telling them again and again that there was simply nothing quite like it in the whole nation.

title: Lindbergh
description: Few Americans of the present century lived more adventurously and dangerously, spiritually as well as physically, than Charles A. Lindbergh, the archetypical aviator. No other contemporary life story, viewed psychohistorically, is richer than his in symbolic meaning and direct historical implication.

title: NEW YORK INSURERS OPPOSE STATE TAX
description: A spokesman for the lifeinsurance industry in New York said yesterday that the industry would strongly resist a reported proposal by Governor Carey's Economic Development Board to impose a sales tax on insurance premiums in addition to those already being imposed.

title: For Second Story Jobs Around The Home
description: Any homeowner who does much work around the outside of his house will sooner or later have to use a tall ladder of some kind to reach his gutters, eaves, upstairs windows, or other areas that are beyond the reach of an ordinary stepladder. To avoid personal injury or other accident when handling one of these tall ladders, it is important that the doityourselfer familiarize himself with a few commonsense safety rules, and that he observe some precautions when selecting and handling the ladder.

title: Notes: California Fever Hits A Chorus Line
description: It's no secret that A Chorus Line stands a very good chance of dominating the Tony Awards next Sunday. Michael Bennett's red  hot musical received nominations in 10 or the 18 Tony categories, including those for Best Musical Play, Best Book of a Musical, and Best Score. Rather more of a secret, in that no one connected with the show really wants to talk about it until after the Tonys have been handed out, so as not to risk making the awards seem in any way anticlimactic, is the fact that most of the original cast will be leaving New York for California after the performance of April 24. Heading west, first to San Francisco for most of May and June and then to the Shubert Theater in Los Angeles starting July 1, will be, among others, Donna McKechnie, the show's featured dancer; Sammy Williams, Priscilla Lopez and Robert LuPone, all of whom are Tony nominees. Miss McKechnie is up for Best Actress in a Musical, Messrs. Williams and LuPone were nominated for Best Featured Actor in a Musical, Miss Lopez for Feain that ry.

title: COAST UNIT FIGHTS NUCLEAR CURBS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10Defenders of atomic power have opened a largescale educational campaign to try to tip the scales of public opinion against a June ballot proposal for stringent state nuclear safeguards.

title: The Vestiges of a Life That Gunpowder Built
description: An incongruous question kept running through my mind as I headed into the rolling estate country north of Wilmington: What hath black powder wrought?

title: A Bas Mitzvah With a Difference
description: LAWRENCE THEY might have been any group of girls studying for their bas mitzvah, the symbolic rite of entering womanhood in Judaism. They sat nervously on the altar, practiced the Torahreading and stared out blankly into the empty pews trying to imagine them packed with relatives and friends.

title: Judging the Judges
description: TOELESS Lutz, said the announcer. Walley, marveled the crowd. Inside Axel, Halt Loop, Salchow, Flip and Split and Stag.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HOUSES with painted clapboard on the outside are very common in many New Jersey communities, especially along the shore and in areas where older homes are seen most frequently.

title: Clifton H.W. Maloney to Marry Carolyne Jane Bosher May 15
description: Carolyne Jane Bosher, special assistant to the deputy administrator of the office of career education of the Bgard of Education, plans to be married May 15 to Clifton Harlan Wells Maloney, an investment banker with Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two local measures aimed at curbing prostitution will he introduced in the City Council on Tuesday by Carol Greitzer, whose district includes the Times Square area. One bill would prohibit renting any room in a hotel, motel or singleoccupancy establishment more than twice within 24 hours. The other bill would require the closing of parking lots with gates or chains during hours the lots were unattended to prevent parking by prostitutes and their customers.

title: RIGHTSUNIT SEEKS END TO LIE TESTS
description: One of every four potential employees tested by companies may be barred from a job because of recommendations by polygrauh operators, according to the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: AROUNG THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Greenwich vs. Big Business
description: AT the foot of Ye Greate Street in Greenwich, a ramshackle pier juts out into the Cohansey River where, on the night of Dec. 22, 1774, a hand of local men dumped a load of tea overboard from the British brig Greyhound.

title: TOULOUSE SLOGAN IS CONCORDE OUI
description: TOULOUSE, France, April 7 It this capital of the French aerospace industry, a majority of the people believe that Paris has quietly dropped plans to continue the troubled Concorde project after the 16th supersonic airliner is completed and that it is up to them to press the Government to change its mind.

title: Novels and stories
description: The ultimate Hollywood noyel! says Blurb, and for once he may be near the mark. Here's the plot of Frederic Raphael's California Time: Victor England, wellknown d?? rector and ladies' man, returns to Hollywood to make a film, runs into old friends and lovers, goes to parties, becomes embroiled in dark studio politics, and does or does not murder a small time porno actress, who then is or is not buried in the desert. Lest we should for a mad moment think it matters either way, Raphael stops the action to assure us it does not; and, since we have paid our admission, and seem to be stuck there in the dark a while, he drops any number of other helpful hints on how best to read a book called California Times.

title: Jacques BeRange's MauveTinted Mannerism
description: The cover of the catalogue for The Etchings of Jacques Bellenge, a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, is a color that could be christened Boudoir Mauve  a cross between shocking pink and a mixture of grape sherbet and strawberry souffl blended with plenty of whipped cream. Some flecks of paint of the same color on the edges of a frame on two indicate that at either the Des Moines Art Center, where the exhibition originated, or at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, where it was shown before concluding its tour at the Metropolitan, the etchings were exhibited on Walls of the same tintwhich could have served as fair warning to visitors unacquainted with the art of Bellange that they were about to enter into an esthetic experience of rather strange flavor.

title: The Week's Concerts
description: 710 A.M., WNCNFM. Chichester Psalms, Anon; The Eternal Gospel, Janacek; Cantata No. 79, Bach: Te Deum, Bruckner.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The gossip journals are unusually lush this season in the private miseries of public persons. The poor old Burtons are separated again. So are Princess Margaret and Lord Snowdon. Jacqueline Onassis suffers under Judith Campbell Exner's scandalous assertions about President Kennedy. Even the Mellons, normally among the most recessive of the world's Croesuses, are involved in a childcustody struggle in which kidnappers were used.

title: Kissinger On the Future
description: The authorized summary of Secretary of State Kissinger's remarks to American ambassadors in London last December discloses the extraordinary stress he put on his view that the dominance of Communist parties in the West is unacceptable. Yet, there may be a contradiction between that strongly held view and a point made on the same occasion by Helmut Sonnenfeldt, one of Mr. Kissinger's closest associates.

title: BARBER WITH FLAIR SUNG BY CITY OPERA
description: The vitality and ensemble flair that have long been primary calling cards at the City Operaand which are absolutely essential to proper showcasing of The Barber of Sevillehelped bring the Rossini favorite bounding cheerfully back to the repertory Friday night.

title: TV VIEW
description: It is manifestly unfair to fault television for not having done what nobody else can do: cope with evil. And yet one kept hoping through the four hours, spread over two nights, of the TV dramatization of Helter Skeltee that some sense would be made of the Tate murders, some intuition would arise from the fretting of raw edges. The script, after all, was intelligent; the acting was good, particularly that of George DiCenzo as the Los Angeles prosecutor, Vincent Bugliosi. What, then, was the meaning of the moonfaces of those children of a mushroom, the bloody graffiti, the thirdrate Satanism? If the witches of Salem can he explained awaywe are told now that they were hallucinated by young girls in the grip of convulsive ergotism after eating contaminated breadthen why not Charles Manson? If evil can be located, then perhaps it can be removed, by ablation. But dislocation, a lack of center, seems to he Its condition, at least in this century. We flounder and gag and dust for fingerprints, call In the helicopters and the psychiatrists.

title: WAGE FREEZE VOTED AT WASHINGTON STAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Circulation workers at The Washington Star represented by the. International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted unanimously today to accept a wage freeze that the newspaper's publisher says is necessary if the financially troubled publication is to survive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On the Wetlands

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market started out last week with a burst of enthusiasm, generated mainly by settlement of the nationwide trucking strike, but then the rally fell apart amid pessimistic predictions by a leading analyst.

title: Robert Danielson. Professor Of Astrophysics at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 10 10Dr. Robert E. Danielson, a professor of astrophysical sciences at Princeton University, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 44 years old.

title: Vegetables to Grow, Row by Row
Summit, a Pioneer
description: COOD teachers are essential to a good school system. In order to determine how good the teachers in a school system actually are, the administrators must have some measure of teacher evaluation.

title: Jane Fonda's Happy Heist
description: LOS ANGELES Jane Fonda is back from the war.

title: Spanish Calling for Sweeping Political Referendum
description: MADRID, April 10Pressure is rising here for an immediate popular referendum to end the confusion and contradiction that now mark Spanish political life.

title: Engagements
description: MaslinMyers

title: New Chinese Stamps Mark Gains in Medical Science
description: TOKYO, April 8 (AP)China has issued a set of four multicolor photoengraved stamps to commemorate its latest achievements in medical science, the Hsinhua press agency has reported.

title: New &Novel
description: The harsh, elemental scenes described by Dominic Cooper recall the rugged seascapes of Robert Flaherty's classic film of the Aran islanders. Like Flaherty's Man of Aran, Cooper's hero wrests a hard living from the North Atlantic. Alasdair Mr is the last of a village of 50 crofters on a windblown island of the Inner Hebrides. A loner, he sustains himself by lobstering from a rowboat in the rough seas, and by keeping a few sheep, some chickens and a cow. It would take a psychopath to want to harm such a gentle hulk of a manand a psychopath conveniently arrives to set up housekeeping on the other side of the island.

title: Early behavior of B. F. Skinner
description: The famous, controversial behavioral scientist B. F. Skinner hankered to be a writer as a young man, and could have been. At least he had in him that one novelhis own storyalmost everybody is said to possess. The first volume of his autobiography carrying us to the year 1928, when he was 24, is meticulously remembered and for the most part gracefully described. There have been so many young people's hectic memoirs lately taking us up to Just yesterday that to read an old man telling of the fullness of a long lifewhether it's Loren Elseley or, at an opposite pole, Edward Dahlberghas become a particular delight.

title: He's Used It 47 Times
description: The strength of the Congress consists in the right to pass statutes; the strength of the President in his right to veto them.James Bryce in The American Commonwealth.

title: Phyllis M. Eyth Is Wed to John O'Brien
description: Phyllis Mary Eyth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Eyth of Yonkers, was married yesterday noon to John Graham O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward O'Brien of Westfield, N.J.

title: Lawns: The Agony and the Ecstasy
description: IT all started as Daniel Dorfman's bright idea. Farming had become highly mechanized, so why not lawns? Lawns, the bane and backache of a generation of city slickers who had moved to the suburbs unprepared for crabgrass, dandelions and the glares of neighbors who had conquered those foes.

title: Dancing for Health
description: DO it with finesse, a trouper named Tessie Tura advised in Gypsy. She wasn't talking about the kind of bumps and grinds likely to be seen in an exercise class; however, thanks to a variety of courses now being offered by adulteducation programs throughout New Jersey, those interested in getting their bodies into shape can combine exercise with everything from pirouettes to Eastern mysticism.
