description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Japanese House Approves '76 Budget Despite Boycott
description: TOKYO, April 10 (UPI)The Japanese Parliatnent's lower house has approved Prime Minister Takeo Miki's $80.9 billion budget for fiscal 1976 despite the boycott of three opposition parties.

title: 6 Riders to Represent U.S. in Europe
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., April 10Six horsemen have heert named to the United States Equestrian Team jumping squad, which will represent this country at five European international horse shows in May and June. Five of the six will be severed for the United States Olympic team.

title: Births
description: Benjamin

title: Service by the Yard
description: IT all started as Daniel Dorfman's bright idea. Farming had become highly mechanized, so why not lawns? Lawnsthe bane and the backache of a generation of city slickers who had moved to the suburbs unprepared for crabgrass, dandelions and the glares of neighbors who had already conquered those foes.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Two of the major farm equipment producers of the western world are sowing the seeds of dtente with Eastern bloc countries. In a program sponsored by the International Harvester Company, 15 young American agricultural specialists will change places this summer with 15 young Russians to see how competing farm systems work.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayRhode Island. K.C. allbreed and oberdience Meehan Auditorium, Brown University Providence; 1,661 dogs 9 A..

title: POPULATION RISE EASES IN COLOMBIA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 10 Colombia's population growth rate, once among the highest in the world, has declined sharply during the last decade as a major familyplanning program has taken hold here.

title: Blanket Tossing In Barrow
description: Stepping off a jet into the middle of a desolate, snowcovered field is a disconcerting experience. At Barrow, Alaska, It is only the first in a long list of contradictions found in an Arctic Coastal city of 3,000 that straddles the fringe of the modern world with one foot still resting on the far side of it.

title: Winner Pays $68 at Gulfstream
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 10 (AP)Enchuma, a 5yearold horse who was the longest shot in the race, caught favored Proud And Bold at the threesixteenths pole and drew away to a fivelength victory in the $28,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap at Gulfstream today.

title: Perennials to Plant This Spring
description: Spring brings out the farmer in many of us. The urge is strong to plant and sow. Luckily, now is the best time to set out many perennials. For certain perennials, peonies and iris, wait until late summer or fall.

title: Jump Opens Chad Ceremony
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 10 (Agence FrancePresse)Chad's head of state, Gen. Felix Malloum, and all members of the ruling military council will make a parachute jump above the city's racecourse on Tuesday to mark the first anniversary of the overthrow of late ;President Ngarta Tombalbaye's regime. The drop will open two days of celebrations.

title: British Columbia Bars MudSlinging in House
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, April 10 (UPI)  You pipsqueak, buffoon, hysterical maniac, Mr. Magoo.

title: New York Is One of 31 States Disputing U.S. on Aid to Poor
description: New York and 30 other states are engaged in disputes with the Federal Government over who is to shoulder what share of overpayments to recipients in the Supplemental Security Income program for the aged, blind and disabled poor.

title: Wife of a Republican Leader in Bronx Shot and Wounded by Unknown Man
description: The wife of a Bronx Republican leader was in critical condition yesterday after being shot by an unkown assailant Friday night after she had left a restaurant with her husband.

title: Letters:
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO and the Leaning Tower
description: BONNNATO's biggest political problemstill more potential than actualis what to do about allies who give cabinet posts to Communists. The name of the game is Italy. Nothing has happened yet but how long can the leaning tower tilt leftward?

title: The Ballet: A New Sleeping Beauty
description: BOSTON, April 10If a thing is worth doing, it is perhaps worth doing badly. Now the Boston Ballet, which has just staged its new production of the Petipa/Tchaikovsky classic The Sleeping Beauty, does not do it badly. Nor does it do it well enough to send you dancing out into the staid Boston streets with the glitter of St. Petersburg chandeliers in your eyes.

title: Judith Kandler to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Kandler of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Judith Ellen Kandler, to Stuart E. Warm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney A. Warm of Cincinnati, A July wedding is planned.

title: STATE WARNS CITY ON WELFARE FRAUD
description: The State Welfare Inspector. General warned last week that permissiveness by the City Department of Social Services would result in the certain loss of $9.1 million in city funds for fraudulent welfare payments.

title: Tennis and the Married Man
description: COMING on with the speed and satanical spirit of a Jimmy Connors, the tenacity of a Ken Rosewall, and the maniacal antics of au Ilia Nitstase, the tennis plague will soon be upon us again, reacbIng epidemic proportions during the raring and summer months and gripping seme of us in a reign of marial terror.

title: Work in Progress By Rod Rogers Is a Dance Portrait
description: Each new work from the choreographer Rod Rodgers has an element of surprise. One is never quite sure whether he will draw on a social protest theme or create an exercise in pure movement. In Visions, currently a work in progress, he has favored theme material but asked the contemporary composer Gwendolyn Watson to provide its abstracted aural setting. His company performed at the Barbizon Plaza Theater Friday evening.

title: Pressure for Callaway's Resort Denied by Forest Service Aides
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Past and present officials of the Forest Service in Colorado denied today that pressure had been put on them by their Washington superiors to approve tenatively an expansion of Howard H. Callaway's ski resort at Crested Butte.

title: New Penitential Rite
description: THOUSANDS of Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of Newark and the Diocese of Trenton will be in for a new experience when they go to church this week to receive the sacrament of penance in preparation for Easter communion.

title: FILM VIEW
description: That the strength, excitement, intelligence and perhaps even conscience of the American cinema are more often to be found in its commercial films than in the work of the independents and backroom innovators is not a proposition I'd want to die defending. It wouldn't be an elegant demisebacked into a corner, being simultaneously suffocated and softened into death through repeated showings of things like The Exorcist, Death Wish, Lipstick and W. C. Fields and Me.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Gerard Oestrelcher and Leonard Marx have purchased the 35story office tower at 708 Third Avenue, at 44th Street, and the two adjoining smaller structures at 7124 Third Avenue for about $7 million.

title: Musici di Roma Play Vivaldi Winningly
description: I Musici di Roma, one of Italy's foremost musical exports, played Vivaldi at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, and, as might be expected, a large audience was on hand for the concert.

title: Rutgers Relays Pick Up Baton From QueensIona
description: The Rutgers Relays will have its inaugural meet this week. The meet takes the place of the QueensIona Relays on the schedule of most major Metropolitanarea col. lege track teams, The Queenslona meet had been held annually since 1935, but was discontinued when Queens College with. drew its support.

title: FUND PLAN GALLED PERIL TO PRIVACY
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The White House Office of Telecommunications Policy has charged that a plan to build a national center for the electronio transfer of funds could give the Federal Government a highly effective tool for keeping track of people and enforcing correct behavior.

title: City Growers Can Plant In Boxes, Tubs and Barrels
description: Fourgallon plastic buckets, 20  gallon plastic garbage cans, old bushel baskets, apple crates, fruit lugs, 18inch paper pulp tubsall of them can be converted into vegetable or flower gardens. All they need is a place in the sun to dwell, some kind of growing medium, preferably the lighter weight soilless mixes and someone who will care. The results will be flowers to cut or smell and vegetables to eat or freeze.

title: Rhubarb Needs a Place In the Sun
description: Rhubarb looks as good in the flower garden as in the vegetable garden. Practically every home garden has room for a plant or even two. Though actually a perennial vegetable, rhubarb is enjoyed as a fruit either stewed, made into a strawberryrhubarb pie or jam, or even used for wine or punch. Country folk have praised it over the centuries as a rejuvenating spring tonic.

title: Yachting
description: AT LARCHMONT Y. C.

title: Isobel Lee Is Bride of Henry Beers
description: At all Saints Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Isobel Carlyle Lee, a vice president of the Steuben Glass division of the Corning Glass Works, was married to Henry Newell Beers, a widower and partner in H. N. Howard & Son Inc., financial advisers.

title: Tale of 2 Young Muggers Who Prey on the Elderly
description: When William Harper was 14 years old, the police say, he dropped out of school and began working as a mugger, preying on old men and women in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.

title: In This Issue
description: PICTURE CREDITS 3. Evening Standard. London. 5. Associated Press. 23. Mike Lien/The New York Times.

title: Francis Gives Up Job With Rangers
description: Emile Francis ended a 16year association with the New York Rangers yesterday when he resigned as vice president of the National Hockey League team. The move was announced by William Jennings, the president of the Rangers.

title: Messersmith Signs A Braves' Contract
description: SAN DIEGO, April 10Andy Messersmith, the 30yearold righthander who became a free agent in a historic baseball decision four months ago, signed a multiyear contract with the Atlanta Braves today that is reportedly worth $1.75 million.

title: Black Mayors Report Progress For Small Towns in the South
description: ATLANTA, April 10For the first time in history, our town will have people working to bring in wnter lines, sewers, better housing and new businesses.

title: How Golf Started in America and Why It Succeeded
description: Today, just about wherever you travel, golf courses with their green fairways, greener greens and pristine white bunkers have become an intrinsic part of the face of America. The game has also penetrated deep into the American consciousness.

title: Wall Street WeekJuicing Up A Dry Subject
description: During the five years that Wall Street Week has been broadcast live (now every Friday evening at 8:30 P.M.) from a hilltop on a state game preserve in Owings Mills, Md., home of the Maryland Center for Public Broadcasting, it has earned the distinction of having become the most popular, regularly broadcast public affairs show on public TV. Last year, the halfhour program was the numberone choice of 240 public television stations in 50 states; this year, it tied for first with Sesame Street.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Last Laugh on Nastase
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POLITICS
description: ONE of the strengths of County Executive John Klein of Suffolk as a politician is his altar boy image. He speaks softly and usually has a gentle manner. He generally resists the temptation to inflate his rhetoric and retinue. He is not overly partisan at least publiclyand at a time when the credibility of politicians is as low as municipal credit ratings, even Mr. Klein's political foes concede that his credibility has been in better shape than most.

title: Drop That Gun
description: Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan has given renewed life to a bill to toughen a Federal guncontrol law badly in need of strengthening. Hope for getting such legislation out of the present Congress was all but abandoned in March, when the House Judiciary committee buried a bill to prohibit manufacture and sale concealable handguns. Mr. Conyers has now sent up a revised version of that bill which is so limited and plainly needed that it is unthinkable that the full committee will again fail to report it to the floor of the House.

title: Bridal Held for Laurie Gilbert And Terry Sanford Jr. in South
description: Marie Laurence Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Austin Gilbert of Greensboro, N. C., was married there last evening to James Terry Sanford Jr., son of former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina and Mrs. Sanford.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: CARIBBEAN

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Noble savages
description: The passing of colonial times, the fading of an empire upon which the sun never set, has had an impact on the practice of anthropology. Not long ago the vast majority of studies suggested, subtly and not so subtly, that primitive people were backward people, halfanimals at worst and children of the wild who at best, given sufficient time and technology and the right religion, might become civilized, or at least civilized. Studies tended to stress differences, specifically those that appeared to document the backwardness. Such customs as the ritual knockingout of teeth, headhunting and headshrinking, and cannibalism may not seem quite as barbarous as they seemed two world wars ago, but they once lent solid support to the whiteman'sburden theme.

title: Remembering Martin Luther King
description: WASHINGTON In the years since Emlyn Williams turned into Charles Dickens for our theatergoing pleasure and Hal Holbrook made a name for himself by pretending to be Mark Twain, the oneman or onewoman show has become a staple of the American stage. At their most effective, such events tend to be tours de force: See the elegance and wit with which Williams carries off Dickens; see the folksiness and humor with which Holbrook does Twain. The material, taken from the higher reaches of English and American literature, is bound to be superior to the lines being uttered on other stages around town, and most of the audience is likely to know enough about the originals to appreciate the actors' intentions, yet not so much as to be put off by their liberties.

title: SESSION DISCUSSES JOBLESS YOUTHS
description: HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 10 A group pf men and women who work with and study the problems of youths on local, state and national levels gathered here from all over the country yesterday and today to discuss whether a universal youth service would curb the high rate of unemployment.

title: ASCAP's Music MonitorsThe Composer's Best Friends
description: It Is a big, nondescript seventhfloor room with windows facing across Broadway to Lincoln Center. A dozen and a half people, of both sexes and miscellaneous ages, sit at booths arranged in rows like a highschool language lab, headphones in place, listening to music produced by the tapes spinning In front of them.

title: Many Newcomers Are Among Fleet of 150 Listed for NewporttoBermuda Race
description: The fleet for the biennial ocean race to Bermuda, which starts off Newport, R. I., June 18, will number 150 yachts, according to an announcement yesterday by the race chairman, Vincent Montesano. The selection is a wide one, going back to Prim, Morton G. Neff s Owens cutter from Chestertown, Md., built in 1948, and including such new boats as Williwaw, Seymore Sennett's TwoTon sloop, which had the best record on the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit last winter.

title: Faculty at Hostos Bids President End Building's Takeover
description: The faculty and staff members of Hostos Community College have passed a resolution urging the president of the college to remove the students and faculty members occupying the school building, using force if necessary, so that classes can resume when the school returns from vacation a week from tomorrow.

title: Mississippi's G.O.P. to Be Uncommitted
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 10Mississippi Republicans decided at their state convention here today to send an uncommitted 30member delegation, which is leaning toward former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, to the Republican National Convention next August.

title: CHESS
description: The Spanish grandmaster Arturo Pomar recently mused on the effect his wife had on his choice of openings: When my wife comes with me to a tournament, I cannot play my preferred CaroKann Defense. You know, it's very safe and it produces many draws, but she knows that, too, and she doesn't like me making draws, not even as Black. What can I do? Well, I must use the Sicilian Defense and you know what that meansevery game I am either a piece up or a piece down, I don't know whether I come out ahead or behind in the score table, but it's too hectic and I don't have any tranquillity.

title: Harlem: Valley of Myths
description: With Harlem on your mind, the ceremonial approach is from Broadway, across the Columbia University quad. Here is the monumental aftermath of King's College that educated the young Alexander Hamilton. Here too the flight of stone steps up to Stanford White's Low Library, site and symbol of the vanished nineteensixties' wri??hing student body.

title: Corrections
description: The review of Hugh Honour's The New Golden Land in the March 21 issue ignored the existence of a paperback edition (Pantheon, $8.95). Martin Woodhouse's Moon Hill, reviewed in the March 28 Criminals at Large column, will not be published until May 28. On April 4 Leonard Nathan's Returning Your Call was Incorrectly referred to as Return Your Call.

description: CLEVELAND, April 10 I Commissioner Frank R. Pokorney of Cuyahoga County has been indicted by a county grand jury for misconduct in office.

description: THE HAGUE, April 10 (AP)The commission probing Prince Bernhard's alleged role in the Lockheed bribes scandal says that its work is being hindered by the delay in receiving documents held by United States authorities.

description: Sunday, April 11, 1976

title: New York's Labor Chief Says Jobs Are Overwhelming Issue
description: The state's new Industrial Commissioner, who is head of the Department of Labor, said that New York State was no worse off than the rest of the industrialized segment of the country, but nonetheless, he said, the overwhelming issue is jobs.

title: NEW LIBEL RULING IS CITED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10Superior Court Judge Thomas W. LeSage has dismissed libel charges brought against Penthouse magazine and two freelance writers by two men whose names have been linked to organized crime.

title: Arms and Money Are Essential After the Nasser Years
description: LONDONPresident Anwar elSadat's European tour has not been the triumphal progress other leaders might have made. Mr. Sadat is not the charismatic figure who might indulge in such ventures. Much less flamboyant than his predecessor, Gamal Ahdel Nasser, Mr. Sadat has one outstanding characteristic: his realism.

title: ART
description: LAWRENCEVILLE IT was not uncommon for American artists in the 19th century to go to Europe to learn their lessons and seek their fortunes. America had not yet established itself as an artistic center, and most artists of this country held the European masters in awe, especially the French ones.

description: EL PASO, Tex., April 10Ronald Reagan's campaign issues tracked President Ford across the Lone Star State today with the relentlessness of a Texas Ranger.

title: Veterinarian Is Sued
description: CINCINNATI, April 10 (UPI) A medical malpractice lawsuit has been filed against a veterinarian. Patrick Fox contends the veterinarian, John S. Lies, was careless and negligent in operating on his German shepherd, Chester. He seeks $1,500 in compensatory damages and $50,000 in punitive damages.

title: Sweating Out the Cure At a Spa in France
description: What time do you wish to be awakened for your bath? The hotelkeeper, a mauve shawl around her shoulders, is standing behind the reception desk in this small, quiet provincial hotel in the South of France. Her pincenez has just fallen into a Byrrh ashtray on the desk. She assumes that my girlfriend and I stopped in BalaruclesBainsin the Midi region not far from the picturesque port of Stefor the 21day mud cure in the local baths. Everyone does.

title: MARINES PUT CURB ON DEATH INQUIRY
description: SAN DIEGO, April 10The Marine Corps acknowledged today that it had refused to admit to its training depot here investigators for the parents of a 20yearold problem recruit who was fatally clubbed while being disciplined by drill sergeants of a correctional platoon.

description: Ovid, some 2,060 years ago wrote about the impatient greyhound slipped from far, bound o'er the glade to course the fearful hare.

description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)A survey of delegates to the 1972 Democratic National Convention shows their favorite Presidential candidate is Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, The National Observer said today.

description: WASHINGTON, April 10A littleknown alliance of nine labor unions called the Labor Coalition Clearinghouse is pushing the election of Democratic National Convention delegates with union loyaltiesand never mind (almost) their preferences for President.

description: There is no Cornwallis among the five perforated stamps on the souvenir sheet for INTERPHIL 76 that reproduces John Trumbull's painting, The Surrender of Lord Cornwallis at Yorktown. In fact, the defeated British general Is not in the original painting.

description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West IndiesSooner or later, those who gain their living from the sea will have a desperate encounter with it or one of its creatures.

description: Diane Marie Zerillo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Zerillo of Mill Neck, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Noel Raphael Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Naples, Fla.

description: AHEARNGerard J., ell April 9, 1976. BeInved husband of Eleanor, loving ?? or Hubert F. and Sally Ahearn, also survived by one brother, John. Reposing at the Waller B. Cooke Funeral Home, 3d Ave. at 85th St. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10 A.M., at St. Paul one Apostle Church. Interment Gale of Heaven Cometery.

title: UNEQUAL JUSTICE CHARGED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, April 10 Some Spanish jurists say the line between what is lawful and what is not can no longer be clearly distinguished as a result of recent Government acts and court decisions.

description: James E. Tarjan, a 24yearold chess whiz from Sherman Oaks, Calif., has attained the title of international grandmaster, the game's highest permanently conferred accolade. He is the first United States player in 12 years to earn the coveted title.

title: Street Signs Replaced For Different Spelling
description: WATERVILLE, Me., April 10 (AP)  The name of a street was spelled Cannibas on new signput up this week, but they have already been changed.

title: 50 in Crisis Coalition Protest Conditions on Lower East Side
description: If that building was on West 10th Street, it would have window boxes filled with flowers, said Grace Paley, a writer, pointing to a vacant, hollowedlout town house on East Fourth Street near Avenue D.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Braulio Baeza, after riding Honest Pleasure to an impressive victory in the Florida Derby: I'm looking forward to the Kentucky Derby. Wouldn't you?

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Club Pro for the Cubs
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10In the locker room before today's third round of the Masters golf tournament, Raymond Floyd, whose reformation does not include abandoning his devotion to the Chicago Cubs, was opening congratulatory telegrams. Not far away, Larry Ziegler, a director of the St. Louis Blues' hockey team between shots, turned and grinned. Cubs zero, Cards 1, Ziegler said. I heard it Floyd said sharply.

title: You'll probably think I'm stupid
description: New York State Senator Richard Schermerhorn (R.C., Orange County) remembers it well. The time was 1972, the place was the State Senate chamber, the vote was on the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution. They were about to call the roll, and Schermerhorn arose. Do you want the attention of the chair? asked the then Lieutenant Governor, Malcolm Wilson. You bet! the Senator said. I'm going to debate against this thing! And everyone laughed. Schermerhorn is not known as one of the heavy thinkers in the Senate. He debated, and they laughed some more, and then they went on to ratify the Federal amendment overwhelmingly, as the Assembly already had done.

title: TAX CLAIMS PERIL 1972 G.O.P. FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The trust that is trying to clean up the financial debris left by Watergate and the 1972 Republican Presidential campaign may have its considerable assets wiped out by pending tax claims.

title: Contempt Case Is Delayed In Lehman Demonstration
description: A Bronx Supreme Court justice has postponed until April 19 contempt proceedings against a group of students and other persons who have seized Lehman College's main academic building.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Law, Zoology
description: Whether or not one or more Loch Ness monsters exist, a number of scientists now believe that considerable evidence consistent with monsters does.

title: BEIRUT DEPUTIES VOTE AMENDMENT TO OUST FRANJIEH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10Surrounded by phalanxes of bodyguards and a mixed force of security troops, 90 members of the Lebanese Parliament met today in a makeshift session and in 20 minutes unanimously approved an amendment to the Constitution to make possible the selection of a successor to President Suleiman Franjieh before his term ends in September.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Emerging from a decade in limbo, the $2 bill returns to circulation this week. Bearing the familiar obverse design of Thomas Jefferson and a new reverse design showing the signing of the Declaration of Independence, the bill should be available at face value in banks throughout the country when the oven for business this Tuesday, the 233d anniversary of Jefferson's birth.

title: A Polish Fencing Champion Gets 25 Years for Spying
description: WARSAW, April 10 (Reuters)A love of cars and entertainment by Jerzy Pawlowski, Poland's former world fencing champion, led him to espionage to earn money, the army newspaper Zolnierz Wolnosci, said today.

title: A Break for the Older Traveler: Discounts Abroad
description: Infirmities aside, age has its advantages for the traveler. The time for leisurely sightseeing is an obvious example. Less familiar is this: Many foreign nations offer their elderly citizens a variety of discounts that are extended to visitors.

title: The Peking Puzzles
description: The struggle for eventual succession to the leadership of China is apparently intensifying. Last week, there was a rare protest demonstration by thousands of Chinese in the heart of Peking and, soon afterward, a change at the highest level of Government. But just as the events were unexpected, their meaning was unclear.

title: The Original Ball Park Obsolete From Start
description: When the original Yankee Stadium opened its gates for the first time on April 18, 1923 to inaugurate the American League season, the spic and span arena was a stately picture of steel, stone and concrete as befitted the successful team which it housed. However, the first day demonstrated that the stadium had become obsolete during its construction.

title: Inhibiting Leadership Shifts, Here and There
description: WASHINGTONThe first official American comment last week on the seismic shift in the Chinese leadership came from George Bush, director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Bush mildly acknowledged that his experts had been surprised by the elevation of the relatively obscure Hua Kuofeng to a position that made him heirapparent to Chairman Mao Tsetung. But he said he was confident that relations between the United States and China would not be affected.

title: Landscape Remodeling Can Transform a House Into a Home
description: Can a dull, thirdacre suburban house lot be transformed into a landscape treasure? You bet. After 12 years of personal poking, hauling and planting, my own place is finally done. Not completed, but done.

title: Hearing Secret Harmonies
description: The publication of Hearing Secret Harmonies, the last of the twelve volumes of Anthony Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time, is unmistakably a literary eventthough the degree of its magnitude will be debated. [A talk with Mr. Powell appears on Page 47]

title: Minute Man Of the Hour
description: SPRINGFIELD I HAVE been in love with him for as long as I can remember. Ever since I was 7 years old and we would pile into our old Flivver and drive from Elizabeth to have ice cream in the drug store in Morristown.

title: Smithtown Voters Seek a Haven
description: SMITHTOWN AN unusual election campaign, marked by an absence of handshaking, speeches and other political paraphernalia is under way here. The candidates, in fact, aren't even human.

title: Carter's Evangelism Putting Religion Into Politics for First Time Since '60
description: Jimmy Carter's open espousal of his Christian beliefs in the 1976 Presidential campaign has raised the issue of religion's place in politics more arrestingly than it has been raised in any Presidential race since John F. Kennedy's in 1960.

title: A Little Soy Sauce
description: MADISON WHEN Nelson Thayer Jr. celebrated his 11th birthday following a school soccer match, he asked for Peking duck for a picnic gathering of 12, a request that flabbergasted his mother.

title: On Henry Wallace
description: The furniture movers were to come early on a Monday morning. On Sunday afternoon I had a telephone call from Henry Wallace asking me to come and have a farewell supper with him and Ilo, his wife. I had known Wallace very well, having been one of the people who had backed his third party presidential bid in 1948, contributed to it at a time when I should not have contributed to anything, and traveled with him on speechmaking tours. As the months went on I became more and more convinced that I had made foolish and thoughtless move. I had seen a third party as necessary in this countryI still dobut I had not wanted all energies turned toward a presidential campaign. I had thought we would concentrate on wards, districts, even neighborhoods, building slow and small for a long future, and I disagreed that so much energy and money, all of it, in fact, was being gambled on a man about whom I had many doubts. My doubts had nothing to do with my fondness for Wallace: his rare odd pieces of knowledge, often remarkable in their practicality, often wacky in their mysticism, interested me; he was serious about the state of America, open about his fears for the future, but there was no doubt that the powerful hand of Roosevelt had held tight rein over the conflicts in Wallace's nature and the strange digressions of his mind.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available.

title: Frazier vs. Foreman At Stadium June 15
description: Yankee Stadium will be the site of the Joe FrazierGeorge Foreman heavyweight fight on Tuesday, June 15, Jerry Perenchio disclosed yesterday.

title: The Legislatures in 3 States: A Farewell to Ignominy
description: Once the chief instrument of government in all three of the New York region's state capitals, Albany, Trenton and Hartford, the state legislatures have until relatively recently adopted with little question the policies of governors and the schemes of state political leaders. As late as the period between 1970 and 1973, the New Jersey Legislature passed nearly twothirds of Governor William Cahill's legislative program without changing a paragraph. As David Ogle, executive director of the Connecticut General Assembly's Joint Committee on Legislative Management, complained 1970: Although the General Assembly does indeed suffer from a poor public image, it suffers equally, and perhaps more, from the lack of any public image at all.

title: Industry Eyes Role of Atlantic
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S industrial future may ie in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: PEOPLE
description: As they used to say in the gossip colurns, don't invite William Kunstler and William Cahn to the same party. Mr. Kunstler, of course, is the lawyer who defended Daniel Berrigan among others, and who will soon defend William and Emily Harrislate of the Symbionese Liberation Army. He criticized public prosecutors in general and Mr. Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, in particular, durinz an address to 200 students at the Hofstra University School of Law. Discussing what he called prosecutorial abuse, Mr. Kunstter described Mr. Cahn as a dangerous and sometimes perverse D,A. Asked for his reaction, Mr. Cahn, reached in his MineoIa law office, said: I have no response. I don't want to get into a contest with Mr. Kunstler.

title: Good notices
description: During the fifties and early sixties, Kenneth Tynan was the most intelligent and effective drama critic writing in English. Intelligence in a regular theatrical reviewer is rare enough, but effectiveness, the ability actually to change, through the pungency and lucidity of critical argument, the esthetic habits of one's time, is a quality that, in this century at least, has almost vanished. Except for Shaw, Tynan is the only theater critic I can think of whose judgments became practice and whose prejudices proved Prophetic.

title: 60 Sterilized in India See Top Entertainers
description: NEW DELHI, April 10 (UPI)Sixty men were sterilized this week in exchange for free tickets to an evening's entertainment with nearly 100 leading actors and actresses, the youth wing of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's governing Congress Party reported.

title: Quick, Who Said, Where Is the Rest of Me?And Other Memorable Questions About Forgettable Lines
description: Listed below are some more or less memorable lines from a number of well known films. But which wellknown films? Movie buffs may test their memories, or simply skip to the end for the correct answers.

title: Bills Name Aide
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., April 10 (UPI)The National Football League Buffalo Bills today named Errol Prisby, assistant coach at the University of Massachusetts, as their special teams coach. Prisby was the defensive backfield coach at Massachusetts.

title: How Jerry Wurf walks on water
description: Jerry Wurf, the international president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, had worked with his staff for more than a week on his speech for the National League of Cities convention at Miami Beach. The tone and content of the final draft reflected exactly what he wanted to impress upon his audience of past bargainingtable adversaries and potential political allies: his union's genuine concern for the plight of governmental jurisdictions caught between falling revenues and rising expenses, its desire to improve the productivity of its own members and its unprecedented (in labor circles) willingness to accept compulsory arbitration of disputes involving publicsafety workers. At last, Wurf rose to the enthusiastic applauseand blew it.

title: TV VIEW
description: Another Presidential election year is here, and the spectacle of media hysterics is upon us. Everybody wants to get into the act, and nobody wants to be scooped by the competition. The voting pattern in a New Hampshire hamlet is studied with the same intensity as the ancients gave to the entrails of a sacrificial beast. Ronald Reagan loses several primaries to Gerald Ford; Ronald Reagan is finished. He wins in North Carolina; he is miraculously a serious contender once more. The primaries are given special and rather intensive coverage on television. But the computers reduce meaningful content to about, five minutes. Walter Cronkite is left with considerable time for light banter with Roger Mudd. One networknews executive describes theselfsustaining process as electronic masturbation.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER INSTALLMENT CREDIT ROSE by $1.17 billion in February after an increase of $1.29 billion in January ... The Federal Reserve Board reported that the money supplycurrency in circulation plus checking accountsrose by $1.2 billion in the week ended March 31.

title: Fred Shero, Hockey Violence and Goons
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Sarah Sorensen Wed to James G. Foster
description: Sarah J. Sorensen, director of public relations for the French Apparel Center in New York, was married yesterday afternoon to James G. Foster, Eastern regional sales manager or Medtronic, Inc.

title: Lunger's Sputtering Career Revives, According to Plan
description: Brett Lunger, who has been racing formula and sports cars since 1965, says he likes to plan his moves. And the 1975 racing season was a frightening one for me because I do like to plan ahead and my plans weren't working, said Lunger. It was such a tough year that Lunger  a member of the du Pont family, a former Princeton political science major and an exMarine Corps captainsays he had to borrow money to pay his taxes.

title: Rebellion Is Feared
description: IN New Jersey, as elsewhere, violent crime is up, and opinion polls suggest that everyone would like to crack down. Unfortunately, the criminal justice system is too paralyzed to respond just now, and the dollars and decisionmakers that could offer some relief are nowhere to be found.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: The country's foremost selfproclaimed deprogrammer of young cultists, Ted Patrick, was in trouble with the law again last January. He was arrested with seven other adults and accused of the sidewalk abduction in Tarrytown, N.Y. of Mark Goodman, a 19  year old member of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.

title: A Talk with Anthony Powell
description: A Dance, to the Music of Time was acclaimed as an English comic masterpiece even before it was finished. It was with no reluctance, therefore, that I interviewed Anthony Powell in his enchanting Regency home near Frome in Somerset; especially as he has been my brotherinlaw for 40 happy years. Alert and smiling, dressed in a dark red shirt, brown pullover and cavalry twill trousers, he came quickly down the polished oak staircase from his workingroom.

title: Admission Are Rising
description: TRENTON STATE PRISON is an antiquated relic of yesteryear's correction system, It stands as a more than centuryold reminder of what is wrong with the system, as well as of the changes we have made over the last 26 months.

title: Dance: Pennsylvanians End Season
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet, which winds up its brief season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this afternoon, has developed into al company dominated by three contemporary choreographers. They are George Balanchine, Benjamin Harkary and Hans van Manen. All three were represented on the company's second program on Friday night.

title: Gurgling Geysers In Iceland
description: Most people think of Iceland, if they think of it at all, as a cold place surrounded by pickled herring  or maybe as an airfield where cheap flights to Europe stop for an hour or so.

title: NEW MEXICO VENDOR CHALLENGES MUSEUM
description: SANTA FE, N.M., April 10A nonIndian has filed a discrimination charge with the New Mexico Human Rights Commission contending that the state museum should not allow only Indians to sell their jewelry on its property at the historic Santa Fe Plaza.

title: Mexico Accuses Aide to Hughes Of Falsifying His Tourist Card
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 10The Mexican Government formally charged an aide to Froward R. Hughes today with falsifying the ailing billionaire's signature on a tourist card when he entered Mexico on Feb. 11, eight weeks before Mr. Hughes died.

title: Italian Communist Chief Urges Entente With Governing Party
description: ROME, April 10 (AP)The leader of the Italian Communist Party, Enrico Berlinguer, told a crowd estimated at 30,000 at a rally today that Italy's economic and political crises were intolerable and asked for an entente with the governing Christian Democrats to avert early elections.

title: E.C. Harding Fiance Of Andrea Halpern
description: Dr. George M. Halpern, dean of the Voorhees Campus in Manhattan of the New York City Community College, and Mrs. Halpern have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Alicia Halpern, to Edward Charles Harding, a news and sports announcer with WPTZTV in Plattsburgh, N. Y.

title: Picture credits
description: 1SHERRY WOLF

title: A writer with a lot on her mind
description: We have a tradition or cult of the unthoughtful writer in this country which can take many peculiar forms. There is Eliot's crack about James having a mind so fine no idea could violate it, and there is Pound's behest to the writer, Don't be viewy. Then there are all those writers who spend their time going to the fights, or arm wrestling and breaking walking sticks in saloons, or at some other form of male bonding, perhaps to distract their minds from thinking thoughts that would be insufficiently commonplace. Behind this cult lie some queer notionsnot only that ignorance is bliss but that it is pure and virginal. Like so much else in modern culture, we seem to owe this notion to that devoted male bonder, Oscar Wilde.

title: The Rozelle Rule Is Dead: Long Live the Free Agents
description: The Rozelle Rule, under which a player's former team was compensated when he moved voluntarily to another, is dead.

title: Lawyer Weds Barbara Goldcamp
description: Barbara Jane Goldcamp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Goldcamp of Rowayton, Conn., and Howard R. Gill 3d, son of. Mr. and Mrs. Gill Jr., of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward J. Howley at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: For young readers
description: The world of tomorrow is a bleak and hostile place in these noveld; survival is the paramount concern. Ben Bova, a practiced hand at science fiction, takes a downtoearth look at New York in the indeterminate future and finds it has become a maximumsecurity prison for undesirables. The city is enclosed in a dome, open to vistors from the Outside only during the summer months. Then, sanitized suburbanites from the superhealthy but boringly regulated Tracts, where even the weather is controlled, come to New York as to some downanddirty Disneyland. Much as they do now, some would say. On Labor Day the dome is closed, the city deserted. Except... people do live there, after a fashion. Warring gangs roam the filthy avenues, the shadows hide poverty, fear and death.

title: The ups and downs of a politician
description: Just before the last Presidential campaign, my agent and I decided that I should write the book on George Corley Wallace. It was, we agreed, a singularly glorious concept, similar in import to the wheel, fire, Turns and the myriad uses of the magnificent juniper berry; but when the outline had made the traditional rounds, the silence from the great world of publishing was stunning. There's a basic problem, an editor mercifully explained. The Wallace book has already been done.

title: Robert Lee Pearlstein to Wed Amy Evans Porterfield in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Porterfield of. New Canaan, Conn., and Crystal Lake, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Evans Porterfield, to Robert Lee Pearlstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Pearlstein of St. Louis County, Mo.

title: Jean Carr Married to Ronald Shindler
description: Jean Therese Carr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Carr of South Orange, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald D. Shindler. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Thomas Cunningham in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Montclair, N. J.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater 5, 20

title: GARDENING
description: DURING the next two or three weeks, many new roses will be planted in gardens, in North and Central Jersey, two areas where the soil is especially suitable for them. Roses are wonderful plants for beginning gardeners, because they bloom gloriously the first year and, although they need careful attention, they are not difficult to care for. Their basic needs are sun, fertile soil and good drainage.

title: Double Edge Sword Romps
description: As a yearling, Aisquith Slable's Double Edge Sword brought only $10,500 at a horse auction. As a 4yearold, the colt was deemed so hopelessly crippled that his owners almost gave him away.

title: ExAtlantic City Mayor
description: AT 27, he was the president of a major bank in South Jersey. At 30, he became Atlantic City's youngest Mayor. And today, 34yearold Joseph F. Bradway Jr. is once again the president of the Guarantee Bank.

title: Remembrance of things past
description: Cleste Gineste was born in 1891 in Auxillac in the Lozre, a Department of the Languedoc in south central France, through which the mountainous spine of the land runsthe Cevennes. It is a remote, rather harsh part of France now; much more se in 1913, when Cleste married a Parisian taxi driver, Odilon Albaret, an occasional holiday visitor to her village. Not surprisingly, she found the great city of Paris alarming in the first months of her marriage. She lived a lonely life: not daring to go out of her apartment, waiting for her husband's return each day or night, for his job necessarily meant uncertain hours. Told like this, the story would seem to be an introduction to one of a hundred French novels, imitations of Zola or Daudet, black romantic epics of ambitious country people devouring the city and, in turn, devoured by it.

title: Firefighters' Elite: Rescue Squads
description: MIDNIGHT is only minutes away and a sleek ambulance  the light from its revolving red lamps bouncing off the affluent Dix Hills homesturns into a long driveway.

title: The Blessings of Plant Togetherness
description: Certain plant combination are favored by gardeners who claim that one plant grown in the vicinity of another is protected from insect damage. While these enthusiasts claim it really works! some gardeners who have attempted to duplicate these efforts may retort, but it doesn't work! Is there a scientific basis for insect control by means of plant companionships? If so, how does it work? And why does it sometimes fail?

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: REPRESENTATIVE Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of Great Neck, is beginning to suspect that if there is a national effort to cooperate with Mexico in trying to curb what he calls the LatinManhattan Trail of heroin traffic, it may well be draped in the Presidential colors and look like a Ford Administration initiative.

title: INVESTING
description: The bad news on the first quarter of 1976 will begin flowing out of the nation's banking community this week, just as Wall Street has turned bullish on bank stocks.

title: NAVY LAYS KEEL FOR TRIDENT SUB
description: GROTON, Conn. April 10The keel was laid today for the Ohio, the first of the giant ballisticmissile submarines of the Trident class that represent the first major improvement in the United States Nuclear arsenal in five years.

title: Screen: 'The Long Night,' About Harlem:Only U.S. Film in New Directors Series First Feature Made by Woodie King Jr.
description: "The Long Night," the only American film to be included in this year's generally undistinguished New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, displays more passion for positive thinking than it does for film making, which is what the priorities are when one is primarily concerned with issues.The film, the first feature to be directed by Woodie King Jr., a major producer on New York's black-theater scene, is an effort to present an accurate picture of Harlem life without exploiting drugs, violence, prostitution or photogenic poverty. It's about gallantry under stress, especially that of Steely Brown (W. Geoffrey King), a young teen-ager whose father, a Vietnam vet with a lot of pride and nowhere to put it, walks out on Steely's hard-pressed mother, the sort of woman who wants to survive by making as few waves as possible.In one exceedingly long night, Steely roams the streets of Harlem trying to scrape together the $27 he owes his mother and recallingin flashbacksthe events that led up to his father's disappearance. "The Long Night" gets high marks for the performance of young Mr. King, who has a winning, unaffected screen presence, and for its good thoughts about black identity and aspirations. As moviemaking it is mechanical and unexciting in almost every respect.The film is being shown at the museum today at 6 P.M. and again Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. It will be released commercially later this year by Mahler Films.Being shown at the museum today at 8:30 P.M. is another black film, this one about the exploitation of a poor, hard-working Senegalese farmer by the Marabouts, religious teachers who turn their pupils into professional beggars." The film, "Njangaan," directed by Mahama Johnson Traore, is of primary interest as a report on life from one emerging African nation. It will be shown again Tuesday at 6 P.M., the last day of the New Directors/New Films series sponsored by the museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center.The conclusion of this year's New DirectorsNew Films programthe fifth in the series sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art and the Lincoln Center Film Society  prompts some thoughts about the problems that arise when institutions commit themselves to such "annual" events. Of the 11 films in this year's program (the print of the 12th scheduled film never arrived), only three deserved the attention this sort of festival confers. Those three were the Greek "O Thiassos," the French "Vronique" and the Hungarian "Adoption."The rest of the films looked suspiciously like program fillers, choices made by the festival's sponsors to keep their annual event going even in a year when they either couldn't obtain new films of remarkable value or couldn't find any worth particular attention.The New Directors  New Films program last year presented at least three highly original works, and all the rest of the films, except two, were of special interest. The mediocrity of most of this year's selections had a way of diminishing the value of even the several worthy films. Conclusion: There may be some years when the festival sponsors should call the whole thing off.

title: World News Briefs
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sunday, April 11 (Reuters)Hundreds of people have been detained during the last 48 hours in what is being called the first: Laotian cultural revolution under the proCommunist Pathet Lao, informed sources said today.

title: Sounders Rate Some Credit For Seattle's Record Crowd
description: Soccer people don't want to hear about all the excuses for the 58,124 who paid to see a North American Soccer League exhibition in Seattle on Friday night. They don't want to hear that it was the first athletic event to be held at the Kingdome, the new $67 million domed stadium. And they don't want to hear that Pel attracted the largest crowd ever to watch a soccer game in this country.

title: If at First You Don't Succeed. . .
description: As a backyard gardener and professional photographer for 25 years, I'm somewhat smug In my attitude toward growing vegetables not only to eat but also to photograph, Despite my smugness, or maybe because of it, I've had many opportunities to learn that the art of gardening is one of constant learning. Just when you think you know it all, the onion plants rot, the broccoli flowers, the deer feast on the tomatoes and the rhubarb is a disaster.

title: Orioles' 5 in Eighth Beat Red Sox, 5 to 1
description: BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) Lee May drove in the goahead run as the Baltimore Orioles rallied for five runs in the eighth inning today and defeated the Boston. Red Sox, 51.

title: DINING OUT
description: SAPPORO was recommended as an authentic Japanese restaurant, presumably in contrast to the popular Japanese steak houses that offer a more limited or Americanized version of Japanese cooking. The menu at Sapporo does not particularly cater to American tastes, what with yudofu (bean curd and vegetables in broth) and sashimi (raw fish) yet many of the traditional Japanese dishes such as yakitori (grilled chicken) and tempura (batterfried foods) should appeal to anybody.

description: DALLAS. April 10  The final order in the fiveyearold Dallas school desegregation case, handed down by a Federal judge here, calls for the busing of 17.328 pupils and the division of the Dallas Independent School District into six subdistricts. It will be implemented when the fall term begins Aug. 23.

title: 'Virility' By Ponti Arrives
description: What is a self-respecting and supposedly modern-thinking Sicilian father to do when he knows that the only truthful way to still the townspeople who are calling his London-educated son a homosexual is to reveal that the young man has cuckolded him?That is the question at the wizened comic heart of "Virility," a Carlo Ponti film that opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse. It isn't that the idea isn't a reasonable updating and extension of the movies' long and occasionally hilarious exploration of the comedic potential of Italian mores.It's simply that "Virility" expends too much time reaching the point where it poses the problem and not enough inventiveness in exploiting the possible answers. Only one scene  of the father, Don Vito, disguised as his son, Roberto, attempting a rape while announcing his assumed identity  begins to hint at what might have been.The movie can boast sun-washed scenery that is escapist entertainment in itself; the attractions of Agostina Belli as Don Vito's young second wife, and a general air of polish that did not, unfortunately, spread far enough to impart the sparkle of inspiration to the script.

title: Link of Kennedy Friend To Mafia Is Still a Puzzle
description: The disclosure last December that President Kennedy and two major Mafia, figures maintained close friendships with the same woman  Judith Campbell  has puzzled many private citizens, disturbed some law enforcement officials and aroused extensive speculation in and out of Government.

title: Jackson Concedes Pennsylvania Allies Prefer Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington conceded today that many of the persons who are running in Pennsylvania a convention delegates committed to him would rather see ISenator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota win the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Yale Gets Wright Papers
description: NEW HAVEN, April 11 (AP)The Yale University library announced today that it had acquired the papers of Richard Wright, the black American author who wrote Native Son and Black Boy. The archive was donated by Mr. Wright's widow, Ellen Wright.

title: Payday for Reformed Playboy
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11  Once a playboy who practiced more with the Chicago Cubs than with his golf clubs, Raymond Floyd is tired of being a mediocre player. In winning the Masters by eight shots today at the Augusta National Golf Club, he tied the event's 72hole record of 271, set by Jack Nicklaus in 1965.

title: Colon Captures 10,000Meter Race
description: Tony Colon of the New York Athletic Club won a 10,000meter race, sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York, yesterday in Central Park.

title: Kate Benjamin Bride in Greenwich
description: Kate Benjamin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Benjamin of White Plains, was married yesterday to Arnold Spector, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Spector, also of White Plains.

title: An Ozark Gardener, 86, Awaits Coming of the Greening Season
description: HOGEYE, Ark., April 6  Spring is late in the Ozark Mountains this year. The oaks and the maples are only now risking a few pale green shoots, tentative little leaves that will not constitute much of a loss if another frost steals in some night on a villainous northwest breeze.

title: Brewers Still Steaming Despite Cold
description: MILWAUKEE, April 11There was no need to ask why the Yankees' game with Milwaukee was called off todaythe 30degree weather made it impractical, if not impossible, to play a baseball game.

title: GIARDINO REBUTS CRITICS OF CITY U.
description: Rejecting criticism that the City University has shirked its full budgetcutting responsibility, the chairman of the Board of Higher Education has urged Governor Carey and Mayor Beame to provide close to $100 million more to the university by withholding planned city cuts and increasing state aid in their next budgets.

title: Books of The Times
description: At 41, Willard Michaels has reached a kind of existential menopause. He is mired between youth and age, too young to give up all ambition and too old to break the comfortable habit of failure. His failure has a boyish charm: it does not threaten anybody except his wife, Elena, who sees herself condemned to a lifetime of his self deprecating ironies. As far as she is concerned, irony is a male perversion, an eternal seminar on the vanity of human wishes. She doesn't find it gallant, as Michaels seems to. Very sensibly, she throws him out. Nothing ages a woman's face faster than a wise, understanding smile. Also, Elena is oldfashioned: failure is not an aphrodisiac for her. but the reverse. And she certainly does not want to mother Michaels: he is much too unpromising a child.

title: Medich, the Doc, Aids Stricken Fan
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP)Doc Medich, the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher leaped into the stands during pregame practice today and tried to save the life of a fan who had apparently suffered a heart attack.

title: CHINA AID IS CALLED CABINETLEVEL TOPIC
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (Reuters)Former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger disclosed today that there had been speculation among Cabinetlevel officials in recent years about providing China with military aid as a way of blunting the Soviet threat.

title: ITALY INVESTIGATES BP AND SHELL GROUP
description: LONDON, April 11 (AP)The British Petroleum Company, twothirds owned by the British Government, and Royal (British Group are under official investigation in Italy in connection wth reported payments to Italian political parties in the early 1970's, British newspapers reported today.

title: Czechslonvak Congress Will Stress Ties to Moscow
description: PRAGUE, April 11Communist Party hardliners here have prepared a weeklong demonstration of strict Czechoslovak fealty to Moscow, and this ancient city was bedecked today with millions of Soviet and Czechoslovak flags hanging from nearly every window.

description: ALBERSJosef on March 25, 1976, husband of Anni Fleischmann Albers, brother of Lena van Bommel. Memorial service on Friday, April 23d, at 2 P.M., in the Art Gallery Lecture Hall, Yale University, New Haven CT Entrance via Weir Courtyard, near 56 High St.

description: BREITBRUNN, West. Germany, April 11 (AP)Enrico Mainardi, cellist and composer, died early today in a Munich clinic. He was 78 years old.

title: Way of Life of Old People Curbed by Fear of Crime
description: CHICAGO, April 11Silverhaired and handsome at age 80, Eugene Hocker can now look back and laugh without bitterness to three years ago when he was beaten and robbed half a block from home.

description: ALBANY, April 11The state of war that now exists between Governor Carey and the Democraticcontrolled Assembly is a source of growing concern to people on both sides of the front who, even as they seek to explain it, agree that the fighting is likely to get worse, before it subsides.

description: Gladys Roth, a field representative for the United Federation of Teachers, and Jack Yourman, director of the College Skills Center were married yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Harold Spivack at the bridegroom's home in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Spinola Arrives in Rio

General Spinola made no statement on arrival. He Is forbidden by Brazilian law to engage in political activities here.

description: Parishioners from eight Upper West Side churches gathered outdoors for an ecumenical blessing of palms yesterday morning as Roman Catholics and Protestants observed Palm Sundaythe first day of Holy Week, which commemorates the final events in the life of Christ before His Resurrection.

title: After Worrisome Week for the Carter Campaign, a Key Test Looms in Pennsylvania

Rival Democrats, left gasping for two months by Mr. Carter's spectacular advances, were suddenly breathing easier and wondering if the Carter balloon had not lost some altitude before the difficult test in Pennsylvania on April 27.

description: Tomorrow afternoon, the Centerreach Fire District on Long Island is scheduled to sell $3 million of bonds, and a week later the Chappaqua School District in Westchester County is slated to sell $5,235,000 of bonds. Despite the problems that some New York State localities have had in borrowing in recent months, Centereach and Chappaqua almost certainly will breeze through their bond sales.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.It is now more than eleven years since China exploded its first nuclear device. The almost universal alarm evident a decade ago is now rarely heard, and properly so.

Solomon's victory kept alive his slim hopes of gaining the W.C.T.

description: LONGPORT, April 11 (AP)A Philadelphia youth drowned and two other youths were injured early yesterday morning when their car plunged into the Atlantic Ocean, the police in this shore community reported.

description: Highlevel negotiations to find an acceptable, schoolfinancing alternative to the one proposed in the controversial Stavisky bill have reportedly produced a plan to free an extra $30 million a year for in struction by abolishing the city school system's hotlunch program.

title: Bridge:

A few months ago he stepped into Gallo in Mascherai for the indisposed Barry Morell, and at Saturday's matinee, Mr. Raitzin once again replaced the American tenor, this time as Enzo, in La Gioconda.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two teenage brothers were killed in Plainfield when fire destroyed a twostory building where they lived, the police said. The victims were identified as Lorenzo Polard, 18 years old, and his brother, Ronnie, 13. According to authorities, who said they were investigating the cause of the fire, six other occupants of the dwelling were not at home when the blaze occurred.

title: Floyd Closes With 70 and Captures as 8 Strokes on 271
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11  Raymond Floyd swept through the Masters today and won by eight strokes in one of the biggest runaways in the 40year history of the tournament.

title: Only Proven Winners Need Apply
description: Ted Turner, the new owner of the Atlanta Braves, is a fiercely competitive millionaire with a wet and salty bottom who buys yachts the way baseball fans buy hot dogs. American Eagle, Vamp X, Lightnin', Mariner, Tenacious, Stinger  the names of his boats are a bluewater litany, and most of them have been winners. He believes in buying boats that are already proven winners ana he sails them hard, screaming invective at his crew in a cornpone falsetto that would earn him a punch in the mouth from normal men, which, of course, excludes ocean racers. Some have sailed with Turner so long they don't even hear his abuse. Andy Messersmith is a proven winner who was for sale. It followed that the first club to bid for him would be the Braves and that they would keep on bidding until they got him. Even before Messersmith was free to listen to offers, Turner was camped on the pitcher's doorstep in Newport Beach, Calif. At that time the training camps were padlocked and clubowners were threatening to call off the season, so it looked as though Turner was trying to hire Messersmith to crank a winch. However, the report of baseball's death turned out to be premature, so Andy will work for Ted on the mound rather than the foredeck.

title: Washington a City They Hate to Love
description: WASHINGTON, April 11It was a typical Capitol Hill scene. A delegation from home was in to see Representative Larry H. Pressler the other day. Flinty, rural looking people, the kind of rockribbed conservetives likely to cite big goverment and government spending as top national problems.

description: DETROIT, April 11Jimmy Carter went home to the family farm in Georgia last night to rest and regroup after what was probably the most unnerving and difficult week in his threeyear quest for the Presidency.

description: BRISTOL, Vt., April 11The yearlong struggle of a small group of landowners here to free themselves from Federal restrictions on their land ended successfully last week when Congress passed a bill that excludes 14 homes and 2,500 acres of private land from the Bristol Cliff National Wilderness Area.

description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 11He made himself a candidate for President without a press release, A speech or a television appearance. Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. let his intention slip out last month in the course of a rambling conversation. When I saw him last week I asked him why he had done it, as it seemed, so casually.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Vandals broke stainedglass windows at Temple Beth El in Rockaway Park, Queens, late Saturday night, causing damage of $2,500 to $3,000. This is the third time in three weeks, said an official of the congregation. We do not think the motivation is antiSemitic because there's been vandalism in nearby churches as well. Temple Beth El, at Rockaway Beach Boulevard and 121st Street, has a congregation of 600.

title: Housing Abandonment Spreads In Bronx and Parts of Brooklyn
description: Housing abandonment, which in the last decade has brought tens of thousands of New York City apartments to ruin, is continuing to ravage slum areas and, in two areas of the central Bronx, is spreading into additional neighborhoods.

title: Marvin E. Holderness Jr., An Official at Doremus, 54
description: Marvin E Holderness Jr., a senior vice president of Doremus & Company, the advertising agency, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 505 East 79th Street.

description: CHIANG SAEN, ThailandEach morning, as he has for the last five months, Chao Sarn rises at dawn, pads across the dirt floor of his strawthatched hut and out the door, feeds his two black piglets rooting in a small puddle, then sits down, smokes his water pipe and waits for the sun to set.

title: Advertising
description: Pan American World Airways loves travel agents. It should, since they are responsible for booking twothirds of its passenger business.

title: Singaporean to Visit China
description: SINGAPORE, April 11 (Reuters)Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew will lead a goodwill mission to China next month, it was announced here.

title: MEDIATION IS URGED FOR COAST TRANSIT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 (UPI)Union negotiators, reporting an impasse in talks, called tonight for Federal mediation in an effort to end a 12day city employee strike that has paralyzed public transportation.

title: Hal, a Bulldog, Takes Best in Montreal Show
description: MONTREAL, April 11A homebred bulldog called Hal, won the biggest victory of his career tonight in the Place Bonaventure, when he was named the best at the 86th show of the United Kennel Club.

title: Deaths
description: ALLARDYCEDonald Morrison, at Pough keepsle, April, 1976, husband of Margaret Middleditch Allardyce and father of Donald, Robert and Fred Allardyce. Funeral services at the Schoonmaker Chapel, April 12, 1916, at 11 A.M. Interment will be at the convenience or the family.

title: 'Sailor Who Fell,' a Film After Mishima:The Cast
description: The blurred and preposterous foreground of "The Sailor Who Fell From Grace With the Sea" is the activity of a band of Nietszche-besotted children straight out of "Lord of the Flies." The limpid and beautifully filmed background is the love story of the mother of one of them and a merchant marine officer. The film's climax is the bloody clash between the two stories, a climax that should be tragic but is simply grotesque and unbelievable.When the main action of a movie is so weak and the background is so strong, a peculiar focus develops. There is a beguilement to "Sailor," which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theaterthat of sitting through a movie in a state of irascible unconvincedness while being more than half seduced."Sailor" is a radical transplant of a short story by the Japanese writer Yukio Mishima, a writer who gathered around himself a kind of heroic cult and who killed himself to protest the softness of the times, Lewis John Carlino moved it from Yokohama to Dartmouth, a Devon port.With the inspired work of his director of photography, Douglas Slocombe, the transposition is an atmospheric triumph. The sweet but somber English coast, its lowering skies and transforming bursts of sunshine, the clean presence of the sea, the white seaside house where the widowed mother lives and into which the sailor comesall these develop a powerful emotional background for their relationship.It is a relationship that manages to be romantic and erotic. Sarah Miles is spectacular; she makes sensual yearning convincing both in itself and as standing for the whole range of human want. Kris Kristofferson, as the American sailor who gives up the sea to marry her, looks good but doesn't convey much more than puzzled weakness.But then there is the main story. The widow's 13-year old son, Jonathan, is one of a clique of six boys led by a precocious, mad towhead who has tailored the cult of the superman down into short pants. The boys sit out beside the sea while the chief lectures them on the merciless nobility of the amoeba. They draw up bills of accusation against adults. They sentence a cat to death for being old and fat; they drug it and dissect it alive. Jonathan is ambiguous about his mother's sailor, but the chief concludes that by leaving the sea the sailor has become like the fat cat and deserves the same fate. So the boys go to work on it.Mishima's implacable mouse-gang had a certain abstract grandness. These round-faced English boys smoking cigars and spouting phrases too large for their mouths simply looked silly. Part of the trouble is the writing; Mishima transposed by Mr. Carlino is not capable, as William Golding or Richard Hughes are, of projecting the local English boy into a primeval childhood.Furthermore, Mr. Carlino, for all his skill with the adults and the atmosphere, seems to have no idea how to direct children. Their murderous games never convey horror; they get no further than embarrassment.

title: Europe's Leaders Take a Gloomy View of U.S. Role
description: PARIS, April 11  Western Europe's leaders have settled into a state of gloom in the belief that the United States is retrenching in world affairs, a mood deepened by their own inability to act together.

title: STAFF INFORMERS OFFERED REWARD
description: Some 10,000 of the nation's most highly placed secretaries will receive letters today or tomorrow offering each of them a $25,000 cash reward for information implicating chief executive officers of major industrial companies in criminal activity relating to corporate operations.

title: Reds Sweep Astros, 93; Red Sox, Pirates Triumph
description: CINCINNATI, April 11 (AP)  Pat Darcy extended the major league's longest winning pitching streak to 10 and Pete Rose became the National League's leader in career hits among active players as the Cincinnati Reds defeated Houston, 93, today for a sweep of the threegame series.

title: Martial Artists Stage a Few HoldsBarred Show
description: From the moment Rico Mercado broke a oneinch board by spitting at it, the martialarts crowd at the Felt Forum was in a heightened state of awareness yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Students Walk 10 Miles to Raise Funds for Families of Imprisoned Soviet Jews
description: The Israelite exodus from Egypt was given a modern interpretation yesterday in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Four youngsters dressed in black and white striped prison uniforms led students in the third annual 10  mile Passover walkathon for Soviet Jewry.

title: Udall Names Campaign Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)  Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona announced today that Angelo Geocaris, a Chicago lawyer, would serve as the deputy manager of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Geocaris was the Illinois state chairman in the 1972 Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.

title: PAUL REWALD
description: Paul Rewald, a vice president. of Sotheby Parke Bernet and head of its Impressionist and postImpressionist painting section, died early Saturday of cancer at his home, 115 East 92d Street. He was 32 years old.

title: PROVINCIAL RALLIES ASSAIL TENG IN CHINA
description: TOKYO, April 11 (AP)Peking broadcasts, monitored here today, said that China's army had vowed to deal resolute blows to supporters of ousted Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping, as mass rallies condemning him, some drawing more than 300,000 people, spread to five Chinese provinces.

title: Conferees to Press for a Campaign Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Money that organized labor spends to promote political candidates among union members would be reported publicly for the first time under the compromise campaign bill being drafted by Senate and House conferees.

title: BLACK MAYORS ASK ENERGY STAMPS
description: ATLANTA, April 11  The Southern Conference of Black Mayors urged today the creation of a system of energy stamps to assist the nation's poor in paying for the increased costs of fuel, electricity and gasoline in the same way that the foodsstamp program assists in food purchases.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 11(Reuters)  The police arrested 38 black Africans here today after clashes between supporters of rival factions of the African National Council.

title: Bobby Riggs's Son, 22, Found Dead in L.I. Room
description: James Riggs, 22yearold son of the former tennis champion Bobby Riggs, was found dead Saturday in a rented room in Manor Haven, L.I.

description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 11 The New York Nets, who were pure gold in their first playoff appearance against. the San Antonio Spurs, found themselves transmuted to lead this afternoon in the second game of the fourofsevengame semifinal.

title: Half a Million Cambodians Reported Dead Since Purge
description: Half a million Cambodians have perished since the Communists seized power a year ago, Time magazine reports in its current issue.

title: Volunteers Are Helping Families to Flee Flood
description: MINOT, N.D., April 11 (AP)Hundreds of volunteer workers joined National Guard troops today as efforts continued to evacuate this floodthreatened town.

title: The Status of This Year's Democratic Convention Is More Quo Than Quota
description: The George McGovern revolution in the Democratic Party four years ago is obviously ebbing. A major characteristic of the 1972 Democratic National Convention was its heavy representation for the first time of women, minorities and youths and its light representation of cigarchewing middleaged men.

title: NEW YORK INSURERS OPPOSE STATE TAX
description: A spokesman for the lifeinsurance industry in New York said yesterday that the industry would strongly resist a reported proposal by Governor Carey's Economic Development Board to impose a sales tax on insurance premiums in addition to those already being imposed.

description: LACROSSE

title: Magazines'Ad Revenues Growing
description: A 1976 smile has replaced a 1975 frown on the face of Stephen E. Kelly, president of the Magazine Publishers Association. What strange force had the power to create this mood change? Advertising increases, of course.

title: New Federalism
description: Drawing on information collected in a study of twentysix southern cities, the Southern Regional Council has painted a depressing picture of the initial impact of the Nixon Administration's New Federalism on urban America.

title: Music: Alicia de Larrocha in Recital
description: Carmen may be responsible. Or Chaminade's Scarf Dance. Or flamenco guitarists. Whatever the reason, the impression seems to be indelibly stamped on the nonSpanish public that Spanish music is all hotblooded, extroverted stuff best played, if not sung, with a rose in the teeth. But, In fact, a deep strain of almost chilly austerity runs through much Iberian music, and Alicia de Larrocha took pains to point that out in her piano recital yesterday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: David Pincus Marries Ronnie Lynn Halpern
description: The marriage of Ronnie Lynn Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Halpern of West Caldwell, N.J., to David Ira Pincus took place at the Manor in West Orange, N.J., yesterday morning. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Pincus of Brooklyn. Rabbi Morris Werb performed the ceremony.

title: HELLER URGES RISE IN FORD'S BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Walter W. Heller, the economist, said today that President Ford's budget would hit the economy with a sickening thud unless it was revised by Congress.

title: Addenda

description: MIAMI, April 11 (UPI)The Coast Guard has suspended its search for three men missing from a disabled yacht that sank Friday while a Soviet freighter was attempting to take her into tow. Two other men listed as missing in the same incident were found yesterday to be alive and well.

title: Voters in West Bank Elect Councils Today
description: RAMALLAH, Israelioccupied West Bank, April 11 (Reuters)Campaigning for local elections in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River ended in a carnival atmosphere today, with radical candidates confident of winning many seats in the voting tomorrow.
