description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, April 12Lebanese leftists last night decided to extend a shaky armed truce until the end of this month to permit the election of a new president, and urged the withdrawal of Syriart troops from the country.

title: Peoples' Symphony Celebrates 75 Years With a Gala
description: Three hours before concert time they are already lining up, and because the tickets are unreserved, the line at 7 P.M. when the doors open, snakes around the wooden pillars of the cavernous lobby of Washington Irving High School, of Gramercy Park.

title: Bardin to Seek Federal Inquiry Of Uneven CleanAir Regulation
description: TRENTON, April 11 (UPI)The State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, David J. Bardin, is planning to ask Congress to investigate Federal practices that he says impose unfairly stringent air pollution regulations on the Garden State.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: The name scrod always strikes our ears with a comic ring, and there have been elements of humor in some of the correspondence to reach our desk after we printed our own explanation of the difference between cod and scrod.

title: Residents Helping to Spend State Out of 3Year Recession
description: TRENTON  New Jersey residents may be spending the state at least part way out of the economic recession of the last three years.

title: SAUDI AIDES WARN ON ARAB BOYCOTT
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, April 7 Two Cabinet ministers declared recently that Saudi Arabia would simply switch to other trading partners if the United States took measures against the Arab boycott of Israel that curtailed United States business dealings with Saudi Arabia.

title: Way of Life of Old People Curbed by Fear of Crime
description: CHICAGO, April 11Silverhaired and handsome at age 80, Eugene Hocker can now look back and laugh without bitterness to three years ago when he was beaten and robbed half a block from home.

title: ExCypriot Chief Awaits Trial But Is Unable to Find a Lawyer
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 11Nikos Giorgiades Sampson, who was president of Cyprus for eight days in 1974, sits in a Nicosia, jail today, facing charges of insurrection and unable to find a lawyer to defend him.

title: Michael F. Gagliano Dies; ExCriminal Court Judge, 74
description: Michael F. Gagliano, who retired last year as a Criminals Court judge after having served on the bench since 1964, died Saturday in. Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 74 years old and lived at 527 Humbold Street in Brooklyn.

title: Pearson Takes Rebel 500
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., April 11 (AP)  David Pearson came from behind to win today's 20th annual Rebel 500, a destruction derby that might have ended on a tragic note, but for a heroic act by Dale Inman.

title: Jane Phillips Wed
description: Jane Gillman Phillips, daughter of Mrs. Bernard Phillips of New York and the late Mr. Phillips, and Dr. David M. Novick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Novick of White Plains, were married yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Temple Israel Center in White Plains. The bride is a senior at Barnard College. Dr. Novick, a resident physician at Beth Israel Hopital graduated from Duke University and the Downstate Medical Center.

title: PAYMENTS UP 21.4% TO NEEDY FAMILIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)The nation's family welfare expenditures increased by 21.4 percent last year, partly because of the growing ranks of jobless fathers, the Government said today.

title: REAGAN STILL SAYS HE CAN BEAT FORD
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11Beleaguered by campaign financing troubles and trailing far behind President Ford in the delegate count after eight primary battles, Ronald Reagan still talks confidently about winning the Republican nomination for President.

title: New York State Will Compare Nuclear and FossilFuel Costs
description: New York State is going to try to settle the controversy between environmentalists and the electricutility industry over whether electrical power generated by nuclear plants is cheaper than that produced by fossilfueled facilities.

title: Proliferation of Prostitution Creates New Kind of Politics
description: The steady growth of prostitution in the city and its rapid spread into liberal communities have created a new kind of politics that Dias forced many legislators to reappraise their attitudes to meet the changing sentiment in their constituencies.

title: CUNNINGHAM AIMS TO KEEP RECORDS FROM GRAND JURY
description: For the last several months, Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, has [fought in closeddoor legal proceedings to dismiss several subpoenas for his personal and business records requested by a special grand jury investigating the possible sale of judgeships in the Bronx.

title: DANCE SERIES BEGUN BY ROBERT WHITMAN
description: Robert Whitman's dance retrospective at the Dia Art Foundation studio, 589 Washington Street, will cover the last decade and a half during the next five weeeknds and is an important series. It shows the turbulence of the innovative 1960's and Mr. Whitman's continued progress in his individual path. The first program, consisting of Prune Flat and Salad P.N., was performed Saturday evening.

title: Wind Blows Out Panes From Midtown Building
description: Several panes of glass were blown from One Penn Plaza, the skyscraper atop Pennsylvania Station, shortly after 7 o'clock last night, showering glass on the street below, the police reported.

title: Mrs. Rosenblatt Wed To Alfred B. Orlin
description: Fredda Rosenblatt of Forest Hills, Queens, widow of Edward A. Rosenblatt, was married yesterday to Alfred E. Orlin of Jamaica Estates, Queens, president and chief executive officer of the Guardian Commercial Corporation of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Redford Now a Hollywood Hyphenate
description: So intense is Robert Redford's involvement with All the President's Men, in which he and Dustin Hoffman costar as Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, that occasionally he forgets himself. In an interview last week, he said, A scene that Bernstein and I had.... He quickly corrected himself A scene that Dustin and I had....

title: Sadat Extends Vienna Stay
description: VIENNA, April 11 (Reuters) President Anwar elSadat of Egypt decided today to extend his private visit here to hold further talks with Chancellor Bruno Kreisky.

title: Hijackers, 71 Hours in Bangkok, Leave in a Bigger Filipino Jet
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, April 12 (AP)Three armed Filipinos holding 10 hostages, eight of them new, flew out of Bangkok aboard a Philippine Air Lines DC8 jetliner this morning and officials said they were headed for Libya with a probable stopover on the way.

title: Sabres Beat Islanders, 53, for 10 Lead
description: BUFFALO, April 11  The New York Islanders offered little resistance to the Buffalo Sabres and the French Connection tonight in losing the opening game of their National Hockey League playoff quarterfinal series, 53.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 11The State Senate convenes tomorrow to clear its calendar of some noncontroversial bills in preparation for the PassoverEaster recess and for the upcoming debate on budget and tax matters.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: POOR LANDS RAISE I.M.F. BORROWING
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The less developed countries are borrowing record sums from the International Monetary Fund following a littlenoticed liberalization at the end of last year in the fund's compensatory financing facility.

title: Vermont Bloc Wins Exclusion of Land From a Wilderness
description: BRISTOL, Vt., April 11The yearlong struggle of a small group of landowners here to free themselves from Federal restrictions on their land ended successfully last week when Congress passed a bill that excludes 14 homes and 2,500 acres of private land from the Bristol Cliff National Wilderness Area.

title: Messersmith Willing to Pitch Rest of Career With Braves
description: MILWAUKEE, April 11Andy Messersmith, who nearly became a New York Yankee, was on the verge of becoming a San Diego Padre and then a California Angel before he finally became an Atlanta Brave.

title: PROBILEM UNSOLVED BY RUFUS SOUL BAND
description: Rufus, the progressive soul hand that features Chaka Khan as vocalist, faced high expectations at the Felt Forum on Saturday night. Two opening acts were allotted only 20 munutes each, despite the crowd's frenzied reaction to Brass Construction Rufus was up against a restless audience that had paid and waited without hearing much music.

title: U.S. Sees Thrust Into Lebanon As a Pressure Tactic by Syria
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Ford Administration believes that Syria's intention in sending armored units into the eastern Lebanese border region is primarily a show of force to compel Lebanese politicians to resolve their differences, a highranking United States official said today.

title: East Europe Debate
description: Ever since Soviet tanks crushed the tragic Hungarian uprising of 1956, when American inaction exposed the hollowness of talk about rolling back the iron curtain, United States policy toward Eastern Europe has neither varied significantly nor been seriously criticized at home. It has favored increased autonomy and internal freedom for the Soviet satellites, while cautiously avoiding encouragement to rebellion or other challenges to Moscow's predominance that might provoke armed Soviet intervention.

title: TV: Funny, Insightful Cakes and Ale
description: In Cakes and Ale, the current import on public television's Masterpiece Theater, the second wife of a recently deceased great man of British letters commissions an official biography of her husband. She's especially anxious to minimize the role of his first wife, Rosie Gann, an uninhibited barmaid, who eventually ran off to America with another man. The problem is that the great man was totally in love with Rosie and wrote his best works during the years he had with her

title: Book Calls Montgomery Vain, Unimaginative
description: LONDON, April 11 (AP)Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery was brave, clever and industrious, but vain, singleminded, unimaginative and often brutally inconsiderate, according to a new biography.

title: PRINTERS BACK CUTS ATWASHINGTONSTAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)  The 272man printers union at The Washington Star voted today to accept a proposal to eliminate 100 jobs through resignation or early retirement for men between 57 and 62, a meat, men between 57 and 62, a measure that the publisher, Joe L. Allbritton, says is necessary for the paper to survive.

title: A Transit Mistake...
description: San Franciscans, standing fast against coercion by striking transit workers and other embattled municipal employees, freely acknowledge that the specter inspiring their resistance is the fiscal plight of New York City.

title: WOOD'S SUCCESSOR IS NAMED BY CBS
description: CBS announced yesterday that Robert J. Wussler, a 39yearold executive who has spent most of his career in the news division, has been named president of the CBS television network.

title: Exploration for Oil Begins Off the New England Coast
description: DAVISVILLE, R.I., April 10  Exploration for oil off the New England coast has begun.

title: DRUM SOLOS PLAYED BY PHILLY JOE JONES
description: Philly Joe Jones, the exceptionally gifted modern jazz drummer who was closely associated with Miles Davis during the 1950's, made his first major New York appearance in several years Saturday evening as featured soloist with the Collective Black Artists' big band.

title: Federal Power Commission Decides to Open Some Meetings to Public and Issue Agendas in Advance
description: WASHINGTON, April 11one eye on sunshine bills in Congress, the Federal Power Commission has decided ??o open some of its meetings to the public.

title: Dance Marathon Nets $40,000 in Cancer Aid
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 11More than $40,000 was raised this weekend for the American Cancer Society as 56 Rutgers University couples danced themselves into exhaustion in a marathon at the Rutgers gymnasium here.

title: Grossinger's Strike Is Voted for Today As Tasks Break Of
description: LIBERTY, N.Y., April 11Grossinger's unionized employees voted today to go on strike tomorrow morning, two days before the major Catskill resort expected a heavy influx of guests for the weeklong Passover observance.

title: RALPH W. VERNEY.
description: Ralph W. Verney, director of labor relations for the General Foods Corporation from 1942, to 1966, died Friday at his. home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 72 years old and had lived in Rowayton, Conn., before retiring.

title: REAGAN STILL SAYS HE CAN BEAT FORD
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11Beleaguered by campaign financing troubles and trailing far behind President Ford in the delegate count after eight primary battles, Ronald Reagan still talks confidently about winning the Republican nomination for President.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Spanish Policeman Slain
description: BILBAO, Spain, April 11 (AP) A 41yearold Civil Guard was electrocuted today when he tried to haul down a Basque I separatist flag from a utility pole supporting high tension wires, the authorities said. The guard died in a hospital at Baracaldo, a suburb of Bilbao.

title: C.C.N.Y.'s Filthy Five Relive Vile 1956 Deed
description: The Filthy Five relived the misadventures of Millie the Madam and their own interrupted academic careers the other night, and amid the conviviality they even managed to produce a couple of postscripts to the longago story.

title: NO ISRAEL ACTION IN LEBANON SEEN
description: TEL AVIV, April 11  The Israeli Cabinet today discussed the entry of some Syrian military units into Lebanon, but officials said reports indicated that no Israeli involvement was warranted.

title: Stockholder Proposals Multiply
description: At last year's annual meeting of the General Electric Company, shareholders who gathered in Boston's Statler Hilton Hotel were presented with only two stockholder proposalsone involving weapons contracts and the other concerning transfer of voting rights.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The idea behind the striking bracelets, collars and earrings that Dionne Cole designs is to give the effect of gold and silver at a fraction of the cost. To this end brass and German silver (a coppernickelzinc alloy) are substituted for precious metals.

title: Miss Farrell Sings With Philharmonic
description: Eileen Farrell has been sing ing professionally for more than 35 years, but she still has a lot of voice left. Appearing with the New York Philharmonic at Fisher Hall on Saturday night, the durable soprano sang the Immolation scene from Wagner's Gtitterciammerung with a robust tone that projected easily over the heavy orchestration and was at the same time lustrous and expressive in its own right. Her interpretation was not the most compelling imaginable, but it certainly respectable.

title: Laos Begins an Attack on Depravity
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 11 (Reuters)  The new Commufist government of Laos has reportedly arrested hundreds of people in the last 48 hours in a cultural revolution intended to root out reactionaries and the depraved Western way of life.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11The second event of the new regime of the San Francisco Giants was an ItalianAmerican Baseball Day, at which Joe DiMaggio was formally honored for the first time by his native city today.

title: HARRY C. SCHMIDT
description: Harry C. Schmidt, former vice president of, traffic for the Erie Lackawanna Railroad died Saturday in Pondville Hospital, Norfolk, Mass. He was 71 years old and lived in South Yarmouth, Mass., since his retirernent in 1969.

title: Physician Weds Lisa Brothers, Medical Student
description: Lisa Robin Brothers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Brothers of Fort Lee, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Amir Israel Arbisser, son of. Mr. and Mrs. Rafael Arbisser of Houston.

title: Tardif Is Hurt in Brawl
description: QUEBEC, April 11 (UPI) A benchclearing brawl broke out in the first period of the World Hockey Association semifinal playoff game between the Quebec Nordiques and Calgary Cowboys tonight. Nearly two dozen policemen came on the ice to restore order, but Marc Tardif was knocked unconscious and taken to a hospital.

title: Floyd Wins Masters
description: Raymond Floyd shot a 70 yesterday at the Augusta National Golf Club to win the 40th Masters tournament with a 72hole total of 271, 17 under par and matching the record for the event set by Jack Nicklaus in 1965. Details and Floyd profile are on pages 39 and 42.

title: Carol Bollag Bride Of David Sidman
description: Carol Susan Bollag, a teacher of neurologically impaired children in East Hanover. N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to David Alan Sidman, senior assistant administrator at Chilton Memorial Hospital in Pompton Plains, N. J. Rabbi Norman Patz performed the ceremony at the New York Hilton.

title: Easter Finery Parade Slow
description: Although a full week remained in the Easter season, clearance sales of Easter clothing were already under way in New York last week.

title: Aleksandr V. Georgiyev, 63, Key Communist Party Aide
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (UPI)Aleksandr V. Georgiyev, first secretary of the Communist Party for the Altai Krai, a region of southwestern Siberia that he was credited with making rich in grain, died suddenly. Pravda, the party newspaper, announced today. He was 63 years old.

title: BODY IDENTIFIED IN CHICAGO MIXUP
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (UPI)The man who falsely identified a corpse found floating in the Chicago River as a missing stockbroker may have been the stockbroker himself who had some large insurance policies,Police Comdr. Joseph Dileonardi said today.

title: Leafs
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP)  The line of Clarke, Reggie Leach and Bill Barber scored two goals and had four assists as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 41, tonight in the opening game of a fourofseven game Stanley Cup quarterfinal series.

title: CallawayFairnessAppeal Halts Hearing in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) A Senate subcommittee recessed its hearings today on Howard H. Callaway's alleged efforts to win Forest Service approval to expand his Colorado ski resort after the former Army Secretary protested he was being treated unfairly.

title: Tough Academic Regime Blamed by Some Cadets
description: WEST POINT, April 12The cadets at the United States Military Academy who were willing to talk today seemed to blame academic pressures for the cheating scandal that may become the worst in West Point's 174year history.

description: BOSTON, April 12 (AP)The murder trial of Susan Saxe, accused in the slaying of a Bostom policeman killed (luring a hank robbery six years ago. wil begin on May 17, a judgo ruled today.

title: BUSH ASSERTS C.I.A HURT BY REPORTS
description: George Bush, the Director of Central Intelligence, said last night that some foreign intelligencegathering agencies with which the C.I.A. had been collaborating were holding backand that some undercover agents were dropping out as a result of recent exposures.

description: ALBANY, April 12The Assembly today killed, at least temporarily, the Carey adminisrat on bill that would have glowed savings banks to offer flecking accounts, after an unisual combination of conscna, lye Republicans and liberal Democrats joined forces to pass m amendment that insured the )ill's defeat in the Senate.

description: LISBON, April 12 (AP)  A Cuban Army officer stowed away on a flight from Angola today and then forced the plane's crew at gunpoint to fly him to Portugal, where he for political asylum, officials reported.

Humphrey, who has said that he would be available for his party's Presidential nomination at the national convention in New York this summer.

title: Back at the Manse
description: A governess arrives at a sinister manse. It feels like the nineteenth century, not only because there are sinister manses all over the countryside, but also because the governess's bosom is heaving. There is also a lot of embonpoint, not to mention a fierce brooding laird striding the grim battlements, a pack of ravenous mastiffs and a suspicious excess of adjectives

title: Concert: Judith Blegen
description: Judith Blegen may be as prodigally talented a young soprano as you could find in a census of the presentday opera population. She does everything so well, in fact, that she often overdoes, like a cook adding just one more spice or herb to a recipe and wiping out a carefully cultivated taste.

title: Westinghouse and I.B.M. Profits Rise
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a 43 percent increase in firstquarter profits, reflecting signs of continued recovery from its business problems of several vears hark

title: CITIBANK IMPOSES CREDIT CARD FEE
description: First National City Master Charge will impose a 50cent fee next month on cardholders who pay their monthly balances before incurring an interest charge, Citibank announced yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) The General Accounting Of. Fice said today it was satisfied that Robert E. Hampton, chairman of the Civil Service Com. mission, was unaware he \do. lated his commission's own rule on conflict of interest by visit. ing a Maryland hunting lodge owned by the Rockwell Corporation.

title: Stocks on Amex and Counter Show Drops in Slow Trading
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished lower yesterday in sluggish trading. Analysts noted that there was little economic news to firm the market.

title: Cypriot Police Repulse Greeks Protesting U.S. Arms to Turkey
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 12 (AP)Hundreds of riot policemen repulsed 2,000 to 3,000 Greek Cypriot demonstrators trying to rush the United States Embassy here today to protest planned American military aid to Turkey.

title: BRITAIN WEIGHING SHELL, BP INQUIRY

title: Nuptials in a Doll House
description: Two toy designers were wed last night in the redshingled doll house in the F.A.O. Schwarz toy store on Fifth Avenue where they met on Christmas Eve five years ago. They had noticed smoke coming from a secondfloor window and summoned help.

description: Bands from Preservation Hall in New Orleans are supposed to represent the most archaic jazz styles, but more recent influences have penetrated the aggregation that appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday, and with salutary effect.

title: Protesters Ejected At 2 City Colleges; Police Arrest 64

title: Philippine New Society
description: President Marcos of the Philippines insisted in his book Notes on the New Society that martial law, the device that enabled him to impose oneman rule, is only a temporary expedient and that we cannot make of this a permanent institution in our national life. But three and a half years later, Mr. Marcos appears determined not only to perpetuate his regime but to name as his successor his wife, Imelda, undiscouraged by the Peron experience in Argentina.

title: Tough Academic Regime Blamed by Some Cadets

title: Kansas Wheat Growers Cut Back Crop Forecast
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., April 12 (AP)The Kansas Association of Wheat Growers has cut back to 235 million bushels its forecast of the state's 1976 winter wheat crop. The growers blamed continuing dry weather over much of its wheatgrowing area.

title: FUTURES IN COCOA CONTINUE TO RISE
description: The strong uptrend in cocoa futures prices continued yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, where the May delivery jumped the 2centsapound limit to close at 76.20 cents a pound.

description: Southern rock lives with a vengeance if Sunday night's, concert at the Beacon Theater, the second of two by Lynyr; Skynyrd and the Outlaws, is any indication. Rebel yells from native New Yorkers can sometimes sound a little incongruous, but the audience enthusiasm by the end of both bands sets was really something to see.

title: Cocoa Futures Up

title: Memory and Amnesty
description: By declining to review his courtmartial conviction and thus allowing him to go virtually free under vague conditions of Army parole, the United States Supreme Court has closed the books on the case of Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. But its decision without comment does not erase the symbol of My Lai: of wartime atrocities, of coverups by the high command, of the failure of military justice, of the larger meaning of the war without end clear purpose in Vietnam.

title: WILLIAM E. MILLER, U.S. JUDGE, 68, DIES
description: CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP)  Federal Judge William E. Miller, whose landmark decision on reapportionment of the Tennessee Legislature paved the way for the Supreme Court's one man, one vote decision, died today. He was 68 years old.

description: PRAGUE, April 12 (AP)Purged followers of Alexander Dubcek were offered some chance today of regaining membership in the Communist, Party if they gave unswerving support to the Sovietsupported Government of Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak Communist leader.

Many of the employees were blacks and women.

title: 2 GUARDS KILLED IN 42D ST. MEP

description: Walter H. Smith, deputy chairman of European operations since 1974 for Young & Rubicam International Inc., died Saturday in London. He was 61 years old.

title: PPG Industries Net Rose By 253.5% in 1st Quarter
description: PPG Industries Inc.'s profits rose 253.5 percent to $35 million, or $1.68 a share, the highest for any quarter in the history of the diversified manufacturer of glass, industrial and special chemicals plus coating and resins. The net for the first quarter included unrealized gains of $3.3 million, or 16 cents a share from translation of financial funds of foreign operations. Sales climbed 33.2 percent to $522 million reflecting the upswing in automotive production and improved residential construction, and price increases, the company said.

title: Hotel Fire Toll Up to Nine
description: MIAMI, April 12 (AP)Two more people have died from burns suffered in a fire that burned through a Miami hotel a week ago, The latest deaths raised the toll to nine. The latest victims were Millie Sutton and Euzenio Romero.

title: East German Couturier Loses Business in Nationalization Drive
description: MAGDEBURG, East GermanyHeinz Bormann was a kind of Communist Christian Dior, an East German couturier well known even in the West, and a successful middle  class entrepreneur until March 1972.

title: Theater: Secret Service
description: With a gnash of villains, a clash of heroes and a flourish of heroines, William Gillette's venerable melodrama Secret Service returned to New York last night at the Playhouse Theater. It heralded the second and last leg of the Phoenix Theater Bicentennial season. Tonight, it will be joined in repertory with Boy Meets Girl, by Bella and Sam Spewack. William Hooker Gillette, who died in his birthplace of Hartford in 1937 at the agp of 72, was one of the great American actormanagers, who wrote his own plays and acted in thend as if they were chariots and he was BenHur. Today, he is best known for his adaptation of Sherlock Holmes, but in addition to the present play there is also Too Much Johnson, recently revived in Washington.

title: CONFLICT FOUND AT MINE HEARING
description: WHITESBURG, Ky.  There has indeed been a* lot of conflicting testimony here, said a member of the investigating panel during a break in a Federal hearing into the causes of two methane gas explosions that killed 26 men in a coal mine near here last month. A lot will depend on who you believe.

description: The Police Department put into operation yesterday the first phase of a new computer system that officials say will gradually replace its Teletypes, speeding messages in seconds rather than minutes and saving the city more than $500,000 Year.

title: Notes on People
description: Drums, cymbals, dancing, chanting and some tears greeted Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India yesterday as she walked a mile through the village of Halur, amid dust clouds. The trek, patterned after those made by the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, was one of the first of many walking campaigns by Government officials to gain public support for Mrs. Gandhi's 20point economic program, announced after she had declared a national emergency and began repressive measures last July. She probed their hearts, the national news agency reported of the hour Mrs. Gandhi spent among the 2,000 villagers. Women fell at her feet in worshipful admiration or distress.

title: ALBERT FRISCH, 60, COMPOSER OF SONGS
description: Albert T. Frisch, who composed such songs as Two Different Worlds, This Is No Laughing Matter and I Won't Cry Any More, died Sunday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived in Blauvelt, N.Y.

description: NEWARK, April 12 (UPI)Four executives of a New York record company, convicted on conspiracy and fraud charges, were sentenced today by a Federal judge who said that the record industry appeared to be a dirty business.

description: It's been said that if one takes care of the small things, the big things take care of themselves, but it isn't necessarily true. description: DWIGHT, III., April 12 (AP)This town's population was evacuated this morning after a poisonous cloud of bromine gas was reported drifting toward Dwight. The people returned home later today after officials reported the gas had dissipated.

title: Giants: Tickets At 2 Sites

description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 12The former courtappointed guardian for Karen Anne Quinlan gave formal assurance to her family today that he would not appeal the New Jersey Supreme Court decision that allows her to die.

title: Carey Malpractice Bills Disappoint Medical Units
description: ALBANY, April 12  Representatives of some doctors and hospitals in the state expressed disappointment today in Governor Carey's bills to alter the conduct of medical malpractice cases. In addition, two key legislators questioned whether the hills would achieve their goal of slowing the rise in the cost of malnractice insurance.

description: John D. Quinn, who has been deputy commissioner of the Michigan state lottery since 1972, has been named by Governor Carey to direct the revamped New York State lottery, which is expected to begin this summer.

title: Goldin Backs $2.3 Billion Debt Service In Bud get and Assails Bankruptcy Idea
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday defended the record amount, of debt service in the coming city budgetabout $2.3 billion in a $13.8 billion document  and said that increasing calls for the city to declare bankruptcy were based on erroneous assumptions.

title: A Sea Change
description: Secretary of State Kissinger made a timely attempt last week to break a deadlock that has been obstructing a threeyearold effort to complete a comprehensive new oceans treaty.

title: TV: Family
description: Family reaches its sixth episode on ABCTV tonight at 10 o'clock, concluding one of the more impressive and most encouraging series to cross a television screen this this year. Venturing beyond the tight little islands of situationcomedy and actionadventure formats, the abbreviated series attempted to explore the typical events and terrible complexities that can be found in ordinary lives.

title: FUTURES IN COCOA CONTINUE TO RISE
description: The strong uptrend in cocoa futures prices continued yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, where the May delivery jumped the 2centsapound limit to close at 76.20 cents a pound.

title: New York Lottery Will Be Directed By Michigan Man
description: John D. Quinn, who has been deputy commissioner of the Michigan state lottery since 1972, has been named by Governor Carey to direct the revamped New York State lottery, which is expected to begin this summer.

title: KODAK TO UNVEIL INSTANT CAMERA
description: Continued From Page 47

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board met for several hours with negotiators for the Realty Advisory Board and a union representing employees working apartment buildings, in an effort to settle a contract dispute that could result in a strike here April 21. Vincent D. McDonnell, the board chairman, said after meeting with the employers and officers of Local 32B of the Service Employees Union, that he had received the union's demands for higher wages and fringe benefits and the owners counterproposals, and after studying them would meet with both sides in a few days..The union represents superintendents, handymen, elevator operators, porters and guards in 4,000 buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Mete Hit the Road
description: The Mets will open their first and longest trip of the season today in Chicago, but behind them in New York they have left two legal problems involving their brightest names: Tom Seaver and Willie Mavs.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: G. &
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a conglomerate based in New York, and the Signal Companies of Beverly Hills, Calif., announced jointly yesterday that they would make a cash tender offer of $20 a common Merger share for a total of 6.4 million shares News of Signal Companies common stock. The Signal Companies will buy the first shares tendered to 2.5 million shares and Gulf and Western will buy the next 3.9 million shares, for a total of $128 million.

title: Menuhin's Sabbatical
description: Yehudi Menuhin, about to turn 60, had scored a small victory over time and was feeling good about it. We just flew in from El Paso, and we've gained two hours. Marvelous. The internationally lionized musician whose travelweary wife, Diana, once oescrineo aim as commercial traveler with a line in violin music, plugged an electric razor into a wall socket at his suite in the SherryNetherland Hotel and began to mow a stubbly chin. After my concert in London on May 9 when I will play the Brahms Double Concerto with Rostropovich, I am taking a year off, a sabbatical. I promised my wife I'd do that when I was 60.

title: CREDIT MARKETS SHOW RATE DROP
description: Interest rates on shortterm and intermediatematurity securities declined yesterday as commercial banks, which have not uncovered a pickup in loan demand, sought to increase

title: Reid Names Aide for L.I.
description: ALBANY, April 12 (UPI)Donald J. Middleton today was named ditreclor of the Stale En.. vironniental Conservation De: northtool's Region I, in Nassau aod Sufi('Ilc Counties, iotter Ogden R. Reid in noun( ed. Mr. Middleton, \Ow, kill he paid $29,671, was Man. lialtan and Staten Island regional director for Now York Office of Neighhorhood soy Servres. Mr. N1iddloton, M Sears old in Babylon 11

title: MYRA K. WOLFGANG, FEMINIST LEADER, 61
description: DETROIT, April 12 (UPI) Myra K. Wolfgang, an international vice president of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders Union who worked for women's rights, died of cancer today at Henry Ford Hospital. She was 61 years old.

title: Prospects Dwindle for Campaign Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Prospects for Congressional approval of new campaign legislation this month dwindled almost to the vanishing point today as Senate and House conferees failed for the third time to agree on a compromise bill.

title: State Board Seeks Details Of Contract From M.T.A.
description: The staff of the Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday asked the Transit Authority to explain fully how productivity savings would pay for costofliving raises in its new contract with the Transport Workers Union.

title: Stage: Beckett's Creative Cascando
description: Cascando, a short radio play by Samuel Beckett, is about the difficulties and the desperation of the creative process, the implausibility of making art. A man is hopelessly trying to finish a story concerning a character named Woburn. Woburn is in flight running, falling in the mud, picking himself up, running again and, finally sprawling in a boat and drifting off to sea.

title: Dont Call Us. Well Call You.
description: WELLESLEY, MASS.

title: Briton Killed on Everest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 12 (Reuters)A British marine on a joint BritishNepalese attempt to climb Mount Everest was killed when he fell into a crevasse nearly 22,000 feet up the south face on Saturday, the Foreign Ministry said here today. The body of 39yearold Capt. Terry Thompson of Exmouth, Devon, was being brought back to base camp by two members of the expedition who were with him when he fell, the ministry said.

title: HIJACKERST AKEOFF; SEEK LIBYA LANDING
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Tuesday, April 13 (AP)Three Philippine Moslem hijackers holding two hostages and eight crew members aboard a Philippine Airlines jet left today for Libya.

title: NLRB. WEIGHING LAWFIRM UNIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12For the second time in three years, the National Labor Relations Board took under advisement today the question of whether nonlawyer employees of law firms have a federally protected right to organize into trade unions and bargain collectively.

title: Strike Ruled Illegal In San Francisco; New Offer Is Made
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP)A new proposal for ending San Francisco's 13dayold city workers strike was made today shortly after a judge declared the walkout illegal and ordered nickeling ended.

title: Evacuation of 12,000 Pressed As River in North Dakota Rises
description: MINOT, N. D., April 12 (AP) Leaving their homes to thej river's mercy, some evacuees from floodthreatened Minot, moved in today with friends or relatives and others checked into nearby motels.

title: Giancana Slaying Suspect Is Called Old Friend of His
description: When Sam Giancana was shot to death at his home outside Chicago last June 19, there, was wide speculation that his slaying was connected with his role in a 1960 Central Intelligence Agency plot to assassinate Fidel Castro.

title: Study Says Candidates Fail to Name Women to Highest Campaign Posts
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Women have held only 10 of the 69 most important jobs on the campaign staffs of 11 major Presidential candidates, and no woman holds a final decisionmaking position, according to a study made public today.

title: Hearst Sentencing Is Delayed for Tests
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12United States District Judge Oliver J. Carter postponed final sentencing of Patricia Hearst today in her bank robbery conviction and sent her, at the defense request, for a Federal institution for 90 days of diagnostic study.

title: Sabres Are Wary of Islanders
description: BUFFALO, April 12There was no braggadocio in Buffalo Sunday night although the Sabres handily defeated the New York Islanders, 53, in the opening game of their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series. The Sabres are quite humble now after wriggling through the preliminary round on two overtime victories against St. Louis. They prudently give the Islandeis the benefit of the doubt.

title: Hearst Sentencing Is Delayed for Tests
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12Uni ted States District Judge Oliver J. Carter postponed final sentencing of Patricia Hearst today in her bank robbery conviction and sent her, at the defense request, to a Federal institution for 90 days of diagnostic study.

title: Du Pont Reports Profit Is Continuingto Increase
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 12 Firstquarter earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company will approximate $2.80 per share on total sales of about $2.1 billion, Irving S. Shapiro, chairman, told some 2,000 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: Explosionin Finland Kills 45, Injures 70 At Munitions Plant
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 13 (UPI)  A gunpowder explosion demolished an ammunition factoryin southwestern Finland] today, killing as many as 45 workers and injuring 70 others in the worst industrial accident in the nation's history.

title: Glasgow, the City of Slums, Is Defying Rehabilitation
description: GLASGOWRickets used to be called the Glasgow disease. In those days the Bridgeton Billy Boys and the Calton Tongs hacked each other up in dancehall brawls. The city whose giant shipyards launched the Queen Mary and two Queen Elizabeths was better known for the Gorbals, an endless slum of Victorian tenement houses.

title: DOCTOR RECOUNTS HUGHES'S LAST DAY
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 13 (AP)  A Mexican doctor who visited Howard R. Hughes shortly before he died last week described the billionaire recluse as unconscious, dehydrated, al. flicted with a head infection and suffering kidney failure.

title: P. &
description: Procter & Gamble, the mightiest of national advertisers, which rarely switches agency assignments, is moving Gleem toothpaste Aug. 1 from Wells, Rich, Greene to the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago. The brand was supported by over $6 million in television alone last year.

title: Miss Evert Wins
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP)Chris Evert won the first set, then had to battle back from a 32 deficit to beat Lesley Hunt of Australia, 63, 63, In the first round of the $150,000 Virginia Slims championships last night.

title: The B1: A Dissent
description: Congress is considering the largest peacetime military budget in American history, $113 billion for the coming fiscal year. Under the pressure of electionyear rhetoric and warnings about estimates of the level of Soviet defense spending, it may well be approved.

title: MISS HEARST HAS A COLLAPSED LUNG
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., April 13 (AP)Patricia Hearst, convicted last month of joining her kidnappers in armed bank robbery, suffered a collapsed lung in her jail cell and underwent minor surgery tonight, the authorities said.

title: RUMANIA ASSAILS U.S. POLICY VIEW
description: VIENNA, April 13 (Reuters)Rumania warned the United: States today that followingi what it called the Sonnenfeldti doctrine would do grave darnage to Washington's international relations.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 14, 1976

title: Books of The Times
description: The piece I like best in The Sound of Two Hands Clapping is a description of Sir Laurence Olivier working himself into the role of Othello. If I take it on, he said, I don't want a witty, Machiavellian Iago. I want a solid, honesttoGod N.C.O. [noncornmisioned officer]. No English actor in this century, he pointed out, had succeeded in the part, because the play belonged to Iago. He was the bullfighter and Othello the bull. It was necessary, then, to reconceive the two characters, and this rewriting of the play tells us a great deal about acting and even more about Sir Laurence.

title: The New York Times/Neal heal YANKEE FOR A DAY: Mayor Beanie takes a turn at bat during dedication of the reconstructed Yankee Stadium. Opening day Is tomorrow, against the Twins. Article, page
description: In beautiful baseball weatherfor AprilMayor Beame dedicated the rejuvenated Yankee Stadium yesterday with some jests, a short speech in which he expressed confidence that the city would profit from the millions it invested to renovate the ball park and aturrt at bat during which he hit Aio grounders into a cluster Of photographers.

title: The Opposing View
description: WASHINGTON, April 131 Three former officials in Democratic Administrations said today that a future Italian Government was likely to include the Communist Party and that the United States should be prepared to deal with such a government.

title: Yankees, Ellis Top Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, April 13 With each game Baltimore plays, Reggie Jackson's $3 million demand must look more and more reasonable to the Orioles.

title: U.S. Urges a Ban on Chemical Weapons Production
description: GENEVA, April 13  The United States called on the 30nation disarmanent conference today to make a start toward outlawing chemical weapons by agreeing to ban further production and to reduce existing stockpiles.

title: Demonstrations for Chou Not Confined to Peking
description: HONG KONG, April 13The outpouring of sentiment for the late Chou Enlai that led to last week's riot in Peking was evidently not confined to the Chinese capital and took place in some form in over half a dozen other major Chinese cities.

title: The Varied Styles of DeMocratic Senate Aspirants
description: Ramsey Clark is to meet today with leaders of the Chinese community. Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein has scheduled a news conference on the sidewalk outside the Internal Revenue Service office. Friends of Representative Bella S. Abzug at $15 per frienddanced with her last night at Roseland.

title: A National Challenge
description: The most remarkable fact about the municipal elections just held in the Israelioccupied, Arabpopulated \Vest Bank of the Jordan is that they were held at all. However distressed it may be by the results of the elections, the Israeli Government can justifiably be proud that it was willing to conduct a secret vote among bitterly contesting parties in territories under .its military control, in whi;:h nearly threefourths of those eligible, including women for the first timefreely participated. The utter lack of similarly tree elections in virtually every other part of the Arab world stands in instructive if ironiccontrast.

title: Rep. William Barrett, 79, Dies; Philadelphian Served Since 49
description: Representative William A. Barrett of Philadelphia died Monday at The Philadelphia Naval Base Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: FORD SIGNS MEASURE SETTING SEA LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) President Ford citing the slow pace of international fishing discussions, pigned into law today a measure that extends the United States fisheries limit to 200 miles offshore from the oresent 12mile limit.

title: CONFEREES BACK JOB OF SCIENCE ADVISER
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Senate and House conferees have agreed on a bill to give the President a science adviser in the White House, a goal of leaders in American science since 1973.

title: Cunningham Refuses to Waive Immunity And Challenges Law Mandating Ouster
description: Patrick J. Cunningham has refused to sign a waiver of immunity before a special state grand jury, and yesterday he went into Federal Court to challenge the constitutionality of the state election law that would remove him as the Democratic state chairman and the party's leader in the Bronx because of his refusal.

title: Fast Eddie and Paul the Loser
description: Red Smith

title: Ford Says Nation Should Preserve Ethnic Heritage
description: WASHINGTON, April 13President Ford said today that he would never use the phrase ethnic purity but he agreed with Jimmy Carter that the Federal Government should try to preserve the nation's ethnic heritage.

title: From 19thCentury Claustrophobic to 20thCentury Sunny
description: PHILADELPHIA  It happens very rarely that one man can put his stamp upon a neighborhood, and rarer stiE, do this without doing violence to its character and looks. Kenneth Parker has done both.

title: OGDEN DISCLOSES PAYMENTS ABROAD
description: The Ogden Corporation, a diversified company with interests in shipping and marine construction, said yesterday it had made about $2.6 million in payments which may have I been questionable overseas and to a lesser extent in the United States from 1970 through 1975.

title: A SITIN PROTESTS HOSPITAL CLOSING
description: More than 200 people took over the administrative offices of Fordham Hospital yesterday and said they would remain until the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation reversed its decision to close the Bronx municipal institution.

title: You Don't Have to Be 100 To Enjoy Caucasus Dishes
description: What should you eat if you want to live to be 100?

title: ExAides Say Justice Dept. Rejected a Sinatra Inquiry
description: The Justice Department under Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy rejected or ignored repeated recommendations for a thorough investigatioh of Frank Sinatra and his relationships with Mafia leaders, according to former Federal officials.

title: About Real Estate
description: 'Dropping a building is perceived as a failure, a Manhattan realestate man remarked last week. Many people hang on to them to protect their reputation.

title: In Memoriam
description: KOMARINPuler Steven, Feb. 24, 1919April 14, 1974. Peler darling, with us you live forever

title: Legislators
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 13 (UPI)  New Hampshire legislators receive the lowest pay of any legislators in the country, according to a summary by the Citizens Conference on State Legislatures. The pay in New Hampshire is $100 a year. New York is highest at $23,500. New Mexico legislators receive no salary, but are paid $40 per diem. The national average is $9,943, according to the summary.

title: U.S. Adheres to Rights Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 13 (Reuters)The United States has become the 79th country to be bound by an international convention on the political rights of women adopted by the General Assembly in 1952, the (United Nations legal affairs office announced today. It provides that women, on equal terms with men and without discrimination, shall have the right to vote, to be eligible for election to all publicly elected bodies to hold public office and to exercise all public functions.

title: United Technologies Reports Record Sales and Net
description: Harry J. Gray, chairman and president of the United Technologies Corporation convened the annual meeting in Hartford yesterday by announcing that the firstquarter sales and earnings set records and that directors had voted a 100 percent stock dividend.

title: SENATE IN ALBANY OVERRIDES VETO OF STAVISKY BILL
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, April 14The Stavisky bill, requiring the city to restore $150 million to the city schools next year, became law early today as the State Senate overrode Governor Carey's veto of the measure, by a vote of 46 to 11.

title: Riessen, Tanner Defeated
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 13 (AP)Bjorn Borg of Sweden advanced, but two Americans, Roscoe Tannin and Marty Riessen, were beaten in the quarterfinals of the Monaco international tournament, a World Championship Tennis circuit event.

title: Inquiry to Determine Whether the A.M.A. Curbs Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would investigate the American Medical Association to determine whether it had unlawfully restrained the country's supply of physicians and health care services.

title: The $2 Bill Returns, Bringing Out Lines Of Buyers in Banks
description: Children with rolls of pennies and adults with large amounts of bills bought firstday issues of the twodollar bill yesterday as though it were going out of style instead of coming back in.

title: The Opposing View
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Three former officials in Democratic Administrations said today that a future Italian Government was likely to include the Communist Party and that the United States should be prepared to deal with such a government.

title: FRANCE ABANDONING UNIVERSITY REFORM
description: PARIS, April 13The French Government today yielded to pressure from students and teachers and in effect renounced present plans for controversial university reform.

title: NEW FALL SHOWS SCHEDULED BY NBC
description: A series based on the John O'Hara story Gibbsville and another drawn from the movie Serpico are among the new programs in NBC's television schedule for next fall.

title: Based on Early Version
description: WASHINGTON, April 13State Department officials said today that the Rumanian critique of policy views of Helmut Sonnenfeldt was based on a March 22 account in the column by Rowland Evans and Robert Novak, which they termed a distortion.

description: 8:00 The Golden Age of Charlie Chaplin: One A.M. and Easy Street

title: Patricia Hearst Ill
description: Patricia Hearst was hospitalized for a collapsed lung, her attorney reported, adding that she was in stable condition after undergoing surgery. Page 19.

title: PRESIDENT CURBS POCKET VETO USE
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)  Attorney General Edward H. Levi announced today that President Ford had decided to limit his use of the pocket veto by using it only during final adjournments of Congress every two years, and not during recesses in the biennial sessions.

title: Prices and Trading Retreat on Amex, Counter Issues Up
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecoanter market finished yesterday with minor price changes in moderate trading.

title: WINE TALK.
description: Bargains in fine French wines should be available for at least six more months in major United States markets but they may well be followed by hefty price increases. Such is the considered opinion of one of the betterknown importers here, Ab Simon, head of the fine wine division of Jos. E. Seagrams & Sons.

title: 30 From New York Labor Groups Elected as Democratic Delegates
description: Organized labor had mixed success in its efforts last week to elect New York & negates to the Democratic National Convention. The moderate labor coalition, whose candidates ran on slates for Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington or were uncommitted, did very well. The liberal coalition, whose candidates ran on slates for Representative Motris K. Udall of Arizona did not.

title: MILITANTS SCORE SWEEPING VICTORY IN WEST BANK VOTE
description: JERUSALEM, April 13 A new, militant leadership dominated by Palestinian nationalists and Arab radicals emerged on the occupied West Bank today after the ballots were counted from the municipal elections yesterday.

title: Flora Purim, Jazz Singer, On First Tour in 3 Years
description: One imagines that Flora Purim, the Brazilian jazz singer, doesn't look back with pleasure on her 16 months in jail. But during lrir term, the result of a cocaine possession conviction, Miss Purim saw her career take off. Before, she had appeared as featured vocalist with Stan Getz, Gil Evans and Chick Corea, with whom she and her husband, the percussionist Airto Moreira, toured for two

title: PENSION AM URGED BY PAYCHECK CUTS
description: Mayor Beame's special pension study panel yesterday recommended that the city contribute $208 million more annually to bolster the retirement system and that this boney come from municipal employees paychecks rather than from the strapped city treasury.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The leader of the union representing nursinghome employees in the metropolitan area warned yesterday the possibility of wildcat strikes on Friday if the homes failed to make back wage payments due tomorrow. Peter Ottley. president of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital and Nursing Home Union, said the 12,000 employees represented by his union had been assured of the retroactive payments after a group headed by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner succeeded in averting a strike threatened for March 3. Mr. Ottley said the nursing homes were saying they were unable to make the payments.

title: International Paper Earnings Up 35.3%
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest papermaking organization, with interests, in building materials, achieved a 35.3.percent increase in earnings for the first quarter setting a record at $63.6 million, equal to $1.43 a share. Sales also at a new high for the initial three months, were $867 million, up 17 percent.

title: RICHARD A. FELDON
description: Richard A. Feldon, a former magazine publisher, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

title: Mississippi River Jam Worse During Repairs
description: ALTON, III., April 15 (Reuters)A massive traffic jam on the Mississippi River worsened today as Army engineers worked to repair the main lock system here.

title: Rev. Daniel Power, Taught History at Georgetown U.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Rev. Daniel E. Power, retired professor and director of public affairs at Georgetown University, died yesterday in the Jesuit Community Residence here. He was 71 years old.

title: ExAides Say Justice Dept. Rejected a Sinatra Inquiry
description: The Justice Department under Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy rejected or ignored repeated recommendations for a thorough investigation of Frank Sinatra and his relationships with Mafia leaders, according to former Federal officials.

title: Archives Get Plans Of Brooklyn Bridge
description: At 9:45 yesterday morning, a darkgreeff truck owned by the Municipal Archives pulled up to a small brick shed underneath the Brooklyn end of the Williamsburg Bridge. Six men got out, went inside the building and quickly emerged carrying wooden chests of drawers which they placed inside the truck and hauled across the East River to Manhattan.

title: Shell Makes Statement
description: THE HAGUE, April 13Ger. rit A. Wagner. president of the Shell board of managing directors said at a news confe ence here today that Shell ??s always refused payment^ to political parties, but sometimes loci! subsidiaries do it because of local customs.

title: Archives Get Brooklyn Bridge Plans

Six men got out, went inside the building and quickly emerged carrying wooden chests of drawers which they placed inside the truck and hauled across the East River to Manhattan.

description: (In pounds sterling Per metric ton)

title: Disaster Area Designated
description: MINOT, N. D., April 13 (AP) President Ford today declared Ward County in north central North Dakota a disaster emergency area because of floods and the threat of floods. The designation opens a wide I range of Federal assistance programs, including housing for (persons evacuated.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park tomorrow, Friday and Saturday on both sides of those streets where altelmitesideofthestreet regulations normally are in effect, The regulations have been suspended because of the Passover and Good Friday holidays. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: GOLD
description: By The Amitvlated Press

title: ALASKAN OIL BIDS AT $571.8 MILLION
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 13Investors offered $571.8 million in apparent high bids for Federal oil and gas leases in the northern Gulf of Alaska today in a sale held by the Interior Department here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: and My Funny Valentine.

title: ALLIE BETH MARTIN, HEADED LIBRARIANS
description: Allie Beth Martin, president of the American Library Association, died Sunday of cancer in Tulsa, Okla., where she lived. She was 61 years old.

title: A Special Way With Food
description: CHICKEN TABAKA

title: Sabres Beat Islanders In Extra Period, 32
description: BUFFALO, April 13Danny Gare bounced overtime goal into the New York Islander net tonight with his chest for a 32 Buffalo victory. Gare and the Sabres have become overtime spe cialistsit was their sixth consecutive overtime victory, going back to last spring's playoffs, and it was the third in their last four playoff games here. The goal came after 14 minutes 4 seconds of the extra period.

title: Gains in School Desegregation Reported
description: WASHINGTON. April 13 A social research agency asserted today that busing and other school desegregation efforts were more successful and less disruptive than conventional wisdom indicated.

title: City Widening Its Search for Scofflaws
description: New York City, for the first time, will reach out of state and even out of the country, if necessary, to dun drivers of rented cars who receive parking violation summonses that they never answer.

title: YACHTSMAN IS HELD 1 ON U.S. TAX COUNT
description: A yachtsman and computer equipment manufacturer was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having filed false personal income tax returns from 1969 throueh 1971.

title: BYRNE BIDS CITIES MOVE ON HOUSING
description: TRENTON, Aprl 13Governor Byrne has directed the state's cities, towns and suburbs to provide the zoning and planning necessary for them to have a fair share of housing for the poor, the elderly and families with small, children.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS LOSE ENERGY TEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 13A Democratic attempt to derail the Ford Administration's plan for phased decontrol of petroleum product prices failed today on the House floor.

title: Lockheed Settles Charges by S.E.C. Of Payoffs Abroad:
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 .. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Lockheed. Aircraft Corporation agreed to: day on a settlement of charges by the commission that the de. fense contractor had violated various securities laws in malv ing secret payments to foreigiigovernment officials totaling at least $25 million between 1968 and 1975.

title: U.S. Fund Cutoff Slows Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Despite the talk of momentum in Presidential politics, the campaigns of nearly all the leading candidates have been slowing since the last Federal matching funds were paid out three weeks ago.

title: Market Place
description: To Hans Randolph Reinisch it was a case of dj vu. As a selfappointed guardian of shareholder rights, he had pressed the Exchange .Firms Information Corporation to reform, and, with the help of the Federal Trade Commission, he thought he had gotten the creditreporting agency to agree to dissolve.

title: The Antiterrorist League
description: BONNThe three principal capitals of Western EuropeBonn, Paris and Londonhave quietly established an antiterrorist league to combat the wave of violence for political purposes. that has recently spread in this area.

title: People in Sports
description: Chuck Muncie, a 220pound allAmerican running bac:: from the University of California, signed a sevenyear contract for a reported sum in excess of $1 million yesterday with the New Orleans Saints. He was the top draft choice of the club and No. 3 in the entire National Football League draft last week.

title: Henry In the Lion's Den
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The scene was a luncheon dungeon in the Shoreham Hotel, which rises at this time of year out of a blaze of azalea and dogwood .blossoms on a steep bank above Rock Creek Park in Washington. The audience was the American Society of Newspaper Editors, whose papers have lately been giving Secretary of State Kissinger a hard time. The speaker: Henry Kissinger.

title: Congress Blocks Efforts by F.D.A. To Curb Vitamins
description: Congress has passed a bill blocking the Fond and Drug Administration's attempts to regulate the sale of highpotency vitamin and mineral pills.

title: Secretary Sees Threat
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned today that if Italian Communists entered the Italian Government a longterm dangerous trend could be produced in the West because other European countries would also be tempted to move in the same direction.

title: PRESIDENT OF CHAD UNHURT IN ATTACK
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 13 (Reuters)  Four persons were killed and 72 wounded today in a grenade attack on President Feix Maflown during a military parade to murk the first anniversary of the coup that trought him to Dower.

title: House Oversight Unit Sets An Investigation of S.E.C.
description: The House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigation will hold hearings on the Securities and Exchange Commission beginning April 27, the subcommittee chairman, John E. Moss, Democrats of California, said yesterday.

description: International

title: Diver to Seek Past's Glories In Mud of New York Harbor
description: There is treasure sunken in New York Harbor. Some of it may be doubloons of gold, guilders of silver, pieces of eight and the gewgaws of acquisitive pirates.

title: Runaway City Pensions ...
description: The need to put a brake on the runaway growth in the cost of municipal pensions is incontrovertible, as Mayor Beame's Management Advisory Board has now proven.

title: Ailing Bank in Newark Named in Investigation
description: NEWARK, April 13The ailing Security National Bank of New Jersey, target of a hotly contested takeover bid, is among several New Jersey banks figuring in a largescale Federal Investigation of the possible misapplication of loan funds.

title: Soprano Scores Knockout
description: LONDON, April 13 (Reuters)Charles Craig Is listed as a doubtful starter as Luigi in Puocini's Il Tabarro at Covent Garden this week. He is recovering from injuries sustained when a 130pound American soprano was thrown on top of .him.

title: Two Federal Judges Retire
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)  President Ford announced today that he had formally acknowledged the retirement of John A. Field Jr. of Charleston, W. Va., as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond. He also acknowledged the retirement of Edward William Day of Cranston, R.I., as a United States district judge for that state.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
HYNES GETS FUNDS FOR INVESTIGATION
description: ALBANY, April 13  The Legislature today appropriated $1.9 million to hire 106 additional auditors, examiners and lawyers for use this year by Charles J. Hynes, the special nursinghome prosecutor.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 750,000 common shares of the Minnesota Power and Light Company, at $19.50 a share, was made by underwriters headed by myth Eastman Dillon & Company.

title: Italian Reaction Muted
description: ROME, April 13Italians, accustomed to scandal and preoccupied with headlines reporting political and monetary crises, arc reacting calmly to the latest revelations of political payments by British Petroleum anti Shell oil companies.

title: Italy's Anxiety
description: Italy is lurching toward a national election in June that no major party desires and that will arouse great anxiety among that country's partners in the Atlantic Alliance and the European Communities. In fact, the election reay also cause concern in the Soviet Union, which seems as worried as the United States about the possibility that the powerful Italian Communist Party may enter the national Government.

title: Cunningham's Action Spurs Speculation on His Possible Ouster
description: New York politiciansaware that Patrick J. Cunningham's survival as De1nocratic state chairman ad county leader in the Bronx now depends upon a state law's being found unconstitutional  speculate yesterday about the likelihood of his removal from those two posts, about possible successors, about Governor Carey's role in their selection.

title: Secretary Sees Threat
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned today that if Italian Communists entered the Italian Government a longterm dangerous trend could be produced in the West because other European countries would also be tempted to move in the same direction.

title: Czech Six Downs Finland, 71
description: KATOWICE, Poland, April 13Jiri Holecek allowed a goal in the opening two minutes and then withstood the Finnish team's attack to keep Czechoslovaki.: undefeated in four Fames of the world hockey championships with a 71 victory.

title: Parents and Security Guards Clash Outside School on the West Side
description: A clash between angry parents and Board of Education security officers broke out yesterday morning outside a.West Side school after the officers refused to allow parents in accompany their children io classrooms,

title: Mets Strand 15 and Lose, 54
description: CHICAGO, April 13Winter turned to summer in Wrigley Field today, but the change in seasons didn't stop the New York Mets from changing their latest mode of losingleaving men on base. Stranding 15 runners, which tied a club record, the Mets lost, 54, to the Chicago Cubs on a pop fly that fell safely with the bases full in the ninth inning.

title: Troubled Americans
description: The myth of the American melting pot has exploded. There are still large groups of Italians. Irish, Jews and Poles and countless others whose cultural values and traditions are still an important part of their lives.

title: Paul Ford, Actor, Dead; Colonel in Bilko
description: Paul Ford, who began acting professionally at 40 and then. became widely known for two roles as colonelsColonel Ha111 in Phil Silvers's Sgt. J3ilko show on television and Colonel Purdy in The Teahouse of the, August Moon on Broadway and in the movie, died Monday in Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L. I. He was 74 years old.

title: Blumenthal Colleagues Break Out Champagne
description: ALBANY, April 13Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi did a tap dance down the hall, the avuncular Assemblyman Harvey L. Strelzin shed bittersweet tears before and after and Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican leader, dispatched an aide with a bottle of champagne for the party he knew would follow.

description: BASEBALL

description: There is treasure sunken in New York Harbor. Some of it may be doubloons of gold, guilders of silver, pieces of eight and the gewgaws of acquisitive pirates.

title: Beame Vow to Help Ends Drug Campout at Gracie
description: A nineday encampment outside Gracie Mansion protesting budget cuts in drugtreatment programs broke up last night after Mayor Beame met with leaders of the protest and later declared he would seek help from Washington and Albany to maintain the services facing reduction.

title: Humphrey Wins McGovern's Praise
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Senator George McGovern of South Dakota said today that he can't think of anybody better to lead a united Democratic party this year than Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, who was his strongest rival for the Presidential nomination four years ago.

title: Tennis Prodigies Flock to City
description: Traveling alone on a midnight flight from California, 11yearold Jimmy Pugh arrived at La Guardia Airport, where he was met by two Easter Bowl aides. Who do I play in the first round? was his opening question.

title: Unwaived Cunningham
description: Patrick J. Cunningham is within his rights in challenging constitutionality of the state law subjecting him to automatic removal from his post as Democratic state chairman, now that he has refused to waive immunity in answering charges of complicity in selling judgeships.

title: Excerpts From Justice's Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion by Justice Aloysius J. Melia of the State Supreme Court dismissing the indictments against Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal:

title: ... How to Control Them
description: But if that is good news, there Is nothing pleasurable in the accompanying disclosure that another $208 million is needed to fund all liabilities over a fortyyear periodthe longest stretchout consistent with responsible fiscal management. The board wants to phase in this extra cost over a fiveyear period, beginning in 1977, and have the money come out of employee paychecks rather than out of the overstrained city treasury. Both proposals are sound.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will he able to park tomorrow, Friday and Saturday on both sides of those streets where alternatesideofthestreet regulations normally are In effect. The regulations have been suspended because of the Passover and Good Friday holidays. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)The Justice Department announced today that the Superior Company and the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, both of Houston, had agreed to accept a court order forbidding them have interlocking directorates. The department filed suit United States District Court in Houston charging that the companies had violated antitrust law by allowing a Canadian industrialist, Marsh A. Cooper, to serve as a direCtor of both concerns.

title: Yale Names New Chaplain
description: NEW HAVEN, April 13 (AP)  The Rev. John W. Vannors drill, chaplain of Gettysburg College, hns been appointed chaplain at Yale University, succeeding the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, the university ?? today.

title: UNITEDAIRLINESASKS FARECHANGE POWER
description: WASHINGTON April 13 (AP) United Airlines, the nation's largest airline urged today that air carriers be allowed to raise and lower their fares by 15 percent a year on routes of their choosing for a twoyear experimental period.

title: SYNTEX UNIT SETS ACQUISITION DEAL
description: Syntex  U.S.A., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Syntex Corporation, announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire BarnsHind Pharmaceuticals of Sunnyvale, Calif., for Syntex

title: Xerox Plans to Sell Controversial Plot In Greenwich Area
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 13 The Xerox Corporation announced here today that it would sell a 102acre tract in the rural back country of Greenwich on which it had been denied permission to build its own headquarters office complex in 1973.

title: Noise Holds Its Own Despite City's Efforts
description: New York City documents that had been kept sealed for 20 years were opened yesterday, revealing that the city is just about as noisy now as it was in 1956.

title: Recovery Is Progressing Smoothly, Economists Find
description: After the bizarre and bumpy ride the economy has been on for the last few years, the expansion now under way may seem almost boring.

title: ARAB MILITANTS WINON WEST BANK
description: JERUSALEM, April 13A new, militant leadership dominated by Palestinian nationalists and Arab radicals emerged on the occupied West Bank today after the ballots were, counted from the municipal elections yesterday.

title: 4 Children Killed With Their Mother In Brooklyn Fire
description: Four children and their mother were killed in a fire that swept through their apartmena at 499 Ralph Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn early this morning, the police reported,

title: Training the Marines
description: The 200yearold Marine Corps, Once the elite of the United States armed forces, has been fighting for survival in an era of modern warfare fur which, according to a recent Brookings Institution study, it massively illequipped. That effort will hardly be abetted by the latest report of primeval brutality at a Marine training camp in San Diego where a yOung problem recruit. was fatally beaten and 62 others injured himulated bayonet practice.

title: An Egg Dish That's Amusing In an Elegant Sort of Way
description: Eggs, of course, in almost any form can be related to Easter. One of the most elegantpid amusingegg dishes we've ever encountered is one we discovered the famed Pot au Feu Restaurant at EugenielesRains France. The patronchef is, of course, Michel Gudrard, who is among the most celebrated chefs of Eurone.

title: Earthquake Hits Oregon
description: THE DALLES, Ore., April 13 (AP)No injuries were reported and apparently there was no major damage from an earthquake last night centered about 35 miles southeast of here. The! quake, which registered 4.8 on the Richter scale, was the first ever recorded in the lower Deschutes River Valley, the United States Geological Survey's Earthquake Information Center at Golden, Colo., said.

title: 2 OIL COMPANIES ADMIT PAYMENTS
description: LONDON, April 13Two major European oil companies, Royal Dutch/Shell and British Petroleum, admitted today that they had made contributions to political parties in Italy's coalition Government. They also said they had made smaller payments in other countries.

title: Jorge Guillen Wins Bennett Award
description: Cited as a consummate craftsman who has brought to the Spanish language an unsurpassed purity of expression, Jorge Guillen has won the first $12,500 Bennett Award, The literary prize, established by The Hudson Review in memory of Joseph Bennett, an editor of the literary quarterly who died in 1972, is to be given every two years to a writer of significant achievement whose work has not received the full recognition it deserves.

title: CHANGES SOUGHT IN WATER CONTROL,
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The House Public Works Committee approved today a bill that would drastically amend the Water Pollution Control Act of 1972. Most of the amendments deal with the Federal grant program covering 75 percent of the cost of constructing or upgrading municipal waste treatment systems.

title: $5.3 BILLION VOTED IN SENATE JOB BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Setting the, stage for another clash with President Ford over the economy, the Senate approved today legislation authorizing nearly $5.3 billion to stimulate employment by public works projects and entirecession grants to states and localities.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Talks With F.B.I. Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Patricia Hearst has recounted for the Federal Bureau of Investigation many of the details of her 19 months underground, including the robbery of a Sacramento bank April 21, 1975, by her radical companions, a governmental source familiar with the case said tonight.

title: N.Y. Rugby Union
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: Bullets Win, Bucks Score In Playoffs
description: The Washington Bullets, experienced and heavily favored, and the Milwaukee Bucks, young and opportunistic, turned in close victories last night as the National Basketball Association playoffs began.

title: The Rites of Spring Range From Fun and Games to the Serious
Conferees Agree on Election Reform; No New Subsidies Seen Before May
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Senate and House conferees reached agreement today on extensive changes in the lavf governing the 1976 political campaign, but their action came too late to permit the restoration before midMay o Federal subsidies for Presidential candidates.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES BILL ON GUN CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)  The House Judiciary Committee approved today a gun control bill that would ban the manufacture and importation of cheap, concealable handguns, commonly known as Saturday night specials.

title: Vindicated Legislator
description: Just before Albert Howard Blumenthal got the news yesterday morning that his indictment had been dismissed, he was alone in his Albany office worrying about a way to work out a compromise proposal for New York City's education budget. When the news came through, he sai for moment and wept.

title: Theater: Spewacks
description: Whatever precisely a madcap farce is, there can be no doubt whatsoever that Boy Meets Girl, by Bella and Sam Spewack, is a madcap farce. Indeed one of the maddest and cappiest in Broadway history. This loving, if sardonic, tribute to the great days of Hollywood, circa 1935, was staged last night at the Playhouse Theater by the Phoenix Theater Company, and it was hilarious. Silly. funny, sweet, but, most of all, hilarious.
