description: Phantom Enthusiast at Whitney Museum

title: COURT DISMISSES BLUMENTHAL CASE BROUGHT BY HYNES
description: The Assembly majority leader, Albert H. Blumenthal, won the dismissal yesterday of all 12 charges in a perjury and bribery indictment stemming from his relationship with Ber., nard Bergman, the nursing. home promoter.

title: Council Bills to Seek Delinquent City Taxes
description: Councilman Edward L. Sadowski, chairman of the Charter and Governmental Operations Committee, said yesterday that he would introduce five bills to speed collections of millions of dollars in delinquent real estate taxes.

title: Gorgo, Venezuelan Horse, Set for Belated U.S. Debut
description: About seven hours before Aqueduct's first race this afternoon, Gorgo, a strapping 6yearold stallion from Venezuela, is scheduled to engage in a threefurlong workout. The session over At the the Big A's strip will be watched Race with great inter Tracks est by clockers. Gorgo earned $266,050 in Caracas in three years of campaigning. He is expected to make his American debut in a onemile handicap event on Saturday that will precede the $100,000 added Wood Memorial. This start has been long time coming, said Santiago Ledwith, who has been commissioned to train Gorgo. The horse arrived in New York last January. We had him ready to go a few weeks later, but he did what horses sometimes do  hurt a leg kicking the wall of his stall.

title: Fossils of Peking Man Hidden by Australian
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 13 (UPI)  A Sydney businessman says he has buried the priceless fossils of a specimen of the Peking man in a rain forest on the Australian island state of Tasmania.

title: New Yorkers and Tokyoites Compare Life in Cities
description: TOKYO, April 13Prominent New Yorkers and Japanese urban specialists meeting in Tokyo last week discovered that their two cities have more differences than similarities but that each could learn much from the other.

title: Concert: Menuhin Notes
description: A little over a week short of his 60th birthday (he was born on April 22, 1916), Yehudi Menuhin, great violinist and citizen of the world celebrnted his hirthda with a concert in Carnegie Hall. It was not a solo celebration. Sharing the music making were friends and family. There also were other persons on stage to participate.

title: Quake Rattles the Crockery In 8 Bergen County Towns

title: ES, FUND CUTOFF SLOWS CAMPAIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Despite the talk of momentum in Presidential politics, the campaigns of nearly all the leading candidates have been slowing since the last Federal matching funds were paid out three weeks ago.

title: Cambodia Announces Its New Government
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, April 14 (AP)The Phnom Penh radio announced today that a new Government had been formed with Khieu Samphan as chairman of the state presidium, and the prime minister's job going to Tol Sat, an obscure officeholder virtually unheard of outside Cambodia.

title: Portuguse Troops Open Fire, Kill One In Political Protest
description: BEJA, Portugal, Wednesday, April 14 (Reuters)The Portuguese Army opened fire yesterday to disperse leftist demonstrators in this Communist stronghold in the southern part of the country.

title: Fire Destroys 6 Buildings
description: PEEKSVILLE, N. Y. (AP)A fire in the downtown business district here destroyed six buildings and left about 30 people homeless. The police said the blaze began in a shed behind an apartment building and spread to the apartment building and the other twoto fourstory frame structures clustered around the corner of Maine and Division streets.

title: Gain Is Emphasized, for TaxExempts
description: While a heavy volume of fixedincome securities was being priced, credit markets continued to advance in price yesterday. Interest rates continued to move downward,

title: Prices Move Down In Potato Futures To Close at 10.70
description: Wild gyrations marked potato futures trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in the May contract. It opened at 11.30 cents pound, up from the close on Monday of 11.08. From 11.30 it moved up to 11.58 and then plunged 99 points to 10.59, before a slight buying rally raised the closing price to 10.70.

title: Reds, on 5Run 8th, Win 4th in Row, 61
description: The world champion Cincinnati Reds, with a fiverun rally in the eighth inning for a 61 victory over the Braves, continued undefeated last night. The victory at Atlanta Stadium was the fourth for the Reds in defense of their National League pennant.

title: Notes on People
description: I'm too happy for words, but I knew I would eventually get permission, Zoya Fyodorova, the Russian actress, said yesterday on learning she had been given a visa to travel to the United States in time for the birth of her grandchild. She stayed in Russia when her daughter Victoria, a movie actress, came to this country in March 1975 to meet her fathfor the first time. He is a retired Navy admiral, Jackson R. Tate, of Orange Park, Fla., and his love affair with Zoya Fyodorova in World War II, when he was stationed in Moscow, later caused her imprisonment for eight years. Three months after her arrival here, Victoria Fyodorova married an airline pilot, Fred Pouy, and the live in Stamford, Conn. Their child is due about May 11. The grandmothertobe said yesterday that she hoped to leave for the United States sometime next week.

title: Patriotic Heartburn for a New $2 Bill
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, April 13Fat Mike's fastfood outlet on Route 17 here offered a special today: All the quarterpound chili wieners you could eat for $2.

description: Dividends

title: Flyers Defeat Leafs and Take 20 Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP)Ross Lonsberry and Don Saleski scored secondperiod goals just 70 seconds apart as the Philadelphia Flyers, beat the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, 31, and took a 20 lead in the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup quarterfinal series.

title: GRANT ADJUDICATED A FORMAL BANKRUPT
description: The W.T. Grant Company, which on Feb. 12 was ordered by a Federal judge to liquidate within 60 days, was yesterday formally adjudicated a bankrupt by John J. Galgay, the bankruptcy judge.

title: Guilty in Crash Near Munich
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 13 (AP)A West German court today found two stationmasters and a timetable clerk guilty of negligent manslaughter and negligently causing injury in a headon collision near here of two commuter trains last year that killed 41 persons and injured 123 others. A new timetable for a single track line was found to have been wrongly calculated.

title: TV: Sandburg's Lincoln
description: The sixth and final installment of Sandburg's Lincoln can be seen on NBCTV at 10 this evening. The series, which has been dropped into the schedule sporadically Over the last couple of seasons, unfortunately ends on a note of singular weakness. The Last Days, using a script by Philip Reisman Jr. seems stuffed with air. Highly dramatic events are reduced to curiously thin anecdotes. Perhaps the budget ran out at Episode Five.

title: Aide Is Released
description: MEXICO CITY, April 13 A Mexican federal judge unexpectedly dropped today all charges against an aide to the late Howard R. Hughes who had been arrested and accused of falsifying the billionaire's signature ln Acapulco two months ago.

title: Stocktoh Victor
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 13 (UPI)Dick Stockton defeated Jeff Borowiak, 46, 63, 64, in the first round of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: About New York
description: For singers, there are only two rules, said Lewis Friedman. No Impossible Dream and no medleys. The limit is three songs, and with medleys they can slip in nine or 10, and frequently have.

title: Reshaping of Amateur Sports Foreseen
description: Federal measures to reshape amateur athletics in America are inevitable, according to members of the President's Commission on Olympic Sports.

title: Police Worker Is Accused Of Being a Welfare Cheat;
description: A 29yearold mother of three children, employed since December 1971 as a clerk in the Police Department, was arrested yesterday by the Bronx District Attorney's office on charges of having fraudulently accepted welfare funds totaling $6,891.

title: COURT DISMISSES BLUMENTHAL CASE BROUGHT BY HYNES

title: Ford Says Nation Should Preserve Ethnic Heritage
description: WASHINGTON, April 13President Ford said today that he would never use the phrase ethnic purity but he agreed with Jimmy Carter that the Federal Government should try to preserve the nation's ethnic heritage.

title: Dr. Donald Keller. Owned Westhampton Nursing Home
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., April 13  Dr. Donald R. Keller, a surgeon and general practitioner here since 1934 and owner of the Westhampton Nursing Home, died yesterday of a heart attack in Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchnpue He was 71 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: As the bidding and play develops, more and more information becomes available to both sides. The amount of guessing that may be required steadily diminishes, and at the 12th trick a good player should never have to guess. But players have been known to go wrong at this stage, usually because they have paid insufficient attention to the earlier play.

title: Court Rules 7 Owe Exchange Millions
description: The New York Stock Ex. change has won a Judgment of more than $23 million against seven former stockbrokers. But it may never collect because the former stockbrokers don't have the money, lawyers close to the case disclosed yesterday.

title: U. of Virginia Pays Tribute to Mr. Jefferson
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 13At 5:42 o'clock this morning, just as the sun eased up over the eastern horizon and touched the dome of Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's mountaintop home, two dozen fairly chilled students from the University of Virginia clustered at his tomb to raise their voices and overflowing cups for a rousing cheer.

title: Jersey Quake Rattles Crockery
description: LEONIA, April 13  An earthquake today that registered 2.5 on the Richter Scale knocked dishes off tables, rattled windows and sent residents to their telephones here and in several surrounding Bergen County communities.

title: Sandra Good Given A 15Year Sentence For Threats Plot
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 13 (UPI)  Sandra Good, a member of the Charles Manson group, told the judge and others in court that you will soon lose your minds as she was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for conspiring to mail death threats.

title: How Woodpecker Keeps From Being a Numbskull
description: Woodpeckers lead the kind of life that would give most other animals a massive headache. For years ornithologists have wondered: Why don't these noisy birds suffer concussion or brain damage as they hammer away?

title: Pay Deductions Proposed For City Pension Systems
description: Mayor Beame's special pension study panel yesterday recommended that the city contribute $208 million more annually to bolster the retirement system and that this money come from municipal employees paychecks rather than from the strapped city treasury.

title: Beame Is at the Top of Batting Order For Dedication of Renovated Stadium
description: In beautiful baseball weatherfor AprilMayor Beame dedicated the rejuvenated Yankee Stadium yesterday with some jests, a short speech in which he expressed confidence that the city would profit from the millions it invested to renovate the ball park and a turn at bat during which he hit two grounders into a cluster of photographers.

title: Assad Says Syria Will Act if Lebanese Renew Strife
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 13  President Hafez al.Assad, whose armed forces have moved into Lebanon during the last five days, he warned Lebanese and Palestinian leaders that his Government will go even further if necessary to stop bloodshed in Lebanon.

title: Manchester Still Backs Its Convicted ExMayor
description: MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP Despite his recent conviction for bribery, former Mayor Joseph S. Portash appears to be as popular as ever in this Ocean County retirement community of 19,000.

title: KILLING MARS PLANS FOR BASQUE RALLY
description: MADRID, April 13Efforts to stage a huge Basque rally appeared wrecked today as result of the killing of an industrialist by the Basque terrorist organization and the divisions and fears that the killing has provoked.

title: Carter Mounts Campaign To Win Blacks
description: ATLANTA, April 13Dipping deep into the reservoir of black sympathy he built as Govergor. of Georgia, Jimmy Carter', mounted today a concerted ef fort to win the black vote.

title: Morgan and Mellon Say Earnings Fell
description: J. P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday that its operating earnings in this year's first quarter fell 8.2 percent to $44.9 million, or $1.15 a share, from the yearearlier $48.9 million, or $1.26 a share.

title: Changing Limits to Horizons
description: The Club of Rome sought, at its Philadelphia meetings this week in honor of the American Bicentennial, to shift its public image from that of a prophet of doomsday to a bearer of hope for mankind. The shift was Economic Analysis symbolized by the change from the first and most famous report to the club, which was titled The Limits to Growth, to the latest meeting, which is called New Horizons for Mankind.

title: Lockheed Settles Charges by S.E.C. Of Payoffs.Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation agreed today on a settlement of charges by the commission that the defense contractor had violated various securities laws in making secret payments to foreign government officials totaling at least $25 million between 1968 and 1975.

title: Carey Aides Vow to Continue BudgetCut Battle
description: ALBANY, April 13Despite renewed insistence from legislative leaders, Governor Carey's office pledged today to continue to defy the Legislature in refusing to make the precise spending cuts that the lawmaokers called for when they passed the budget last month.

title: A Troubled West Bank
description: The West Bank of the Jordan River, a territory of 2,270 square miles with roughly 600,000 Arab inhabitants, has Lean under Israeli military occupation since June 1967, when Jordan joined in support of Egypt in military action against Israel and the Israelis overran the area.

title: Vorster Returns Home
description: JOHANNESBURG, South, Africa, April 13 (UPI)Prime, Minister John Vorster returned today from the first visit of a South African head of Government to Israel in more than 20 years. Mr. Vorster said on: arrival at Jan Smuts airport that a firm foundation has been laid for future cooperadon between South Africa and Israel.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Rise; Dow Is Up by 12.99 to 984.26
description: Selected blue  chip issues, prominently represented in the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial issues, led a stock market upturn yesterday. Trading volume remained light.

title: Bach Is Performed at Its Best
description: There are good performances and correct performances, and on rare occasion the two meet. Such a happy conjunction took place on Mpnday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, where Fortunate Arico and Albert Fuller put their scholarly heads together for a Bach program. Musicology and musicianship, which often seem to be working separate sides of the street, met in this concert, and the result was pure pleasure.

title: Plan to Name Administrator of Howard Hughes Estate Reported
description: HOUSTON, April 13The first clue to the disposition of Howard R. Hughes's billiondollar fortune came to light here tonight when sources close to the Hughes industrial empire said that a local law firm, representing both Mr. Hughes's business interests and his relatives, would seek the appointment of a temporary administrator of his estate here tomorrow.

title: TV Crime Shows to Thin Ranks in the Fall Season
description: The ranks of police and detectives are beginning to thin on television, after a seven or eightyear wave of lawenforcement series that has caused the networks to he criticized by the public, members of Congress and some advertisers for !preoccupation with crime and violence in the peek viewing tours.

title: Suit Is Seeking Extra Pay for Migrants
description: OLASSBORO, April 13The American Civil Liberties Union, charging gross underpayment of Wages to thousands of migrants, has filed a classaction suit to obtain the records of hundreds of South Jersey farmers.

title: NOW ORIENTAL ART IS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Did the artist really do the painting, and if so, when? Or was it done by a talented apprentice? Such questions, long pondered by scholars of Western Art, are now beginning to surface in the more esoteric field of Oriental art, as the latter is increasingly shown on the museum circuit.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 13 Governor Byrne said today that because of adverse public reaction to his proposal to eliminate free state motorvehicle inspections, he would reevaluate his stance if the Legislature found a way of coming up with the approximately $9 million for the program.

title: Baltimore Councilman Is Slain And 4 Others Shot at City Hall
description: BALTIMORE, April 13A Baltimore City councilman was shot and killed today by a man who wounded a second councilman, a secretary to the Mayor, and a city policeman before being shot by policemen who cornered him in a City Hall office.

description: ParisLoucif Hamani, 157 pounds. Algeria, outpointed Ruby Robles, 159, Los Angeles; 10 rounds.

description: MERJ UYUN, Lebanon, April 13Trucks supporting Syria's intrusion into Lebanon have, passed through thissmall town four miles from the Israeli border. But no one seems sure what the Syrians are up to.

description: JIDDA:. Saudi Arabia, April 13The Saudi Air Force transport plane that was forced down in Israel yesterday returned without further incident to Saudi Arabia today.

title: Schatzki Book and Print Store Is Closing
description: All over New York, and for that matter all over the world, there are people in ones and twos who swear by Walter Schatzki, and by the printcumbookstore he runs at 153 East 57th Street.

description: ALBANY, April 13  The State Senate tonight turned down Governor Carey's nomination of Herman Schwartz as chairman of the Commission of Correction.

But there are enough such virtuosos, doggedly replowing the standard repertory. Mr. Zukofsky has refreshingly staked out a fertile turf of his owncontemporary music for the violin, and especially contemporary American music. At that, it's safe to say there are better.

The speech was Mr. Johnson at his besthomely, compassionate, audacious, and noblea hard, practical appeal embedded in a strong moral statement.

title: People and Business
description: How does it feel to owe $23.4 million and not have it? Robert F. Schlifer, a stock broker, came close to finding out.

title: 'River Niger' a Screen Disappointment
description: "The River Niger" is the screen version of Joseph A. Walker's award-winning Negro Ensemble Company play that opened off Broadway in 1972 and later went on to have a successful run on Broadway. Now it's virtually an object lesson in how not to make a movie out of a theater piece.Among other things one should not do is to open up the play to take advantage of the camera's mobility. The people who made "The River Niger" have opened it, all right, then they've left it opened upexposed and sort of gapingso that while the actors act, the director directs and the cameraman practices tricks used better by other cameramen, the life of the work has passed on to that great theatrical warehouse in the sky."The River Niger" is essentially a black variation of the kind of family play that Arthur Miller once wrote, about fathers and sons and husbands and wives, at a crucial moment of reckoning in their lives. It's about such a moment in the life of Johnny Williams (James Earl Jones), a house painter who writes poetry, his wife, Mattie (Cicely Tyson), and their son Jeff (Glynn Turman), who is coming home after what his parents believe to have been a successful tour of duty as an Air Force navigator.Jeff, however, has not been entirely truthful with his parents. He was cashiered from officer's training school for refusing to play the role of "Supernigger" for the white officers. Neither has Mattie been entirely truthful to Jeff and her husband. She's dying of cancer, while Johnny, when he isn't painting a house or writing a poem, is a bit of a lush.There are further problems, especially a subplot involving some old friends of Jeff's who have formed a black revolutionary army of four, one of whom is apparently a police informer.What really wrecks the screen version of "The River Niger" is not the on-screen melodrama that once was mostly offstagethough it is pretty dopeybut what appears to be a total lack of cohesive style and cinematic intelligence.I have no idea whether the responsibility is that of Mr. Walker, who adapted his play for the screen, of the director, Krishna Shah, who at times seems to have no idea where his camera should be, or of the editor, Irving Lerner, who may have done the best he could with the footage he was given. Many times two successive shots within a single scene don't match and, worse, characters have a way of leaving a scene without making a conventional exit.The actors have the air of people who've arrived at a party where there's no host. They are on their own. Mr. Jones, one of our finest actors, plays it big, sometimes explosively so, as if he knew things were going on around him that we don't. Miss Tyson carries her nobility around the sets with grim determination, looking like the housewife who says her bulging, 200-pound shopping bag isn't a bit heavy.Perhaps because he doesn't try so hard, Mr. Turman, who was so effective in "Cooley High," is less offensive, though Hilda Haynes, as the grandmother, is little more than a sight gag, and she doesn't try at all.Lou Gossett, as the family friend, a doctor whose roots are in the West Indies, is the one cast member not to be compromised by the mess around him.There are not so many decent black films that the failure of a property like "The River Niger" can be accepted as anything but a major disappointment.

title: New Jersey Bitiefs
description: Judge Jacques H. Gascoyne of the Morris County Court ordered the 19squaremile community of Montville Township to draft its zoning ordinance to provide for its fair share of housing for people with low and moderate incomes and to provide for adequate varieties of housing choices. The township thus became one of the first communities in New Jersey to be adjudged not in compliance with the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decision one year ago. That decision declared unconstitutional zoning ordinances that excluded lowincome families through such requirements as minimum lot sizes and number of rooms, and through prohibition of multifamily housing. The judge gave the township until next Jan. 31 to redraft its master plan.

title: Japan's High Court Rules That Nation's Election System Is Unconstitutional
description: TOKYO, April 14The Supreme Court of Japan declared the nation's election procedures unconstitutional today on the ground that they failed to provide equal representation for voters or to give equal weight to each vote.

title: Jersey Police Head Opposed to Casinos
description: TRENTON, April 14  The head of the New Jersey state police, Col. Clinton L. Pagano, warned a committee of the Legislature today that organized crime would almost certainly move in on the gambling casinos proposed as a way to rescue Atlantic City from its economic collapse.

title: Hofstra Wins, 107
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 14 Rallying from a 50 deficit early in the second period, Hofstra defeated Washington and Lee, 107 in Lacrosse tonight at the winner's field. Dow, 63, at the half, Hofstra outscored the Generals, 51, in the third quarter to take control of the game. Rich Stoecker led Hofstra with three goals and two assists.

title: PROFITS UP 2H% AT PHILIP MORRIS
description: Philip Morris, Inc., the cigarette producer, reported yesterday a 27.6 percent increase in firstquarter earnings on revenue gain of 17.8 percent, continuing an unbroken record of quarterly results for 12 years,

title: Dutch Get Lockheed File
description: WASHINGTON, April 14, (Reuters)The Justice Depart, ment said today it had turned over to the Netherlands Government everything in its files on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation payoff scandal. The information is meant for a commission to determine whether Lockheed made illegal payments to Dutch officials.

title: Sextuplets Are Born; Two Die in Britain
description: NEWCASTLEUPONFYNE, England, April 14 (UPI)A teacher's wife gave birth to sextuplets, but two girls died, a spokesman at the maternity hospital here said tcday.

title: Plainfield, Site of 1967 RaCial Disorder, Emerges as AllAmerican City for 1976
description: PLAINFIELD, April 14  This Union County community of 47,000 persons has come a long way.

title: Soviet Jews Mark Passover
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (AP)Jewish sources said 1,000 Jews attended Passover services at the Moscow synagogue today. The Soviet press agency Tass said services took place in 90 synagogues throughout the Soviet Union and that there were 60,000 practicing Jews out of total Jewish population of over two million, The weekly New Times said 10 men were training to become rabbis.

title: Cassidy Stops Cochran
description: Bobby Cassidy, of Levit town, LI. stopped Dennis Cochran of Toronto at two minutes 33 seconds of the third round of a scheduled 10round lightheavyweight fight last night at Sunnyside Garden for his 10th straight victory.

title: PLANE SAFETY PLAN ANNOUNCED BY U.S
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  The Government announced today a program under which pilots and others in the air industry can report nearcollisions and other safety problems without getting into trouble.

title: Aide Says Proxmire Let Wife Use Capitol Facilities for Tours
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Derhocrat:of Wisconsin, authorized the use of Congressional facilities about 30 times over the past five years for his wife's sightseeing business, an aide said today.

title: Air Crash Kills 2 in Jamaica
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 14 (AP)A twinengine. plane en route to Miami crashed today in the hills about 35 miles east of Montego Bay and the bodies of two men were found in the wreckage.

title: Strike Stalis Japan Transit
description: TOKYO. April 14 (UPI)Transportation workers walked) off their jobs today to demand more money and to protest the handling of the Lockheed payoff scandal in Japan.

title: Threat Called a Bluff
description: MANILA, April 14 (UPI)The president of Philippine Air Lines said today that the hijackers had been bluffing when they threatened to blow up the plane. The executive, Benigno Toda Jr., said that the hijackers had only two pistols, having surrendered their hand grenades during negotiations in Bangkok.

title: Hothouse
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 14About 4.000 fat and flourishing rainbow trout, pampered and specially fed by indulgent caretakers, were shipped today from an experimental project at a utility company's power plant here on the Delaware River to the real world of anglers and natural predators_

title: Budget Goal Met
description: New York State announced the successful completion of its $4 billion spring borrowing late yesterday, although the effort to self large quantities of shortterm notes to outofstate banks and corporations was likely to fall short of the state's goal. The shortfall was scheduled to be made up by additional investments from state employee nension funds. Page 22.

title: KISSINGER WARNS SYRIAN ACTS TEST ISRAEL'S PATIENCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that recent Syrian military movements into Lebanon were getting very close to the borderline of Israeli tolerance. He warned that despite some political progress made in Beirut, the situation could blow up tomorrow.

title: CONGRESS BEGINS EASTER RECESS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPIThe 94th Congress left today for a 12day Easter recess. It has completed threequarters of its tenure; if the gnat for final adjournment by Oct 2 is met.

title: 5 Brown Supporters Shift Their Backing to Carter
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI) Five former supporters of California Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that they would support Jimmy Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination, saying Mr. Brown is a standin for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota.

title: Plane Hijackers Surrender in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, April 14 (UPI)Three Philippine Moslems who hijacked an airliner over the southern part of their country a week ago freed their 12 hostages here today and surrendered to Libyan authorities.

title: On Waiving Immunity
description: Late in the 16th century, Thomas Hobson, an English liveryman who catered to Cambridge University students, would show his customers a wide choice of horses, but then forced them to take the horse nearest the stable door.

title: Union Carbide to Expand
description: BUFFALO, April 14 (AP)The Union Carbide Company plans an expansion of its Linde Division plant in the nearby town of Tonawanda, James V. Ryan, the town supervisor, disclosed the plans today at news conference. A Union Carbide spokesman later confirmed tho plans, but declined coinmrnt on the cost of the project or how many jobs it would add.

title: Spurs Beat Nets, 111103, For 21 Lead
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 14The San Antonio Spurs, with the earpiercing screams of an arenaful of partisans behind them, defeated the New York Nets tonight, 111103, to take a 21 lead in the American Basketball Association semifinals.

title: Beanie Is Assailed on Superagencies
description: The City Council leadership accused the Beanie administration yesterday of footdragging in reorganizing the superagencies.

title: News Broadcasts
description: All News: WCBS. WINS, WNWS. Hourly on the Hour. WOXH,.. WILK, WMCA. WNBC. WNCN, WNEWAM, WOR. WSOU. Five Minutes to the Hour. WABC also five minutes to the half. hour),WNYC, WPIX, WRFM. Fifteen Minutes Past the Hoar

title: 37 Are Killed in Crash Of Argentine Oil Plane
description: BUENOS AIRES April 14 (AP)  A plane owned by tie Argentine state oil company crashed today in southern Argentina, killing ail 37 people aboard, the author??es ruorted.

title: Clark Resolution Asks Increase In Senate's Role on Agreements
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Senate is being asked, to change its rules to require that all major international agreements be approved by a twothirds Senate vote before becoming effective.

title: Problems Still Plague Boston Tower
description: BOSTON. Apirl 14  This time it was an electric drill head that flew out of the hands of a workman installing Venetian blinds. And there, early yesterday morning, went another window on the John Hancock Tower.

title: Mrs. Bristol, Kinard Badminton Victors
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 Mrs. Pain Bristol of Flint, Mich.. and Chris Kinard of Pasadena, Calif., regained the singles titles in the 36th United States amateur badminton championships today at the Drexel University fieldhouse.

title: Ice on a Hot Stove: II
description: DAVIS, Calif.You ask him the time, and you get a history of water clocks. That quip, by a liberal critic of Jerry Brown, sums up one complaint about his performance as Governor: that by calling for a deeper look at issues before government acts, as he often does, he fails to meet immediate needs.

title: City May Ease Eligibility for Day Care
description: The city agreed yesterday to work with the state to establish new daycare eligibility schedules to enable fourperson families, for instance, with pretax incomes of $14,605 a year to be eligible, as against a current limit of $11,411. The increased cost would have to be absorbed by the city.

title: Need for Social Change Is Seen by Club of Rome
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14The world can avoid a catas trophe only by substantially changing its social and political institutions as well as its growth patterns, according tc a concensus of the latest studies by the Club of Rome, a private group of about 100 businessmen and scholars concerned with the future of man.

title: Bella Spewack, Comedy Author, Prefers Tragedy
description: A day after the opening of the Broadway revival of Boy Meets Girl, the 1935 farce she wrote with her late husband, Bella Spewack flicked cigarette ashes into a wastebasket, bounced off and on her living room sofa and said despite a lifetime of writing fastpaced comedies, she preferred tragedies. But, she added, tragedies do not sell.

title: NEW YORK MEETS BORROWING GOAL
description: State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, announced late yesterday that the state had successfully completed $4 billion in spring borrowing, although the effort to sell large quantities of shortterm nqtes to outofstate banks and corporations was likely to fall somewhat snort of the state's goal. The shortfall was made up when the trustees of the Teachers Retirement System, a state pension fund, voted yesterday afternoon to buy $200 million worth of state notes.

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Wayne L. Hays, the 14term Ohio Democrat, made public yesterday his marriage in Arlington, Va., Tuesday to Patricia E. Peak, a longtime associate who has been administrative secretary in his Ohio office. A reception followed in what has been described as the most elegant room in the Capitolthe thirdfloor Rotunda meeting room of the House Administration Committee, of which Mr. Hays is chairman. The room faces the White House. The bride, said to be in her 40's, is a sister of Paula Peak, the committee's deputy staff director. The 64yearold Representative and his first wife, Martha, married in 1937 and were divorced recently after a long separation.

title: NEW BODY CLUES PICKED UP IN POND
description: Portions of human skeletons large enough to indicate sex and approximate age have been discovered by investigators for Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold in a renewed search of Briscoe Pond in the southern Catskills, where the skeletal remains of two young girls had been found in previous searches.

title: Britain's Unions Unlikely to Accept 3% Limit on Wage Increases
description: LONDON, April 14Britain's trade union leadership suggested today that it would not accept the 3 percent ceiling on annual wage increases that the Government proposed last week.

title: Retail Executive Likely To Head Discount Group
description: Richard I. Hersh, executive vice president of the Metropolitan New York Retail Merchants Association, which represents more than 20 of New York's largest retailers, is expected soon to be named president of the Mass Retailing Institute, the discount retailer's national trade association, reliable sources indicated yesterday.

title: Judge William Hastie, 71, Of Federal Court, Dies
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP)Judge William H. Hastie, the first black appointed to a Federal appeals court judgeship and a former Governor of the Virgin Islands, died today at Suburban General Hospital in East Norriton. He was 71 years old.

title: Stavisky Bill Backers Act To Ease Burden on City
description: ALBANY, April 14Backers of the StaviskyGoodman schoolaid bill, which became law early this morning as the State Senate overrode Governor Carey's veto, made plans today fur amendments that would assure more money to schools without necessarily binding New York City to allot a fixed portion of its budget to education.

title: Prisoner Hangs Herself
description: CRANSTON, R.I., April 14 (AP)Cheryl flumes, facing lift imprisonment for the murder of her husband, comnutted suicide today by hanging hermit in her prison cell, prison aide said. There had been no Indication at all [that she would kill herself], Lillian McDaniel said. She seemed agitated but not desvondent,

title: PARLEY ON CYPRUS IS NEAR COLLAPSE
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 121 Procedural squabbles between! ethnic Greeks and Turks have again brought the Cyprus peace talks to the edge of collapse.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WELCOME BACK Walt Disney's Fantasia (1940) and Alice in Wonderland (1951) are back as family entertainment over the spring holidays, and there is a free showing today of another classic, the Sovietmade Alexander Nevsky (1939), at a midtown library.

title: RCA FirstQuarter Net Up 101%
description: With that bullish report, Anthony L. Conrad, who took over as president and chief executive officer of the giant electronics company with the Nov. 5 resignation of Robert W. Sarnoff, held yesterday, his first press luncheon at the company headquarters, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: DR. LOEWENSTEIN, PSYCHOANALYST, 78
description: Dr. Rudolph M. Loewenstein, a retired psychoanalyst, died yesterday at the Isabella Home, Amsterdam Avenue and 190th Street. He was 78 years old and lived at 1148 Fifth Avenue.

title: Jury Fines Doctor For Pulling Stitches Over an Unpaid Bill
description: MARION, Ala., April 14 (AP) An allwhite jury has awarded damages of $20 in a $50,000 suit filed on behalf of a black youth who contended that a doctor after stitching a cut in his arm, took out the sutures immediately when the boy's full bill could not be paid on the spot. me veraict was returnea in Perry County Court in the case of Melvin Armstrong, 13 years old, of Uniontown. The youth's father, Robert Armstrong, a farm laborer with 12 children, filed suit against Dr. Bobby Merkle, charging assault and battery. Dr. Merkle was ordered to pay the $20.

title: Nine Jailed in Yugoslavia
description: HAMM LUKA, Yugoslavia, April 14 (Reuter)Nine pro. Soviet dissidents were senfenced here today to prison terms ranging from three to 12 years for crimes against the state.

title: U.S. DENIES JORDAN DROPS MISSILE DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The State Department said today that negotiations to sell Jordan an airdefense system were very much alive alfinancial arrange ments had become more complicated and timeconsuming than originally contemplated.

title: STADIUM'S COSTS NOW SEEN AS LOSS
description: In 1971, when Mayor John V. Lintlsay was urging Yankee Stadium's renovation, the City Council President, Sanford D. Garelik, said: The stadium is going to cost the city $24 million and six judgeships.

title: Japanese Regret Extension of Fishing Limits by U.S
description: TOKYO April 14 (AP)Japan's Foreign Ministry said today it regretted the unilateral American action in extending its fishing waters to 200 miles offshore. It said the move could produce big adverse effects on the current international efforts at the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 15, 1976

title: 40 Yankees Doodle Dandily in Old London
description: LONDON, April 14A high school band from Fairfield, Conn., made a bow to history today and created a bit of its own when it played a lunchtime concert near St. Paul's Cathedral as a gesture of friendship to the British in the Bicentennial year.

title: Kleppe Acts to Bar Dams On North Carolina River
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Secretary of the Interior Thomas S. Kleppe formally signed papers today designating 26.5mile stretch of the New River in northwest North Carolina to he a component of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: NURSINGHOME UNION BARS STRIKE DELAY
description: Delegates representing 12,000 nursinghome employees in the metropolitan area turned down a request yesterday that they put off a strike set for tomorrow in their longdrawnout dispute over a wage increase and retroactive pay due under their current contract.

title: New British Prime Minister Lists 22 MiddleRank Shifts
description: LONDON, April 14 (AP)Prime Minister James Callaghan announced 22 middlerank changes in his Government today, nine days after succeeding Harold Wilson as Labor Party leader and head of Government.

title: Chamber Unit Host to Miss Chung
description: KyungWha Chung, the Korean violinist, was the principal guest of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center for its concert at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday night and she participated in three worksBeethoven's Trio No. 3 in C minor (Op. 1), Franck's Sonata in A for Violin and Piano and Stravinsky's arrangement for violin, clarinet and pi?no of music from his L'Histoire du Soldat.

title: Will the West Coast Eligibles Run for the Roses?
description: The only West Coast possibilities for the Kentucky Derby will be part of a ninehorse field in this Saturday's $200,000  added Hollywood Derby at Hollywood Park in the Los Angeles suburb of Inglewood.

title: JOSEPH R. MARES, 73, A CHEMICALS EXPERT
description: Joseph R. Mares, a petrochemical consultant and former chemicalcompany executive, died Tuesday at his home in Dickinson, Tex. He was 73 years old.

title: LOS ANGELES FACES NEW TRANSIT VOTE
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14Voters in sprawling, populous Los Angeles County, which once had one of the world's most extensive rail mass transit networks, will be offered their third chance in eight years to consider a rebuilding of the transit system.

title: Prisoner Hangs Herself
description: CRANSTON, R.I., April 14 (AP)Cheryl Humes, facing lite imprisonment for the murder of her husband, cnnimilted suicide today by hanging herself in her prison cell, prison nide said. There had been no indication at kill that she would kill herself, Lillian McDaniel saki. She seeined agitated but not despondent.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO. April 14 (UPI)Striking workers tried without success to shut down City Hall today jostling and abusing nonstriking workers and others entering the building.

title: GUNMAN IS KILLED AT A FAMILY SEDER
description: One of two armed men pcsing as flower deliverers was fatally shot and a police officer was wounded last night in shootout in an apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, where the gunmen had attempted to rob a family that had just begun its Passover seder, the police reported.

description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday. Condon: MarnIna 919100 0127,90, down $020; afternoon fiXine 112730, down $0.40.

title: Personal Finance: Shopping for Bargains in Bank Credit Cards
description: The decision earlier this month by Citibank to impose a service fee on users of its Master Charge credit cards who do not pay a finance charge took many consumers by surprise. At least for the short run, it may give those who use such bank cards an opportunity to shop around for a bargain. Master Charge, one of the two major bank creditcard systems, is administered by the Interbank Card Association, a group of 7,342 banks across the country. The 37 million cardholders of the member banks spent $11.3 billion last year with their

title: Miss Hearst to Cooperate In Prosecution of Harrises
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14Patricia Hearst has agreed to testify against William and Emily Harris and other members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army in an apparent move to gain judicial leniency in a number of cases in which she is involved.

title: WILLIAM S. TAYLOR
description: William Sentman Taylor, professor emeritus of psychology at Smith College, died Monday in Cooley Dickinson Hospital, Northampton, Mass. His age was 82.

title: ILLNESS DELAYS TRIAL OF HARR1SES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14The illness of Patricia Hearst today forced the postponement for at least one week of her appearance in Los Angeles to start court proceedings in a case involving William and Emily Harris, her codefendants.

title: Business Briefs
description: WACO, Tex., April 14The president of the American Farm Bureau Federation armounced today that a settlement had been reached between the maritime unions involved in last fall's boycott of the American grain bound for the Soviet Union and the National Labor Relations Boa rd.

title: Cyprus: Still the Key
description: In an effort to defuse antiAmerican passion in Greece and disarm antiTurkish sentiment on Capitol Hill, the Administration is ready to initial a fouryear military aid agreement with Athens roughly parallel to the one concluded with Turkey last month. If approved by Congress, the pact would provide $700 million in military aid to Greece over a fouryear period and continued American use of four military installations in that country.

title: Miss Goolagong Forced To Three Sets on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 Evonne Goolagong of Australia was forced to three sets tonight before subduing Marita Redondo, 64, 5.7, 64, in the gold division of the. $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament.

title: Worker Accused of Threat
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 14 P. Brandmaier, 34 years old, an Indianapolis winker was indicted today for allegedly makiag a threat agaml the life of President 1 ni 1. Federal agents charged Ih it ho had told fellow emhl Tres at the soft drink botthng company he would shoot Mr. Ford right between the eyes, when he visited Indianapolis.

title: Paners
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Declining readership is the major problem: faced by newspapers today, according to a poll of leading editors from across the country.

April 14About 4,000 fat and flourishing rainbow trout, pampered and specially fed by indulgent caretakers, were shipped today from an experimental project at a utility company's power plant here on the Delaware River to the real world of anglers and natural predators.

title: CHURCH VOTE BACKS SELECTION OF SPONG
description: the standing committee of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark unanimously approved yesterday the election of the Rev. Juhn S. Soong as Bishop Coadjutor of the diocese, which includes 135 parishes in eight northern New Jersey counties.

title: Mets Get 3d Loss By 1 Run
description: CHICAGO, April 14Legs proved the difference today in balmy Wrigley Field.

title: Stocks on Amex End Day Mixed; Counter Trend Is Also Indecisive
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed mixed yesterday in continued light trading.

title: Kosygin, in Message to Hua. Calls For Better Relations
description: MOSCOW. April 14 (AP)Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin has sent a telegram of congratulation to China's new Prime. Minister, 11tt Kuofeng, in which the Soviet Union says it is prepared to normalize relations, lass reported today.

title: CHRYSLER POSTS A $12 MILLION NET
description: DETROIT, April 14  The Chrysler Corporation reported today that it had returned to a profitable basis in the first quarter, after having sustained 18 months of deficits. The company announced a net income of $72 million, or $1.20 a share, after a $15 million tax credit, for the three months to March 31. In the first quarter of last year Chrysler's net loss reached $94.1 million.

title: Fire Damages Resort
description: The Suomi Hovi Hotel, an old resort at Nolan's Point in Lake Hopatcong, N.J., was extensively damaged last night by a fire of undetermined origin, according to the Nolan's Point police. The building was still closed from last summer's trade and no one was reported injured in the blaze

title: 5 MORE ARGENTINES SLAIN BY TERRORISTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 14 (AP)Gunmen killed a Chrysler Corporation executive. navy captain end three policemen today.

title: Teamster Aide to Retire
description: DETROIT, April 14 (UPI)David Johnson, the president of FeLimsters Local 299 who once hoped to step aside to make room for James R. floffa to climb hack to the top power position in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that he will retire July I. Mr. Johnson, 69 years old, has been active in the union for more than half a century. Mr. floffa disappeared last July 30 and is presumed dead at the hands of his enemies.

title: Islanders Hampered By Injuries
description: When a man who had suffered a concussion barely an hour and a half earlier is the best replacement for a teammate whose injured finger and jammed knee impairs his faceoff abilities, a team can be said to be hurting.

title: $250,000 Donated to Whitney to Buy Art
description: A grant of 5250.000 for the purchase of work by Iiing American artists has been given to the Whitney Mu, seum of American Art by an artcollecting couple, France and Sydney Lewis of Richmond.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Caretakers Named For Hughes Affairs
description: HOUSTON, April 14Lawyers for Howard R. Hughes's closest associates moved in three states today to join with the late billionaire's relatives for an orderly disposition of his estate.

title: Chess
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, April 14Efim Geller of the Soviet Union and Gudmundur Sigurjonsson of Iceland are tied for the lead with 5 points in seven rounds in the fifth Las Palmas international tournament here in the Santa Catalina Hotel.

title: Yanks Go Home Again Today, to Bronx
description: Freshly shorn and scrubbed, the Yankees will end their two years of wandering in the wasteland of Flushing Meadow today when they return to their promised land and open Yankee Stadium II.

title: A Juclge Refuses to Dismiss Indictments of Susan Saxe
description: BOSTON, April 14 (UPI)A trial judgo today refused to dismiss murder and hank tri!)Ivry indictments against Susan B. Saxe.

title: Crosland to Visit China
description: LOND0N, April 14 (Reuters) Britain's new Foreign Spi'lary, Anthnny Crosland, will visit China and Japan fnr talks from May 2 to II, Ihr Foreign Ofcee announced today.

title: Market Weakens in Moderate Trading; TaxExempts Pace Rise in Bond Prices
description: Good to excellent firstquarter earnings reports notwithstanding, the stock market closed lower yesterday. The decline, carried out in moderate trading activity, almost erased Tuesday's technical upturn.

title: GEORGE G. CONNELLY TAUGHT AT WILLIAMS
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., April 14 George G. Connelly, retired Williams College professor and a columnist for The Berkshire Eagle, Wed today at Anne Arundel General Hospital in Annapolis, Md., following complications after recent surgery. He was 75 years old.

title: FRANCE STARTING 78 ELECTION NOR
description: PARIS, April 15French politicians, in a drastic departure from custom, have proclaimed that the campaign for the next national election is on although the voting is not scheduled until the spring of 1978.

title: Plaza's Old Elevators Wheezing to a Halt
description: A cluster of hydraulic passenger elevators in the Plaza Hotel, among the most elegant and among the last of their kind in the city, are on their way to a technological graveyard.

title: NewIssue Sales and Fed Buying Help
description: The bond market, helped by Federal Reserve purchases and by an enthusiatic reception for new taxexempt bond issues, continued to advance in price yesterday. Though there was some wavering in the corporate sector, the bond market's extended move toward lower interest rates, which began at the start of this month, remained intact.

title: Stavisky Bill Backers Act To Ease Burden on City
description: ALBANY, April 14Backers of the StaviskyGoodman schoolaid bill, which became law early this morning as the State Senate overrode Governor Carey's veto, made plans today for amendments that would assure more money to schools without necessarily binding New York City to allot a fixed portion of its budget to education.

title: Hughes Asks Stiffer Sentences For ViolentCrime Convictions
description: TRENTON, April 14New Jersey's top judge, Richard J. Hughes, said today that he intended to do everything in his power to get longer prison sentences for violent criminals.

title: Great Western Sugar Co in Farm Pact
description: DENVER, April 14 (AP)The Great Western Sugar Company, the nation's secondlargest sugar refiner after the Amstar Corporation and beet growers in five Western states reached tentative agreement today on a new contract, avoiding what industry sources said could have been an increase in sugar prices to consumers.

title: U.S. Carrier Joins Force In Waters Near Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  The aircraft carrier Saratoga has joined the amphibious task force engaging in what the Pentagon calls normal movements in the Mediterranean near Lebanon.

title: GASOLINE STOCKS OFF FROM EARLIER WEEK
description: Gasoline stocks declined in the week ended April 9 to 235.68 million barrels from 237.96 million barrels in the weekearlier period and 241.08 million barrels in the comparable week of 1975, according to statistics issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Giants Are Happy To Leave Houston
description: The San Francisco Giants were happy to leave Houston's Astrodome last night after losing to the Astros, 53. The victory gave Houston a sweep of the threecame series.

title: Moscow Is Said to Modify Expectations of Detente
description: MOSCOW, April 14The antidetente sentiments running through the American Presidential campaign have begun to stimulate shifts in the mood in Moscow.

title: U.S. Is Bolstering Nuclear Force to Survive Attack and Then Destroy Enemy
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, NebraskaThe United States has begun a farreaching program to improve its strategic nuclear forces. The basic objectives are to improve the chances of the survival of the ICBM system in a nuclear war, to increase flexibility In targeting and to increase effectiveness through greater striking power and accuracy.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK
description: PARIS, April 11At the fall readytowear showings here, designers obviously gave more thought tetheatrics than to clothes.

title: ILLNESS DELAYS TRIAL OF HARRISES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14The illness of Patricia Hearst today forced the postponement for at least one week of her appearance in Los Angeles to start court proceedings in case involving William and Harris, her codefendents.

title: Electoral Compromise
description: The HouseSenate conferees reached a reasonable compromise on the bill reconstituting the Federal Election Commission. The House receded somewhat on the seriously objectionable features of its bill. Those provisions would have forced the commission to submit all of Its proposed regulations and advisory opinions Congress not only for review but also for possible wordbyword item veto. The compromise permits the commission to issue advisory opinions on specific factual situations but not of a general nature without submitting them to Congress.

title: Palmer Cards 63
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 14 (UPI)  Arnold Palmer pbsted a 63, tying the course record at Killearn Country Club and won the pro title today in the proamateur event preceding tomorrow's opening round of the Tallahassee open.

title: 5 Suspended in W.H.A. Brawl
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 14 (AP)The World Hockey Association suspended Coarh Joe Crozier and Rick Jodzio of the Calgary Cowboys indefinitely today for their roles in a brawl during the second game of the playoff series between the Cowboys and the Quebec Nordiaues.

title: Friends and Foes in Utah Surprised at Withdrawal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 14 Withdrawal today of the Southern California Edison Company's application to construct a threemillionkilowatt coalburning generating station on southeastern Utah's Kaiparowits Plateau surprised opponents and supporters of the project alike.

title: Leftists in Smith Lebanon Protest Syrian Incursion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14Palestinians and Lebanese leftists demonstrated today in southern port towns against Syria's armed presence in Lebanon, while in the north there were reports of defections from the left to the Syrian camp.

title: Stage: Negro Ensemble
description: Last week's play in the Negro Ensemble Company's series of studio productions, a seasonwithinaseason, never should have left the author's typewriter. This week's offering, Samm Williams's A Love Play, on the other hand, belongs exactly where it isin a workshop.

description: The Control Data Coporation! .ntroduced yesterday a compti: terbased education system, called Plato, that appears to be the largest and most sophisticated commercial attempt yet to utilize computer technology in the educational process.

title: Britain's Payments in Surplus By $186 Million During March
description: LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) Britain announced today a balance of payments surplus of $186 million for Marchthe country's best performance in more than five years.

title: ZUZU ANGEL IS DEAD; BRAZILIAN DESIGNER
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14 (AP)Zuzu Angel, the fashion designer who dressed such stars as Joan Crawford, Kim Novak and Dame Margot Fonteyn, died last night in an auto accident.

title: A Good Friday Hymn Being Questioned
description: A portion of Roman Catholic liturgy for Good Friday that, was apparently overlooked in recent efforts to remove bias against Jews from the ritual is becoming a subject of growing concern among those who believe it contains the seeds of antiSemitism.

title: Rev. Alexander Purdy, 85, ExDean of Earlham College
description: The Rev. Alexander C. Purdy, former dean and acting president of Ear'ham College in Richmond, Ind., died Saturday in Swarthmore, Pa., where he lived. He was 85 years old.

title: STEIN URGES CHANGE IN INCOME TAX CODE
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, Democrat of Manhattan, called yesterday for an amendment to the Internal Revenue code that would permit New Yorkers who take the standard deduction in computing their Federal income tax to receive an added allowance for state and city taxes they pay.

title: Sakharovs Detained in Soviet on Charge of Hitting Policemen
description: MOSCOW, April 14Andrei D. Sakharov, who won the Nobel Peace Prize last year for his outspoken defense of human rights, was detained by the police today in the Siberian city of Omsk after he had tried to attend the trial of a Tatar nationalist accused of slandering the Soviet state.

title: . . . School Deception
description: In its precipitous override of Governor Carey's veto of the Stavisky bill, the State Senate has stooped to false promise to aid the city's schools. The action offers lint the slightest hint how that promise is to be redeemed. The new law's requirement to restore $150 million next year's school budget disposes of funds which simply do not exist. They could only be found by slashing other services.

description: Two things are certain around this time of year: income taxes and Bloomingdale's spring model rooms. Both, have been known to separate New Yorkers from their money.

title: KISSINGER WARNS SYRIAN ACTS TEST ISRAEL'S PATIENCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that recent Syrian military movements into Lebanon were getting very close to the borderline of Israeli tolerance. He warned that despite some political progress made in Beirut, the situation could blow no tomorrow.

title: $1 MILLION IN GEMS STOLEN IN FLORIDA
description: PALM BEACH, Fla. April 14 (UPI)Three masked gunmen overpowered two guards and a switchboard operator at the Palm Beach Towers condominium today and escaped with Jewelry estimated to ho worth $1 million.

title: The Wrong Trumpet
description: President Ford fired former Defense Secretary Schlesinger in November in order to trim back his spending plans and avoid a major Congressional struggle over the defense budget. In the event, little trimming was done; and the expected Congressional struggle has failed materialize. In fact, Congress has virtually abdicated responsibility for a meaningful defense review.

title: Strikers Are Pawns to Some in Meriden
description: MERIDEN, Conn., April 14As this city's 580 striking teachers marched on picket lines for the sixth day today, some said they felt they were pawns in a complex game of power politics that did not concern them.

title: Lung Collapse Termed Common Among Young
description: PALO ALTO. Calif., April 14 (AP)A lung collapse such as the one suffered by Patricia Hearst is fairly common among young people and often can he repaired without major medical effort, a respiratory specialist says.

title: ZUMWALT SCORES RICKOVER IN BOOK
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, with his emphasis upon constructing expensive, nuclearpowered ships, has become a malady afflicting and distorting the Navy, in the opinion of Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the former Chief of Naval Operations.

title: CONGRESS IS SILENT; CAIRO ARMS DEAL ON
description: WASHINGTON. April 14 (Reuters)Congress went !!,to recess today without acting on President Ford's request to sell Egypt six C130 military transport planes, thereby giving tacit approval to the S65 million arms deal.

title: PROBST PICKETING AND WORKING, TOO
description: In a case of dhlided loyalties, Leonard Probst, the critic and producer for NBC Radio, is walking a picket line as part of the strike by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, while still reviewing plays on the padio for NBC's News and Information Service.

title: DOLLAR IS MIXED IN TRADING ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS. April 15 (UPI)The Italian lira improved almost I percent against the dollar in Milan today following moves by the Government to bolster Its value and earlier support by the Bank of Italy. The dollar was mixed in European markets.

title: John R. Stiles, Manager Of Ford's Congress Drives
description: BELMONT, Mich., April 15 (AP)  John R. Stiles, President Ford's campaign manager in his first hid for elective office and currently a special adviser to the President's election campaign, was found dead today beside his wrecked car, which had apparently struck a metal post, according to Kent County Sheriff's deputies. He was 59 years old.

title: Carter Is Said to Possess A Slim Pennsylvania Lead
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 15 Jimmy Carter appears to have built a fragile lead over his two main rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination in Pennsylvania's possibly decisive April 27 primary.

title: PENTAGON RESUMES NORTHROP PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Defense Department announced today that it had resumed final contract payments to the Northrop Corporation following an agreement by the company to reimburse the Government for $2.3 million in unallowable costs for political contributions, entertainment and lobbying.

title: PicketLine Tyranny
description: The three major active candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination cast doubt on both their judgment and their political courage by surrendering mindlessly this week to the keepout tyranny of pickets involved in a labormanagement dispute that had nothing whatever to do with the group all three had promised to address or even with the hotel in which the group was meeting.

title: Sue Barker Scores an Upset Over Miss Wade at Coast Net
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13Sue Barker has finally beaten Virginia Wade, the British Wightman Cup captain, after so many times of coming close. The No. 2 English star triumphed in an incredible match that had a hundred spectators at the Sport Arena still cheering at 2 o'clock this morning. The young wom an trom Devon, who is tour days short of her 20th birthday, took the first set 75, led, 52, in the second and in a comedy of strange calls that prompted Queen Victorian stares from Miss Wade, took the match at 76 when a forehand by Miss Wade blooped out under the strain in the tiebreaker, won, 5.4.

title: Family Planning Unit Is Being Cut Sharply
description: The familyplanning program operated by the city's Department of Social Services is being cut back sharply. partly as an economy measure and partly because of substantial overlapping with services provided by other agencies.

title: City Charter Committee Mails Partial Refund to Contributors
description: Archibald L. Gillies's office telephone rang yesterday.

title: Nessen Says Canal Talks Defend
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Calling Ronald Reagan's attacks on the Panama Canal negotiations political rhetoric, Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said today that the negotiations were intended to defend American interests in the Canal and not to give away anything.

title: T.W.A. FreeBeer Idea Runs Afoul of the Law
description: NEWARK, April 15  A Trans World Airlines promotion promising free beer to inconvenienced passengers at Newark International Airport attracted two too many enthusiasts today.

description: ROME, April 15The Socialist Party today rejected a plan to avoid general elections this summer, intensifying Italy's political problems.

description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed yesterday to admit a limited number of public diners to its exclusive luncheon club atop the World Trade Center. The State Liquor Authority then issued a liquor license for the club and it will open next Monday, a week behind schedule.

description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 15(UPI)Topseeded Ken Rosewall defeated Geoff Masters, 6.2, 6.3, tonight to advance to the semifinal of a $60,000 tennis tournament.

(Middle of the Road) lists of record sales.

title: Paterson Farmer's Market Flowers
description: PATERSON, April 15That hardy perennial, the Paterson Farmer's Market is in bloom. Row on row of hyacinths, lilies azaleas chrysanthemums and countless other plants and flowers are arrayed in colorful profusion, shaded from the sun by gaily appointed umbrellas set up in tribute to the holiday season.

title: Taxi Drivers To Return To San Francisco Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP)The Yellow Cab Company, which operates the, city's largest taxi fleet, reached an agreement with striking drivers today that will put the company's 500 cabs back on the streets while mediated negotiations contnue.

title: Former Aide Says Hughes W rote Will And Put It in Bank
description: LOS ANGELES, April 15(AP)Howard R. Hughes, intending to leave his fortune to a medical foundation, wrote a will with alternate versions for each page, put it together in secret and placed it in a Hollywood safe deposit box, a former assistant said today.

title: The Oldest Dilemma
description: New York City is threatened not Just by bankruptcy but also, to hear many New Yorkers tell it, by prostitution. And in fact there's no doubt that the city's numerous streetwalkers have been moving out from their usual haunts around Times Square into quieter, more nearly residential neighborhoods.

title: CIRCULATION'S BASE OF PEOPLE TO RISE
description: Time Inc. shareholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting that the company's newest publication, People, effective with the July 19 issue this year would increase its circulation rate base from 1.6 million a week to 1.8 million a week.

title: Gen. David Elazar Dead; Israeli Chief in 1973 War
description: TEL AVIV, April 15Lieut. Gen David Elazar, commander of Israeli forces during the October war of 1973, died today of a heart attack while swimming in a pool near his home here. He was 50 years old.

title: State's Democrats to Pick 68 Delegates
description: More than 400 Democrats from all parts of New York State, representing virtually every shade of party opinion, have applied to their party's state committee for selection as atlarge delegates to the Democratic National Convention. The state will have 68 atlarge seats at the convention here in July.

title: Sinatra Comments on Report Inquiry on Him Was Barred
description: Frank Sinatra, the singer and actor, made his first comment yesterday on an article in The New York Times that reported that the Department of Justice under Robert F. Kennedy had rejected or ignored recommendations for a thorough investigation of the entertainer and his relationships with Mafia figures.

title: Quarter Net Loss At United Airlines Totals $43 Million
description: United Airlines, the nation's. largest air carrier, announced yesterday that its loss during, March totaled about $8 million,: bringing its deficit for the first! auarter to a record $43 million.!

title: PRICES IRREGULAR IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on theAmerican Stock Exchange ended mixed in pre holiday trading yesterday while those on the overthecounter market finished higher.

title: Loughlin Runners Take Title in TwoMile Relay
description: Power Memorial dropped the stick on the first leg and Archbishop Molloy had its third man suffer a muscle pull so with its chief opposition thus handicapped Bishop Loughlin went on to win the twomile championship relay easily yesterday in the Iona Relays at Mount St. Michael's track in the Bronx.

title: 12 SUSPECTS SEIZED IN GAMBLING RAIDS
description: After receiving complaints about a numbers racket from local residents, police officers in Queens raided a food market, a luncheonette and a private house in St. Albans yesterday and arrested 12 persons. The police said they believed that they had broken up a $5 millionayear gambling operation.

title: New York City Facing Hard Decision' On Wage Policy: Raise Pay or Fight
description: A handful of labor experts and city officials, now struggling to fashion a wage policy for 250,000 municipal workers, are in a debate the outcome of which could determine whether New York emerges from the fiscal crisis and in what shape.

title: Honor Code at West Point Focus of Renewed Turmoil
description: WEST POINT, April 15Cadet Stephen Verr said today that he would probably resign soon from the United States Military Academy, a victim, he said, of harassment by officers and cadets who have objected to his being cleared of an honorcode violation.

description: Eastern Airlines yesterday asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to postpone to May 15 the effective date of its request for a 2 percent general domestic passenger fare increase.

title: Top Editor of Ms. Finds Press Remiss On Women in News
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The managing editor of the magazine Ms. today told a group of newspaper editors, most of them males, that they must change the way they report news about women.

description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The Ford Administration has asked the Supreme Court to rule that a state may not require parental consent before allowing minors to receive contraceptives under welfare or Medicaid programs.

description: Beginning May 1, owners of multiple dwellings in New York City will be required to install window guards in all apartments containing children 10 years old or younger.

description: WASHINGTON, April 15The United States and Greece; announced agreement in principle today to allow the continued American use of four military facilities in Greece in return for $700 million in American military aid over the fouryear span of the accord.

description: Firstquarter earnings reports by bank holding companies yesterday included declines for the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, a loss for the Marine Midland Corporation and a record for the Continental Illinois Corporation.

description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15At a time when he had expected to be riding the crest of his victory in the New York Democratic Presidential primary toward a similar conquest in Pennsylvania, Senator Henry M. Jackson was working in a suite at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel here today trying desperately to raise money to keep his campaign moving.

description: TRENTON, April 15Gover'nor Byrne's executive order directing counties and municipalities to revamp zoning regulations so as to provide a fair share of housing for the poor, the elderly and families with small children has nettled some legislators.

description: The financially troubled Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust. the nation's largest real estate investment trust, reported yesterday sharply lower losses on its business for the third fiscal quarter and nine months ended Feb. 29.

description: In case anyone missed it in the glare of the sparkling edifice and the glittering personalities, there also was a baseball game at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Doctors Says Miss Hearst Has Slight Malnutrition
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 Patricia Hearst is suffering from slight malnutrition and perhaps from a liver disorder, in addition to the collapsed lung that led to her emergency surgery Tuesday night, her doctors said today.

title: Norway Abandons Bid for Extradition Of Memphis Woman
description: MEMPHIS, April 15 (AP)Norway has decided not to press for the extradition of a Memphis woman accused of having murdered the wife of a Spanish diplomat in Oslo two years ago.

title: Dow Rises by 5.83 to Close at 980.48
description: The stock market produced a mild rally yesterday as some issues responded affirmatively to favorable corporate news.

title: Castenad:t Is Victor In 10,000Meter Run
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 15 (AP)Ted Castenada of the Colorado Track Club opened the Kansas Relays today with a winning time of 29 minutes 17 seconds in the 10,000meter run.

title: Music: Two Premieres
description: The choice of programming was such that the first two pieces on last night's New York Philharmonic program had more than a few things in common. Leonard Bernstein conducted the United States premiere of Benjamin Britten's Suite on English Folk Tunes and the New York premiere of William Schuman's Concerto on Old English Rounds, and while one work could not be taken for the other, it most decidedly was a nostalgic evening of Merrie Englande.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15Rival forces bombarded each loftier in Beirut today with rockets, mortar rounds and light artillery fire as hostilities increased despite the armed truce proclaimed 13 days ago.

description: Gerald L. K. Smith, the antiCommunist lecturer and columnist and founder of the Christian National Crusade, died yesterday. Mr. Smith, a preacher whose political activism began with support of Huey P. Long In the 1930's, was 78 years old. Page 30.

description: WASHING ON, April 10, (UPI)Members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians said today that they were stunned when Senator Hubert H. Hum1 phrey addressed a meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors that they were ! picketing yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, April 15The United States Government's attitude toward Africa, long unfocused and drifting with events, has hardened since the crisis in Angola into determination to eliminate superpower conflict from black Africa.

They are vulgar, sophomoric selfsatisfied, literate, illiterate charmless, crass. subtle and absolutely terrific. They are the funniest thing ever to cmlle out of a television boxif, indeed, they have come nut of a television box. Services Park West, 115 W. 79 St., Sunday, April 18th at 10:00 A.M.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threeday strike by 250 employees at the Grossinger Hotel and Country Club ended as the Catskill Mountain resort prepared for the Passover holiday weekend. Paul Grossinger, president of the resort, announced that the striking members of Local 76, Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International Union had voted to return to work. Details of the new contract were not disclosed, but Mr. Grossinger said there had been certain compromises on both sides.

title: STATE BORROWING HAD ITS PROBLEMS
description: As recently as last weekend, New York State was falling so short in its critical spring borrowing drive that state fiscal aides convened a hurried meeting to come up with several other options as fallback uositions.

title: Suffolk Prosecutor Investigating Secret Report's Charges on Sewer Work
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., April 15The Suffolk County District Attorney is investigating a confidential report on the controversial 5700 million Southwest Sewer District charging improprieties in the project and raising questions about possible kickbacks.

title: They're Royal Rulers Without Magic Wands
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The rulers of Liechtenstein, who live in a 100room castle and tootle around their tiny principality in a Volkswagen, sat on a brocade sofa in a Georgetown drawing room for a sort of news conference. They talked about their lives in a country where, said the Princess, there is no discontent.

title: Leafs Stun Flyers With 54 Triumph
description: TORONTO, April 13 (UPI) The Toronto Maple Leafs broke a threeyear nonwinfling jinx against the Philadelphia Flyers with a 54 victory tonight in a fight and penaltymarred game of their National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff series, which Philadelphia still leads, 21.

title: Futures in Soybeans and Grain Climb on Midwest Exchanges
description: A late burst of buying lifted grain and soybean prices on the Midwest exchanges yesterday, shattering the caution that normally rules the market before the release of an important Government crop report.

It has also focused new attention on the relative powers of the central Board of Education and the locally elected hoards, which oversee the system's 32 decentralized community school diltricts.

Down four runs to none inside three innings, the good guys came on to win the first baseball game, 114. And so, in a confusion of mixed blessings, the wandering Yankees came home to the Bronx yesterday to be welcomed to their $100

title: Borg

The drawing will be on the 19761977 stamp, which everyone who hunts ducks or geese in the United States must purchase.

title: Fall in British Pound Creates A Host of Government Fears
