description: Longines, once a big name in broadcast advertising, is starting a comeback on the airwaves as part of its 1976 advertising programabout $4 million and just about double last year's.

title: Jerry Lewis Set For liellzapoppin
description: Jerry Lewis has agreed to star in a new production of Hellzapoppin, on Broadway next season under the sponsorship of Alexander H. Cohen. Although he has acted in, produced and directed more than 40 films, as well as appeared in nightclubs and on television, Mr. Lewis has never been in a legitimate Broadway show.

title: Chinese Attempting to Redirect Political Campaign
description: HONG KONG, April 15The Communist Party's committees In Peking, Tientsin and Shanghai, China's three largest cities, have called on their citizens to emphasize study and to promote production, apparently indicating that China's leaders are trying to bring the current political campaign under tight control.

title: Alcoa's Net Drops 21% but Sales Rise 12%, Meeting Is Told
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15The Aluminum Company of America's first,quarter net income trailed the yearago period by 21.5 percent, W. H. Krome. George, chairman, reported at the annual meeting here today.

title: Green Ahead In Golf
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., April 15(AP)Hubert Green, playing in the worst weather golf's touring pros have seen this year, managed a threeunderpar 69 today and took a twostroke lead in the $225,000 Tournament of Champions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERBOOKING STUDY. OF AIRLINES BEGUN
description: WASHINGTON. April 15The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it was conducting a new inquiry into the overbooking of seats by domestic airlines. It ordered the carriers to. report the degree to which, they sold or confirmed more; seats than were available in the expectation that a certain pertentage of travelers would not show up.

title: Auditors Said to Acquit U.M.W In a Financial Misconduct Study
description: WASHINGTON. April 15 (tJPI)Labor Department auditors have found no evidence to support charges of financial mismanagement by top officials of the United Mine Workers, department sources said today.

title: Honor Code at West Point Focus of Renewed Turmoil
description: WEST POINT, April 15Cadet Stephen Verr said today that hr world probably resign soon from the United States Military Academy, a victim, he said, of harassment by officers. and cadets who have objected to his being cleared of an honorc ode violation.

title: Unraveling in Albany
description: The Legislature's override of Governor Carey's veto of the StaviskyGoodman bill represents a setback both for the Governor and for orderly government In New York that transcends the substantial problems the bill could create for New York City.

title: Fast OilReserve Buildup Is Supported by President
description: WASHINGTON, April 15After a delay of weeks that has irritated some members of Congress, President Ford has resolved a bitter interagency dispute in favor of a relatively fast buildup of the country's first strategic oil reserve as a protection against another foreign embargo.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 15The Board of Trustees of the State Prisons met privately here today to consider reports of continuing turmoil at the maximum security prison at Trenton.

description: In a kind of halfrun displayit is being shown in the afternoons but not the eveningsa fulllength cartoon version of Jack and the Beanstalk opened at neighborhood theaters yesterday.

title: Marathon Woman: She Runs With Pride and Pain
description: Kathy Switzer's feet were In terrible shape.

title: Braves Top 76ers, Pistons, Cays Win
description: The Buffalo Braves never have won a National Basketball Association play off series, but after last night's 9589 triumph over the 76ers in Philadelphia, they seem on the verge of finally turnine the trick.

title: Educator on Move
description: When the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, a Jesuit, left the executive vice presidency of Fordham University in 1969 to become vice chancellor of the City University of New York, he explained his move to the crisisridden secular institution with this quotation he attributed to Sir Thomas More: Let us not desert the ship in the tempest because you cannot control the winds.

title: Bark Leaves Tokyo for U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 15The Nippon Maru, one of the 16 tall ships that will participate in the Operation Sail parade into New York Harbor on July 4, left here today for the United States. The vessel, a fourmasted hark 320 fret long, said to he Japan's oldeit sailing ship.

title: POSTAL SERVICE WINS 2 DECISIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The United States Postal Service won today two decisions that it hopes will make it more competitive with private mail handlers.

title: GOINA OUT Guide
description: TONAL OASIS Easter strollers in the West 40's. an area almost entirely titvoid of live classical music, might care to look in at 1:30 P.M. or at 7:15 P.M. on the regular Sunday programs of chamber music held at the grothers and Sisters nightThe cabaret is at 335 West 46th Street. on Restaurant Row between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. .Admi:;gart is $3 and drinks are available.

title: U.S. DETAILS PUS ON FISHING LETS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The United States announced wideranging plans today for enforcing a 200mile restricted fishing zone off its coasts starting next March.

title: Bonn Parties Skirting Question Of Communists
description: BONN, April 15As the possibility of a government with Communist participation draws closer in Italy, politicians and leaders in West Germany are acting concerned but they are not getting seriously involved.

title: Rise in Corn and Wheat Acreage Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Farmers intend to increase sharply their planting of corn and spring wheat above the levels that produced record crops last year, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Supreme Court Rulings Awaited on obligation of Suburbs in Solving Probletns of Cities
description: CHICAGO, April 15  Do America's suburbs have a legal obligation to aid in the solution of such problems as housing, segregation and unemployment that have beset the centers of the nation's older cities?

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: A paperback copy of John Holt's How Children Fail sits on the bookshelf. It is worn, having been passed from one teacher to another. And most of its pages show signs of diligent reading: sentences underlined, notations in the margins.

title: U.S. TO URGE BANK FOR POOR NATIONS
description: The United States is planning to call for the formation of a new international agency to encourage private investment in producing raw materials in developing countries, according to high Treasury and State Department officials. The agency, tentatively called the International Resources Bank, is expected to be announced by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger at next month's meeting of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Stewart Hooker, ExPublisher Of Racing Newspapers, Dead
description: James Stewart Hooker, a publisher and labor relations director who retired in 1974 after having served 30 years with Triangle Publications Inc., died of cancer yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. Hig aee was 63.

title: FIRST TESTS NEAR FOR A FLU VACCINE
description: BETHESDA, Md., April 13The first tests of the effectiveness of the new vaccine against swine influenza may begin here next week, scientists said today.

title: 6 DIE IN PLANE CRASH DURING COAST STORM
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.. April 15(UPI)A twinengine propeller plane, carrying six persons, crashed in the Santa Rosa Mountains during a rain and wind storm today, and all aboard were killed.

title: Nuggets, Capture Opener
description: DENVER, April 15 (AP)Ralph Simpson and Chuck Williams, guards, scored 24 and 21 points, respectively., as the Denver Nuggets held off the Kentucky Colonels and won, 110107, tonight in the opening game of their American Basketball Association playoff series.

title: STUDENT PROTEST ERUPTS IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Friday, April 16Riot policemen used tear gas and nightsticks last night to disperse militant demonstrators after tens of thousands, of students marched through central Paris protesting changes in university curriculums.

title: CocaCola Reaches Accord With F.T.C. On Future Contests
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The CocaCola Company has ;signed a binding agreement with the Federal Trade Commission that commits the soft ;drink concern to specific rules whenever it runs a promotional contest

title: The New York Times/Jack Mannin?
description: THE PRICE OF FAME: Andy Warhol, in The Factory, his studio on Union Square, says that he does not recognize the names of the artists who signed their massive portrait of him in white masking tape on the street below. The artists: Chip Duyck, Jon Kasai and Jody Eihaum. Mr. Warhol, however, endorsed the work.

title: Notes on People
description: This wedding had to be wedged in between interviews about the book, Nora Ephron said yesterday as her marriage to Carl Bernstein of The Washington Post was being toasted with champagne at Esquire magazine, where she is associate editor. Mr. Bernstein, author with Bob Woodward of The Last Days and the earlier All the President's Men, was even at that moment off with Harrison Salisbury to do Between the Lines for Channel 13, Miss Ephron said.

title: ELECTIONS SLATED BY UNITED BRANDS
description: The United Brands Company. which was rocked by scandal last year when it was disclosed that the company had paid a $1.25 million bribe in Honduras for favorable tax treatment, disclosed in its proxy statement that four new directors were standing for election at the annual meeting May 12.

description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 15Syria's decision to send troops into Lebanon on April 9 was made more than 10 days earlier, after an unsuccessful meeting between President

title: Islanders Top Sabres, Trail, 2 to 1
description: UNIONDALE, L. L, April 15Whether it was the challenge of adversity or, finally, the advantage of home ice taking effect, the New York Islanders beat the Buffalo Sabres, 53, tonight for the first time in Nassau Coliseum.

title: U.S.COURTUROLDS MIAMI CLUB'S BIAS
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 15 (AP)The Biscayne Bay Yacht Club in Miami may legally exclude blacks or Jews from membership, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Beatty Will Play Hughes for Warner
description: Warren Beatty will play Howard Hughes in a Warner Brothers movie to be based on the life of the late, mysterious billionaire. The movie, which is scheduled to begin filming in August, will be produced by Mr. Beatty.

title: New Trade Policies Urged For Drugs and Vaccines
description: GENEVA, April 15 Dr. Halfdan Mahler, director general of the World Health Organization, has said that exporting and importing countries must formulate together drug policies of greater worldwide public health interests, with adequate priority given to essential drugs and vaccines.

title: Bomb Hoax Interrupts 747 Flight to Germany
description: A Pan American World Airways jetliner with 329 persons aboard made an unscheduled landing at Boston's Logan International Airport last night because of what airline officials described as a bomb hoax.

title: 600 Months of Books and Still Picking
description: The Book  of  the  Month Club, rounding out its 50th anniversary this month and still at its selfappointed task of selling books to the nation, is looking at its,present state and past achievements with what might be called middlelige pride.

title: New York City to Lay Off Last 1,048 In W orkRelief Jobs, Endinerogram
description: New York City is laying off 1,048 workers next Friday to end the threeyearold Work Relief Employment Project, which gave employable homerelief recipients parttime city jobs with pay at least equal to welfare grants.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Watchdog Wanted
description: Who watches the watchdogs? The question is ancient as Plato and as modern as the Central Intelligence Agency. It is never easily answered, as the members of the United States Senate are once again discovering.

title: Fans Call Stadium Beautiful But Have Doubts About Cost
description: The rich and the not so rich were there. So were the poor and the not so poor. So were the black, the white, the Latin American and all the ethnic groups between.

title: KIBBEE PUTS OFF PAYING SUPPLIERS
description: The chancellor of the City University said yesterday that he would not submit vouchers to the city for payment to the university's suppliers this month because the money was needed to pay his teachers and other employees.

title: TESTIMONY HEARD IN HELSTOSKI CASE
description: NEWARK, April 15 (AP)A drug and securities smuggler who turned Government infor: mer was granted immunity, and testified today before a grand jury investigating possible wrongdoing by Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of East Rutherford.

title: Bridge:
description: An enthusiastic player who regularly attends every session of major New York tournament knowing that he, or she, has no chance of winning a title might seem to be in a sad case. But the sufferer in this case feels little vain.

title: MEXICO RULES OUT PESO DEVALUATION
description: MEXICO CITY, April 15The Mexican Government has force fully denied persistent reports that the Mexican peso may he devalued this weekend for the first time in 22 years.

title: Gerald L.K. Smith Dies
description: Gerald L. K. Smith, the antiCommunist lecturer and columnist and founder of the Christian National Crusade, died yesterday. Mr. Smith, a preacher whose political activism began with support of the Presidential ambitions of Huey P. Long in the 1930's, was 78. Page 30.

title: U.S., Stung in Angola, Forges Africa Policy
description: WASHINGTON, .April 15The United States Governmcnt's attitude toward Africa, long unfocused and drifting with events, has hardened since the crisis in Angola into determination to eliminate superpower conflict from black Africa.

title: Libyan Government Refuses Refuge to Three in Hijacking
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, April 15 (AP)The Libyan Government has refused asylum to the three Filipino Moslems who surrendered yesterday in Benghazi after the longest aerial hijacking In history, the official Libyan press agency reports.

title: Foreign Policy Debate
description: In their remarks before the American Society Newspaper Editors in Washington this week, Secretary of State Kissinger and three of his most articulate critics launched what could become a highly timely and useful foreign policy debate in this election year. The format was not a debate but a separate address by the Secretary after a panel discussion among three former highranking officials in Democratic administrationsGeorge W. Ball, Paul C. Warnke and Prof. Zbigniew Brzezinski.

description: Liviu Negut, a partly blind, 5yearold Rumanian boy who came to New York three weeks ago for tests by ophthalmologists, returned home last night with renewed hope that his sight would some day improve.

title: U.S. Steel's Rails And Tubular Goods Rise in Price May 1
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing its prices for rails and for certain tubular products as of May 1. The company said that rail prices, used

title: Soviet Jails a Tatar and Exiles an Amnesty Official for Slander
description: MOSCOW, April 15Two dissidents were convicted today of antiSoviet slander. In the Siberian city of Omsk, a court sentenced a Crimean Tatar nationalist to two and a half years in a labor camp. In Moscow, the secretary of the Soviet branch of Amnesty International was sentenced to five years of internal exile.

title: MARTIN RACKIN DIES; FILM PRODUCER, 58
description: LONDON, April 15 (UPI)Martin Rackin, for 35 years a Hollywood film writer and producer and a former head of Paramount Studios, was found dead in his bed at the Grosvenor House Hotel today. He was 58 years old.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters ENGLISH LEAGUE Fourth Division

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, April 15United States automobile production totaled 144,491 units this week, off 26.8 percent from last week because assembly plants will be closed tomorrow for a long Easter weekend. Last week the industry built 196,532 cars, the highest weekly total since the week ending Nov. 9, 1974.

title: People and Business
description: President Ford disclosed yesterday that he intends to nominate David M. Lilly, chairman of the Toro Company, manufacturers of power lawn movers, to become a member of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Boulez to Open 77 Philharmonic Series; Yvonne Minton to Sing in MahlerWork
description: Pierre Boulez is expected to open the New York Philharmonic's 197677 subscription season in the new Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 21 with Mahler's Symphony No. 3, a massive work in six movements with Yvonne, Minton, the mezzosoprano; the Camerata SingersAand boy choirs from The Little Church Around the Corner and Trinity School and the Brooklyn Boys Choir.

title: Soliah Defense Seeks to Learn What Miss Hearst Is Reporting
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 15(UPI)Steven Soliah's defense attorney demanded today that Federal prosecutors disclose what Patricia Hearst may have told them about his client's part in a fatal bank holdup.

title: London Times Apologizes To Wilson's Press Aides
description: LONDON, April 15Today's Times of London printed prominently an apology to the press secretaries of former Prime Minister Harold Wilson, thus ending a fivemonth quarrel.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 17
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Department of Commerce said today that retail store sales for the week ended April 10 were an estimated $12.6 billion, up 17 percent from the corresponding week a year ago, when sales were an estimated $10.8 billion. Department store sales were an estimated $1.2 billion, up 18 percent from the yearearlier $1 billion.

title: TV: After Adams Chronicles,
description: Public television is learning that success can be treacherous. The Adams Chronicles, which ambled to a somewhat subdued halt this week with the 13th episode, generated enthusiastic reviews, record audiences for the system and positive proof that Americans given the time and opportunity, can compete with the British in terms of quality television. One problem: What does public television do for an encore? And when?

title: For Many, The Day To Reckon
description: Making out an income tax return must rank with having a tooth extracted among the least pleasant experiences in someone's life. At least so it appeared yesterday, April 15, at the Internal Revenue Service's office here in Manhattan, where gloomy taxpayers met to settle their accounts.

title: LEBANESE RESUME FIGHTING AS SYRIA SEEKS AN ACCORD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15Rival forces bombarded each other in Beirut today with rockets, mortar rounds and light artillery fire as hostilities increased despite the armed truce proclaimed 13 days ago.

title: F.B.I. AGENTS CUT ARREARS ON LOANS
description: The Security National Bank of New Jersey said yesterday that about 300 F.B.I. agents to whom it had routinely made unsecured loans at 8 percent had reduced the interest arrears on the loans to a total of about $130.

title: UNION IS ADVISED TO OBEY COURT
description: The president of the nursinghome union here advised its 12,000 members last night to obey a court restraining order and refrain from striking 90 homes in the metropolitan area today.

description: GENERAL

title: Good Friday Closings
description: All securities and commodities exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today in observance of Good Friday.

description: You might have noticed, if you are a New Yorker, that the Wm. Wrigley Company, although based in Chicago, has been displaying a special affection for New York.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.April 15 The city commissioner who takes care of international personnel here has noted an increase in strains between foreign diplomats and New Yorkers because of the world organization's dimming urestige

title: Maudie Prickett, Actress, Appeared with Jack Benny
description: PASADENA, Calif., April 15 (AP)Maudie Prickett Cooper, a character actress who portrayed the secretary in Jack Benny's television series and appeared in about 300 films and television productions, died yesterday at the age of 62.

title: RISE IS REPORTED IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: The money supply in the nation rose, for the second consecutive week, to a seasonally adjusted average of $300 billion in the week ended April 7, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: India to Send Ambassador To China, First in 15Y ears
description: NEW DELHI, April 15India announced today that it was sending an ambassador to Peking for the first time in 15 years.

title: TAX TRIAL OPPOSED FOR REP. METCALFE
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (AP)Federal officials recommended today that the Justice Department not seek an indictment against Representative Ralph H. Metcalfe, Democrat of Illinois, for alleged tax irregularities.

title: The Long Weekend Termed a Factor
description: The credit market slipped back yesterday as It relinquish a little ground after its advance during the preceding two weeks. Trading lightened, and this combination of easing prices and quiet activity was viewed as. normal market behavior before a threeday weekend. Prices in the taxexempt sector of the bond market, however, continued to Inch upward, and the Bond Buyer reported that its index of municipal bond yields dropped II basic points this week to 6,54 percent from 6.65 percent a week ago.

title: Weyerhaeuser Raises Quarter Net 84.8%
description: The improved rate of family housing starts and strengthening domestic demand for all paper and paperboard products helped the Weyerhaeuser Company lift firstquarter earnings by 84.8 percent, the nation's largest lumber and wood products producer reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Subsidizes Taxi Fare for the Elderly
description: DANVILLE, Ill.  When Raymond and Margaret Steinsdoerfer, who are both blind, or Dewey. Maxwell, who is 77 years old, need to go to the city for a doctor's appointment or for shopping they make sure they have their blue plastic charge cards and then call one of Danville's three taxi services.

title: About Newyork
description: Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz ???lid folders bulging with correspondence across a table in his office on Wednesday for a visitor to examine.

title: Pirates
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15 (AP)Al Oliver and Willie Stargell hit consecutive homers in a fourrun seventhinning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 93 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Hanna, Turbulent Utica Mayor, Throws Hat in Ring for Senator
description: SYRACUSE, April 15Edward Hanna, whose rambunctious conduct of the Utica Mayor's office has brought him into conflict with his city's press and politicians, came here today to announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

title: Jackson Strategy Hampered by Lack Of Federal Funds
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15At a time when he had expected to be riding the crest of his victory in the New York Democratic Presidential primary toward a similar conquest in Pennsylvania, Senator Henry M. Jackson was working in a suite at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel here today trying desperately to raise money to keep his campaign moving.

title: Gerald L. K. Smith Dead; AntiCommunist Crusader
description: GLENDALE, Calif., April 15 (AP)Gerald L. K. Smith. the rightwing Arkansas preacher who once backed Gov. Huey P. Long of Louisiana for President, died today of complications from pneumonia. He was 78 years old.

title: Mefs Top Cubs, 108, on Kingman's 2d Homer
description: CHICAGO, April 15Rapidly becoming a Wrigley Field legend, Dave Kingman blasts two .more mighty home runs today to lift the New York Mets to a 108 triumph over the stunned Chicago Cubs.

title: ... Mission for Congress
description: The revelations of the select committee chaired by Senator Frank Church, Idaho Democrat, last year made it clear that the status quo with regard to Congress and the intelligence agencies must not continue. If Congress fails to tighten its controls, the public will regard this as an extraordinary dereliction of duty. In his comment to the nation's editors yesterday, C.I.A. Director Bush described reforms in the internal organization of the agency, made by executive order, designed to prevent such abuses as have occurred in the past. However, C.I.A. accountability to the public can, we believe, best be achieved through a Congressional committee armed with control over the agency's budget,

title: ISRAEL SETS LIMIT ON MOVES BY SYRIA
description: TEL AVIV, April 15 (Reuters)Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that Israel had set its own limits on the degree of Syrian involvement in Lebanon,

title: U.S. SUITS ALLEGE SEX BIAS ON LOANS TO HOME BUYERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Justice Department, in its first such actions under a 1974 law, charged two mortgage lenders today with discrimination against women.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map that appeared on ,page 1 of The Times yesterday, accompanying a dispatch on the Kaiparowits power project, incorrectly labeled as Montana the state northwest of Utah. It should have read Idaho.

title: Ex JaspersExcel Fibak At Rutgers Track Upsets
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ.April 15Three former Manhattan College runners distinguished themselves in the metropolitan area's first outdoor meet of this Olympic year, held in the twilight today at Rutgers Stadium.

title: Zummo, ComposerTrombonist, Offers Three. Works at a Recital
description: The trombone is not the most malleable of instruments, as thel paucity of solo repertory written for it would suggest. But Peter Zummo, an avantgarde trombonist and composer who gave a solo recital Wednesday night, has found some interesting ways to exploit his instrument's limited potential. The program closed a series of six composers evenings at Phill Niblock's Experimental Intermedia Foundation loft, 224 Centre Street.

title: Beame Urges Transfer Of City Stations
description: Mayor Beame yesterday prolming.

title: Wave of Forest Fires Laid to Arson and Drought
description: TRENTON, April 15Intense activtiy by arsonists, coupled with a continuing lack of rainfall, has caused as many as 60 fires a day in New Jersey, the Forest Fire Service reported.

title: Southern Railway and Missouri Pacific Plan to Study Feasibility of Combining
description: The Mississippi River corporation, the holding company that controls the Missouri Pacific Railroad, and the Southern Railway announced yesterday that they hld begun joint studies to determine the feasibility and advisability of combining under common corporate ownership and control. The Missouri Pacific and the Southern are among the most profitable and best maintained railroad: in the nation.

title: Murder Conviction Overturned On Basis of Brawl
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court overturned a murder conviction yesterday on the ground that disorderly conduct by the prosecutor and defense attorneys had prevented the defendant from setting a fair trial.

title: The Great Nondebate
description: WASHINGTON, April 15We are supposed to be having another Great Debate on American foreign policy here these daysWhither America in the World?but you should not be deceived. It is mainly campaign rhetoric from candidates who have no chance of replacing President Ford in the White House, and from ambitious, talented men interested in replacing Henry Kissinger in the State Department.

title: Yankees Win First Game in Rebuilt Stadium
description: Fiftythree years after Babe Ruth opened Yankee Stadium by hitting a home run, the historic old ball park in the Bronxbought and rebuilt by City Hallwas reopened yesterday before a sellout crowd of 54,010 persons and a full house of memories.

title: NEW OFFICIAL URGED FOR HUGHES ESTATE
description: LOS ANGELES, Apri 16 (UPI) A:chunty supervisor said today that he would introduce a motion to ask the Superior Court to put Public Administrator Bruce Altman in charge of the local estate of Howard Hughes

title: Jersey Is Sued to Nullify Its Tax on New Yorkers
description: New York State has filed a suit against New Jersey in the United States Supreme Court, seeking more than $225 million that New Jersey has collected in income taxes from New Yorkers who work or have worked in New Jersey.

title: Pittsburgh Scaife Gallery A Lesson in Architecture
description: PITTSBURGH  By now, the art museum has become the playing field of architecturethe commission in which architects are invited by clients to disport themselves with certain abandon, most unlike the way they are permitted to go about designing projects such as office buildings. The art museum is to civic architecture what the private house is to smallscale architecturethe place in which the architect can, within certain limits, let himself go.

title: Tenafly Expects Final Aid to Buy Land
description: TENAFLY, April 16Governor Byrne is expected to an nounce here on Tuesday that; funds will be made available to enable Tenafly to buy the 274acre East Hill property from its present owner and to preserve it as an unspoiled woodland atop the Palisades.;

title: DR. WALTHER NEUBAUER
description: Dr. Walther B. Neubauer, a physician who retired from the gynecological and obstetrical staff of Mount Vernon Hospital last year but practiced as a school doctor until this spring, died in the hospital Wednesday. He was 82 years old and lived at 155 Crary Avenue, Mount Vernon. N.Y.

title: Mediator Seeks to Avert Apartment Building Strike
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, requested the Realty Advisory Board and the union representing 20,000 employees in apartment buildings in the city to continue their bargaining talks for two weeks beyond next Tuesday's contract expiration date.

title: CITY PAYS FIRST PORTION OF ITS DEBT TO U.S. Kenneth Hartmann, left, city's Assistant Comptroller, handing checks totaling $275 million to Edward Lynch of The Bankers Trust Company and Emergency Financial
description: U.S. SETS PAYMENT ON NEW YORK LOAN

title: U.S. GETS PAYMENT ON NEW YORK LOAN
description: New York City yesterday paid off two notes totaling $270 million, the first installment on the $1.26 billion it had borrowed from the Federal Government in the last six months to stave off bankruptcy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Saturday concerning the custody of four girls should have attributed to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court the statement that the foster parents should not have allowed their love to grow too deep. The statement was incorrectly attributed to Justice Bernard F. McCafirey.

title: City Boys Go Back to the Soil, And Central Park's the Gainer
description: I would have been home watching old movies on television, said 13yearold Larry Fessenden. I would probably have been practicing on the piano: said Mark Sussman, also 13. Their friend David Forster said he would likely he skateboarding, or doing homework.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement announced agreement yesterday on moves to end the Lebanese civil war and said they would take a unified stand against any party that resumes military operations. But the communique issued by both sides made no mention of the presence of an estimated total of 2,000 to 4,000 Syrian and Syriancontrolled Palestinian troops that have recently entered Lebanon. Western diplomatic sources predicted that these forces would remain to guarantee that there would he no major resumption of fighting. [Page Column. 8.1

title: Kissinger Seems to Be Aiming At Reagan in Phoenix Speech
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, in another defense of the Ford Adm'nistration's policies, said today that the American people should reject fairy tales of America being second best and forever taken in by wily foreigners.

title: Broken Clock Costs Nuggets $2,500
description: DENVER, April 16 (AP)The Denver Nuggets were fined $2,500 today in the aftermath of'last night's wild American Basketball Association playoff game between Denver and Kentucky that was played without a scoreboard clock.

title: San Diego Plane Curfew Stirs Federal Opposition
description: SAN DIEGOAn extraordinary airport curfew banning latenight takeoffs and most latenight landings here has entered its fourth month with none of the dire economic effects or serious inconveniences forecast by airlines and other opponents of the measure, which is designed to reduce noise during sleeping hours.

title: Recent Sculptures by Miro Are Larky and Subversive
description: Joan Mir6 is in his 60th year as an ailist of the first consequence. It was in 1917, and with his Portrait of E.C. Ricart, now in the Marx Schoenborn collection,. that he produced one of the most commanding of this century's images. We have to remember, first, the psychological penetration of the portrait; second, the steadied ferocity of the design; third, the skill with which the physicality of the paint and the prisonlike simplicity of the general presentation are allied to the animation of the Japanese print that has been collaged onto the canvas. Mir6 the man Was 24 in 1917 but Mir6 the complete artist had just been born.

title: Stage: House of Mirth
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15Novels can make great movies but rarely lend themselves to stage adaptation. Why? The multiplicity of incident perhaps or, more persuasively possibly, that novelist's tone, that subiec Live note of unerring cornment that more easily finds space in a movie than on the stage. And then, of course, there is simply the question of movementa novel can fly in many directions, almost at once, and so can a film. A stage is a nutshell kingdom.

title: Art:Ammi Phillips's Children Steal a Show
description: The name of Ammi Phillips (17881865) is nowadays so well known to the large and growing public interested in 19thcentury American folk art that it still comes as something of a shock to realize how recently the work of this delightful painter was rediscovered and identified. Only in the last 18 years has Phillips emerged as an artist of some importance, and the exact scope of his oeuvre is still unknown. Yet no figure in the folk art of the last century is now more admired, and no folk paintings of the period are more eagerly collected than his.

Mr. Byrne wants the Port Authority pay for an extension of the Port Authority TransHudson railway system to Plainfield and a switching system that would allow rail service between New Jersey's new sports complex at Hackensack and Penn Station in Newark by the old Erie Lackawanna Railway line.

title: Film: African Adventure:'Countdown at Kusini' About Political Plot
description: "Countdown at Kusini" is the sort of movie that illustrates what happens when achievement falls short of aims.Conceived as a conventional melodramatic vehicle for the transmission of excitement and as a medium for explanation of the black revolution in Africa to an alien audience, this moviefilmed in and around Lagos, Nigeriaemerges as subpar adventure and less than lucid ideology.For the most part, it concerns itself with a plot by multinational corporationsthe postcolonial villainsto remove a black revolutionary leader through the efforts of a French mercenary and his black and white collaborators. A woman dedicated to the revolution and an American jazz musician, drawn more to the woman than to politics, provide the romantic interest and the effort to thwart the mercenary.The script is burdened with lamentable lines that require the best efforts of Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee and Greg Morris in the lead roles to overcome and failing that, invite the use of nearly constant music to drown out the dialogue.Compounding the troubles are the occasional mismatched shots and, in effect, an epilogue that vitiates its educational strivings.

title: Dave Anderson
description: By his nature, a hockey goaltender is a rugged individualist with an ego to match his responsibility. He's not like the forwards or the defensemen, who rotate during game. The goaltender is out there alone with his burden. Sharing the position means sharing the pride of accomplishment. On some National Hockey League teams, the two goaltenders are rivals rather than teammates. But the New York Islanders, who hope to square their Stanley Cup series with the Buffalo Sabres tonight at two games each, are fortunate, if not unique. The Islanders have two goaltenders for the price of one. When the Islanders astonished the N.H.L. by extending the Philadelphia Flyers. the champions the last two seasons, to seven games in the semifinals a year ago. Glenn (Chico) Resch provoked chants of Chico! Chico! at the Nassau Coliseum; now those spectators are reacting to Billy Smith's saves against the Sabres with a chant of Billy! Billy! and subconsciously at least, Chico is chanting with them.

Tass tops it all off by accusing Nobel Prize winner Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife of physically beating policemen the Dzhemilev trial in distant Omsk. description: Within the past week the American environment enjoyed two triumphs that go far to prove the country's basic concern for its natural heritage in spite of economic difficulties and the continuing cry for more energy.

title: Hanoi Says Kissinger Misread Notes Concerning Normal Ties
description: HONG KONG, April 16North Vietnam charged today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had irresponsibly misinterpreted a recent exchange of notes between Hanoi and Washington by suggesting in Senate testimony that progress was being made toward normalizing relations between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Pro Transactions FOOTBALL
description: CHICAGO (NFC)  Signed Bill Merck, running back, and Clarence Reece, wide recelvercornerback, free agents.

title: PLAN ON LEBANON DRAFTED BY SYRIA AN PALESTINIANS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April I6Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement announced agreement today on moves to end the Lebanese civil war and said they would take a unified stand against any party that resumes military operations.

title: Good Friday Is Marked In Solemn Observances
description: Good Friday. the day when Jesus died on the cross, was marked yesterday in all its solemnity by millions of Christians churchgoers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCIER TO TEST CAMPAIGN RULING
description: Max Palevsky. the multimillionaire backer of liberal causes and candidates, said yesterday that he and a few others were considering a major financial effort for Jimmy Carter in the June 8 California primary.

title: Access to Justice
description: At the recent national conference on Causes of Popular Dissatisfaction With the Administration of Justice, there was a collision of ideas on the subject of access to the courts. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger held that too many unnecessary cases are being brought, thus overloading the judicial circuits. Public interest and civil rights attorneys countered that recent rulings by the Burger Court discouraged litigation by all corners especially people at the bottom of the social and economic ladder.

title: BALTIMORE SNIPER KILLS A POLICEMAN
description: BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP)A sniper firing a highpowered rifle from a southwest Baltimore row house killed one city policeman and wounded four other officers and a civilian tonight before surrending, the authorities said.

title: Byrne, Carey to Discuss Jersey Transit Problems
description: TRENTON, April 16Governor Byrne and Governor Carey have agreed to meet soon to discuss northern'New Jersey's transit problems, which Governor Byrne said need quick attention from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: SOVIET NAVY SHIPS QUIT EGYPTIAN PORT
description: CAIRO, April 16 (AP)The last five Soviet warships sailed from Alexandria at 11 P.M. yeaterday, one hour before the deadline for ending Egyptian service to the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean, the newspa per Al Ahram reported today.

title: India Plans Strong Steps To Slow Population Rise
description: NEW DELHI, April 16The Indian Government today outlined a broad new birthcontrol policy designed to give top national priority to slowing the rapid population growth.

title: Red Bank Hopes to ReCreate Royal Visit
description: RED BANK, April 16Residents of this rive front community hope to be able to show The British are coming, during their Bicentennial celebration July 4.

title: 2 New Veterans
description: MENLO PARK, April 16A nursing home adjoining the Soldiers' Home here in Middlesex County, completed two years ago at a cost of $2 million, has never been staffed and has yet to accept a single patient.

title: Small Southern College continues Rescue Mission
description: WEST POINT. Miss.In all its 84 years, Mary Holmes College has never been well known outside the black communities of the Deep South. So when racial integration came to Southern campuses, a number of observers assumed that the twoyear college would wither And die.

title: Laos Orders Death Penalty For 6 Named as Terrorists
description: VIENTIANE, Laos. April 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  A people's court today handed down the death penalty for six people found guilty of terrorist acts including a grenade attack that injured four Russian diplomats at the Soviet Embassv here on March 12.

title: Television
description: 7:30 P.M. Insight (7)

title: I.R.S.Will Increase Depredation Time For New Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it planned to increase to 12 years, from the present six years, the period of time over which airlines may depreciate the aircraft they place in service in the future.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Consumer affairs officials are warning homeowners to beware of a rash of unsolicited offers to repair roofs and chimneys.

title: FORD BARS CURBS ON SHOE IMPORTS; FEARS PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Ford decided today against imposing higher tariffs or other import restraints on shoes made abroad.

title: WOMAN ACQUITTED IN GUN CONSPIRACY
description: A 31yearold ChineseAmerican woman suspected of involvement in a plot to assassinate Emperor Hirohito of Japan when he visited this city last October was acquitted yesterday on charges of conspiring to transport weapons from California to New York.

title: Harassed Rosedale Black Cleared of Gun Charges
description: A black resident of Rosedale, Queens. whose home had been bombed twice and whose family had been subjected to a campaign of hate mail was cleared yesterday of criminal charges stemming from his use of a gun in a confrontation with a white rights group last summer.

title: Army Vetoes Wetland Project in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, April 16, (UPI)The Army Corps of Engineers, providing a major victory for environmentalists, today denied permits for developmeat of two large Florida wetland tracts along the Gulf Coast.

title: Memory BubbleInvented For I.B.M. Typewriters
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Apparatus invented by four International Business Machines Corporation researchers may make it practical for electric typewriters to in clude, at relatively low cost, extensive memory editing capabilities. Such a typewriter could make It easy for a writer to correct mistakes, revise or rearrange the text, and then have a perfect copy printed out at high speed.

title: James Ware Sykes, 66, Is Dead; Long a Newspaper Ad Leader
description: James Ware Sykes, chairman of the hoard of the SawyerFergusonWalker Company, newspaper representative concern, died yesterday at his home, 200 East 66th Street. He was 66 years old and lived also in East Hampton, L. I., and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Congressional Study Questions The Safety of Breeder Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, April (UPI)Proponents of Liquid metal fastbreeder reactors to produce nuclear fuel may be overstating the urgency and overlooking critical safety questions according to a study released today. year 2000 could be less than half that predicted earlier. Mr Sharcfl<in said because of conservation efforts and the rapid rise in fossil fuel costs.

title: Evert's Narrow Escape
description: LOS ANGELES, April 16The secret of being the world's No. 1 player is to be angry on the court and hate your opponent, said Chris Evert last night after having won a hardfought match against Sue Barker that stretched over three sets and an hour and a half in the Virginia Slims championships.

title: Ali Begins Drills For April 30 Bout
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 16 (AP)Muhammad Ali held the first workout here today for his heavyweight title defense against Jimmy Young April 30 and announced afterward that he had been invited to hold a championship bout in Turkey.

title: 3 Flyers Accused of Assault in Toronto
description: TORONTO, April 16 (UPI) The Ontario Attorney General, Roy McMurtry, issued arrest warrants today against three Philadelphia Flyers  Don Saleski, Joe Watson and Mel Bridgmanin connection with onice incidents last night during a National Hockey League playoff game between the Flyers and the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: A New Kind Of American Indian
description: litestroying the ethnic characteristics ofkleigltborhoods is as American as General Custer. It began when the Indians looked down to the beach at Jtestown and Plymouth and saw shiploads of Europeans moving into the neighborhood.

title: Kissinger to Begin Tour Of African Nations Friday
description: WASHINGTON, April 16, (Reuters) Secretary of Stat, Henry A. Kissinger will begin a sevennation tour of Africa on April 23, the State Department formally announced today.

title: PLAN ON LEBANON DRAFTED BY SYRIA AND PALESTINIANS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement announced agreement today on moves to end the Lebanese civil war and said they would take a unified stand against any party that resumes military operations.

title: Lefkowitz Brief Backs Law Removing Cunningham
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz submitted court papers yesterday strongly defending a law that would remove Patrick J. Cunningham as the Democratic state chairman for refusing to sign waiver of immunity before erand iury.

title: Going out Guide
description: TOP OF THE TOWN Southbound strollers and family groups who decide to sample the view from our tallest building Easter weekend will find a program of free entertainment if they go today.

title: Panamanian Scores Reagan on Canal
description: Panama's Foreign Minister yesterday accused Ronald Reagan of willfully deceiving the people of the United States in his campaign speeches on the status and future of the Panama Canal.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PEACOCK SPRING. By Rumer Godden. 274 pages. The Viking Press. $8.95.

title: Pirates
description: PITTSBURGH. April 16Two renegades from the American League crossed paths tonight in a National League mound duel. George (Doc) Medich, the former Yankee pitcher got the best of it as he led his new team, the Pittsburgh Pirates, to a 31 victory over Mickey Lolich, the exDetroit Tiger, now a New York Met starter.

title: Good Friday Closings
description: All securities and commodities exchanges in the United States, Europe and Canada were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday.

title: Jersey Is Sued to Nullify Its Tax on New Yorkers
description: New York State has filed a suit against New Jersey in the United States Supreme Court, seeking more than $225 million that New Jersey has collected in income taxes from New Yorkers who work or have worked in New Jersey.

title: Comsat Cites 13.4% Drop in FirstQuarter Earnings
description: The Communications Satellite CorporationComsatreported yesterday a 13.4 percent decline in firstquarter net income, reflecting a 6.15 percent drop in operating earnings and a 51.3 percent drop in investment income.

title: Buccaneers Sign Selmon Brothers
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 16 (UPI)The new Tampa Bay Buccaneers of the National Football League signed their firstround draft choice, Leroy Selmon, and his brother Dewey to longterm contracts today. Both were defensive tackles at Oklahoma. Dewey was the last player takers the second round. Leroy won the Outland Trophy as the nation s outstanding interior collegiate lineman. Another brother, Lucious, was an Oklahoma star two years ago.

title: ATOM PLANT VOTE FOUND CONFUSING
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17The controversy over restricting atomic power development In California is proving to be one of the most confused issues in recent political history.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesArt Hafey, 127 pounds, San Diego, outpointed David Sotelo, 128, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: He Eschews Continental Dominance
description: BONNBy most standards, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany should be the dominant leader of the Western European democracies. His personality is commanding, he is in vigorous physical shape at 57, his country's economy is clearly on the way to recovery from its worst postwar recession, even with more than a million people out of jobs there is no social unrest and there is no danger of Communists working their way into power as in Italy and France.

title: A Loitering Law in Seattle Said to Inhibit Prostitutes
description: SEATTLE, April 17  Call girls and prostitutes who are not conspicuous fare well in Seattle. But their more aggressive sistersalong with their customersare being inhibited 'y the city's unusual loitering law.

title: Tennis Clinic
description: The serve is the only shot in tennis that is never stroked on the fly or on the run. It can always be hit from the same stance, at the same distance from the net and the boundaries of the court, and with the ball at the same place in the air. It can be practiced alone or with others or during an actual match.

title: Miss Lempke Is Bride Of William Cochrane
description: Elizabeth Ann Lempke, daughter of Mrs. Richard J. Lempke of Wayne, N.J. and the late Dr. Lempke, was married yesterday morning at the Packanack Community Church in Wayne to William Henry Cochrane, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Cochrane of Hawthrone, N.J. The Rev. Milton D. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: CAREY OFFERS Bill ON NURSE TRAINING
description: Governor Carey proposed legstation yesterday that he said; would recognize the higher degree of training given to nurses now by allowing them a wider role in treating patients.

title: U.S. Acts on Sex Bias in Lending
description: The Justice Department has filed suit against mortgage lenders in Cherry Hill, N.J., and Salt Lake City, charging them with such acts as requiring working women, but not men, to state in writing that they intended to go on working, giving less weight to a wife's income than to her husband's and refusing to consider alimony and child support as income.

title: Richard Pantell Fiance of Carina Ohman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allan Ohman of Borlange, Sweden, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carina Inger Ohman, to Richard Keith Pantell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Pantoll of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: What's Under the Rock at the Bottom of the Budget?
description: INCREASED budgethigher taxes. The more things change, the more they remain the same. Events of the last two years have dramatically demonstrated the dangers of restrained governmental spending. In New York City, fiscal crisis followed fiscal crisis and the threat of munici 01 bankruptcy loomed over the hori zon like the final scene in Greek tragedy. Events in Yonkers demonstrated that budgetary problems and runaway spending were not confined to the Big Apple and rumblings from Albany gave warnings of stateWide fiscal malaise.

title: Joy Levitt Is Bethrothed to Louis Zivic
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Levitt of Centerport, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Joy Devra Levitt, to Louis Zivic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zivic of Skokie, III.

title: Yale Crew Beats Northeastern Rutgers
description: DERBY, Conn., April 17Yale's varsity crew beat Northeastern by threefourths of the length of its 60foot fiberglass shell and Rutgers by 1 1/2 today on the flat water of the Housatonic River. The outcome further complicated the pecking order among the Eastern crews as Northeastern had been the favorite.

title: 2000Meter Mark Set
description: ATHENS, April 17 (AP)Natalia Maracescu of Rumania broke the world record i' the women's 2,000meter run today with a time of 5 minutes 43.94 seconds at the GreeceRumania track and field meet. The 20yearold eclipsed the record of 5:48.08 held by Grete Andersen of Norway.

title: Shoemaker Victor On Crystal Water
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 17A major test for 3yearolds was won today by a 44yearold as Bill Shoemaker rode Crystal Water to a twolength victory in the $240,250 Hollywood Derby.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 17 (AP)Marshall Holman, 21 years old, of Medford, Ore., became the youngest bowler ever to win the $125,000 Tournament of Champions today by defeating veteran Billy Hardwick of Louisville, Ky., 203198. Holman also only the second man ever to win the Professional Bowlers Association's premier event on his first attempt, needed a mark in the final frame to claim the $25,000 first prize and spared by picking up the 47.

title: Janet Guthrie vs. Bobby Unser: 200 M.P.H. Battle of the Sexes
description: Women drivers are no joke this year, not in racing.

title: East Side Principal Wins Round In Battle on School Harassment
description: An embattled school principal on the Lower East Side has won a round in a court fight to retain his job and end alleged harassment by school officials and the teachers union.

title: Mozart MiniFestival by Chorale
description: It was called a Mozart MiniFestival, and devotees MiniFestival, and devotees certainly got their money's worth at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. Under the energetic direction of Martin Josman, the National Chorale presented two major worksthe nearly halfhour yesperae de Dominica, (K. 321), and the almost hourlong Grand Mass in C minor, (K. 427)  with the Regina Cocli, (K. 276), as a robust little curtainraiser.

title: Yanks Romp by 100
description: So far the newly renovated Yankee Stadium has been like Aladdin's lamp for the home team, providing everything it could wish for.

title: Deliverer Facing Action As Flouter of Postal Law
description: PITTSBURG, KAN.A legal battle is shaping up over the effort of a private company here to compete with the United States Postal Service.

title: Mail Service Competition Rising
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.In Chicago, high school youths employed by the Peoples Gas Company are delivering more than 1.5 million utility bills yearly to customers.

title: Gale A. Lansing Becomes Bride Of Shelby Davis
description: The marriage of Gale Abbie Lansing, daughter of Livingston Lansing of Boonville, N. Y., and the late Edith B. Lansing, to Shelby Moore Cullom Davis of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Shelby Cullom Davis, Ambassador to Switzerland from 1969 to 1975, and Mrs. Davis of Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: Jonathan Keith to Wed Helen E. Paine in Fall
description: Augustus G. Paine of Hobe Sound, Fla. and Iris Smith Russell of Locust Valley, L. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Ellis Paine, to Jonathan C. Keith, son of Norman C. Keith of Locust Valley and Jocelyn Sullivan Freer Keith of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Trust Means Scrutiny
description: In the view of the law, public officials and public servants may be different from other citizens.

title: Food
description: New England boiled dinner

title: Is ABC's New
description: ABC News will introduce a new format for the examination of highly controversial public issues on televisionand raise some interesting questions about TV journalism, toowith its documentary Gun Control: Pro and Con on Tuesday night at 10.

title: Italian Labor Pact Reached
description: ROME, Apri 17(Reuters)After six months of negotiations and 120 hours of strikes, employers and union leaders today agreed on pay raises for Italy's 350,000 chemical workers.

title: The List of Her Detractors Is Growing
description: In the best of times, almost any politician can do reasonably good job as the governor of a small New England state. And in the worst of times no governor, however good, can expect to come away without a long list enemies and a diminished reputation.

title: FOR SOMETHING COMPLETELY
description: What is humor? I have been asked by the editors of this magazine to structure an indepth analysis of the comedy of the BBCTV writerperformers who collectively call themselves Monty Python's Flying Circus. A name, incidentally, that strikes me as singelady unapt, for, as I've discovered In my researches, they are neither a circus nor do they fly. Nor. perplexingly, is there anyone called Monty Python who is even remotely associated with the group, which is made up of five Englishmen and an expatriate American in their early 30's. And now, apparently, they have descended upon New York to do whatever it is they do in person, at the City Center until I believe, May 2, a circumstance that lends considerable urgency to the completion of my analysis. Be that as it cannot analyze the comedy

title: Commercials And Awards Don't Mix
description: The giving of awards on television has expanded to plague proportions. At the very center of the blight, there remain the big three: Hollywood's Oscars, Broadway's Tonys (which will be presented this evening) and TV's Emmys. But surrounding these recognized heavyweights (all is relative In the world of hoopla) is an array of lighter spectacles that include awards for music as judged by the recording industry, for music as judged by the performers, for comedy, for a variety of beauty contests, for best performing animals, for commercials and, it seems, for anything that strikes the fancy and publicity ambitions of an advertising agency.

title: Bill Is Proposed to End Abuses In NoFault Insurance Claims
description: ALBANY, April 16Assemblyman Leonard Silverman, asserting that nofault automobile insurance premiums would rise this year because of artificial inflation of medical costs in such cases, said today that he would propose legislation to curb such abuses.

title: Consequences Called Major
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 17 (UPI)The chief scientist for the Viking project asserts that there will be tremendous consequences if America's first unmanned interplanetary mission lands on Mars and finds living organisms there.

title: Mine Field
description: The cautious intervention of Syrian troops with Israeli acquiescenceand the continuing mediation of Syrian President Hafez alAssad, aided by independent American and French diplomatic effortsappears to be stabilizing the offandon ceasefire in Lebanon's civil war.

title: Opera: The Mother of Us All
description: The Mother of Us All, the Gertrude SteinVirgil Thomson opera about Susan B. Anthony, has been turning up in small productions over the last few years, and it is pleasure to report that it is back again, this time in thoughtful and moving production mounted by Encompass Theater. This new, nonprofit producing company introduced its version of the masterpiece in a Greenwich Village theater and then brought it uptown to the Good Shepherd Faith Church at 152 West 66th Street, next door to the Juilliard School.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: IT is time, Governor Byrne told a group of New Jersey labor leaders a week or so ago, for New Jersey to stop keeping our light under a bushel. He intends, the Governor said, to promote New Jersey as New Jersey has never been promoted before.

title: CHESS
description: More than 65 years ago, the German theoretician, Siegbert Tarrasch, insisted that a strong move had to look beautiful, that is, that it had to strike one immediately as harmoniously fitting the position. He was particularly outspoken in his criticism of the then wq;ld champion, Emanuel Lasker. Lasker, he said, made ugly moves; even after those ugly moves had thrashed him twice in their two title matches, Tarrasch refused to shut up.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Joy Of Hunting Shellfish on Beach
description: The delight in gathering edible mollusks has never subsided in me since the first time my mother took me to a clam flat shimmering in the late afternoon sun and showed me how to fill my red tin bucket with socalled steamers.

title: 2 Worlds of Prague: One Is Very Soviet, Another Mostly Mozart
description: PRAGUE, April 17  Opposite the ponderous window displays of the Soviet Cultural Mission stands the graceful little opera house w'ere Mozart's Don Giovanni was first performed nearly two centuries ago.

title: New Branches Trim the Old
description: ADEPOSITOR walks into a Long Islandbased bank in Suffolk County, with, diaws his money, carries it to one of the new branches of a New York Citybased savings bank, deposits it and walks out with a new hair dryer, basketball, electric blender or set of pots and pans. The transaction, multiplied countless times in the last month, has cost Islandbased banks millions of dollars.

title: Summer College: For Body and Soul
description: I have just finished lugging a suitcase and a typewriter and an armload of American history, archeology and sociology books up three flights of stairs. It's a hot sticky Sunday afternoon in July, the first of my six days at Brown experiencing what summer colleges all over the country proclaim in their brochures will be an intellectual adventure combined with a real vacation. (See listing on page 15.)

title: Newark Airport: Going Nowhere
description: IT is a huge, uncluttered airport, with some runways nearly two miles long, gracefully lined passenger terminals, convenient parking fields and a fresh appearance that suggests modernity and class with a capital C. A dream airport, a huh for world traveland that's the way Newark Airport was planned in the mid1960's.

title: Easter
description: Since time immemorial, this has been a season special celebration. It is the beginning of a natural year, a pastoral way of marking time, and it signals the start of new growth, renewal of the old. It has long been the occasion of faith renewed, of belief and understanding given new life. It was the beginning of a new season in the earth and in the heart of mankind.

title: Savannah:
description: Droning endlessly down 195 across the ugly swamp country of South Carolina (so reminiscent of World War battlescapes, with its seas of mud and naked trees), I hope that Georgia will be an improvement, and allow my mind to dwell on the beautiful name of our nightstopSavannah. Although the word is commonly thought to be Spanish, Oviedo says the conquistadors picked it up from Carib Indians, who grunted something like zabana when referring to land that was flat, green and tropical. It soon worked its way into English travel romances. {On the Bank of this Brook, reported Robinson Crusoe in 1719, I found many pleasant Savana's, or Meadows, plain, smooth, and covered with Grass.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Black Nationalism, White Racism Are Forcing a Choice
description: WASHINGTONThe blackwhite issue in southern Africa is forcing American leaders to confront ever deeper levels of what is realistic and what right in forming policy. The potential for human catastrophe imbedded in this vestige from another century can no longer be ignored in Washington now that Moscow and Havana, with the world looking on, are threatening to liberate the blacks by force.

title: Design
description: Outside and far below the Riverside Drive apartment, the Hudson River rolls like an endless plain. There are no curtains, not even shades, to obscure the view. Inside, equally uninterrupted, space sweeps 50 generous feet from one end of the living room to the end of the dining room. This space is a welcoming room for guests, a pleasant spot for chambermusic gatherings and the center of the Pinkus Zuchermans home.

title: A Connecticut Playhouse With That Broadway Touch
description: EAST HADDAM. Conn.

title: Luther Burbank, R.I.P.
description: APRIL is the cruelest month, says my husband (a man not given to the reading of English poets) as he gazes wistfully out on his backyard, where all manner of flowers and vegetables have perished in mysterious fashion over the years. It is April again, all the seed catalogs have been perused, and he has decided to foreswear all else and pursue his consummate lovetomatoes.

title: The real zek's story
description: Readers of Alexandr Solzhenitsyn's The First Circle will remember Dimitri Sologdin as the rigorously selfdisciplined prisonerengineer, chopper of wood, steadfast opponent of the Stalinist regime, and guru of survival and spiritual growth in the world of the Gulag archipelago. It was Sologdin who engaged in intellectual jousts with the equally steadfast Communist

title: Utilities Drop Plan For Big Utah Plant
description: A plan to build the nation's largest coalfired electric generating plant on Utah's scenic Kaiparowits Plateau has been abandoned by its sponsors, a consortium of power companies, because for a variety of reasons had become economically risky.

title: Parent and Child
description: Every year some 10,000 to 20,000 American babies are born into what has been called a legal noman's land. With their numbers estimated around the halfmillion mark, these are children of artificialinsemination donation (A.I.D.), conceived with donated semen and raised as the natural offspring of their mothers and their mothers husbands.

title: The Church and the State
description: ABOUT 200 years ago, a European visitor to the middle colonies in America looked around him and exclaimed: All shades of Sectarians exist here down to open infidelity Besides the English. Swedish and German Lutherans, and the Scotch, Dutch and German Reformed, there are Arminians, Baptists. Mennonites from Danzig, Arians, Socinians, Schwenckfelders, German Old Tunkers, New Tunkers, New Lights, Inspired Sabbatarians or SeventhDay Baptists, Hermits, Independents and Free. Thinkers.

title: Northrop Frye exalting the designs of romance
description: Northrop Frye, in his midsixties. has earned the reputation of being the leading theoretician of literary criticism among all those writing in English today. By common consent his major works arc Fearful Symmetry (1947). still the best study of William Blake, and Anatomy of Criticism (1957), the

title: A.C.L.U. Stalwart Explains Why He Quit
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Chuck Morgan put his feet up on the edge of his desk, stroked the Siamese kitten squirming on his lap and said, If Moses had been at Harvard and spent two years on Capitol Hill, he would have written the Ten Commandments with two exceptions and a savings clause.

title: Miss Prudden Engaged To Henry A. Clark 3d
description: Pamela Prudden, a writer of management training programs for Louis A. Allen Associates In Palo Alto, Calif., and Henry Austin Clark 3d, who expects to receive a master's degree in business administration in June from Stanford University, plan to he married June 24 in Tappan. N.Y.

title: Gross Tries A New Life
description: EDGEWATER THE ferryboat Binghamton, which sat rotting in mud flat near the George Washington Bridge for several years after she went out of service in 1967, is now carrying the hopes of a man who was once one of the state's most powerful public figures and is fighting to stay out of Federal prison and start a new careerNelson G. Gross.

title: Making out in Moscow
description: The novel, as George Orwell once said, is a Protestant art form, for its author must give a fair trial to his subjects. Becauie of that, what we call an autobiographical novel seems a contradiction in terms; and Moscow Farewell is here to prove it. The author of an autobiographical novel is obliged to give a fair trial to his alterego, and this requires an amount of objectivity scarcely attainable by a mortal. To cover this difficulty, an experienced writer resorts either to some particularly colorful type of speech or to complexity of plot. Inexperienced ones keep insisting on their sincerity. George Feifer, an American journalist, falls into the later category, and if anything saves hls second novel, it is those moments when he abandons his selfproclaimed honesty and gets down to the extremely peculiar character of the material he is dealing

title: Doris Orgel's most recent book is A Certain Magic.
description: F. N. Monjo tells the story of Robert E. Lee's 1863 invasion of Pennsylvania and its repulse at the bloody, threeday Battle of Gettysburg from the viewpoint of President Lincoln's 10yearold son Tad. (Mr.

title: The Fabricator
description: Oscar Wilde who bemoaned the decay of lying, might have admired the style of a prevaricator who uses untruths as social solvents. The hero of this cheerful whimsy engages in lying the way others practice

title: Safe Alternative Landing Site Sought for Viking Craft on Mars
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) An intensive search is under way for an alternative super safe landing site on Mars in case disaster strikes the first of two Viking spacecraft attempting to land there, scientists say.

description: SEA CLIFF

title: Rhodesians Seek to End Rift
description: LUSAKA. Zambia, April 17 (ReutersiThe external faction 'f Rhodesia's African National Councit, led by Bishop Abel Muzerewa. met here today to discuss uniting with the inter nal fiction, headed by Joshua Nkomo.

title: Who Works Where At What
description: WHEN New Jerseyans put down their morning newspapers, finish their breakfast coffee and start for work, they head to factories, farms, mines, stores and offices in impressive number.

title: Kenneth Lackey Is Dead at 74; One of Original Three Stooges
description: COLUMBUS, N. C., April 17 (UPI)  Kenneth Lackey, a vaudeville actor who started his career on a dare and joined the original Three Stooges slapstick comedy team, died yesterday after a lengthy illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Ruth Laredo Plays Strong Piano Recital
description: Ruth Laredo operated within a relatively narrow range at her piano recital Friday night in Alice Tully Hall from firstrate to superb. Despite small size, she has a commanding tone and technique. More crucial, she has the sort of musical insight that makes an occasional missed note seem genuinely unimportant.

title: Albany Looks for Gold in Trenton
description: In an action that could help one financially strapped state but injure another, New York State has gone into the United States Supreme Court to try to collect $225 million from New Jersey. Albany contends that Trenton's income tax on New Yorkers who work in New Jersey Is unconstitutional end wants the return of revenues paid since 1962.

title: A Monster Of Our Own

They will be open from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. seven days a week, and until the fall each player will he charged only 25 cents an hour.

description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)President Ford has announced the appointment of four men to the Citizens Advisory Committee on Environmental Quality for terms expiring May 3, 1978. The four were: James L. Taft Jr., Mayor of Cranston, R. I., Harrison L. Richardson, a lawyer from Portland, Me.; James S. Gilmore Jr. of Kalamazoo, Mich., and former Gov. Thomas McCall of Portland, Ore. The last two men were reappointed to the panel.

title: Trouble on the Left, in Both Italy and France
description: Very little changed last week in the Italian political crisis that seems certain to force national elections in lune, but the political paralysis is hurting the alreadyweak economy. The lira has fallen to the lowest _point ever in relation to the dollar.

description: Increases in manpower and the modernization of weapons in the Soviet ground and air forces in Central and Eastern Europe has sharpened Western Europe's anxiety over its abild ity to deter Russian political pressure hacked by superior military force.

title: 18 MEDICAL DEANS WARN ON TUITION
description: The deans of the New York State's eight private medical schools have warned that tuition increases could price the schools out of the range of all but the wealthiest students because of major reductions in state and Federal assistance for medical education.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Romantic Music Festival in Indianapolis starts its ninth season on Tuesday, and for six days Frank Cooper and his merry men will have a lot of fun with forgotten 19thcentury repertory. To give an idea: on the opening program, Jorge Bolet and the Indianapolis Symphony will be heard in piano concertos by Hummel and Sgambati, while the orchestra on its own will play music by Chadwick and Schelling. Now that's the romantic revivalwhich, incidentally, Cooper (who teaches piano at Butler University in Indianapolis) launched nine years ago. His Romantic Music Festival was the first of its kind.

title: Nancy Werner Is Wed To Alfred C. P. Lucas
description: Nancy Ellen Werner, daughter of Dr. jesse Werner, chairman and president of the GAF Corporation, and Mrs. Werner of New York, was married at noon yesterday to Alfred C. P. Lucas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Casassas Lucas of Biarritz, France, and Barcelona, Spain.

title: Company Bribes, British Style
description: Two major European oil companies have provided evidence that the practice of making payments to foreign political parties was not restricted to American corporations. British Petroleum and the Royal Dutch Shell Group have admitted secretly paying more than $6 million to Italian political parties from 1969 to 1973 to secure favorable government policies.

title: Prague Remains A Moscow Echo

description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Chief of Scotland Yard, Sir Robert Mark, credits British social conditions with keeping crime rates relatively low compared with United States crime rates.

title: In Praise of Redwing Blackbirds
description: In the spirit of 76 my house guest shouted, The redwings are coming The redwings are coming It was the first day of March and this was a signal that nature was truly preparing another spring.

Post

title: McTear Takes 100, 200Meters
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 17 (AP)Houston MeTear, the school sprinter from Florida, was a spectacular double winner today in the San Jose Relays, with times of 10.1 secends In 100 meters and 20.3 In the 200 meters.

title: Food Stamp Program, as It Is, Has Very Few Friends
description: The 12yearold program of bolstering the nation's nutrition by distributing food stamps is certain to be changed. Members of Congress are divided on whether the changes should be drastic or moderate, but there is remarkable agreement that the program has grown larger, more inclusive and more expensive than was ever intended.

title: Local Colombia Elections Seen as Test for Leftists
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 15 Voters in Colombia, one of the two remaining democracies in South America, will elect new state assemblies and municipal councils on Sunday in a contest viewed as a test of radical leftist strength against the traditional parties. The campaign period since early March has been shaken by a wave or agitation, imitating labor strikes, student violence,the assassinations of a prominent army general and a wealthy industrialist and the kidnapping of an antiCommunist labor leader. But the campaign by all the contending parties, including the Communists and other leftist groups, has developed freely.

title: Kodak Makes Its Response To Polaroid At Last
description: ROCHESTERThe Eastman Kodak Compriy, which has dominated the photographic industry almost from the day George Eastman coined the word in 1888, has a lot riding on the Polaroidtype camera it is to unveil on Tuesday.

Schager to Robert Alexander Anderson of Cambridge, Mass., a portrait painter, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schager of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Key Biscayne, Fla., parents of the future bride. description: Spokesmen for the black community, noting a general decline in black voting and continuing low registration among blacks, have voiced concern that apathy and cynicism about politics could seriously dilute gains of recent years and hinder future progress.

title: Dr. George W. Auxier, 70, Aide to Three Presidents
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif., April 17 (AP)Dr. Gebrge W. Auxier, who worked in the Presidential executive office during the Truman, Eisenhower and Johnson Administrations, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived in Sun City, Ariz., since his retirement in 1968.

title: Music: East Berliners
description: For the final event this season of her excellent, hourlong Coffee Concerts yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall, Kazuko Hillyer presented a return engagement of the Berlin String Quartet. These musicians, all members of the Berin Staatskapelle, the orchestra of the East Berlin German State Opera, were the first group from East Germany to play in this country when they toured here three years ago.

title: BigColleges Shuniona's TrackMeet
description: The meet's program lists as recordholders such college track powers as Villanova, Manhattan, Seton Hall, Pentsylvania and Georgetown, among others. But the Iona Relays suffered a power failure yesterday even though the sun shone brightly at Mount St. Michael's Field ill the Bronx.

title: Bees, Then Reds Sting Giants, 110
description: CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) Baseball was upstaged..by honey bees today at Riverfront Stadium when a swarm estimated at between 5.000 and 10.000 in number, took up residence in the San Francisco Giants dugout before the game, forcing a 35minute delay. The Reds went on to rout the Giants, 110.

title: DELAY TO BE SOUGHT IN NEW HEARST TRIAL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 !hospitalized, Patricia Hearst !hospitalized, her attorney said jtoday that he would try to postpone indefinitely a courtroom confrontation with William and Emily Harris, now !charged as her kidnappers. Citing Miss Hearst's frail health, Albert Johnson, the attorney, said he would urge Judge Mark Brandler of Los Angeles Superior Court to halt all proceedings in 'iss Hearst's prosecution there. He said he also wanted to sever her case from that of her codefendants, the Harrises.
