description: SHORT HILLS, N.J.Ira D. Salliman, a textile converter and fabric supermarketer sees himself as Cie little guy who survives hi the land of the junglethe jungle being the fadridden textile business, where giant corporations dominate.

title: Freshmen Crews Encourage Columbia
description: With a look to the past and a hope for the future. Columbia's heavyweight crew lost the varsity and junior varsity races to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology but won the freshman race yesterday on the Ilartem River.

title: Glum Days At a Resort In Portugal
description: SINTRA, Portugal. April 13 This ancient, aristocratic resort, 20 miles west of Lisbon, quietly accepted the Portuguese revolution two years ago and has tried to make the best of it with as few shocks as possible.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Meet a new pair of private eyes. They turn up in STRAIGHT by Steve Knickmeyer (Random House, $6.95). This is Knickmeyer's first novel. He is a reporter for a newspaper in Oklahoma. Thus it is not entirely by happenstance that the locale of Straight is Oklahoma.

title: Cost Advantage Forecast for Nuclear Power
description: In an appraisal that differs substantially from the position of the lord Administration, the Edison Electric Institute predicts that nuclear power will remain less costly than electricity from coal through the 1980's.

title: Associated Press
description: VOLUNTEER LABOR IN MOSCOW: Against the backdrop of St. Basil's In Red Square, Soviet citizens help to clean up the city's streets after long winter. Over a million residents of Moscow took part in what officials called a voluntary festival of Communist labor, but for most of the 140 million who participated nationally, the day or unpaid labor was no holiday. Most citizens are believed to take part because of official and social pressure. By coincidence the annual spring event, known as Stibbotnik, for Saturday, falls on the 106th anniversary of the birth of Lenin, who founded the Soviet state and introduced the custom 57 years ago.

title: Mr. Ford Opts For Low Tariff
description: President Ford has decided against imposing higher tariffs or quotas on shoe imports, and the decision is expected to have major implications for United States trade relations. It also provides Mr. Ford's domestic economic policies with an added bonus: Shoe prices, at least, will stay stable.

title: Sitting In on a HouseSenate Conference Committee
description: WASHINGTONA Congressional study designed to resolve the incongruities of the present Presidential nominating process has been abruptly shelved because some Senators wanted to be able to earn more than 515,000 year in outside speaking fees. The action itself may seem incongruous, even by Congressional standards. But it was a completely consistent result of the procedure called the Congressional Conference that has determined the final shape of all important Federal legislation for the last 187 years. Until six months ago, conferences were closed to both the press and public, and no one really knew how such bizarre bargains were struck.

title: Lewis Schwartz Fiance of Beth Mestel
description: The engagement of Beth Wanda Mestel and Lewis Michael Schwartz has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Ascher Lawrence Mestel of Brooklyn, parents of the prospective bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Schwartz of East Meadow, L.I.

title: A Marathon Spectrum: Music, Mind and Body
description: The desire to run comes from deep within us. From the unconscious, the intuitive, the instinctive. And that desire becomes a passion when the runner learns to race. Then the race becomes all. Becomes the lovemaking of the runner. The feeling after a 10miler truly run is something beyond his previous experience. But all this is just an overture for the marathon. Eventually, every runner begins to hear that tune, the marathon singing in his head.

Jackson of Washington combined, among Democratic Presidential contenders, and far more than President Ford, the Federal Election Commission reported today.

There is something about the cold abstraction of a formula that threatens to sap the joy out of gardening as if there is something in the ground we're better off not knowing about.

The gift will ceate an endowed professorship and related programs of internships and seminars in the field of American business and economic enterprise, the college said.

Designed to teach in a total photographic atmosphere where participants work and learn in a concentrated full time program that promotes both formal and informal interaction between students, and between students and faculty, these workshops enable an adventurous photographer to learn anything from improving one's darkroom techniques to new of seeing.

description: BELMAR AST September, to be closer to my job, I moved from Jersey City, my beloved hometown, to this Monmouth County town on the Atlantic Ocean. I didn't want to lie a strange kind of commuter who iivga in the city and works at the Shore.

title: Blumenthal Wins A Personal Vote
description: The law came down firmly on Albert Blumenthal's side last week, as the briberyperjury indictment of the New York Assembly majority leader was thrown out of State Supreme Court with gusto. While a comfort to Mr. Blumenthal, the court's highly critical explanation for the dismissal represented a first and major setback for Charles Hynes, the state's special nursing home prosecutor.

description: Richard J. Wood, who retired some years ago as president of, Montgomery Ward International, a subsidiary of the mailorder and retail chain, died Thursday while visiting friends in Flagstaff, Ariz. He was 65 years old and lived in Chicago, and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Give the people a vision
description: t is time, I believe, to reexamine the causes of the social and economic plight in which black Americansand particularly the poor blacks of the Northern citiesstill find themselves, despite the legal advances of the 60's. Since so many past analyses of this problem have failed to bring about satisfactory improvement, I think it is time to suggest some new approaches, based largely on new values. It is my view that such a fresh start offers the best hope not only of lifting up the black people but of saving America's cities.

title: Manila Collision Kills 5
description: MANILA, April 17 (Reuters) Five people were killed and 64 injured today, many seriously, in a collision between two buses on a highway near here.

title: SCHOOLS IN GUAM FACING TURMOIL
description: TAMUNING, Guam, April 17 This American island's public school system, the largest in Micronesia, is in the midst of severe educational and financial turmoil that has prompted the substantial United States military community here to consider withdrawing its dependents from the schools.

title: Second of Four Suspects Is Identified in the Slaying of Two Armed Guards
description: A second man was identified yesterday as a suspect in the murder last Monday by four thugs of two armed guards in the New Amsterdam Theater at 214 West 42d Street.

title: Notes: Baby Doe On TVLive From The City Opera
description: When Douglas Moore's The Ballad of Baby Doe is telecast live from the New York State Theater this Wednesday (it starts at 8 P.M on WNET/Channel 13 and WQXRFM in New York City), it will be the largest stereo simulcast ever engineered, reachingvia satelliteover 50 percent of the nation's TVequipped households. Julius Rudel, director of the New York City Opera, makes a point of the fact that the production has not been altered in any way for the purposes of televising, and that the audience in the opera house on Wednesday day night will be undisturbed by the procedure. The business  as  usual approach is made possible by the use of specially developed lowlightlevel cameras which require only oneseventh the amount of light necessary for good transmission.

title: Miss Hearst Decides to Talk
description: Patricia Hearst has decided to cooperate with the authorities in a number of possible cases involving her former associates. The decision presumably will mean a lesser sentence for Miss Hearst, who was convicted for taking part in a bank robbery, and might also head off her prosecution on other charges.

title: Harrington Is Reelected As Liberal Party Leader
description: The state committee of the Liberal Party reelected Dr.l Donald S. Harrington yesterday as chairman for his sixth term, along with David Dubinsky. a party founder, as first vice chairman, and Alex Rose, its chief political strategist, as vice chairman.

The police said they arrested Randolph James Leyendecker, who was charged with capital murder.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 17If you beat her, you feel you've achieved everything, said Evonne Goolagong today.

Other awards will be given to Whitey Ford, Sid Luckman. Sugar Ray Robinson, Irving Jaffee, Leslie MacMitchell and Gertrude Ederle.

title: Somebody Should Have Put Their Names in Lights
description: Let us now praise not so famous men and womenthose timeless smalltime substars of the 30's and 40's whose names deserve to be spelled out in bright lights.

title: Amis and Drabble look back
description: These books are both about novelists who have been out of fashion in their native England and by novelists of a much later generationwriters who made their own names as rebels against tradition, but who now acclaim and reclaim these elders as a glorious heritage. Their books are in some sense conservative, then, but not dramatically so. Kingsley Amis's conservatism is no longer new and dramatic, though it gives a liveliness to his reading of Kipling. Margaret Drabble's essayists are conservative only in the weak sense of the word, conventional in their judgments and fairly truistic in their arguments, though her own interest in Hardy could be called conservative in that it fits the pattern of her recent scholarly and backwardlooking work on Arnold Bennett and Wordsworth. Altogether, the authors and their subjects are symmetrically disposed: Hardy being so good at female characters, so susceptible to women in private life and to Nature as the Great Mother in his literary life, Kipling being so much the celebrant of responsibility and authority, the soldier and the governorfigures Amis has undertaken to praise in defiance of lettwing orthodoxy.

title: Encounter: A $2 Bet With a Blacksmith
description: At Knott's Berry Farm; a huge amusement park in Buena Park, about 22 miles southeast of Los Angeles, the legends of the Old West come alive. Or almost alive. The sheriff is there with his sixguns, and the taffetaclad schoolmarm rules her oneroom empirebut sheriff and schoolmarm and the other inhabitants of this fantasy world are lifeless statues or mechanical contrivances. Not so the blacksmith.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: We love you, Slava
description: Moscow, February 1971: A smiling Mstislav Rostropovich walks onto the stage of the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall to play the cello with an orchestra of students from the Moscow Conservatory. It has been three months since he wrote a letter defending his friend Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn the Nobel Prizewinning novelist who is living at R'stropovich's dacha. Everyone in the hall knows that Soviet authorities have already begun to punish the famous cellist by canceling his foreign tours. The audience rises and applauds for 10 minutes in one of the few Moscow political demonstrations that cannot be punished. Who can take down the names of everyone at the concert? Who is to say the audience is not simply paying tribute to a great musician? Rostropovich takes bow after bow and motions several times for an end to the applause, Many of the young musicians eyes are filled with tears they begin a program of baroque music.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: For the last, several weeks, most economists in goverment and in the private sector have been patting themselves on the back for the perceptiveness of their forecasts last fall on the likely performance of the American economy this yearand with good reason. Some have even begun to tilt their projections slightly upward now that nearly everyone is convinced that the incumbent recovery is not a mere flash in the pan.

title: New York Lutheran Group Acts Over a Possible Split in Church
description: To prepare for the possibility of a schism over the doctrinal and political controversy now besetting the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod, a New York district of the 2.8millionmember denomination has set up an alternative organization called the Association for the Support of Luthern Ministries.

title: Improviser, $12.20, Scores
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 17 (AP)Improviser held off Green Room, a long shot, to win the $143,369 Pan American Handicap at Gulfstream Park today. Pampered Jabneh was third and Lord Henham. the 21 favorite, finished fourth.

title: A Continual Decline in Foreign Area Studies
description: One of the strongest and most persistent trends in American education today is the decline of foreignlanguage and foreignarea studies. The trend raises the question: Will the current generation be adequately prepared to function in an interdependent world?

title: The Scots Don't Just Drink It
description: GLASGOW  Thomas Houston, head of one of the big whisky bottling factories here says that an 80yearold friend visited his home one day and tripped and fell on entering. He was all right. the friend said, but his leg hurt, and he asked for some whisky. Mr. Houston said the friend doused the leg with the whisky and, thereafter, the leg was all right.

title: Mortgage Money Plentiful, Raising Hopes for Housing
description: ??? home buyers will find mortgage money much more available this spring than last fall or a year ago.

title: Kindness Persists Even as Children Are Brutalized
description: BEIRUTIt is easy to be ambushed in the shell pocked, garbagestrewn streets of Beirutby teenagers with real weapons or, more often, by scampering packs of children emulating their elders with sticks, pieces of lead pipe or, in the wealthier quarters, with plastic submachine guns.

title: Bronx Rape Suspect Fails In Bid to Escape Custody
description: A suspect accused of rape tried unsuccessfully to escape from custody yesterday in the Central Booking Facility in the Bronx by seizing the gun from the holster of Police Officer Donald Brand, his captor.

title: Television This Week
description: American Indian assigned to the District Attorney's office in New York

title: Jean Middendorf, Bank Aide, Bride
description: Jean Reynolds Middendorf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Kennedy B. Middendorf of Syosset, L. 1., was married yesterday afternoon to Garretson Rasmussen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Forbes Rasmussen of Rye, N. Y.

description: A large majority of Americans favor the instruction on morals and moral behavior in the schools, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

description: TodayJunior Olympics, Thomas School of Horsemanship, Round Swamp Road, Melville, Li. Green maiden special, junior and children's working hunters; combined training, pleasure, junior olympic jumping, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Notes: Washington Braces for Onslaught
description: Faced with the prospect of a 20 percent increase in visitors this year, result of Bicentennial fever, the nation's capital is launching today a park and ride program aimed at minimizing traffic congestion and easing the path of an estimated 17.2 million tourists.

title: SARETT RUDE RUSSO
description: Sarett Rude Russo, a screenwriter and coauthor, in 1949, of the stage play Flow Long Till Summer, died Friday at New York Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Milan, Italy. Mrs. Russo leaves her husband, Armando, and two sons, Paolo and Joshua.

title: Miss Rich Fiancee Of J. A. Cosentino Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Willis F. Rich Jr. of Tonka Bay, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roxanne Rich, to John Arthur Cosentino Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cosentino of Upper Montclair, N. .j. The wedding is planned for Aug. 14.

title: La Verne Wood Wed to L. W. Wertz
description: La Verne Jill Wood, daughter of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Harold L. Wood of Somers, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Langston W. Wertz, son of the late Rev.and Mrs. James F. Wertz of Charlotte, N.C.

title: Health Plan Urged
description: ATLANTA, April 17 (AP)Mayor Mark Heller of Greenville S. C. told the Democratic Platform Committee today, It Is imperative to Include health statement in the platform, especially for preventive health care.

title: A Dead
description: Oh, the ??? of my compositional We is not to be believed! Ever since the premiere of Nine Rivers From Jordan I haven't touched an opera; I thought I'd never write one again. Do you know what It is to have a major failure at the New York City Opera? You fed dirty, you feel that you've conned everybody, you feel guilty. I don't mind bad reviews. But when you know that you've bored everybody, that the audience hates your music because they're bored, then you really take stock of yourself and say, maybe this Isn't my business after all.

title: For 5 PrieststoBe, Some New Realities
description: AT midday next Saturday in St. Agnes Cathedral In Rockville Centre, five young men will be imbued with the indelible character of a priest In the eyes of the Roman Catholic church.

title: Temple EmanuE1 Links Bicentennial to Passover
description: Temple EmanuEl celebrated the Bicentennial yesterday morning with a special Sabbath service that emphasized the relationship of the nation's principles of independence and religious freedom with the Passover festival.

title: Polyansky Is Made Envoy
description: MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI)Dmitri S. Polyansky, dismissed as Agriculture Minister because of Soviet crop failures, was appointed ambassador to Japan today. He was the only man dropped from the Soviet Unlion's ruling Politburo last month. Mr. Polyansky is scheduled to arrive In Tokyo on April 22.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: 0 NE recent weekend, I drove up Glen Ridge Avenue, a winding street that connects Glen Ridge with my town, Montclair, and I was somewhat dismayed, I must admit, over the changes wrought along the Montclair end of the street in just a few months.

title: In Balkans, Old Borders Are Fading
description: FLORINA, GreeceEvery Wednesday and Saturday, peaceful coexistence gets a tryout in Florina. Those are market days, and many of the customers are Yugoslays, who drive across the border 10 miles north of here. Many of the Greek shopkeepers greet the visitors in their own language, a Slavic dialect that is basically a form of Bulgarian.

title: What to Do When Seasickness Occurs
description: What to do about mal de mer has been an acute problem ever since the first Phoenicians started to sail the high seas. The problem is becoming more wide

title: Vodka Is No. 1
description: In 1939, John G. Martin bought a struggling little liquor company named Smirnoff for $14,000. I'll never know why, says Mr. Martin.

title: Paperbacks
description: IS THAT YOU MISS BLUE? by M. E. Kerr. (Dell/ LaurelLeaf, $1.25.) Life is unjust in direct proportion to one's vulnerability: that's the theme of this funny, sharp tale for teenagers, one of the best of the contemporary crop of boarding school novels.

title: Dedicated Jersey Swimmer Sets Sights on Olympic Berth
description: The American women's recordholder in the 100meter butterfly swim owes much of her success to an unusual source:

title: Coast Narcotics Arrests Off
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 17 (Reuters)  Kenneth Budman, a state narcotics officer says that the authorities have most given up arresting people found carrying marijuana. Un der a new law in effect since January, the penalty for being caught with one ounce or less of marijuana is a $100 fine. Previously, possession of any amount was a felony and term, by a possible prison term,

title: ART VIEW
description: This Is The Very Model Of a Modern Museum Catalogue

title: A Little Late, Agreement on A Campaign Law
description: Congress has reached a major station on its slow progress toward reconstitution of the Federal Election Commission, with agreement on compromise legislation. But, even if President Ford does not veto the bill, Federal subsidies to Presidential candidates probably will not resume until midMay at the earliest, and there is growing evidence that a number of campaigns are beginning to hurt.

title: Manfred
description: Out for a walk I was, wanted to clear my head, I'd been drinking the night before, tequila mostly, a bit of lime juice, one lime per bottle, or four limes in all, by the end of the evening. I was feeling poorly. I had asked for help with the tequila, but no one came, all sent regrets, busy elsewhere, prior engagement, don't go out after dark any more, that sort of thing, allergic to rats, that sort of thing, could not blame them. My brother sent regrets, from his room behind the kitchen, stuffy bastard, nose in a book probably, or playing his drums, the jackass, fraternity is not among his talents.

title: Houstnn Hires Tellez
description: LOS ANGELES, Anril 17 (AP)Tom Tellez, University of California, Los Angeles, field event coach for the last eight years, was named today as head track and field coach at the University of Houston, succeeding the retiring Johnnv Morris. Tellez, 42 years old, will take over at Houston after the current season ends. Morris, 68, has been at Houston since 1957,

title: Nash K. Burger is a former member of the Book Review staff.
description: In 1870 Victoria Woodhull was the first woman to declare herself a candidate for President of the United States.

title: Breaking the Bank
description: THE South spawns them and leaves them to die. The weak, the gentle, the lame. When the bus comes for them, they need no promises of joy or jewels or fortune. They leave their private hells, for purgatory.

title: FLU SHOTS TO BEGIN IN TEST IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)  The first shots of the new swine flu vaccine will be administered in experimental doses next week to hundreds of Federal employees. It is the first step toward mass immunization of the United States population.

title: ART
description: ONE of the biggest surprises about the current exhibition at Hofstra's University's Emily Lowe Gallery is that the gallery possesses such a distinctive collection of its own. Ever since the gallery opened in 1963, it has had to use Its shoestring budget for the most basic costs, such as maintenance. It has had almost no funds for the purchase of art works.

title: NATO Allies Divided Over Tank Gun
description: WASHINGTON. April 17At a time when the North Atlantic Treaty allies are emphasizing standardization of their weapons the United States. West Germany and Britain are going in separate directions in planning guns for tanks.

title: If You Go
description: to college on your summer vacation, check first at the colleges near your home. If you are planning to travel farther afield, canvass the colleges en route for courses and ask whether they provide oncampus accommodations. Increasingly American universifies, hardpressed for cash, are putting their idle dormitories to work and soliciting the tourist dollar by offering vacations with perspective and depth.

title: Hurok Presents A PlayItSafe Season
description: Tomorrow night, when the curtain rises on the Royal pallet's production of Romeo and Juliet at the Metropolitan Opera House, Hurok Concerts will begin its most ambitious ballet season ever in New York, presenting five major companies in a total of 15 weeks of dance. The Royal's fourweek visit will be followed at the Met with three  week engagements each by the Royal Danish Ballet, American Ballet Theater and the National Ballet of Canada. In addition, Hurok will present the Australian Ballet at the Uris Theater for two weeks this summer.

title: Penn, Drake Relays Go to Metric System
description: The Penn Relays Carnival is making its own contribution to Philadelphia's Bicentennial celebration this week by staging a meet that will be both historic and revolutionary. The Penn

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Loans to less developed countries are frequently cited as a major problem area in international banking. According to some observers, a crisis is developing and widespread defaults will occur.

title: The Midas Consequence
description: Legends tell us that Midas was given not only thee golden touch, but also ass's earsthis because he preferred the music of Pan to that of Apollo. The late Michael Ayrton has worked both of these mutations Into a concentration of musings that the publisher calls a roman d clef about Picasso.

title: CUNY Solutions Are All Painful
description: It is increasingly clear that without greater state or local financial help, which is highly unlikely, the City University of New York will either have to charge tuition or end its open admissions policy.

title: Postal Service Raising Some Charges Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)The Pos'al Service's fees for special delivery, registered mail and other services increase tomorrow up to 33 percent.

description: MONTREALAfter 11 years in public life, nearly eight of them as Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau can still surprise his fellow Canadians and American observers.

title: Hospitals Resist a Trustee ConflictofInterest Bill
description: Officials of voluntary hospitals, contending that they are already under more than enough governmental scrutiny are resisting new legislative attempts to require disclosure of possible conflicts of interests by their trustees.

title: EgyptRumania Arms Deal
description: CAIRO, April 17 (UPI)Egypt's War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Ghany elGamasy returned home yesterday after a fiveday armsshopping visit to Rumania, which he described as successful. General Gamasy, who made similar visits to France and Yugoslavia in recent weeks, was seeking spare parts for Soviet equipment as well as arms.

title: Road to the Olympics
description: Red Smith

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: photography In me 1930's was not all documentary pictures of bread lines, dust howls and dam building. It was also glamour pictures of beautiful and talented ladies and gentlemen Icing improbable things in gorgeous settings. Barbara Mathes at Knoedler had the bright idea of hanging both kinds of pictures together in what is currently the most enjoyable photography snow in town.

title: Susan Spalding, Alexis C. Towle Plan Marriage
description: Mrs. John Franck Spalding of Pittsfield, Ill., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Susan Mary Spalding, to Alexis Charles Towle, son of Sidney N. Towle, headmaster of Kent School, and Mrs. Towle.
It was July in April yesterday as the temperature reached 91 degrees, a record, shortly after 2 P.M., erasing the 80yearold mark of 88 degrees for the date.

title: N.Y. State Gets All Its Loans
description: The most pressing part of New York State's fiscal crisis came to an end last week when State Comptroller Arthur Levitt announced that the state had met its $4 billion spring borrowing goal, The state is now assured of having enough cash to pay its hills and meet its localaid commitments for the fiscal year without further borrowing from the public credit market until next spring.

title: Motorcycles Move Up in the World
description: FROM an unsavory image projected more than 20 years ago by a youthful Marlon Brando in The Wild One, the motorcycle has moved on to encompass a larger, more varied audience.

title: Dear Tourist: It's Not Money If It's Not Dollars
description: The United States can marshal an extensive inventory of surprises for the visitor from Europe, most of which are less than daunting. But how does one deal with the secondclass treatment handed a visitor by firstrate midtown Manhattan banks?

title: Brazilian Death Squad Linked to the Police Continues to Cause Controversy
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 17  Using 30 investigators and three planes, Brazilian security policemen have tracked down a squad of kidnappers through the jungles and backlands. The police caught the criminals this week and rescued their vicvictim, 5yearold Gustavo Aoki Yoshioka, son of a JapaneseBrazilian agricultural millionaire.

title: High Tuition in Colleges Will Go Still Higher
description: Leading private colleges are apparently becoming economically accessible largely to children of the rich and of those poor enough to qualify for extensive financial aid. The trend is reflected in enrollment figures: Onefourth of all American college students are now in private institutions, compared with onehalf 25 years ago.

title: Revenge
description: By Noel Hynd. 274 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $7.95.

title: The Old Testament
description: Dave Anderson

title: Alternatives to Detente
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford deserves high marks for quietly and skillfully distancing himself from the extravagant pretensions of Nixonera dtente. The word has been banished from our vocabulary as of March 1, 1976, and it was high time. We ought to quit trying to conduct our foreign policy in French, which confuses our citizenry, even when elucidated in dulcet GermanAmerican accents.

title: The Empty Seat at the Seder
description: After the 1975 Boston Marathon, Rabbi Richard J. Israel learned from a computer printout that the runner who had helped him during the race (U6) was Tomiji Yamamoto of Japan. He invited Yamamoto to be a guest at last week's traditional Passover seders.

title: Askew Endorses Jackson
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 17 (UPI)  Gov. Reubin Askew endorsed Senator Henry M. Jackson for President today and applied as a delegate for Mr. Jackson at the Democratic National Convention.

title: POLITICS
description: NASSAU and Suffolk are often viewed as political Siamese twins. As one county goes, so goes the the other, according to the theory. But the New York Presidential primary demonstrated, as other elections have, that the theory is often not vaild.

title: Man Guilty in Live Burial
description: FERNANDINA BEACH, April 17 (UPI)A circuit court jury yesterday found William Peter Wright Jr., 29yearold on of n wealthy dairy farmer guilty of first degree murder in the live burial by bulldozer of his wife, Laura, 19.

title: FRANK C. SCHELL Sr.
description: Frank C. Schell Sr., a retired vice president of the Savings Banks Trust Company of New York, died Friday night at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived at 45 Popham Road in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Law Student Fiance Of Maria Zequeira
description: The engagement of Marla Teresa de Jesus Zequeira Zequeira to V. Anthony Maggipinto has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Anacleto Zequeira Rios to South Miami, Pla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Maggipinto of Southampton. L. I.

title: Carter Has Ad Headstart in Pennsylvania
description: PITTSBURGH, April 17Jimmy Carter has stolen a march on his Democratic rivals by raising enough money for fairly intensive television and radio advertising campaign in the week leading up to the crucial Pennsylvania primary.

title: The StillStrange Stavisky Story
description: Supporters of the Stavisky bill said the bill was for the schoolchildren; critics said it was for the politicians. No sooner did the New York State Senate override Governor Carey's veto, and the bill become law, than the supporters started talking compromise and the opponents, legal action.

title: U.S. Sues to End Redlining
description: Lending institutions have often been blamed for contributing to the decay of black or racially mixed neighborhoods by unjustifiably refusing mortgages there, a practice known as redlining. The Justice Department last week indicated it shares that belief by filing a suit that accuses several nationwide organizations of banks and real estate appraisers of using racially discriminatory standards,

title: The Bishops Of New Jersey
description: NEW JERSEY'S four topranking Roman Catholic bishops, the chief pastors for 3 million people in 21 counties, constitute a healthy mix of churchmanship.

title: FILM VIEW
description: There is no war. No foreign troops are massed on the border making threatening gestures. Everyone has enough to eat. Unemployment and discrimination on the basis of race or class are unknown. Something very nearly like the perfect state has been achieved. Yet not long ago the representatives of this perfect state swooped down on Ingmar Bergman, while he was in a theater rehearsing a new play, and carried him off under guard to question him at length about charges that he had defrauded the state of tax monies due. It was frontpage news in Stockholm, and here too for a while. Shortly before the charges against Bergman were dropped, Bernard Welnraub, The Times correspondent in London, reported from Stockholm that as much as anything else, many Swedes resented Bergman's talent. He was con sidered to have gotten too big for his britches. Bergman, the internationally acclaimed filmmaker, had somehow spoiled Swedish symmetry by being a large lump in a flat landscape, by being recognized, critically and financially, for his genius, and genius is something they don't dispense m governmentrun clinics. It was as if the Swedish national organism automatically was trying to reject him. The aberration had to be excised.

title: William Buckley snubbed him, Styron lost some crabmeat
description: This is an interesting book which gets better as it goes along and gradually absorbs one once again into a familiar, very current form; the author's search for himself in the guise of fulfilling a much more merchantable assignment. In this case, Joe McGinniss was sent out with a lucrative contract to look for the vanishing American hero. Even to begin with. for many reasons which he enumerates, he was pessimistic about finding

title: Artificial Breeding of Peregrines Is Succeeding
description: A program that many wildlife experts consider to he one of the most ambitious attempts by man to restore an endangered animal species to the wild is under way in a barnlike structure on the outskirts of Ithaca, N. Y.

title: Updating a Heritage from Greece
description: HEMPSTEAD HARDBOILED eggs dyed red are symbolic of the Greek Orthodox Easter. The holiday will be celebrated next Sunday, one week later than the Western Easter because of the discrepancy between the older Julian calendar and the more widely used Gregorian system. Greek Easter begins after a midnight service with the distribution of the red eggs, representing both blood and a new life. The eggs figure prominently in the Easter dinner. At the beginning of the meal the guests tap one another's eggs and the person whose egg remains uncracked the longest is considered blessed with good fortune. Red are baked into the Easter breads, the lambropsomo and the sweet, rich braided loaves of tsourekia. Four eggs are used, one for each arm of the cross.

title: Ten Miles Per
description: Price increases on automobiles are nothing new in this era of rising costs, but RollsRoyce has just announced what may be the biggest increase in history. The British producer of luxury cars has just raised the tab for its new Camargue model by $15,000  from $75,000 to $90,000.

title: Gramp: Family Album for a Small Town
description: CLARK'S SUMMIT, Pa. Gramp, book about the last three years of a senile old man as photographed by his grandsons, is a best seller here in his hometown.

title: In the Third World, Newest Is Oldest
description: KARACHI, PakistanAcross the bottom of a muggy bowl in the bonedry hills that surround this seaside desert city stretch row after row of freestanding concrete walls, clustered in various arrangements, some cubicles, others whitewashed crosses.

title: Getting To Know The Alps On Foot
description: The Lotschengleticher, a massive lake of dirty, crusty snow, lies before us, looking like the outsized paw of some mountain monster. Wedged tightly into a broad canyon high in the Alpine wilderness, the glacier appears i mmovable and secure. It Is thousands of years old. Still, there is a precariousness about it, as it it might break apart without warning and send tons of ice charging down the valley, burying entire villages in its wake.

title: Editors
description: BLOODSHED, by Cynthia ()rick. (Knopf. $6.95.) The title story and three novellas by an adventurous writer with a lot on her mind and a feeling for life as mystery and riddle. HEARING SECRET HARMONIES, by Anthony Powell. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) The last of the i2 volumes comprising Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time chronicle of English life over 40 years; this, one of the more successful novels in the series, is set in the sixties and the tone is both autumnal and sinister.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: National Coin Week begins today, and it has seldom had more auspicious numismatic surroundings. Not only have coins and medals been playing the leading role in commemorating the nation's Bicentennial this year, but the public's attention has also just been even more dramatically refocused on numismatics as the result of last weeks rebirth of the $2 bill. Now it is up to the individual collector and the local coin club to put it all together.

title: Bronx Mart's Job Loss Greater Than Indicated
description: An official survey of the Bronx Terminal Market suggests that the decline in employment there has been far greater than anyone has previously charged.

title: Letters
description: Singular rivals

title: Notes: All in The Family
description: Archie Bunker and his brood Will be moving again next fall, this time to Wednesday nights. It will be the fourth address in six years for the CBS first family, and is an attempt at blockbusting on the part of the network.

title: Unconstitutional Veto
description: President Ford has submitted to the Senate the nomination of William B. Poff to fill a Federal district judgeship in Virginia. Mr. Poff is a wellregarded attorney, a former president of the Virginia Trial Lawyers Association. He is approved by the bar association, endorsed by the Republican Congressman from his district and acceptable to the Republican Governor of Virginia.

title: Laurie Lane Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Marc Lane Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Ann Lane, to Robert Ballard Horner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Horner of Louisville Ky. An August wedding is planned.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Orle of the most widely quoted statistics of the socalled dance explosion is that for every person in the United States who bought a ticket for a professional dance performance in 1965 about 16 bought a ticket in 1975. The figure for 1976 is likely to be substantially larger. A lot of this vast increase in activity is accounted for by moderndance performances. There are now 139 dance companies on the books of the National Endowment for the Arts, and the majority of those are moderndance troupes. A rather smaller percentage of the increase is due to the larger audiences and greater number of performances being given by America's Big Three classic companies, New York City Ballet. American Ballet Theater and City Center Joffrey Ballet, and by foreign touring companies, as is witnessed by the longer season the Hurok organization takes at the Metropolitan Opera House these days. Yet over and above all this, and vital to the entire picture, are the resident ballet companies across the country.

title: Seton Hall Triumphs In 3 Relays
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 17Take away a 14second hurdler from most 480yard shuttle hurdles relay teams and there won't be much left. But take Joe Myatt, a 14second hurdler suffering from a hamstring pull, away from Seton Hall's shuttle hurdles team and there still is a team that boasts the fastest time in the country this year.

title: Jane C. Lovell Towed in July
description: Jane Clarice Lovell, who expects to receive a B.A. degree in education in June from the University of Tennessee, and Gary Joseph Thibodeau, a physical education instructor at Maryville (Tenn.) College, will be married July 31 in the Concord (Tenn.) Methodist Church.

title: Renae Dawn Walaker Is Engaged to Scott Wenner, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ray E. Walaker of Leonard, N. D., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Renae Dawn Walaker, to Scott Jay Wenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Wenner of New York. The couple plan to marry June 26.

title: lavits Meets With Sadat. Praises Stand on Peace
description: CAIRO, April 17 (UPI)Senator Jacob K. Javits, one of Israel's staunchest supporters in Congress, said today he believed President Anwar elSadat was seeking peace between the Arabs and Israel.

title: BRIDGE
description: In the half century that contract bridge has been played one might suppose that every corrceivable type of defensive strategy has been discussed in the literature of the game. But that would be a rash assumption, and there is a lot to be said for the proposition that bridge is an inexhaustible mine for the analyst.

title: BILL WOULD SHIFT CITY INSPECTIONS
description: Beame administration offidais began a drive last week to win passage in the City Council of a bill that would permit licensed architects and engineers to perform much of the inspection work on new building projects now done by city employees.

title: 3 TRINITY CHAPELS WILL BE CHURCHES
description: The three chapels remaining under the care of historic Trinity Parish are well on their way to becoming fullfledged Episcopal churches, following an overwhelming vote for independence by their congregations.

title: Chinese Leader Reappears Amid Reports That He Had Resigned to Protest AntiTeng Drive
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, April 18Yeh Chien'ing, China's Minister of Defense and one of the leading members of the socalled moderate faction, reappeared in Peking last night for the first time since the beginning of the antirightist camDeign over two months ago.

title: Ohio State Grant To Women's Sports
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17 (AP)A grantinaid pro gram will be initiated by Ohio State Universiy this fall for women's intercollegiate athletics, it was announced today.

title: Miss Gorowitz Engaged to Scot Perlin
description: Martha L. Gorowltz. who is with the Chase Manhattan Bank N.A. as a cash compensation officer in its human resources department, and R. Scot Perlin, who is with the Bankers Trust Company In its lendingofficers training program, plan to be married at the Plaza on May 23.

title: Reneging on a Promise
description: First the Supreme Court and then Congress changed the rules of political financing in the middle of the 1976 election, and President Ford soon will have his chance to make matters worse. An unfair burden has been placed on the backs of candidates laboring in the primaries, and the Presidential nominations of both parties might be decided as an unfortunate consequence.

title: No More Uncirculated Sets
description: The U.S. Mint normally gives plenty of advance warning before it cuts oft the ordering period for any of its various coin offerings. Under the pressures, apparently, of its many coin and medal activities In this Bicentennial year, the Mintfor the first time in memoryhas slipped up. The ordering period for the regular annual 1976 nonsilver 12piece uncirculated coin set, which opened Feb. 2, was cut off by the Mint as of last Thursday, April 15, but the official announcement was not issued in time for inclusion in this column last Sunday (April 11). Mint officials have expressed regret over this timing mixup.

title: Rent control must go
description: Within a few weeks New York City's system of rent control may finally be laid to rest. Like a Japanese straggler on a Pacific Island, rent control is the last survivor of the economic controls of the Second World War and has hung on in the limited turf of the five boroughs for 33 years; it has weathered New York's shift from a manufacturing to an office center, waves of suburhanization, ethnic changes in the city, two more wars, the longest prolonged boom in the history of the nation and numerous recessions. But it is beginning to appear that rent control may not survive the present economic and fiscal crisis of New York. Though the City Council granted its approval for an extension of rent control earlier this spring, the State Legislature is expected to take up the issue before the adjournment of its current session. A serious battle is expected, and the outcome could be a major alteration of the current rentcontrol system or perhaps its total abolition.

title: What's Doing in CINCINNATI
description: LEBENSKUNSTOutsiders often dismiss this onetime Queen City of the West (so christened by Longfellow) as just another old Midwestern city. Most people recognize it as the home of the World Series champion baseball Reds, some as the home of Proctor & Gamble. But how many know that it is seductively Southern in nature, practically Viennese culturally and boasts two fivestar restaurants? All told, Cincinnati with its 19thcentury Lebenskunst, or art of living, may be the bestkept secret in the United States. It has identity, a sense of place, style. An active urban renewal program has forestalled the innercity blight besetting other metropolitan areas. After 188 years the downtown section, one you can walk about in safety at night, is still the hub of commercial, cultural and sports life. One welltraveled resident says, There is more activity here at 2 A.M. than in most other cities at 8 P.M. Cincinnati's 1.4 million peoplepredominantly ethnic German, black and Appalachianthrive on music, sports and good food; they are politically conservative and rarely trendy. Five years hence there will be double the current (1,400 room) hotel space, tangible evidence that they mean it when in shops you hear, Y'all come

title: Headliners
description: The latest attempt by Andrei D. Sakharov the dissident Russian physicist, to indicate his support for other Russian dissidents has ended with his being detained by police after striking two policemen. Mr. Sakharov had gone to the Soviet city of Omsk last week to attend the trial of a Tatar nationalist accused of slandering the state. When Dr. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena, were refused entry into the courtroom, they protested that the ban was illegal. Dr. Sakharov said that police then began to push him and others out of the corridor and that he then struck two policemen. The Sakharovs were taken to a police station, where they signed statements describing what had happened and were released. It was not clear whether charges would be brought against them, but a charge of violence or the threat ot violence against a policeman is punishable by up to five years in prison under Soviet law.

title: Ford Leads Reagan In a California Poll; Gov. Brown Ahead
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16President Ford has regained the lead over former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California in a contest for'this state's 167 delegates to the Republican Presidential convention, according to the most recent California poll released this week.

title: The Mideast Turmoil May Yet Produce Some Hope
description: JERUSALEMRestraint, that rarest of commodities in the Middle East, has been on conspicuous display in the region recently, leading to hope here that something positive may actually emerge from the year of chaos in Lebanon and other developments in the area.

title: POLITICS
description: RESIDENT FORD wanted someone wealthy and politically attractive. someone who would make him look good in the November election, someone like Representative Millicent Fenwick.

title: GETTING IN
description: On my first day at Columbia College, a high point was the welcome extended the freshman class of which I was a part by Admissions Director Henry Coleman. I chose each of you to come here, he said. Among you are countless newspaper editors, varsity captains and valedictorians. But there were many others, of equal attainment, who were not selected. I found something, in each of you, which was worthy. We loved Henry Coleman for this, for having seen our worth and for having seen to it that, henceforth, we would forever be among the elect. That was in 1965.

title: A Case of Discovery: GAF vs. Kodak vs. U.S.
description: It is 5 P.M. last Jan. 29 and inside the Federal Courthouse in downtown Manhattan two prominent attorneys were preparing to square off.

title: Gerry Yokota, Kevin Crowell Plan Marriage
description: Gerry Yokota, daughter of Ruby Bell Yokota of Frankfort, Ky., and the late George John Yokota, and Kevin Chamberlain Crowell of Noroton, Conn., plan to be married. The prospective bride's mother has announced the engagement.

title: Islanders Win, 42, For 22 Series Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 17Determined to return to Buffalo with their National Hockey League quarterfinal series against the Sabres squared, the New York Islanders never trailed tonight in posting a 42 victory. The fourofsevengame series resumes upstate Tuesday night with the teams tied at two games each.

title: Cheesy
description: For 18 months I have studied the depravities of Times Square. They are extensive, as everyone has reported, but what everyone has generally overlooked is how inferior, how banal, how lowerclass they are. Compared to the depravities of Paris. London and Southern California, which I have also studied, Times Square's are decidedly bottomdrawer. It is a pity the word cheesy has disappeared from American slang because there is no other that so adequately describes the depravities of Times Square. Its depravities are the cheesencountered.

title: Gerulaitis Overcomes Rosewall
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 17 (UPI)  Vitas Gerulaitis easily defeated an ailing Ken Rosewall, 75, 62, and Tony Roche downed Eddie Dibbs, 64, 62, in the semifinals of the $60,000 W.C.T. tournament today.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The article, Teaneck: A Sales Pitch for Integration (March 21), stated that Teaneck was the first community in the United States to voluntarily integrate its schools (in 1963).

title: Cunningham Isn't Giving Up
description: If Patrick Cunningham, the New York State Democratic chairman, finally cooperates In Special State Prosecutor Maurice Nadjari's corruption investigation In the Bronx, it will not he because he failed to explore the possibilities of legal exemption.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: MASSACHUSETTS

title: 100 Days, Gradually
description: DaORE than anything else, it would he a question of style and of priorities. Floyd Sanford Linton knew that three months ago when he became the first Democrat to occupy the of. lice of Presiding Officer of the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: PriceFixing in the Professions
description: WASHINGTONLewis H. Goldfarb feels very gratified these days and in the best David and Goliath tradition, he has good reason.

title: The Secret of Woodpeckers
description: Like the migration of birds and the ability of whales to withstand the bends during deep dives, the hammering of woodpeckers without suffering head injury has never been fully explained. A team of California researchers has come up with some possible answers, and those answers, curiously, might help in such things as the improvement of protective helmets.

title: Cosmos Open on TV Today Only in New York and Peru
description: MIAMI, April 17 The United States national television networks have ignored' tomorrow's North American Soccer League opener here between the Toros and the New York Cosmos, but News a Peruvian network hasn't and of neither have Soccer Channels 9 and 47, which will show the game live in New York at 4 P.M. in English and Spanish 11, respectively.

title: India, China Rapprochement?
description: India and China are planning to exchange ambassadors for the first time since a border dispute alienated the two nations 15 years ago. The moves could have an important impact throughout Asia, especially if New Delhi's action represents a desire to assert a degree of independence from the Soviet Union.

title: LEBANESE REPORT PRESIDENT OPENS WAY TO REMOVAL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17President Suleiman Franjieh was reported today to have signed a weekold constitution al amendment that would permit the election of a new head of state and the opening of a possible way to end the Lebanese civil war.

title: Legislative Aide in Connecticut Is Cleared of Conflict Charges
description: HARTFORDArthur Lewis, legislative commissioner for Connecticut's General Assembly, has been cleared by the Assembly's Ethics Committee of charges of conflict of interest by the Connecticut Civil'.. Liberties Union.

title: 1,267 COMMITTEES GIVE ADVICE TO U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)  At the end of last year, according to a new Government report, there were 1,267 Federal advisory committees whose only purpose was giving advice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Slow trading volume and a subdued tone characterized the stock market last week, as it continued the gingerly process of consolidating the heady gains early 1976. The Dow Jones Industrial average, after dropping more than 23 points in the previous week, wound up with an advance of 12,20 points to close 980.48 last Thursday before closing for the Good Friday holiday.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown refleets prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: CONCERT BY FLUTIST EVOKES INDIA'S PAST
description: The transverse bamboo flute is more redolent of India's distant past than any other instrument played by the country's concert artists. And because of its traditional association with the god Krishna, it calls up pastoral images of spring. The Indian flutist T. Viswanathan drew on these associations and images during his concert at Asia House yesterday afternoon, while Easter strollers took advantage of the balmy weather on nearby Fifth Avenue.

title: Chatist, 28, is Killed Alter Midair Collision
description: SENECA FALLS, N. Y., April 18 (AP)A parachutist fell to her death here today after colliding in midair with another jumper, the state police reported.

title: Prisons Head Subpoenaed
description: TRENTON, April 18 (UPI)William H. Fauver, head of New Jersey prisons, was subpoenaed yesterday to appear May 15 before the State Parole Board investigating the reasons behind the release of many ineligible inmates. The State Parole Board chairman, Christopher Dietz, has ordered Mr. Fauver to provide his panel with information on nearly 3,000 inmates.

title: BISHOP MOORE HITS BETRAYAL OF CITY
description: Episcopal Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of New York yesterday accused corporations that leave the city of betrayal.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Soma Morgenstern Dies at 85; Novelist of Rural East Europe
description: Soma Morgenstern, the Polishborn novelist whose books reflected the simple, pastoral life of village and farm that once existed in Eastern Europe, died Saturday at. Roosevelt Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 61 West 74th Street.

title: GOY. MOORE FACES EXTORTION TRIAL
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 17Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. goes on trial Tuesday in Federal court here for alleged extortion.

title: BISHOP MOORE HITS BETRAYAL OF CITY
description: Episcopal Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of New York yesterday accused corporations that leave the city of betrayal.

title: TEXAS POLITICIANS GIVE REAGAN EDGE IN MAY I PRIMARY
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 18Ronald Reagan holds a clear advantage in the campaign leading to the Texas primary on May 1, most Texas politicians believe.

title: LAXITY IS FOUND ON MEDICAID CARDS
description: State auditors have found that controls and security over blank Medicaid identification cards by a city agency were nonexistent and that as a result the state's Medicaid program was being exposed to many potential fraudulent abuses.

title: FRANK E. MARTIN
description: Frank E. Martin, former head of the industrial arts departIment at Glen Cove (L.I.) High School, died Friday at the home of his son, Dr. William F. Martin, at 1 St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove. He was 84 years old.

title: Cosmos Capture Opener
description: MIAMI, April 18  The New York Cosmos parlayed a faultless defense and a secondhalf goal by David Clements for a 10 victory over the Miami Toros today in the North American Soccer League opener for both clubs.

title: Norton Simon Inc. Reports Record Sales and Earnings
description: Norton Simon Inc., maker of consumer products, achieved record sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended March 31. Its report, issued over the weekend, showed net income in the quarter at $20.8 million, or 45 (cents a share, up 13.8 percent from the yearearlier $18.3 milIlion or 39 cents a share.

title: 2,000 Young Jews Hold Lively Fairon Park Mall
description: One New Yorker who was apparently not troubled by the heat yesterday was Daniel Freedlander, 24 years old, a rabbinical student. In the midst of the 96degree temperature on Central Park's Mall, Mr. Freedlander looked at the cloudless sky and said.

title: PRESIDENT'S PARTY AHEAD IN COLOMBIA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 18 (AP)Early returns in municipal and provincial elections today appeared to give a qualified vote of confidence to the Liberal party of President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen.

title: New Finds Suggest Mayas Originated in the Highlands
description: Archeologists digging in Guatemala have unearthed evidence that may shed light on one of the oldest mysteries surrounding the ancient Maya civilization: why such an advanced culture should have arisen in so inhospitable a place as the hot, tropical lowlands of northern Guatemala and Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula where most of their ruined cities are found today.

title: Blacks and Puerto Ricans a Bronx Majority
description: New York City's white population declined by more than 600,000 between 1970 and 1975, according to an analysis of United States Census figures. During that period the Bronx became the first borough in the city's history with a majority black and Puerto Rican population, the figures showed.

title: DR. WARREN I. TITUS
description: Dr. Warren Irving Titus, an internist on Long Island for 50 years, died Friday at his home, 6 Highland Road, Glen Cove. He was 76 years old.

title: Rice Farms Team Takes Show Title
description: MELVILLE, LI., April 18 The Rice Farms team of Huntington scored 24 points and won the Division A championship today at the Junior Olympic horse show.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An organization formed to save the battleship New Jersey from destruction is seeking to bring back the ship, a veteran of three wars and the most decorated of World War II, possibly to rest in Sandy Hook,. as a memorial in her homestate waters, the group's rector said. The effort was initiated by the Battleship New Jersey Historical Museum Society, under whose; prodding Governor Byrne appointed the nine member Battleship New Jersey Commission to work toward bringing the ship home.

description: SAGAFJORD (Norwegan. Ampriran). Lett Montego Bay April 15; due 9 A.M. at W. 55th St.

description: Ellen: A Mother's Story of Her Runaway Daughter by Betty Wason (Reader's Digest: Crowell, $7.95).

title: The Stage: Lowell's The Old Glory
Congress Likely to Press Its Role in Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Interviews with nearly two dozen members of Congress indicate they believe that changes of the last six years in Congress and the law make a continuing struggle with the Presidency over the formulation of foreign policy nearly certaineven if there is a new Secretary of State or a Democratic administration next year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, charged yesterday that Washington was interfering in the internal affairs of Western European countries by warning them against participation by Communists in their governments. The newspaper was obviously replying to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who recently said that the United States could not be expected to defend countries that admitted Communists into their governments. It said that such statements violated the Helsinki agreement. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: 5TH AVENUE SLAYING MYSTIFIES POLICE
description: The police said yesterday they were mystified by the murder of 29yearold Richard Coco, who was found fatally shot in the chest at 3 A.M. Saturday at 89th Street and Fifth Avenue, near the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Bridge
description: There have been four World Team Olympiads with an open teams and a women's teams, but the United States has never won a title.

description: Easter, the feast of Christ's Resurrection, the most holy day of the Christian calendar, was celebrated yesterday in churchfi es, at family outings and in. displays of new fashions.

description: Call this the origins of things.

title: Some Violence Marks Easter Rite in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 18 (AP)Youths hurled rocks at a Belfast police station today as the Provisional Irish Republican Army concluded a ceremony to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Easter uprising against Birtish rule.

title: Soviet Icebreaker Helps Open a Gas Field in Siberia
description: The Soviet atomic Icebreaker Lenin, In an unusual Arctic experiment, has succeeded in convoying a freighter through heavy winter ice to open a Siberian natural gas field from the sea side for the first time, the Moscow press has reported.

title: Chatist, 28, is Killed After Midair Collision
description: SENECA FALLS, N. V., April 18 (AP)A parachutist fell to her death here today after colliding in midair with another jumper, the state police reported.

title: MEDIATORS ENTER RUBBER PARLEYS
description: CLEVELAND, April 18 (AP)  Federal mediators have entered contract talks between the United Rubber Workers and the Big Four of the rubber and tire industry as a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. Wednesday approaches.

title: Weather Service Explains Why July Came in April
description: The National Weather Service said yesterday that the met ropolitan area's July weather at Eastertime was a result of a highpressure system that became stationary along much of the Atlantic coast, with southwesterly overland winds drawing the warm air northward from the southeastern states and the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Pennsylvania's Complexity Confounds Political Seers
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18One night last week, an aide to Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign slouched into a local hotel bar, collapsed into a chair and wheezed a long, tired sigh.

title: Derailment Spills A Toxic Chemical In Tennessee Lake
description: JASPER, Tenn., April 18 (AP)  Forty cars on a 90car freight train derailed coming down a mountain grade today, spilling a toxic wood preservative into Nickajack Lake, Civil Defense officials said. No injuries were reported.

title: Here Come Jeepers, Riding Tall in West
description: MOAB, Utah, April 18From out of the back country they come, over the mountains and through the desert, riding high and proud on their heavyduty shock absorbers, bumper to bumper, or, more precisely, winch to trailer hitch. Broncos Scouts Renegades. Blazers. Jimmys.

title: Judy Rankin Wins in Golf By 7 Shots
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 18 (UPI)Judy Rankin, playing with very little pressure from her fellow competitors, shot a threeunderpar 69 today and won the $80,000 KarstenPing golf tournament. It was her third victory in six events this year.

title: Baltimore Leader Looks Favorably on Brown if He Will Make an Effort in Maryland Primary
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Time is running out for Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California to make a serious effort in Maryland's Presidential primary on May 18, just a month away.

title: Blacks and Puerto Ricans a Bronx Majority
description: New York City's white population declined by more than 600,000 between 1970 and 1975, according to an analysis of United States Census figures. During that period the Bronx became the first borough in the city's history with a majority black and Puerto Rican population, the figures showed.

title: La Guardia School Taking Hispanic Radical's Name
description: The name of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia is to be removed from a Harlem public school in favor of the name of Pedro Albizu Campos, the Puerto Rican nationalist leader who turned to violence and terrorism in seekint Puerto Rico's independence.

title: SPANISH UNIONISTS ASK FULL FREEDOM
description: MADRID, April 18The Socialist General Union of Workers today ended its first congress in Spain in 44 years with a demand for political and labor freedom and for a complete break with the present staterun syndicate organizations which join labor and Management.

title: About New York
description: The super at an East Side aparunent building fired the doorman again last week, according to a report reaching this column: He had done it two or three times before, usually when he was depressed or hung over. Each time, the dismissal was rescinded. This time he seemed determined to make it stick.

title: Flood Peril Receding as River Begins Dropping at Minot, N. D.
description: MINOT, N.D., April 18 (AP)The Souris River began dropping today, reducing the danger of a fifth flood in seven years in lowlying sections of the city.

title: MOSCOW CHARGES U.S.INTERFERENCE IN WEST EUROPE
description: MOSCOW, April 18Pravda, the official Communist Party newspaper, charged today that Washington was interfering in the internal affairs of Western European governments by warning them against allowing Communist participation.

title: Foreign Investing in U.S. Surged in First Quarter
description: Foreign investment in manufacturing facilities in the United States was up sharply during the first three months of 1976, according to a survey conducted by the Conference Board and released today.

title: Saudis May Review Stand on Oil Price
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  As the next ministerial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries approaches, Saudi Arabia is standing by its stated opposition to an increase in the price of oil, according to wellplaced Arab and Western sources.

title: Church Celebrations and Outings Mark Easter
description: Easter, the feast of Christ's Resurrection, the most holy day of the Christian calendar, was celebrated yesterday in churches, at family outings and in displays of new fashions.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows.

title: 2 Parolees, Suspects in Double Slaying In 42d St. Theater Holdup, Give Up
description: Two prison paroleesone of them a convicted murdereraccompanied by an Episcopal minister, surrendered yesterday to the police in the Bronx, in the holdupslaying of two armed guards last Monday in a Times Sauare movie theater.

title: CONGRESS IS TOLD DEFENSE FORCES CAN'T BE REDUCED
description: WASHINGTON, April 18A civilian commission created by Congress to study the mounting costs of military manpower has concluded that over the next decade no significant reductions are possible in either the size or the cost of the armed services.

title: Bananas Fail to Lure 50 AWOL Baboons
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, April 18 Fifty baboons are on the loose here.

title: I.R.S. Supplied Tax Returns of Thousands Called for Federal Jury Duty for Scanning forPossible
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Thousands of Americans called for Federal jury duty have been subjected to background checks by the Internal Revenue Service without their knowledge as United States prosecutors have sought to pinpoint those with possible anti government biases.

title: 150,000 Get Look At Olympics Site
description: MONTREAL, April 18 (Reuters)  About 150,000 tourists and Canadians enjoyed their first close look at the muitimultondoitar Olympic complex over the Easter holiday weekend.

title: The Recession Takes Its Toll: Family Discord, Mental Illness
description: A New York City couple in their late 30's have seen the income from their jointly operated beauty salon drop by half in the last two years because of the recession.

title: High of 96 in New York Melts Quite a Few Records
description: Young women discarded their shoes and men took off their jackets and ties, babies cried, outdoor water fountains drew long lines and midsummer lassitude fell over New York City yesterday as the temperature climbed to 96 degreesthe warmest for an April day, any April day, ever recorded in the city.

title: Why Wood Left CBS For Coast
description: As president of the CBS television network, Robert D. Wood earned more than $150,000 3 year, commuted to work in a chauffeured Cadillac Seville provided him by the company. traveled frequently to the West Coast News and Europe, moved Analysis among Hollywood producers and stars as a person of extraordinary importance and had the respect of his peers in the business world.

title: U.S. Six Beats West Germany, 51
description: KATOWICE, Poland, April 18 (AP)Steve Jensen the Minnesota North Stars scored once and had an assist to help the United States defeat West Germany, 51, today at the World hockey championships. The victory gave the Americans a berth in the A final of the tournament.
