description: WASHINGTON. April 23  The Supreme Court turned down tonight the pleas by seven contenders in the Presidential primaries for a resumption of Federal campaign subsidies.

title: The Housing Decision
description: The Supreme Court's unanimous judgment that Federal courts have the power to order Federal officials to promote lowincome housing for minorities In the suburbs accomplished two laudable aims. It interrupted the recent unfortunate tendency of the Court to limit access to the Federal judiciary of constitutional and civil rights claimants and it recognized grim urban realities which the Administration's housing officials have steadfastly ignored.

title: Born Under Pisces, But They're Not Limited to Cooking Fish
description: It was culinary admiration at first sight, the young women explained. Shawn Villa went to a party at Ruth Mai'hot's, later invited her hostess back for a dinner of her own. Each thought the other a good cook. So they did a joint dinner, found that their skills complemented each other nicely and decided to start a catering business.

title: Suffolk Airport Operators Say G.O.P. Aides Got Contributions and Free Rides
description: WESTHAMPTON, L.I., April 23 Authorities are investigating charges made by the concessionaires at Suffolk Airport that Republican officials in the county demanded and received political contributions and free flights on private planes in exchange for their approval of permits and licenses.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Bloomington, Minn.Duane Bohick, 214 pounds, Philadelphia, outpointed Scott LeDoux, Minneapolis, 10 rounds,

title: Oil Stockpiles...
description: The massive political obstacles encountered by programs to curb consumption and revive production of petroleum have increased the need to create the nation's first strategic oil reserve. Buffer stocks of one billion barrels, half by the end of 1982, were approved by Congress in December and President Ford now has rightly overruled his Budget Office in favor of a relatively rapid buildup toward that level.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 23 While Governor Byrne was saying at a luncheon in Newark yesterday that close public scrutiny was good for state government, reports here of audits made of daycare center operations in the state were being withheld from newsmen.

title: Center Says 11,000 Died In Latest Flu Epidemic
description: ATLANTA, April 23 (UPI) The National Center for Disease Control said today that an influenza epidemic that started in February killed an estimated 11,000 Americans.

title: U.S. Orders Banks to Halt Paying Clubs Showing Bias
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  Banks and other financial in istitutions have been ordered to !stop paying memberships for ;their executives in private clubs that discriminate against women and minorities, the Treasury, iDepartment said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Yearning for Palestine
description: WASHINGTONWherever I move or turn in this country I see images of my occupied country, Palestine, and its dispossessed people, the Palestinians. Every breathing moment I feel the exile, suffering and pain of it all. As if mankind's wounds and tragedies are centered in Palestine, in me. And I keep asking: Do Americans really know the suffering of my people? For sixty yearsdeath, torture, exile and the denial of freedom and human dignity. Of all nations we stand faceless, stateless.

title: Ballet: The Royal Swan
description: It was another grand performance by the Royal Ballet on Thursday night, when Rudolf Nureyev and Merle Park led the cast in the first Swan Lake of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Rubber Strike Is Viewed as Roadblock To Resurgence of American Economy
description: The rubber workers strike, which began last Wednesday, is being viewed with some apprehension by economists and industry executives not in the tire business as a roadblock that could slow down the thrust of the nation's economy at a time when it is building up considerable momentum.

title: Daniels Will Leave Congress; LeFante Picked as Successor
description: JERSEY CITY, April 23 Representative Dominick V. Daniels, Democrat of Hudson !County, announced today that he would not seek a 10th term in Congress because my personal and family responsibilities, at this time in my life. nust dictate the course of my future.

title: A Respiratory Stimulator for Babies Is Invented
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Infants, especially those prematurely born, often suffer from cessation of respiration, or inability to get their breath. A biomedical engineer has invented a system that detects this condition and autoWeek matically raises a pillow under the baby, startling the patient into a natural respiration pattern. Patent 3,950,799 was granted this week to Ulrich A. Frank and assigned to HoffmannLa Roche Inc. of Nutley, N. J. Mr. Frank is a senior member of the technical staff of Roche Medical Electronics Inc., a subsidiary in Cranbury, N. J.

title: Animal Welfare Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  President Ford signed today a bill to insure that animals used for research purposes or shipped in interstate commerce are treated humanely.

title: CUBAN BOAT INQUIRY YIELDS NO SUSPECTS.
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 An investigation by three Federal agencies has failed to turn up any suspects in the ramming and sinking of a Cuban fishing vessel, the Ferro Cemento 119, on April 8 off Florida, United States officials said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 23 A Sept. opening for the new Meadowlands Race Track in East Rutherford was confirmed today. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority applied to the State Racing Commission for a 102night harness meeting starting on that date. A commission spokesman said approval was expected.

title: JAVITS IS OPTIMISTIC ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: TEL AVIV, April 23 Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that the process toward a Middle East solution might start before the United States elections in November.

title: State Democrats Reelect Cunningham as Chairman
description: His voice breaking, tears in his eyes, Patrick J. Cunningham accepted reelection yesterday as Democratic chairman of New York State.

title: P.B.A. Seeks a Vote To Bar Further Cut In Police Personnel
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association disclosed plans yesterday to seek a public referendum in November to block further cuts in emergency services.

title: Indians Hurler Regains Rookie Form
description: As far as 2Iyearold Dennis Eckersley is concerned, the Oakland A's are just another ball club. Last year, he was the only Cleveland pitcher to beat the A's in 12 games. Last night in Municipal Stadium, the righthander held the powerful A's to two hits in pitching the Indians to a 30 victory.

title: ALIBI BY SOLIAH IS NOT CONFIRMED
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 23 (UPI) A young masseuse was unable today to verify the alibi of Patricia Hearst's friend, Steven Soliah, that he was in San Francisco at the time of a fatal bank holdup 90 miles away.

title: Brokers Sentenced For a Stock Fraud
description: Edwin Mendlinger and Stanley Snyder, who operated the stock brokerage house of Mendlinger, Snyder Inc. at 50 Broadway were sentenced to four months in prison and fined $5,000 each yesterday for their conviction in a stockfraud scheme.

title: Reactions Differ Over MediaF.B.I. Link
description: The disclosure that the Fed. eral Bureau of Investigation has used, and may still be using, journalists as informers brought reactions from editors yesterday ranging from assertions that reporters should never supply information to intelligence agencies to speculation as to when providing such information might be proper.

title: Japan's Steel Exports to China Reduced by 75% for First Half
description: TOKYO, April 23 Japan's steel shipments to China have been reduced by 75 percent for the first half of this year in negotiations between six major Japanese steel makers and Peking's metal and minerals importexport corporation.

title: Beanie Gets Award
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 23  Mayor Beame received an honorary award tonight from Beta Alpha Psi, the national howaer accounting society, at the Hestra University School of Business.

title: Presidential Press Aides Talk of Truth
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 23 (AP)  Many former White House press secretaries said Friday they were never told to lie to the press, but some said they had relayed information that turned out to be erroneous.

title: Moses, Villanova Spark Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23  There was something old today at old Franklin Fieldthe Penn Relaysand a lot MOM new.

title: EXXON NET UP 22% ON CURRENCY GAIN
Two Get Jail Terms For Sending Rifles To I.R.A.Terrorists
description: A licensed gun dealer and a founder of the Irish Northern Aid Committee in Yonkers received prison sentences in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday for a scheme that sent semiautomatic rifles to the Irish Republican Army.

title: HIGH COURT DENIES VOTE FUND PLEAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The Supreme Court turned down tonight the pleas by seven contenders in the Presidential primaries for a resumption of Federal campaign subsidies.

title: Man Who Won $75,000 Now Wins $100,000
description: In 1973, Paul Kramer, a 50yearold Farmington, Conn., dealer of homeheating oil, won a $75,000 jackpot in Connecticut's weekly lottery. Thursday night, he did it again  only this time the prize was $100,000.

title: Of 13 Portuguese Parties, Only 4 Count
description: LISBON, April 23 When the Portuguese vote Sunday they will be giving their verdict on this country's two years of social revolution.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Japan's Gardens: Serenity Amid The Eternal Rocks
description: TOKYO, April 23 Until his death not long ago an elderly man named Kubotasan could be seen every morning here carefully opening the sliding doors of his Tokyo home and walking across the backyard past the pond and the trees until his wooden cane tapped a mosscovered boulder.

title: Military Abroad to Get Vaccine for Swine Fla
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Pentagon plans to give swine flu vaccine to nearly 800,000 United States military personnel, their wives and children stationed abroad about the same time that other Americans are being immunized at home.

title: 4 SOUTH AFRICANS KILLED NEAR ANGOLA
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 23 (Reuters) Four South African soldiers have been killed in a guerrilla ambush on the border between SouthWest Africa and Angola, a defense spokesman said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, April 23 (UPI)Emergency action by the Bank of England today to shore up the ailing pound failed to halt its downward slide. The bank announced it was raising its minimum lending rate 1.5 percentage points to 10.3 percent.

title: Bridge
description: Whether or not one of your opponents is a good player may be a vital consideration in the play. The right play against an inexperienced performer may he the wrong against an expert, who will know the right. counter.

title: NEW DEFENSE CHIEF IN THAILAND IS DEAD
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 23 Thailand's Defense Minister died of a heart attack today, less than 48 hours after his appointment to the Cabinet.

title: Art: Inca Conquers Spaniard in Peru
description: There are times in our artsurfeited culture when we mistakenly think we have seen everything in the world of art  if not at first hand, then at least in the form of photographic reproduction and then something comes along that is at once totally unfamiliar, and we realize bow much remains to be discovered in this world.

title: Fibik Upsets Vilas To Gain Semifinals
description: STOCKHOLM, April 23 (AP) Wojtech Fibak of Poland scored the first major upset in the $60,000 Stockholm World Champlonship Tennis tournament with a 46,.75, 76 quarterfinnl victory today over topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina.

title: Labor Nominee Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  Michael Moskow, director of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, is expected to be nominated by President Ford as Under Secretary of Labor, Administration sources said today.

title: Hauge Sees Rise in Prime And M.A.C. Redemption
description: Gabriel Hauge, chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, predicted at the annual meeting in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday that the prime rate, which is now at 63 percent, would begin rising.

title: A Correction
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times yesterday that book sale in Montclair was scheduled to open on that day. The sale begins next Friday.

title: Amex and O.T.C. ShowPriceDrops; Turnover Declines
Cunningham Accused of Stonewalling Jur'y's Demand for His Bank Records
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, wit accused yesterday, at an Appellate Division hearing, o stonewalling tactics in tryingi to thwart a special grand jury's demand for his personal bank, records.

title: CAR SALES RISE 70% FOR 10 DAYS
description: DETROIT, April 23 American newcar sales increased 70 percent in the April 1120 period from last year and were near record levels.

title: ELIZABETH M'K. SCOTT
description: Elizabeth McK. Scott, executive secretary of the New York Legislative Service, died Tuesday In Pittsfield, N.H. She was 78 years old and lived in this city.

title: Ballet: The Royal Swan
description: It was another grand performance by the Royal Ballet on Thursday night, when Rudolf Nureyev and Merle Park led the cast in the first Swan Lake of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Joe David Brown Is Dead at 60; BestSelling Author, Journalist
description: Joe David Brown, a bestselling novelist and journalist whose book Addie Pray became the basis for the hit movie Paper Moon and the television series it spawned, died Thursday night of a heart attack at his home, Covey Rise Farm, in Mayfield, Ga. He was 60 years old.

title: RIGHTWARD TREND SEEN IN PORTUGALI
description: LISBON, April 23The campaign for Portugal's first free Parliament elections in half a century ended tonight, with the armed forces placed on full alert in case of violence during the voting Sunday and in the tmmediate postelection period.

title: NO VICTOR DISCERNED IN NEW MEXICO VOTE
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N,M., April 23 (UPI) Neither Jimmy Carter, Representative Morris K. Udall nor Hubert H. Humphrey can claim overall victory, judging from results in the New Mexico Democratic ward and precinct caucuses.

title: People and Business
description: In the first test of its procedure in which a speculator may seek to recover money be may have lost because of action by his broker, the yearold Commodities Futures Trading Commission decided yesterday in Washington to intervene in a New York court action involving a dispute between Hornhlower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes Inc. and a college student who lost $56,000 in the commodity market.

title: Jackson Endorsed
description: PITTSBURGH, April 23  Senator Henry M. Jackson, while campaigning here today, received the endorsement of more than 100 leaders of organized labor who have formed a western Pennsylvania labor committee in behalf of his candidacy. A similar committee was formed this week in Philadelphia.

title: Fund Scandal Is an Issue in Race to Succeed Scott in Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 When Senator Hugh Scottannounced last December that he would not seek reelection, there were few tears shed among his fellow Pennsylvania Republicans.

title: .and a Common Front
description: More important, without a good beginning, the whole program would appear in deubt at a time when the 17 other countries in the Americansoonsored International Energy Agency, disturbed by the lagging American oil conservation effort, are wondering how committed the United States really is to a common energy program.

title: Dow Falls by 7 to 1,000.71 On Fear of Tighter Credit
description: Stock prices declined yester. day as a recurring fearfha tightening of credit conditions by the Federal Reservestalked Wall Street on a balmy spring day.

title: COLIN M'INNES, 61, NOVELIST, IS DEAD
description: LONDON, April 23  Colin MacInnes, one of the first novelists to deal with Britain's community of blacks, died last evening. He was 61 years old.

title: Susan P. Casteras Married at Yale
Ford Acts to Release Reagan Movies for TV
description: LOS ANGELES. April 23 (UPI) President Ford, writing in a letter that Ronald Reagan's old Western movies have no bearing on the political process, has waived his rights to equal time, paving the way for television audiences to once again see the films.

title: Levittown Trustee Describes Plight of His School District
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 23Levittown schools have teachers teaching out of closets and storerooms and . . .teachers sharing desks, a trustee of the Levittown Board of Education testified today in State Supreme Court here.

title: Carter Says His Economic Policy Would Foster Private Jobs, Tax Incentives
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 Jimmy Carter declared today that his top priority for the economy would be the public promotion of jobs in private industry through training, tax incentives and longterm economic planning.

title: NEW YORK STATE LETS GECO RAISE CAR RATES BY 47%
description: A 47 percent increase in the automobile insurance rates of the half million New York State customers of the financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company has, been approved by the state's Department of Insurance.

title: ForeignCar Assembly In U.S. Is Nothing New
description: DETROIT, April 23 The Volkswagen and Volvo plants on American soil will not turn out the first foreign cars to be built in this country. That distinction belongs to Mercedes. William Steinway, the American piano maker, had a license from Gottlieb Daimler to build his engines in North America. This lice se was issued in 1888, eight years before Henry Ford built his first car.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Approve VW Output in U.S.; Choice of Plant Site Is Still Undecided
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, April 23 Volkswagen's supervisory board agreed unanimously today to produce its Rabbit automobiles in the United States starting In late 1977. The decision came only after auto workers were given strong guarantees that the plant would not cost German jobs.

title: Pittsburgh Area Offers Unofficial Carter Referendum
description: PITTSBURGH, April 23 Election posters for two rival Democratic candidates for the state legislature have been left to curl and fade in the window of Cupka's Cafe.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COMEBACK Remember Lover, Come Back to Me? Of course, everybody does, though it's not easy to link the Sigmund Romberg song with the right operettaThe New Moon. There have also been two films, one in 1930, with Grace Moore and Lawrence Tibbett, and the 1940 version, with Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy. And the tuneful old show, a Broadway production from 1928 to 1930, is due back tonight in its first major revival since 1944.

title: A Prospective Juror Is Facing Charge for Rejecting Questions
description: A prospective juror in State Supreme Court in Manhattan refused to answer certain questions on a routine court questionnaire and, as a result, faces a charge of contempt.

title: Public Defender Named
description: TRENTON, April 23 (UN) Daniel J. Carluccio, a Toms River attorney, was named the state public defender for Ocean and Burlington counties by Public Advocate Stanley C. Van Ness, who also serves as the state public defender.

title: State Democrats Reelect Cunningham as Chairman
description: His voice breaking, tears in his eyes, Patrick J., Cunningham accepted reelection yesterday as Democratic chairman of New York State.

title: Paper in Callaway Case Is Losing Ads
description: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo., April 23 (AP) Advertising has fallen off sharply in a weekly newspaper whose articles led to a Senate investigation and the subsequent resignation of President Ford's former campaign manager, Howard H. Callaway.

title: GENERAL SHTEMENKO OF WARSAW PACT, 68
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) Gen. Sergei M. Shtemenko, Chief of Staff of the Warsaw Pact military forces, died yesterday in Moscow of cancer, Soviet sources reported today. He was 68 years old.

title: Market Place
description: P. R. Mallory & Company, the maker of Dura Cell alkaline batteries, is asking shareholders to approve a novel compensation plan for outside directors at its annual meeting next Wednesday.

title: Portugal at the Polls
description: Portugal is approaching what ought to be one of the greatest events of its modern history: the first free parliamentary elections in half a century, marking the formal return to democracy after the long night of the SalazarCaetano dictatorships and the failure of a totalitarian leftist putsch last November.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH IN BOSTON RALLY AGAINST VIOLENCE
description: BOSTON, April 23 Tens of thousands of people marched in the sunshine through the center of Boston today in a Procession Against Violence that sought to ease the city's racial tensions.

title: Adolph Goldberg, 79, Dead; Architect for City Projects
description: Adolph Gold berg, who retiredas an architect in this city in 1967, died Monday evening in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 79 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights,

title: Teacher Layoffs Threaten
description: TRENTON, April 23 (UPI) Trenton education officials said almost onefourth of the city's teachers might have to'be smissed unless the city found additional funds for the public schools. Dr. Jean Emmons, the city's superintendent of schools, said that there were no immediate plans to implement any layoffs, but that if no, extra money is found we will have to lay off people.

title: Opera: Lizzie Borden
description: There is, presumably, operatic logic that makes sense of the way opera companies are run, but since outsiders are not privy to this reasoning, it is difficult, even impossible, at times for them to understand why things happen as they do.

title: New AntiZionist Moves at U.N. Sought
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.,I April 23 Arab diplomats are pressing for a new broad drive in United Nations bodies to renew charges of racism against Israel, thirdworld informants here say.

title: U.S. Statistics on Soviet Question Extent of Threat
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Intelligence estimates prepared at the Defense Department show that nearly half the Soviet Union's military forces are engaged in essentially civilian work or are assigned to military missions not directly threatening to the United States.

title: New Fishing Limit Is Hailed
description: CAPE MAY, April 23 "We are or the right track, said Harry J. McGarrigel Jr., an Atlantic City fish wholesaler, regarding the bill that President Ford recently signed into law extending United States jurisdiction over fishing from 12 miles to 200 miles.

title: Daylight Saving Time To Begin Tomorrow
F.L. FITZPATRICK, 76, TAUGHT EDUCATION
description: Frederick L. Fitzpatrick, professor emeritus of natural sciences at Teachers College of Columbia University, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 460 Riverside Drive.

title: ALEXANDER LAIN, TEACHER, WRITER
description: Alexander Laing, an author who retired in 1968 as a literature professor, at Dartmouth College, died yesterday at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N. H., from injuries received in a bicycling accident. He was 72 years old and lived in nearby Norwich. Vt.

title: Afghan Disaster Reported
description: GENEVA. April 23 (Reuters)  About 100,000 people in Afghanistan have been left homeless by earthquakes and torrential rains followed by floods, the League of Red Cross Societies said here today.

title: LOUISIANA YOUTH IS DENIED 2D TRIAL
description: HAHNVILLE, La., April 23 Gary Tyler, a 17yearold black youth sentenced to die in the electric chair on May 1 for allegedly killing a fellow student in an outbreak of racial fighting at a high school near here, was denied today a motion for a new trial.

title: JOSEPH NOWICKI, 53, EXASSEMBLYMAN
description: Joseph F. X. Nowicki, a member of the Assembly from 1961 to 1964 and counsel to Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson from 1958 to 1962, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Nanuet, N. Y.

title: Dr. Kate Frankenthal, 87, Former Berlin Councilor
description: Dr. Kate Frankenthal, a psychiatrist who was a member of the Berlin City Council and of the Prussian State Parliament in the era of Germany's Weimar Republic, died Wednesday at her home, 41 Central Park West. She was 87 years old.

title: Breathing Aid
description: A patent was granted this week for a device that automatically stimulates respiration in babies who suffer from inability to get their breath. Page 37.

title: ALBANY ALLOWING GEICO AUTO RATES TO RISE 47% MAY 3
description: A 47 percent increase in the automobile insurance rates of the half million New York State customers of the financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company has been approved by the state's Department of Insurance.

title: BARWICK'S DEAL NOT COMPLETED
description: The agreement between E. T. Barwick, chairman of E. T. Barwick Industries Inc. and an unnamed buyer to sell an 83 percent interest in the company has not been consummated, the company anI nounced yesterday. Charles E. Selecman, president and chief, executive officer said that at Mr. Barwick's request, the board had granted Mr. Barwick an indefinite leave of absence.

title: Candidates Express No Differences on Issue of Housing Segregation
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Two events in the last two weeks have brought the question of desegregating housing patterns to the forefront of the Presidential primary campaigns.

title: O'Dwyer Formally Enters Race For Nomination for U.S. Senate
description: Labeling himself as the most likely Democrat to bring unity and enthusiasm to the diverse elements of the party. Paul O'Dwyer yesterday plunged into the crowded race for United States Senator from from New York.

title: Stephenson UP by Shot After a 65
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 23 (UPI)Jan Stephenson of Australia carded a course record, sevenunderpar 65 today and took the openinground lead by a stroke in the: $40,000 Birmingham Classy

title: Abolition Society, 201 Years Old, Holds Annual Meeting Out of Force of Habit
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22  Since this is the fourth Thursday in Apriland for no reason more compellingthe Pennsylvania Abolition Society met today.

title: Ford Denies Plans for Ties With Hanoi
description: ATLANTA, April 23 President Ford, again on the defensive from an attack on his foreign policy by Ronald Reagan, denied today that the United States planned to establish diplomatic relations with North Vietnam.

title: Memo Says F.B.I. Sought Cambodia Article's Source
Kazakhstan Beckons Refugees From China
description: ALMAATA, U.S.S.R.  Three times a week, a small newspaper is published here in flowing Arabic characters. Yeni Khayat  the name means New Life in the Uighur Language  is aimed at helping assimilate some of the Central Asian refugees who have fled China for Soviet Kazakhstan.

title: Special Drug Prosecutor Gets Police Bodyguards
description: The Police Department has begun providing round theclock bodyguards for Sterling Johnson, the New York City special narcotics prosecutor, in response to a report that a group of Harlem drug dealers had offered $100,000 for his death.

title: Details of the Itinerary For Kissinger in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (Reuters)  Following is the itinerary of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, as made available today by the state department.

title: Jimmy Carter's Appeal
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 23Anybody who still doesn't understand the nearly mystical appeal of Jimmy Carter to the American people in 1976 should have been at the West Shore Senior Citizens Center in New Cumberland Township near here today. To a packed house of several hundred Pennsylvanians in the center's recreation hall, Mr. Carter spoke of three recent national traumas as follows:

title: JAzz IMPROVISATION BY HEMPHILL,WADUD
description: Julius Hemphill, an alto saxophonist and composer from St. Louis, first attracted attention in the jazz world with recording he produced himself, Dogon A.D. His ensemble included Abdul Wadud's electric cello and produced a very unusual sound, with the cello serving as both bass and chording instrument.

title: G.O.P. IN ARIZONA ENDORSESRSESREAGAN
description: PHOENIX, April 24Senator Barry Goldwater denounced tactics used by Ronald Reagan's supporters, suggested that Mr. Reagan was misinterpreting President Ford's foreign policy and all but endorsed the President today at the Arizona Republicans state convention here.

title: PARIS HAS DESIGN TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: PARIS, April 24 The French Government has just introduced its seventh fiveyear plan, which seeks to set the broad lines of French economic and social development between now and 1980.

title: TV VIEW
description: What are the effects of violence shown on television? The question is as old as the medium itself. Definitive answers have yet to be devised. Given the demonstrated power of televisnn to sell products, it must be presumed that the medium can also sell and attitudes. And several isolated instances are on record that show how a specific televised act of violence was imitated in reality within a couple days of the program. Law enforcement agencies and many judges and lawyers are convinced that there is a direct alues correlation between TV (and movies) and rising crime rates. Yet, the debates, pro and con, continue. The search for accurate measurements proves almost suspiciously elusive.

title: For young readers; A Child's Book Of Seasons; By Satomi Ichikawa. Unpaged. New York: Parents Magazine Press. $5.50. (Ages 3 to 6)
description: The first verse on the first page of this book about the seasons acts as the introduction: Please take a look inside this book to see what children do/ In snow and sunshine, wind and rain, the changing seasons through. Succeeding couplets are written with equal simplicity. Each describes children at play as the year goes by. The verses do not star. They serve more as subtitles for the real poetry which is in the illustrations. Drawn in muted colors these are filled with graceful groups of children who pick berries, wade, sculpt snow, climb trees. Green is the grass and green the deep sea,/ But nothing's so green as the world of a tree. The portrait of the lush, leafy tree decorated with climbers shimmers on the page. True to its verse it is a little world.

title: Like taking the Napoleon chapters out of War and Peace
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn is by no means the first Russian writer to realize that the rhetoric of socialism and revolutionary change can be easily usurped by authoritarian fanatics. Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy and Chekhovall of whom had at various times expressed sympathy for certain aspects of the Russian revolutionary movementall depicted memorable characters whose idea of liberation was the imposition of their own ideology on everybody by force. Tolstoy's third big novel, Resurrection, in particular, contains the charismatic figure of the famous revolutionary Novodvorov, for whom the chief aim of the coming revolution is to replace the existing government with the absolute rule of his own faction.

title: P.S.C. to Require Electric Meter for Each Tenant
description: As an energy conservation measure, the New York State Public Service Commission intends to require that all new residential, commercial and industrial buildings provide an electric meter for each tenant.

title: With real and bogus footnotes
description: Having borrowed motifs from H. G. Wells for The Andromeda Strain and from Mary Shelley for The Terminal Man, Michael Crichton has now attempted to do the same with medieval sources. Taking as his point or departure an Obscure 10thcentury Arab travelogue by 1bn Fadlan, Crichton's new sword and sorcery novel chronicles Ibn's kidnapping by the Vikings and his role in helping them combat a primitive race of cannibals who are devouring the inhabitants of King Rothgar's meade hall. The tale is strongly reminiscent of Beowulf": Crichton even names his doomed hero Buliwyf.

title: U.S. OIL COMPANIES ARE NEGOTIATING WITH VIETNAMESE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Despite a continuing chill in political relations between Hanoi and Washington, several American oil companies have been quietly invited by Vietnam to submit proposals for resuming the offshore oil exploration that was suspended when South Vietnam fell to Communist forces a year ago.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOLIGH few, if any, Island lawns are as yet r:!ady for their first cutting, it won't be long until most homeowners will once again he dragging their power mowers out of the garage or basement to crank them up for another season's work of trimming the grass. Unfortunately, some will find that their mower engine just won't start as it should after its winter hibernation. Others will get their machine; started but then will find that other repairs are needed usually, just as the season is at its peak and just when local mower repair shops or service centers are jammed with machines that need sharpening or other service.

title: On Putting the Money Where the Talent Is
Bringing the Handicapped Into the Mainstream
description: At about 8:45 each maiming, 15yearold Jim maneuvers his wheel chair out of a specially designed bus and into the special homeroom at the Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx, where he will spend the first period of the school day with other orthopedically handicapped young people.

title: BRIDGE
description: In one important area. little ,understood by rankandfile bridge players, the experts are divided into three parts: The. question of whether or not to sacrifice against an opposing slam. A thousand pojnts or more can ride on The decision, so the subject repays study. trick or morehe passes. With no tricks he also doubles and refers the decision back.

title: One Issue, Four Sides
description: NOBODY'S against peace and prosperity  or the environment, either. At least not until the issues become clearly defined.

title: Braves Dismiss Davidson
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (UPI)  Donald Davidson. vice president and traveling secretary of the Atlanta Braves and a member of the Braves frontoffice staff for 28 years, was dismissed today by R. E. (Ted) Turner, the new owner of the team.

title: BRIDGING THE GAP
description: Leo Beebe looks like he knows his business. Until three years ago, when he retired at age 55, his work spanned some 25 jobs over 27 years at the Ford Motor Company. His life since hasn't slowed down so you'd notice. He works as a management consultant and is starting a repair business in Villanova, Pa. He is also a professor of marketing at Glassboro State College in New Jersey, a job that marks a return to the teaching career he abandoned years ago when he joined the Navy and was assigned to Ensign Henry Ford II.

title: $2.5 Billion Smuggling Reported by Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 24 (AP)  Smuggling of goods ranging from birdseed to expensive furs amounted to $2.5 billion last year, almost equal to Argentina's export goal for the same period, the government has reported.

title: PEOPLE
description: Hard on the heels of its announcement that one of its new shows next season will be called Executive Suite, CBSTV made some ultraimportant changes in its own executive suites, and two New Jersey men are the chief beneficiaries. Robert Wussler, a 39yearold native of Newark and a 1957 graduate of Seton Hall University, was named president of the CBS Television Network. Within days, he created the new post of executive vice president of the network and filled it with the appointment of Robert A. Daly, a veteran of 20 years with CBS. Mr. Daly lives with his wife and three children Woodcliff Lake.

title: Marilyn Horne Sings From Operas of 10 Composers
description: Marilyn Horne demonstrated her vocal prowess and endurance a t Carnegie Hall on Friday night with a recital of recitatives, arias, cavatinas, cabalettas and what not drawn from operas of 10 composers from Handel to Massenet by way of Rossini, Meyerbeer, Donizetti, Verdi and SaintSa&m, among others.

title: City Island Sailor Building Boat for Another Single Handed Crossing
description: Jean Lacombe, who has sailed alone across the Atlantic five times in small sloops, has created what he says is the first small sailboat designed from the keel up for crossing oceans and exploring barren shores.

title: Downtown Englewood Plans a New Look
description: THE city of Englewood, bisected by railroad tracks, has historically presented an example of the other side of the tracks development, accord ing to a master plan, but it Is moving to change that now. Plans are in the works to redevelop the city's downtown area, and the emphasis is on the other side.

title: NEW ROLES WORRY WOMEN OFFICERS
description: For 12 years, the concerns of Rita Kaplowitz as a police officer were shoplifters, confidence artists and furtivelooking men in darkened movie theaters. Sometimes she also searched female prisoners or did a little typing and filing.

title: Sri Lanka to Bar Tourists During Nonaligned Parley
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 24 (UPI)  The Sri Lanka Government has announced that no foreign tourists will be permitted to enter the country in August when a conference of nonaligned nations is scheduled.

title: Of Things To Come
description: The title of Michael Moorcock's LEGENDS FROM THE END OF TIME (Harper & Row. $7.95) perfectly describes its contents. Unimaginable centuries from now, a handful of people have inherited the earth. Through the dispensation of a science only hinted atpower rings that can drain the energies of a star at the touch of a fingereach individual has access to virtually unlimited power. Everyone is assured of living as long as the universe itselfa guarantee not to be confused with eternal life, considering how fast the stars are being used up. But no one seems worried about this ultimate energy crisis; the real problem of the immortals is boredom. To fill their endless days, they play at science, at art, at life and death. For instance: Werther de Goethe collects odd emotions like fear and love": the Duke of Queens and Lord Shark the Unknown fight a duel: My Lady Charlotina gives a Masquerade Ball in an enormous transparent ball. And so on. Periodically, things are enlivened by the arrival of timetravelers from previous millenniabrave explorers unfortunately unaware that, because of a quirk in the spacetime continuum, no return from the final epoch is possible.

title: Miss Woods Wins Plea On Her Personal Items
description: WASHINGTON. April 24 (AP)  A Federal District judge has ordered the immediate return to Rose Mary Woods of personal items impounded in a court fight over former President Richard M. Nixon's papers and tapes.

title: NATO Satellite Is Placed In Orbit Over Pacific Ocean
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.. April 24 (Reuters)A North Atlantic Treaty Organization communications satellite was put into stationary orbit above the Pacific today after its ,launching from here Thursday.

title: DAVID SCHULKIND, PRINT LEADER, 81
description: David W. Schulkind, who was credited with introducing many advances in the binding and finishing of books and other publications in more than half a century in the printing industry, died Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: Lizabeth Perry Wed to K. I. Light
description: Lizabeth Van WleMe Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Stoddard Perry of New Canaan, Conn., was married last evening at Waveny, the former Lapham estate there, to Kenneth Ian Light, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Light of Syosset, L. I. Probate Court Judge Penfield C. Mead performed the ceremony.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Why not just call this Marybeth Hurt Week and let it go at that? Miss Hurt is the ingenue of the present Phoenix Theater company, and if anyone rises from the ashes of William Gillette's Secret Service and Bella and Sam Spewack's Boy Meets Girl, it is she.

title: Daylilies Are Dandy For Summer
description: The popularity of daylilies has increased rapidly In the last few years. Breeding efforts have been so successful that the average lifespan of dayllly flowers has jumped from about 12 hours to 16 or 18 hours,

title: Eileen Cole Bride Of John A. Schunke
description: Eileen Marie Cole, daughter of Mrs. John Joseph Magovern of Garden City, LI., and the late Richard Joseph Cole, was married yesterday to John Arthur Schunke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Schunke of Flushing, Queens.

title: A New Day for the Gifted
description: The country's rising tide of concern with providing special education for the handicapped has begun to spill over onto another neglected group, the gifted.

title: Skyscraper Fire Law: Even City Is Balking
description: The city's new fire safety regulations for highrise office buildings are meeting such resistance from building ownersincluding, paradoxically, the city itselfthat full compliance in the foreseeable future appears virtually Impossible.

title: Rosa Hayward Married To Christopher Jones
description: Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Rosa Laird Hayward, daughter of Mrs. Ellice McDonald Jr. of Montchanin, Del., and the late Nathan Hayward Jr., to Christopher George Lewis Jones. He is a son of Mrs. G. Lewis Jones of Washington and the late Mr. Jones, a career Foreign Service officer, who served as first United States Ambassador to Tunisia and as an Assistant Secretary of State under Presidents Eisenand Kennedy.

title: Lebanese Refugees Crowd a Cypriot Port
description: LARNACA, Cyprus In hotel lobbies and seaside restaurants of this town, the main languages one hears these days are French and Arabic. The conversations are sprinkled with unusual namesPhalange, Franjieh, Saiya.

title: ART
description: AS a name, the Mini Gallery in the Newark Museum might be misleading or, at best, ambiguous. It is not a display area in which only miniature items can be seen, although objects of small dimension have beer, put on view there.

title: Athens Appeals Court Alters Sentences of ExOfficers
description: ATHENS, April 24 (AP)  A military appeals court has sen. tenced 18 former army officers, to jail terms of 10 months to 22 years for torturing political prisoners during the military dictatorship.

title: Spain Acts to Clear Way for a Referendum in June
description: MADRID, April 24 in an important step toward holding a popular referendum on political changes as early as June, new rules have been imposed on Parliament to prevent a filibuster by conservatives who form a majority of the chamber.

title: From Korea
description: The Japan of the lagt 123 years is recreated each night in Pacific Overtures, a Broadway musical that depicts the arrival of foreigners on the shores of the floating world in 1853 and the country's subsequent acculturation.

title: The Moods Of the Sound Are Many
CULTIVATING THE CASUAL
description: The New York City Transit Authority pays for Joseph Walters's working wardrobe the dull blue leisure suit he wears as he drives a bus through the streets of Brooklyn five days a week. His own wardrobe is for his own time, and it tends to reflect his consuming passion: the studied cultivation of grass, flowers, vegetables and little trees on the postage stamp'; of land that flank his twostory frame house in Ozone Park. interested in buying his own clothes since he was a teenager, and if he sticks to jeans It befnin When I Melted up a booklet from the agricullure department about lawns, he says, as he relaxes on his livingroom couch in a pair of green knit slacks and a forest green shirt printed with huge pink roses. It took him about two years to learn to grow grass properly, and in the process he ay.(wired a deep interest in soils and plants. Now he is into tomatoes, which he tries to grow organically, though for particularly gross worms he regresses to a chemical pesticide.

title: Girls Turn Wives
description: 351 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $8.95.

title: How Nichols and Rabe Shaped Streamers
description: Streamers, the new David Rohe play which opened at tile Newlicuse Theater last week, has been accused of trying to outgore the Grand Guignol. The experience not a new one for Rabe, whose 1972 play, Sticks and Bones, ended with the bloody onstage suicide of a blinded Vietnam veteran. But Streamers is something of departure for its director,. Mike Nichols, whose reputation was built on mirth, not Botb Rabe ard Nichols discussed the play and Its meaning in a series of recent interviews.

title: China Is Permitting Small Group to Live Outside the System
description: CHING HUNG, China, April 21 (Agence FrancePresse) In China's Yunnan Province, near the Laotian border, dwell the only known people who, with the approval of the authorities, live outside the country's Communist system.

title: LETTERS
description: The Maysles Defend Their Film

title: Scoundrel Time
description: At the opening of Scoundrel Time. Lillian Hellman's memoir of the McCarthy era, she says that there is no mystery why this, the most painful episode in her life, was never told in two previous autobiographical works, An unfinished Woman and Pentimento. The story will be familiar to many of her readers: in May 1952 she took a dangerous and honorable stand when the House UnAmerican Activities Committee called into question her loyalty to the United States. Hellman's introductory pages are deceptively plain. Her rhetorical directness is much like Thoreau's at the beginning of Walden": she will simply tell her audience what they have wanted to know. But the narrative itself, intricately and elegantly conceived, is in the tradition of a fine moral essay like Emerson's The American Scholar. which begged for trouble. This story, of artistic necessity, had to be singled out from the polished memoirs that preceded it: is a beautiful work of selfdefinition.

title: A Study of Comets Indicates That Sixty Had Common Origin
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  The orbits of 60 comets indicate they originated from the explosion of a giant planet that once existed between Mars and Jupiter, according to Dr. Thomas C. Van Flandern of the *United States Naval Observatory here.

title: TV VIEW
description: Did you know that the Emmy Awards will be announced on May 17? Can you wait? The National Academy of Television Art. and Sciences emerged from its respirator long enough last week to nominate 342 people, places and things for one serendipity or another, according to a scheme of categories and subcategories that looks like the floorplan of General Amin's brain. Highlevel diplomatic negotiations are now in progress between the Academy and ABC. ABC will televise the awards ceremony but wants the number of winners cut down from 68 to 47, on the theory that the fewer winners there are around cluttering up the stage, the more room there will be for entertainment. Sixtyeight winners, ABC figures, would mean seven minutes of entertainment.

title: Testing to Discover Needs:
description: The objective seems laudable enough to identify as early as possible in a child's life potential impediments to learning that might block educational progress. But the screening process by which this goal is to be achieved remains vague, uncertain and controversial.

title: A Lifelong Passion For Sleeping Giants
description: I became hooked on volcanoes at the age of 6. It happened one Sunday in Memorial Hall, a BeauxArts edifice left over from Philadelphia's Centennial Exhibition of 1876. There in the basement, in a moldering diorama, I met my first volcano.

title: Problems of decorum
description: In J. D. O'Hara's picture book, A History of Poetry, there appears familiar photograph of the aging John Berryman, with gurulike beard, flowing, grizzled, unkempt. On the same page are pictures of Robert Lowell, Sylvia Plafh and Anne Sexton; and to all of these the caption reads: Lowell ... was the first American poet to write in the intimate, introspective verse style that has since been dubbed confessional poetry. This new approach to poetry was to prove the undoing of at least one of Lowell's contemporaries and two of his disciples. And in case we have any doubt about who the contemporary is, and who the disciples, the caption makes it plain: John Berryman along with Sylvia Plath . . . and Anne Sexton . . . all harboring unresolved personal torments, wrote poems filled with angst and death wishes that were ultimately fulfilled by suicide. Perhaps unintentionally, this conveys the clear impression that Berryman was a confused character who lost his head as did, more excusably, a couple of much younger poetsbecause of the example of a stronger poet, Lowell, and the critical brouhaha that Lowell's developing career provoked. It should he said at once that this pitiably veering weathercock is not at all the figure that emerges from the volume of Berryman's erstwhile uncollected esand stories.

title: The Power and Delicacy Of Chinese Landscapes
description: New York offers at the moment a couple of exhibitions of Chinese landscape painting. Listening to the Bamboo: The Art of Wen Chengming at Asia House and Summer Mountains: The Eternal Landscape at the Metropolitan Museum. These shows are, respectively, a delight and a disappointment. The disappointment, however, has a consolation in the form of an absolutely beautiful book attached to it.

title: Beating Funeral Costs
description: THERE are at least 10,000 people in New Jersey  and their number is growing rapidly  who know to the penny what their funerals will cost, and what the service, if any, will be like. Or, if they survive beyond the oleyeFt term of existing 'memorandums of understanding with cooperating funeral directors, they will have a say in new cost schedules, confident they are beating the high cost of dying by a substantial margin.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW; Can New York Save the Schomburg Center?; ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE
description: No one is asking whether New York is anything more than a debt structure or a credit rating these days, and what, precisely, is being saved from a fate worse than default. One has the feeling that the money men at City Hall are dealing in fiscal card tricksnot in a place. The cuts being made hurt most heartbreakingly and immediately in human services. But where they are going to hurt the worst, in the long run, is in their damage to the essential nature and quality of the citythose areas of art and commerce, culture and communication, that give New York its traditional style and strength and that provide its competitive edge for business, talent, leadership and money. This truth occasionally glimmers through the dismal trick figures: it is the city's real bottom line.

title: Anne F. Thomas Is Betrothed To John Donaghy, a Teacher
description: Lieut. Gov. and Mrs. Lowell Thomas Jr. of Juneau, Alaska, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Frazier Thomas, to John Donaghy, son of Dr. and Mrs. R. M. Peardon Donaghy of Burlington, Vt.

title: Springtime for Portugal
description: PARISThe Sunday balloting in Portugal is historically unique. It represents the first time a country that was, if briefly, on the very brink of Communist dictatorship has been able to break away, establish a workable provisional government, and vote. These are the first free legislative elections the Portuguese have held in fifty years.

title: FollowUp on  The News
description: April 1973: Inflation at the supermarket was cresting, and bee prices were rising higher, higher, higher. Shoppers began to shun the meat counters. And in Westbrook, Conn., Kent Carlson opened the first federally inspected horsemeat market on the East Coast.

title: Party to Aid Memorial
description: Proceeds from a theater party to Thursday's performance of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue at the Mark Hel Jnger Theater will go to the LAI Memorial Grove on the Potomac, honoring the 86th President. Tickets at $40, $60, $100 and $125 are available from Mrs. Gillette fioland, 40 East 68th Street.

description: NORTHPORT

title: Entry Rolls Are Shorter at Two Events
HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH it will be several weeks before most New Jersey lawns need their first cutting of, the season, some diligent residents in South Jersey who applied fertilizer last month are already starting their weekly grassmaintenance chores. And, as could be expected, one homeowner is, already having problems with his power mower.

title: Unrelated Donor's Marrow Saves a Boy
description: Matthew Ruffer, not yet 3 years old, Is the only person now alive who has apparently successfully received a honemarrow transplant from a donor unrelated to him.

title: Life With a Retarded Child: The Will to Prevail
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C.Our 9yearold son, Jay, is severely retarded. That simple fact has significant consequences for all of us. There is nothing the parents of a handicapped child can take for grantedincluding whether the schools will be providing programs for your child from year to year.

title: Mary Mulhearn, Designer, Bride
description: Mary Estelle Mulhearn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Mulhearn of Bronxville, N.Y., was married in

title: Never kill a monkey in a carnival
description: Robertson Davies has written a long, complex trilogy that revolves around a single, childish incident. Packing a stone into a snowball, Percy Boyd Staunton throws it at his friend Dunstan Ramtay. Instead it strikes the Baptist minister's pregnant wife, who goes into premature labor and, after a difficult delivery, is left mad. The repercussions of the event upon Ramsay, a man of reason, and Staunton, a man of instinct, were dealt with in Fifth Business and The Manticore. World of Wonders concerns Magnus Eisengrim, issue of the minister's wife and now a renowned magician, whose life began 80 days early and under a dark shadow because of the errant snowball. The key to this novel, to the entire trilogy, is an almost Newtonian concept of morality no action is without conse

title: A Parent's Guide to Specialty Camps
description: Like millions of other girls who watched Olga Korbut hurl herself to fame, my daughter Jane began dreaming of Olympic glory. As soon as she started cartwheeling across the living room and racing off to gymnastics classes, I knew how I would lure her into a camp.

title: For the Gifted, There Are Other Frustrations
description: Most people assume that gifted childrenbecause they are so obviously intelligentcan more or less take care of themselves in school. My own experiences as a child identified as gifted In the 1950's suggests that the very onnosite is often true.

title: The Agonizing Voyage Of a Master Novelist
description: sense of unspeakable security is in me at this moment, on account of your having understood the book, Melville wrote back. I have written a wicked book, and feel spotless as a lamb.

title: The Seven Basic Herbs
description: Thyme, sage and winter savory, lemon balm and apple mint, basil and dill, these are the seven magic herbs I can't do without.

title: Endpaper
description: Harvey G. Cox, Harvard University Divinity School: There is. quite possibly, no such thing as an utterly new and/or original idea (there's A new idea). Our most original ones were thought of and forgotten long ago. The most original idea I've heard for a long time is a very old one, now staging a renaissance: that human intelligence may not be unique in the cosmos, that other levels and layers of molecular and celestial reality may have their own modes of intelligenceand that our ancestors had some clues (now nearly forgotten) of how to be in touch with these

title: LOYAL TO TRADITION
description: Michael Korda wears blue jeans most of the time, but he doesn't think he ought to. It's a compound of laziness, selfindulgence, the fact that I can get away with it, he says. I think men look best in very simple dark plain clothes. The more men try to be sporty, trendy, stylish, the worse they look:

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT flower has been cultivated for more than 3,000 years and is still the world's most popular flower? The rose, of course. Our modern roses are the product of centuries of breeding and selection that have provided a wide variety of types, sizes and colors to meet our gardening needs. As a bonus, many are fragrant as well.

title: COLUMBIA TO DROP CAMPUS PROJECT
description: In a move that has stirred angry protests from local residents and political leaders, Columbia University has announced that it cannot afford to provide $350,000 next year to finance a popular educational program.

title: Alger Hiss
description: In 1950, at the conclusion of what was prpbably the most important trial of our time, a Federal jury declared Alger Hiss guilty of perjurythough, in effect, this was really a conviction for espionageand sent him to prison for three years and eight months.

title: Rust Removers: Some Dissolve It, Others Convert It to a New Coating
description: Whenever ferrous metals (those containing iron and most steels) are exposed to air and moisture, rust is a constant threat and often a recurring problem. For years the classic way to remove rust was to mechanically polish or scrape it off, using wire brushes, steel wool, abrasive papers, or anything else that would do the job.

title: Reagan Wins Bulk of South Carolina's Delegates
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  South Carolina Republicans, meeting in their biennial state convention today, awarded most of their 36member delegation to the Republican National Convention to Ronald Reagan.

title: Her predecessor didn't say hello, her successor didn't say goodbye
description: When Frances Perkins appeared in Washington in March 1933 to assume her new post as Secretary of Labor, the incumbent, one of Herbert Hoover's less distinguished appointees, could not believe that thisthis womanwas taking over his job. He ignored the arrival of the first woman Cabinet member in our history, failed to invite her to the office he was still occupying, and when she came anyway, after being sworn in at the White House, his secretary kept her waiting, saying I'll see if he is free.

title: Honeyvwell Bull: Episodes in Swiss Finance
description: ZURICHA picture of corporate fraud, sloppy international financing practiceand just possibly the bribing of public officials is coming into focus in this Swiss City. bank that was reportedly the funnel for the missing money.

title: Betty O'Donnell to Be Married To Jeffrey Landercasper June 12
description: Mr. and Mrs. John s. (Bud) Palmer of Vail, Colo., formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Palmer's daughter, Betty Niall O'Donnell to Jeffrey Landercasper. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Louis Landercasper of Cozad, Neb., where his father is a grain farmer.

title: Here's How to Avoid Owning a Boat
description: Heredity and environment can exert powerful pressures on a, man trying to avoid going. into commission, but onceagain I have conquered both and will launch the boating season without boat.

title: Mark Tobey, Abstract Artist, 85, Dies
description: Mark Tobey, the American abstract painter, died yesterday irt Basel, Switzerland, where he had been living since 1960. He was 85 years old.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Wants to Draw Her Neighbors Closer
description: NEW DELHIAs India's leaders peer across this country's tense and wellguarded borders, their greatest fear in recent years has seemed to be that China and Pakistan, two powerful and hostile neighbors, would unite militarily, in a joint attack.

title: The Dance: Midi Garth
description: Midi Garth, an experimental choreographer who has pursued her own ideas for many years, presented two premieres and other works with her company Friday night at the theater of the Riverside Church. The program will be repeated this afternoon.

title: INVESTING
description: Xerox, a favorite on Wall Street and a dominant force in the photocopier market for two decades, is threatened by a tough new competitor with longstanding expertise in the graphics field.

title: Barbara Wechsler Plans June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Francis Wechsler of Hartford have announced the engagement cif their daughter, Barbara Cartier Wechsler, to Robert Terhune Stewart, son of William Thomas Stewart Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mrs. Stewart.

title: New Moscow Trade Center Getting a Lift From America
description: Dtente may be in doubt, but things are looking upand downin Moscow for at least one American institutionthe Otis Elevator Company. Otis has just landed a $3.5 million contract to install elevators and escalators in the new Moscow World Trade Center, now under construction.

title: From the Faculty File
description: Florence Miller, a New York City guidance counselor and writer, claims in no great seriousness to have found carbons of these letters in a desk purchased in a thrift shop in Blenheim, Ohio.

title: Tennessee Equals World Relay Mark
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24  Inspired by a second straight day of sunny, mid70's weather, a hyperfast new polyurethane 400meter track and a crowd of more than 30,000, athletes at the S2d Penn Relays produced one dazzling performance after another today at Franklin Field.

title: The Dipper
description: Regardless of the weather, the stars point the season. Go out now and look up and to the north in midevening. The moonless sky is filled with stars that still glitter with winter's brilliance, but the Rig Dipper hangs high overhead, higher than at any other time of the year, well above Polaris and with its bowl inverted, no longer a Winter Dipper.

title: U.S. Residential Patterns: Still Separate and Unequal
description: During the 1960's, many of the nation's cities underwent a dramatic transformation that created a pattern of residential apartheid: predominantly black inner cities and predominantly white suburbs. It was This stark demographic pattern, more than any other fact, that forced the President's Commission on Civil Disorders, eight years ago, to the pessimistic prophecy that our nation is moving toward two socities, one black, one whiteseparate and unequal.

title: Up From the Basement: A Teacher's Story
description: In the 1960's I accepted my first teaching position, a special education class in a basement room next door to the furnace. Of the 15 educable mentally retarded children assigned to work with me, most were simply nonreaders from poor families. One child had been banished to my room because she posed a behavior problem to her fourthgrade teacher.

title: Accounting the Way to Real Profits
description: The results of last year's corporate operations are in and for many companies it was a banner year, with earnings back at their peak levels. However, there is no certainty that these record earnings reflect reality. Our present accounting system cannot cope with the unprecedented inflation of the past several years and profits in many cases have been significantly overstated because of that failing.

title: The Engine: It's Time to Go
description: Owners of small boats may do their own prelaunching check of hull and outboard motor if they so choose.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE

title: In Many Ways, It's Just a Matter of Time
description: One of the most promising scientific responses to the energy crisis has been an increased interest in ways of harnessing directly the sunlight captured by living plantsenergy equal, according to one estimate, to twenty times the current p:sent level of fuel consumption worldwide. The fossil fulscoal, oil and natural gasare the remains of longdead plants, and the combustible elements in them were extracted nom air and water by solarpowered photosynthesis some 350 million years ago.

title: OVERSEAS INDIANS OPEN LONDON TALK
description: LONDON, April 24Indians abroad opposed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's emergency measures announced plans today to start a campaign to restore democracy to India.

description: From 18th century fieldstone houses In Connecticut hamlets to Victorian homesteads along the New Jersey shore, dozens of private homes will be open this spring and summer for the curious to visit and for charity and preservation groups to profit by.
