title: Should the last three sisters stay single?; Peculiar Institutions; An Informal History of the  Seven Sister Colleges. By Elaine Kendall. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $8.95.
description: The history of women's colleges is short, and, according to Elaine Kendall it is almost over. It began in 1837 when the first, Mount Holyoke, was founded. Thereafter Vassar, Smith, Wellesley, Radcliffe, Barnard and Bryn Mawr were horn. Now all but three are strongly tied to male schools or are coeducational, and the remaining three, the writer sug

title: The Man Who Films Bergman's Nightmares
description: Great movie cameramen must work in a peculiarly schizophrenic manner. Formidably creative in their own right, they can fulfill themselves only by serving the vision of a strong director, without whose ideas and leadership they remain expert technicians turning out meaningless pretty pictures. They must be decisive and intuitively right about questions of composition, light, color, and a hundred other things, yet flexible enough to put ,up with the vagaries of whatever man or woman they are working for. How many firstrate artists have the temperament to function this way?

title: You Can Doze Through the Speech and Then Take It Home
description: Conventiongoers who are bored with the speeches they must endure can now take the speeches home and be bored again.

title: Town School to Gain
description: The Town School, 5,10 East 76th Street, will benefit from the final preview of man Pennsylvania Avenue at the Mark HellInger Theater on May 3. Tickets are $40 and $75.

title: Pooling Local Resources
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y. Several years ago a child with handicap in the Yorktown school district would probably be attending special class in a church basement or some other rented quarters, part of a completely separate educational system, says Dr. Donald Coe, assistant director of special education for northem Westchester nnd Putnam counties.

title: M. W. Brennan to Wed Mary Ellen Carideo
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo R. Carideo of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Carideo, to Martin W. Brennan, son of State Supreme Court Justice William C. Brennan and Mrs. Brennan of Elmhurst. Queens.

title: Fashion
description: Jan Bush is a passionate shopper. She spends days poring over the racks of Fifth Avenue stores and Madison Avenue boutiques, then travels downtown to inspect Village and SoHo wares. She makes regular trips to Seventh Avenue, and last year she went abroad six timesto Europe, South America and the Far Eastin pursuit of clothes. And when she sees something that she really likes, she orders itseveral thousand times over.

title: $2 MILLION OFFER BY G E. REPORTED IN POLLUTION CASE
description: ALBANY, April 24 The General Electric Company has reportedly offered to pay the state at least $2 million to settle the controversial PCB's case, provided the payment is not cited as a penalty and the company is not required to make restoration, reclamation or other like remedy because of its discharge of the toxic chemical into the Hudson River.

title: MEMO SAYS F.B.I. GOT MISSING FILES
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The contents of a briefcase allegedly stolen from the 196S Presidential candidate of the Socialist Workers Party mysteriously turned up a moath later in the hands of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to F.B.I. documents provided by the bureau to the candidate, Fred W. Halstead.

title: I Want to Be a Doctor, Mom
description: Parents who think they lived through the ultimate trauma when their children filled out college applications don't know what trauma is until one child applies to medical school. Now that's a real conscicusnessraising for any college student, mother or father to contend with. Not to mention the frantic 2 A.M. call, Morn, the application wants to know you or Dad ever had heart palpitations. (Not till now, son.) Medical school applications run anywhere from four to six or even eight pages. The only pleasant thing about them is they sometimes come in varied colors Kansas pink is pretty cute. But those pages are also chockfull of odd questions, the meaning of which must be on an ultrahigh intellectual plane since they strike a note of sheer obscurity in the hearts of most students and their families.

title: BROOKE NOT HOPING FOR SPOT ON TICKET
description: PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) Sentor Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts said today that he did not think it likely he would be the Republican VicePresidential nominee, and he asked a group of black leaders not to waste their time campaigning for him.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Justice is being done at Knoedler to one of the most complex American painters of this century: Mark Tobey. Fifteen years ago Tobey was thought of in Europe as the most famous American painter since Whistler. He had won a major prize at the Venice Biennale In 1958, he had had a particularly successful show at the Musee des Arts D6coratifs in Paris andimpbrtantly he lived in Europe. The New York School had been seen in Europe, but it had not yet taken hold. The seraphic intimations of Mark Tobey were all the rage.

title: Harianne S. Wiener Has Nuptials
description: Harianne S. Wiener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wiener of New York, and David Squires Wallenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Wallenstein of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., were married yesterday evening in the White and Gold Suite of the Plaza by Rabbi David M. Posner.

title: Snap, Crackle and Divestiture
description: WASHINGTONcheerios, Crispy Critters, Corn Flakes and Cap'n Crunch with Crunchberries are not the stuff of Which new antitrust law has generally been made. But the staff of the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday formally will begin its longawaited attempt to do exactly that.

title: Youth,17, Awarded A TV for His Poster By Humane Society
description: Herman Rodriguez, 17 years old, was awarded first prize ir the second annual poster campaign for Be Kind to Animals Week for his depiction of cats lounging amidst overflowing garbage cans In a graffiticovered alley.

title: Sigmund Cowan in City Opera Debut
description: Sigmund Cowan, who made his New York City Opera debut as Figaro in Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia Friday night, could very clearly be a valuable addition to the company. One puts it that way because City Opera newcomers have a way of popping up and then popping out of sight again.

title: TOP ITALIAN PARTY SETS CRUCIAL TEST
Allen Young Weds Linda H. Rousselot
description: Linda Hobbs Rousselot of Winchester, Mass., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ranald Purcell Hobbs of South Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Allen Young, son of David Yale Young of New York and the late Mrs. Young.

title: Paul Gibian Weds Patty Schneider
description: Martha Hoopes Parke Schneider, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Parke of Dowingtown, Pa, and the late Dr. Parke, was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Gibian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gibian of Forest Hills, Oueens.

title: In TradeUp, Prize Is a $100,000 House
description: A family looking for a suburban house these days is apt to be told that there are a few nice ones available at around $100,000.

title: Turning off an earthquake
description: A development paralleling the identification and testing of earthquake warning signs has been the totally unexpected discovery of a way to turn earthquakes on and offat least in some areas. One of the most embarrassing and troublesome problems of the Army's chemicalwarfare branch has been disposing of nervegas residues and other highly toxic materials. As one solution, the Army bored an extremely deep well at its Rocky Mountain Arsenal, east of the Denver airport. At a depth of 2.2 miles a layer of rock was reached sufficiently fractured to permit dispersal of the noxious fluids. Because above it a layer impermeable to fluids had been penetrated, there seemed no danger of contaminating ground water at shallower depths. By the mid1960's, half a million tons of toxic liquids had

title: Moment of Truth
description: In modern American politics, there is a dynamic relationship between opinion polls and primary elections. A Presidential hopeful who is relatively unknown has a low.. standing in the opinion polls because immediate name, recognition is a critical factor. If he wins the early primaries, he radically improves his standing the polls. Money and support then flow to him, making it easier for him to win subsequent primaries and endowing him with that useful intangible called momentum.

title: Bridge Inc. to Benefit
description: The Bridge Inc., a psychiatric rehabilitation center affiliated with Roosevelt Hospital, has chosen Tuesday's performance of Knock Knock at the Biltmore Theater for its spring theater benefit.

title: RECORDINGS VIEWS; Is the Great American Opera Really an Opera?;
description: When Gershwin's Porgy and Bess opened in New York on October 10, 1935, few people seemed to know what to make of this unique blend of Broadway, blues, Tin Pan Alley and grand opera. Theater critics, attuned to Gershwin's musical comedy successes, praised the songs but felt that the elaborately throughcomposed connective passagesrecitatives, choral interjections, orchestral interludesimpeded the action. Music critics took a totally opposite view. They were impressed by the composer's technical ingenuity and inventiveness but objected to the songs, which, they maintained, condescended to low popular taste.

title: The Costly Joys of Horsemanship
description: Anyone who has ever owned or ridden a horse or a pony knows that horseback riding is an exhilarating activity for children as well as adults. A horse provides a youngster with an outlet for affection, in addition to serving as a testing ground for his or her growing physical skills. For adults, the challenge is more often that of developing patience, skill, a bit of daring, and an instinct about how a horse will perform in a variety of situations.

title: Humphrey to Shun Jersey, Last Primary Open to Him
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota says he will bypass the New Jersey Presidential primary on June 8, the last one open to him, regardless of what happens in Pennsylvania on Tuesday.

title: Union Seeks World Backing
description: CLEVELAND, April 24 (UPI) Mr. Bommarito is preparing to leave tomorrow for Geneva, where he will meet with European labor leaders. A spokesman said the union president would seek worldwide solidarity action among world rubber councils of the International Federation of Chemical and General Workers Unions on the strike.

title: Henrik Dam, Vitamin K Discoverer, Dies
AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Brown pustules on stems of pachysandra indicate disease spores; spray twice, at two week interval, with fungicide such as ferbam, maneb, or zineb. . . . Prune rhododendron branches where leaves remain tightly curled because of fungus or borer damage. . . . Use halfrate water soluble fertilizers on seedlings growing indoors. . . . Caution on hasty planting outdoors of tender seedlings; there still might be frost.

title: Derby Week: When the South Rises
Home Clinic
description: Q: In order to refinish the top of an antique cherrywood table I used varnish remover to strip off all of the old finish. I found that many stains and discolorations still remained in the wood, so I used a bleaching agent (sodium hydroxide and hydrogen peroxide). These worked well on the clean areas, but not on all of the discolored areas, so I then used oxalic acid solution. This still left some darkened areas that mar the appearance. Apparently some sealer was used that keeps the bleach from penetrating. Do you know What else I can do? P.S.M., Moorestown, N. J.

title: He Makes Scientists Come Alive
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Gregor Mendel, the German priest who developed the prindple of heredity in 1865, was smoking a cigar as he waddled briskly into a packed auditorium at the University of California here.

title: Ambulance Boat Is Ready to Serve
description: STAMFORD, Conn. Probably the first fullyequipped and staffed ambulance boat in existence, Star of Life No. 1, was christened here earlier this month at Yacht Haven East marina for patrol and rescue duty on Long Island Sound between Norwalk and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Team America Has International Roster
description: The Brazilian Soccer Federation last week released the names of players to represent the country in the American Bicentennial Soccer Cup. Pele's name was not on that list, as Pele is expected to play for Team America in the tournament that also includes the national teams of England and Italy.

title: SOVIET SEES US,  LOSING BUSINESSI
description: MOSCOW, April 24A Soviet economist asserted today that the collapse of the SovietAmerican trade agreement 15 months ago had cost the United States as much as $1.6 billion In Soviet orders that were placed elsewhere.

title: Zoned for Contention: 2 Homes in 1 House
description: FOR Carmelo Ricca, it was the fulfillment of the great American dream: a ;louse in the suburbs. Three years ago Mr. Ricca, a mechanic, bought a twofamily house in Mineola that had a rentpaying tenant, sent his three .children to school and was content. Then his dream began to fall apart: He was laid off from his job and was served with a summons from the town informing him that he was living in a home zoned for only singlefamily residences and that the tenant must move. Without income from his job or his tenant, Mr. Ricca will not be able to afford the costs and will have to give up his house.0

title: Outraged Taxpayers Report
description: SHE drives a car, goes to bingo, hires babysitters for her two children that she neglects so badly, goes to bars, has two phones, plus men coming her home all hours of the day and night.

title: It's Special to Know You
description: Grownups as well as children have widely differing attitudes about any kind of body disability. Although we may not recognize it, some adults may feel very uncomfortable in the presence of a handicapped child because we haven't mastered our own childhood fears that we might damage our own bodies or somebody else's.

title: Weddings
description: BerlletCanape

title: Yankees Beat Royals, 98, on Chambliss Hit in 11th
description: In a minor classic in which seeing wasn't believing, the Yankees defeated the Kansas City Royals, 98, in the 11 th inning yesterday at the Stadium.

title: Federal Policing Asked
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP)Bob Donahue, an aide to Mr. Carter, said today that the Federal authorities had been asked to assist In policing Tuesday's primary election because of the threatening calls made to the candidate's campaign headquarters here.

title: Mark Lorin Kaywood Marries jeanneR.Hook
description: In St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church last evening, Jeanne Ruffin Hook, daughter of Louise Pabst Hook of Belmont, Mass., and George Matthew Verity Hook of Paris, was married to Mark Lorin Kaywood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Angel Kaywood of New York.

title: Nautical Flea Markets Can Save Boat Buyers Both Time and Money
description: If fitting out your old boat has got you down, don't give up the ship. Take it to a used boat show.

title: The Nation Continued
description: WASHINGTONIn the old World War II movies, the squad of American soldiers usually consisted of slice of American lifethe country boy, the city slicker, the Jewish kid, the fellow of Polish descent.

title: Rail Merger
description: In the wake of Conrail, the parent companies of the Southern Railroad and the Missouri Pacifictwo of the nation's more profitable railroadshave announced that they are studying what in effect would be a merger, following the creation of a new corporate entity.

title: ON AND On THE COURT
description: Most of Richard Northern's pupils see him in his business clothestennis shorts, a shirt and sweater and, in colder weather, a warmup suit. The very model of a hardworking tennis teacher, with his 25 shirts, 15 pairs of shorts. 10 sweaters, 5 warmup suits and 4 pairs of sneakers, he is adequately accoutred pour le snort.

title: INDUSTRY CHANGES SAUDI LANDSCAPE
description: RAS TANURA, Saudi Arabia  Selfpropelled cranes rumbled over the sand, hammers clanged on huge new naturalgas tanks, and Abdullah Kadhim gave a slightly dazed smile.

title: North Vietnam Puts the Emphasis on Literacy
description: It is hard for you Americans who have always had schools to understand the enthusiasm of our people for literacy classes, said Nguyen Van Trao, an official of the North Vietnamese Department of Education. In French colonial times, only monks and mandarins could read. The peasants were dependent on the mandarins, who often exploited them. Even today the written word has great importance for us Vietnamese.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Most people know how fascinating it is to see their favorite slides projected on a large screen so that even the tiniest detail is enlarged with startling clarity, and so that all present can view each picture simultaneously.

title: Blossoms Month By Month
description: From late February into November there is bloom in my New Jersey garden. It starts with the first snowdrops and crocus in winter's snows, and ends with a few rosebuds. mums and annuals that have survived light frosts.

title: JAMES FLAVIN, 69, CHARACTER ACTOR
description: James Flavin, veteran Hollywood character actor who played toughtalking detectives. Marine sergeants and policemen, died Friday in Los Angeles of a ruptured aorta. He was 69 years old.

title: The Island Takes a Look at Itself
Notes: Hotel Game in The Inscrutable East
description: Dale Keller & Associates is a firm of interior designers that operates primarily out of Hong Kong and specializes in hotels abroad, mostly in Asia and usually in the socalled developing countries. Current projects range from the 183room SoalteeOberoi in Nepal to the 2,000room Porto Carras resort in Greece.

title: Bridal Is Set By Amy Finn
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Finn of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Finn, to Dr. Ralph Binder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Binder of Millburn. N.J.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY ASSAILED BY T.W.U.
description: The counsel for the Transport Workers Union charged yesterday that the Transit Authority had double crossed the union by voting Friday night to have wage increases in the new contract contingent on funds from productivity imnrovements or other savings.

title: Medical SchoolsThe Facts of Life
description: Every applicant knows how keen the competiticn is to gain a place in medical school. Our experience at the Graduate Studies Center in dealing with premedical students, as well as schools and officials, indicates that students can improve their chances by careful planning. Here are some typical questions that applicants ask the center and the kinds of advice that it offers:

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . to Arrowhead from New York City, plan on a threehour drive and a distance of about 150 miles. Drivers should pick up Interstate 684 from the Hutchinson River Parkway and proceed to the 184 Junction. There one has a choice of the Taconic State Parkway or State Route 22 north. Route 22 is slower but shorter. Drivers taking Route 22 should turn east on State Route 23 at Hillsdale, N.Y., and connect with U.S. 7 in Massachusetts going north. Routs 7 will mesh with U.S. 20 in Lenox, and pass within a halfmile of Herman Melville's home. Watch for Holmes Road running off Routes 7 and 20 in Lenox. Arrowhead is at 780 Holmes Road, a short distance across the Lenox. Pittsfield line. It is white frame farmhouse with a granite marker out front identifying it as the residence for 13 years of Herman Melville, Mariner and Mystic.

title: POLITICS
description: THE political futures of former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia and Governor Byrne are both at stake in the Democratic Presidential primary in New Jersey.

title: ART VIEW
description: The art of the French painter Jean Hdlion is, even to someone sympathetic to its special quality, something of a conundrum. Mr. Helion is obviously an immensely gifted artist, and his long careerhe has just observed his 74th birthdayis one of the most interesting of his generation, In the 1930's, he was probably the best nativeborn abstract painter in Paris. He is also an accomplished writer, and not only about arthis book about his experiences in World War II, They Shall Not Have Me, was published in New York in 1943. It was during the war years that

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE quest for knowledge through the analysis of garbage is a relatively recent science. Robert Maheu, who once worked for Howard Hughes and the Central Intelligence Agency, and who subsequently became involved in a vast lawsuit with the late rich man, claims that his garbage outside his Los Angeles home was collected dailyand, he suspects, sifted for secretsby Hughes operatives. And Henry Kissinger has told us that people have been looking into his personal garbage for some timeand he does not like it.

title: 2 Reborn Houses And a Dispute
description: OLD mansions brought back to life for the benefit of charities don't usually generate controversy any more serious than the negative comments of some visitors who dislike the choices of the interior decorators.

title: Early stories, full of human grief and literary pleasure
description: Vladimir Nabokov's new collection of his old stories, Details of a Sunset (19241935), is much concerned with different kinds of lossexile, failure of romantic love and family love. the death of a wife, the death of a son, the death of one's selfand yet the effects of these stories are mainly exhilarating, even affirmative. in the last story, as if to comment on this paradox. Nabokov says, human consciousness is an ominous and ludicrous luxury. In other words, if our world were a simple, rational place. then sad stories couldn't be exhilarating, ominous wouldn't rhyme with ludicrous, and there would be no such thing as humor (certainly not black humor) and also no such thing as art. There might even he no consciousness, but only the Sort of mental life as exists, for example, in Marxian utopias. (These considerations are more subtle and more elegant in Nabokov's stories.)

title: THE PRESS IN SPAIN ENJOYING A BOOM
description: MADRID April 24 Spain is enjoying a kind of journalistic springtime.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A. MORE ON PEACH TREE BORER PROBLEM (March 28) The appearance of a large gelantinous mass at I the base of the peach tree is a goodindication of damage from the peach tree borer. The remedy recommended was a ring of moth (PDB) crystals placed in a ring around the base of the trunk about oneinch from it. The crystals are then covered with soil and allowed to remain. However, because of the vaporizing of the crystals, especially in the warm spring weather, the crystals should be removed in two to three weeks time by taking away the soil Mound and raking up the crystals. Usually a fall treatment; a spring application can be made in late April and May if the soil temperature is warm, about 60 degrees. Ed.

title: Curbing Road Blight
description: THE unorganized commercial development of Nassau County in the last four decades has produced many commercial strips with a carnivallike quality in which eyesore signs dot a landscape of buildings lacking any coherent relationship to one another, according to a justcompleted study.

title: Urges Rhodesia Talks
description: LONDON, April 24 Secretary of State Kissinger, before leaving here for a tour of seven African nations, pledged today that the United States was determined to seek early majority rule in Rhodesia.

title: Heroin Crackdown May Not Cut Crime
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The conventional wisdom that law enforcement efforts to interrupt drug traffic tends to reduce heroinrelated crime may be incorrect, the Drug Abuse Council said in a report released this week.

title: The World
description: China and Egypt, once allies of the Soviet Union, have signed an agreement of cooperation that reflects animosity that now marks the relationship of each with Moscow. The agreement has tangible military benefits for Cairo and political implications obviously pleasing to Peking.

title: Penn Crew Defeats Yale And Retains Dodge Cup
Modern Bass Boats Invading Eastern Lakes
description: Spawned in the South, the black bass fishing craze, with its fast, modern boats powered by big outboards and equipped with a dazzling array of electronic eguipment, has reached the Norcheast.

title: Levitt Says State Overpaid City $8.4 Million for Health Projects
description: Auditors for Arthur Levitt, the State Comptroller, reported yesterday that the city's Department of Health owed the state $8.4 million for excess reimbursements made from July 1, 1969, to June 30, 1974.

title: Engagements
description: GottesmanFisher

title: In Art, a Modern Trend to Old Ways
description: Michelangelo would have been proud. There in the middle of a studio in the School of Visual Arts in downtown New York stood a motionless young woman, arms akimbo. Around her 30 students, their easels pressed close together, were busy trying to transfer her image onto paper.

title: Six New Members Elected To Freedom House Board
description: The election of six new members to the board of trustees of Freedom House was announced yesterday by former Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine, who has been reelected chairman of the board.

title: Miss Stewart, David R. Grace Plan to Marry
description: Mrs. William Henry Osborn of Glen Head, L.I., and James Stewart of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barry Martin Stewart, to David Richard Grace, son of Mrs. David Ralph Grace of Oyster Bay, L.L. and the late Mr. Grace.

title: Child to Mrs. Aldrich
description: A daughter was born last Tuesday to Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Aldrich of Barr .town, N.Y., at the Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The child has been named Katharine Delano, in honor of Mrs. Aldrich's grandmother, former Congresswoman Katharine St. George of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and of Mrs. St. George's grandmother, the late Katharine Lyman Delano, who was the grandmother :f.'s() of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Her father is an assistant to the New York Slate Commissioner of Environmental Conservation. Mrs. Aldrich is the former Katharine Delano Ryan.

title: Saving the Old School's Ties to The Community
description: NO MORE pencils, no more books, no more teacher's dirty looks  so went the old vacation chant of schoolchildren. It meant empty classrooms, auditoriums, gymnasiums, offices and other spaces of learning for two months. All that was lat was the swish of the custodian's mop or the sound of children in thd playground as books and blackboards stood patiently awaiting Labor Day, and the return, of the children.

title: Learning for Lollipops
description: In a North Brunswick, N.J., classroom, fourthgrade students are praised for good penmanship and ignored when their writing is sloppy.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS SLOWING DECLINE
description: CHICAGO, April 24  The precipitous enrollment decline that threatened the existence of this country's Roman Catholic parochial schools has eased, and the schools are now drawing new strength from an emphasis on spiritual and moral values that many parents find lacking in public schools.

title: On Being 17, Bright and Unable to Read
description: One day a substitute teacher picked me to rend aloud from the ??? When I told her No, thank you, she came unhinged. She thought I was acting smart, and told me so. I kept calm, and that got her madder and madder. We must have spent 10 minutes trying to solve the problem, and finally she got so red in the face I thought she'd blow up. She told me she'd see me after class.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Paris in the Spring Sans Carpentier
description: Imagine not wanting to go to Paris In the spring. Well, this year I don't. Other yeafs when the daffodils came out I used to walk with Georges Carpentier in the Tuileries gardens. But he died before this year's daffodils came out. In November Peggy Roch of Elle Magazine said said: I saw Georges yesterday in the Tuileries with his dachshund, Nobert, looking very fit. That afternoon when I went to call on him, as I normally did when I was in Paris, he was out. Two days later I read he was dead.

title: Gallup Finds Ford Is Trailing Carter, Tied With Humphrey
description: The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that President Ford would probably face a tough battle against .both leading Democratic contenders, former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, if the election were held today.

title: Right, for Ford
description: Alan Greenspan, an Ayn Rand conservative, seems an unlikely chairman for the Council of Economic Advisers. But even Democrats acknowledge his credibility and his stock is high.

title: It all began with Poe
description: A month or so ago, there occurred in London an event which helped me to understandin a way no work of criticism has ever managed to dothe mood of helpless solitude and menace one associates with the British crime novel. For two days London was submerged in a fog so thick the streetlights were ridiculous little twinklings wreathed in yellowtinted vapor, the streets were empty, there was no sky or ground, and visibility was so poor I had the constant apprehension that I was either being closely followed or was about to bump into an unseen presence a few feet in front of me.

title: A. E. Martin 2d Weds Patricia Humphreys
description: Patricia Anne Humphreys, who is with the marketing and planning division of the Chemical Bank, and A. Emerson Martin 2d, a member of the corporate finance department of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, were married yesterday morning in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Hingham, Mass. he Rev. James Morrissey performed the ceremony.

title: State Supreme Court: A New Team
description: TRENTON

title: Martha Brewer Bay State Bride
description: Dr. Martha Marion Brewer, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Cyrus Brewer of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married to Dr. William Collins Nugent Jr. yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nugent of Morristown, N. J.

title: A New Middle East Boom
description: TEHERAN, IranThe Omani Government is handing out free Korans to schoolchildren. A halfdozen new universities are sprouting in Iran, And the number of children enrolled in Saudi Arabian schools is to double by 1980.

title: Price for Babies Rising In Wider Black Market
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP)Babies are being sold in a fast growing black market that charges anywhere from $5,000 for an illegal adoption to $50,000 for a custommade child.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: MUSIC & DANCE

title: Ideas &Trends
description: New archeological findings in the highlands of Guatemala may require extensive revisions of widely accepted theories about the origins of the Maya civilization of Central America, and of the direction of prehistoric cultural influences in that area.

title: The Economy Holds Little Cheer For Democrats
description: There must be an economic issue that the Democrats can dig up for the Presidential racebut I'll be darned if I can figure out what it is, said an economist of that party affiliation.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Aballet classroom is a cold placea place for rituals, a place for learning, a place for initiation, a temple of pain. Dancers first go to class almost before they know it. Their parents send them there, and their young, supple bodies and pliable minds are transformed by the rigors of a discipline they learn to forget. A ballet stage is something differenta place for testing, a place for the exercising of expertise, a place to face audiences and other horrors. The distance between a ballet classroom and a ballet stage is enormous; it is a chasm and a mystery.

title: The Dependence on Property Taxes Is Under Assault
description: At a time when they would seem least able to respond, the legislatures of New Jersey and Connecticut are under court order to restructure the way they raise and distribute funds to support their public school systems. Both states have enacted new formulas to equalize schooldistrict funding but the legislatures, in a period of serious financial difficulty, have resisted raising the revenues needed to make the formulas work.

title: The Proper Study of Mankind...
description: The kind of controversy that surrounded new math in the 1960's is swirling again, this time in social studies, with battle lines drawn on some of the same public issues and many nf the same nrivate ones.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 25, 1976

title: Watehing the Island Grow
description: BEFORE the First World War, Charles Hanson Towne, the poet, used to walk the length of Long Island every year to sketch its rural beauty, commune with nature and record the charm of its open spaces in unforgettable prose,

title: Vieinamizing South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, One year after the fall of the Thieu regime, Saigon is still a city in transition, half of it living in the past, the other half in a future partly undefined. The downtown bars are still mostly open, and in their empty dimness the bar girls still seem to be waiting for the return of their former patrons. The cafes, patterned on their Paris namesakes, are full. Lean youths in tapered shirts, long hair and flared jeans throng around the juke boxes, with their ceaseless blare of hard rock. Most of the French restaurants are still in business (though their French owners have left). and Saigon still offers the best cheese souffle and crepes flambees in Asia.

title: ART
description: ROSLYN

title: Costs of Welfare Soar
description: PUBLIC welfare costs in New Jersey have increased by an average of 22.8 percent a year in the last decade, rising to the point where public assistance and Medicaid are costing the state one of every five tax dollars that it collects.

title: G.M.Turns Out Bumper Crop of Graduates
description: FLINT, Mich.At first glance, the compact college campus tucked away In a residential corner of this automobile city could be a satellite of similar scenes in Cambridge, New Haven or any number of other cities.

title: '72 ELECTION SET SPENDING RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The onesided Presidential election of 1972 set a campaign spending record of nearly $137 million for the two major parties that will probably stand for the foreseeable future.

title: How a Man Bilked Chase of $732,000 By Duping Banker
description: In repeated visits to the Rockefeller Center branch of Chase Manhattan Bank, Munroe Schwehel sought more than $732,000 and got it alljust for the asking.

title: IF THE SHOE FITS ...
description: According to Plutarch, a Roman who divorced his wife was rebuked by his friends. Was she not chaste? Was she not fair? Was she not faithful? they demanded. In answer, the man held out his shoe and asked, Is it not new? Is it not well made? His friends agreed that it was. And yet, he admonished them, none of you can tell where it pinches me.

title: Oregon Prisoners 6rni Their Own Credit Union
description: SALEM, Ore., April 24 (UPI) A new credit union will open operations soon In Oregon, but Its members and directors will be limited to convicted felons.

title: Buildings Speak to Us  How To Listen
description: I once walked a friend, a banker, from her Wall Street office to her Greenwich Village apartment. She suggested we walk since it was a pleasant summer evening, even though, she said, It's awfully boring.

title: STAMPS.

But A. M. Sullivan has made the transition with poetry his peers have found worthy of the Poetry Society of America's Gold Medal of Achievement.

title: Aid to Taxpayers Improves
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Internal Revenue Service figures show that the quality of I.R.S. responses to taxpayers questions consistently improved as the tax season progressed this year, according to a House panel. The House Ways and Means Cornmittee's investigating subcommittee said Wednesday that I.R.S. data requested by the panel indicated a 14.6 percent error rate on test calls in January dropped to 9.2 per cent by March.

title: Voters In Plymouth, Mass., Back Second Nuclear Plant
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., April 24 (AP)  Voters in an advisory ballot approved by a 4to1 margin today the construction a a second nuclear power plant here.

title: New Blow at I.L.O.
description: Just when it appeared that relations between the United States and the International Labor Organization were as rough as they could get, the House of Representatives proved that it could make them rockier still.

title: BRIDGE
description: CARDPLAVING and horse racing, frowned on equally in the Puritan tradition, have little in common nowadays. But they are geographically linked this weekend. since the Island's biggest bridge tournament of the year has been taking, place .t Belmont Park Race Course, home of the Belmont Stakes, rmethird of racing's triple The tournament is the lenth Long Island Regional titampionships organized by the NassauSuffolk Bridge Association, and while favorites went down to defeat, anguished citizens could be heard bewailing unsuccessful doubles and the frailties of the flesh.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE has been threatening for some time to bring the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to heel. He could do this, Mr. Byrne said, by refusing to sign the minutes of a meeting of the 12member agency.

title: FORECASTING DISASTER
description: In Missouri's Tom Sawyer country, the people who were alive on Dec. 15, 1811, never forgot that night. Particularly for those living along the Mississippi near New Madrid, it was as though the world were coming to an end. Shortly before 2 A.M., there was a creaking and groaning of the timbers in houses and cabins. Then a fearful crashing as furniture was overturned, chimneys crumbled and china fell to the floor. Fleeing from their homes, the people shivered outdoors through the rest of the night.

title: Watching the Tall Ships
description: When the tall sailing ships of Operation Sail arrive in New York Harbor July 4 to commemorate our nation's maritime heritage, boatmen based near Sandy Hook, N.J., will have what amounts to a ringside seat.

title: KISSINGER BEGINS HIS TOUR IN KENYA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 24 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger began his African visit here tonight by declaring that he sought to identify the aspirations of Africa with the aspirations of the United States.

title: Performing poet
description: Of all the poets of my generation, none has done more than Anne Waldman to bring poetry before the public at large. As director of Manhattan's St. Mark's ChurchontheBowery's Poetry Project, over the past decade she has arranged for poets from all over the globe to read in the church. During this same time she edited the church's poetry magazine, The World; and to date two anthologies of work that first appeared there have been issued. More recently she has emerged as an exciting readerperformer of her own poems; she has been reading her work to enthusiastic audiences throughout the country. This past summer, she and Allen Ginsberg founded the School of Poetics at the Naropa institute in Boulder, Colo where she now teaches.

title: Banker Weds Kathleen Ryan
description: Kathleen Anne Ryan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Ryan of Islip and Shelter Island, L. I., was married in the city yesterday morning to Anthony R. H. Gerard. The ceremony was performed in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. John F. Ryan, a cousin of the bride. There was a luncheon at the River Club.

title: Court Refuses Mrs. Exner Quick Access to F.B.I. File
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 (AP)A Federal appeals court has delayed efforts by Judith Campbell Exner, who has told of hating an affair with President Kennedy, to sec the files on her kept by the Federal Burau of Investigation.

title: FILM VIEW; Are Black Films Losing Their Blackness?; VINCENT CANBY
description: It may not actually be a trend as yetit may simply be a superficial impression, based on several weeks of rather ordinary moviegoingbut it does seem as if the bottom has dropped out of the market for black exploitation films. I'm referring to those supercharged, badtalking, highly romanticized melodramas about Harlem superstuds, the pimps, the private eyes and the pushers who more or less singlehandedly make whitey's corrupt world safe for black pimping, black privateeyeing and black pushing. By next week I may be eating my hat, hut right now it seems as if more and more films that once would have been categorized as black films are really films for the general market. They are black films that you don't have to be black to respond to favorably, or to find dreary and pretentious. foolish and inept. The most dynamic and entertaining of these new black films is a candidly commercial boxoffice attack called Sparkle, a story about three young women from Harlem and the high price they pay in their climb to the top as the country's most popular singingsister act. It sounds terrible, a sort of retread of Sally, Irene and Mary' transposed to the nevernever land ruled by Barry Gordy and Motown Records. The confusion may well be intentional. The routines performed by the girls in Sparkle, and the new music provided them by Curtis Mayfield, definitely recall the style and effect of The Supremes and, in Lonette McKee, who plays the sister who goes bad, in the way Lana Turner did in a movie like Ziegfeld Girl, it has a leading actress whose beauty, talent and verve recall the extraordinary Diana Ross herself.

title: For young readers; The Turning Place; Stories of a Future Past. By Jean E. Karl. 213 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton 8c Co. $7.95. (Ages 12 and Up)
description: The place is Earth, and the turning results from the Clordian Sweep, a cataclysm engineered by the inhabitants of a galactic rival planet named Clord. These nine interrelated stories cover the history of Earth, and eventually most of the universe, from just before the Sweep until a very long time after. Mutations among the survivors of the Sweep cause them to develop in unpredictable ways. They acquire telekinetic and other powers ana eventuauy put together a civilization that takes its Place beside others in the exploration and governance of the galaxy. So far, a classic but serviceable situation.

title: Holtz's Tight Ship Buoys Aspiring Jets
description: They are, after all. not far past boyhood, these powerful young men, moit of whom are still college students. They sat on the floor of the Jets camp, uncomplaining, as they waited for someone to look at their teeth or for someone to probe their muscles or to test their strength.

title: Normal Ups and Downs
description: WASHINGTONThe late, unlamented recession 197475 is over: The economy has been moving up since last May. In retrospect, perhaps, the most striking feature of this recession was how classic both the decline and the recovery have been.

title: The Puzzle of Learning Disabilities
description: Tim, 8, is the best science student In his clasi, but he has a hard time reading, principally because he can't tell the differences among the letters of the alphabet. Rebecca reads well, but at the age of 10 she still hasn't learned to subtract because she can't grasp the concept that one number is more or less than another. These two children and a significant number of others in this country suffer from a littleunderstood group of related physiological problems called learning disabilities. These disabilities, believed to be primarily neurologic in origin, make it difficult or impossible for these children to learn normally or behave well.

title: PRINCE or THE PIT
description: Last night's wine and a brief sleep have left Richard Dennis properly groggy for Monday's trading. At a Sunday evening dinner party, he helped a friend celebrate his candidacy for the Illinois State Senate; consequently, he rose with heavy eyes and reluctant spirit, and that is a mood he's not afraid to bring to work. He'd prefer a lingering cold or a mild depression, but this small hangover slows him sufficiently as he walks onto the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade at 9 o'clock. Other traders mill about, studying computer printouts that report their previous day's buying and selling. Dennis has a printout, too, and it shows very large numbers, for he is one of the biggest futures traders the floor.

title: An Intended Bridegroom Is Killed After Party
description: MANORVILLE. L. I., April 24 (AP)A bridegroomtobe and three close friends were killed today when their car struck a tree in this Suffolk County community as they drove home from a bachelor party. Two other passengers in the car were hospitalized with serious injuries.

Cherchez l'homme
description: Barbara Howar's first book, Laughing All the Way, was a delightful, direct, witty, memoir of one woman's hegira through Washington during the L.B.J. Administration. It was perhaps the most honest book to come out of the Johnson years. After Lady Bird's saccharine diary and L.B.J.'s leaden selfdefense, Barbara Howar's book came as a blast of clean aira book about politics that only a woman could have written, a book about power seen from the excellent vantage point of the boudoir, a book about deception and selfdeception at the top. Back in the days when, not having had one, I disdained all best sellers, I grabbed Laughing All the Way from a drugstore rack, read it, expecting nothing, and was left with great respect for the author's talent and honesty.

title: The Olympic Time Capsule

Helped to his feet, he fell three more times. Finally he was Sports of The Times dragged across the fin ish line by officials who feared for his life. a But that resulted in the Italian's disqualification and the award of the gold medal to Johnny Hayes, the tiny American who had arrived 34 seconds later under his own power. title: Headliners
description: British Prime Minister James Callaghan did not attend Queen Elizabeth II's 50th birthday party last week, a decision not well received by Britons at large. Newspapers of various political persuasion lambasted Mr. Callaghan for snubbing the Queen. Mr. Callaghan's official explanation was that he was busy reading up on his new job, but unofficially it was said Mr. Callaghan might have felt uncomfortable in the opulence a royal party while trying to convince trade unions accept minimal wage increases. A spokesman for the Queen said she understood perfectly the Prime Minister's reasons for not attending.

And its acceptance is being spurred on by the evangelical efforts of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who is a director of the llwha Pharmaceutical Company, a major Korean ginseng production and export firm. In seven comfortable rooms sprawling high over Central Park, Misha and Cipa Dichter live surrounded by three pianos, memorabilia from countless concert tours and a hammock strung from the livingroom ceiling. More than anything else, this insouciant touch characterizes an easy life style that, much as possible, puts the children first.

title: The Dying Speak For Themselves On a TV Special
description: Death is death only for the living, the German philosopher Ludwig Feuerbach wrote more than a hundred years ago. This Thursday evening at 10 on Channel 13, three terminally ill patients and the widow of a fourth document this maxim in an hourandahalf Public Broadcasting System film special, Dying, directed by Michael Roemer under a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Previous television specials, on PBS and the ccrrnmercial networks, have handled this topic gingerly and didacticallydeath as something to In this production, the dying speak for themselves: all had willingly agreed to this invasion of privacy, and, indeed, we are invited to share the final few months of their lives as they wait for the end. How they wait, of course, is the film's message. Television thus becomes a medium for dying in public, the patient an actor In a drama for which he is writing the script and the

He also was the purveyor of such pretty tunes as Country Gardens (his most famous piece), Shepherd's Hey and Molly on the Shore. Kitsch, in short.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW

The Dow's net gain last week came to 20.23 points.

New orders for durable goods rose by $2.9 billion or 6.5 percent to $47.9 billion In March, the largest onemonth advance since April 1975.... The nation's money supply rose $3.4 billion in the latest reporting week.

title: Bumpy Road for Motorcycles

title: OnShore Planning

It is just possible that this preliminary drilling will reveal prospects too scant to justify production drilling at the risk of severely damaging one the richest resort and fishing areas of the country. It equally possible that it will promise an appreciable return, as similar testing has done in the Baltimore Canyon off New Jersey.

title: Stenotype Finalists Unfazed By 220 to 280 wordsaminute
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 25The keyboard postures ranged from Vladimir Horowitz to Victor Borge and the nimble fingers beat a silent tattoo to the tobaccoauctioneer delivery of a reader.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development will subsidize 25,000 living units across the state. The units, new and renovated housing, will be scattered in urban, suburban and rural sections. The agency said it planned to spend more than $95 million in rent subsidies for the living units.

title: Hanoi General Was Surprised At Speed of Saigon's Collapse
description: HONG KONG, April 25North Vietnam's leaders did not expect their offensive last year to achieve complete victory and were surprised by the speed of Saigon's collapse, according to a lengthy new account by Hanoi's Chief of Staff of the war's final battles.

title: Bergen Councilwomen Meet to Trade Ideas
description: HARRINGTON PARK, April 25  Women Council members from 10 Bergen County communities have begun a series of monthly daytime meetings to trade ideas and explore common problems about serving in government, in addition to hearing from appointees to planning and zoning boards as well as elected officials.

title: Bank Earnings Down or Are They?
description: On the surface at least, news in the banking business does not appear good.

title: Bridget Potter Wed to Robert Wool
description: Bridget Potter and Robert Wool were married yesterday in a civil ceremony in Zermatt. Switzerland.

title: PLUTONIUM PLANT SCORED ON SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, April 25One of the nation's leading expens on the lethal dangers of radiation says that the managers of an Oklahoma plutonium factory appear to have shown little concern about the longterm cancer risks of plutonium.

title: SOCIALISTS AHEAD IN PORTUGAL VOTE BY REDUCED EDGE
description: LISBON, Monday, April 26The Portuguese Socialist Party led this morning in returns from the nation's first free parliamentary elections in half a century, but centrist and Conservative parties made stronger showings than had been expected.

title: 700 Drop In on Careys on Rainy Day
description: ALBANY, April 25About 700 rainspattered residents of the Albany area found a little warm hospitality and dry humor from Governor Carey this afternoon when the Executive Mansion was thrown open to all corners for the traditional Governor's Open House.

title: The Wind of Change: II
description: BOSTON, April 25Mr. Kissinger's African tour is a sign, at least, that the American Government may finally be taking Africa seriously. An optimist would hope for more: the beginning of a considered and rational African policy. But before that could happen, Washington would have to understand the consequences of its past folly in the area.

title: Nepal Finds Growing Power of India In South Asia Imperils Independence
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 12 Every sign of India's growing predominance in South Asiaand particularly the most recent one, the annexation of nearby Sikkim last yearis a cause for some uneasiness in Katmandu.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Pressure on Peso Grows Amid Devaluation Denials
description: The value of the Mexican peso, unchallenged for 22 years, has suddenly become suspect in the international money market. Foreign banks, corporations and private investors with peso holdings have quietly begun to convert them into dollars.

title: Ruined Church Yields Some Notes of History
description: Newspapers selling for 2 and 3 cents an issue and reporting on such topics of current interest as shipping accidents and the untimely death of a young sharpshooter were found yesterday in a lead box taken from the cornerstone of a Brooklyn church.

title: Yanks End Stand With a Rainout
description: The final game of the New York Yankees eightgame home stand against the Kansas City Royals was postponed yesterday by rain.

title: Pay of Executives Trails Superstars'
description: The acceptance by Barbara Walters last week of fiveyear, $1 millionayear contract as television network anchorwoman for the American Broadcasting Companies Inc. brought into sharp focus the difference between salaries of personalities and those of top executives at major American corporations.

title: Comniunist Guerrillas Blast A Main Malaysian Rail Line
description: IPOH, Malaysia, April 25 (Reuters)  Communist guerrillas today blew up a stretch of Malaysia's main northern rail line in the state of Perak, the police said.

title: Group in Boston Bombing Held Unit of Terror Front
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (AP) The Samuel MelvilleJonathan Jackson Unit, which said it was responsible for the Boston courthouse bombing that injured 22 people last Thursday, is part of the terrorist New World Liberation Front, so its threats should not be taken lightly, a man who acts as messenger for the front said today.

title: Return of Roller Derby: Past Is Too Much With It
description: Where have you gone, Charlie O'Connell?

title: CLAIRE R. SETLOW
description: Claire Rappaport Setlow, secretary of SetloWear Inc., maker of work clothes, died yesterday in YaleNew Haven Hospital of a liver ailment. She was 62 years old and lived in New Haven. She was the wife of Herbert D. Setlow, president of the company and national chairman of the commission on volunteer sevices of Binai Birith.

title: Military Manpower Study Is Said to Overrate Draft
description: The Defense Manpower Commission's report, presented to Congress last week, raises serious questions about the pay, promotion and support of the 2.1 million men and women in the United States active military services. But many serving officers and civilian students of military affairs feel the report neglects or misunderstands some aspects of effective manpower employment for national security.

title: I.R.A. DEFIES BAN ON DUBLIN MARCH
description: DUBLIN, April 25Thousands of Irish Republican Army supporters defied the Dublin Government today and marched through the city to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the. 1916 Easter uprising.

title: FORESTS KEPT SHOT DESPITE RAINFALL
description: More than a million acres of forest in central and southern New Jersey were to remain. closed today as showers that fell yesterday in many parts of the state proved too light to douse a number of blazes burning stubbornly in parched 3,500acre area.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 25A challenge by two state Assemblymen of the New Jersey Supreme Court's order to the Legislature to give $378 million additional to public schools will be argued in Superior Court in Jersey City this week.

title: Time Again Running Out For French Watch Giant
description: BESANCON. France The clean, low buildings fan out across several acres of immaculate lawns and flowering gardens behind the big white clock now tolling the knell of the Lip watch company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State auditors criticized the elevator inspection program of the city's Department of Buildings, declaring that a sampling of 118 Manhattan elevators showed more than 10 months between inspections on the average, although the auditors said, they are required at threemonth intervals. In an earlier report, in July 1972, the auditor had found 17month lags between inspections and other shortcomings.

title: PCB CLEANUP COST PUT Al $20 MILLION
description: It may cost more than $20 million to cleanse the upper Hudson River of the toxic chemical PCB's, and the State Department of Environmental Conservation plans to ask General Electric to pay the entire cost of cleaning up the river it has damaged.

title: Matthau Has Heart Surgery
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 25 (AP)Walter Matthau was listed in satisfactory condition today after having undergone heart surgery yesterday. Doctors said they performed a bypass procedure on the 52year,old actor and described the operation as a success. It was elective rather than emergency surgery, officials at Daniel Freeman Hospital said.

title: Planners Back Times Sq. As Convention Center Site
description: Times Square and the proposed new convention center need each other, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.

title: Tool Orders Rose In First Quarter; Shipments Slipped
description: The machine tool industry had a busy first quarter with orders totaling $414.95 million, or 84.3 percent higher than in the first three months of 1975, the Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend. However, shipments slipped by 16.2 percent to $533.5 million, which left the industry's backlog of orders at $1.16 billion on March 31. A year earlier the backlog stood at $2.1 billion.

title: St. Cecilia Chorus in Brahms Requiem
description: The Brahms German Requiem has lately fallen into disrepute. Its conjunct, rather glutinous choral writing and the Biedermeier comfort of its Scriptural settings has had a deadening effect. Yet it is, if early, entirely characteristic Brahms, majestic in its beauty and containing at least one choral masterstroke: the emergence of the altos from the choral cloud of Holle, wo ist dein Sieg?

title: Geisel Visits France
description: BRASILIA, April 25 (Reuters)  President Ernesto Geisel and his wife left for Paris today on the first state visit ever made to France by a Brazilian head of state.

title: Vote Denied Swiss Women
description: TROGEN, Switzerland, April 25 (Reuters)Men in the locality of Appenzell Outer Rhodes, voting in this small Alpine town today, maintained a 500year tradition by voting four to one against giving women a say in local government. Swiss women won the right to vote In national elections in 1971, but the men of Appenzell Outer Rhodes, known for its cheeses and yodellers, have repeatedly defeated women's attempts to win a vote at the local level.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FOLLOW THE LIEDER  In a concert tonight at 8, solos, duets, trios and quartets by Haydn, Mozart Beethoven, Schubert, Schumann. Loewe, Brahms, Wolf. Strauss, Mahler, Schoenbet ?? and Weill will trace the de velopment that culminated in the flowering of German art song in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. This is one of the typical, carefully planned presentations at Goethe House, the German cultural institution at 1014 Fifth Avenue (opposite the Metropolitan Museum). The performers are the Soloists Ensemble of New York, with a connecting lecture provided by Maurice Edwards.

title: Man Is Killed, 3 Are Hurt: In Accident on Turnpike
description: SPRINGFIELD TOWNSHIP, April 25 (AP)A Glenarden, Md., man was killed and three others were injured today, when the car in which they were riding struck a guard rail and trees on the New Jersey Turnpike here, the state police said.

title: Excerpts From General's Account of the Offensive
description: HONG KONG, April 25Following are excerpts, in unofficial translation, from the account of North Vietnam's Chief of Staff, Gen. Van Tien Dung, of the spring offensive of 1975 that led to the Communist victory in South Vietnam.

title: Genghis Khan Hailed at Rites
description: Before a ninetiered altar decorated with wine, fruit and dairy products. 50 Mongolians who live in the New York City area chanted songs and recited poems yesterday in memory of Genghis Khan, the Mongol conqueror who created a vast Asian empire in the 13th century.

title: Center for Times Sq.
description: Citing the area's rich mixture of theaters, restaurants and hotels, the Regional Plan Association yesterday proposed the Times Square area as the site of the city's planned convention center. Details are on page 42.

title: Inmate Runs for Selectman in Concord
description: CONCORD, Mass.  I'm not a criminal any more, just a convict, said Carl Velleca, candidate for town selectman, from his campaign headquarters in the gift shop of the Massachusetts Correctional Institution here.

title: Screen:'Bambina' an Italian Feature About Sex
description: The Italian director Alberto Lattuada has made some splendid movies in his time: "Mafioso," for example, and the odd and interesting "Letters From a Novice." It doesn't seem to be his time any more, judging from "Bambina," which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater. There is a flicker of style in it, but it seems like a dying reflex.The film is about a scheming young real estate promoter who loses his schemes and most of his wits in a passionate love affair with a mentally retarded 16-year-old girl. A feeble attempt is made to justify it as a kind of innocent Adam and Eveidyll. What is being justified is a lot of fairly explicit sex, aimed  such are the wonders of pornographic specialization  at people with a fetish for imbeciles.Teresa Ann Savoy never really reaches imbecile level. Luigi Proietti looks as if he could be funny if he were ever to be cast in a funny movie. Irene Papas, as the girl's mother, presides in mournful amazement.

title: Toyota Said to Weigh Building Plant in U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 25 (UPI)Japan's Toyota Motor Company will follow the lead of West Germany's Volkswagen and build a passengercar factory in the United States, automobile industry sources in Tokyo said today.

title: Alexander Brailowsky Is Dead; Pianist Played All of Chopin
description: Alexander Brailowsky, the Russianborn concert pianist whose interpretation of the works of Chopin brought him worldwide acclaim, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital of complications brought on by pneumonia. He was 80 years old and lived at 107 East 64th Street.

title: Cleaning and Greening Just a Family Affair
description: It was a good day for things that growplants and children, that is.

title: About New York
description: Ever since A Chorus Line opened, it has been impossible to look at the boys and girls who sing and dance in musical comedies in the same old wayrating them on the brilliance of their smiles, their agility, their faces and forms. Nowadays the sensitive spectator looks for signs of emotional trauma beneath the grease paint. What conflicts, he asks himself, are tearng apart that cute brunette, the third from the left?

title: SOVIET ASSESSES KISSINGER'S TRIP
description: MOSCOW, April 25  The Kremlin, which is thought to be carefully watching Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's trip to Africa for a cue to its own future policy on the continent, has painted a gloomy picture of his prospects for success.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Pennsylvania senatorial race in The New York Times on Saturday said that a variety of polls showed Representative H. John Heinz 3d and Arlen Specter a few percentage points behind George Packard in the Republican primary. The polls showed Mr. Heinz and Mr. Specter leading, with Mr. Packard trailing by a few percentage points.

title: KISSINGER MEETS 2 AFRICA LEADERS
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 25 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with the heads of state of both Kenya and Tanzania on the first full day of his tour of Africa.

title: Cholera Kills 10 in West Java
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 25 (Reuters)Ten people died from cholera In West Java last week, and more than 200 were In hospital suffering from the disease, an official spokesman said today.

title: Water Supply Pollutants In Dover Seen Widening
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, April 25 The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection fears that pollutants that affected the underground water supply in a section of this township two years ago may be spreading.

title: The New Integrity
description: The new chairman of Gulf Oilwhose predecessor was ousted as a result of the company's involvement in illegal domestic and foreign political paymentswas probably right in telling stockholders at the annual meeting last week that the greatest problem facing Gulf was restoring our confidence in ourselves and our creaibility with others. He went on to say that the company was trying to build a new bridge of understanding with Washingtona bridge built on integrity rather than influence.

title: A Rusty Trust
description: Festivities and dancing brought cheer to the balmy Mariana Islands last weekbut not to Americans concerned with the future of the United States position the Western Pacific. The 14,000 residents of those farflung island outposts have received what they asked for, the covenant which leads them eventually into an illdefined commonwealth status under American sovereignty, flag and, not incidentally, social security.

title: Screen: 'Stay Hungry':Rafelson Film Is About 'New' South
description: "Stay Hungry," the new film directed by Bob Rafelson ("Five Easy Pieces" and "The King of Marvin Gardens"), isn't all bad. It just seems that way when it pretends to be more eccentric than it is and to have more on its mind than it actually does.From time to time there are some awfully good things in it, including its picture of the "new" go-getting South, in this case Birmingham, Ala., a place where old-money families live side by side in peace and harmony with the new rich, have the same accents, belong to the same country clubs and sometimes share a rapacity that would please the greediest of 19th-century carpet-baggers.There are also good performances by Jeff Bridges as the oddball scion of landed Birmingham gentry, by Sally Field as his something-less-than blueblood mistress and by Arnold Schwarzenegger as a Mr. Universe contestant, a nice, honorable young man who appears to be trapped inside a huge, grotesquely muscled body that has no relation to the conventional head on top of it.The film, which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and the 86th Street East Theaters, was written by Mr. Rafelson and Charles Gaines, who also wrote the original novel and who, according to the program notes, was ready to make any changes in the novel that Mr. Rafelson wanted. "Frankly," Mr. Gaines is reported to have said, "I just wanted to write a screenplay."Mr. Rafelson is quoted as saying: "It was more than just adapting a novel to the screen. It meant restructuring the script, bringing new characters to life. [Mr. Gaines's] creative juices flowed as though it was a new project and the whole experience was exhilarating."This, I fear, is just what's wrong with "Stay Hungry." Mr. Gaines was ready to jettison a lot of his novel, on which, I assume, he had worked long and hard, in order to make a movie, any movie, while Mr. Rafelson ran around keping those old creative juices flowing, instead of turning off the taps once in a while. The experience may have been exhilarating for the two of them, but for us it's all clutter.It is the sort of movie whose vapidity is exposed as soon as the clutter is removed. "Stay Hungry" is essentially a story about a rich kid who betrays his class by playing with the poor kids down the block. However, the consequences aren't especially dire, and we never do understand why he does it, or why he is so fascinated by the society of body builders, whose gym is on the downtown Birmingham property coveted by his erstwhile business associates."Stay Hungry" has the air of a story repeated by someone who has forgotten the point he set out to make. Which may be one of the dangers in bringing new characters to life and letting creative juices flow at random.The film isn't about very much, but the clutter does keep our attention, such as a sequence in which Mr. Schwarzenegger and Mr. Bridges participate in a real down-home fiddling contest, and another in which Helena Kallianiotes (the manic hitchhiker in "Five Easy Pieces") discusses a dentist who keeps his freezer full of doves. R. G. Armstrong creates a wierd, memorable character as the owner of the body builders' gym, an aging body builder himself who sees his potency fading away with his hair.The movie apparently means to respect these body builders, and as long as Mr. Schwarzenegger keeps his clothes on, it does. However, when the camera, at the end of the film, roams over physiques so carefully and lovingly exaggerated they seem about to burst, you suspect the movie of being a freak show that couldn't care less about its freaks.

title: Bergman, on Coast, Says He'll See De Laarentiis
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25The Swedish film director Ingmar Bergman, beset by tax problems, arrived here today and announced that he would meet with Dino De Laurentiis tomorrow to discuss new films.

title: End of a Dream
description: The projected 40 percent drop in the number of freshmen who will enter the City University's senior colleges in September is more than a matter of academic statistics. Together with the lesser, but still substantial, decline in the anticipated admissions to the community colleges, this drastic shrinkage represents the end a dream.

title: ST. JAMES'
description: The Very Rev. Hays Hamilton Rockwell, dean of Bexley Hall, the Episcopal member of a cluster of seminaries in Rochester, will become rector of St. James Episcopal Church at 71st Street and Madison Avenue in New York City.

title: Service Honors Dead of Holocaust and Warsaw Ghetto
description: The candles glowed on the altar of Temple EmanuEl yesterday and the El Mole Rachamimthe Hebrew prayer for the deadechoed in the sanctuary, in remembrance of those who died in the Nazi holocaust and in the Warsaw Ghetto uprising 33 years ago.

title: 5,000 Hail Mighty Ramp
description: COSBY, Tenn., April 25 (UPI) The rites of the ramp, the onionlike mountain weed noted for its mighty reek, where celebrated today when 5,000 persons showed up to picnic and listen to gospel and country Music. The Cosby Ramp Festival, a salute to the mountain delicacy, is held each year.

title: Center for Times Sq.
description: Citing the area's rich mixture of theaters, restaurants and hotels, the Regional Plan Association yesterday proposed the Times Square area as the site of the city's planned convention center. Details are on page 42.

title: Pennsylvania Politicians Are Trying to Detach Local Contests From the Presidential Primary
description: PITTSBURGH, April 25 Pennsylvania is one of a dwindling number of states where the Presidential primaries coincide with Congressional and legislative primarles and contests for party posts, a local connection that, in one view, roots the Presidential competition in the real world or, in another view, distorts the national contest with local issues and power games.

title: Rumsfeld Asserts Defense Is Adequate for Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that American military capability was adequate to do the Job today and that what was important Is future capability.

title: WALL ST. DIVIDED ON FED'S ACTIONS
description: The Federal Reserve's actions in the credit markets last Thursday and Friday divided Wall Street into two unarmed camps. One concluded that the central bank had decided to push interest rates higher, while the other contended, with equal conviction, that the money managers on Liberty Street had done no such thing.

title: Rain Postpones Miss Guthrie's Debut
description: TRENTON, April 25Outside, it was raining and Janet Guthrie kept looking at her watch, waiting for the inevitable decision by United States Auto Club officials to postpone the Trentonian 200 and her debut in an Indianapolistype racing car until next Sunday.

title: Shortfall of $500 Million Is Feared in Beame's Plan
description: New York City's current austerity plan eventually may have to be bolstered by as much as $500 million in additional financing, according to key officials involved in the task of restoring balance to the city's fiscal affairs.

title: The Opera
description: Maralin Niska did a full evening's work Saturday night with the New York City Opera when she sang the leading soprano roles in both Pagliacci and Cavalleria Rusticana.

title: Wayne Harris Marries Laurie Carlin
description: Laurie Ellen Carlin, a specialeducation teacher, and Wayne Ira Harris, who is with the New York office of Employers Insurance of Wausau, a Wisconsinbased insurance company, were married yesterday evening in Temple Sholom in Lawrence, L. I. Rabbi Robert Rabb performed the ceremony.

title: BLACK DEMOCRATS OPPOSE MOYNIHAN
description: Reacting to reports that Daniel Patrick Moynihan, former United States representative to the United Nations, has begun sounding out New York politicians about his chances of seeking the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, the Council of Black Elected Democrats has written to Governor Carey reiterating its stand that Mr. Moynihan was unacceptable.

title: Byrne Wants No Cuts In Antipollution Budget
description: TRENTON, April 25 (UPO Governor Byrne urged the Legislature this weekend not to approve a proposal to cut $1 million from the state air pollution control program.

title: PekingCape Verde Ties
description: PEKING, April 25 (Agence FrancePresse)China and the Cape Verde Islands today established diplomatic relations at the ambassadorial level, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported here.

title: Braves Beat Celtics, 98 to 93
description: Ernie DiGregorio, Buffalo Braves highpriced benchwarmer, cries out for playing time, something Jack Ramsay, the coach, had been reluctant to give him. DeGregorio moves the Braves offensively, but his lack of height makes him a liability on defense.

title: No Tickets for Honeymooners
description: Two days before the big game, Bob Cahill, ticket manager at Notre Dame, had a call from a doctor who was an alumnus. You won't believe this, the caller said, but my kids made a bonfire of my two tickets on the kitchen floor. I've got the ashes.

title: Nichols Puts On Show Starring His Arabian Horses
description: BRIDGEWATER, Conn., April 24It was like a Greek statue suddenly taking life; the horse bursting from the barn, neck arched, nostrils flaring, veins standing out beneath the satin coat.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: VOTE OUTLAY CUT IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25The three active Democratic candidates in the crucial Pennsylvania primary, taken together, will spend less than half the limit the new campaign law imposes on a single candidate running in the state.

title: Suffolk Legislature Asked To Monitor Sewer Work
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., April 25The chairman of the Suffolk Legislature Finance Committee proposed today that all engineering contracts for future sewer work be reviewed and approved by the County Legislature and that the Legislature monitor the spending and procedures of the controversial $700 million Southwest Sewer District project.

title: Part of Copter That Fell Into Gulf found by Divers
description: CAMERON, La., April 25 (AP)Part of a helicopter that crashed into the sea near here last week, killng 12 offshore oil workers, was recovered today by divers and a salvage boat.

title: NED BROWN DEAD; WRITER ON BOXING
description: Ned Brown, a boxing writer for many years and the biographer and ghost writer for Jack Dempsey, the former heavyweight champion, died last Sunday in a Los Angeles nursing home. His age was said to be about 94.

title: Congressmen, Talking to Voters, Hear Complaints on Government
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Some members of Congress, accustomed to hearing complaints about the economy and energy from their constituents, have encountered a strong antiGovernment sentiment in visits with the voters back home during the Congressional Easter recess.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We had the pleasure a short while ago to visit Charlottesville, Va., primarily to renew our acquaintanceship with Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's home. During the course of our stay in the town we were taken to dine at a restaurant that bears the unlikely name, C. & O., a name that will have a nostalgic ring for railroad buffs.

title: Jan Stephenson Winner By 4 Shots on a 68203
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 25 (UPI)  Australia's Jan Stephenson ignored gusty winds today and charged from four strokes behind Kathy Martin to win the $40,000 Birmingham Golf Classic.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 26, 1976

title: Connors Tops Case In Final
description: DENVER, April 25 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors, always the aggressor, vanquished Ross Case of Australia, 76, 62, and won the $65,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Hanoi General Was Surprised At Speed of Saigon's Collapse
description: HONG KONG, April 25North Vietnam's leaders did not expect their offensive last year to achieve complete victory and were surprised by the speed of Saigon's collapse, according to a lengthy new account by Hanoi's Chief of Staff of the war's final battles.

title: Argento's Poe, a Rich Opera, Is Staged in St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL, April 25The Voyage of Edgar Allan Poe, a new opera by Dominick Argento, had its premiere in the I. A. O'Shaughnessy Auditorium of the College of St. Catherine here last night. The composer is well known for two of his earlier operas, The Masque of Angels and Postcard From Morocco, and for his recent song cycle, From the Diary of Virginia Woolf, which earned him the Pulitzer Prize in 1975. There were high hopes for his latest opera, which the University of Minnesota commissioned and for which it gave the composer a leave of absence from his teaching duties there to work on. The hopes were largely justified. It is a rich, mature and substantial creation.

title: DAVID FRIEDLAND, COUNCILMAN, DIES
description: David B. Friedland, a member of the City Council from the Washington Heights  Inwood district of northern Manhattan since 1965, died Saturday in a nursing home in Westwood, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived at 615 West 172d Street.

title: Jamestown Welcomes Gustav, Despite Rain
description: JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 25 (UPI)  King Carl XVI Gustav of Sweden arrived here today after a brief stop at Bradford, Pa., where his plane was forced to land because of bad weather.

title: Doctors Strong, Patients Weak, Costs Up
