description: WASHINGTON, April 25A monopolylike control by physicians of medical services and a frequently passive role by patients in purchasing medical care are helping to push health care costs up at record speed, the President's Council on Wage and Price Stability said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: New York City Cuts Its Welfare Costs
description: New welfare management systems to speed the closing of cases and the redaction of grants will reduce welfare costs in New York City $24 million in the year ending June 30 and will save $57 million in the next fiscal year, Human Resources Administrator J. Henry Smith announced yesterday.

title: Rex by Rodgers Stars Williamson
description: Richard Rodgers is a great man who has done the American musical theater some service. But even Othello went wrong, and even Homer nodded. Mr. Rodgers's new musical, Rex, which opened, or at least began, at the LuntFontanne Theater last night, has almost everything not going for it.

title: Ballet
description: A soldout house turned out Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House when Anthony Dowell and Natalia Makarova stepped into the leading roles of the Royal Ballet's production of Swan Lake.

title: Ohio AllStars Win
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 25 (AP)  A Toledo University guard, Larry Cole, scored 24 points today to lead the Ohio College AllStars to a 9883 victory over the Indiana AllStars in the seventh Annual OhioIndiana AllStar Basketball Classic.

title: Two Rivals Attack Carter On Labor and Black Issues
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Senator Henry M. Jackson, Representative Morris K. Udall and their political allies today attacked Jimmy Carter, their rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as being unsympathetic to organized labor and blacks.

title: 60 Volunteers a Week Aid Retarded Boy
description: When Solomon Izenzon was 2 years old, he could not speak, he could not recognize his parents, he could barely see shadows and he could hear only chaotic noises.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Penneylvania senatorial race in The New York Times on Saturday said that a variety, of polls showed Representative H. John Heinz 3d and Arlen Specter a few percentage points behind George Packard in the Republican primary. The polls showed Mr. Heinz and Mr. Specter leading, with Mr. Packard trailing by a few percentage points.

title: IDAHO PLAN OPPOSED ON PHOSPHATE MINES
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)  Proposals to increase dramatically the mining of Federal phosphate deposits in southeastern Idaho would reduce air and water quality and cut down the area's recreation resources, according to a draft environmental impact statement released today.

title: Princess Anne, Unsteady, Leaves Hospital in London
description: LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) Princess Anne of Britain, looking pale and slightly unsteady, was discharged tonight from a London hospital where she had spent four days recovering from a horseriding accident.

title: Steamy Dressing Room
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (UPI)  Danny Ozark, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, had to be physically restrained from throwing a punch at a sports writer today following the team's 32 loss to the Atlanta Braves. The club's vice president, Bill Giles, apologized on behalf of the Phillies when the writers protested the incident, which included Ozark ordering all the writers from the dressing room.

title: Gullett Makes Belated First Start a Victory for Reds,70
description: Seventeen days after the Cincinnati Reds opened the National League baseball season, Don Gullett finally made his first start of the season yesterday. The ace of the Red's staff pitched six scoreless innings, giving up only five hits, as Cincinnati topped the Expos, 70, In Montreal.

title: Portugal's Parties Shun Discord
description: LISBON, April 25  The parties on either side of Portugal's political spectrum. steered clear of each other's strongholds today as Portuguese elected a Parliament. They didn't even bother to send poll watchers to preserves on the opposite side.

title: Bridge:Weichsel's Team Leader In L. I. Regional Tourney
description: A powerful New York City team held a substantial lead going into the final section of the Long Island Regional knockout team championship at Belmont Park last night.

title: ExConvict in Rampage Kills 3 And Wounds 14 Before Suicide
description: JACKSON, Ga., April 25 (UPI) A former convict shot and killed three persons and wounded 14 others in a ninehour rampage that ended today when he killed himself.

title: Horse Show Results
description: THE HIGHLAND AT JERICHO, L.I.

title: Books of The Times
description: The people of the City of New York paid $150,000 to a management consulting firm in the late 1960's for a glossy, 75page transportation study of the Bronx that included detailed descriptions of the history and topography of the Bronx and concluded that whether one was in Riverdale or on Mosholu Parkway, traffic tended to move toward Manhattan in the morning and away from Manhattan by nightfall.

title: GISCARD MEETING LEFT'S CHALLENGE!
description: PARIS, April 25Declaring that the choice for France lies between reform and upheaval, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing is pressing ahead with plans to increase worker rights in industry and to spread the tax burden more equitably, despite skepticism and even open hostility expressed by the political left and right.

title: ExCol. Yefim Davydovich, Soviet Dissident Jew, Dies
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (Reuters) Yefim Davydovich, a former Red Army colonel and one of the most noted Soviet Jews denied permission to emigrate to Israel, died yesterday of heart attack at his home in Minsk, capital of Soviet Byelorussia, Jewish sources said today. He was 54 years old.

title: Bishop Consecrated
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 25 (AP)  Archdeacon James Barrow Brown of New Orleans has been consecrated to the office of Episcopal Bishop of Louisiana. About 3,000 people crowded the Louisiana State University Assembly center, where the ceremony was held. The Bishopelect, who succeeds Bishop Iveson B. Noland, will be installed as the ninth Bishop of Louisiana May 27 in New Orleans.

title: Candidates Find Time to Visit 6Hour Radio Talk Show
description: PITTSBURGH, April 23Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington dropped in on Roy Fox this evening for 45 minutes. Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia spent an hour with him on Wednesday. Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama spent an hour that night with Mr. Fox's neighbor. John Cigna. And Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona would have done the same yesterday if his plane had not been delayed.

title: Kentucky Mine Explosions To Be Studied by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) Two committee chairmen said today that Congress would conduct its own investigation of the Scotia coal mine explosions that killed 26 men, even though the Department of the Interior is already investigating the disaster.

title: Music: Brooklyn Strings End Season
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music ended its third season of Saturday eveningSunday afternoon chamber concerts yesterday with a charming MozartLeon KirchnerMozart program. The participants were Scott Nickrenz, the violist who directed the series for the last two years; Donald Weilersteln, the first violinist of the Cleveland Quartet; Laurence Lesser, a cellist who, like Mr. Nickrenz, teaches at the New England Conservatory of Music, and Mr. Kirchner, who besides being a composer, is a pianist of sensitive musical gifts, if not the most refined technical finesse.

title: Allon Cancels Trip to U.S. For Talks on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, April 25 (UPI) Foreign Minister Yigal Alton has postponed plans to visit the United States next week, saying that he was needed in Israel for talks on Jewish settlements in the West Bank area. Mr. AlIon had planned to meet Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and address American Zionist groups during his trio.

title: Jones Enjoys His Revenge As Nets Eliminate Spurs
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: One Critic Falls Asleep; It's Composer's Dream
description: Ever gone to a concert you had really looked forward to and then fallen asleep? Perhaps you'd had a good dinner and some wine, or perhaps you'd had too little sleep the previous night or a strenuous day.

title: Research on Blacks by Two Groups on the Wane as Funds Shrivel
description: The Metropolitan Applied Research Center, a major black research organization founded nine years ago to serve as an advocate for the urban poor, is closing July 1, a victim partly of declining resources in a tight economy.

title: Stenotype Finalists Unfazed By 220 to 280 wordsaminute
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 25The keyboard postures ranged from Vladimir Horowitz to Victor Borge and the nimble fingers beat a silent tatoo to the tobaccoauctioneer delivery of a reader.

title: BOY HELD IN KILLING OF A MISSION PRIEST
description: The Rev. David Sanford Duncombe, administrator of St. Michael's Episcopal Mission to the Northern Arapahoe Indian Tribe and vicar of the church in Ethete, Wyo., was stabbed to death early Saturday on the Wind River Indian Reservation in Wyoming.

title: C is for Country, A is for Anniversary, S is for Solicitude, H is for History
description: A citizen of the Sick Man of Europe, I creep around the campuses, receiving the condolences of my hosts.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON. April 26The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Tower,Goldwater, Refuse To Sign Panel's Report
description: Two Republican members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities refused yesterday to sign the panel's final report on foreign and military intelligence activities.

title: SWAN E. BERGSTROM
description: CINCINNATI, April 26Swan E. Bergstrom, a past president of the National Machine Tool Buildings Association and former board chairman of the Cincinnati Milacron Company (formerly the Cincinnati Milling Machine Company), died yesterday in Naples, Fla.

title: Male Workers'
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)Although women have made substantial gains in terms of life expectancy, education and employment since the turn of the century, the income gap between men and women continues to widen, the Government said today.

title: TIGHT RACE ENDS IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 The Pennsylvania primary campaign, once widely regarded as blandly inconsequential, finished its hectic course today as the most critical contest so far in the 1976 Democratic Presidential contest.

title: Yonkers Raceway Entries
description: Horses listed In order of post positions letter designates OTB listing

title: Cousin Says Hughes Sent a Will To Bank in 38, but It's Missing
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26A cousin of the late Howard R. Hughes asserted today that he had found evidence that Mr. Hughes prepared a will in 1938, but said a worldwide search has failed so far to locate it.

title: Advertising
description: As a result of an intensive sales meeting called last November by Jack Yogrnan, its president, Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the country's largest distiller, will be changing the advertising emphasis on some of its many brands.

title: Media Men Give Message to Foreigners
description: The executives of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising met yesterday, with nine journalists, cinematographers and artists from abroad to explain why the relationship between the mediurn and the message is so important in the United States.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a chart in The Times last Friday that accompanied reports on a national poll conducted in April by The Times and CBS News, a number was recorded incorrectly. Among the Democrats interviewed, those aged 18 to 29 constituted 25 percent of the sample, not 35 percent.

title: Students of Heidelberg Turn From Rebellion
description: HEIDELBERG. West GermanyChurch bells still toll each quarter hour from Gothic towers throughout thiq picturepostcard town, complete with gabled houses on narrow streets and castle ruins on a hill. The swans still float serenely on the Neckar River, undisturbed by the rowers of the university team.

title: House Democrats Battle to Keep Seats Won in 1974
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 22Since taking office just over 15 months ago, Representative Floyd J. Fithian, a freshman Democrat, has held 170 town meetings for talking and listening to constituents in his sprawling, largely rural district here in northwestern Indiana.

title: U.S. Aide Expected To Lead Food Body
description: Robert O. Aders, Under Secretary of Labor, is expected shortly to be elected president and chief executive officer of the soontobe merged National Association of Food Chains and the Super Market Institute.

title: New York G.O.P. Delegation Is Called Uncommitted
description: ALBANY, April 26Richard M. Rosenbaum, who was reelected today as Republican state chairman, declared in the strongest terms to date that the New York delegation to the Republican national convention was truly uncommitted and not, as some observers have suggested, uncommitted for President Ford.

title: People in Sports
description: Glorgio Chlnaglia, a 29yearold Italian soccer star, arrived from Rome yesterday and was met by Clive Toye, the president of the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: In fact, the Governor has requested a 25 percent increase in the college's 1974 statesupplied budget of $400,000, and the school has widened its horizons by becoming the nation's first college to offer ballet students an opportunity to participate in a major degree program.

title: Southern Bell Debentures Drop 2 Points in Secondary Market
description: Predictions that new tripleA corporate bonds would yield less than. 8 percent evaporated yesterday as the Southern Bell Telephone Company debentures that were offered originally last Tuesday sank in price after they were permitted to trade In the secondary market. The issue dropped 2 points, raising their yield to 8.47 percent from 8.29 percent. This move in the corporate bond market  the equivalent to a 20point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in the stock market  was the most pronounced action in the credit markets yesterday.

title: Mrs. Ford to Be Honored
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Betty Ford will be honored at Central High School in Grand Rapids, Mich., where she was graduated in 1936. She will attend the high school commencement June 7 and receive distinguished alumna award, Shelia Rabb Weidenfeld, her press secretary, said today.

title: DROPS CONTINUE IN POUND AND LIRA
description: LONDON, April 26 (UPI)The British pound fell again today despite Bank of England and Government efforts to buoy it. The Italian lira, weakened by Italy's political and economic situation, dropped almost onehalf of one percent.

title: RAVE SHANKAR BACK WITH RAGA PROGRAM
description: Ravi Shankar's impact on American music making has probably been more profound in the last decade than that of any other nonWestern musician. As the first Indian concert artist to attract a really substantial audience here, he both spearheaded and benefited from the discovery of things Eastern that characterized the sixties.

title: $1.1 Million Won for Shoplifting Arrest
description: Laureen Bernstein, a 2.1yearold former hank telIer, has been awarded $1.1 million in damages as a result of her wrongful detention on charges of shoplifting by a Korvette store.

title: Bargaining In the Sunshine
description: When State Attorney General Lefkowitz protested last week that he could not pass on the legality of cotofliving increases for New York City transit employees without knowMg the specifics of their new wage agreement, he Was echoing a frustration often expressed by watchdogs of the public purse seeking to learn wha,t obligations the city had saddled itself with at the bargaining table.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 26 Spectators attending sessions of the State Legislature will hereafter be screened.

title: STRIKE IS AVERTED AT NURSING HOMES
description: An agreement to pay nursing home workers back wages and raise their salaries to contractmandated levels has averted a threatened strike, a gubernatorial task force announced last night.

title: A Ride in the Country, But Not for the Scenery
description: Soggy Sunday. Sleepy Sunday.

title: 2 Nursing Homes in State And 2 Hospitals Draw Fines
description: ALBANY, April 26 (UPI) Two nursing homes and two hospitals have been fined for violations the Health Commissioner, Dr. Robert P. Whalen, said today.

title: Literary Magazines, Films and Plays Thrive Amid the Squalor of Calcutta
description: CALCUTTA, India, March 27  In a dim and cluttered garret apartment, three young essayists thrash out the wording of an article on the imagery in Christopher Marlowe's lesser plays. In a busy Arts coffeehouse nearAbroad by, a middleaged billing clerk who, when asked his occupation replies poet, is fretting over a long critique of his poems, published by a friend who last month published the poems themselves. A few tables away, the editor of another review with a circulation of 350 solemnly declares.

title: Egypt Plans Reforms
description: CAIRO, April 26  Egypt plans a major reform of its currency system that Western bankers hail as a breakthrough in the country's dealings with the international financial community.

title: Voting Panel Unable to Investigate Illegal Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Federal Election Commission, barred by court order from providing subsidies for primary elections, has also lost a less publicized but important powerthe pursuit of complaints of illegal campaign activities.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Government witness in the murder trial of a reputed Canadian mobster was sentenced on separate charges five years in jail by a Federal judge who refused to hold the proceedings behind closed doors. Judge Herbert J. Stern in Federal District Court in Newark imposed the sentence on Joseph Rodriguez, 35 years old, of Newark, after he pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the interstate transportation of stolen goods. Mr. Rodriguez, who has been in Federal protective custody, testified recently in the trial of Donald Cote, 43, reputed to be an organized crime figure in Montreal. Mr. Cote is charged with the murder of two drug pushers who he believed were responsible for the murders of his wife and 5yearold child at their Montreal farmhouse.

title: TV: La Traviata and Baby Doe
description: Suddenly opera seems to  have returned to public televisionopera live and studiorecorded, opera domestic  and imported. Last Wednes day, Live From Lincoln Center carried Ballad of Baby Doe from the stage of Lincoln Center's State Theater. Tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, the sumptuous prod uct is Verdi's La Traviata, a 1973 production of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: On Resignation
description: Charles Morgan Jr. moved out of his office at the Washington headquarters of the American Civil Liberties Union last week, and it's hard to know whether the rest of us are better or worse off as a result. The A.C.L.U.'s Washington director since 1972, and its Southern regional director for eight years before that, Mr. Morgan became one of the few public figures of the time to resign an advantageous and useful position on a matter of principle.

title: HEADMASTER'S DAY MARRED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, April 26  The Federal Courtappointed headmaster of South Boston High School had a difficult first day of classes today as the city's schools reopened after Easter vacation in a tense week marked by incidents of racial violence.

title: $200,000 Mixed Doubles Golf Scheduled
description: A $200,000 mixed doubles golf championship, an event Involving men and women contestants, will be held Dec. 1719 at the Doral Country Club in Miami. The tournament, in which the winning partners will split $40,000, was announced yesterday by Ray Volpe, the commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association. This is the first major tournament in which women and men have played u partners since 1966, said Volpe. Women pros will invite men. golfers to compete in the 54hole event. A celebrity proamateur tournament will precede the championship on Dec. 15 and 16.

title: Geisel Begins Paris Visit
description: PARIS, April 26 (Reuters)President Ernesto Geisel of Brazil arrived here today for a threeday official visit.

title: Browns Waive Pair
description: CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) The Cleveland Browns an. nounced today that Ken Brown, a running back, and Jack LeVeck, a linebacker, had cleared National Football League waivers and had become free agents.

title: CARL BOYER DIES; A MATHEMATICIAN
description: Dr. Carl B. Boyer, professor and historian of mathematics at Brooklyn College, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 997 East 19th Street, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: EXTREMELY FUNNY! Barn??, Times

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times editorial of April 21, Pension Ripoff, is distressing to every fire officer. It is most unfortunate that criticism was leveled at a muchneeded benefit for the man who daily lays down his life for his fellow citizens.

title: Increase Continues In Copper Futures; Coffee Also Gains
description: Speculators flocked to buy copper futures yesterday much to the surprise of some leading metals analysts, who said they were bewildered by the sudden interest. Buying involved 7,869 contracts on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

title: Democrats Reply to Nadjari Subpoena
description: The New York County Democratic committee agreed yesterday to turn over its records for the last five years to a grand jury that was under the direction of Maurice H, Nadjari, provided that the special state prosecutor received judicial approval before questioning individuals named in the files.

title: C.I.A. Secretly Owned Insurance Complex and Invested Profits in Stock Market
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Central Intelligence Agency secretly owned a complex of insurance companies whose profits were for years successfully invested in private securities, according to the final report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities.

title: LISBON SOCIALIST BARS A COALITION
description: LISBON, April 26Portugal's Socialist leader, Mario Soares, said tonight that his party stood ready to form a minority government if called upon as result of its strong showing in parliamentary elections yesterday.

title: Report Says C.I.A. Agents Picked Up Bar Patrons for L.S.D. Experiments
description: For nine years, beginning in 1954, employees of the Central intelligence Agency randomly picked up unsuspecting patrons in bars in the United States and slipped LSD into their food and drink, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities disclosed in its final report, released yesterday.

title: Labor Campaign to Stop Carter Seems Ineffective
description: JEANNETTE, Pa.. April 26The vaunted stopCarter effort mounted by orgnized labor and the Democratic organization for tomorrow's Pennsylvania primary is nowhere to be seen in Westmoreland County, which has the state's third largest concentrations of Democrats.

title: Forests and Woodlands To Be Reopened Today
description: TRENTON, April 26Governor Byrne issued today proclamation reopening as of noon tomorrow the state's forests and woodlands of South and Central Jersey, which had been closed to the public since Saturday because forest fires.

title: STEEL PRODUCER TO RAISE PRICES ABOUT 8% JUNE 1
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth largest steel maker, took the lead yesterday in announcing a longexpected increase in prices for flatrolled steel. The increase of almost 8 percent on some products, which is effective June 1, is part of a general movement of higher metals prices that has gathered force in the last few weeks.

title: Prospects Fade for Big Changes In New York RentControl Laws
description: Although an Assembly committee held a hearing on the subject yesterday, the prospect that the New York Legislature will make major changes in the controversial state and city rent control programs has dwindled sharply in the current session, key legislative aids lay.

title: RONALD VAN DERWENDE
description: Ronald J. Vanderwende, who retired In 1962 as a vice president and general manager of the Hoboken division of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, died yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived at 114 Arcadia Road, Allendale, N.J.

title: Connecticut Democrats Will Pick Primary Delegate Slates Tonight
description: HARTFORD, April 26With Democratic caucuses looming in all 169 towns in Connecticut tomorrow night, party workers around the state were working today to complete the slates of delegates corn. mittedtothe six candidates left in the stac's Presidenial voing on Mav 11.

title: Irrational Primaries
description: Granted the lofty motives that originally inspired the Presidential primaries, they have degenerated into thirtystate obstacle course, tempered only by the individual candidate's freedom to pick and choose which obstacles he will try, depending on the primary rules the respective states and his own local appeal. The voter turnouts are generally low and the interpretations of the outcome are accordingly misleadingoften with serious psychological impact on the campaign.

title: H.E.W. Rights Chief Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, F. David Mathews, today named Martin H. Gerry, 33yearold lawyer, as the department's new civil rights chief. Mr. Gerry had been rights acting director since last Nov. 28.

title: Legislators Return Today To Fragile Unity in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 26  The State Legislature will return from its EasterPassover recess tomorrow to face the prospect of its fragile unity, forged by the state's budget crisis and badly strained by the centrifugal forces of partisanship and regional selfinterest.

title: GROUP BACKS RULING ON PUBLIC HOUSING
description: CMICAGO, April 26 (UPI) A group of prominent urban scholars has formed a national coalition to implement a recent Supreme Court decision extending public housing to suburban areas.

title: STANLEY G. LEE
description: Stanley G. Lee, a partner since 1969 in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Neuberger & Berman, 522 Fifth Avenue, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: Helstoski Gains Support Of Three Hudson Leaders
description: NORTH BERGEN, April 26Representative Henry Helstoski won the support today of Democratic leaders from three Hudson County communities in his bid for reelection.

title: Wider Congress Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, like the actions taken by President Ford several months ago, seek to strengthen the role of the President News and the Director Analysis of Central Intelligence in control. ling covert operations and the hands of enforcement authorities in dealing with violations of the law.

title: Concern Voiced Over Social Security Terminations
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  Social Security Commissioner James B. Cardwell expressed concern about the effects of terminating coverage for government workers but made no recommendations as Congress began hearings today on Social Security coverage.

title: People and Bustness
description: Michael Chetkovich, managing partner of Haskins & Sells, the accounting firm, called yesterday fr the development of a new international organization for coordinating worldwide professional accounting standards.

title: CambodiaBurma Ties
description: HONG KONG, April 26 (UPI) Cambodia and Burma have established diplomatic relations, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today. The agency, quoting a communique broadcast by Cambodian radio, said the governments had agreed over the weekend to set up relations at the ambassadorial level.

title: The Calandra Charade
description: Mavor beam ts on solid ground in rejecting a subpoena from a State Senate subcommittee to testify on a bill that would attempt to dictate to the city the amount of money it must spond on police and fire protection. The Mayor already has granted the subcommittee all of the cooperation it could reasonably expect by agreeing to send his fire and police commissioners as well as thc Directors of the Budget and Personnel to testify on the city's behalf.

title: Fiscal Malaise
description: New York's fiscal experts are expressing growing concern about the soundness of the city's latest plan for balancing its budget by the end of fiscal 1978. Their doubts are not surprising. The plan is based on some dubious assumptions about the city's ability to cut costs, to win new Federal and state assistance and to milk revenues from a local economy that continues to falter despite evidence of a national recovery.

title: EAST AND WEST MEET IN A DANCE
description: Saeko Ichinohe has continually sought a common meeting ground for traditional Japanese dance and the Western balletic and moderndance forms. She has studied each, and her programs reflect the range of her interests.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a chart in The Times last Friday that accompanied reports on a national poll conducted in April by The Times and CBS News, a number was recorded Incorrectly. Among the Democrats interviewed, those aged IS to 29 constituted 25 percent of the sample, not 35 percent.

title: Bridge
description: Winning, and losing, by nose is a not uncommon event at the Belmont race traCk. but until this weekend no horse has been involved in four such finishes within three days.

title: Mist Drifts Over The Cherry Orchard
Blackbag Jobs Among Spy Terms Defined in Report
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (Reuters)  The final report of the Senate Intelligence Committee released today includes a glossary of intelligence terms that gives a glimpse into the world of blackbag jobs and sheepdipping.

title: Schmidt Hits 2 Homers to Equal Record, Fans to Win 109 Game
description: Mike Schmidt is so hot that even when he strikes out he wins a game.

title: Ford Said to Agree to Consider $375 Million Aid Plan for Israel
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 President Ford, who earlier had threatened to, veto efforts to increase foreign aid for Israel this year, has reportedly agreed to consider a compromise plan to allow Israel an additional $375 million in military credits.

title: Concert: Organ Recital
description: David Craighead presented a varied program of organ works Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, but its sum did not equal the parts. The program included, from the 17th century, Samuel Scheidt's pleasant variations on Warum betrithst du dich, mein Hertz, from he 18th, the Bach Sonata No. 4 in E minor and the Mozart. Fantasy (K. 608), and four works from the 20th century.

title: Lockheed Nears Loan Pact To Finance Sale to Canada
description: OTTAWA, April 26 (Reuters) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has almost reached agreement with a consortium of banks for a $300 million loan to finance the early stages of Canada's purchase of 18 Orion patrol planes, Defense Minister James Richardson said today.

title: MARGARETMOORE,83, SURVIVOR OF TITANIC
description: Margaret Graham Moore of Greenwich, Conn., a passenger on the Titanic when the ship sank on her maiden voyage in April 1912, died in Greenwich Hospital yesterday. She was 83 years old.

title: KANSAS GOVERNOR SEES A WHEAT LAG
description: MADRID, April 26  Gov. Robert F. Bennett of Kansas warned here today that current low wheat prices may cause drop in American production and, consequently, in the world's food supplies.

title: 15MONTH INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Senate Select Committee or Intelligence Activities, concluding its 15monthlong investigation, today urged Congress to adopt a new, omnibus law covering foreign and militaty intelligence gathering that would create charters for the major agencies and sharply limit the use of covert action as a tool of foreign policy.

title: Transit Union Says Law Allows LivingCost Raise
description: The Transport Workers Union contended yesterday that its new contract with the Transit Authority included a deferral agreement and therefore met the requirements of state law for receiving a costofliving increase.

title: Bergen Program to Fight Child Abuse
description: HACKENSACK, April 26A new Bergen County program for combating child abuse and neglect at the family level was announced jointly today by the State Department of Institutions and Agencies and the County Board of Chosen Freeholders.

title: Recovery Abroad
description: West Europe's economic recovery, which had been lagging behind the cautious upturn in the United States, evidently is beginning to lag less. In the last few weeks, the indicators of growth in virtually all countries have begun to turn more definitely in the same direction: up. This is true in Japan as well, with the result that the industrial world as a whole, despite the currency difficulties of some countries, should now be able to look ahead to rising trade and mutually reinforcing expansion.

title: I.B.M. Discloses $53,000 Payments Made by Employees
description: PHOENIX, April 26The International Business Machines Corporation said today that its employees had made four questionable payments totaling $53,000 in the last seven years.

title: Inmate Loses in Voting For Concord Selectman
description: CONCORD, Mass, April 26 (AP)When unofficial returns tonight gave him only 500 votes from residents outside Concord state prison, Carl Velleca, an inmate, conceded that he had lost his race for town selectman.

title: Business Briefs
description: Steel Production at 1976 Peak

title: Rhodesia Imposes Censorship In Move to Combat Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 26 (Reuters)The Rhodesian Government today announced immediate censorship of the press, radio and television to combat what it said were intense psychological pressures directed against the country.

title: Court Orders New York To Effect CleanAir Plan
description: The city and state must put into effect a major clean air plan that includes imposing tolls on East River and Harlem River bridges and banning taxis from cruising on long stretches of several midtown streets, a Federal appeals court ruled here yesterday.

title: 40 Soldiers Reported Killed By Rebels in the Philippines
description: MANILA, April 26 (Reuters) At least 40 soldiers have been killed in skirmishes with Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines in the last month, military sources said today.

title: PAUL KIRK GILES
description: Paul Kirk Giles, an actor, died Friday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Katherine Ward Is Dead; City's Oldest Woman, 108
description: Katherine Bree Ward, who was recently notified by the Social Security Administration that records showed her to be the oldest woman in New York City, died Saturday at the age of 108 in the Mary Manning Walsh Home.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 27, 1976

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Columbia has awarded the Eisenhower Watch, presented annually to the athlete achieving the highest academic average over two semesters, to Andrew Sama.

title: MISS HEARST MOVED TO FEDERAL PRISON
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26Patricia Hearst, gaining weight and much recovered from a deflated lung, was moved from her Redwood City hospital room today to a Federal prison at Pleasanton, Calif.

title: Scene of Early Courtship Revisited by Mary Beame
description: Mary Beame returned yesterday to the University Settlement at Eldridge and Rivington Streets. It was there that she had become acquainted in the mid1920's with the future Mayor of New Yorkover game of checkers.

title: Wider Congress Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, like the actions taken by President Ford several months ago, seek to strengthen the role of the President and the Director of Central Intelligence in control. ling covert operations and the hands of enforcement authorities in dealing with violations of the law.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Leonard Baskin

title: Fleur Cowles Today: As Creative as Ever
description: Almost everyone said it couldn't be done so of course, Fleur Cowles did itcreated Flair, a beautiful, expensive magazine that died in infanvcy more than two decades ago, but has neer been forgotten. Fleur Cowles has never accepted traditional limitations.

title: Memorial Services
description: ELLENBOGENFrankhm, Jr. In cherished memory of our beloved son and brother who went sway twentythroe years soo. ROGOFFMarion Doyle. A service will be offered at The Holy Family Church, 315 E. 47 St., N.Y.C. on Wednesday, April 21, 1976 at 5 P.M. In memory of Marlon Doyle Rogoff who died on March 27, 1976.

title: Bill Moyers Will Leave PBS to Work on CBS Reports
description: Bill D. Moyers, the former press secretary to President Johnson who in recent years has been a principal journalist for the Public Broadcasting Service, has been hired by CBS News as a correspondent for the monthly documentaries CBS Reports.

title: Court Orders New York To Effect CleanAir Plan
description: The city and state must put into effect a major clean air plan that includes imposing tolls on East River and Harlem River bridges and banning taxis from cruising on long stretches of several midtown streets, a Federal appeals court ruled here yesterday.

title: Fireman Killed at Diner
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP) A suburban Bucks County fireman was killed and two others injured early today in an George Diner and Restaurant in explosion and fire at the St. Levittown. The dead fireman was identified as Garry von Hoffman, 21 years old, of Fairless Hills.

title: Security Check by I.R.S
description: WASHINGTON, April 26In the mid1950's, the Central Intelligence Agency decided to test the security arrangements of Air America, a charter airline service that was secretly a wholly owned operation of the agency.

title: Insiders Again Showing StockOption Enthusiasm
description: About the only interest corporate insidersofficers and directorsare showing in the stock market . these days involves their longdormant stock options.

title: Peer Sought in Murder Reported in Cape Town
description: LONDON, Tuesday, April 27 (AP)Lord Lucan, the British earl sought by Scotland Yard for 17 months on a murder warrant. is living in South Africa, The Daily Mirror reported in today's issue, in a dispatch from Cane Town,

title: Employees Thin Down, Employer Pays Up
description: Jim Miller bought $2,814 worth of fat the other day.

title: Grechko Soviet Defense Chief, Dies at 72
description: MOSCOW, April 26Marshal Andrei Antonovich Grechko, the Soviet Minister of Defense and, for average Russians, the bridge between the celebrated Red Army of World War It and the modern Soviet Army, died today at the age of 72.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS UDALL BALLOT PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)The Supreme Court ruled today against Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona in holding that Indiana's Jaw for qualifying for the May 4 primary does not violate the Constitution.

title: Franklin M. Haines, 87, RealEstate Man, Is Dead
description: Franklin M. Haines, a retired realestate executive who formerly lived at ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., and Fishers Island, L. I., died Sunday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: CAREY URGES A PLAN OF U.S. AID TO REGION
description: Criticizing what he termed inc'oherent national planning without an overall vision,' Governor Carey last night called for a national redirection. , of Federal priorities as the only way to revitalize the ecohomy of the New York region.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RIALTO REVISITED

title: Academy Reopens In Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP)The Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, the oldest art museum and school in the United States, has reopened after a $4.3 million restoration,

title: Coalition for Portugal
description: Portugal's first free parliamentary election in half century proves the feasibility of and the necessity for coalition Government of the democratic forces of center and moderate left. It would generate confidence at home and abroad if the Socialists and the Popular Democrats, who together captured about 60 percent of the votes, would promptly discuss forming such a coalition.

title: Congress Ends Recess and Faces Mass of Legislation
description: WASHINGTON. April 26 Congress returned from an 11clay Easter recess today to grapple with a mass of legislation that may force night and weekend sessions before the July recess for the Democratic National Convention in New York.

title: A Change in Rules Is Drafted to Lift Veil From FamilyCourt Proceedings
description: Draft rules that would open up the longsecret proceedings of Family Court in New York City are being circulated in the state court system. The restrictions, however, would still prohibit publication of names.

title: Queens Republicans Make A Change in Leadership
description: A shift in the leadership of Queens Republicansthe only major change at the top as New York City political parties reorganized after the primary electionwas interpreted by politicians yesterday as a continuation of real control by the county clerk, John J. Durante.

title: Fiscal Commission Urges Repeal of City Estate Tax
description: The immediate repeal of New Ygrk City's estate tax, which] takes effect on Saturday, was urged yesterday by the Ternporary Commission on City Finances.

title: NEW DELHI BALKS ON PRISONER DATA
description: NEW DELHI. April 26The number of political prisoners in India is a constant topic of conversation in New Delhi these days. But no oneexcept perhaps a few highly placed Government officials who are not likely to sayknows the answer.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Biggest in 18 Months
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (Reuters)  The United States recorded Its biggest monthly trade deficit in more than 18 months in March, when imports exceeded exports by more than $650 million, the Commerce Department reported today. This was the third consecutive month in which United States trade accounts were in the red and brought the total deficit for the first quarter of 1976 to more than $864 million.

title: Tuition With State Aid Rise Studied for City University
description: ALBANY, April 26  A plan to require the imposition of tuition at the City University at the levels at the State University beginning this summer, in return for about $45 million in additional state aid, is under consideration by aides to Governor Carey and the Democratic legislative leaders.

title: National League Bars Expansion
description: CHICAGO, April 26The National League again refused to expand today. It voted down a proposal to add Washington and Toronto and increase the league to 14 teams.

title: Ashe Heads 8 In W.C.T. Final
description: With the windup of the World Championship Tennis circuit, the eight players with the best records will meet in Dallas next Tuesday for the $100,000 W.C.T. singles championship. The winner gets $50,000.

title: STATE COURT SAYS RAISE FOR POLICE MUST BE PAID NOW
description: A New York State appellate court ruled yesterday that the city must pay policemen $19.5 million in wage increases that had been postponed until at least 1978 because of the city&s fiscal crisis.

title: Concert: Philadelphia Orchestra
description: Anniversaries are natural and legitimate times for looking back. Faded photos can take on new and sometimes startling meanings and old songs can strike the ear with a painfully potent freshness. This Bicentennial season is providing us with many such opportunities for reappraisal, the Philadelphia Orchestra offering two of them last night at Carnegie Hall.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT OF INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Following are excerpts from the Report on the Foreign and Military Intelligence Activities df the United States, the final report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities. Passages that were changed by the committee at the request of executive agencies appear in italics.

title: Beirut Speaker Meets With Syrian Leaders
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON, April 26Kamal alAssad, Speaker of the Lebanese Parliament, flew to Damascus. today to talk with Syrian leaders about the presidential election that is supposed to be held here shortly.

title: The Grace Notes Come From Connecticut to Sing the Praises of New York
description: Every day their husbands leave Connecticut for work in New York City. Yesterday the Grace Notes  29 strong  put on their blue skirts and striped, bowatthethroat blouses, got intc a school bus and rode to the city themselves For an hour, before a shifting crowd of bemused New Yorkers and tourists, they gave an a cappella serenade in the lobby or the Empire State Building. New York, New York. is a wonderful city where the men work and play and the ladies are pretty. They interpolated those lyrics into Lullaby of Broadway", which they sang four times during their concert. We came to sing just because we love New York, Isabel Malkin of Greenwich explained afterwards. Her husband, Peter. works for the owners of the Empire State Building. Helen Bingaman of Riverside. Conn., who directed the chorus, said they had visited New York just to offer some fun for the people here. They did that along with a bit of puzzlement. Tourists or something? wondered woman in the crowd of about 100 as she surveyed the chorus, grouped under the inset silhouette of the building in the main lobby. They're a tour group, her companion advised. Usually the group of unpaid volunteers subdivides into quartets and entertains in nursing homes or schools in the GreenwichStamford area. Yesterday, with an occasional husband stopping by to wave a greeting or sneak a quick kiss on the cheek, they sang a group greeting to New York.

title: DONALD O. SWAN
description: Donald O. Swan, president since 1968 of what is now the Exxon Chemical Company, the chemical division of Exxon Corporation, of which he was a vice president, died yesterday M Memorial SloanKettering Cuncer Center, He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gas Clouds Support Theory on Matter Between Galaxies
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Huge clouds of gas that could have come from exploding galaxies have been discovered in, spaces of the universe thought by many, astronomers to be empty, University of Arizona scientists say.

title: DEFICIT OF PAN AM PARED IN QUARTER
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday a net loss for the firt quarter of $51.1 million. This compared with net loss of $59.8 million in the first quarter of 1975.

title: London Paper Prices Rise
description: LONDON, April 26 (UPI)Two London Sunday newspapers have announced price increases. The News of the World said it would go up 1 penny to 9 pence17 centsa copy next week, and The Observer announced a similar increase to 15 pence27 cents.

title: Hotel Dispute Focuses on Tax Abatements
description: A taxabatement plan to make possible the reconstruction of the Commodore Hotel into a hotel run by the Hyatt chain will come before the Board of Estimate today. It is an example of what could become, under the Beame administration, a widening use of taxabatement powers to generate new construction of commercial buildings, a familiar enough process elsewhere in the state and nation.

title: VIETNAM ASSEMBLY WILL MEET SOON
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 26 (AP)The National Assembly elected yesterday in Vietnam will meet within 60 days to adopt a new constitution and ratify the reunification of the North and South, according to Vietnamese officials.

title: Tanzania Welcomes Kissinger's Stand
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 26Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's assurance of United States support for the concept of majority rule in Southern Africa was welcomed with slightly qualified enthusiasm today by President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania.

title: Sonics a Bargain Paying Off
description: Who are the Seattle SuperSonics? They are Bill Russell, the funloving general manager and coach, who demands loyalty and dedication. They are Bob Hopkins, the assistant coach, a fundamentalist whom Russell describes as taking basketball as seriously as a heart attack. They are a collection of draft choices, some unheralded, and castoffs whom most teams were more than happy to discard. They are one of the youngest teams in the National Basketball Association, with their players averaging 24 years of age and having less than three years experience.

title: Chinese Radicals Appear First Time Since Teng'sOuster,
description: HONG KONG, April 27The leading members of what is known as China's radical faction, including Chairman Mao Tsetung's wife, Chiang Ching, took part in a ceremony honoring the militia in Peking last night. It was their first appearance since the ouster of Teng Hsiaoping, the former Deputy; Prime Minister earlier this month.

title: Private School Segregation Is Defended in High Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Supreme Court was told by a lawyer for a small Virginia school today that the Godgiven right of Americans to be left alone and to be free means that they may have pri vate schools that keep out black children because of their color.

title: Democracy, at Least, Is a Clear Winner in Portuguese Election
description: LISBON, April 26As the count neared completion today, Portugal's parliamentary elections yesterday produced no major incidents or surprises. Two turbulent and dramatic years to the day after the revolution that ended half a century of dictatorship, the voters answered the clearcut issue of whether they want democratic civilian government with a resounding yes.

title: BROWN TO. CAMPAIGN FOR MARYLAND VOTE.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 26 (UPI)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he would leave California this week for the first time since he took office and would campaign for the Maryland primary Wednesday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Palestine Radicals Assume Council Posts on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, April 26 (Reuters)  Palestine nationalists took over local council on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan today.

title: 15MONTH INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, concluding its 15monthlong investigation, today urged Congress to adopt a new, omnibus law covering foreign and military intelligence gathering that would create charters for the major agencies and sharply limit the use of covert action as a tool of foreign policy.

title: Weiskopf Withdraws
description: TOKYO, April 26 (UN)Tom Weiskopf, one of America's top professionals, has withdrawn from the $200,000 Chunichi Crowns open golf tournament, to be played April 29May 2 in Nagoya.

title: Buckley Declares for Senate as a Republican, Too
description: Senator James L. Buckley of New York, who was elected to the Senate as an antiestablishment Conservative Party candidate six years ago, yesterday announced his candidacy for a second term as both a Republican and a Conservative.

title: New Laws to Spur Economic Growth Proposed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 26  The Senate President, Matthew Feldman of Teaneck, proposed today the creation of a 10member joint legislative committee to develop legislation that would encourage business expansion, promote full employment in the state and spur economic growth.

title: Involuement by Mafia Is Alleged In $700 Million L.I. Sewer Job
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., April 26Lay enforcement authorities in Suftolk are investigating allegations that some contractors associated with the county's controversial $700 million Southwest Sewer District project maintained ties with Mafia figures.

title: 100 Georgians for Carter Invade Pennsylvania
description: YORK, Pa., April 23O. A. Phillips stopped short to contemplate the radiant vision that had, with a long sliding sidestep, just materialized in his path as he walked down Market Street in the noonday sun.

title: Panels Urgedto Monitor Covert Actions Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The United States has undertaken thousands of covert actions abroad since 1947, including 900 major or sensitive projects in the last 15 years alone, with only partial success and, in some instances, severe damage to the nation's foreign policy, according to a report today by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities.

title: 17YearOld Roman Youth Convicted in Pasolini Death
description: ROME, April 26 (AP)A 17yearold Roman was convicted today of the murder of film director Pier Paolo Pasolini and sentenced to 9 years, 7 months and I0 days in prison.

title: S.E.C. Suit Aims to Curb Javelin Founder and Others
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Securities and Exchange Commission said It filed suit today seeking to enjoin John C, Doyle, the founder of Canadian Javelin Ltd., and others from further alleged manipulations of Javelin stock on the American Stock Exchange and two Canadian exchanges.

title: Greening of the Press
description: Now that Barbara Walters has broken the milliondollarayear salary barrier which has kept journalists economically depressed for so long, there should be better days ahead for Republicans.

title: HIGH OIL LEA SE BIDS! ACCEPTED IN SALE
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)The Interior Department said today that it had accepted high bonus bids totaling $559.84 million for offshore oil and gas drilling leases in the northern Gulf of Alaska.

title: Articles in 1974 Spurred Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON; April 26The report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, part of which was released today, is the result of the most intensive investigation ever conducted into America's foreign and domestic intelligence system.

title: Chile Davis Cup Victor
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 26 (UPI)Jaime. Fillol enabled Chile to capture the American Zone Davis Cu P tennis final. today. when be completed a 75, 63, 46, 62 victory over the injured Bernie Mitten of South Africa in the deciding singles.

title: Emigre Says Soviet Abused Evidence
description: An migr Russian economit charged yesterday that information that had been obtained from him under duress in the Soviet Union had been used by the authorities there recently in sentencing a human rights leader to labor camp.

description: ALMA ATA, U.S.S.R.  A file of bluesuited speed skaters glided in synchronized slowmotion around the Medeo Sports Center's clean ice track, still firm despite the late morning sunshine.

title: Sidney James, British Comedian In Lavender Hill Mob, Is Dead
description: SUNDERLAND, England, April 26 (UPI)  Sidney James, one of Britain's bestloved comedy actors, collapsed on stage while acting in The Mating Game here this evening and died shortly afterwards in a hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Beirut's Political Leaders Strive To Make Secret Ballot Secret
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 26In the midst of a savage civil war, some of Lebanon's sturdy political warhorses are trying to bring about a major reform to make the secret ballot secret.

title: STATE COURT SAYS RAISE FOR POLICE MUST BE PAID NOW
description: A New York State appellate court ruled yesterday that the city must pay policemen $19.5 million in wage increases that had been postponed until at least 1978 because of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Horton Slugging Honored
description: Willie Horton of the Detroit Tigers was named the American League's player of the week yesterday after compiling a batting average of .556 and a slugging percentage of 1,111 during fivegame span from April 19 through last Sunday.

title: Islanders Rested for Next Round
description: The National Hockey League's best goaltenders, best defense, best powerplay unit and best penaltykillers will all be on the Montreal Forum ice tonight when the New York Islanders open their four of  seven game Stanley Cup semifinal series against the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Accord Is Near on Issue Of Foreign Banks in U.S.
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 26 A leading foreign banking official and American bankers came close to agreement today on proposed new United States legislation in the area of rapidly expanding foreign banking operations in the United States.

description: Pan Am Fined $60,000 in Air Crash

title: South Africa and Taiwan ReEstablishing Full Ties
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 26Nationalist China and South Africa, which have both been struggling to avoid political isolation, announced today the establishment of full diplomatic relations. Each is represented in the other's capital by a consulate general rather than an embassy.

title: Schoendienst Goes Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)Manager Red Schoendienst of the St. Louis Cardinals left the team today and returned home because of the illness of his oldest daughter, Colleen, 25 years old. She is to undergo major surgery tomorrow in St. Louis.

title: About the Yankees ..
description: Lou Piniella, who has a ninegame hitting streak (every game he has played this season) says the operation on his inner ear last season to correct dizzy spells proving to be 95 percent effective. Piniella's average fell to a career low of .196 in the 74 games he played last year. He is hitting .485. Once the scouts start seeing what I'm doing, he says, they'll tell the pitchers and they'll adjust. Then I'll have to adjust. Baseball is a game of adjustments. . . . Chris Chambliss, has an eightgame hitting streak and a .367 average. Chambliss has at least one run batted in each of those eight games.

title: New Data on Lockheed Ready for Italians
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A Senate Subcommittee today turned over to the State Department for transmission to Italy the identification of another Italian official who may have taken bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Days of Whines and Roses at Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26For the nine horses now considered likely starters, the ordeal of a Kentucky Derby won't have to be faced until next Saturday. For their trainers, it began today.

title: Helping New York
description: For 93yearold Mary Barrel!, the weekly visits by Darlene Dranda provide a vital, if not the only, link to an outside world she can no longer keep pace with and in which she has few friends.

title: COMPUTER DECISIONS BY U.S. CRITICIZED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Federal computers that issue checks and make decisions automatically are wasting millions of dollars each year because of mistakes programmed into their systems, Congressional auditors said today.

title: Amex and OTC Changes Are Minor
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished with minor price changes yesterday in slower trading.

title: Senate Votes Federal Takeover Of Grain Checking at Terminals
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Senate passed by a wide margin today a reform bill providing. for a Federal takeover of gram inspection at all export and major inland terminals. The vote was 52 to 18.

description: ALBANY, April 26Richard M. Rosenbaum, who was reelected today as Republican state chairman, declared in the strongest terms to date that the New York delegation to the Republican national convention was truly uncommitted and not, as some observers have suggested, uncommitted for President Ford.

title: Benefits Suspended
description: CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP)Negotiators faced a new issue today as they returned to the bargaining table for another attempt to end the sixdayold strike by the United Rubber Workers against the industry's four biggest companies.

title: Hearing on Plutonium Plant Is Told Of a Conflict Over Health Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 26on the day a Federal agency publicly said that health problems at an Oklahoma plutonium faxtory were of little significance, an official in the some agency, was privately telling the top executive of the company that the factcry had serious problems, it was disclosed today.

title: John Stanton Williams Jr., Member of Loeb Rhoades
description: John Stanton Williams Jr., stockbroker, shot himself to death Friday in his home at 1725 York Avenue. According had been depressed over mari to members of his family, hetal problems. He was 48 years old.

description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 26The Democratic Assemblymen from Nassau County said today they would not support a request from the County Board of Supervisors for a onecent increase in the county sales tax to meet an anticipated $17 million deficit in this year's county budget.

title: ARMS BUDGET RISE IS SOUGHT BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 26President Ford, citing the slow pace of the strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union, asked Congress today to add $260 million to the military budget to permit continued production of the Minuteman intercontinental missile.

title: Dearly Precious Wins 10th in Row
description: The trip into the winner's circle by Dearly Precious, last year's 2yearold filly champion, continues to be a routine chore.

title: Unions in Foreign Subsidiaries To Help Rubber Strikers in U. S
description: GENEVA, April 26A ban on overtime in the foreign subsidiaries of the big United States tire manufacturing companies will be the first international trade union action in support of the striking American rubber workers, trade union officials said today.

title: 3 SENATORS SCORE C.I.A. OVER REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency used national security arguments to strip the final report of the Senate Intelligence Committee of any data that might embarrass or inconvenience it, three members of the committee said today.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In his tour of the National League as a symbol of baseball's nouveau riche, Andy Messersmith will discover his popularity rating in New York when he starts for the Atlanta Braves against the Mets tomorrow. He already knows where he stands in Philadelphia and San Diego.

title: Students of Heidelberg Turn From Rebellion
description: HEIDELBERG, West GermanyChurch bells still toll each quarter hour from Gothic towers throughout this picturepostcard town, complete with gabled houses on narrow streets and castle ruins on a hill. The swans still float serenely on the Neckar River, undisturbed hy the rowers of the university team.

title: WILLIAMS TO SEEK 4TH SENATE TERM
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 26 Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. announced today that he would seek election to a fourth term.

description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  Ai major Saudi Government finandal institution, the Saudi Industrial Development Fund, has declined to provide financing for a proposed General Motors truck assembly plant here, Arab and Western business informants have reported, and the outlook for the project is unclear.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES SUED ON HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A coalition of 10 civil rights and housing groups sued four Federal financial regulatory agencies today, charging that they failed to enforce laws against discrimination in mortgage lending.

title: DRESSER SUGGESTS DEAL WITH SIGNAL
description: The Signal Companies Inc. announced yesterday that it had received an unsolicited letter from Dresser Industries Inc. expressing a desire to combine the two companies through an exchange of stocl valued at abou $448.7 million. Sig nal said the lette would be dis cussed at a boarc meeting scheduled for toda3 after Signal's annual share holder meeting. The compan3 said that the Dresser letter wa: not an offer and was made subject to a number of conditions, including a complete identification and verification of the business assets and financial afffairs of Signal.

description: The aluminum industry, following the lead of the Reynolds Metals Company, took only three business days to decide that the time had come to increase mices.

title: Needless Flood Victims
description: For the fifth time in seven years the Souris River has forced citizens of Minot, N.D., to abandon their homes and shops in fear of a flood. Although the worst of the threat now seems lo be over, 12,000 people have had to be evacuated once again from lowlying areas, h,ardships have been considerable and there is no certainty that the city will not experience, next year or, the year after that, the devastation that drowned it; out in 1969.

title: Connally Is Arousing Speculation Over His Future as He Roams Country in Support of the Republican.
description: HOUSTON, April 26We don't understand how affluent and abundant we really are. We use more energy for airconditioning alone in the United States than 800 million mainland Chinese for all purposes. That's the kind of perspective we need in this country.

title: Angolan to Visit Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 26 (Reuters) Prime Minister Lopo do Nascimento of Angola plans an official visit to the Soviet Union in late May, the Soviet press agency Tass announced today. It will be the first toplevel visit by an Angolan leader to Moscow since the African state gained independence from Portugal last October.

title: SENATE INTELLIGENCE PANEL CALLS FORA LAW TO CURB COVERT ACTION AS IMPLEMENT OF FOREIGN POLICY
description: ControlsThere have been failures at all levelsexecutive, Congressional and within the agenciesto control adequately and direct covert activities and to make the best use of intelligence resources. Sweeping changes are urged to provide external control of the intelligence community.

title: Ford Denounces Congress On Its Economic Policies
description: WASHINGTON, April 26President Ford, buoyed by the current. economic recovery, accused the Democratic controlled Congress today of pursuing economic policies that he said would put the nation orr a road that inevitably leads to ruin.

title: A Ride in the Country, But Not for the Scenery
description: Soggy Sunday. Sleepy Sunday.

title: ITALY'S PRESIDENT IS UNDER PRESSURE
description: ROME, April 26  President Giovanni Leone is coming under growing pressure in connection with bribery scandals involving the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: TIGHT RACE ENDS IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 The Pennsylvania primary campaign, once widely regarded as blandly inconsequential, finished its hectic course today as the most critical contest so far in the 1976 Democratic Presidential contest.

title: Sir Carol Reed, Film Director, Is Dead
description: Sir Carol Reed, the British movie director whose most famous films included The Third Man, Odd Man Out and The Fallen Idol, died of a heart attack Sunday night in his London home. He was 69 years old.

title: Spaniards, in Poll, Reject Movie Curbs
description: MADRID, April 26After almost 40 years of film censorship, most Spaniards reject the notion that the state should watch over public morals, according to a poll just taken.

title: Fashion It's Just One Big Family
description: The fall fashion collections are being readied, but not so swiftly that the people who design, make, sell and admire clothes don't have a chance to enjoy a mini social season. In many cases, they mix business with pleasure.

title: Notes on People
description: The Boulder Boys, the Navy's World War II intelligence organization in the Pacific, have been reunited for the first time in over 30 years. Swapping stories in Washington over drinks and hors d'oeuvres were 220 of some 2,000 graduates of a naval intelligence Japaneselanguage program, established less than a year before the, attack on Pearl Harbor, at the University of Colorado in Boulder, Colo.

title: BeBop Deluxe, British Quartet, Gets Off to a Rocking Start
description: Bebop Deluxe is a British rock quartet that has aroused a fair flurry of cult enthusiasm on the basis of its records. Sunday night at the Beacon Theater, the group completed its first American tour, a sevenweek odyssey as opening act for a variety of bands, with its first New York performance.

title: Buckley Declares Senate Candidacy As Republican, Too
description: Senator James L. Buckley, who was elected to the Senate as an antiestablishment, Conservative Party candidate six years ago, announced yesterday his candidacy for a second term as both a Republican arid a Conservative.

title: Capezio Dance A ward Presented to Robbins
description: Jerome Robbins, the choreographer and stage director, received this year's Capezio Award in dance yesterday. Edward Villella and Patricia McBride, principal dancers of the New York Ballet, where Mr. Robbins is a balletmaster, made the presentation at the Pierre Hotel before many members of the dance world.

title: Steelworkers End Strike
description: PROVIDENCE, April 26 (AP) Steelworkers at Textron's Gorham Division plant have accepted a 28month contraci, lending a sevenandahalfmonthold strike. The settlement calls for a 40centanhour increase the first year, 30 cents the next, and 25 cents In the third. The contract also includes an increase in fringe benefits.

title: External Degree College Escapes Byrne Budget Cuts
description: NEWARK  Thomas A. Edison College, the state's college for external degrees, has been spared from Governor Byrne's proposed budget cuts.

title: Books of The Times
description: HEROES. By Joe McGinniss. 176 pages. Viking. $7.95.

title: C.I.A. Will Keep More Than 25 JournalistAgents
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Central Intelligence Agency plans to continue to employ as agents more than 25 journalists or other representatives of American news organizations, according to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities.

description: Mickey Lolich reached two milestones yesterday as the Mets defeated the Atlanta Braves, 31. He needed 463 starts and 3,386 innings to reach the first and only four starts and 23 innings to achieve the second. Yet the second had to be more meaningful.

description: NEWARK, April 27 Jimmy Carter focused his Presidential campaign on New Jersey today as he attacked the state's Democratic Party organization and its chairman, who, he said, were attempting to bring about a deadlocked, brokered Democratic National Convention.

title: BILL ON RESERVE DILUTED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The House Banking Committee, by the narrowest of margins, deleted the two most important provisions of its Federal Reserve Bill today and passed a measure leaving very little of the changes envisioned by its sponsors.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27President FOrd said this morning that he Was disturbed by an announced price increase for a major line of steel products and that he wanted his pricemonitoring agency to look into it.

title: Urban League, Eying Boston Violence, Reconsiders Having Convention There
description: BOSTON, April 27The National Urban League, in light of continuing racial hostility here, is reconsidering holding its annual convention in Boston in July.
