description: Charles D. Dickey, who was prominent in banking in New York City and Philadelphia for many years, died yesterday in Chestnut Hill Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 82 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill and Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: Stock Moves Small OnAmex andOTC; TradingIsModerate
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday for the sfourth consecutiye session finished with minor price changes moderate trading.

title: Jackson's Defeat Viewed As Blow to Union Prestige
description: WASHINGTON, APRIL 28 The defeat of Senator Henry M. Jackson in the Pennsylvania Democratic primary yesterday was widely regarded to have dealt a body blow to the political prestige of the organized labor establishment, if not to its longrange power.

title: OnceinLifetime Dog Bowing Out at Bank
description: Today will be the last opportunity for New Yorkers to see the greatest winning terrier in the history of dog shows in America. He is Ch. JoNi's Red Baron of Crofton, a Lakeland owned by Mrs. Ronald Dickson of La Habra, Calif. The Baron has been appearing all week in the lounge of the Manhattan Savings Bank, at 47th Street and Madison Avenue, where from noon until 1:30, the institution's 16th annual exhibition of purebred dogs has been going on. It continues tomorrow but the Lakeland and his handler, Ric Chashoudian, are flying back this afternoon, immediately after they have gaited around the ring for final time.

title: Madrid Announces a Voting Timetable
description: MADRID, April 28Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro announced tonight that a referendum on proposed constitutional changes would be held in October in preparation for general elections at the beginning of next year.

title: No Foreign Policy Change
description: TOKYO, Thursday, April 29 (AP) Foreign Minister Chiao Kuanhua oi China was reported today to have said that Peking's foreign policy would not change under the new leadership.

title: U.S. CANCER AIDE QUITS IN PROTEST
description: The head of the National Cancer Institute's program to investigate cancer  causing agents has resigned in protest over what he has called fragmentation of and lack of support for research in this area of growing public concern and public health importance.

title: Mariners Best Aeros
description: HOUSTON, April 28 (UPI)  Gene Peacosh and Kevin Devine scored secondperiod goals tonight to spark the resurgent San Diego Mariners to their second straight victory over the defending World Hockey Association Champion Houston Aeros, 32.

title: Tower and Goldwater Refuse to Sign Report
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)  The vice chairman and one other member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence refused to sign the panel's report on domestic survellance, which was released today.

title: Senate Rift Looms OverPower of Intelligence Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Senate Rules Committee voted today to give no lawmaking or budgetary authority to a proposed new Senate committee that would monitor the activities of intelligence agencies.

title: Business Briefs
description: Kodak Canadian Unit Sues Polaroid

title: Wollow Wins 2,000 Guineas Race
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 28 (UPI)Wollow, the evenmoney favorite, won the 2,000 Guineas English horse racing classic today. Wollow's victory, worth $99,160, clinched a double for his owner, Carlo D'Alession, a Rome lawyer; Henry Cecil, an English trainer, and Gianfranco Dettori, the Sardinian jockey, who won the 1975 race with Bolokonski. The 3yearold Wollow, now unbeaten in six races, was immediately installed as the 31 favorite for the English Derby, his next race.

title: New Burroughs System
description: The Burroughs Corporation introduced yesterday a new small general purpose computer family system called the B80 Aeries.

title: Old Plaster Casts of Statues Turn MarbleLike in Queens College Art Class
description: Old plaster casts of works by Michelangelo, of a frieze at Persepolis and of a Laocoon group at the Vatican are getting the gleaming look of marble at the hands of art students from Queens College, who are working out a plan arranged by their school with the Queens Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Contrast in Appeal Shown By Carter and Humphrey
description: Jimmy Carter and Hubert H. Humphrey, to whom,the Democratic Presidential race has apparently narrowed, have never confronted each other in a primary election. But if they had, New York Times/CBS News polls indicate, they would have attracted voters from two very different groups within the party's rank and file.

title: U.S. WARNS AT U.N. ON ZIONISM ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28  The United States reaffirmed today that it will never accept an equation of Zionism with racism.

title: A Million Gallons Of Poison Spilled Off Jersey Shore
description: CARTERET, N.J., April 28 More than one million gallons of toxic liquids spilled into the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey and New York Harbor today when a Colombian freighter rammed a barge loaded with chemical waste.

title: DILORENZO TRIAL IS SENT TO JURY
description: Both sides summed up their arguments yesterday in State  Supreme Court in. Brooklyn in the perjury trial of Ross Di Lorenzo, a retired Brooklyn Ci vil Court judge. The jury will begin deliberating today.

title: Another School District Rebels And Abandons Shortened Day
description: Another Manhattan school district has directed its principals to restore regular school hours in defiance of the central Board of Education's policies.

title: Jackson's Camp Wobbly After Pennsylvania Loss
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, who went into Pennsylvania three weeks ago after winning in New York with visions of delivering a crushing blow to Jimmy Carter's hopes for the Democratic Presidential nomination, returned here today with his own campaign in almost total disarray.

title: A Bomb in Jerusalem Kills 2 and Injures 4
description: JERUSALEM, April 28 (UPI) A time bomb in a paint can in the heart of the city today killed two policemen and injured four other persons, a police spokesman said.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is the doctors who are making us sick "the medicaf establishment has become a major threat to health"argues Ivan Illich, megacritic, in his compactly written, heavily footnoted, highly articulate polemic, Medical Nemesis: The Expropriation of Health. We are experiencing an epidemic of iatrogenesis (from iatros, the Greek word for physician, and genesis, or origin"), meaning illness caused by doctors. Which argument, viewed in a narrow perspective, may sound outrageous. For although in the part of his book called Clinical Iatrogenesis Mr. Illich goes so far as to claim that the effectiveness of medical intervention in combating both infectious diseases is questionable (major diseases such as tuberculosis, cholera, dysentery, and typhoid peaked and dwindled outside the physicians control"; new killers inevitably replace old ones; the rise in human life expectancy can be attributed more to environmental improvements than to the defeat of disease), Mr. Illich's position here is not so overwhelming as to prevent us from getting our next strep throat swabbed, our next broken bone set and our next pregnancy monitored as closely as medical science will permit.

title: Care Is Urged on TenantsRights Rules
Chess:
description: It may appear laughably obvious to say that winning a bestplayedgame prize against one of the world's top competitors is a difficult task, but this remains true even when the strategic conception is absolutely correct and the game is won.

title: Notes on People
description: David and Julie Nixon Eisenhower are scheduled to move from Washington about May 15 into a leased twobedroom apartment at The Pavilion, 500 East 77th Street at York Avenue. The 35story, 852unit building was the largest apartment structure in the city:with one of the most elaborate security systemswhen it was built a little more than 10 years ago. It overlooks the East River,

title: U.S. Is Dubious
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The United States does not believe that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's formula for bringing blacks into his Government meets its conception of representative government for Rhodesia, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Cairo Reports Syrian Arrests
description: CAIRO, April 26 (Reuters) The Cairo newspaper Al Gomhouriya said today that 62 Syrian Army officers were arrested after an alleged attempt last month to depose President Ilafez alAssad. Yesterday the paper said that 4,000 members of the ruling Baathlst Party leadership and some senior army officers had been arrested.

title: Lufkin Joins Sellers Of Brokerage Stock
Nassau Election Commissioner Is Guilty
description: Marvin D. Cristenfeld, a commissioner of the Nassau County Board of Elections, was convicted yesterday of extortion and fraud in connection with the award of more than $2 million in county engineering contracts from 1969 to 1973 while he, was chairman of the county's Democratic committee.

title: SOVIET ASKS ANEW FOR MIDEAST TALK
description: MOSCOW. April 28 The Soviet Government sounded a new call today for the resumption of the Middle East conference in Geneva and proposed that it take place in two stages.

title: Carter in Pennsylvania
description: Is Jimmy Carter headed for a firstballot victory Madison Square Garden?

title: Reagan Finds an Effect
description: ATLANTA, April 28 (AP) Ronald Reagan said today that his warnings about America's defense position had led President Ford to request funds for strengthening the Minuteman missile system.

title: GENERAL TIRE FOCUS OF INQUIRY BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)The General Tire and Rubber Company's alleged bribes of $500,000 to keep United States competitors out of Morocco in 1969 are under investigation, the Federal Trade Commission said today. An F.T.C. spokesman, William Weaver, said the staff had begun an inquiry, but said he could not comment on the in. vestigation process.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: TV Review
description: Last night on public television, the Subject of death was dealt with artistically in Edward Albee's .play All Over. Tonight, the protective hospital screen is re moved from in front of the patient, and death is; .confronted directly in an extraordinary documentary. called "Dying." The 97minute program was Produced by Michael Rohmer for station WGBH in Boston.

title: Soviet Captures Davis Cup Series
description: MOSCOW, April 28 (UPI) The Soviet Union took an unbeatable 30 lead ol.er Monaco in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis seriac today at Tbilisi in Georgia, the Tass press agency said.

title: EXPERTS DISAGREE ON CIVIL DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Two scientific advisers to the Defense Department expressed concern today that the Ford Administration's shift to a flexible nuclear strategy was the opening wedge for a massive civil defense program designed to protect Americans from a limited Soviet nuclear strike.

title: Mrs. Hills Says Suburbs Will See Housing Needs
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, says that local communities will see a need to supply lowincome housing for the poor outside of city slums without the Government's forcing it on them.

title: City University Union Agrees To Forgo Increases in Salaries
description: A union representing 17,100 instructors and other professionals at the City University of New York announced a tentative contract settlement yesterday in which the workers agreed to forgo salary increases and to defer until July 1, 1978, two weeks pay and nine months of increment payments.

title: STRIKES IN QUARTER LOWEST IN 10 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  Strike activity in the United States in the first three months of 1976 fell to its lowest level in any first quarter in more than 10 years, the Labor Department said today.

title: LeFrak Says He Will Cut New York City Operation
description: Citing an Unfavorable political and economic climate for builders and owners in New York City, Samuel 3. LeFrak, the 'city's biggest private landlord, said yesterday that his or ganization was phasing out its acitivitiesin this city.

title: House Defeats Attempt to Limit Rise in 1977 Defense Spending
People and Business
description: Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio arrived in Tokyo yesterday for a fiveday visit that appeared almost certain to include a bid for a Toyota auto plant in his state that would match recent Volkswagen and Volvo moves to assemble cars in this country.

title: Benton &
description: It all started with a Christmas gift Hillary Vermont, an assistant art director at Benton & Bowles, gave to her boss Alvin Hampel, executive vice president and director of creative services. She took his favorite slogan It's not creative unless it sells and baked it for the ages. That's right, baked it like an unruly pretzel.

title: Peking Paper Says Teng Plotted Against Mao and Split Leadership
description: PEKING, April 28 (Reuters) China's official party newspaper today stepped up a campaign against Teng Hsiaoping; prompting speculation that the former Deputy Prime Minister might be expelled from the Communist Party.

title: Incinerator to Make Fuel Appears Set for Yonkers
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 28 Westchester County appeared today to have made the final arrangement for its $100 million soildwaste disposal plant when Yonkers tentatively accepted a fuelproducing incinerator.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The former president of the Brownsville Community Federal Credit Union in Brooklyn and three other men have been indicted on charges of stealing and forging Federal checks and using the credit union as a fence to cash them. The charges involve at least $20,000 worth of checks stolen and cashed early in 1974.

title: GENERAL MOTORS SHOWS BIG PROFIT
description: DETROIT, April 28The General Motors Corporation, recovering from the depressed earnings of a year ago when the auto industry was in a severe slump, reported a sharp rise in firstquarter earnings yesterday to $800 million, or $2.78 a share.

title: Albany Hearings Assess Adopted Persons Rights
description: ALBANY, April 23 The right or need of an adult who was adopted to know the identity and as much as possible about his natural parent as opposed to that parent's right or need for privacy, was the subject of legislative hearings today on proposals to remove the legal shroud that now surrounds adoption records in the state.

title: INEQUITIES CITE IN MEDICAID PAY
description: William McCann, assistant commissioner of the State Health Department, said yesterday that it was possible that the state,. under its costbased reimbursement system, was reimbursing voluntary hospitals for salaries that were twice as high as those paid in municipal hospitals for the same job.

title: Soviet Asian City Overcomes Environment Perils
description: ALMAATA, U.S.S.R. The snowcovered peaks of the Tien Shan soar abruptly south of this capital of Kazakhstan, offering a stunning view from almost every street.

title: Teng Accused in Shanghai
description: PEKING, April 28 (Agencel FrancePresse) Mr, Teng tried last year to publish a new review to put forward his ideas and policies, according to a Shanghai journal, Studies and Criticisms.

title: Reduction in World Birth Rate Attributed to Control Programs
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  Birth control programs have spread across the globe and have contributed to a significant decline in birth rates in the last decade, a new Governmentfinanced study said yesterday.

title: Sanitation Dept. to Test ProfitMotivation System
description: The Beame administration is planning to establish profitmotivated garbagecollecting cooperatives in two existing sanitation districts as part of an effort to find new management techniques for the city.

title: Treasury to Reduce Borrowings in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Treasury said today that Government spending was running below expected levels and consequently Treasury borrowing in the first half of 1976 would be about $4 billion. to $5 billion less than expected.

title: Couples Take a Course, to Avoid the Dangers of Success
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Svea Fraser never had any doubts about her husband's ultimate ibusiness success. Her fears were of a different order.

title: Beame and a Broadway Cast Call for Eradication of Porno Plague
description: Mayor Beame and an entourage of politicians, actors, producers and businessmen went to the Broadway stage yesterday to voice their determination to rid the city of what they describe as the porno plague that has Caused much of the decay of the midtown district.

title: Poems by Emperor Hirohito And Empress Nagako
description: The New York Times asked Emperor Hirohito of Japan, through the Imperial Household Agency, to compose a poem for the occasion of his 75th birthday anniversary, which he is celebrating today. In response, the Emperor and Empress Nagako selected the two poems, untitled  which they wrote last year  that are printed here. In the Japanese, they are written in an ancient 31syllable form known as Waka. The translation is by the Agency, and the calligrapher is Motoi Oi of East Elmhurst, N. Y. The  Emperor's poem appears below at the right, the Empress's at the left.

title: Job Decline in Private Sector Easing Off in New York City
description: Declines in government em ployment now are a major drag on the city's economy and accounted for more than half of the 100,700 jobs lost here between February 1975 and last February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Virgin Islands Tragedy
description: For anyone who has ever landed at the Harry S. Truman Airport in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, the surprise must be not that a plane crash killed several dozen people the other day, but that this airport has not been the scene of many more accidents and fatalities than have actually occurred.

title: Health Violations Cited in Inspections of 19 Food Outlets
Gien. Tomas Garcia Rebull, Led Burgos in Basque Case
description: MADRID, April 28 (Reuters)  Retired Lieut. Gen. Tomas Garcia Rebull, a leading rightwing military figure, died here today of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: 1,506 VOTERS POLLED BY TIMES AND CBS
description: The New York Times and CBS News polled 1,506 Democratic voters in Pennsylvania Tuesday as they left the polling places. Thirty voting precincts were chosen in the state, and, within each precinct, each voter had an equal chance of sciecdon.

title: Plea Changed in Murder
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 (AP)Joseph Malcolm Purifory, 30 years old, of Philadelphia, has entered plea of nonvult contendre in the murder of an 33yearold widow who was found dead in her Hopewell farmhouse last July. Mr. Purifory withdrew his original not guilty .plea in the murder of Ethel Perry. The plea means. that he does not wish to fight the charge. Mr. Purifory also pleaded guilty to breaking and entering, assault with intent to rob and larceny.

title: March Sales by Chains Up 11%; Quarter Volume in 13.4% Rise
Train Hits Swiss School Bus
description: BELLINZONA, Switzerland. April 28 (AP) A train hit a school bus at an unguarded crossing near here today, killing the bus driver and at least five of the nine children aboard, the police said

title: Soviet Is Purchasing $400 Million Worth Of American Grains
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Soviet Union, in a longawaited reentry into the United States market, has bought 3.1 million tons, or 122 million bushels, of corn and 300,000 tons, or 11 million bushels, of wheat, the Depart. ment of Agriculture announced today.

title: Tennis Post Of Talbert In Limbo
description: They may not have Bill Talbert to kick around anymore.

title: Ford Assails Reagan View On Defense as Simplistic
description: HOUSTON, April 28 President Ford accused Ronald Reagan today of being so simplistic on national security metters that he might maim ???esponsible and fundamentally harmful policy decisions if elected President.

title: E.R.A. DEFENDED IN LEGISLATURE
description: ALBANY, April 28 The State Assembly's Judiciay Committee today rejected a move to repeal the Legislature's earlier ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: Carter, in Unity Bid, Seeks Humphrey Endorsement
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28 Jimmy Carter today offered Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota not an armored gauntlet but a velvet glove.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: DAVID MECKLER, 85, EDITED DAYJOURNAL
description: David L. Meekler, editor in chief of The DayJewish Journal, which ended publication in 1971 after 57 years as the largest Yiddishlanguage newspaper in the United States, died Monday in Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 920 East 17th Street in Brooklyn.

title: 4 Black Cabinet Ministers Take the Oath in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 28 (Reuters) Four tribal chiefs took oaths of office today as the first black members of the Rhodesian Cabinet.

title: Royal BalletTriumphs in Month in Country
A Festive Presentation of Givenchy's Styles
description: The circuslike ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria was transformed yesterday by cool blue tablecloths and delicately towering arrangements of white flowersdogwood, lilacs and calla lilies. Bunny Mellon had brought them from her Virginia farm and worked out the centerpieces with Robert Perkins, whom she calls the best flower man in the country. Jim Goslee of the Fernery executed the arrange ments.

title: Robinson's Hit Caps 3Run 5th As Orioles Top Angels Again
description: Brooks Robinson, the Golden Glove at third base for the Baltimore Orioles, has had a difficult time at the plate in his 22d major league season.

title: The Carterwagon Rolls
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  Jimmy Carter is no longer merely the Democratic frontrunner. With Pennsylvania in his pocket, he is now the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, an Emergence, that has different effects on several groups:

title: Jersey Official Backs APower and Offshore Drilling
description: CHERRY HILL, April 28 Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, called today for an end to scare talk about nuclear power and a swift start on drilling for offshore oil and the expansion of nuclear generating capacity.

title: STOCKS MOVE UP IN QUIET SESSION
description: An upturn in the final halfhour of quiet trading yesterday again lifted the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks labove the 1,000 level.

title: Post at Minneapolis Papers
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 28 (UPI)Gale W. Freeman was named yesterday to the newly created position of general manager of The Minneapolis Star and The Minneapolis Tribune newspapers. Mr. Freeman has been associate publisher for the last four years. The publisher, Donald R. Dwight, said the move was to provide a clearer definition of management responsibilities within the Minneapolis newspapers.

title: Support for Rubber Strike
description: DETROIT. April 28 (AP) Delegates to the national Ford Council of the United Automobile Workers unanimously adopted a resolution today pledging the full support of union's Ford members to striking United Rubber Workers. A strike by the rubber workers is In its second week.

title: MARINES TO TRY 4 IN YOUTH'S DEATH
More Food Stamp Aid Voted by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON. April 28 The Senate Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee voted today to give the food stamp program $400 million more to see it through Sept. 30.

title: New Release Effort Begun By Jailed Jersey Witness
description: TRENTON, April 27 (AP) Louts Anthony Manna, who has been in jail for nearly four years for refusing to testify about underworld activities be. fore the State Commission of Investigation, has renewed his attempt to gain freedom.

title: Nuggets Triumph, Face Nets in Final
description: DENVER, April 28 (UPI) David Thompson scored a gamehigh 40 points and paced a 37point thirdquarter offensive tonight in leading the Denver Nuggets to a 133110 victory over Kentucky and a spot in the American Basketball Association playoff finals against the New York Nets.

title: Experts Doubtful on Safety at the St. Thomas Airport
description: In the eyes of numerous airsafety experts. Tuesday's plane crash on St. Thomas, in the United States Virgin Islands, is deemed a textbook example of a, crash that was almost bound to happen, sooner or later. The reason: Conditions at the Caribbean airport  the short runway anti the hills confronting an airliner at the'far end after an eastbound averwater approachprovided little safety cushion in case of trouble, even though they met official criteria.

title: Political Jawboning
description: President Ford certainly ought to be disturbed"as he says he isabout the 7.9 percent increase for flatrolled steel announced by the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation. But what he intends to do about is another matter.

title: Excerpts From the North Vietnamese Chief of Staff's Account of the Spring Offensive in 1975
description: HONG KONG, April 28 Following are additional excerpts, in. unofficial translation, from the account of North Vietnam's Chief of Staff. Gen. Van Tien Dung. of the spring offensive of 1975 that led to the Cornmunist victory in South Vietnam. Earlier excerpts were published in Monday's New York Times

title: Britain's Crisis Is Tourist's Bonanza
description: LONDON, April 28John Rasmussen, an 18yearold Dane, was sitting on the steps of the British Museum. He took a plasticwrapped egg and tomato sandwich from his bag. The sandwich cost him eight pence, or barely 15 cents, It's very cheap to go out eating here, Mr. Rasmussen said. Everything is much cheaper than in Denmark.

title: Governor Is Urged By Mayor Beame To Veto Heart Bill
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would urge Governor Carey to veto a bill that would permanently allow police officers and firemen to retire on threequarters pay for heart disease on the presumption that the illness was jobrelated.

title: Lebanese Banker Backed by Syrians Seeks Presidency
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 28 With the Lebanese Parliament scheduled to choose a new President in three days, a banker who has the backing of Syria and major rightwing factions here announced his candidacy today.

title: Anonymity May Be Costing South American $250,000
description: MIAMI, April 28 (UPI) A South American automobile dealer's refusal to identify himself could cost him $250,000. The money was seized by Customs officials in February 1975, when they arrested Geoffrey A. Whitehead, a Bahamian banker who was trying to leave for Nassau with the undeclared currency in his brown briefcase.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON CAMPAIGN BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) House and Senate conferees agreed today on a bill changing the Federal Election Commission, hours after a court refused to release Presidential campaign funds.

title: ALFRED LEWIS DEAD; RAN THE TAFT HOTEL
$6 MILLION WASTE IS LAID TO H.R.A.
description: Billing delays, backlogs and bureaucracy in New York City's payments to childcare institutions are costing the hardpressed municipal treasury $6, million a year in unnecessary interest, Comptroller HarriSon J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Seoul Party Assails Curb On Arrested Foe of Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea. April 28 The opposition New Democratic Party, has issued a st:ttement criticizing the Government's alleged refusal to let Kim Dae Jung, a former opposition Presidential candidate, see his lawyers.

title: Bridge:
description: A foursome headed by Sam Stayman of New York holds a commanding lead going into the second half of the New York Grand National final tonight. Play will begin at 6:30 P.M. at the Barclay Bridge Club, 7535 31st Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Confessed Killer Charges State Reneged on Penalty
description: TRENTON. April 28 A confessed murderer and cocaine smuggler whose cooperation helped the state to convict nine members of an organized crime ring has filed court papers contending that the state reneged on its promise of a light prison sentence.

title: Retired Fireman Helps Save Others in Plane Crash
description: Cecil Shackelton, a., retired fireman whose windowgate invention is used in thousands of New York City homes with Fire Department approval to guard against burglars, was trying to save lives again in Tuesday's American Airlines crash on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands.

title: Judge Accuses the Nassau D.A . Of Impeding Grand Jury Inquiry
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 28 The administrative judge of Nassau County Court charged today that the District Attorney's office inhibited the rights of al grand jury and prevented It from operating In an atmosphere conducive to open, fair, objective and independent inquiry.

title: Women at a Players Club Lunch
description: I must say, we did tms in true Players style, observed one member yesterday afternoon, as he glanced about him, counting only three women lunching In the woodpaneled dining room of the Players Club. Our members didn't ignore it, but on the other hand there wasn't any sort of fanfare either.

title: Texans Will Choose Among Obscure Aspirants to a Panel That Cherishes Obscurity
description: HOUSTON, April 28 One candidate travels by bus with a country hand called the Rolling Ripoff, , Review. Another one fuels his campaign mostly from a shot glass. A third contender is so steeped in oil industry funds that opponents say voters might as well elect the president of an oil company.

title: Thomson Set to Buy I.T.T.'s French Unit
Widespread Lawbreaking Laid to Intelligence Units
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 In 1954, an assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation sent J. Edgar Hoover a memordandum recommending that the bureau plant an electronic listening device in the hotel room of a suspected Cornmunist sympathizer.

title: GENERAL MOTORS SHOWS BIG PROFIT
description: DETROIT, April 28 The General Motors Corporation, recovering from the depressed earnings of a year ago when the auto industry was in a severe slump, reported a sharp rise in firstquarter earnings yesterday to $800 million, or $2.78 a share.

title: ExSkipper of Queens 2d Mate on Banana Boat
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 29, 1970

title: INTELLIGENCE PANEL FINDS F.B.I. AND OTHER AGENCIES VIOLATED CITIZENS RIGHTS
description: Culpability Government officials at all levels knowingly took part in illegal activities in a decadeslong campaign to which Presidents, Cabinet members and members of Congress clearly contributed. Presidents from Franklin P. Roosevelt onward, and their aides, have requested or accepted from the F.B.I. politically useful information about opponents and critics.

title: Police Magazine Plans Apology on Ethnic Slur
description: The Police Department plans to apologize in its next issue of Spring 3100, its monthly magazine, for an item in the March issue that has led to a protest by an organization of ItalianAmerican police officers, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: PALME DENOUNCES SWEDISH RIGHTISTS
description: STOCKHOLM, April 28 (AP)  Prime Minister Olof Palme, a Social Democrat, charged today that rightist forces are trying to create a rightist reactionary climate in Sweden by making issues of cases like that of Ingmar Bergman, the film director involved in a tax dispute.

title: Udall to Continue His Uphill Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Representative Nlorris K. Udall said today that he would continue his campaign for the Democrat ic Presidential nomination in spite of his weak third place finish in the Pennsylvania primary election.

title: Half of 500 Laotians Who Escaped Jail Reported Captured
description: NONG KHAI, Thailand, April 28 (Agence FrancePresse) Nearly half of the 500 Laotian political and other prisoners who were said to have broken out of a jail in Vientiane Sunday were reported today to have been recaptured.

title: CAREY SAYS PACT ON TRANSIT WAGE MUST BE REVISED
S.E.C. MAY DROP SHORTSALE RULE
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was considering elimination of its shortsale rules, designed to prevent exaggerated declines in stock prices.

title: 45 Slain by Burmese Rebels
description: RANGOON, Burma, April 28 (UPI)  Insurgents attacked a passenger vessel off the coast of southern Burma on Monday and killed 45 passengers, according to reports reaching the capital today.

title: Ingmar Bergman to Make 2 U.S. Films
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 Ingmar Bergman, the Swedish film director, said today that he planned to make at least two films in the United States and that he would like to direct on Broadway and possibly on American television.

title: Contrast in Appeal Shown By Carter and Humphrey
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Subtle Changes, Yes, but Still the Familiar Pucci
description: Time was when the audience side of a fashion show any fashion showwas a sea of women in Pucci prints. The tide seems to have receded in recent years, to be replaced by a wave of Ultrasuede dresses as everywoman's uniform.

title: End of the Affair
description: When a mistake has been made, only a forthright apology can heal the wound. Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller made a serious and uncharacteristic mistake recently when he casually impugned the patriotism two members of Senator Henry M. Jackson's staff at a vrivate meeting with Georgia Republicans.

title: Bureau Accused of Trying to Manipulate News Media
description: WASHINGTON, APRIL 28 The Federal Bureau of Investigation repeatedly and covertly attempted to manipulate the news media in an effort to influence public opinion and discredit citizens and organizations that were its targets, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities reported today.

title: BEAME THREATENS 5,000 NEW LAYOFFS
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that if the city was forced to Implement the StaviskyGoodman Education Aid Law, 5,000 additional municipal workers would be laid oft and there would be tremendous damage to the vital lifesupport services of our city.

title: Brown Opens Drive In Maryland Race; Is Greeted by 3,000
description: BALTIMORE, April 28 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr, of California opened his campaign in Maryland for the Democratic Presidential nomination tonight before crowds that rivaled in enthusiasm those that greeted John F. Kennedy when he campaigned in the state in 1960.

title: RECOMMENDATIONS
description: Recommendation 1There is no inherent constitutional authority for the President or any intelligence agency to violate the law.

title: Two Crash Recording Devices Found In Search of Wreckage on St. Thomas
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE. Virgin Islands, April 28 7 Investigators assigned to find the cause of yesterday's crash of an American Airlines 727 jet here began focusing attention today on a key question of how far &ma the unusually short runway the plane made its first contact. The crash killed 37 of the 88 passengers and crew members on board.

title: SUPPLY OF GASOLINE DECLINED FOR WEEK
Irrelevance in Rhodesia
description: Rhodesia's black nationalist leaders used the right word"irrelevant"to describe Prime Minister Ian Smith's transparent move in appointing four tribal chiefs to an otherwise white Cabinet. It has long been evident that, as his position worsened, Mr. Smith would try to confuse world opinion by bringing compliant blacks into his white minority Government.

title: Antiabortion Measure Is Killed As Senate Refuses to Debate It
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  The Senate rejected today an effort to amend the Constitution to bar abortions, voting 47 to 40, against putting the issue to a final vote.

title: STUDY PANEL SEES VICTORY OVER ILLS
Auto Union Says It Has Funds for 2Month Strike
description: DETROIT, April 28 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers will have a record $175 million strike fund when auto contracts expire in midSeptember, the union says.

title: Nuclear Pact Gains in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 28 (Reuters)  Japan took a step today toward ratification of the 1970 treaty prohibiting the spread of nuclear weapons when it was approved by the lower house of Parliament. Observers said that the chance of the bill winning approval in the upper house was uncertain.

title: Jockeys Give Opinions
description: Three regular innamtants of Aqueduct's jockey colony Braulio Baeza, Angel Cordero, and Jorge Velasquezare scheduled to ride in the Kentucky Derby. Despite the proximity of their important dates, however, they continued to do business as usual yesterday at the Big A.

title: On Prostitution Row, Business Hums as Mayor Talks
description: Even as Mayor Beame and an assortment of city officials were inside a theater on 44th Street off Eighth Avenue pledging to sweep prostitution from the city's streets, less than a half block west on Eighth Avenue it was business as usual.

title: Cape May Housing Permit Rejected To Protect Prime Agricultural Land
description: TRENTON, April 28  The State Department of Environmental Protection denied a construction permit today for a 341unit singlefamily housing development in Cape May County on the ground that it would destroy prime agricultural land.

title: Million Gallons of Poison Spilled Off Jersey Shore
description: CARTERET, N.J., April 28 More than one million gallons of toxic liquids spilled into the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey and New York Harbor today when a Colombian freighter rammed a barge loaded with chemical waste.

title: Tuesday Voting's Effects
description: Following are the latest tallies in the Democratic Presidential primary in Pennsylvania, the United States. Senate races in that state and the convention delegate votes, in Pennsylvania and overall:

title: LONGTERM BONDS ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: The credit markets again moved carefully toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday. The Treasury's refinancing plans, disclosed late in the afternoon, failed to produce any dramatic market reaction. The Treasury decided to sell $750 million of longterm bonds, an amount below the $1 billion or more that had been expected in Wall Street, so longterm bond prices advanced after the news was issued.

title: Armstrong W. Sperry, 78, Book Author and Illustrator
description: BEDFORD CENTER, Vt., April 28 (UPI) Armstrong W. Sperry, author and illustrator of more than 25 books, died Monday in Hanover, N. H., at the age of 78.

title: New Start in Transit
description: The transit wage agreement, made under the bludgeon of an illegal strike threat four weeks ago, is now a dead letter. Informed by Attorney General Lefkowitz that the proposed costofliving adjustments violated the statemandated wage freeze for New York City, Governor Carey has rightly directed that the pact be rewritten to conform to law.

title: Batten the Key to Needham Shift
description: After months of courtship, the willingness of William M. Batten to take the post of New York Stock Exchange chairman became the deciding factor in the abrupt resignation of James J. Needham, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Nelson G. Gross, former Republican state chairman, lost a motion yesterday to work for a convict rehabilitation program instead of serving a twoyear prison term for obstruction of justice. He was ordered to report on May 17.

title: Rggins to Shop for Best Deal
description: John Riggins has told the Jets he will not sign with them until he finds out how valuable the rest of the National Football League thinks he is.

title: South Africa Says Troops in Angola RoutedCubaForce
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 29 (AP) The South African Army said today that its troops in Angola routed a superior force of Cubans late last year, killing 150 to 200 while losing only four of its own men.

title: Brewers Win, 85, Tie Yanks for First
description: CHICAGO, April 29 (UPI)  George Scott singled.hdine two runs to cap a threerun ninth inning rally that gave the Milwaukee Brewers an 85 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. It Was the fourth straight triumph for the Brewers and the fifth consecutive loss for the

title: Spending Cuts in the City Criticized As Too Slow
description: ALBANY, April 29 A task force of Democrats in the Senate charged today that both Mayor Beame and the Emergency Financial Control Board had been too slow to implement spending cuts and too compliant toward labor unions in New York City.

title: F.C.C. PHONE MOVE STAYED BY COURT
description: A court order yesterday held up a Federal Communications Commission ruling that would have allowed telephone users to attach their own phone equipment without paying a charge to the phone company.

title: SHIPYARDS PRESS CLAIMS ON NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, April 29Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr. said today that some private shipbuilders were refusing to construct naval ships unless there was an equitable adjustment of their claims against the Navy for past contracts.

title: Judith Blegen and Boulez Combine Musical Forces
Record WheatCrop Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, April 29, (Reuter)World supplies of wheat and feed grains should reach a record level near 1.2 billion metric tons during the new crop year beginning this summer, the United States Agriculture Department said today. In an initial forecast of supply and demand prospects for the 197677 grain season, production of wheat and feed grains and stocks from the present crop year could increase total supplies to around 1.178 billion tons. That would be roughly 100 million tons more than the amount available during this season.

title: SHIRLEY U. CHOLET
description: Shirley Untermyer Cholet, secretary to the director of Region H of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, died at her Irvington, N. Y., home Wednesday. She was 53 years old.

title: A. H. Raskin to Get A NewPost at Times
U.S. Agrees to Continue Giving Lockheed Information to Italy
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Justice Department agreed today to continue furnishing, Italy with information about. Lockheed bribes, despite disclosures in Italy that apparently violated an agreement, that the material be kept secret.

title: RizzoRecall Sponsors Hail Petition Progress
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (UPI) Leaders of the movement to oust Mayor Frank L. Rizzo say that during the first 10 days of their petitioning drive, they have collected about 45,000 signatures calling for a recall referendum.

title: At Home, Labor
description: HONG KONG, April 29  A university professor has become a bicycle repairman after his school was closed. A lawyer has gone to work clearing scrub jungle in the countryside after his profession was abolished. The wife of a major in the former South Vietnamese Army lost her house and had to sell all her furniture after her husband was taken away for what was said to be a threeweek reeducation course last June. He is still not back and now she runs a portable soup stall to earn enough to live.

title: Richard Hughes Is Dead at 76; Wrote High Wind in Jamaica
description: Richard Hughes, the English novelist and dramatist who sprang to fame with his novel !`.A. High Wind in Jamaica in 1929, died Wednesday night of leukemia at his home at Moredrin, Talsarnau, near Harlech in Merioneth, Wales. He was 76 years old.

title: ALBANY HELD KEY TO EDUCATION BILL
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 29 Dr. Donna Shalala, chairman of a group appointed by Governor Carey to advise on a change in the state's education financing methods, asserted today that the present system was inequitable and that there would be no chancefor reform unless the courts ordered the Legislature to act.

title: A Faculty Reversal Awards Aptheker A Seminar at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN. April 29The Yale College faculty has approved the appointment of Dr. Herbert Aptheker, a member of the Communist Party's national committee, to teach a seminar next fall on the late W.E.B. DuBois

title: Food Spices the Music at Jazz Clubs
description: Is there any place left in New York where one can go after theater to hear some decent jazz and have some equally decent food?

title: The Kissinger Mission in Africa
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 29 In some ways the new American policy on southern Africa that is being outlined on the current visit here by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger bears a similarity to his Middle East mediating efforts. No one expects Mr. Kissinger to begin a round of shuttle diplomacy between Pretoria and black Africa. But it is the prospect of bridging the gap between white and black Africa that Mr. Kissinger is exploiting in his approach to the black leaders of the south.

title: Panama Canal Pact Plays Big Role in Texas Voting
description: HOUSTON, April 29  The Panama Canal is Playing an increasingly prominent role in the Texas Presidential primary election, largely because of Ronald Reagan's giveaway charges against the Ford Administration.

title: Panel Urges Broader Powers For Wiretapping and Bugging
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) The National Wiretap Commission Is urging legislation that would give law enforcement officials broad new authority to use wiretaps and other electronic surveillance.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished with small changes yesterday in continued light trading.

title: Exaggeration Is Reported In Monthly Jobless Data
description: The monthly unemploymen estimates the New York State Department of Labor has been publishing have been exaggerating joblessness in New York by an average of 6.1 percent, the department said yesterday. as it issued new estimates showing jobless rates for March sharply lower than those for February.

title: 25 New Yorkers Honored for Showing They Care
BEIRUT ELECTION MAY BE DELAYED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 29 A search for a compromise candidate for the presidency of Lebanon was begun today by an important bloc of members of Parliament, and as a result there were predictions that the election would be held early next week rather than on Saturday as scheduled.

title: CHARLES HENRY KOOS
description: Charles Henry Koos, retired president of Koos Brothers, a chain of furniture stores in New Jersey, died Tuesday in Westfield, N.J. He was in his late 70's and lived in Westfield and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Kissinger, His Stomach Upset, Cancels Activities
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 29 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger canceled his day's activities today after waking up with a stomach ache following a dinner of wild boar and leaves of manioc plants.

title: JAY G. FRIDAY
description: Jay G. Freiday, a stockbroker, who was senior partner in Freiday and Company, died Wednesday at his winter home in Pornnano Beach, Fla. He was 56! years old and a resident of Deal, N.J.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting today and continuing every Friday, the business/finance section will be expanded to provide several new features. These will include columns on labor matters, management issues and developments in Washington, as well as analytical articles on national, international and metropolitan economic subjects. There will also be articles on major issues, developments and personalities in the corporate and industrial world.

title: Police Hunt Kidnappers Of L.I. Man
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L. I., April 29 Federal agents ahd Suffolk County Police detectives sought clues and witnesses today in what the police called a bizarre abduction of a motorcycle dealer from his home in this affluent North Shore community before dawn yesterday.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS CURBED ON COSTS
description: Central education authorities have imposed tight financial controls on two local school districtsDistrict 4 in East Harlem and District 5 in Central Harlemin a move to curb overspending there.

title: Canadiens'
description: MONTREAL, April 29 The. Montreal Canadiens hung on and beat the New York Iilanders, 43, tonight, chiefly on the goaltending of Ken Dryden, who faced 41 shots in a contest that was hardly the tight, defensive game Montreal cultivated during the regular season.

title: 2 JOURNALISTS WIN THE BERGER AWARD
description: Two New York City journalists were named by Columbia University yesterday as the winners of the 16th annual Mike Berger Award. They are Israel Shenker, a reporter for The New York Times, and Howard Blum, a staff writer for The Village Voice.

title: Dow Up 1.42 to 1,002.13; Turnover Remains Light
description: The stock market closed yesterday with a slight gain in continued light turnover. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks ended at 1,002.13, up 1.42.

title: News Awards Announced By New York Press Club
description: The New York Press Club announced yesterday its 1976 awards for outstanding news coverage by newspaper, radio and television reporters.

title: Legislature Hopes to Add $150 Million to the Budget
description: TRENTON, April 29 With State Treasury officials predicting an increase in revenues from sales and corporate taxes, the chairman of the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee said to day that he hoped to add about $150 million to Governor Byrnes's $2.76 billion budget for the corning fiscal Year.

title: Nursing Homes Beginning To Pay Out Back Wages
description: Nursing homes began yesteet. day to pay employees back wages and increases due since last December under terms of a contract with Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital and Nursing Home Union, according to Peter Ottley, president.

title: Mozart and Saul Bellow, Too
description: Julius Rudel, moving into his 20th season as director of the New York City Opera, announced yesterday seven new productions for 197677 that range from Poulenc and Mozart to Gilbert and Sullivan and Saul Bellow.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker:
description: HOBOKEN is the last real European community in America, a working class city that is riddled with history and teeming with places that make things freshthings like smoked mozzarella cheese, bacon and rich German pastry.

title: WindowGuard Provision Postponed Until the Fall
description: After stirring widespread confusion and uncertainty among landlords, tenants and city officials, the Board of Health is planning to postpone a controversial new regulation that requires the installation of window guards in virtually all apartments in New York City where there are children 10 years of age or younger.

title: 80th Straight Weekend for Reggae Film
description: Chuck Zlatkin has found what may be the perfect midnight film. For SO consecutive weekends, he has attracted from 150 to 200 people to the Elgin Theater in Chelsea to pay $2.50 each for what seems to be everyone's third or fourth viewing of The Harder They Come, a Jamaican film about a singer turned outlaw turned hero.

title: A Dream Dies
description: The dream of the Presidency is one that becomes a real possibility for very few persons, but for those few, iris a strong and somewhat distorting experience. Once her has seriously imagined himself as the occupant of the most powerful job in the world, no man is ever quite the same again. Defeat redoubles desire. Hope crushed to earth inevitably rises again and lurks forever in the recesses of the mind.

title: Exit the Old Warrior
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Hubert Humphrey hesitated briefly at the end, when his wife Muriel and three of their four children changed their minds and urged him to challenge Jimmy Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but his doubts didn't last for long.

title: WILTON S. BURTON
description: Wilton S. Burton, a registered representative with White Weld & Company, investment banking house, died of cancer yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 62 years old and lived on Plateau Circle in Bronxville.

title: Toyota Reports No Plans To Set Up Plant in Ohio
description: TOKYO, April 29 (UPI)The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest automobile manufacturing company, said today, that it had no plans to set up a plant in Ohio. A spokesman for the company said it had no plans to establish its plant anywhere in the United States in the near future.

title: Dr. John N. Dill, 70, Internist And Consultant in Yonkers
description: Dr. John N. Dill of Yonkers, an internist and consulting gastroenterologist at St. John's Riverside Hospital, Yonkers, before he retired two months ago, died Wednesday in the hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Publishing: Robert Payne's Quantum Leaps Through History and Ideas
A TOP NEOFASCIST IS SLAIN IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 29 A leading neoFasdist politician was assassinated today in Milan in the latest incident in a continuing wave of political violence.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Thirteen persons, including a former assistant prosecutor in Camden County, were named in indictments charging them with operating a major. drug distribution ring in Burlington, Camden and Atlantic Counties and. in Philadelphia. Criminal Justice Director Robert J. Del Tufo said the investigation by the state police and other officials and the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration was continuing and more indictments could be expected. The drugs, Mr. Del Tufo said, were obtained largely through legal means from pharmaceutical houses by two pharmacists.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ROME, April 29 (UPI)Col. Pietro D'Inzeo, riding Easter Light, won the Grand Prix of Rome at the Rdihe International Horse Show today and gave Italy its eighth victory in the last 11 years.

title: Court Asks Clearer Rules For Phosphate Pollutants
description: Federal waterpollution rules looking toward virtual ending of medically harmful effluents from chemical plants by 1983 have received a setback in the United States Circuit Court in New York City.

title: Kremlin Mortality
description: Marshal Andrei A. Grechko's unexpected death at age 72, following hard on the equally unexpected death of another top Soviet military figure, Gen. Sergei M. Shtemenko, raises with renewed force the political problems facing the ruling Kremlin gerontocracy. Only a few weeks have passed since the 25th Soviet Communist Party Congress was, the stage for Marshal Grechko's reelection to the Politburo.

title: Baeza's Status Is Clouded for Classic Race
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 LeRoy Jolley gave both his horse and his jockey a final workout today as nine 3yearold colts but only eight riders were named at Churchill Downs for Saturday's 102d running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: DR. REUBEN STEINHOLZ
description: Dr. Reuben Steinholz, a pediatrician, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 325 West End Avenue.

title: People and Business
description: Alexander C. Tomlinson, who had been a senior managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, has joined the First Boston Corporation, one of the nation's leading investment banking firms, as a member of the board and chairman Of the executive committee.

title: Flyers Top Bruins, Tie Series
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29 The Boston Bruins and Philadelphia Flyers both switched goaltenders tonight in the second contest of their semifinal round of. the National Hockey League playoffs. But the Flyers also switched their singer, and whether or not that was the difference, the Flyers won, 21, in overtime and evened the fourofsevengame series at one apiece.

title: DILORENZO FREED IN PERJURY CASE
description: Ross biLorenzo, a retired, Brooklyn Civil Court judge, was acquitted yesterday on all four counts of perjury by a jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: HUMPHREY BARS A CAMPAIGN NOW, DOUBTS A DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey tearfully rejected today the pleas of his friends that he undertake a fourth campaign for the Presidential nomination.

title: Down to the Wire
description: FORT WORTH, April 28  Jimmy Carter's victory in the Pennsylvania primary was so convincing that it obviously will catapult him into a strong showing in the Texas primary on Saturday. Mr. Carter's latest triumph could even prove a small plus for Ronald Reagan, who needs it

title: Parks to Test DoItYourself Bench Repairs
description: Mayor Beame offered details yesterday on a threemonth experiment by New York City to determine whether mutucipal employees could repair park benches at a cost less than could private contractors.

title: Rugged Outdoorsman
description: Two weeks before he was elected Governor in 1974, a confident Hugh L. Carey was already weighing the names of people he expected to Place in high posts in his administration. one name was that of Peter A. A. Berle. It took Governor Carey 21 months to come up with something for Mr. Berle, but people both in government and out agreed yesterday that the former Assemblyman from Manhattan was just the kind of person to be Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.

title: A Strike in Apartment Houses Is Threatened for Next Week
description: The president of Local 32B of the Service Employees Union said yestbrday that contract negotiations with apartmenthouse landlords were deadlocked, and he warned of a possible strike next week that would affect 4,000 buildings in the city.

title: Italian Journalist Finds Life Worsening in Vietnam
description: For most people in South Vietnamparticularly those in the citiesdaily life is worse now than during the war, according to an Italian journalist who returned Wednesday from a threeweek visit to the country.

title: At The Movies
description: Assuming that alf his recent troubles don't stop him from getting to work on it, Ingmar Bergman's next film will be a considerable departure for him. For one thing, it will be the first hp has ever done outside Sweden. In his open letter announcing his decision to quit his country, Mr. Bergman wondered, in effect, what would happen to his talent without the context of language, Iinht and national mood that has always eiven form to it.

title: Hemingway Libel Suit, A Footnote
description: An unusual literary battle focusing on the friendship between Ernest Hemingway and A. E. Hotchner is being fought in a Federal Court in Manhattan.

title: Carter Voices Regret Humphrey Won't Enter Primary in Jersey
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., April 29 Jimmy Carter said today that he wished Senator Hubert H. Humphrey had decided to enter the June 8 New Jersey Democratic primary election.

title: U.S. Beats Met Five
description: John Engles, a 6foot8inch forward from Penn, and 61 Archie Talley led the United States AllStars to a 10994 college basketball victory over the Metropolitan AllStars last night in the first Big Apple Classic at St. John's University Alumni Hall in Queens. Engles led all scorers with 20 points while Talley, a guard from Salem, (W.Va.), College had 18.

title: Broadway
description: PETER USTINOV, in full beard, was doing imitations. He was doing them while dining with his wife, and with Alexander H. Cohen and his wife, in a French restaurant on East 58th Street. Mrs. Cohen, who is Hildy Parks, the actress and writer, said later that it was a little like listening to the old Allen's Alley on radio.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS A BLAST IN PEKING NEAR ITS EMBASSY
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Soviet press agency Tass reported today that an explosion had occurred at the gates of the Soviet Embassy in Peking, killing two Chinese guards.

title: Connecticut Opens OTB Parlors, Without Mrs. Grasso
description: Eager crowds that ranged from dozens to hundreds of persons pushed their, way into 11 OTB branch offices in 10 cities. to bet An, horse races legally for the first time in this state, which was founded by New England Puritans and is Still somewhat leery of gambling.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND QUESTIONS STAFF
description: LONDON, April 29  The Bank of England, for nearly three centuries a pillar of security and integrity in the oftenturbulent world of banking, has announced an unusual investigation of itp staff. Few details were disclosed, but it is clear that Britain's central bank fears bribery and forgery among its officers.

title: Art People
description: IT'S called TriBeCa, though nobody's wild about the name. That's City Planning Commission short talk for Triangle Below Canal Street, but those who live there have other designations for itLo Cal, Washington Market, the Lower West Side or even SoSo (for South of Soho).

title: Phils'
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP)Larry Bowa, the Philadelphia Phillies shortstop, was s.uspended for three games and fined $350 by the National League president, Charles S. Feeney, the club announced today.

title: Business Briefs
description: Iranian Oil Talks Recessed Again

title: Strong Singing by Jeffreys
description: Garland Jeffreys is as New York as New York can behe was born in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, and has been part of the New York music scene since he met Lou Reed at Syracuse University in the mid1960's. But despite playing solo and in bands, touring with Mr. Reed in 1973 and putting out a couple of albums, Mr. Jeffreys has never really made it, at least until now. His work seemed too mannered and too torn between the various styles at which he was equally adept.

title: 1776, etc.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Let's revise some history concerning the American Revolution.

title: Religious Leaders Say Manila Regime Tortures Prisoners
description: MANILA, the Philippines, April 29 (AP)  In a leapage pamphlet distributed through the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines, the Association of Major Religious Superiors has accused the Government of torturing and killing political detainees.

title: Bond Prices Rise and Then Fall Sharply As Nation's Money Supply Grows Again
description: The credit markets yesterday, as one utility bond trader put it, were up a little and then down a lot. Prices of most fixedincome securities rose yesterday morning, continuing the advance that had started on Tuesday, and then fell back sharply. In late afternoon, the basic money supply, was reported higher for the fourth week in a row, and bond prices dipped further.

title: U.S. STEEL RAISES ITS PRICES BY 6%; ARMCO FOLLOWS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel maker, yesterday became the third major producer to raiSe prices on sheet and strip products. The company announced that prices for those items, its major product lines. would go up about 6 percent effective June 14.

title: Carey Proposes Bills Easing Powers of Adirondack Agency
description: ALBANY, April 29 Governor Carey today proposed a series of laws to give local jurisdictions within the sixmillionacre Adirondack state Park more freedom in drawing up local landuse ordinances.

title: Playing the Angles on the Piano
description: Franz Liszt, musical anthropologists tell us, was the first pianist to play a public recital in profile, probably because people had been telling him for years what a nice profile he had. Like most such historical tidbits, this one is suspect, but in the absence of other testimony Liszt must get credit for giving us the sidesaddle recital, by now an almost inviolable tradition.

title: Horsenappings Italian Style
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 29  The mother of the 1980 Kentucky Derby winner is a dark filly with a crewcut mane and sore feet who came within 24 hours of being sold for 30 cents a pound in a butcher shop in Milan, Italy. Her name is Carnauba and she is grazing placidly on Nelson Bunker Hunt's Blue Grass Farm out the Versailles Pike, but four months ago she was being held for $250,000 ransom by Italian horsenappers. She was snatched August and recovered in January, and although she was a sorrylooking thing when she flew over here in March, she kept a tryst with the celebrated stallion, Vaguely. Noble, and he got her into a delicate condition on their very first date. Now she shares a paddock with 10 or a dozen other mares in foal.. All are ladies of quality bred to established studs, yet none of the foals they drop next spring will boast more distinguished lineage than the one Carnauba is carrying. She is an Italian Oaks winner who also won a stakes England; Vaguely Noble the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe.

title: Driver Burned to Death
description: ZION, III., April 29 (UPI) A truck filled with molten aluminum hit a concrete abutment on the Tristate Tollway today and overturned, spilling hot metal, and burning to death the driver, Younger Barnes, 50 years old, of Gary, Ind.

title: It's Official: Doubleday Acquires Dell
description: Doubleday & Company, the country's largest hardcoves book publisher. has acquired the Dell PubliShing company, one of the top five in the paperback field.

title: Stovisky Is Willing to Sue Beame On Education Low
REGAN FORECASTS 900 TO 1,100 DOW
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, Iparent of the brokerage firm, Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., told shareholders yesterday that the Dow Jones industrial average could fluctuate between 900 and 1,100 by the fourth quarter.

title: OneBoat Navy Clean Waters Monitors Impact of Sludge Dumping
description: EDISON, April 29  Monitoring the effeet of five million cubic yards of municipal sewage sludge dumped in the ocean 12 miles off the New Jersey coast eVery, year is the Mission of a oneboat navy operated by Region 2 of the Federal Environmental Protection A eencv.

title: About Real Estate
description: A move is on in Albany to extend the socalled DeaneGoodman law, which many housing specialists believe has been the largest single roariblock in the last two year.: lo the conversion of under. linanced rental h,ousing in the city into cooperatives.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Ron Johnson Gets Freedom Tonight
description: Ron Johnson, the only Giant to rush 1,000 yards a season, will not be a New Yorker after tonight, when his option year ends.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Stripers and Bookworms
description: A delightful certainty in this troubled age is that the migratory striped bass and summer flounder, or fluke, will soon be responding to anglers .offerings in the Northeast.

title: Israeli Burglar Sets Record
description: TEL AVIV, April 29 (Reuters) The Israeli police have charged a suspect with 120 burglaries in three months, a record. The police prosecutor, Mordechai Schnitzer, told a court that the accused, Rafael La Louche, had set a new record, often carrying out two and three robberies a night in various towns.

title: Indochinese Refugees Get Jobs Through State Offices
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) \ The Labor Department said today that, of 27,000 Indochinese refugees who listed their names with state employment offices, jobs were found for 5,500 over the last eight months.

title: People in Sports
description: General James Van Fleet (Ret.), a former Army fullback, was named yesterday to receive the Distinguished American Award for 1976 from the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame. He will be honored at the foundation's awards dinner in New York next Dec. 7

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Each horse carries 126 pounds.

title: 9 Are Entered, But 2 Favorites Hold Spotlight
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29  The other race in Kentucky this week was won by a little ark with latticework trim named the Julia Belle Swain in the Great Steamboat Race down the Ohio River. But for big kicks and big money, everybody was focusing today on the great match race that was gathering on, the Churchill Downs dirt for the 102d Kentucky Derby.

title: Bridge:
description: The big bridge event of the year for students is the Intercollegiate Championship, in which college partnerships qualify in local and then regional games. One of the favored pairs in the national final, beginning today in Knoxville, Tenn., will be Eric Robinson and Art Moore of New York, who are representing Harvard and the New England region. They met the diagramed deal in their qualifying game.

title: The Gaudy Primrose
description: Earliest of the primroses are the P. juliae. The bright purple, deep red, claret, or Sometimes white flowers of this diminutive species and its many hybrids often break right through the crust of late . March snow. Used to the alpine climate of their original Transcaucasian homeland, the flowers remain unaffected by the snow  except esthetically, the White crystal blanket draping like ermine around them.

title: INTRUDER ENTERED SENATE UNIT OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 An intruder entered last week the office of a Senate team that has been investigating the grain scandals and left documents in disarray atop desks and on the floor, a staff aide said today.

title: Vatican Reports Deficit For the 75 Holy Year
description: ROME, April 29 (AP) Inflation, the stock market crisis and shrinking offerings put the Vatican's balance sheet deeply In the red in 1975, a Jubilee Holy Year for the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Books of The Times
description: Robert Ludlum cooks up generously portioned thrillers, combining the fast hands of a good shortorder cook with the flair of a chef at Chicago's late lamented Pump Room. The flaming skewers, rich sauces, spectaculla cuts of beef, sinful dessertsthey're all working in his kitchen. As a writer, Mr. Ludlum may not be Escoffier, but neither is Ronald MacDonald.

title: Inquiry on for Shark Victim
description: GALVESTON, Tex., April 29 (UPI)  The authorities hope that dental records will supply them with the identity of a human devoured by a 400pound shark. The shark was caught yesterday morning by fishermen aboard the fishing boat Cape Willy of Aransas pass about two miles south of the south jetty lighthouse on the east end of Galveston Island. The Laman remains found included a jaw. bone with all teeth intact, a hand, an arm and a foot.

title: Dollar Is Weaker As Pound Climbs And Lira Slumps
description: BRUSSELS, April 29 (UPI)The dollar declined on European money markets today. The British pound strengthened, while the Italian lira, beset by Italy's political instability, fell sharply.

title: Purported Will of Hughes Found at Mormon Office
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 Officials of the Mormon Church disclosed today that a handwritten will purportedly made six years ago by Howard R. Hughes had been found.

title: YONKERS SUICIDE HELD ACCIDENTAL investigator Says Youth Who Was Jailed in Error Meant Only to Make Pretense
description: YONKERS, April 29Investigations into the death of 20year  old Steven Karagianis, who hanged himself in a Yon keys jail cell on April 7, indicate that the youth had not meant to kill .himself. according to an Official involved in one of the inquiries.

title: NewMoon, Grand Operetta By Romberg,Getsa Revival
description: WHETHER the reason is nostalgia or the delight in good oldfashioned melodies, there have recently been a number of Off Broadway revivals of operettas outside the everpresent Gilbert and Sullivan repertory and the occasional Viennese masterpiece. Victor Herbert's Naughty Marietta and Rudolf Friml's The Vagabond King started it off. Coming up is Sigmund Romberg's The Student Prince while the same composer's The New Moon is now on display. New Moon has been produced at the Fashion Institute Theater by the excellent Village Light Opera Group.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Dumbest damn thing I ever did in my life was cut out my Merciful Sunday Brunch. It's on again." CHARLEY O; Every bloody Sunday, all day Sunday (then we stay open late for Dinner). Brine your Times. Bring whoever.

title: Ford Joins Rebound in Profits, Reports $343 Million in Quarter
Notes on People
description: Less than a month after the Supreme Court refused to review William L. CaIley's courtmartial, invitations have been mailed out for his May 15 wedding to Penny Vick in Columbus, Ga. The former Army lieutenant has lived there since his 1971 conviction for murdering 22 unarmed civilians at My Lai in South Vietnam. He served three years of house arrest at Fort Benning before he was freed on bail in 1974, pending his appeal. The Army has Said it will not confine him again.

title: U.S. Aide Forecasts Huge Rise in Solar Panel Energy
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 By the end of this century it is hoped that a substantial partl of American power needs can be generated by rooftop panels coverting sunlight directly into electricity, according to the Federal official responsible for the program.

title: I.T.T. Must Give Data on Alleged Payoffs
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) A Federal judge said today that the International Telephone and Telegraph Company must give the Federal Government details of an alleged $3.8 million it had paid overseas and all illegal campaign contributions in the United States.

title: Advertising
description: There is a small segment of the communications business that appears to be growing by leaps and bounds. And it has to do with the most basic form of communicationsoral.

title: Ilana KlossUpsets Miss Navratilova in 3 Sets
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., April 29 Secondseeded Martina Navratilova, who recovered from a 03 deficit in the third set and won her firstround match yesterday, found herself at that same perilous juncture today in the $100,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup tennis tournament.

title: In U.S., Less Hope
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.On a sunny afternoon not long ago, a onceprosperous lawyer from Saigon sat in his tiny, darkened apartment here, sipping from a plastic cup and sadly pondering his days as an exile.

title: LOCKHEED EXPECTS $750 MILLION DEAL IN CANADA TODAY
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Canadian Government are expected to sign a $750 million contract today for Canadian purchase of a. fleet of 18 longrange patrol aircraft.

title: Saudi Arabia Seeks to Balance New Wealth and Old Tradition
description: RIYADH. Saudi ArabiaBe Arabia what it may, it is ours, the Emir Faisal ibn Turki, greatgrandfather and predecessor of King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, Said III years ago to a hardy British colonel who had turned up here the isolated Saudi capital in the heart of the Arabian Peninsula.

title: Saddened Smithsonian Returns Gift of Estate
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The Smithsonian Institution, having looked a gift horse in the mouth, has reluctantIcr decided that inflation has transformed into a white elephant.

title: Whitlam Says Lockheed Paid Australian Official
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 29 (Reuters) The former Prime Minister of Australia, Gough Whitlam. alleged today that in the late 1950's a former government minister received large sums of money from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to promote sales in Australia.

title: Prof. William Ebenstein Dead; Writer on Political Science, 65
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 29 (AP) William Ebenstein, a professor of political science at the University of California at Santa Barbara and an authority on totalitarian government, died yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: FATAL JET FAILED TO TAKE OFF AGAIN
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., April 29 The crew of an American Airlines Boeing 727 that crashlanded here Tuesday, killing 37 of the 88 persons on board, landed far down the unusually short runway, tried to take off again sharply and failed and braked sharply in vain, investigators of the National Safety Board disclosed today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.3 billion ton  miles, 5.3 percent above the yearearlier week. Carloadings in the same period totaled 469,212 cars, up 3.6 percent from 2 last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 11.5 percent :above last year.

title: Congress Approves a Revision Of Breeder Reactor Contract
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  Congress today authorized a major revision in the contract under which the nation's first fullscale nuclear breeder reactor is to be built.

title: Hidden Asset for Ford: Son Jack's Campaigning
description: HOUSTON, April 29 President Ford's hidden asset in the important Texas Republican primary on Saturday may be the young man who just toured the state saying he would rather that Gerald R. Ford had never taken up residence In the White House.

title: Violence Born in a Woman's Hate
description: EVA'S MAN. By Gayl Jones. 177 pages. Random House. $6.95.

title: Voting Timetable Deepens Split in Spanish Cabinet
description: MADRID, April 29  The timetable for political change that Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro presented last night in a broadcast to the nation has deepened a Government split over the issue, with many ministers favoring a faster and less complicated procedure.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 29 Governor Byrne, in a gently prodding letter, asked the Legislature today to begin work on the program he outlined more than two months ago.

title: Order Aims at Handicapped
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) President Ford Wednesday ordered the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to establish rules barring discrimination against handicapped workers in Federally assisted programs. In an executive order, Mr. Ford instructed the department to establish guidelines for compliance with the allocation of Federal financial assistance and to determine what constituted discriminatory practices.

title: Perspective
description: Many Americans in April were busy reliving the mystery of Watergate in a new book and film. For economists, however, the month focused on the mystery of low interest rates.

title: Brokers to Dicker Among Themselves On Fees in Phase 2 of S. E. C.'s Mayday
description: One year ago tomorrow the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a landmark decision, ordered stockbrokers to end a nearly 200yearold practice of charging fixed brokerage fees and to permit customers to dicker. And dicker they did.

title: Lady Is the Same, but Different
description: When the curtain rose on a recent matinee of the revival of My Fair Lady, Mary Williams of Middletown, N.J., took one look at the stage, nudged her husband, and said, I like this better.

title: Money Supply Growth Eases for Week
Change at the Exchange
description: Little has changed in Wall Street's clubby power structure. Admittedly, the new chairman of the Stock Exchange, Williarn M. Batten, is a distinguished corporate executive and not an entrenched professional of the securities industry. The recent report of a study group which he headed made some worthwhile and controversial recommendations for altering the sacrosanct status of the exchange specialists. It did not, however, venture upon any of the truly fundamental reforms which Congress, the Securities and Exchange Commission and outside experts have been advocating for over five years.

title: POLITICIANS WEIGH HUMPHREY'S STAND
